ABCDEF
1
ATUSUBClassificationsCategorySubcategoryVariation Example
2
1-The Theft of FishAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox lies in the road pretending to be dead. A fisherman throws him on his wagon which is full of fish. The fox throws the fish out of the wagon & jumps down after them. A wolf tries to imitate this & pretends to be dead, too. The fisherman catches him & beats him. In some variants one animal pretends to be dead in order to distract a man who is carrying a basket of food. Another animal steals the basket. Or an animal makes a hole in the basket so that the contents fall out.
3
2-Tail-FisherAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA bear meets a fox who has caught a big load of fish. He asks him where he caught them, & the fox replies that he was fishing with his tail through a hole in the ice. He advises the bear to do likewise & the bear does. When the bear tries to pull his tail out of the ice (because men or dogs are attacking him), it is frozen in place. He runs away but leaves his tail behind.
4
2ATorn-off TailsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox who has been tricked into losing his tail asks his companions to tie their tails together. When they run away suddenly, they pull each others’ tails off. The men in pursuit cannot tell which fox they were chasing, because now there are many foxes without tails. In some variants a fox who has lost his tail in a trap tries to convince other foxes to have theirs cut off. Often, he does not succeed.
5
2BBasket Tied to Wolf's TailAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA wolf sees a fox who has many fish, & would like to catch some himself. The fox tells him to hang a basket from his tail. The wolf does this. The basket is filled with water, or the fox fills it secretly with stones, so that the wolf cannot pull his tail out.
6
2DThe New TailAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA bear gets a tail out of hemp to replace the tail he has lost. A fox provokes him to jump over a fire. Thus the new tail is burned (the bear himself is burned). The fox tells the bear to hold his burning tail up in the wind, but it only burns faster. The bear is injured or killed. In some variants, the fox convinces the bear to go to a smith to have a new tail welded on. The bear is thus severely injured.
7
3-Simulated InjuryAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox covers his head with a milky substance or dough & convinces a wolf that he has been so badly injured that his brains are coming out.
8
3*Wolf Supplies Food for FoxAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox convinces a wolf to go into a hen house & throw the chickens out to him. Then the fox tells the dogs & they attack the wolf. The fox runs away taking the chickens with him. When he meets the wolf later, the fox pretends that he has been attacked worse than the wolf.
9
4-Sick Animal Carries Healthy OneAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox tricks an injured wolf into carry ing him on his back by pretending to be injured himself. While he is being carried, the fox says, “The sick animal carries the healthy one” (“The one who was beaten carries the one who was not.”) When the wolf asks about his chant, the fox changes the words around or threatens the wolf (by saying that dogs are chasing them).
10
5-Biting the Tree RootAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA wolf chases a fox & is able to seize his leg. To get free the fox pretends that the wolf has only a tree root in his mouth, so the wolf lets go & seizes a tree root. The fox runs away.
11
6-Animal Captor Persuaded to TalkAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox catches a crow & is about to eat it. The weak animal asks a question & the fox answers. Thus he releases the prey & it escapes.
12
6*Animal Captor Talks with booty in his mouthAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA wolf catches a goose & a fox catches a chicken. The fox asks the wolf something so that he opens his mouth & the goose is able to fly away. Then the wolf asks the fox, but the fox answers without losing his booty.
13
7-The Three Tree NamesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA bear & a fox wager as to which can name three trees first. The fox wins because the bear names three different varieties of the same tree. The fox names three different trees which can be pronounced more quickly. In some variants the devil & a man wager.
14
8-False Beauty TreatmentAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox tells a bear that he has painted the birds. The bear wants to be painted too, although the fox warns him that it will hurt. The fox has the bear fill a pit with pitch & lay wood over it. He ties the bear on top & sets the wood on fire. The bear is burned, wounded or killed. In some variants the fox hurts the bear in another way, promising to make him more beautiful or to cure him & then putting on him red-hot stones, drenching him with boiling water, shaving his head or tail, or putting out his eyes with a hot poker
15
8*The Fox Trades the Burned Bones of the Bear for ReindeerAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox gathers the burned skeleton of a bear & puts it in a sack. He rattles the bones as if they were money & trades the sack for a reindeer.
16
9-The Unjust PartnerAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox & a bear work their land together & agree to share the profits. While the bear threshes the grain in the barn, the fox rests, saying he has to support the beams in the roof so that they will not fall on the bear. When they divide the harvest, the fox takes the grain & gives the bear the bigger pile of chaff. When their harvest is ground at the mill, the fox’s share sounds different from the bear’s. When the fox’s grain is cooked it looks light, but the bear’s looks dark. In order to convince the bear that all the grain tastes the same, the fox secretly takes a spoonful from the bear’s dish & pretends it is from his own. In some variants the animals have a race to determine who gets which part of the harvest.
17
10***The Fall Over the EdgeAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox & a bear sleep together on the edge of a cliff. The fox pushes his companion over the edge so that he falls down & dies
18
15-Theft of Food by Playing GodfaterAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox & a wolf live together. The fox pretends that he has been invited to be godfather at a baptism (invited to a funeral or wedding) but instead he secretly eats up the butter (honey) that he & the wolf have stored. This happens again (three times). When the wolf asks him the name of the baptized child, the fox makes up names that reflect the diminution of the stored food. When the wolf discovers the butter is missing he accuses the fox, who denies having taken it. The fox proposes a test to deter mine who took the butter: both of them will lie in the sun & after some time the butter will melt & appear. While the wolf sleeps, the fox smears butter on him & thus “proves” his guilt.
19
15*Fox Entices Wolf Away from his BootyAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis misc. type consists of various tales about a fox who entices a wolf away from his booty so the fox can eat it himself
20
20AAnimals Caught In a Pit Eat One Another UpAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA number of animals go on a journey or pilgrimage together to seek their fortunes. They try to jump over a pit but fall into it instead. When they grow hungry, the fox proposes that they eat the one amongst them with the ugliest name, then who can sing highest or loudest , then who can howl the longest, then who is the youngest or the smallest. Thus all the animals are eaten one after another, until only two (fox & wolf) remain or only the fox is left.
21
20CAnimals Flee in Fear of the End of the WorldAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA chicken is frightened by a nut that falls on its head, or another animal is frightened by a noise. The chicken thinks this is a sign of an approaching war (the end of the world, the sky is falling down), & flees in panic together with the rooster & they go to tell the king about the disaster. They meet other animals who come to share their fear & go along with them. The misunderstanding is cleared up, or the animals fall into a pit. In some variants they arrive at the fox’s den. The fox invites them inside & eats them.
22
20DPilgrimage of the AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA rooster wants to go to Rome in order to become pope. His wife accompanies him, along with more & more other animals. They meet the fox, who invites them to rest in his den. He asks them to sing & eats them one by one afterwards. Often the fox pretends to go on a pilgrimage to a convent. Other animals go along with him. The fox asks to hear their confessions or accuses them of sins which are characteristic of the different kinds of animals. Then the fox eats them as a punishment. In some variants the fox tells the rooster that he has become religious & repents his past actions, or he dresses as a nun. Then he reproaches the rooster with his sins (his polygamy) & offers to hear his confession. When the rooster comes near, the fox catches him & gobbles him up. Or, the rooster escapes by a ruse.
23
21-Eating his own EntrailsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox & a wolf fall into a pit together & grow hungry. The fox has concealed under his body the entrails (brain, eye) of an animal that he had killed earlier, & begins to gnaw on them. He tells the wolf that he cut open his own belly & is eating his own entrails. When the wolf tries to copy this, he dies.
24
23*Fox Induces Wolf to Impale HimselfAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox challenges a wolf to jump over a stake. The fox notices that the wolf jumps sideways, so he shows him how he should jump straight forward. Thus the wolf becomes impaled on the stake. The fox tells him he should make an effort to get off, which causes the wolf to be stuck even more firmly.
25
30-The Fox Tricks the Wolf into Falling into a PitAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox entices a wolf to a pit. He dares the wolf to jump over the edge, or tells him there is food in the well. The wolf falls (jumps) in & is trapped. Or, the fox lures the wolf into a concealed trap.
26
31-Fox Climbs from the Pit on the Wolf's BackAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox jumps (falls) into a well & cannot get out by himself. He entices another animal to come down with him. When the wolf asks how they will be able to get out, the fox says they will help each other. He climbs up on the wolf’s back & gets out. On top of the well he mocks the wolf & does not help him out as he had promised
27
32-The Wolf Descends into the Well in One Bucket & Rescues the Fox in the OtherAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox falls or jumps into a well because he is thirsty (is fleeing from someone, or wants to trick the wolf into coming down) & sits in a bucket. He persuades the wolf to get into the other bucket, & this lifts the fox’s bucket up to the top so he can get out. Often men find the wolf in the well & beat him.
28
33-The Fox Plays Dead & is Thrown out of the Pit & EscapesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (often together with one or more other animals) is caught in a trap (pit) & cannot get out. When the hunter comes, the fox pretends to be dead. The hunter takes him out of the trap and, thinking he will not move, lays him down. The fox runs away. Other animals try to imitate the fox’s trick & pretend to be dead, but the hunter is not fooled a second time.
29
34-The Wolf Dives into the Water for Reflected CheeseAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA wolf sees the moon reflected in water & thinks there is a cheese lying under the water. He jumps in to get it. Often another animal (the fox) persuades the wolf to do this. In some variants the animal tries to drink up the water in order to get some cheese that he supposes is under it. He bursts. Or, the fox plugs him with a stopper just before he would have burst, & removes it when they come to a party.
30
34ADog Drops His Meat for the ReflectionAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA dog swims across a river with a piece of meat in his mouth. When he sees his reflection, he thinks it is another dog with a bigger piece of meat. In an effort to take the meat from this dog, he dives after him (jumps into the water) & loses his own meat.
31
34CMonkey with the LentilsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA monkey drops a lentil out of his hand. As he climbs down the tree to find it, he drops the other lentils which he also had in his hand. When he reaches the ground, he cannot find any of the lost lentils
32
35A*The Fox Asks the Wolf for MeatAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox smells the meat that a wolf has caught, but gets nothing. He suggests to the wolf how to protect the meat from greedy neighbors, & steals it at night.
33
35B*The Fox Gets Bait from Trap by Luring Wolf into ItAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox finds a piece of meat by the roadside, but he is afraid that it might be a trap & does not eat it. When a wolf comes the fox tells him about the meat. The wolf goes to take it & falls into the trap. The fox is then able to eat the meat without danger. In many variants the fox pretends to be fasting & thus says that he cannot eat the meat. When he eats it afterwards, he tells the wolf that the time for fasting is over.
34
36-The Fox Rapes the She-BearAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (Rabbit) asks the children of the mother bear (wolf, fox, lioness) about their mother & says he would like to sleep with her. The mother bear overhears this & lies in wait for the fox so she can catch him. He slips between two trees but she is caught between them, & the fox rapes her. The fox uses mud to color himself black & comes back to the bear disguised as a monk. She asks him if he has seen the fox. He asks her if it was the fox who raped her, & she worries that all the animals already know what happened to her.
35
37-The Fox as Nursemaid for the Mother BearAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A mother bear needs a nursemaid to take care of her children while she goes out hunting. Out of all (e.g. Rabbit, wolf, ox, fox) who apply, she chooses the fox (hyena). Each time she goes out he eats one of her children, but makes sure that she does not notice that they are missing. After the fox has eaten all of the children, he leaves. In north European variants the mother bear requires that the ap-plicants sing well, & thus chooses the fox. In a few variants the fox & the goose raise their children together & take turns minding them. The fox eats the goslings. (2) The applicants must sing to prove that they would be good hired mourners. While the mourning husband organizes the burial, the fox eats the corpse. (3) Instead of a nursemaid, a shepherd is needed for a herd of sheep. One after another, the sheep are eaten by the fox.
36
38-Claw in Split TreeAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA man (fox) asks a bear (tiger) to help him fell a tree (split wood). The bear is to hold his claw on a part of the tree. The man removes a wedge he had put there, so that the two pieces of wood spring back together & the bear is caught. In some variants the bear asks the man for help, but the man says that the bear must help him first.
37
40AThe Wolf & The BellAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A wolf & a fox eat food that does not belong to them. The fox fixes a bell to the wolf so that, if anyone opens the door, they will be warned & be able to escape quickly. The wolf’s tail becomes caught in the bell cord (he is hung up on the cord). (2) A wolf forces a fox to give him food. The fox takes revenge by ringing a bell which betrays the wolf, or the wolf accidentally reveals himself by ringing a bell. (3) The animal that wolf & fox want to eat wears a bell, which the fox rings in order to betray the wolf.
38
41-The Wolf Overeats in the CellarAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (cat, jackal, hedgehog) convinces a wolf (polecat, hyena, antelope) to join him in breaking into a cellar (store-house, stable, kitchen, vineyard) to steal food. While they eat, the fox keeps checking to be sure that he still fits through the narrow exit. The wolf eats so much that he cannot leave. He is caught & beaten (killed). In early variants, a fox in a storehouse eats so much that he cannot leave. A weasel advises him to fast. Or, the fox pretends to be dead because he is so fat that he cannot leave the cellar without help. Thus he is able to escape.
39
43-Bear Builds a House of Wood, the Fox of IceAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxIn the winter, a fox (wolf, bear) builds him self a fine house of ice. A Rabbit (wolf, fox, bear, sheep, goat) builds himself a house of wood (stone, iron, grass, wool). When summer comes, the fox’s house melts, & he goes to live in the Rabbit’s house. He gradually pushes the Rabbit out.
40
44-The Oath on the IronAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxTo settle a dispute (about their communal food supplies) a fox (hedgehog, sheep) proposes to a wolf that they swear on an iron trap (called Gospel) to tell the truth. This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) The fox touches the trap delicately. The wolf hits it hard so its jaws snap together & catch him. (2) A hedgehog wants to swear on a tree with a trap that is called a judge. When the judge does not answer him, a wolf pushes the trap so hard that he is caught in it. (3) A wolf wants to skin a sheep, but a fox, who is the sheep’s friend, makes the wolf promise not to harm him. He swears by kissing a trap, & is caught in it. (4) A sheep proposes to swear on a bush in which a dog is hiding. The dog attacks the wolf.
41
47AThe Fox Hangs Onto the Horse's TailAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (wolf, bear, monkey, several animals) runs into a seemingly-dead horse (donkey, dog) & (on the advice of another animal) wants to take the carcass home for food. He ties (bites) himself to the dead animal’s tail & starts to drag it home. The horse jumps up & runs away, dragging the fox to his master, who beats (kills) the fox. Or, the fox persuades the wolf to tie a rope around the wolf’s neck & the other end around the animal they want to eat. The wolf is strangled. Often the animal only pretends to be dead, in order to catch the fox. Sometimes the Rabbit witnesses the event & laughs so hard that his lip splits
42
47BHorse Kicks the Wolf in the TeethAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA wolf (lion) wants to eat a horse (mule, donkey, foal). Before the horse will let himself be eaten, he demands that the wolf does him a favor, e.g. take a thorn out of his foot, remove his iron shoe, or read his name (his genealogy, age, selling price) which is printed on the bottom of his hoof. Or, he asks to be eaten from his hindquarters forward. When the wolf approaches his hoof, the horse kicks him. Sometimes a fox persuades a wolf to look for a horse’s name (genealogy) under his hoof. Or, the wolf asks God to give him something to eat, or pretends to be a doctor & examines the horse’s hoof. In some variants a lion sends a wolf and/or a fox (jackal) after a donkey (horse, camel), who is absent from the parliament of the animals. When they ask why he did not attend, the donkey says he has a charter under his hoof that excuses him. When the wolf attempts to read the document, the donkey kicks him.
43
47DDog Wants to Imitate a WolfAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA wolf (bear) teaches a dog (jackal, fox) to hunt and, before he preys on a horse, he asks the dog whether his eyes are bloody and/or his hindquarters are trembling. Then he attacks the horse & kills it. When the dog hunts by himself, he asks the same question to a weak companion (cat, Rabbit). After a horse wounds (kills) the dog, his companion says that the dog now really looks frightening be cause not only his eyes are bloody.
44
48*Flatterer Rewarded, Honest One PunishedAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThe fox flatters the monkey (bear, siren, animal king) & says his children are pretty. The monkey rewards him (gives him food). The wolf (bear) is also hungry, but he tells the monkey the truth about his children & the monkey beats him. In some variants, a self-appointed emperor of the monkeys asks two travelers who he is. One says he is the emperor & is rewarded; the other says he is a monkey & is punished.
45
49-The Bear & The HoneyAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox promises to take a bear (hyena) to a beehive. Instead he takes him to a wasps’ nest. The bear bites into it & is badly stung.
46
49AThe Wasp Nest as King's DrumAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA monkey (Rabbit, fox, deer) & a tiger (bear, lion, coyote) go hunting together. The tiger finds the monkey sitting next to a wasps’ nest (beehive). The monkey says he is guarding his master’s drum (organ, garbage). Or, he has a snake which he calls his flute (scepter, walking stick). The tiger asks him to play his drum, & is stung by the wasps.
47
50-The Sick LionAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA lion (bear, tiger) is sick, & all the animals except the fox (jackal) visit him. The wolf (lynx, coyote, hyena) calls attention to the fox’s absence, which angers the lion. The fox overhears this. He comes & tells the sick lion that he will recover if he applies a fresh wolfskin to his body (eats fresh wolf meat). The lion has the wolf skinned
48
50AFox Sees all tracks going into Lion's Den but None Coming OutAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA lion who is too weak (lazy) to hunt any more pretends to be sick & stays in his den. One by one the animals come to visit him & he eats them. When the fox comes, he sees the tracks going in, but none coming back out. He decides not to go in.
49
50BThe Fox leads the Donkey to Lion's Den but is Himself EatenAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxIn order to save himself from being eaten, a fox brings his friend the donkey to a lion. But the lion eats the fox anyway, before the donkey.
50
50CDonkey Boasts of Having Kicked the Sick LionAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxAn old, weak lion is insulted & attacked by the animals whom he used to hunt. A bear, ox, donkey, etc. take their revenge & boast of it.
51
51-The Lion's shareAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA lion (tiger), a wolf (donkey, panther, dog), & a fox (jackal) go hunting together. The wolf has to divide the booty & gives each the same amount. The lion kills him. Then he demands the fox to divide the booty. The fox gives it all to the lion (gives the lion the meat & takes the bones for himself). When the lion asks the fox where he learned to do that, the fox replies, “From the wolf”.In some variants the booty is never divided. Instead, the lion claims it all & no one dares to contradict him.
52
51***The Fox as Umpire to Divide CheeseAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxTwo animals fight over some prey (cheese, meat) & ask a fox (monkey, cat) to judge the case. He eats it himself (cat eats the two animals). In some variants the fox takes bites from the pieces of food to make both parts the same. In the end he eats them both.
53
51AThe Fox Has the SnifflesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA lion (wolf) asks the animals if his breath smells bad (his den is dirty). Those who say yes are killed. The monkey gives a flatter ing answer so that the lion will not kill him. Later the lion pretends to be sick & claims that he needs monkey meat to be cured, so the monkey is killed after all. The fox says he has the sniffles (forgot his glasses) & cannot smell, so he is not killed. Often the animals are killed, whether they say the lion’s breath stinks or not
54
52-The Donkey without a HeartAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA lion (tiger, wolf) wants to eat a donkey (deer, ram, camel). A fox (jackal, hedgehog) persuades a donkey to go with him to the lion (to go into the service of the king of animals). On the first approach, the donkey runs away, but the fox persuades him again & the lion kills the donkey. The fox secretly eats the donkey’s heart (ear, brains). The lion notices that the organ is missing, but the fox claims that this donkey never had a heart, because if he had one, he would not have let himself be deceived. In variants from central Asia, a wolf, a bear, & a fox catch a camel who lets himself be eaten. While the bear & the wolf clean (butcher, transport) the carcass, the fox eats the heart (brains, in-testines). He tells the wolf that the bear ate it. While the bear & the wolf fight, the fox runs away with the meat.
55
53-The Fox at CourtAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox is summoned before a judge because of his crimes (e.g. stealing chickens, being absent from the parliament of the animals) & is con demn ed to death. By means of his last request, he manages to escape. In some variants the fox is finally killed by a man.
56
53*The Fox Investigates a RoarAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (lion) hears a loud roar & is frightened but he goes to see what caused it. He finds a frog who is croaking & steps on (kills) him.
57
55-The Animals Build a Road (Dig Well)Animal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThe animals (birds) decide (are commanded by God) to build a road (well, reservoir). One animal (mole, mouse, snake, crab, swallow, raven, oriole) refuses to help because he thinks he can go where he wants without it (can always find enough water). The animals prevent him from going to the well , or he is killed when he crosses the road
58
56-The Fox Through Sleight Steals the Young MagpiesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis type number refers to a cycle of related tales with the same introduction
59
56AFox Threatens to Cut Down Tree & Get Young BirdsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (jackal) threatens to cut down the tree (using his tail as a saw) of a mother bird (magpie, woodpecker, dove, thrush, nightingale) unless she will throw down to him one of the chicks (eggs) which are in her nest. Thus the fox eats one of the chicks every day. When only one is left, the mother tells another mother bird (crow, magpie) about her misfortune. This bird replies that a fox cannot cut down a tree. The mother refuses to give the last chick to the fox, who de cides to take revenge on the neighbor bird. When he sees her, he pretends to be dead. The bird approaches him, & the fox kills & eats her.
60
56A*Fox Plays Dead & Catches BirdAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (cat) pretends to be dead in order to catch a bird (crow) that comes near him. The fox eats it. In some variants the fox blows up his stomach like a balloon, so that he seems to be dead & bloated. Or, the fox lies beside the hens’ roosting place & pretends to be sick. When the hens come near him, he kills them.
61
56BFox as SchoolmasterAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (jackal) persuades a bird (magpie, woodpecker, dove) or a crocodile (wolf, leopard, hyena) to let him educate her children. The fox eats them. When the mother comes to visit them, the fox says they are not there (shows her one that is still alive). After a while the mother discovers what has happened. She goes for help to a dog (wolf). The dog pretends to be dead (lures the fox into a trap) & kills the fox. Or, the fox leaves before the mother can take revenge. ( 56C.) In some variants the fox baptizes the hen’s children & becomes their teacher. Then he eats them. ( 56D*.)
62
56DFox asks Bird what she does when the wind blowsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (jackal) asks a bird (sparrow, duck, heron, flamingo) what she does with her beak when it is windy (when she goes to sleep). When the bird puts her head under one wing to demonstrate, the fox gobbles her up.
63
57-Raven with Cheese in his MouthAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox flatters a raven (crow), who is carrying a piece of cheese (meat, breadcrust, a grape) in his beak, by complimenting him on his beautiful singing voice. The raven wants to sing to the fox & drops the cheese. The fox grabs it & gobbles it up. In some variants, the fox provokes the raven by saying that it is too bad that such a beautiful bird as he is, is unable to sing.
64
58-Crocodile Carries the JackalAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA rabbit (jackal) wants to cross a river in order to get some food (because he is invited somewhere). He persuades a crocodile (camel) to carry him across on his back. During the ride, the rabbit declares that the crocodile stinks (the camel is chased on the opposite bank by men). On the return trip, the crocodile, offended, lets the rabbit drown. Occasionally the rabbit escapes. In some variants a monkey (fox) declares that he has been com-manded to count the crocodiles. He orders them to lie in the river next to each other. He counts them by walking on their backs & is able to cross the river
65
59-Fox & the Sour GrapesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (cat, bear, jackal) cannot reach some grapes (pears, rowanberries, pomegranates, flesh, cheese). He persuades himself that they are not ripe enough to eat (that they stink, or that he cannot eat them because it is a fast day). In some variants the fox tries in vain to pick some pears. He follows after a donkey, hoping that his testicles, which he thinks are pears, will fall off so he can eat them. When this does not happen, the fox tells himself that they were black & smelly. In Iberian variants, the fox wants to steal fruit at night & asks for some light so he can see it. He is nearly caught by a hunter. The fox says he did not want that much light.
66
59*The Fox as Trouble MakerAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA jackal (cat, fox) carries dissent between two animals (e.g. lion & tiger, lion & bull, eagle & hog) who had formerly been friends. They fight & kill each other (they die of hunger).
67
60-The Fox & the Crane Invite Each OtherAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (jackal, wolf, cat) invites a crane (stork, woodpecker, heron, crow, snipe) to dinner. He serves him soup (milk, mush) in a shallow dish, & the crane cannot eat the food. The crane invites the fox to dinner in return, & serves the food in a bottle (tall jar), or he strews peas on the floor. In this case the fox cannot eat the food. In some variants the stork invites the fox first, so that the two parts of the tale are reversed
68
61-The Fox Persuades the Cock to Crow with Closed EyesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox meets a bird (rooster, partridge) whom he persuades to sing (dance) for him. He asks the bird to close its eyes as his father had always done (the fox comes near the bird, pretending that he cannot understand it). The fox grabs the bird. In many variants, the bird, caught in the fox’s mouth, induces him to speak, e.g. to say grace before he eats or to tell someone what he has caught. When the fox opens his mouth, the bird escapes.
69
61BCat, Rooster, & FoxAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA cat & a rooster live together (along with a man or other chickens). When the cat goes out to hunt, he warns the rooster not to open the door to the fox (not to show himself at the window). The fox comes & lures the rooster out (by offering him a ride on his tail).
70
62-Peace Among the Animals – The Fox & the RoosterAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (jackal) wants to catch a rooster (dove, titmouse, swallow, fish) who is up in a tree (on a dunghill, roost, in the sea) where he cannot reach it. In order to lure the rooster, the fox announces that it has been decreed that all animals are united in peace. The rooster is dubious. The rooster tells the fox that two dogs are coming their way & that maybe they are bringing along the proclamation of peace. The fox is about to run away, & the rooster asks why. The fox says that he is not sure whether the dogs know about the treaty. In some variants the fox offers the bird a kiss to celebrate the peace treaty, & promises to close his eyes if the bird is afraid. The bird comes near the fox’s mouth & is eaten. Or, the fox offers to pray along with the rooster. The rooster wants to wait until the Imam, who is a dog, arrives. The fox runs away, claiming he forgot to wash in preparation for prayer.
71
62*Forbidden to Sit in TreesAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxIn order to be able to catch some geese, a fox tries to convince them that there is a new law that forbids them from roosting in trees. He accuses them of breaking the law & catches & eats them. In some variants dogs come by & chase the fox away.
72
62APeace Between Wolves & SheepAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThe wolves convince the sheep (goats, shepherds) that the dogs are responsible for the enmity bet-ween sheep & wolves. The sheep agree to deliver the dogs to them as hostages (for punishment). The wolves eat the unprotected sheep. Or, the sheep give the dogs to the wolves as hostages & take the young wolves in return. The sheep are attacked by the wolves.
73
63-The Fox Rids Himself of FleasAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox (jackal) takes a bunch of wool (grass, moss, wood) in his mouth & backs slowly into the water. The fleas in his coat jump forward until all of them are on the wool. Then the fox lets go of the wool or dives under the water.
74
65-The She-Fox's SuitorsAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) In order to test his wife’s devotion, an old fox pretends to be dead. The widow rejects the first suitors who come to her because none of them has nine tails, as her husband had. Finally a suitor comes who has nine tails, & the widow agrees to marry him. The old fox who was supposed to be dead comes to the wedding. He beats his wife & her suitor & sends them out of the house. (2) An old fox is truly dead. One after another, the wolf, dog, stag, Rabbit, bear, & lion (other wild animals) come to woo the widow. Only the young fox has a red coat & a pointed snout, so it is he whom she marries. (3) In Hungarian variants an old widower marries a she-fox, & they invite other foxes to their wedding. The widower pretends to be sick & asks for an axe to put under his pillow. Believing her groom is dead, the bride invites more & more guests. A Rabbit notices that the husband is alive but is unable to warn the others. The old widower catches them, kills them, & skins them.
75
65*The Fox Catches a BeetleAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox finds a beetle beside a river & wants to fry it. However, the only fire is on the opposite side of the river (the fireplace is from last year). The fox eats the beetle raw, but he imagines it was fried & thinks it was a little bit too crisp.
76
66A"Hello House!"Animal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxAn animal (crocodile) wants to catch a weaker animal (jackal, monkey) & hides in wait in its den. When the jackal comes home he smells danger (sees tracks going into his den but not coming out). He calls out several times, “Hello, house!” When no one replies, the jackal announces that usually the house answers him. The animal in the den then answers, & the jackal knows that someone is in his den. He runs away (kills the intruder).
77
66A*Fox Buys Himself a PipeAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThe Fox Buys Himself a Pipe & goes into the barn to smoke. The hay begins to burn. The fox extinguishes the fire with his tail & singes himself.
78
66BSham Dead (hidden) Animal Betrays SelfAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA jackal (fox, rabbit) tests another (dangerous) animal (fox, crocodile) who pretends to be dead (is hiding) to see if it is really dead. The jackal says that dead animals open their mouths or wag their tails. The “dead” animal does this. The Jackal knows it is not really dead & runs away.
79
67-Fox in the Swollen RiverAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox caught in a fast-flowing river loses control of his course. He claims to be swimming to a distant town.
80
67**The Fox Caught by ButcherAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox goes into a house to steal food. He is caught inside & locked in. Finding no way out, he pushes the new boots of the owner (butcher, farmer, old man) into the fire. When the man rushes into the room to rescue his boots, the fox escapes through the open door. Or, a fox is caught in a bakehouse & pretends to look for a back door. His captors run to the rear & the fox escapes through the front.
81
67A*Trash Substituted for Booty taken from Fox's BagAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis misc. type consists of various tales about a fox (antelope) with a sack of booty (goslings, peanuts). Another animal (dog, chicken, leopard) steals the contents of the sack & substitutes stones (ashes, thorns)
82
68-The Jackal Trapped in the Animal HideAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA jackal (gopher) climbs inside an elephant (through the anus) & eats it from the inside. The elephant dies & the jackal is unable to get out because of the shrunken carcass. He induces the rain god to make rain, and, when the water bloats the carcass, the jackal is able to climb out. In some variants, the elephant lets the jackal climb in to share the water which the elephant has drunk. Once inside, the jackal begins to eat the elephant’s flesh. In other variants, the elephant is already dead when the jackal climbs inside it. The elephant’s children open the dead animal to find out why it died. They discover a hyena & a gopher inside. The gopher claims that the hyena alone caused the animal’s death.
83
68*Fox Jeers at the Fox TrapAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A fox sees a trap & jeers at it. Then he grows curious & approaches it. The trap catches the fox. (2) A magpie, a crow, & a raven talk about a trap. The raven becomes caught in it. (3) A swallow warns other birds against a branch covered with birdlime. They disregard the warning & are caught.
84
68AThe Jug as TrapAnimal Tales (1-299)1-69 Clever FoxA fox sticks his head inside a jug to eat what is in it. He cannot remove the jug from his head & is caught (killed) by a human. In order to remove the jug, the fox submerges it & thus drowns himself. Or he tries to bash the jug to pieces. (68B.) In some variants the fox becomes angry at the jug & ties it to his neck or his tail in order to drown it. Instead, he drowns himself.
85
70-More Cowardly Than the RabbitAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsThe Rabbit is afraid of all creatures. At an assembly, the Rabbits announce they will go & drown themselves (go to another country). As they approach a pond, they see that the frogs (ducks, fish) run away from them in fright. Having learned that other animals are even more cowardly than themselves, they return to their home. In some variants, the Rabbits laugh so hard at their stupidity that they split their lips
86
71-Contest of Frost & the RabbitAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsFrost tries to freeze a Rabbit (fox, sparrow) that lies under a bush. He asks the Rabbit whether he is cold. The Rabbit says no, & points out the snow melting under him. Frost tries harder, but the Rabbit manages to get up & declares that he is still warm. Frost admits he has lost the contest. In some variants, the Rabbit laughs so hard at the end that he splits his lip
87
72-The Rabbit Rides Fox A-CourtingAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA fox (tiger, jaguar, alligator, wolf, hyena , elephant) & a rabbit (Rabbit, fox, jackal, tortoise) both woo the same woman, who prefers the fox. The rabbit tells her that the fox is only his horse & promises to prove it. He pretends to be sick & convinces the fox to carry him. The fox lets the rabbit put a bridle on him & ride (whip) him. When the woman sees this, she decides to marry the rabbit.
88
72*Rabbit Emancipates Her ChildrenAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA mother Rabbit does not want to provide for her children any longer. She asks them to look in her eyes & says, “You have such big eyes (long whiskers) now, you can take care of yourselves”. Since then, Rabbits care for their young only for a short time
89
72B*Why the Rabbit Jumps over the PathAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA fox (father Rabbit) asks a Rabbit (his child) why Rabbits jump over the path (run over the mountain). The answer is, “Because we cannot crawl under it”.
90
72D*Tales about RabbitsAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsThis misc. type consists of various tales in which a Rabbit or rabbit wins or loses in a conflict with another animal.
91
73-Blinding the GuardAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA rabbit (fox), who is imprisoned, throws dirt (salt, pepper, tobacco juice) into the eyes of his guard. While the guard is blinded, the rabbit escapes
92
74CRabbit throws a CoconutAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA rabbit (monkey) sits in a tree eating (prickly) fruit (coconuts). A wolf (coyote, crab) asks him to throw one down. The rabbit throws a coconut & (almost) kills the wolf (throws a prickly fruit which kills the wolf).
93
75-The Help of the WeakAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A lion (tiger, bear, elephant) catches a mouse (squirrel, rat) (the mouse disturbs his sleep). The mouse begs for its freedom & promises to come to the rescue of the lion in the future. The lion laughs but sets the mouse free. Later, when the lion is caught in a net (pit, or tied with a rope), the mouse comes & gnaws him free (fills the hole with sand). (2) A mouse (rat) runs under a net where a cat is also caught. When the danger is past, the mouse gnaws the net to free the cat out of gratitude that the cat did not eat him. The mouse says he regrets that a longer friendship between the two of them will not be possible. (3) A lion asks a mouse to rescue him from a net. In return, the mouse asks to marry the lion’s daughter. The lion at first refuses but then agrees to the marriage. The lioness (accidentally) treads on the mouse.
94
75*The Wolf & the NurseAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA hungry wolf (tiger) hears a nursemaid (mother) threaten her child that she will give him to the wolf if he does not stop crying. The wolf waits expectantly for this event. When the child starts crying again, the nursemaid comforts him by saying that she had not really meant what she said & she would kill the wolf if it ever came near the child. The wolf goes away still hungry. Or, the waiting wolf is killed the following morning by the villagers.
95
75AThe Lion & The WormAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsTree roots (branches) grow & block the entrance to a lion’s (bear’s) den. A worm (bark beetle) offers to help, but the lion does not believe he can. After some time the tree dies, due to the worm’s work.
96
76-The Wolf & the CraneAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA crane (stork, woodpecker) pulls a bone from a wolf’s (lion’s) windpipe. When he asks for payment, the wolf says, “That you were allowed to take your beak from my throat is payment enough”.
97
77-The Stag Admires Himself in a SpringAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA stag, seeing his reflection in a spring, is proud of his horns but ashamed of his legs. Later, when he is running away from hunters (dogs, a lion), his horns become caught in the bushes & he is killed.
98
77*Wolf Confesses his sins to GodAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA wolf (who is about to die) confesses his sins. He has eaten a thousand sheep, five hundred hogs, a hundred cows, & fifty horses.In some variants, the wolf’s penitence vanishes as soon as he sees his next prey.
99
77**Wolf at SchoolAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA wolf learns the alphabet (the wolf joins a monastery). The wolf can learn to read only the words “lamb” & “sheep” (“agnes”, “aries”).
100
78-Animal Tied to Another for SafetyAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA tiger (demon, leopard, wolf) is overpowered by a human (donkey, monkey, billy goat) who tricks him. When the tiger tells a fox (wolf) how powerful this human is, the fox makes fun of him & wants to prove that the animals are stronger. The fox proposes to tie together for safety. Together they approach the human. He greets the fox & pretends that it is bring-ing the tiger to him as an offering. The tiger runs away in panic, dragging the fox along with him.
101
78AAnimal Tied Up Becase of a StormAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA rabbit tells a tiger that the end of the world is approaching. The tiger lets himself be tied up. The rabbit beats him, kills & skins him. In some variants, the tiger, advised by the rabbit, climbs into a bag in a tree to escape the end of the world. The rabbit pelts him with stones.
102
80-The Hedgehog in the Badger's DenAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsMisc. type. The narrator reports on something that takes a long time & says that he will continue the tale when it is completed. The following is the most common version: a shepherd has to take many sheep over a bridge, which is so narrow that they have to pass over one at a time. The listeners have to wait while each sheep crosses the bridge to the other side
103
80A*Who Gets the Booty?Animal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA wolf, a fox, & a bear (donkey, camel, dove, badger, crane) seek to divide their booty. They decide to give it to the oldest. Two of the animals boast of their great ages. The third (wolf, bear, camel) admits he is younger but goes off with the prize.
104
81-Too Cold for Rabbit to Build House in WinterAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA rabbit (dog, lark, grouse) freezes during the winter. He vows to build a house the next sum-mer, when it is warmer. In summer, when it is sunny, the rabbit is too lazy & tells himself that last winter he went without a house.
105
85-The Mouse, the Bird, & the SausageAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA mouse, a bird, & a sausage (shrimp) live together sharing the housework. The bird gathers wood, the mouse carries water, makes the fire & sets the table, & the sausage does the cooking & flavors the food by jumping into the pot. The bird complains that his work is the hardest, so they exchange duties. The bird drowns in the well, the sausage is eaten by a dog while gathering the wood, & the mouse is scalded to death when it jumps into the pot to flavor the soup. Or, the mouse (chicken) & sausage live together. While the mouse goes to church on Sunday, the sausage cooks their dinner. One Sunday they change roles, & the mouse is scalded to death when it tries to flavor the soup.
106
87AThe Bear Stands on a Heap of WoodAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA bear chased by wolves (wild pigs) takes refuge in a wood-pile (haystack, tree). He pelts the wolves with logs.In some variants, he finds a man in the haystack (tree), who pokes him with a stick (the branch on which he sits breaks). The bear falls down & is torn to bits by the wolves.
107
88*The Bear Climbs a TreeAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA bear climbs a tree to get some honey. A block hanging in the tree causes him to lose his balance & he falls down. He injures (kills) himself.
108
90-The Needle, The Glove, & The SquirrelAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA needle, a glove, & a squirrel live together. When the needle goes out walking, he finds an old kettle, a knife, & a match (a puddle, a tree stump). The others think these are worthless & beat the needle. When the needle sees an ox (elk, stag), he climbs onto it & kills it. The others rejoice at the successful hunt.
109
91-The Heart of a Monkey as MedicineAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA monkey (fox, jackal) & a turtle (crocodile, fish) are friends. The turtle’s wife becomes jealous & pretends that she has an illness which can be cured only if she eats the heart of a monkey. The turtle meets the monkey & swims into the sea with him on his back. On the way he tells him about his wife’s problem. The monkey sympathises but says he has left his heart in a tree. When the turtle takes him back to the land to get his heart, the monkey runs away. In some variants, the illness of a king (princess) can be cured only by the liver of a rabbit. When one is caught, it pretends to have left its liver at home & offers to go & get it. Then it runs away.
110
92-The Lion Dives for His Own ReflectionAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsA fox (hare) has to supply a lion every day with his dinner. One day he pretends to have met a stronger lion (who took the dinner). The first lion wants to fight against the second. The fox takes him to a well & shows him his reflection. The lion takes it for his rival, jumps in (is pushed in), & drowns . In some variants a rabbit drives an elephant (several elephants) out of the realm of the hares by showing it a reflection of the moon in water, seemingly quivering with anger
111
93-The Master Taken SeriouslyAnimal Tales (1-299)70-99 Other Wild AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A mother fox & her children hear the owner of a vineyard in which they live cursing them. They do not leave until he begins to cut the vines. (2) A bird & her young have their nest in a field of grain. When the farmer asks his neighbors to help with the harvest (the farmer’s sons begin to harvest the field), the birds remain in their nest. They leave only when the farmer himself begins to harvest the field
112
100-The Wolf is Caught Because of His SingingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA dog (fox) invites a wolf to a feast (cellar full of food). The wolf eats & drinks too much. When he sings in spite of the dog’s objections, he is thrashed or killed. The dog escapes
113
101-The Old Dog as Rescuer the Child (Sheep)Animal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA farmer plans to kill his faithful old dog because it cannot work anymore. The wolf makes a plan to save the dog: The latter is to rescue the farmer’s child from the wolf. The plan succeeds & the dog’s life is spared. The wolf in return wants to steal the farmer’s sheep. The dog refuses to help & loses the wolf’s friendship.
114
102-The Dog as Wolf's ShoemakerAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsAn old dog (fox, jackal, hare) promises to make shoes (fur coat) for a wolf (lion, hyena). The dog orders a cow, hog, sheep, etc. to make the shoes, but instead he eats the animals. When the wolf notices the deception, the dog escapes by a trick e.g. he orders the wolf to cross a swamp & says that he has shoes now.
115
103-War between Wild Animals & Domestic AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA dog & a wolf are in conflict & look for allies. A cat & a rooster join the dog, & a fox & a boar join the wolf. The wild animals flee when the domestic animals arrive: The cat shrieks or raises her tail, & they believe it is a gun. The bear falls out of the tree & breaks his back.
116
103AA Cat as She-Fox's HusbandAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsAn old tom-cat is chased away by his master & marries a she-fox. When the other animals want to visit them, the she-fox tells them her husband is a dangerous beast & they should make offerings to him. They must lay these down in front of the fox-earth & then hide themselves. The tom-cat frightens the other animals so that they flee.
117
103A*Cat Claims to be King & Receives Food from Other AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA cat is chased away by his master. He tells a fox that he is the king of the animals. The fox invites him to sleep & warns the other animals to be quiet. The other animals cook a meal & invite the cat to eat with them. When the crow tries to trap him, the cat gets up & the other animals flee in fright.
118
103B*Cat Goes HuntingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA huntsman leaves a dead stag. A tom-cat licks its blood. The other animals, thinking he has killed the stag, bring him food.
119
103C*An Old Donkey Meets the BearAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsAn old donkey is chased away by his master & meets a bear (lion, tiger). They have various contests. The donkey frightens his opponent with dung called cannonballs, or by braying. Later, the bear describes or shows the “strange” animal to the fox or wolf.
120
105-Cat's Only TrickAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe cat in danger saves herself by climbing a tree. A fox, who has boasted that he knows a thousand tricks, is captured by dogs.
121
105*Hedgehogs Only trickAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA fox, who has boasted that he knows a thousand tricks, persuades a hedgehog to steal grapes with him. When the fox is caught in a trap the hedgehog advises him to play dead, so that the huntsman will throw him away & he can escape. When the hedgehog is caught in a trap, the fox refuses to help him. The hedgehog outwits him & escapes.In some variants a hawk (crane) & a fox live together. When huntsmen approach, the hawk plays dead. Thus the fox is also saved from the hunters.
122
106-Animal's ConversationAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis misc. type consists of various tales with imitations of animal sounds.
123
106*The Wolf & The HogAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsAt night a sow goes out beyond the gate. A wolf eats her even though she promises to bear many piglets for him.
124
107-Struggle Between Dogs & WolvesAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe leader of the dogs fears the wolves because they are all of one kind while the dogs are of different breeds & of different colors.In older variants the grey dogs join the wolves but after the fight the wolves kill them.
125
110-Belling the CatAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe mice want the cat to wear a bell, but they cannot find anyone to tie it on her.
126
111-The Cat & the Mouse ConverseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsTo escape from being eaten, a mouse tells a cat a tale or has a long dialog with her. Finally the cat announces that she will eat the mouse anyway.
127
111AWolf Unjustly Accuses Lamb & Eats HimAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA lamb is accused of muddying water even though it is drinking downstream from the wolf.
128
111A*Drunkard's PromiseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA drunken mouse challenges a cat to fight. The cat is about to kill him when the mouse reminds the cat that, when the cat was drunk, he had promised the mouse never to kill him. “That was a drunkard’s promise”, says the cat, & kills the mouse.
129
112-Country Mouse Visits the Town MouseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA town mouse is given hospitality by a country mouse but is shocked by his poor food. The town mouse persuades the country mouse to visit her & leads her into the pantry. They are interrupted by a cat or the owner of the house. The country mouse is frightened & prefers her own poverty.
130
112*The Mice Carry the EggAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA mouse (rat) lies on her back & holds an egg between her legs. A second mouse pulls her into the cave by her tail.
131
112**The Mice & the RoosterAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe mother mouse warns her children about the cat & tells them that the rooster whom they fear is harmless.
132
113-The Mice Choose Cat as KingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis misc. type consists of various tales in which mice choose a cat as their king.
133
113*The Cat's FuneralAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsMice preparing to bury a cat find that it is not really dead. The cat kills them.
134
113APan is DeadAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA man (dwarf) hears a voice (of a cat) that tells him to announce that a third figure (the god Pan, the king of the cats) is dead. The man does not recognize either the voice or the name of the dead person. When he comes home he tells what happened. When the maid (cat) hears this, she says she has to leave (is now the new king of the cats), goes away, & never comes back. In some variants a man kills a cat that follows him. Before she dies, the cat tells the man to inform a particular person of her death. When the man comes home & tells what happened, his own cat kills him.
135
113BCat as Sham Holy ManAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA cat (tom-cat) who pretends to be a holy man (a pilgrim) enlists mice (rats) as disciples. It eats them one by one as they file by or listen to his sermons. In some variants the cat fails to deceive the mice.
136
115-The Hungry Fox Waits in VainAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe Hungry Fox Waits in Vain for the scrotum of the ram to fall off.
137
116-Bear on the Hay-WagonAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA bear enters a horsedrawn vehicle in the forest. The horse starts & the bear is mistaken for the clergyman.
138
117-The Bear Riding the HorseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe Bear Riding the Horse lets his claws sink into the horse’s flanks. When he is caught on a tree & the horse runs on, he is torn in two.
139
118-The Lion Frightened by the HorseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsAn old horse meets a lion who asks him if he can press water out of a stone. The horse says no, but he can strike sparks (with his hooves) out of the stone. The lion is very impressed & he tells the wolf (bear) about the horse. The wolf boasts of having eaten many horses. The lion thereupon picks up the wolf to show him the horse & squeezes him to death by mistake. But he thinks the horse’s glance killed the wolf.
140
119B*Horse's Defense Against WolvesAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) In a fight between a lion & bulls, the lion sets the bulls against each other so he can overcome them. (2) Horses protect themselves from wolves by putting their foals in the middle of a circle & turning their hindquarters toward their enemies.
141
120-The First to See the SunriseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA fox & a hog have a contest to see who can be the first to see the sunrise. The fox places himself on a hill facing the east, the hog in a lower place facing the high trees in the west. The sun shines first on the top of the trees & the hog wins. (Sometimes with human actors.)
142
121-Wolves Climb on Top of One AnotherAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsWolves (tigers) want to punish a man (hog) who has hurt one of them (cut off his tail, poured hot water on him). The man escapes up a tree & the wolves climb on top of one another to reach him. When the man threatens the wolves again, the lowest wolf runs away & all fall down (are killed).
143
122-Animal Loses His Prey Because his Victim Can Escape by False PleaAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsAnimal Loses His Prey Because His Victim Can Escape by False Plea.
144
122AWolf Seeks BreakfastAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf (fox) threatens to eat various animals (hog, sheep, horse), but they ask for a last favor: One has to baptize his children, a second one wants to squeal before the wolf eats him up, so that help comes, & one wants to finish his prayer. The wolf stays hungry (is killed)
145
122BRat Persuades Cat to Wash Face Before EatingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA cat catches a rat (sparrow, squirrel) & is about to eat it. The rat tells the cat that no one eats a meal without having washed his mouth. The cat cleans her mouth & the victim escapes. The cat promises herself to clean her mouth only after a meal.
146
122B*The Squirrel Persuades the Fox to Pray before EatingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe Squirrel escapes.
147
122CSheep Persuades the Wolf to SingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe Sheep Persuades the Wolf to Sing before he eats him. The wolf starts to howl (play the flute), so that the dogs come & farmers beat up (chase away) the wolf.
148
122DCaught Animal Promises Captor Better PreyAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA captured rabbit (sheep, rooster, blackbird, fox) pretends to help a wolf (fox, lion) & promises a more desirable victim. Thus the rabbit escapes.
149
122D*To Make a Bird TastierAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA fox puts a bird into the hub of a wheel to make it tastier.
150
122F"Wait till I am Fat Enough"Animal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA captured animal (hog, sheep, dog) persuades his captor (wolf) to wait until he is fat enough to eat. Thus he escapes.
151
122G"Wash Me" (Soak Me) before EatingAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A wolf (jackal, fox) wants to eat a piglet (crabs & fish). The sow persuades the wolf that she has to wash the piglet first, & pulls the wolf into the water. (2) A turtle explains to a jackal that he has to be soaked in water in order to soften his shell. Thus he escapes.
152
122H"Wait until I get Dry"Animal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA monkey is pulled from mud by a tiger who wants to eat him. He asks the tiger to be allowed to dry in sun before being eaten. Thus he escapes.
153
122K*The Wolf as JudgeAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf meets two rams (goats) & wants to eat one of them. They ask him to settle a quarrel between them about the ownership of a meadow. The wolf will eat the loser. The animals run to the wolf from both sides of the meadow & hit him with their horns. The wolf is killed, or the animals can escape while the wolf is unconscious.
154
122L*Blind Wolf Keeps Guard over a Captive Ox.Animal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA blinded wolf guards an ox. The ox’s legs are tied together. The ox begs the wolf to free them because the bonds are too tight. Then he gives the wolf wooden sticks to hold instead of his feet, & runs away.
155
122M*The Ram Runs Straight into the Wolf's StomachAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf wants to eat a ram. The ram asks him to open his mouth wide so that he can jump right into it. He butts the wolf with his horns & escapes.
156
122N*The Donkey Persuades the Wolf to ride on His Back to the VillageAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf wants to eat a donkey, but the donkey persuades him that the villagers want the wolf as their mayor. The wolf rides on the back of the donkey to the village, & the villagers beat the wolf with sticks.
157
122ZOther Tricks to Escape Being EatenAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis misc. type consists of various tales about other tricks of animals to escape being eaten by the wolf (fox, etc.).
158
123-The Wolf & The KidsAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf comes while a mother goat is away, hoping to eat her kids (kid). When they do not open the door, the wolf changes his voice & colors his paws with flour The children believe that it is their mother & they open the door. The wolf eats the kids (all except one). The youngest kid hides in a clock. The mother returns & takes revenge on the wolf. She finds him asleep, cuts her children out of his belly, & fills it with stones. Or, she challenges him to a fight, which she wins. Or, she invites him to her house where he falls into a pit of hot coals. In older variants the kid obeys his mother & does not open the door.
159
123AThe Fox Buys a Foal & Leaves it at HomeAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA fox cheats some herdsmen out of a foal which he raises. One day when the fox is not at home a wolf changes his voice. The foal lets the wolf into the house & is eaten. The fox takes revenge on the wolf.
160
123BWolf in Sheep's Clothing Gains Admission to the FoldAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis misc. type consists of various tales, in which a wolf (fox) disguises himself as a sheep (occasionally a shepherd) in order to join the herd & eat the sheep. Either he succeeds, or he is discovered & beaten (killed).
161
123EWait for the Fat GoatAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf lies in wait to eat a goat that is passing. He says to wait for his brother, who is much fatter, & to eat him instead. The second goat tells the wolf their third brother is much bigger than him & much more edible. The third goat is huge & kills the wolf.
162
124-Blowing the House InAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA goose builds a house of feathers, a hog one of stone. A wolf (bear) blows the goose’s house down & eats her. He cannot blow down the hog’s house. He tries to lure the hog but the hog outwits him: e.g. the wolf suggests they steal apples together (go to the market) but the hog goes earlier so that the wolf cannot eat him. Finally the wolf tries to get into the house through the chimney. He is burned or scald ed with boiling water. Or, three pigs build one house of straw, one of sticks, & one of iron. The wolf destroys the first two houses & eats the pigs but the third pig is able to outwit him.
163
125-The Wolf Flees from the Wolf-headAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsDomestic animals (sheep, donkey) find a sack & the head (bones) of a dangerous animal (wolf, tiger). They meet another wolf & make him believe that they have killed one of his kind. The wolf flees in terror
164
125B*Contest between Donkey & LionAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A donkey brags to a lion about his abilities & is challenged to press water out of a piece of wood (offers to beat water from the ground with his hoof). When the donkey urinates from the effort, the lion takes him for the stronger animal. (2) A lion pulls down the top of a tree & challenges a donkey to do the same thing. The donkey is thrown into a bush where he falls on a rabbit & kills it. After that the donkey boasts about his abilities ( 125C*). (with human actors). (3) A donkey impresses a lion by catching a fish in his ear while he takes a bath in the river.
165
126-Sheep Chases the WolfAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf (tiger) wants to eat a sheep (goat). The sheep pretends to eat wolves & chases the wolf away.
166
126A*The Frightened WolvesAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA he-goat, a cat & a ram run away from their owners. When they meet some wolves & a bear, they take refuge in a tree. While they are in the tree, the wolves threaten to eat them. The he-goat falls in fright on a wolf & injures him with his horns. The wolves run away.
167
127A*The Wolf Induces the Goat to come down from a Cliff & Devours itAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsIn some variants the goat refuses to come.
168
127B*The Goat Eats in the Garden & is CaughtAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe fox says, “If your sense were as long as your beard, you would have looked for an exit as well as an entrance”.
169
129-Two Sheep Kill a FoxAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsTwo Sheep Kill a Fox who licked up the blood they spilled in a fight.
170
129A*Sheep Licks Her New-Born LambAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsWhen a wolf watches this he says, “This is not fair. If I were to do that they would say I was eating it.”
171
130-Animals in New Quarters (Bremen Town Musicians)Animal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic Animals(Bremen Town Musicians) Donkey, dog, cat & rooster are ill-treated by their owners because they are too old to work. They run away & find a lonely house in the forest. Thieves come & begin to divide their money. The four animals climb on one another’s backs & cry all at once. The thieves (robbers) are frightened & run away, leaving the money there. When the thieves try to come back the animals hide in various parts of the house & attack them with their characteristic powers. The four animals drive the thieves away & live happily ever after.
172
130AAnimals Build Themselves a HouseAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsDomestic animals (ox, rooster, ram, pig) escape from their owner & want to build a house. In some variants only one of them builds a house for the winter & the others think they do not need one. The animal with the house nevertheless must give them shelter.
173
130BFleeing Animals Threated with DeathAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsDomestic animals (goat, ram, cat, donkey, dog, rooster) flee from their home. In the night a pack of wolves wants to eat them, but they defend themselves successfully.
174
130CAnimals in Company of a ManAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsDonkey, goat, dog & cat look for a new home. They find an old woman (man) & promise to work for her.In some variants they cheat the old person, & in other variants they help her.
175
130D*Animals Warm ThemselvesAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsDomestic animals flee because they are treated badly. To start a fire, the cat advises the goat to wind some birch bark around his head like horns & to have a fight with the ram. The bark begins to burn. A bear warms himself at the fire. When they are attacked by wolves, they defend themselves successfully.
176
131-Tiger as False Friend to the CowAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA tiger & a cow become friends & both bear offspring. The tiger drinks water downstream from the cow, decides her flesh would be sweet, & kills & devours her. The calf flees. The cub of the tiger is ashamed of its mother & accompanies the calf on adventures.
177
132-Goat Admires his Horns in the WaterAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsThe Goat Admires His Horns in the Water, & says to himself that he does not have to fear the wolf. The wolf stands behind him & asks what he was saying. The goat answers, “Nothing – people who have drunk too much say foolish things”.
178
133*The Goat Carries the Snake over a StreamAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA goat (turtle, fox) carries a snake (scorpion, crocodile) over a river. When they have crossed it, the snake kills the goat: Nature always asserts itself. In some variants the goat kills the snake.
179
135*The Mouse Makes a Boat of a Bread-CrustAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsShe takes other animals & birds into the boat & it capsizes. The animals quarrel.
180
135A*The Fox Stumbles over a ViolinAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsWhen he is chased by dogs, a fox stumbles over a violin & says, “What a fine opportunity to dance if I had the time!”
181
136-Wolf Surprises Pig in Apple TreeAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA wolf sees a pig in an apple tree. He promises not to eat the pig if the pig will throw him one his hams. The pig throws down a piece of thorny wood instead, which cuts the wolf’s throat.
182
136A*Confession of AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA cat says she will confess her sins. Other animals (rabbit, wolf, fox) want to do the same & accompany her. At a ditch the cat says, “He who can cross it safely shall be without sin”. [M114]. Only the cat crosses the ditch; the other animals fall in & the cat laughs at them.
183
137-The Filthy Hog & the Clean FishAnimal Tales (1-299)100-149 Wild & Domestic AnimalsA fish laughs at a hog because it is so filthy. The hog says to the fish, “People will spit when they eat you, whereas in my case all will lick their fingers”.
184
150-The Bird's Three PreceptsAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansIn return for his freedom, a bird (fox) gives a man three pieces of advice: first, “never try to reach the unattainable”, second “Do not regret a thing that is past”, & third, “Never believe what is beyond belief”. The bird tells him a lie. The man regrets having freed the bird, & the bird says that the man learned nothing from the advice. In some (parodistic) variants a fox promises three pieces of advice to a ferryman. As they cross the river the fox offers two trivial aphorisms. When they reach the bank, the fox, as the third piece of advice, tells the ferryman that he will never get rich if he transports everyone so cheaply.
185
150A*The Frog's CounselsAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA farmer agrees to take in a frog for the winter, & in return it gives him three trite counsels.
186
151-Man Teaches Wild Animal to Play FiddleAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA wild animal (bear, wolf) sees a man playing the fiddle in the forest, or a man is locked up with a dangerous animal (lion, tiger, wolf). He plays on his fiddle for the animal, who asks to learn how to play the instrument. The man says he must cut his claws & catches the animal’s paws in a cleft tree. Similarly the man tricks other animals. After the animals get free, they try in vain to take revenge.
187
151*The Lion in LoveAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA lion in love asks to marry the daughter of a farmer, who tells him he must give up his teeth & his claws. He allows them to be cut, but then he is helpless against the farmer’s abuse.
188
152-Plowman & the AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA plowman punishes animals that disturb him in his work. He burns a bear (wolf) with red-hot iron, tears off the legs of a crow (magpie) & pricks a gadfly with a blade of grass. The animals then watch the man with his girlfriend & interpret his behavior accordingly. The bear says: “He is drawing a pattern on her sides”. The crow says, “He is twisting her leg”. The gadfly says, “He is sticking a stalk of grass into her backside”.
189
152A*The Wife Scalds the WolfAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansAt a signal from her husband, a wife scalds a wolf with boiling water. The next day, the man is attacked by the wolf. He escapes by shouting, “Pour, Catherine!” The wolf flees.
190
153-The Gelding of the Bear & the Fetching of SalveAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man tells a bear that the horse is strong because it is gelded. The bear has the man geld him to make him strong. The next day the bear wants to geld the man. The man substitutes his wife to pretend they have been already castrated. The bear is shocked by the “wound” of the woman & goes for salve. A fox guards the woman, but she drives him away with her farts.
191
154-Fox & His MembersAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man in anger calls his horse “bear-food”. A bear comes & threatens to eat the horse. A fox agrees to help the man against the bear in return for geese. The fox goes into the forest & imitates the barking of dogs. The bear is intimidated & killed. The man pretends to go for the geese but instead brings dogs back in his bag. The dogs chase the fox to his hole. Here the fox asks his feet, eyes, ears, & tail how they helped him in his flight. His tail admits that it did not help. As a punishment the fox sticks out his tail & is attacked by dogs. In some variants a rabbit asks his members about their help in his flight
192
155-Ungrateful Snake Returned to CaptivityAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man rescues a snake (wolf, bear, tiger) from a trap. In return the snake seeks to kill the rescuer. Other animals are asked if a good deed should be repayed with a bad one. The fox, as judge, asks the snake to show how it was trapped. The snake is tricked into captivity. In some variants a man warms a cold snake. The ungrateful snake bites the man & he dies
193
156-Androcles & the LionAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA shepherd pulls a thorn out of a lion’s paw. When the shepherd is thrown as a punishment into a pit of lions, the lion recognises him & licks his hand instead of tearing him to pieces. The emperor releases both. Or, a bone is removed from an animal’s (wolf, tiger, bear) throat, & later the animal shows gratitude to the rescuer.
194
156AFaith of the LionAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man rescues a lion (often from a struggle with a dragon) & out of gratitude it follows the man for his whole life, even to his grave.
195
156B*Grateful SnakeAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a person (man, woman) who helps a snake (e.g. in a battle or to give birth). The snake rewards the person (with gold or money).
196
156C*The Boy & the Bear in PitAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA boy falls into a pit on top of a bear, & helps him to get out of the pit. The bear helps the boy & shows him where to find money.
197
157-Animals Learn to Fear MenAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA wolf (lion, bear) boasts about being stronger than a man. The fox wants to convince him that men are dangerous. They see a boy, & the fox explains that he will be a man later. When they meet an old man, the fox says this was a man but is no longer one. Then they see an armed hunter. The wolf approaches, but the man shots & stabs him with a sabre. Later the wolf tells the fox he could have defeated the man if he did not spit fire & attack him with a sharp rib.
198
157ALion Searches for ManAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA young lion, warned by his parents to shun man, asks other large animals if they are man. They answer that they are only the ill-treated servants of men. He meets a man & is scornful of him, but the man tricks him into entering a cage & leaves him to starve. Or, the man tricks the lion into placing his claws in a cleft of a tree where he is trapped.
199
157BThe Sparrow & His SonsAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA sparrow whose children were lost meets them again & asks how they survived. Three of them tell where they lived, & the sparrow praises them. The fourth lives in a church & the old sparrow admires his wise decision.
200
157C*Hiding from MenAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe animals want to hide themselves from men. The wild beasts hide in the forest, the birds in the air, the fish in the water. However, man catches them all with his gun, his noose & his fishing-rod.
201
158-The Wild Animals on the SleighAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansOther animals ask the fox for a ride on his sleigh, which breaks. To repair it, the animals bring unsatis-factory material from the forest. When the fox goes for good material they eat the horse & build a dummy to replace it.
202
159-Captutred Wild Animals Ransom ThemselvesAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansAn old couple spread pitch on a straw calf. One after another, a bear, a wolf, a fox, & a rabbit touch the calf & stick to it. In return for not being slaughtered, they promise to bring cows, horses, geese & cabbage. Thus the animals ransom themselves & the old people get rich.
203
159*Quarrel over the StagAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansSitting in a tree, a man hears a lion, a dog, a cat & an eagle quarreling over a dead stag (donkey). They ask the man to arbitrate.
204
159AAnimals Warm Selves at Charcoal Burner's FireAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThey are sent after food for dinner. Each of them brings some back, but the charcoal burner drives them away or kills them.
205
159BEnmity of Lion & ManAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA lion (bear) helps a man with his work. The man praises his virtues but criticises the bad smell of his mouth. The lion forces the man to strike him on his head with an axe. After a year, the man & the lion meet again. The lion says that his wound is healed but it stills hurts, & devours the man.
