In some variants the man’s wife complains about the lion. The lion overhears this & forces the man to wound him.
206
159CThe Lion & The StatueAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansIn order to demonstrate the superiority of humans over animals, a man shows a lion a statue of a conquered lion. The lion replies that if a lion had made the statue, it would have looked different.
207
160-Grateful Animals; Ungrateful ManAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA traveler saves a tiger (lion, crow), a monkey (bear), a snake, & a man (jeweler) from a pit (from a tree trunk floating in a flood). The animals give their rescuer a reward or promise to help him later. One animal gives him stolen jewels. The man also promises to reward the rescuer but later he denies it. He accuses the rescuer before the king of having stolen the jewels. The rescuer is to be punished. The snake saves him by biting the king’s child & then showing the rescuer the proper remedy. The traveler is freed & the jeweler is punished. Often the traveler is warned not to rescue the man.
208
160*A Woman Betrays a BearAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA woman is attacked by a bear in the forest. The bear lays her down near a stump of a tree & starts to dig a hole. The woman ties her head-covering to the stump & slips away.
209
161-Farmer Betrays Fox by PointingAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA farmer hides a fox from the hunters in a basket, & promises not to betray him. When the hunters come, he says, “The fox just went over the hill”, but he points to the basket. The hunters do not see this. When the farmer asks the fox to thank him, the fox answers that he would have thanked him if gestures & words had agreed with each other.
210
161A*Bear with the Wooden LegAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA poor old man cuts off a sleeping bear’s leg with an axe. His wife cooks the leg & spins the fur into yarn. The bear makes himself a leg from linden wood. At night he comes to the house & eats the old man. Or, the bear comes to the house & sings about what was done to him, “All the people are asleep; so are the little birds. Only one old woman is awake, & she spins my wool & boils my flesh.”
211
162-Master Looks More Closely Than the FarmhandAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA stag hides from hunters in a stable, but the cows warn him that he would be more secure in the forest. The farmhand does not notice him, but the master finds him & kills him.
212
162A*The Wolf Steals & Eats One SheepAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe Wolf Steals & Eats One Sheep, then two, & finally the whole herd & the shepherd. The wolf is killed.
213
163-The Singing WolfAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansBy his singing (threats or compliments) the wolf compels an old man to surrender his cattle, his children & grandchildren, & finally his wife. In the end the wolf eats the man.
214
165-"Fish, Not Flesh"Animal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe wolf promises to give up eating flesh. When he finds a pig in a puddle, he says, “It’s fish, not flesh”, & eats it up. Or, the wolf promises to give up killing animals & wants to be a saint. On his way to the desert he wrings the neck of a gander. He excuses himself, saying: “He should not have hissed at a saint”.
215
165B*The Wolf is Punished by being MarriedAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe wolf is condemned to the most severe punishment. He is forced to get married. In some variants the wolf must take two wives.
216
166A*The Wolf Puts his Tail through the WindowAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe Wolf Puts His Tail through the Window of the stable & alarms the sheep. The farmer snatches at the tail & tears it off.
217
166B*The Wolf tries to Get HorsesAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansIn the night a wolf comes near the horses. He plunges into the river & then shakes near the fire to exstinguish it or he wallows in the mud to splash it into the eyes of the horses. A sleeping driver awakes, seizes the wolf’s tail & tears it off.
218
168-The Musician in the Wolf TrapAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA violinist falls into a wolf’s hole (sometimes together with a bear). There he encounters a wolf already trapped, & saves himself by playing music until someone (sometimes the bear) helps him out of the hole. The wolf is killed.
219
168AThe Old Woman & the Wolf Fall into the Pit TogetherAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe old woman urges the wolf & other animals to sit still. She is rescued by a hunter who either kills the animals or saves them.
220
169*Misc. Tales of Wolves & MenAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThree main themes can be distinguished: (1) Tales of wolves that do not attack the people they meet. (2) Tales of wolves that harm or want to harm people. (3) Tales of wolves that are punished by people.
221
169KThe Man Drives with a Tub & Little PigsAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansWolves attack a man. He pulls a tub over himself & the little pigs. The wolves put their paws under the tub & the man splits them with a knife.
222
170-The fox eats his fellow-lodgerAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA fox who has a shoe spends the night in a house with a rooster. The fox destroys the shoe & blames the rooster, which he demands as reparation. The next night, in another house, the fox eats the rooster, & in the morning he accuses a sheep of having eaten it. He demands the sheep. In the next house he blames the ox for having eaten the sheep, etc.
223
171A*The Bear Plays with the Boar's YoungAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA boar pursues him. The bear climbs up a tree, but the branch breaks & the bear falls down on the boar. They fight each other & the bear is killed.
224
173-Human & Animal Life Spans are ReadjustedAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansGod (Zeus) originally gives 30 years to all animals & humans. Donkey, dog & monkey refuse some of their years because of their sufferings. Man wants to have more years & takes them from the animals. Therefore in the middle of their lives people must do the hard work of a donkey, then they bark like old dogs, & at last they are foolish like monkeys.
225
175-The Tarbaby & the RabbitAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA cunning rabbit (hare, fox, jackal) steals fruit from a garden (field). A figure spread with tar, wax or glue is set out to trap the thief. The rabbit tries to make the tarbaby talk & finally becomes so angry that he strikes it. He sticks to the tarbaby & is captured. The rabbit is punished.
226
177-The Thief & the TigerAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA tiger overhears a person saying that he fears something worse than the tiger. The word is unknown to the tiger (dripping of rain, sweet, twilight). Thinking it must be a terrible thing, the tiger hides (sometimes among sheep) & is found by a drunken man (thief) who mistakes him for his horse. He rides off on the tiger (steals it because it seems to be a very big sheep). The tiger thinks the man must be the terrible thing he has heard about & meekly submits. In the morning the man sees his mistake & flees.
227
178-The Faithful Animal Rashly KilledAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe Faithful Animal Rashly Killed
228
178AInnocent DogAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA dog (cat, mouse) saves his master’s child from a snake. When the master sees the dog’s bloody mouth, he thinks the dog has eaten the child & kills it. Later on he finds the dead snake & realizes his mistake.
229
178BThe Faithful Dog as Security for a DebtAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA poor man leaves his dog with a wealthy man as security for a large loan. The dog helps the wealthy man by retrieving stolen goods & driving off thieves. The grateful man sends the dog back to its owner with a letter saying the debt is cancelled. The owner, thinking the dog has run away, kills it before he finds the letter.
230
178CThe Thirsty King Kills HIs Faithful FalconAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA king who is out hunting is about to drink a cup of water. His falcon (horse) knocks the cup from his hand. The enraged king kills the falcon. Then he finds out that the cup was full of poison from a snake.
231
179-What the bear whispered in his earAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA traveler & his guide (two friends) go through a forest in which they meet a dangerous bear. The guide climbs a tree & leaves the traveler at the mercy of the bear. The traveler feigns death & the bear sniffs at him & leaves.
232
179*Tales about Men & BearsAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThis misc. type consists of various tales in which the bear is generally hurt (killed).
233
179A*The Bear Pursues MenAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA bear pursues a man who hides in a bush. When the bear puts his paws around the bush, the man rips open the bear’s belly.
234
179A**Man & Bear Hold Each Other Around a TreeAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man & a bear take hold of each other around a tree & will not let go. Another man hurries home for help, but does not come back for a long time. When he comes at last, his comrade, who is holding the bear’s paws, makes him to take his place & goes away. He also stays away for a long time, to take revenge for his friend’s thoughtlessness.
235
179B*An Old Man Carrying a Kneading TroughAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man goes through the forest, lies down to rest, & draws a trough over himself. A hare, a wolf, a fox, & a bear come & admire the fine little table. All of them bring something to eat: a cabbage, a lamb, a goose, some honey. Then the man under the table moves, the animals run away & the man gets all their food.
236
180-The Rebounding BowAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA hunter who has killed several animals is bitten by a snake. A jackal comes by & nibbles at the hunter’s bowstring. He is killed when the bow rebounds.
237
181-The Man Tells the Leopard's SecretAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA lizard & leopard (tiger) play hide & seek. The lizard fastens himself (a crab) onto the leopard’s tail or coats himself with mud so that the leopard cannot grab him. A man witnesses their contest. The leopard is ashamed & threatens him unless he maintains silence. The man betrays the secret & the leopard carries him off. The man escapes by making a noise so that the leopard thinks that the lizard is coming, or by saying he has eggs from which lizards will soon hatch.
238
182-The Helpful Animal & the SnakeAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe helpful animal sees a snake bite his master. He catches a crow, who is the snake’s confederate, & forces the snake to revive his master by sucking out the poison.
239
183*The Rabbit Promises to DanceAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansThe rabbit says he will dance when the gate is opened. He escapes.
240
184-Half of the Money thrown into the WaterAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man makes money by selling milk (wine) mixed with water. A monkey throws the man’s money alternately into water & on land (ship) because the man sold half water & half milk.
241
185-The Nightcap Dealer & the MonkeysAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA man who sells nightcaps puts one on & lies down to sleep. Some monkeys steal some of his caps & put them on. When the man wakes up & sees that the monkeys have his nightcaps, he takes his off & throws it in anger down on the ground. The monkeys copy him, so he gets his night-caps back.
242
186-The Monkey & The NutAnimal Tales (1-299)150-199 Wild Animals & HumansA monkey throws a nut away because it has a bitter shell, & overlooks the edible kernel.
243
200-The Dog�s CertificateAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe dogs have a certificate which they give to a cat to keep it for them. A mouse destroys this certificate. Since then dogs & cats are enemies, also cats & mice.
244
200ADog Loses a CertificateAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe Dog Loses a Certificate (previously Dog Loses his Patent Right) which he had put under his tail to cross a river. The certificate guar-an teed the dogs a privilege. To search for this lost certificate, dogs look (sniff) under each other’s tails.
245
200BWhy Dogs Sniff One AnotherAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Animals arrange a banquet & discover that the pepper is missing. One dog is sent to buy some but he does not return. Since then dogs sniff at one another to find that dog. Or, a dog is sent to get some medicine & does not return. (2) Some dogs are sent to heaven for an audience and, while waiting, they shit in heaven & are chased away. The next time spices or perfume are attached under their tails, but again they are chased away. These dogs do not return to the other dogs, who continue to look for the missing dogs by sniffing under each other’s tails.
246
200C*Enmity between Rabbit & DogAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The rabbit (stag) borrows the shoes of the dog (hare) & runs away with them. Since then the dog chases the rabbit. (2) The rabbit secretly shaves the fur off the dog’s soles.
247
200D*Why Cat is Indoors & Dog Outside in ColdAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA dog envies a cat her place indoors. They have a race & the winner gets to live indoors. The dog is faster than the cat, but loses because during the race he is attacked & detained by a beggar.
248
201-The Lean Dog Prefers Liberty to Abundant Food & a ChainAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA lean dog (wolf, lion, donkey, goldfinch, butterfly) would rather be free than have abundant food & be chained.
249
201D*The Dog Barks at ThievesAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA thief tries to feed a watchdog to stop his barking. The dog realizes it & continues to bark to chase the thief away. If his master is robbed, there will be nothing left for the dog.
250
201F*Hostile Dogs are Made FriendlyAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThey unite against a common enemy (wolf)
251
201G*The Dog at the BanquetAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA dog is invited to dinner by another dog but is chased off by the cook. On his way home he meets a dog who asks him how the dinner was. The first dog claims that he was so drunk that he cannot remember anything.
252
202-Two Stubborn GoatsAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsTwo goats (horse & donkey, lion & fox) meet each other on a small bridge (stone). Neither will step aside. Both go ahead (fight with each other) & fall into the water.
253
203-Sheep & Horse Have Eating ContestAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A sheep & a horse have an eating contest. The sheep thinks he lost because his legs were too weak. (2) In the contest between goat & rabbit the goat wins because it ruminates.
254
204-Animals in Peril at SeaAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsWhen some animals (e.g. duck, rooster, sheep, goose, pig, goat, cat, mouse, rat) are in danger at sea the duck swims, the rooster flies up the mast, & the sheep drowns. Each animal calls out something that corresponds onomatopoetically to its characteristic voice.
255
206-Straw Threshed a second TimeAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsAt night, the animals say they have good food because the straw has not been well threshed. The master hears this & threshes the straw a second time. The animals go hungry.
256
207-Rebellion of the Work AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA rooster advises a donkey & an ox to feign illness so they can work less. The farmer overhears this talk & has the rooster slaughtered.
257
207AA Donkey Induces Overworked Ox to Feign SicknessAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe donkey must do the ox’s work, so he persuades the ox to stop being ill.
258
207A*The Lazy HorseAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe lazy horse (hard-working donkey) always waits for the next season. The diligent one is pleased with any season.
259
207BHard-hearted Horse & DonkeyAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA horse refuses to help an over-burdened donkey, so it collapses. Afterwards, the horse has to carry the load alone.
260
207CAnimals Ring Bell & Demand JusticeAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA king (Charlemagne, Anu-širwān) has a bell which petitioners for justice may ring. An old horse (donkey) rings the bell & accuses his master of having chased him away because he is old & weak. The king orders the master to care for the old animal. Or, the bell is rung by a snake which is menaced by a toad. The king kills the toad & the snake shows gratitude by healing the blind king
261
209-The Donkeys Decide to Kill the SaddlerAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsSome donkeys decide to kill the saddler to get rid of their work. When an old donkey warns them that the next saddler will be inexperienced, they renounce their plan.
262
210-Rooster, Hen, Duck, Pin, & Needle on a JourneyAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe animals & objects (also egg, millstone, dog, mouse, crayfish) hide in various parts of a house. They kill the house’s owner with their characteristic strengths. In some variants they save him (a young woman) from danger or take revenge for one of their companions who was killed.
263
210*VerliokaAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe terrible demon, Verlioka, kills two girls & their grand -mother. The grandfather sets out for the demon’s hut to punish him. On the way he meets various objects & animals (e.g. rope, cow-dung, stick, duck, crayfish, acorn) which join him since they also want to take revenge. Together they kill the demon.
264
211-Two Donkeys & their LoadsAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA donkey loaded with salt falls into a river. His load becomes light. A second donkey loaded with sponges (feathers) tries to reduce the weight in the same way, but he (almost) drowns, because the water makes his load heavier. Or, two birds have a contest to see which of them can fly higher while carrying a load. One bird carries cotton, the other salt. During the contest it rains, so the second bird wins.
265
211B*Animals Go into a TavernAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThree animals go into a tavern. The first animal (gander, duck) orders a beer, the second (drake, goat) says they cannot pay for it, but the third (boar, turkey) reassures the innkeeper that they will pay later. Conversation between animals with imitation of animal voices.
266
212-The Lying GoatAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA man sends the members of his family one after the other to pasture the goat. Back home, the goat always complains it did not get anything to eat. The man angrily sends away his sons (daughters, wife) or kills them. When he himself pastures the goat he realizes that it lies. He skins the goat (shaves its head) to punish it. The goat escapes into a foxhole & drives away a fox, a wolf & a bear. A bee (hedgehog, ant) succeeds in driving the goat away.
267
214-Donkey Tries to Caress his MasterAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA donkey, watching how well the dog is treated, tries to flatter his master in the same way. But he is punished for his actions.
268
214*Donkey Envies the Horse in Its Fine TrappingsAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsWhen the horse is killed in a battle (must work in a mill) the donkey is no longer envious.
269
214ASinging Donkey & Dancing CamelAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA donkey & a camel (fox & donkey, scorpion & frog) are captured because of the donkey’s singing. They have to work in a caravan. When the donkey refuses to cross a river with the caravan the camel has to carry it. The camel starts to dance & throws the donkey into the river.
270
214BDonkey in the Lion's SkinAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA donkey (hare), disguised in a lion’s skin, spreads fear, but is found out by its voice or another characteristic feature.
271
215-A Crow Tries to Carry Off a Lamb as an Eagle doesAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsThe lamb is too heavy but the jackdaw cannot drop it because it is caught in the lamb’s fleece.
272
217-The Cat with the CandleAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA man trains a cat (monkey, dog) to hold lighted candles on its head. When a mouse runs through the room, the cat drops the candle & chases the mouse.
273
218-A Cat Transformed to a Maiden Runs after a MouseAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA cat (weasel) is transformed into a woman so she can marry a young man, but she continues to chase mice.
274
219E*The Old Man Has a Rooster, the Old Woman a HenAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsAn old man envies a woman because of the eggs of her hen. He sends his rooster off to bring him some money. When the rooster returns with a lot of money, the old woman sends the hen off to do the same, but she returns without success.
275
219E**The Hen that Laid the Golden EggsAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA hen (goose) lays one golden egg every day (for a poor woman). Thinking that the hen must be full of gold, the woman (her husband) kills it but finds nothing special inside.
276
219F*The Dog & the Sow ArgueAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA dog & a hog argue about which one of them gives birth more easily. When the dog declares that, of all animals, she gives birth the most easily, the hog points out that the dog’s pups are blind at birth.
277
219H*The Rooster & the PearlAnimal Tales (1-299)200-219 Domestic AnimalsA rooster prefers a single seed to a lot of pearls.
278
220-The Council of BirdsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe eagle as judge assigns to each species of birds their nesting places & work.
279
220AThe Trial of the Crow by the EagleAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA crow is tried & punished for various crimes. In order to avenge itself, the crow slanders other birds who are then also punished.
280
221-The Election of King of BridsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe birds have a contest to choose their king. The wren wins by cleverness & becomes king.
281
221ATest: Who can Fly Highest?Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe birds agree that whichever of them flies highest will be their king. The wren hides in the eagle’s wings & waits until the eagle reaches his highest point. Then the wren flies out, higher than the eagle.
282
221BTest: Who can Go Deepest in Earth?Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe birds agree that whichever of them can go deepest in the earth will be their king. The wren goes down into a mousehole. The other birds try to starve him out. The owl is supposed to guard the exit of the hole, but the wren escapes nevertheless.
283
222-War between Birds (Insects) & QuadrupedsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA bear (wolf, lion) insults the children of a wren (insults an insect). The wren declares war, & the flying animals fight against the quadrupeds. The fox leads the quadrupeds & lifts his tail to signal that they are on the advance. Gnats bite the fox under the tail, so he lowers it. The quadrupeds think they have lost & retreat. The flying animals win.
284
222ABat in the War Between Birds & QuadrupedsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBecause of its ambiguous form the bat joins first one side & then the other, but it always takes the side of the winner. The animals notice this when they make peace. Consequently, the bat is despised by all animals.
285
222BQuarrel between Mouse & SparrowAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA mouse & a sparrow want to share the food they have stored for the winter (try to divide a single remaining grain). Their quarrel turns into a war between birds & quadrupeds in which the eagle is injured.
286
223-The Bird & the JackalAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA jackal (fox) orders a bird (often a lark) to obtain food. The bird flies near men carrying baskets of food. The men drop the baskets to pursue the bird & the jackal eats the food. The jackal orders the bird to make him laugh. The bird lands on the heads of two men so that they fight with one another. The jackal orders the bird to make him cry. The bird leads men or dogs to the jackals’s hiding place. The jackal orders the bird to save his life. The bird lures the jackal to a crocodile, then strikes the crocodile so that the jackal is able to escape.
287
224-Bird WeddingAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsMisc. type. Birds (turtle & peacock, frog & mouse, owl & hoopoo, lark & nightingale, etc.) or insects (beetle, grasshopper, ant, etc.) intend to marry. Many guests (birds, insects, other animals) are invited and/or they are assigned to prepare for the wedding. The course of the wedding feast is described (including unpleasant event).
288
225-Crane Teaches the Fox to FlyAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA fox (jackal, wolf, tortoise) asks crane (stork) to teach him to fly. Once high up in the sky, the bird drops the fox. Usually, the fox dies upon hitting the ground, but in some cases he is saved.
289
225ATortoise Lets Itself be Carried by BirdsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA tortoise is carried up into the air by two birds (herons, geese, swans) who hold onto a stick which the tortoise holds in its mouth. When it speaks, it loses its grip & drops to its death. Or, a bird (eagle) takes the tortoise into the air, drops it so that it smashes, & eats it. Sometimes used to explain why the shell of the tortoise has cracks.
290
226-The Goose Teaches the Fox to SwimAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe goose drowns it. In some (German) variants, the goose teaches the fox to dance & flies away.
291
227-Geese ask for Respite for PrayerAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA fox (wolf) wants to eat geese (ducks, piglets) but they ask him to grant them a last wish: a prayer or a dance. They crackle continuously. Sometimes people come to help them (they are able to escape).
292
227*The Crow & the CrayfishAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA crow catches a crayfish. The crayfish compliments the crow, who opens its beak to reply. The crayfish falls into the water & escapes.
293
228-A Little Bird Tries to be BiggerAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA titmouse (wren) ruffles up her feathers to be as big as a bear but her children laugh at her. In her usual shape (sometimes also gnat, bee) she flies into the bear’s (tiger, wolf) ear & kills him.
294
229-Animals Fear a Bird's Body PartAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA hawk is afraid of a snipe’s bill, but is reassured by the snipe. Other animals fear the rooster (a fox fears a bell) because they believe that it has fire on its head. One animal tells them that it is harmless.
295
230-The Rearing of the Large-headed & Large-eyed birdAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsAn eagle (hawk) fosters an owl. When he learns how long the owl can live, he kills it.
296
230*The Race of the Rooster, the Birch-Cock & the Birch-HenAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe animals decide whichever wins a race may live in town (on the farm). The rooster deceives the others & wins.
297
231-The Heron & the FishAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA heron (crane) tells the fish that their lake is drying up. It promises to transport them one by one to another lake, but eats them instead. A crab sees through the deception, seizes the heron by the throat, & kills it.
298
231*Animals Eat Each OtherAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThis misc. type consists of various tales in which smaller animals are eaten by bigger ones. Sometimes the last one in the food chain (fox, lion, bear) is shot by a hunter or bursts.
299
231**The Falcoln & the DovesAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsDoves beg a falcon to help them (they elect him king) but he eats them & their young.
300
232C*Which Bird is Father?Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA very small bird goes to God with his adult son, & asks God to guess which of them is the father & which the son. God: “There is a spot on the father’s nose”. The father quickly rubs his nose & God knows the answer.
301
232D*Crow Drops Pebbles into a Water JugAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA thirsty crow drops pebbles into a tall jug of water. The water level rises so that the crow is able to drink from the jug.
302
233AThe Birds Escape by Shamming DeathAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBirds caught in a fowler’s net (cage) follow the advice of an old bird & pretend to be dead. After the fowler throws them out onto the ground, they fly away.
303
233BBirds Fly Off with the NetAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBirds caught in a fowler’s net fly off with the net. They fly to a mouse (rat) who gnaws the net & sets them free.
304
233CThe Swallow & the Hemp-SeedsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBirds ignore the advice of a swallow (owl, tortoise) to eat hempseeds (mistletoe) as fast as they are sowed. Ridiculed, the swallow builds his nest among the dwellings of men. Later the other birds are caught in nets made from the hemp. Sometimes used to explain why the swallow lives close to humans.
305
233DThe Birds & the FowlerAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBirds see the watery eyes of a hunter (from cold) & think he weeps out of pity for them. One clever bird tells them that it is not so.
306
234-The Nightingale & the BlindwormAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBoth have one eye. The nightingale (crow, dove, fox, tick) borrows the blindworm’s eye & then refuses to return it. Since then, she has two eyes & the blindworm has none. The latter lives in a tree where the nightingale has her nest & in revenge bores holes in the nightingale’s eggs.
307
234A*Birds Brew BeerAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBirds brew beer in a river with one grain or one ear of grain. They rejoice that the beer is excellent.
308
235-The Jay Borrows the Cuckoo's SkinAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBut he does not return it.
309
235C*A Bird has New Clothes MadeAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsIt flies away without paying.
310
236-Magpie Teaches the Dove to Build a NestAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA dove (magpie, sparrow) asks a magpie (thrush, swallow, crow) to show her how to build a nest. As soon as the magpie starts, the dove says “I know”, & persists in building her nest as before, so that the eggs nearly drop out. In some variants the dove promises to give her cow to the magpie & then regrets losing the cow. (Imitation of bird sounds.)
311
236*Misc. Tales with Imitation of Bird SoundsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsSome variants explain the sounds made by bittern & hoopoe. Two herdsmen send their cows to the wrong pasture. The hoopoe & the bittern tell them that one pasture is too rich, & another pasture too poor. (Imitation of bird sounds.)
312
237-The Talking ParrotAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA parrot (in early variants a magpie) gives wrong orders or makes inappropriate remarks & is punished by its master (thrown in the mud, loses the feathers on its head or is chased & hides under the stove). There the parrot meets an animal (sow, cat) or bald person & says, “You too must have had a quarrel with your master”.
313
238-The Dove & the Frog Boast to Each OtherAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA dove (falcon, crow) claims to have keen sight, & a frog (bee) believes it hears everything. They demonstrate their abilities to each other.
314
239-The Crow Helps the Deer Escape from the SnareAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA deer helps a jackal, but when the deer is caught in a snare the jackal refuses to help him. On the advice of a crow the deer feigns death. When the hunter releases him, he bounds away.
315
240-The Dove Trades Her EggsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA magpie (crow, hen) persuades a dove to exchange eggs (in English variants to exchange nests): the dove gets the two eggs of the magpie for her seven. Since then the dove lays only two eggs & mourns the loss of the other eggs. (Imitation of bird sounds.) In some variants a dove & a hen have a race for the eggs. The hen deceives the dove & wins.
316
240A*The Bee Falls into the WaterAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA dove saves a bee (ant) from drowning. When a hunter wants to shoot the dove, the bee stings the hunter.
317
241-The Officious Bird & the MonkeyAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA bird, sitting in its nest during a cold rain, asks a shivering monkey why it doesn’t build a house since it has hands like a man. The enraged monkey destroys the bird’s nest.
318
242-The Crow's OathAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA crow (another bird) entices a frog (toad) out of his hole & swears not to eat him. The crow breaks his oath.
319
243*The Crow MarriesAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA crow marries because her bridegroom told her that he owns all grainfields. As the grain is being harvested in the autumn, the wife calls out, “Iaak, they are stealing the grain”.
320
243AThe Rooster Who Crows about Mistress's Adultery Killed.Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe first rooster crows about the adultery committed by the mistress. He is killed. The second rooster crows about the first rooster being killed for telling the truth. He is also slaughtered. The third rooster is discreet & is allowed to live.
321
244-Crow in Borrowed FeathersAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA raven puts on swan (peacock) feathers. Other birds take them from him & leave him disgraced in the cold. Sometimes a crow borrows feathers from other birds for his wed-ding day.
322
244A*Crane & the HeronAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA crane (stork) proposes to a heron. She refuses him. After some thought she goes to the crane, but he sends her away. Then he changes his mind & goes to the heron again, but is refused, etc.
323
244B*The Two Starving SparrowsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsTwo sparrows are starving. One flies away to look for food & finds some cherries. He eats his fill & flies back with some for his companion, but finds he is already dead.
324
244C*Raven Drowns His Young Who Promise to Aid Him When He Becomes OldAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsHe saves only the one who admits that he will not carry the old bird because he will have to carry his own young.
325
245-The Tame Bird & the Wild BirdAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA tame bird advises the wild bird to look about him. The wild bird is shot.
326
246-Two BirdsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsWhen a hunter bends his bow, one bird (fish, deer) flies away. The other one remains & is shot.
327
247-Each Mother Likes Her Own Children BestAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A partridge asks an owl (raven) to take some food to its child at school. The owl wants to know how to recognize the child & the partridge answers that its child is the most beautiful. But the owl considers its own child as most beautiful & gives it the food. (2) A snipe asks an eagle (hawk, wolf, sportsman) to spare its young, saying that they are easily recognized as the prettiest in the forest. The eagle eats only the ugliest little birds it can find. They are the young snipes.
328
248-The Dog & the SparrowAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA man inadvertently runs over a dog, the friend of a sparrow. The sparrow takes vengeance & annoys the man. He tries to kill it but, in so doing, he kills his horse or destroys his cargo. The man catches the bird & devours it alive. When the bird looks out from his backside or his mouth, his wife tries to kill it. Instead, she hurts or kills her husband.
329
248AThe Elephant & the LarkAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsAn elephant tramples a lark’s nest. The lark’s friends take revenge. The frog croaks & causes the elephant to fall into a dry pool, the crow pecks out the elephant’s eyes, & the bees sting the elephant to death.
330
250-Swimming Match of the FishAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe fish have a race, & the smaller one wins. The perch hangs on to the tail of the salmon & is the winner.
331
250AFlounder's Crooked MouthAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe fish have a race to elect their king. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The flounder cries out in jealousy because the herring is winning. (2) The flounder makes a discourteous remark to God. It is punished by having its mouth made crooked.
332
253-The Fish in the NetAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe little fish slip through the mesh; the big ones are caught.
333
275-The Race between Two AnimalsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsIt's a race between two animals.
334
275ARace Between Tortoise & RabbitAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsIn a race between a fast animal (hare) & a slow animal (tortoise, toad), the fast animal sleeps on the road because it thinks it has plenty of time. The slow animal is able to pass it & wins the race by its endurance.
335
275BThe Race of the Fox & the CrayfishAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe crayfish (crab, frog, toad, tick, chameleon) hangs on to the fox’s tail & wins. In some Asian variants the animals have a jumping contest. The smaller animal hangs on to the bigger & wins.
336
275CRace Between Rabbit & TortoiseAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe slower animal outwits the faster. The hedgehog (tortoise, mussel, snail) asks a relative (his wife) to wait at the other end of the race course or several relatives are placed along the course. The rabbit (fox, jackal) runs from one end to the other until he is completely exhausted.
337
275C*The Race of Frog & SnailAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe snail wins the race because the frog cannot pass a gate on the road & has to wait. The snail crawls over it.
338
276-Crab Walks Backwards: Learned from his ParentsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe father (mother) of a crab wants to oblige its child to walk straight. The child answers that the parent should walk straight first.
339
277-King of the FrogsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsWhen the frogs (ants) ask God (Jupiter) for a king, he throws a log into the water. They are unhappy. God sends a crane (stork, snake) to be the king & it eats up the frogs. They regret that they were not satisfied with their first king.
340
277AFrog Tries in Vain to be as Big as an OxAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsHe puffs himself up until he bursts.
341
278-Frog & Mouse Tied TogetherAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA frog (toad) ties its feet to those of a mouse in order to cross a lake (marsh). On the way, the frog almost drowns the mouse. A falcon carries them off & eats them both.
342
278AFrog Persists in Living in Puddle on RoadAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA frog disregards the advice of another frog to move with him to a lake. He is run over.
343
278A*Frogs Decide Not to Jump in WellAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsWhen their spring dries up, the frogs consider jumping into a well. They decide that the well may also dry up & they would be unable to get out.
344
279*Snake Trying to Surround Crab Refuses to Straighten HimselfAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA snake & a crab want to live together, but the snake surrounds the crab too closely. The crab objects & kills it. Then the snake straightens itself out & the crab thinks, they can be friends.
345
280-The Ant Carries a Load as Large as HimselfAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsAn ant & a raven (bear) have a contest to see if they can each carry a load as large as themselves up into a tree. The ant wins. Often combined with an etiological explanation (why the raven lays its eggs in March, why the bear eats ants).
346
280AAnt & the CricketAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsDuring the summer, an ant collects food for the winter while a cricket (grasshopper) sings. In the winter, the cricket asks for food from the ant, but it refuses to help & advises the cricket to dance.
347
281-Misc. Tales of GnatsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThis type exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) Gnats want to kill a horse. When it rolls over, they think they have thrown him. (2) Some gnats apologize for landing on bull’s horns. But the bull did not feel their weight. (3) Gnats defeat a lion but are killed in a spider web. (4) A man cannot chase a buffalo away from a mud hole. A gnat succeeds.
348
282A*The Flea & The FlyAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe two insects (often an insect & an illness, or two illnesses like fever or gout, also with spider & mucus or mucus & excrement) meet & complain about their lives. The flea is unhappy in the country (with poor people) & the fly in the city (with rich people), so they switch places & are content.
349
282B*Conversation of Fly & FleaAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA flea & a fly talk about their lives. The flea is hunchbacked because he crawls under rags all night long on the sleeping man. The fly has swollen eyes because he laughs so much over man’s unsuccessful efforts to catch him.
350
282C*The Louse Invites the FleaAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA louse invites a flea to spend the night. The flea bites a sleeping person & jumps away. The sleeper searches his bed, finds the louse, & kills it. Sometimes the flea & the bedbugs are killed too.
351
282D*The Louse & the Flea Spend the Night in a woman's backside & vaginaAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe next morning they tell each other what happened to them. The woman had sexual intercourse.
352
283-Spider & the FlyAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A spider invites a fly (wasp) to rest on her “curtain”. But it is really her web & she eats the fly. (2) A spider catches many flies & releases one of them so that it can tell the others that the spider is harmless. But when more insects come to the spider’s web, the spider eats them.
353
283B*The House of the FlyAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsFly, mouse, hare, fox, & wolf gather in a mit-ten (skull). A bear sits down on the mitten & crushes all of them.
354
283D*The Woman Laughs at the SilkwormAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe Spider Laughs at the Silkworm for working so slowly. The silk-worm replies that his work is valuable, whereas that of the spider is worthless.
355
283H*The Dungbeetle Keeps Destroying Eagle's eggsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsFinally, the eagle flies up into the sky & lays the eggs on Zeus’s lap. The dungbeetle causes Zeus to shake his apron & break the eggs.
356
285-The Child & The SnakeAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA child shares its milk with a snake. When the mother sees this, she fears for her child & kills the snake. Soon the child becomes ill & dies.
357
285AMan & the Wounded SnakeAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA snake is fed milk & brings luck (money) to a man (household). Some one kills (injures) the snake (its young) by mistake (from greed) & thereafter the snake brings bad luck. Often the man tries to conciliate the snake (bird). It refuses because the pain it suffered cannot be forgiven.
358
285A*The Adder Poisons the Children's FoodAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBecause their mother has thrown away her eggs. The mother puts the eggs back. The adder up sets the pot with the poisoned food.
359
285BSnake Stays in the Man's StomachAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA farmer sleeps under a tree & a snake is about to crawl into his mouth. A nut drops from the tree & wakens the farmer, who kills the snake & eats the nut.
360
285B*The Snake Stays in the Man's StomachAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA man (woman) sleeps under a tree with his mouth open. A snake crawls unnoticed into his body, & he feels sick.
361
285ESnake Tries to Bite on a FileAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA snake (weasel) bites a sharp metal file & injures its mouth, but the animal thinks that the file shed the blood.
362
288B*The Over-Hasty ToadAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA toad has spent years ascending some steps. On the last step it falls & curses its haste.
363
288B**Festina Lente (Haste makes Waste)Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA man asks the way to the next town & is advised not to hurry. When he hurries all the same, a wheel breaks or his horse is injured.
364
288C*The Deliberate TurtleAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA turtle is sent by animals to ask God for rain. After two months, the animals go in search of him. When they speak ill of him, he raises his head from under a rock & rebukes them.
365
289-Bat, Diver, & Thornbush ShipwreckedAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA bat, a thornbush & a diving bird want to be business partners. The bat lends money, the thornbush puts on clothes, & the diving bird brings leather. All are shipwrecked, but survive. Since then the diving bird has been looking in the water for his leather. The thornbush has been looking for its clothes & holds tightly to everyone who passes by. The bat appears only at night to escape its creditors.
366
291-Deceptive Tug-of-warAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA small animal (rabbit, tortoise) challenges two large animals (elephant, hippopotamus, whale) to a tug-of-war & arranges it so that they unwittingly pull against each other (one end of the rope is tied to a tree).
367
292-Donkey Tries to Get a Cricket's VoiceAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA donkey asks a cricket what it eats to get such a voice. The answer is “dew”. The donkey eats only dew & starves to death.
368
293-Debate of the Belly & the MembersAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe members accuse the belly of being lazy & gluttonous. They refuse to carry the food but, in so doing, they harm themselves because they all depend on each other. There are variants of this type with different opponents, e.g. house & stone (Serbian) or head & tail of a snake.
369
293B*The Mushroom Reviles the Young OakAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe Mushroom Reviles the Young Oak for clinging to it. After three days the mushroom collapses. The oak keeps on growing.
370
293C*The Flies in the Country and in TownAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsAt a meeting town flies (flies from Prussia) say that, when they fall into the food, they are lifted out with a silver spoon & licked off. The country flies (flies from Lithuania) say that they are thrown away with the contents of the spoon, & always have enough to eat.
371
293D*The Hops and the Turnips Quarrel.Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsHops (bean) & turnip (onion) insult each other. Later they are reconciled & compliment each other.
372
293E*The Grains Talk with One Another.Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThe barley (corn) would like to go where gold can be found. The wheat answers that it itself is gold.In some variants the grains insult & praise each other.
373
293G*The Hedgehog, the Shilling, and the GentlemanAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA hedgehog finds a shilling which a young gentleman takes away from him. The hedge-hog shouts at the man, “Because you have nothing, you took it away from me”. The gentleman throws back the shilling. Then the hedge-hog shouts, “You gave it back to me because you are afraid”.
374
294-The Months & the SeasonsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThis misc. type consists of various tales with etiological explanations & symbolic actions, e.g.: (1) The months invite & threaten each other. (2) Also variants about the question of which month is the best. The best answer, which is every month has its good characteristics, brings luck to the person who gives it.
375
295-The Bean (Mouse), the Straw & the CoalAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA piece of coal & a straw escape from the fire in a stove . A bean escapes from a pot on top of the fire. They go on a journey. When they have to cross a river, the straw serves as a bridge. The coal burns the straw in two & both fall into the water & drown. The bean laughs at them until it bursts. Someone sews the bean together, & that is why beans have a black stripe.
376
296-Clay Pot & Brass Pot in RiverAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsTwo pots are floating in a river. The clay pot is afraid it will bump into the metal one & break.
377
297BThe War of the MushroomsAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA mushroom summons all the mush-rooms to war. All refuse except one kind of mushroom.
378
298-Contest of Wind & SunAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsBoth try to make a traveler take off his coat. When the wind blows violently, the traveler pulls his coat closer around him. The sun succeeds by its warmth.
379
298AThe Frostgod & His SonAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsTwo frosts agree to make a gentleman in his fur coat & a farmer shiver. The gentleman suffers greatly from the frost. The other frost creeps into the farmer’s old fur coat. The farmer takes it off in order to hew wood, & its fur is frozen hard. The farmer beats it, & so the frost also gets a thrashing.
380
298A*The Man Greets the WindAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) Sun, frost (moon) & wind meet a farmer who greets one of them. They cannot decide who is being addressed & ask the farmer. He answers that he intended to address the wind because it protects him from severe heat & cold. (2) Cold & wind compete for supremacy & ask a farmer’s opi nion. The farmer favors the wind. The cold wants to take revenge for this answer, but the wind helps the farmer so that he does not loose his harvest. (3) Cold & wind quarrel about their strength. The wind overcomes the frost.
381
298C*Reeds Bend before Wind (Flood)Animal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA reed & an oak argue which is the stronger. The reed wins because it saves itself by bending in the wind, while the oak is uprooted. In some variants a thornbush tells a beautiful pine tree that in the future when the pine tree is cut down, it will be happy to change places with the thornbush.
382
299-Mountain Gives Birth to a MouseAnimal Tales (1-299)220-299 Other Animals & ObjectsA mountain goes into labor but gives birth only to a mouse.
383
300-The Dragon-SlayerTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA youth acquires (e.g. by exchange) three won-derful dogs. He comes to a town where people are mourning & learns that once a year a (seven-headed) dragon demands a virgin as a sacrifice. In the current year, the king’s daughter has been chosen to be sacrificed, & the king offers her as a prize to her rescuer. The youth goes to the appointed place. While waiting to fight with the dragon, he falls into a magic sleep, during which the princess twists a ring (ribbons) into his hair; only one of her falling tears can awaken him. Together with his dogs, the youth overcomes the dragon. He strikes off the dragon’s heads & cuts out the tongues (keeps the teeth). The youth promises the princess to come back in one year (three years) & goes off. An impostor (e.g. the coachman) takes the dragon’s heads, forces the princess to name him as her rescuer, & claims her as his reward . The princess asks her father to delay the wedding. Just as the princess is about to marry the impostor, the dragon-slayer returns. He sends his dogs to get some food from the king’s table & is summoned to the wedding party. There the dragon-slayer proves he was the rescuer by showing the dragon’s tongues (teeth). The impostor is condemned to death, & the dragon-slayer marries the princess.
384
300AFight on the BridgeTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesAfter having eaten a (three) fish, the daughter of a tsar, her maid, & a she-dog (cow, mare, cat) give birth to sons at the same time. The three sons together go out for adventure. While his brothers are sleeping, the animal son (often a fool) fights against a three-headed dragon on a bridge. In the following two nights he defeats six-, twelve- or multi-headed dragons (is able to defeat the third one only with the help of his horse). (In the form of a fly, cat or the like,) the animal son overhears the con versations of the dragon-wives (dragon-daughters), defeats their enchantments, & thus saves his brothers. The dragon’s mother pursues the three brothers & devours two of them. The animal son hides in a magic forge. He outwits the dragon’s mother, who spits out the brothers she had devoured. Together with the smiths, the animal son kills the dragon’s mother, & the smiths forge her to a horse. In some cases, a magical old man (father of the slain dragons) defeats the animal son in a contest (horse race) & takes away his horse. The old man sends out a hero in order to win a bride. In addition to this regular form, there exist two versions without the introductory part of the magic conception: (1) The dragon-slayer wins back the celestial lights which the dragon had stolen & gives them to men. (2) The animal son defeats the strongest dragon & wins his horse for the tsar.
385
301-Three Stolen PrincessesTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part:Introductory episodes: (1) A king banishes his three daughters to the underworld (they are abducted by monsters. Three brothers (a supernatural hero with his extraordinary companions) go to find the daughters. (2) A monster (dragon, snake, etc.) steals golden apples from the king’s garden. Three brothers (princes) lie in wait. Only the youngest is able to wound the monster. The brothers follow his bloody tracks. (3) A child of magic birth (son of a bear or horse, born from tears) grows into a youth gifted with exceptional strength. He takes to the road for adventure (luck), & allies himself with two companions with extraordinary powers. When they prepare their food, twice a little man (dwarf, devil, giant) spoils it (eats the food & beats up the cook). Only the hero is able to catch & punish the little man, who then shows the companions the entrance to the underworld. Main part: The companions (brothers) come to a well (pit, cave) & lower the hero (youngest brother) into it. The hero overcomes monsters (dragons, devils) & rescues (the three) princesses (with the princesses’ help, using a weapon, only by his strength, by magic means). (The princesses give him presents.) His treacherous companions pull the princesses up but leave the hero below (cut off the rope, overturn the basket). They force the maidens to name them as their rescuers. The hero returns to the upper world with the help of a spirit, which gives him the ability to fly (a bird to whom he has to feed his own flesh; he ascends on a climbing plant which he himself planted, etc.). The princesses delay their wedding (for a year). On the wedding day, the hero comes to the castle & is imprisoned. But the truth comes to light (the hero is recognized by the princesses when he shows the presents), & the impostors are punished (banished, killed). The hero marries the youngest princess & becomes king. In some variants, the hero has to go to much deeper regions of the underworld before he is able to come back to the upper world, because he mistakenly mounted a black animal (ram, sheep, goat, horse, lion, snake) instead of a white one. Finally the white animal carries him up again.
386
301D*Princess's RingTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesWhen she goes for a walk, a princess (daughter of a tsar) disappears. Her father promises her to whoever finds & rescues her. A soldier takes a ship & goes out to search for the princess. On a lonely island he meets a dragon (giant, devil), makes him drunk with wine, cuts off his head & takes away his keys. He finds the princess & takes her to the ship. Just when they are about to sail, the princess asks for a ring she forgot, & the soldier goes back to get it. Meanwhile the ship sails away & the treacherous captain forces the princess to name him as her rescuer. The soldier takes service with robbers (devils, magician) & finds magic objects in a forbidden room of their house (castle) (gets them as payment). With the help of these objects he gets back home. On her wedding day with the captain, the princess recognizes the soldier by her ring, tells her father the truth, & marries the soldier.
387
302-Ogre's (Devil's) Heart in the EggTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesBecause he helped some animals to divide a meal in a fair manner, a youth is rewarded with the ability to trans-form himself into their shapes (they promise their help because he spared or nourished them). He goes to rescue a princess who has been abducted by an ogre (giant, dragon, devil) (to rescue his wife who has been abducted by a supernatural enemy. As an eagle, the youth comes to the ogre’s castle, as an ant into the princess’s chamber. He learns from the princess that the ogre cannot be defeated because his heart (power of life, soul) is hidden outside of his body. The princess elicits the hiding place from the ogre: His heart lies – enclosed in various animals – in an egg (little box). The youth follows the princess’s instructions, finds the ogre’s soul, & destroys it (the grateful animals do so for him). The ogre dies, & the youth marries the princess.
388
302BLife Dependent on a SwordTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA childless couple magically conceive a son. An old man (his father, God) gives the son a sword (knife) which he should always carry with him (should not lay it on the ground, not pull out from its sheath). Or: The youngest of three brothers inherits a horse, clothes, & a sabre from his father, & goes out for adventure, accompanied by some companions (blood-brothers) with magic powers. With the aid of his sword he defeats the king’s army & kills a dragon(s). His companions marry the rescued women. The youth himself marries a woman of extraordinary beauty. When the king catches a sight of her picture or of a curl (ring, slipper) which she lost in the sea (river), he falls in love with her & sends out an old woman (witch) to capture her. By a trick the old woman enters the youth’s house, learns the se-cret of the sword, & throws it into the sea. Deprived of his strength, the youth dies, & his wife is taken to the king. Through a life token, the youth’s friends discover what has happened, recover the sword, restore it to its original condition, & resuscitate the youth. The youth creeps into the king’s castle, hides in the room of his wife, kills the king (the old woman), & becomes king himself.
389
302C*The Magic HorseTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesAt the wish of the dead king, his youngest son permits his three sisters to marry the first suitors who come for them. Visiting his brothers-in-law, he learns that they are the masters of the three kingdoms of animals. The prince wins a wife who forbids him to enter a certain room. He disregards her prohibition & revives a dragon (demon) who is impaled on a wall (contained in a hoop). The dragon frees himself & abducts the prince’s wife. The prince searches for her & three times tries to flee with her. Riding on his magic horse, the dragon overtakes the two but does not kill the prince, because he promised to spare his life three times; the fourth time, he cuts him up. Signals of distress tell the brothers-in-law that the prince is in danger, & they come & resuscitate him. He goes back to the dragon, asks his wife to find out where the magic horse came from, & learns that a certain witch owns one. On his way to the witch, the prince wins the gratitude of three animals which help him to tend the witch’s three horses (daughters) that live in the earth, the clouds, & the sea. In payment, the prince chooses a scabby foal which turns into a magic horse (with extra legs), & he & his wife flee on his back. The magic horse is the brother of the dragon’s horse, & it compels the latter to throw off its rider, the dragon. The dragon is killed, & the prince returns home together with his wife.
390
303-The Twins or Blood-BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesAfter having eaten a magic fish (apple, water), a woman gives birth to twins. Grateful animals accompany the grown-up brothers, or animals give them one or more of their young ones because the brothers did not kill them. (The brothers are given unusual animals; they win them or bring them up; in some variants, the animals are born at the same time as the brothers. Together with his animals, one of the brothers sets out. When the brothers separate, they agree upon a life token that gives a warning when one of them is in mortal danger & needs help: Water will become cloudy, a plant or a tree dry up, a knife stuck in a tree will grow rusty, etc.. The first brother frees a princess (three prin-cesses) from a dragon (trolls), unmasks an impostor (“Red Knight”) who pretended to be the princess’s rescuer, & marries the princess. Against a warning, the hero follows a light (is tempted by an animal). He falls into the power of a witch & is turned to stone. His twin brother is warned by the life token & sets forth in quest of him. The princess mistakes him for her husband, as the two brothers are very much alike. At night the brother puts a naked sword in the bed between himself & his sister-in-law. Then he finds the witch, makes her remove the spell from his brother, & kills her. The first brother learns that the second has slept with his wife & kills him out of jealousy. Later on, when he asks his wife why she had put the sword in the bed, he realizes that his brother was innocent. The brother is resuscitated by magic means (water of life). In some variants, a youth saves the life of a raven (crane, eagle). As a reward he obtains magic objects. The youth defeats a sea monster, delivers three princesses, & marries the youngest of them.
391
303ABrothers Seek Sisters as WivesTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA number of brothers (usually six, twelve or one hundred) set out to find a number of sisters as wives for themselves & their youngest brother who remained home. On the way an old man (giant, troll) transforms the brothers & their brides into stone & takes the youngest bride for himself. The youngest brother goes to look for his lost brothers & comes to the old man’s house. Here he finds the youngest bride who tells him that the heart (life) of the old man is enclosed in a bird. With the help of grateful animals which he had fed on his way, the youngest brother catches the bird & kills it, thus killing the old man (he rescues his brothers & the brides by performing different tasks). Brothers & brides are restored to life. In some variants, the brothers marry the daughters of a witch. During the night in bed the brothers exchange their places with those of their wives. The witch kills her own daughters.
392
304-Dangerous Night-WatchTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesTogether with his brothers (companions), a youth (youngest of three brothers, hunter, prince, soldier, etc.) has various hunting adventures, or he defeats dragons (wild animals, monsters) during one (three) night-watch(es) in the forest (at his father’s grave). While the youth fights, his fire (light) goes out (the youth loses his way, is tempted away by a bird). He (stops time and) meets giants (robbers, supernatural beings) whom he impresses by shooting tricks or by his extraordinary physical strength. The giants go to plunder a castle (town) or to carry off a princess, & take the youth with them. The youth shoots a watchdog (rooster), enters the castle first, calls the giants and, as they enter, he cuts off their heads one at a time. Often he cuts off their tongues (heads, other parts of the body) which he takes away as trophies. In the castle, the youth comes to a room where a princess lies sleeping. He looks at her (falls in love, kisses her, rapes her) and, before leaving, takes a souvenir (jewelry, handkerchief, shoes, etc.) which later becomes a token. Then he returns with a burning log (lets time resume) & kindles the fire again. An impostor pretends that he had killed the giants & claims the (pregnant) princess for his wife. The princess refuses to marry him. She sets up (is made to live in) an inn where guests need not pay anything if they tell a tale (life-history, news). (Accompanied by his brothers & mother,) the youth stops at this inn, proves his identity by means of his tale & the tokens, & marries the princess. The impostor is punished.
393
305-Dragon's Heart-Blood as RemedyTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A king falls ill & learns that he can only be cured by the milk & blood of a dragon’s heart. He promises his oldest daughter to whoever is able to get the remedy, & his youngest daughter to whoever assists. A nobleman & a farmer boy set out and, with the help of an old woman, arrive at the dragon’s forest. The farmer boy kills the dragon, squeezes milk & blood out of its heart, & hides them. Threatening to kill him, the nobleman takes the dragon’s heart, presents it to the king & wins the eldest daughter & the kingdom. The farmer boy & the youngest daughter are sent to live in the goose house. Because there were neither milk nor blood in the dragon’s heart, the nobleman, the farmer boy, & the old woman are questioned. Truth comes to light, & the kingdom goes to the farmer boy. (2) During his travels, a workman learns that the sick king can only be cured by a dragon’s liver. He sees the dragon’s vulnerable spot in a dream. He kills the dragon & boasts of his victory in an inn. The host steals the man’s knapsack which, however, contains only a stone. The workman arrives at the king’s court prior to the host, cures the king, & wins the princess as his wife. The thievish host is hanged. (3) A father orders his son to bring him the devil’s tongue to cure his illness, but the son cannot find the devil. An old man advises him to knock with a stick on a certain trunk. A horse appears & carries him to the devil. The horse gives the son a piece of his hoof which he can use to call it whenever he is in danger. The son challenges the devil, but, during the fight, the devil thrusts him into the earth up to his waist. With the help of the horse, the son defeats the devil, brings the devil’s tongue to his father, & thus cures him. (4) While hunting, a prince is bewitched & loses his voice. A young woman appears in his dream & tells him about a remedy: a medicine consisting of dragons’ eyes, a dragon’s heart & other ingredients, which must be prepared in a certain manner. In return the young woman demands that the prince marry her. After the prince agrees, a youth appears & produces the medicine in the prescribed way. The cure is successful, & the prince marries the young woman.
394
306-The Danced-out ShoesTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesEvery day, a princess(es) wears out a pair of shoes. Her father wants to know why & offers the princess (one of the princesses) to whoever discovers the secret. Anyone who fails will lose his head. A youth (soldier, Gypsy, tailor, shepherd, farmer, etc.) acquires a magic object (e.g. shoes, cap, overcoat, stick) which makes him invisible. He refuses a narcotic drink & does not fall asleep. After making himself invisible, the youth accompanies the princess on a magical underground journey. In the under-world he watches the princess wear out her shoes by dancing with the devil (dragon, other supernatural beings). The next morning the youth tells the king what happened & corroborates his tale by tokens (e.g. twigs, apples, ring, piece of the princess’s garment) from the underworld. He marries the princess & becomes king. Mainly in Indian variants, a prince accompanies his wife to the otherworld where she has to dance each night before a divinity. He frees her.
395
307-The Princess in the CoffinTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesAfter a hasty wish (curse), a diabolic (black, mute) daughter is born to a childless couple (king & queen). The daughter demands that when she dies, there should be a night-watch at her coffin in the church (graveyard) (someone should watch over her for three nights in or-der to save her). The dead girl rises every night from the coffin & swallows the man on guard. A soldier (boy) learns from an old man what he must do to free the girl from the witchcraft. During the first two nights, he hides from the dead girl. During the third night, when the girl leaves the coffin, the soldier lies down in it, refuses to let her in, & forces her (by means of a rusty sword) to say a Paternoster (sing a hymn at the altar). As she says the prayer, the rooster crows & the girl is disenchanted. The guards are revived & the girl marries her rescuer. (The soldier tears his bride into two parts & shakes out the bad spirit in the form of reptiles.) Various other magic or religious means can be used to save the princess.
396
310-Maiden in the TowerTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA (pregnant) woman steals herbs (fruits) from the garden of a witch (sorceress) & is forced to promise her unborn child to the witch. The woman bears a girl, & after a certain time the witch comes for the daughter (often called Petrosinella, Rapunzel, etc. ac-cording to the name of the stolen plant). The witch locks her up in a tower. Whenever the witch wants to visit her, she enters by climbing on the girl’s long (golden) hair as on a ladder. A prince discovers the girl in the tower because of her hair shining in the sun & falls in love with her. The girl gives the witch a sleeping-draught. The prince climbs up on the girl’s hair & they have a love affair. The witch finds out about the nocturnal visits of the prince. She wants to prevent further visits, but accidentally discloses that the lovers could flee by transforming themselves with the help of three oak galls. The girl overhears the conversation & explains the magic oak galls to the prince. They flee together & are pursued by the witch. They escape & the witch is killed. The prince marries the girl.
397
311-Rescue by the SisterTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesTwo sisters, one after the other, fall into power of a demonic suitor (cannibal, dragon, magician, devil) & are taken into his (subterranean) castle. There the sisters open a forbidden room full of dead bodies, in the course of which the key (a magic egg, apple) becomes bloody, or they refuse to eat human flesh. The demon kills them for their disobedience. Using a trick, the third (youngest) sister escapes from the same fate. She finds her sisters & resuscitates them by putting their bones together. She hides them beneath some gold in baskets (bags) & persuades the demon to carry the baskets home without looking into them. The youngest sister pretends to marry the demon & leaves a skull (straw dummy) dressed as a bride to deceive him. Unwittingly the demon carries this sister home in the third basket. Or she smears herself with honey & feathers & escapes as a “strange bird”. The demon is burned in his own house or is killed in another way.
398
311B*The Singing BagTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA Gypsy (old man) puts the niece of an old washer-woman (only daughter of an old couple) into a bag & carries her off. The Gypsy goes begging from door to door & exhibits his “singing bag”: He gives the bag a pinch, threatens to beat it with his stick, & orders it to sing. Thereupon the girl in the bag starts singing her tale: I left my rosary on a stone by the river when I was washing. When I wanted to get it, a Gypsy put me in his bag & carried me off. (I am the only daughter of an old couple. An old man carried me off when I was gathering berries in the forest.) One day the Gypsy arrives at the old washerwoman’s house. The woman recognizes her niece, invites the Gypsy into his house, & entertains him until he gets drunk. When he is sleeping, she rescues the girl from the bag and, in her place, puts two cats (horse-dung). When the Gypsy exhibits his singing bag the next time, the cats mew. The Gypsy opens the bag & is scratched or bitten.
399
312-Maiden-KillerTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesAn odd-looking rich man (e.g. with a blue beard) takes his bride to his splendid castle. She is forbidden to open a certain room, but she disobeys & finds it full of the dead bodies of her prede-cessors. The husband wants to kill her for her disobedience, but she is able to delay the punishment (three times). She (her sister) calls their brother (three brothers) band (sometimes with help from a dog or other animal) & rescues his sister (s) who kills the husband.
400
312AThe Rescued GirlTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA man gives his daughter in marriage to a tiger (monkey, supernatural being) because he made a rash vow (as a payment for the tiger’s help, or because the tiger threatened him). The tiger eats the girl & demands her sister (s), whom he also eats. The youngest sister (brother) kills the tiger (the girl escapes & the tiger is lured back to the village & killed).
401
312CThe Rescued BrideTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural Adversaries(A man promises his daughter to the devil.) The girl marries the devil. (Or: A youth curses his sister: The devil may take her. This happens.) The brother searches for his sister, finds her & rescues her (frequently with the help of his dogs).
402
312DRescue by the BrotherTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA dragon (devil) carries off a girl (three girls) & kills her brothers when they try to rescue her. After a magic conception (often by swallowing a pea), the mother of the siblings gives birth to a strong son. This son kills the dragon, rescues his sister, & resuscitates his brothers. The envious brothers plan to kill the youngest. But because of his strength he is able to free himself & to punish his brothers.
403
313-The Magic FlightTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis type combines various introductory episodes with the two main parts of the “Magic Flight” & the “Forgotten Fian-cée”. Introductory episodes: (1) After a war between birds & quadrupeds, a wounded eagle is cared for by a man. The eagle (its relatives) gives the man a box which he must not open before he arrives at home. The man disobeys & a castle appears. An giant helps the man close the box and, in return, is promised the man’s unborn son. In some variants, a boy is promised to a demon, giant, or devil or the boy promises himself to the demon. Threat-ening him with death, the demon (giant, devil) assigns the youth (often three) impossible tasks (e.g. building a castle in one night, bailing out a pond with a sieve, felling a forest using an axe of glass, capturing a magic horse which he performs with the help of the demon’s daughter. Before the youth can marry the daughter, he must identify her in a group of women (her sisters) who look just like her. (2) A youth watches girls (transformed swans) bathing in a lake & steals the swan dress of one of them. The girl agrees to marry the youth & takes him to her father’s house. (3) A king suffering from leprosy (scabs) captures a prince & feeds him with sweets for forty days, in the hope that the prince’s blood will cure his sickness. The princess falls in love with the foreign youth. Main parts:Magic Flight. The daughter of the demon (king) uses her magical power to flee together with the youth. She leaves magic speaking objects (spittle, blood) behind to deceive her father. Never-theless the flight is discovered & the father follows them. In order to escape, the girl transforms herself & her fiancé into various things or persons (e.g. into rose & thornbush, church & priest, lake & duck), or she throws magic objects (comb, brush, mirror, etc.) which become obstacles in the way of the pursuer. After the third transformation, the pursuer has to give up (dies). In some variants of the Magic Flight two children (brother & sister) flee from a witch (demon, dragon, ogre, witch, wolf, bad step-mother). The youth goes to visit his home & leaves his bride behind. At home he breaks a taboo: Disobeying the bride’s warning, he kisses someone (eats something) & thus forgets his experiences. When the youth is about to marry another woman, the forgotten fiancée reawakens his memory by performing magic actions (paralyses three lovers in embarrassing positions, magically stops the wedding carriage of the new bride, brings a couple of birds who remind the youth of her help, or buys a place for three nights in the bridal bed from her husband’s new bride, & in the third night successfully reawakens his memory . The youth marries the true bride.
404
313E*The Sister's FlightTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA brother wants to marry his sister. She flees & arrives in the underworld at the house of a witch. There she meets the witch’s daughter who resembles her. Both girls escape from the sorceress by a magic flight, throwing objects behind them. The girls change into birds, & the brother is not able to distinguish them. He pretends he is going to kill himself. The sister betrays herself by an involuntary cry. The brother marries the sorceress’s daughter.
405
314-GoldenerTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductory episodes: (1) A boy has been promised (often in return for magic conception) to a demon (devil, giant), or he voluntarily becomes a servant in a demon’s house. The demon orders him to care for two (groups of) animals, to feed the one & to neglect the other. The boy does not follow these instructions & thus makes friends with the abused animal (magic horse).
