Against the prohibition of the demon, he enters a certain chamber. As a mark of disobedi-ence, his hair turns gold. The boy & the magic horse escape from the demon by a magic flight. (2) A boy (usually the son of a ruler) & a magic foal are close friends . The mother (stepmother) wants to kill the boy. The magic foal warns the boy of her secret murderous attempts. At last the mother demands that the boy or the foal be killed. The boy pretends to agree but asks his father to be allowed to ride the foal one last time. During this ride the foal flies away together with the boy (3) In return for his magic conception, a boy is promised to a demon. On the way to the demon’s house, the boy is forewarned (given instructions for how to kill the demon or to flee). In the rooms of the demon’s house, the boy finds prisoners or corpses (and his hair turns to gold). The boy kills the demon & flees. Main part: The youth covers his golden hair, pretending to be a scaldhead, & takes service in the king’s court as a gardener. (He says nothing except, “I don’t know”.) But the youngest princess sees him in his true form (as a golden-haired knight who destroys & restores the garden three times). She falls in love with Goldener & chooses him as her husband by throwing a golden apple to him. They marry but the angry king banishes the couple to a shabby lodging. The king demands the help of his sons-in-law. Goldener has only a poor kit & is mocked. With the help of his magic horse he achieves various heroic deeds: He obtains the magic remedy (e.g. milk of a bird, water of life) for the king who had grown blind, kills a dragon, defeats a foreign army three times in disguise. He is wounded & is bandaged by the king. Three times he withdraws & is mocked as a fool. Goldener’s identity is revealed (e.g. by wounds, brands) & his true status is recognized. The horse asks to be decapitated & becomes a prince (princess, other person).
406
314AThe Shepherd & the Three GiantsTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA poor youth (orphan, fool, young est of three brothers) sets out with his only heirloom (e.g. rusty sabre ) or with magic objects (stick, flute, etc.) which grateful old people gave him. He becomes the king’s shepherd. The youth is allowed to pasture his livestock on the king’s land but not on the neighboring territory which belongs to three giants (because no one has ever returned from there). The youth disobeys and, with the help of his magic objects (strength), overcomes the three giants one after the other (sometimes their mother, too). In the giants’ lodging the youth finds a magic horse & armour of three different metals (magic weapons, immeasurable wealth, helpful spirits, enchanted persons). The king promises his daughter to whoever rescues her from a (three) dragon(s), wins a tournament, or helps him in battle. The youth, wearing his shining armour & riding his magic horse, succeeds three times. He with-draws & hides until the princess recognizes him as the true champion. The youth marries the princess & becomes king
407
314A*Animal as Helper in the FlightTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A bull (horse, moose, ox, bear, wolf, birds) helps children (an-other person) to escape from their pursuer (devil, witch, robbers). (2) The devil (white wolf) wants to abduct (marry) a princess (girl). A goat puts a straw sheaf in the place of the princess, asks the real princess to climb in a cart, covers her with hay, & tells the devil whom he meets on the way that the princess is at home. The devil grabs the sheaf & takes it to hell. The goat brings the girl home.
408
315-The Faithless SisterTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesBrother & sister leave home (are driven out). The brother kills a number of robbers (devils, giants, dragons) but does not realize that the last one is merely wounded. The sister helps the wounded robber to recover, & he becomes her lover. In order to get rid of the brother, she pretends to be ill & sends him out to get her the milk (liver) of dangerous animals. The brother spares the animals & they follow him (give him a whistle). After the first attempt fails, the sister binds her brother with a silk thread, or she sends him to a magic mill where the animals are kept. When the couple is about to kill the brother, he whistles for the animals. They (break out from the mill and) tear the robber to pieces. The faithless sister is imprisoned (has to repent & to fill a barrel with her tears). The brother takes to the road, rescues a princess from a dragon, & marries her. The sister is brought to the court. She tries to take revenge on her brother by putting a (poisoned) bone into his bed. The brother dies. The animals lick the bone out of his body & he revives. The sister is punished by death.
409
315AThe Cannibal SisterTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA woman (queen) who has only sons gives birth to a daughter. The girl first devours the animals, then her brothers & parents, & finally the inhabitants of the village (city). Only one brother escapes. (Or: At a king’s court every night someone devours horses. The elder princes who keep watch fail, but the youngest shoots the monster. He recognizes his baby sister as the cannibal because one of her fingers has been shot off. The youth is driven away [as a liar] or flees [sometimes together with his mother or elder sister].) The youth marries, gives his wife a life token, leaves his dogs (young lions, panther) behind, & returns home. He finds everything devastated. His sister devours his horse & threatens to devour him, too. While she is sharpening her teeth, the youth must play an instrument to prove he is still there. A mouse takes his place & he flees. The youth escapes & climbs three trees in succession which his sister gnaws down. Warned by the life token, his dogs come to save him & kill the cannibal sister.
410
316-The Nix of the Mill-PondTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA poor fisherman (miller) (unwitting-ly) promises his son to a water nix, who makes the fisherman wealthy. The parents keep the child away from the water. When the appointed time comes, the son learns about his father’s promise & flees. On the way the youth divides the carcass of an animal among a lion, a falcon, & an ant (other animals) by taking the animals’ characteristics into consideration. In return he receives from the grateful animals the power to transform himself into their shapes. Using this power he wins a princess as his wife. After winning a battle (while hunting) the youth comes near the water & is seized & pulled down (swallowed) by the water nix. By offering precious objects (three golden apples), his wife tempts the nix to the surface. In exchange for these objects the water nix exhibits her husband: first up to his head, then up to his waist. When the water nix exhibits the husband’s whole body, he changes into a bird & escapes.
411
317-The Tree That Grows uo tp the SkyTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesIn a king’s yard a tree grows up to the sky. A dragon (giant) living in the tree carries off the princess. The king promises her as a wife to whoever can bring her back. In some variants, the king promises his daughter to whoever brings him healing fruits from the tree. After noble canditates have failed, a young swineherd succeeds in climbing the tree wearing iron boots. In the upper world the youth guards the dragon’s magic horse which tells him (he asks the princess to find out) where the dragon’s power is hidden. The youth kills the dragon, returns to earth together with the princess, & marries her. In some variants, in the upper world the youth watches over the magic horses of a fairy (Tündér Ilona) who gives him clothes of copper, silver, & gold. The fairy falls in love & marries the youth. The youth enters a forbidden chamber & frees a dragon which carries off the fairy.
412
318-The Faithless WifeTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesIntroduction: Two brothers live together. The younger works for the elder, who is married. The wife attempts to seduce the younger brother but he refuses her. She complains to her husband that her brother-in-law attacked her. The youth flees from his angry brother.In some variants, this part continues as follows: The fugitive is caught & castrated. After this he lives in a foreign city. A princess falls in love with him & marries him in spite of his mutilation. When the king learns of his son-in-law’s defect, the latter has to flee. He is cured by a supernatural being & is able to return to his wife. Main part: A youth acquires magic objects, among them a magic gift (rusty sword, shirt that imparts strength) from a serpent which he rescued (by theft, by other means). Using these objects, he helps a king to be victorious and, in return, marries a princess. The princess has a lover. She persuades her husband to give her the magic objects (exchanges them). The husband is killed and, as he had requested, his dismembered body is loaded on his horse & carried to the serpent’s castle. The dead youth is resuscitated (by the serpent) & given the power of self-transformation. As a horse with a golden mane he is sold to the king. The princess recognizes the horse as her former husband & orders that it be killed. (On his advice) a maidservant catches drops of its blood which turn into a tree with golden apples. The princess recognizes the tree as her former husband, & orders that it be felled. (On his advice) the maidservant throws a chip into a pond, where it turns into a golden drake. The lover, leaving the sword & shirt behind, tries to catch the drake. The drake becomes a man & uses his magic power to kill his rival & his treacherous wife. He marries the maidservant
413
321-Eyes Recovered from WitchTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA youth takes service as a herdsman with a blind man (couple) whose eyes have been stolen by one or more dragon(s) (giant, witch, fairy). The youth is warned not to take his flock to pasture beyond a certain point, but he disobeys. He meets a dragon & defeats it or tricks it. He retrieves the stolen eyes or receives a magic remedy which enables him to cure the blind man
414
322*Magnetic Mountain Draws Everything to ItTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA king’s ship is drawn to a magnetic mountain & smashed to pieces, & the king is washed ashore unconscious. Advised in a dream, the king finds a copper bow with three lead arrows. As instructed he climbs the mountain without looking back or speaking & shoots a copper rider off a copper horse in a temple with copper pillars. The rider falls into the sea, & the king buries the horse. The magnetic mountain begins to sink. A copper man arrives in a copper boat & rescues the king at the last mo-ment.In some variants, the rescuer is a giant bird.
415
325-The Magician & his PupilTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA father apprentices his son to a magician. In order for the son to be released at the end of the apprenticeship, the father has to recognize him. The youth secretly learns how to practice magic & flees, or his father identifies him among a flock of identical doves (other birds) with the help of tokens which the son (an old man) had given to him. The son is released. The father sells the youth successively as a greyhound, an ox, & a horse, but the son tells him not to sell the things that bind them (leash, yoke, bridle). Thus father & son become wealthy. But at last the youth as a horse returns to the magi cian’s in-fluence because, contrary to instructions, the father let the magician take the bridle. So the youth loses his power & is tormented by the magician. Finally the youth succeeds in removing the bridle. He conquers the magician in a transformation combat (they change themselves into hare, fish, bird, etc.) & escapes. At last, transformed into a ring (apple, etc.), he falls into a princess’s lap. When the magician asks for the ring, the princess throws it away & grains of corn fall on the ground. The magician as a rooster is about to eat the corn, but the youth becomes a fox & bites off the rooster’s head. He marries the princess
416
325*Sorcerer's ApprenticeTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA sorcerer’s apprentice who reads a verse from a forbidden book calls up a spirit, but cannot make him go away. When the sorcerer reads the verse backwards, the spirit disappears.
417
325**Sorcerer PunishedTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA sorcerer who committed evil deeds (e.g. killed a farmer’s sheep) is punished by another sorcerer (e.g. he is bewitched & grows a tail).
418
326-The Youth Who Wanted to Learn What Fear IsTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA youth (fool) who does not know what fear is goes to find it. He tries various frightening experiences without becoming afraid: He is shaved by a barber-ghost, spends the night under a gallows or in a haunted castle, plays with dead persons (bowling, cards), etc. Through his fearless behavior he disenchants a castle (wins a treasure, a promised princess). The youth finally learns what fear is when cold water is thrown on him, fishes are put into his bed while he is asleep, birds fly into his face, his cut-off head is put on backwards, etc. Sometimes sexual: he finds a woman in his bed
419
326A*Soul Released from TormentTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA poor soldier spends a night in a haunted house to earn a reward. He is not afraid of dragging chains, cries, falling limbs, etc. The soldier releases a restless spirit from punishment by his fearless behavior (by giving its ill-gotten gains to charity). He discovers a treasure (and may keep part of it for himself).
420
326B*The Youth & the CorpseTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA fearless youth carries a corpse (several corpses), frightens some robbers by pretending to eat it, & takes away their booty. Using the corpse, he overpowers evil spirits, frees a princess, & marries her.
421
327-The Children & the OgreTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis type refers to a cycle of related tales. It combines episodes from types 327A, 327B, & 327C.
422
327AHansel & GretelTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA (poor) father (persuaded by the stepmother) abandons his children (a boy & a girl) in the forest. Twice the children find their way back home, following scattered pebbles. On the third night, birds eat the scattered peas (bread-crumbs). The children come upon a gingerbread house which belongs to a witch (ogress). She takes them into her house. The boy is fattened, while the girl must do housework. The witch asks the boy to show his finger in order to test how fat he is, but he shows her a bone (stick). When the witch wants to cook the boy, the sister deceives her by feigning ignorance & pushes her into the oven. (The witch’s son finds out that his mother has been killed & pursues the children.) The children escape, carrying the witch’s treasure with them. Birds & beasts (angels) help them across water. They return home.
423
327BThe Brothers & the OgreTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesSeven (three, twelve, thirty) brothers come to an ogre’s house, where they are given night lodging. The ogre intends to cut off the brothers’s heads. In order to recognize his own daughters, the ogre gives them nightcaps (head-scarves). One brother (often the youngest , Thumbling) detects the plan, & all brothers put on the nightcaps of the ogre’s daughters (exchange their caps for the daughters’ head-scarves, change sleeping-places with the daughters). In the night, the ogre cuts off his own daughters’ heads by mistake. The brothers escape.
424
327CThe Devil (Witch) Carries the Hero Home in a SackTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA witch (ogre) entices a boy (conceived by magic, Thumbling) into her bag & carries him away (from his home). By deceiving the witch (putting stones, thorns, mud, etc. in his place), the boy is able to escape twice from the bag. The third time, the witch carries him to her home. He is to be killed by the witch’s daughter. The boy tricks the daughter (by making her show him how he should prepare to be killed), throws her into a pot (burns her in the oven), & serves her as a meal to her family. He taunts the witch, kills her, & returns home (sometimes with the witch’s treasure)
425
327DThe KiddelkaddelkarTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA boy & a girl lose their way in a forest & come to the house of an ogre. The wife protects the children, but the ogre discovers them & intends to hang them. The girl persuades the ogre to show them how it is done. Hanging himself, the ogre begs to be released & promises the children his “kiddelkaddel kar”, a magic cart pulled by (golden) bucks, & much treasure. The children flee & on the way ask three men not to reveal their route. The third man is so much frightened by the ogre that he betrays the children, who hide in a cave. The ogre, not suspecting the children’s presence, lies down to sleep & blocks the way out. The children kill him but cannot leave the cave for three nights until a giant bird eats the ogre’s corpse. Then they return to their parents with the ogre’s treasure.
426
327FWitch & the Fisher BoyTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesBy imitating the words & voice of his mother who brings him food to the shore each day, a witch tries to catch a fisher boy. She succeeds after she has her tongue made thin by a smith, & carries the boy to her home. When the witch’s daughter tries to bake the boy, he pushes her into the oven. The boy hides in a tree & tells the witch that she has eaten her own daughter (witch finds the daughter’s ring or hair). He is discovered. The witch fells the tree, but at the last moment birds rescue the boy (he makes wings for himself), & he flies home (the witch is trampled by animals, or she bursts while trying to drink the boy’s image reflected in the water).
427
327GBrothers at the Witch's HouseTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA witch (devil) catches three brothers – one of them a fool – & fattens them. Her youngest daughter is to roast one of them. The fool pretends he does not know how to lie on the bread paddle & roasts the daughter, whom the old witch eats unwittingly. The same happens to the other two daughters. Then the fool kills the old witch & the three brothers make their way home carrying the witch’s corpse. They climb a tree under which they see robbers. The fool drops the witch’s corpse, the rob bers flee, & the brothers take all their booty.
428
328-Boy Steals the Ogre's TreasureTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesIntroduction (sometimes missing): Three (twelve, thirteen, thirty, etc.) brothers arrive at the house of an ogre (devil). He would kill them in the night, but the smart young est brother saves them by exchanging their caps with those of the ogre’s daughters. The brothers take service at the king’s court. Main part: The jealous brothers claim that the youngest can steal the ogre’s treasures: magic horse, bedspread, carpet, parrot (lamp, sword, silver or golden poultry, musical instruments, etc.). Using tricks the youth gets these objects. At last the brothers claim that the youngest can kidnap the ogre himself. In disguise the youth tells the ogre that the thief died & persuades him to lie down in the coffin to measure it. The youth nails up the coffin, traps the ogre, & is given a princess as his wife. In some variants, the youth sets out to steal from the ogre in order to get revenge for former ill-treatment or to help a friendly king. In some variants, mainly from northern & north-western Europe & the Americas, the protagonist is female.
429
328*Three Giants with One EyeTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesTwo brothers lose their way in a forest (a son leaves his parents’ house & takes a rest while walking through a forest). They are threatened by three giants (trolls) who share only one eye which they put by turns into their foreheads. The brothers steal the giants’ eye & give it back in exchange for a rich reward of gold & silver (magic gifts).
430
328AJack & the BeanstalkTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA poor boy named Jack trades his cow for some beans (his mother finds a bean while sweeping the house). One of the beans grows into a giant beanstalk, which Jack climbs to an upper world where he finds the house of a giant. The giant’s wife gives him food & hides him when her husband comes home. The giant smells human flesh but his wife tells him he is mistaken. The giant eats dinner, counts his money, & then falls asleep. Jack steals the money & runs home down the beanstalk. He makes two more trips, stealing the giant’s hen that lays golden eggs & his self-playing harp. The third time, the harp cries out & awakens the giant, who runs after Jack. Jack reaches the bottom of the beanstalk & chops it down. The giant falls to his death, & Jack & his mother have plenty of money.
431
328A*Three Brothers Steal Back Sun, Moon, & StarsTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThree brothers go out to retrieve the sun, the moon, & the stars which were stolen by three multi-headed dragons (devils). One of the brothers (often the son of a she-dog) defeats the dragons & releases the celestial lights.
432
329-Hiding from the PrincessTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA princess promises to marry whoever can hide himself so well that she cannot find him. Those who fail are beheaded (heads are displayed on stakes). A (poor) youth (youngest of three brothers) undertakes the task Because he had helped some animals (an old man), a fish hides him in his belly, an eagle behind the clouds (the sun), & a fox under the earth. The princess finds him with her magic mirror (magic book) or her perfect sight. The princess gives the youth a fourth trial: He hides behind the magic mirror (under the princess’s seat) or transforms himself (is transformed) & sits as a louse (sticks as a rose) in her hair, etc. The princess cannot find him, so she grants his superiority & marries him.
433
330-The Smith & the DevilTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA smith, who because of poverty (other reasons) sold his soul to the devil (death), gives shelter to Christ & St. Peter during their visit on earth. In reward, three of his wishes shall be fulfilled. St. Peter warns him to wish for a place in paradise, but the smith wants a tree & a bench (chair) to which people stick & a knapsack that draws people into it (a pack of cards with which he shall al-ways win, etc.). When the devil (death) is about to carry the smith away, he sticks to the bench & the tree & has to give the smith more time to live (terminate the contract), or no one would be able to die At last the devil is put into the sack & beaten up (on the anvil). The smith, tired of life, cannot go either to heaven or to hell. He tricks St. Peter by pushing his knapsack into heaven, where it pulls him in (throws his cards inside the gate of heaven & is permitted inside to pick them up).In some variants the trickster-protagonist is an allegorical figure (e.g. Misery, Envy, Poverty) who traps the devil in a tree until the devil promises him immortality. Then he sets the devil free.
434
331-The Spirit in the BottleTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA man (son of a woodcutter, smith, fisher-man, soldier) frees an evil spirit from a vessel (bottle) out of curiosity (because he was asked by the spirit). The spirit (which stretches out to an enormous height,) wants to take revenge for being locked for so long, & threatens to kill his rescuer. The man tricks the spirit: He pretends he does not believe that the spirit could grow small again & thus induces him to go back into the vessel. The man stoppers the bottle & the spirit is trapped.In some variants, he is released again in return for a gift (wonder-ful remedy, magic power.
435
332-Godfather DeathTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA poor man with many children wants a (just) godfather for his new-born son. He refuses God (saint, devil) & chooses death (angel of death, plague) because he treats everyone alike. As a gift the father (son) receives the magic power of forecasting recovery or death, depending on whether death stands at the head or the foot of the sick person’s bed. Thus the man becomes a famous doctor & grows wealthy. The doctor betrays death (several times): When promised wealth (the princess), the doctor turns the bed & thus saves the life of a person who was supposed to die (in the doctor’s dying hour, death grants him time to say a last Paternoster, but the doctor does not finish the prayer. Death tricks the doctor into finishing the prayer.) In some variants, death shows the man his life-light in the under-world & suddenly extinguishes it. Or the man attempts to lengthen his life by various means (usually without success).
436
332C*Immortality Won through Betrayal of DeathTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis tale exists in two different forms: (1) An old soldier becomes the doorkeeper for heaven. Death asks him several times whom he should take next. God wants death to take the old people (then people in the middle of their life, then young people in succession). However, the doorkeeper wants to save his parents (wife, children), so he tells death instead to fell firs (beech-trees, oaks). God discovers this deception & shows death whom he should take next. Thus the soldier & his relatives are reunited in heaven. (In some variants, the soldier is banished to hell. Here he delivers a number of souls from purgatory & is chased away. (2) A prince wants to gain immortality. He travels through three different kingdoms, in which the rulers have to perform tasks which must be finished within 600 (800, 1000) years (pulling out a tree, carrying off a mountain, wearing out thousands of sewing needles). During this time death has lost his power. Each time the prince is given magic objects & asked to stay, but he travels on. Finally he arrives at the empire of immortality. After a thousand years he goes to look for his parents. The queen of immortality gives him water of life which he uses to resuscitate the deceased rulers of the three kingdoms. The prince, finding no trace of his former home & family, returns. Pursued by death, he reaches the border of the empire of immortality. In a contest with death, the queen of immortality wins the prince & they live together forever.
437
333-Little Red Riding HoodTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA little girl, called “Red Riding Hood” because of her red cap, is sent to her grandmother who lives in the forest & is warned not to leave the path. On the way she meets a wolf. The wolf learns where the girl is going, hurries on ahead, & devours the grandmother (puts her blood in a glass & her flesh in a pot). He puts on her clothes & lies down in her bed. Red Riding Hood arrives at the grandmother’s house. (She has to drink the blood, eat the flesh, & lie down in the bed.) Red Riding Hood doubts whether the wolf is her grandmother & asks him about his odd big ears, eyes, hands, & mouth. Finally the wolf eats Red Riding Hood. A hunter kills the wolf & cuts open his belly. Red Riding Hood & the grandmother are rescued alive. They fill the wolf’s belly with stones; he is drowned or falls to his death. In some variants Red Riding Hood arrives at the grandmother’s house before the wolf. The wolf climbs on the roof to wait until Red Riding Hood leaves. The Grandmother who had boiled sausages asks Red Riding Hood to fill the broth into a big trough in front of the house. Enticed by the smell, the wolf falls from the roof & is drowned in the trough. In an Italian version, a woman who is going to bake cakes sends out her daughter (Caterinella, Caterina, Cattarinetta) to borrow a pan. The lender, an ogre (witch, wolf), asks the girl to bring back some cakes & wine. On her way she eats the cakes, drinks the wine, & replaces them with horse-dung & urine. Angry about the trick, the ogre pursues the girl home & devours her (is not able to get into the house, is tricked out by the girl’s mother).
438
334-Household of the WitchTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA girl (woman) disregards the warning of friendly animals (parts of her body) & visits her godmother (grandmother) who is a cannibal. The girl sees many gruesome things (e.g. fence of bones, barrel full of blood, & her godmother with an animal’s head). When the girl tells her godmother what she has seen she is killed (devoured).
439
335-Death' MessengersTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesDeath promises to warn a certain man before he comes to him, so the man lives happily. When death finally comes to take him, the man accuses him not having kept his promise. Death replies that he warned him with the illnesses & infirmities of old age, & takes the man away.
440
360-Bargain of the Three Brothers & the DevilTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThree traveling journeymen (brothers, friends) conclude an agreement with the devil: They receive a large amount of money (purse which will never be empty) on the condition that they pledge themselves always to say the same words, “we three”, “for gold”, “that was right”. The host of an inn kills a rich merchant & accuses the journey-men. Because of their stereotyped answers they seem to confess the offence. The devil rescues them from the gallows. The host is hanged in their place, & the devil is satisfied to take his soul & leave the journeymen alone.
441
361-Bear-skinTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA poor soldier sells his soul to the devil for an immense amount of money (a purse which will never be empty). The soldier’s soul will be released after he has lived for seven years wit-hout washing or combing himself. The soldier helps a poor man, who agrees to let him marry one of his daughters. The two elder daughters scoff at the dirty man, but the youngest daughter agrees to marry him. The soldier leaves her a token (half of a ring or coin). After seven years the bargain is completed. The devil washes & dresses the soldier, & releases him. He returns to his bride as a rich gentleman & is recognized by the token. The envious elder sisters commit suicide. Thus instead of one soul the devil gets two (sometimes more).
442
361*The Wolf with an Iron HeadTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA wolf with an iron head helps a poor man (shepherd) in distress & demands that he should not marry (threatens to eat the man & is put off until his wedding day). On the wedding day, the wolf appears again, the man flees and, after a number of adventures, finally kills the wolf with help of his dogs.
443
362*The Devil's KindnessTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThe devil helps a poor man with his work (gives a poor man the treasure of a rich couple). A second man (couple ) hangs himself out of envy (grief) & thus the devil receives his payment.
444
363-The Corpse-EaterTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA young woman wants to marry a man with an unusual feature (green beard, golden nose, etc.). A demonic bridegroom with these characteristics appears, & she follows him to his far-away castle. On the way she watches him eating corpses in three churches (graveyards). The bridegroom asks her whether she has seen anything. She says no, even when he appears in the form of her father & brother. Finally, in the form of her mother, he asks her & she confesses. She is devoured (is able to flee at the last moment).
445
365-Dead Bridegroom Carries off His BrideTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA young woman mourns for her bridegroom who did not return from war (brings him back to life by magic). One night he appears, invites her to ride with him, & carries her behind on his horse. Two times he asks her whether she is afraid. She says no because her lover is with her. The third time they arrive at a graveyard. When the bridegroom wants to entice her into an open grave, she realizes that he is dead. He grasps at her & tears her clothing. The bride escapes (is pulled into the grave, danced to death by the dancing dead, or torn to pieces)
446
366-The Man from the GallowsTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man (woman, child) takes the liver (lung, heart, stomach, backside) of a corpse who has been hanged (other dead person). At home the meat is eaten (often without knowing what it is). At night the dead person appears, asks for the stolen part of his body, & punishes the perpetrator (eater) by carrying him away (to hell) or by killing him. (2) A child (adult person) who has lost a leg (arm) wears a gold-en (diamond) one as a substitute. The child dies, & the parents (ser vants, grave-diggers, etc.) take the golden leg. At night the dead child appears, complains about the loss of his leg, & receives it back.
447
368C*The Death of the Cruel StepmotherTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA cruel stepmother sends her stepdaughter in March to the river to wash wool. Two travelers, Christ (God) & St. Peter, help the girl, & she brings back a flower. Thus the evil stepmother thinks that spring has already begun. She drives her flock of sheep into the mountains & freezes to stone.
448
369-The Youth on a Quest for His Lost FatherTales of Magic (300-749)300-399 Supernatural AdversariesA boy (young man) sets out to find his father who went away (disappeared) before his birth. He comes to the house of an old woman (witch) & tricks her (kills her, wins a contest with her son). He finds his father (alive, dead, or transformed into an animal). The boy (a god) releases (resuscitates) his father.
449
400-Man on a Quest for His Lost WifeTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A man in distress (impoverished fisherman, merchant) un-wittingly promises his (unborn) son to the devil. When the boy is delivered to him later, the devil cannot use him because he is protected by magic. Thus the boy is cast out in the sea (river, desert). He arrives in a foreign country & finds a lonely castle where he meets a bewitched princess (maiden, fairy) in the form of a serpent (deer). He rescues her by enduring three nights of torture. They marry. When he wants to visit his parents, his wife gives him a ring to carry him home, & she forbids him to call her to come to him (to boast of her beauty). At home he is induced (by his mother) to break the taboo. His wife appears, takes the ring, & leaves him destitute. The man sets out in search of his wife. On his way he meets three hermits (rulers of animal kingdoms, or moon, sun, & wind) whom he asks for directions. With the help of the third he arrives at the empire of his wife, or he pretends that he wants to help three giants who are fighting over magic ob-jects (inheritance, booty). He steals the magic objects (magic sword, magic coat or hood, seven-league boots). With their help he is able to overcome the obstacles on the way to his wife. When he finds his wife, she is about to marry another man. He discloses his identity as her real husband. (2) Meeting the princess & disenchantment as in version (1); but the disenchantment is not complete. The princess wants to travel back to her own distant land. She asks her rescuer to wait for her at a certain time & place. She ap-pears three times, but each time a servant (witch) has put her husband into a deep sleep from which he cannot be awakened. The princess informs him (in a letter) how & where to find her (on the glass mountain). The man sets out to find her. Continued as in version (1). (3) A youth watches a flock of birds (swans, ducks, geese, doves) land on the shore. The birds take off their feather coats & become beautiful maidens. While they are bathing, the youth steals the feather coat of the most beautiful girl, who cannot leave with the others & thus must marry the youth. Later, because of carelessness (of the man’s mother), the maiden takes back her coat & flies away (together with her children). She tells the youth her destination in the otherworld (e.g. glass mountain). The man sets out in search of his wife (as in version 1). Some variants include elements from Type 313 (Magic Flight).
450
401A*The Soldiers in the Enchanted CastleTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeMisc. type. Twelve (seven , three) soldiers (deserters) come (often with the help of an animal or person) to a lonely castle (small house), where they receive food & lodging. A white woman (maiden who appears in a dream) asks them to stay in the castle for seven years (one year & two days) (to keep guard for three nights) & to fulfill certain conditions (not to think of a maiden, not to touch or look at the maidens who sleep in their beds, not to open a certain door). They disobey the prohibition & flee, or all (but one) leave the castle before the end of the vigil. Thus their efforts to disenchant the princesses who live in the castle are unsuccessful. The soldiers often return later, & the one is rewarded (often after having performed different tasks), but the others are killed. In some variants the soldiers succeed in disenchanting the prin-cesses & each of them marries one of them (seven seven-year-old boys finally break the spell)
451
402-The Animal BrideTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA father is not able to decide which of his (three) sons should inher-it his property (kingdom) & sends them all on a quest for one year. They are told to bring back a special object (yarn, linen, fine chain, ring, horse, smallest dog, money ) or they must learn a profession. Whoever performs the task best will be the heir. The youngest son, often a fool, goes into a forest & becomes the servant of an animal (cat, rat, frog, mouse). As a payment he is given the object that his father had asked for. It proves to be the most beautiful one, & thus he should be the heir. Because his brothers (parents) are envious, two further tasks are set, & finally the brothers are required to bring a bride (most beautiful woman The youngest returns to the animal which again promises to help. The animal is disenchanted by burning, mutilation, decapitation, or by crossing a river, & becomes a beautiful princess with a castle. They return happily to his parents as bride & bridegroom. Sometimes they deceive the parents: The youngest son arrives dressed in rags & is ridiculed; then the bride arrives & they reveal their identities. When the son arrives in the first place dressed as a prince, a mole helps to identify him. Often the youngest son renounces his inheritance & goes with his wife back to her castle.In some variants from eastern & southeastern Europe & the Near East, the youngest son takes the animal (often a frog or toad) to his home & hides it from the family. The father assigns tasks to his daughters-in-law which the frog performs best. The last (third) task requires the brides to attend a feast, where the frog turns into the most beautiful woman. The bridegroom burns the frog’s skin so that the bride cannot change back. As a consequence she leaves him, & he sets out on a quest & finally is able to retrieve her.
452
402*The Princess Who Scorned an Unloved SuitorTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeThe Princess Who Scorned an Unloved Suitor is turned into a frog (mouse, etc.). She is disenchanted (by another man) & her animal skin is burned in order to prevent her from changing back.
453
402A*The Princess Transformed into a ToadTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA princess who has been transformed into a toad (old witch, etc.) is disenchanted by a young man’s kiss (pity) & marries him.
454
403-The Black & the White BrideTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA stepmother hates her stepchildren. The stepdaughter is kind to someone she meets (e.g. Christ & St. Peter) (she is sent after strawberries in winter, & meets dwarfs who help her). In return she is given great beauty (the power of dropping gold or jewels from her mouth). The stepmother’s own daughter is unkind under these condi tions & is made ugly (made to drop toads from her mouth). The stepdaughter’s brother is in service at the court of a king. He takes his sister’s picture with him. The king sees the girl’s picture, falls in love with her, & sends the brother for her. (The beautiful stepdaughter is seen accidentally by a king or prince, who marries her On their journey to the king’s court, the stepmother or stepsister casts the true bride out of the carriage (overboard). The king marries the ugly stepsister, & the brother is thrown into prison or a pit of snakes. (The king’s wife gives birth to a child. The stepmother throws her & her child into the water & substitutes her own daughter for the bride.) The true bride is transformed to a duck (goose), & comes to the king’s court three times (to care for her child). The last night the king wakes & disenchants her by decapitation (cutting her golden belt, holding her during successive transformations). The brother, unharmed in the den of snakes, is rescued. The true bride is married or reinstated, & the false bride & her mother are punished.
455
403CThe Substituted BrideTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA witch secretly substitutes her own daughter for the bride. On the way to his home, the bridegroom discovers the substitution & throws the witch’s daughter out of the carriage. The girl falls down to the earth (under a bridge), & from her navel grows a reed in which the witch recognizes her own daughter.
456
404-Blinded BrideTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA girl is blessed at birth by fairies (is kind to a snake) who cause her to produce gold (jewels, flowers) from her hands (mouth, footsteps, tears). A king sees the girl & wants to marry her. Her wicked stepmother (aunt) & stepsister accompany her on the journey to the king’s court. On the way, the girl’s stepmother feeds her with salty food. When the girl asks for water, the stepmother puts out both of her eyes or mutilates her. They take her clothes & throw her into the sea. The step sister, posing as the bride, marries the king. A kind fisherman (poor man) finds the blinded girl, takes her home, & becomes rich from the gold from her hands. He uses the gold (jewels, flowers) to buy back the girl’s eyes (the snake commands this). The girl recovers her sight, dresses in beau-tiful clothes, & goes to the king’s court. The king recognizes her when she washes her hands. He marries her, & the wicked women are burned. (The snake is the girl’s guardian angel & returns to heave.
457
405-Jorinde & JoringelTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeThe lovers Jorinde & Joringel accidentally go to the magic forest of a sorceress (witch). She transforms Jorinde, as she has many other girls before, into a bird & keeps her in a cage.Joringel dreams about a magic flower, goes on a search, & finds it. He touches Jorinde & all the other birds with the flower & thus changes them back into their former shapes.
458
406-The CannibalTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA couple have a child who is a cannibal who eats everyone up. A man succeeds in breaking the enchantment, & the cannibal is transformed into a maiden. They are married.
459
407-The Girl as a FlowerTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A girl (woman, fairy) has been transformed into a flower (twig, bush, tree, fruit) (transforms herself). A man (her predestined lover) breaks a stalk & the flower changes back into a girl (he takes the girl in the form of a flower on a journey with him & transforms it afterwards). He marries her (some times her ve-getable clothing has to be burned). (2) After a hasty wish, a woman gives birth to a twig (bush, fruit), plants it in a pot, & cares for it as for a child. A prince is irresistibly drawn to the plant & becomes love-sick. He obtains the plant. During the night a girl comes out of it, eats, & makes love with him. When the prince has to go to war, the girl stays in the plant. The prince attaches a bell to the plant which he will ring when he wants to call the girl. An envious woman (fiancée) signals the girl to come. She appears & is killed, & her plant is destroyed. A compassionate woman resuscitates the girl, & the rival is punished. Because of its structural similarity, also the previous Type 702B* is integrated here.) (3) A beautiful girl wants to have a lover, even if he is the devil (a dead man). The devil comes in the form of an attractive man (with animal feet). She follows him & sees him eating corpses in a church. Several times she is asked whether she had seen anything. She denies this repeatedly, even when the devil kills her sister, mother, & father. At last she herself dies. Because she had made special arrangements for her funeral, the devil cannot find her. From her grave grows a beautiful flower (lily, rose, tulip) which only her predestined husband (nobleman, prince) is able to pick. Because she has to eat, at night she becomes a beautiful woman Her husband takes her as his wife (often on the condition that he may not talk about her or present her in public, so that the devil will not be able to find her). The couple succeeds in tricking or killing the devil (the devil takes the woman to hell).
460
408-The Three OrangesTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA prince insolently breaks an old woman’s jar (makes her angry in another way). She utters a curse: he is to fall in love with three oranges (lemons, other fruits, girls of magic origin). The prince sets out on a (sometimes very long) quest during which he is given directions, advice, & help to overcome obstacles. The prince finds the fruits in a garden (castle). When he opens them, out of each comes a beautiful, often naked, young woman who asks for water (comb, mirror, towel, clothes, etc.). The prince can give only the third woman what she asks for, & the other girls die (disappear, return into the fruits). The prince hides the woman on a tree besides a fountain while he goes to get clothes (carriage, company) for her. An ugly black woman (Gypsy woman, witch) comes to get water. She thinks that the reflection of the Orange Girl is her own, & breaks her water jar because she thinks she is too beautiful to carry water. The Orange Girl laughs, & the black woman discovers her. The black woman succeeds in taking the Orange Girl’s place (two different versions). The prince returns, & though he is astonished at the sudden change (excuses: sunburn, influences of wind & weather), he marries the false bride. (1) The black woman pushes the Orange Girl into the water, where she changes into a fish (bird). The false bride demands that it be killed, but from its remains grows a tree. She demands it be felled, but an old woman (man) takes away a splinter (log). Out of this once again comes the Orange Girl, who secretly does the old woman’s housework. The old woman finds the girl & adopts her. The prince recognizes her when he hears her life history (when the girl tends one of his horses). (2) The black woman combs (louses) the Orange Girl & sticks a magic needle into her head. The girl changes into a dove & flies to the castle. The gardener (cook) hears the bird’s song ask-ing about the prince & his black wife. The dove is captured & the prince is much pleased with it. He finds the magic needle & removes it, & thus the dove changes back into the Orange Girl. After the couple’s reunion, the false bride is punished (sentenced to a cruel death; she often pronounces her own judgment).
461
409-The Girl as WolfTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeAn evil stepmother substitutes her own daughter for her married stepdaughter & transforms the stepdaughter into a wolf (lynx, fox), which hides in the forest. Every day the wolf comes, throws off her animal skin, & suckles her child (the child is brought to the forest). The child’s father observes this, recognizes his beloved wife & (on the advice of a magician) burns her animal skin. Thus she is restored to human form. The stepmother & her daughter are executed.
462
409AThe Girl as GoatTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA childless woman wants a child even if it is only an animal. She bears a girl with an animal form (goat, jackdaw, pig, fish, etc.). (An old woman finds a magic pumpkin which, at night, turns into a beautiful woman who cleans her house.) A youth (prince) observes the girl when she (while washing clothes, etc.) has removed her animal skin. He proposes to her & marries her. His mother disapproves of the marriage & torments the girl (who often plays a trick on her). Three times the girl appears at a festival in her human form, is admired, & dances. Twice she escapes & assumes her goat form. The third time the youth destroys the goat covering & disenchants the girl. In some variants, another young man decides to get married in the same way. But he is disappointed: his wife, a little pig, never changes into a girl.
463
409A*The Girl as SnakeTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA snake which is pulled out of a fire turns into a woman & marries her rescuer. The husband promises never to call his wife “snake”. When he breaks this promise, the woman changes back into a snake & disappears (is once again delivered by her son-in-law).
464
409B*The Promised Supernatural WifeTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeAn unborn boy who came into a woman’s womb by magic conception begins to weep. When someone promises him a supernatural being (fairy) as his wife, he stops crying & is willing to be born. The boy grows up very fast & sets out on a quest for the girl. With the help of supernatural beings he finds her. They marry.
465
410-Sleeping BeautyTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA daughter is born to a royal couple. A fairy (wise woman) who has not been invited to the celebration (baptism) utters a curse that the princess (on her 15th birthday) will die of a wound from a spindle (needle, fiber of flax). Another fairy changes the death sentence into a long (hundred-year) sleep. The king orders that every spindle (needle) in his empire be destroyed; but, because one of them has been overlooked, the prophecy is fulfilled: The girl meets an old woman who is spinning in a hidden chamber, pricks her finger with the spindle, & sinks, together with the whole court, into a magic sleep. Around the castle grows a hedge of thorns (the girl is enclosed in a tower). At the end of the appointed time, a youth (prince) breaks through the hedge & awakens the princess with a kiss (he impregnates her; she gives birth to two children, one of whom sucks the fiber out of her finger & thus disenchants her). In some variants the prince takes his wife & children to his family. During his absence the evil mother-in-law asks the cook to slaughter & roast the woman & the children. The cook disobeys, & the mother-in-law demands that the three be thrown into a tub full of poisonous toads & snakes. Unexpectedly the prince returns home, & the mother-in-law herself jumps into the tub.
466
410*The Petrified KingdomTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA soldier comes to a kingdom where everything has been turned to stone. He spends three successive nights in a castle which is inhabited by evil spirits (devils), without succumbing to fear. All the kingdom revives, & the soldier marries the princess.
467
411-The King & the LamiaTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA king sees a lovely girl who is actually a snake-woman, falls in love, & marries her. Little by little the king’s health deteriorates. A fakir tells him to feed his wife salty food & to stay up at night & watch her. The wife assumes her snake form & goes for water. An oven is heated red-hot & the snake is pushed in. A pebble is found in the ashes: Anything that it touches turns into gold.
468
412-Maiden with a Separable Soul in a NecklaceTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA maiden’s life depends upon her necklace which she must keep safe. She marries a prince. When a jealous girl (stepmother, stranger) steals the necklace, the bride seemingly dies & the jealous girl takes her place. The body of the seemingly dead woman is placed in a church (temple). She comes to life whenever her rival takes off the necklace. The prince finds the body of his wife & recovers the necklace (a son is born who recovers the necklace). The impostor is punished.In some variants, a prince whose soul is in a necklace seemingly dies when the necklace is stolen (by his stepmother). A woman marries the prince & recovers the necklace.
469
413-Stolen ClothingTales of Magic (300-749)400-424 WifeA youth comes upon a holy man (old woman) in the forest. He is told not to go in a certain direction, but when he does so, he sees three beautiful maidens bathing. The holy man agrees to help him, turns him into a bird, tells him to steal the clothes of one of the bathing girls, & warns him not to look back under any circumstances. The first time he does look back & is burned to a pile of ashes. The holy man restores him, & the youth succeeds on his second attempt.
470
425-Search for the Lost HusbandTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThis type refers to a cycle of related tales. It combines episodes from types 425A-E.
471
425*The Insulted Bridegroom DisenchantedTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA princess (the youngest of three sisters) wants to marry. Her father insists that she must marry the first one whom she meets (whoever picks up a certain rose). A mouse with a stinking tail (a poor man carrying water) comes by, & the princess marries him. During the wedding feast, when guests insult the mouse-bridegroom, the castle & all its inhabitants disap-pear, & the princess finds herself alone. She sets out on a quest for her lost husband. Two hermits direct her to the underworld. There she finds the castle of the mouse-bridegroom. Through her love he is disenchanted & turns into a beautiful prince.In some variants the princess lives in poverty with her husband. She dreams of a splendid castle & of wealth. Two times the dream comes true, & she invites her relatives to the castle. When her poor husband appears, someone calls his name & the castle disappears. The third time, she instructs them not to call her husband’s name. Thus he is disenchanted.
472
425AThe Animal as BridegroomTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThis type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductory episodes: (1) The youngest daughter asks her father (the king) to bring her a (musical) rose (lark, etc.) from his journey. He finds it in the garden of a beast, but in return has to promise his daughter (the first being he meets when he arrives at home) to the beast. The father tries in vain to send another girl instead of his daughter. (2) An animal-son (snake, crayfish, also pumpkin, etc.) is born (because of the hasty wish of his parents). He demands a princess for his wife & performs difficult (impossible) tasks. The princess has to marry him. (3) A girl is intended (by fate) for an animal bridegroom or agrees to marry him . (4) For other reasons a girl has an animal husband & lives to-gether with him in his castle. He becomes a beautiful man by night. Main part: When the young wife (often on the advice of her female relatives) burns the animal-skin of her bridegroom (looks at him during the night or burns him with candle wax reveals his secret, or otherwise prevents his disenchantment), he goes away. The young wife sets out for a long & difficult quest (in iron shoes, etc.). On her way she is given directions & precious gifts by the sun, moon, wind, & stars (helpful old people or animals) She arrives (sometimes by climbing a glass mountain) at her bridegroom’s far-away residence. She finds that her husband has another (supernatural) bride. She takes service as maid & trades her precious things (golden implements for spinning, jewels, magnificent clothes, etc.) for three nights by the side of her lost husband. She wants to awaken his memory of her, but two times he is drugged by a sopor ific. He spills the soporific on the third night, stays awake, & recognizes her as his true bride. (Death of the false bride.)
473
425BSon of the WitchTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThis type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductory episodes: A young woman marries a supernatural bridegroom: (1) She is given to her bridegroom because of a present that she has asked her father to bring back from a journey. (2) The bridegroom performs a set of difficult tasks. (3) She pulls up an herb & discovers the bridegroom’s subterranean castle (a wind carries her there). (4) She finds him in another way. The bridegroom is the son of a witch (ogress) or he is (during the day) an animal. Main part: The young woman breaks the bridegroom‘s prohibition, & he goes away. (Before he leaves, he gives her a token, e.g. ring, feather.) (In iron shoes) she sets out to find him. The bride comes to the house of her bridegroom’s mother, a witch, who swears by her son’s name not to devour her. The witch imposes difficult tasks on the young woman, which she performs (with the help of her bridegroom): to sort a large quantity of grain, to fill mattresses with the feathers of all kinds of birds, to wash the black wool white & the white black, to sweep a house but leave it unswept, etc. In some variants she enchants (three) suitors & makes them fight (part of previous Type 425N). The young woman is sent on a dangerous journey to bring a casket from the sister of the witch. Having passed obstacles (with the advice from her bridegroom) & obtained the casket, she is for-bidden to open it. When the bride acts against the prohibition, her husband helps her. At the wedding of the bridegroom & the witch’s daughter, the young woman has to hold ten burning candles (torches). Her bridegroom saves her from being burned. The young woman remarries her bridegroom, or both escape by a magic (transformation) flight. In some variants a female demon (witch) demands that a young woman accomplish impossible tasks. Among other things, the girl has to bring a letter to another demon telling her to kill the girl. A wolf helps the girl to escape the danger. As a reward, the wolf is disenchanted. He turns to a prince & marries the young woman.
474
425CBeauty & the BeastTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA merchant sets out on a journey & intends to bring back presents for his three daughters. The two elder ones demand jewels & clothes, the youngest a rose. The father is not able to find one. He loses his way & stays overnight in a deserted castle, where he breaks off a rose. An (invisible) animal (beast) demands that the man return or send a substitute. The youngest daughter meets her father’s obligation but refuses to marry the (ugly) animal, who treats her kindly.In a magic mirror she sees her father is ill. She is allowed to visit him but (influenced by her envious sisters) overstays the allotted time. She returns & finds the animal near death, realizes she loves him, & caresses or kisses him. By this means she dis-enchants the prince from his animal shape. They marry.
475
425DThe Vanished HusbandTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 Husband(A childless couple adopts an animal or object which grows up & wants to marry). The animal (crayfish, frog, he-goat, bird, etc., or the head of a donkey) performs the tasks set for the suitors & marries the king’s youngest daughter. During the night he turns into a beautiful young man. He warns his wife against telling his secret, but she breaks the taboo & he leaves her. The wife sets up an inn (bakery, bathhouse) where everyone who tells a tale gets free service (disguised as a man, she gives a golden coin to everyone she meets, if they will tell a tale). She thus learns where her husband lives & how to save him. She finds her husband & disenchants him.In some variants a princess loses her enchanted bridegroom, a bird, & becomes melancholy. The king promises a reward to anyone who can make the princess laugh. An old woman, who knows where the bridegroom lives, tells the princess & makes her laugh. The princess finds her bridegroom in his castle. She re-leases him from his enchantment by starving for seven years (stand-ing without shelter out in the wind & rain for a year or more). By doing this she becomes so ugly that the prince does not want her. With the help of kind fairies she becomes beautiful & wealthy. Her bridegroom falls in love with her. She makes demands on him (he must build a bridge & lie down in a coffin). They are reunited.
476
425EEnchanted Husband Sings LullabyTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA young woman follows an enchanted man (usually a prince) to his underground castle (grotto) & marries him. During the night her husband takes on his human shape. He forbids her to open a certain room (she is not allowed to watch him at night, to wake him up, to open the padlock of his heart or to look through a keyhole into his body). She breaks the taboo and, although she is pregnant, she is chased away. The pregnant woman finds lodging in the house of a rich woman (queen) whose son had disappeared a long time ago. Here she gives birth to a child. At night the enchanted husband visits his sleeping wife, sings a lullaby to the child, & thus tells how he may be dis-enchanted (roosters must not crow, church bells must not ring, etc.). Maidservants report this to the lady of the house. In the third night the conditions demanded in the song are met (the enchanted man is embraced or seized). The man is released from the enchantment & is recognized as the missing son.
477
425MThe Snake as BridegroomTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA serpent (water being, dragon) steals the clothes of a bathing girl & gives them back only when she promises to marry him. The serpent takes her as his bride to his splendid castle (at the bottom of the sea) where she gives birth to two children. The serpent promises that the woman may visit her parents if she performs certain impossible tasks (wearing out iron shoes, spinning an endless thread, etc.). By following the advice of an old woman she succeeds, & finally she & her children are allowed to visit her parents for three days. But she is warned not to tell anyone about her husband. The woman keeps the promise. The children, however, tell the relatives about their father & give away the secret of the magic formula by which he can be summoned. The woman’s brothers call the serpent & kill him. Together with her children the woman returns. She calls her husband, but there is only blood in the sea. So she realises that the children have betrayed her & condemns them to be turned into trees.
478
426-Two Girls, the Bear, & the Dwarf (Snow White & Rose Red)Tales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandDuring the winter two sisters (called “Snow White” & “Rose Red”) invite a bear into their hut. Three times the sisters rescue an evil dwarf who was going to steal some treasures, but he is ungrateful & insults them. Thereupon the bear (who had been enchanted by the dwarf) catches him. The dwarf offers treasures to the bear if he will devour the girls instead of him. But the bear kills the dwarf & thus is dis-enchanted & turns into a prince. The prince marries one of the sisters & his brother (who was not mentioned until then) the other.
479
430-DonkeyTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 Husband(Asinarius.) After a royal couple have long wished for children, the queen finally gives birth to a donkey. Raised as a human, he learns courtly customs & how to sing & play the lyre (harp, etc.). On the day when he first sees a reflection of his face, he runs away accompanied by a servant. In a foreign country he entertains the king’s court with his musical talents. He meets the king’s daughter & is charmed by her beauty. When the donkey wants to return home, the king tries to prevent him by offering him his daughter in marriage. On the wed-ding night the donkey takes off his skin & turns into a hand some prince. A servant who observes this tells the king, who burns up the skin on the following night. The prince, unable to become a donkey again, wants to flee, but the king stops him & gives him part of his kingdom.
480
431-The House in the ForestTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThree sisters one after the other go to a house in the forest where an old man lives with his three animals. The two older girls cook & make a bed only for the man, not for the animals, nor do they wait for the old man to go to bed before they do. He shuts them up in his cellar. The youngest girl takes care of the animals, feeds them & takes the leftovers for herself, & goes to bed only after the old man is settled down for the night. She wakes up in a palace. Instead of the old man, she finds a young prince, who, together with his three servants, had been enchanted by a witch. The girl & the prince marry, & the sisters must serve as maids until they prove themselves to be sympathetic to animals.In some variants a woman spoils her lazy, bad-tempered daughter & mistreats the industrious stepsister, giving her only a little food. She follows a rolling loaf of bread to a (enchanted) house in the forest. She shares her food with animals who live there (whom she has brought with her) & is kind to an old man or an animal-man (forest spirit). On the advice of the animals, she takes the man to bed with her, & he is disenchanted (along with the animals). She marries the man or is given a reward. The jealous sister comes to the house with good food, but does not share it with the animals, so they do not give her advice. She is unkind to the old man (spirit) & is (severely) punished.
481
432-The Prince as a BirdTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThe youngest of three sisters asks her father, when he goes on a journey, to bring her an unusual present (feather, plant, book, violin, mirror, pearl, etc.). The father at first cannot find such a thing, but then he obtains it from an unknown prince. The daughter uses the present to call its owner, who comes (in bird form) through her window. The envious sisters (stepmother) spy & discover the lover. They put knives or broken glass around the window. The prince is wounded & does not visit any more. The youngest daughter (disguises herself as a man and) goes to look for her lover. She overhears a conversation between birds (demonic beings, who meet in or under a tree) who speak about where the prince is & how he can be cured by a medicine. The woman prepares the medicine, finds her lover, & heals him. In payment, he gives her a present (ring, hair, shirt, horse). The prince recognizes his love. Or, back home, she summons him by means of the feather (etc.). He comes but is angry because he believes that she had injured him, & she explains what really happened. She shows him the second present (ring, shirt etc.) to prove that it was she who had cured him. They are reconciled.
482
433BKing LindormTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThis tale deals with a brave woman who marries a snake (worm, frog or toad, lizard, another animal). She disenchants him by kissing or embracing him or by sharing his bed, or because she wears more shirts than he has layers of skin. This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A poor woman gives birth to a snake (a couple adopt a snake or a frog as their child). When the animal grows up he wants to marry the daughter of the king. The king sets impossible tasks, which the snake accomplishes (the snake frightens the king). The snake marries the princess, & after the wedding he turns into a handsome man (prince). (2) A childless queen (through a hasty wish or magic conception) gives birth to an animal son (snake, dragon, etc.) whom she keeps secret. When he grows up he wants to marry, but every woman who marries him is killed on her wedding night. One courageous young woman (a mistreated stepdaughter) puts on seven shirts one on top of the other (on the advice of a wise woman, her dead mother). She challenges the snake to shed one of his skins every time she takes off one of her shirts. When he is completely stripped, she whips him & then bathes him in milk. She lies down beside him & he turns into a handsome young man. (The skins are destroyed.) (3) A young woman marries a snake who gives her jewelry & turns into a handsome young man. The woman burns the snake skin & lives happily with her husband. Another jealous woman tells her father she too wants to marry a snake. She is left in a room alone with such an animal, who kills her. In some variants after the husband is disenchanted, the woman is (slandered by a jealous woman and) banished. She disenchants a prince (who has been transformed into a bird) or a dead man, marries him, & gives birth to a son. Her first husband finds her after a long search. She must choose between the husbands & decides to stay with the first
483
434-Stolen JewelryTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 Husband(In order to avert a prophecy, a princess is confined to a tower or underground cave.) A prince in the form of a bird visits her three times & each time takes something away (jewelry, comb, mirror, hair ribbon). The princess becomes lovesick & goes to find the bird. She learns (from an old man) where the bird has gone & discovers that he can change into a handsome young man. She becomes pregnant by him and, in his mother’s house, gives birth to a child. She learns (from him) how she can disenchant him. She fulfills the requirements (together with his mother) & he is disenchanted.
484
434*The DiverTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA man skilled in diving lives like a fish in the sea (and sometimes transforms himself into an ocean animal). The king summons him & orders him to go & report on various places under the water. The diver complies at first, but then he refuses to go to a particularly dangerous place. The king throws his crown into the sea, sending the diver on a quest from which he never returns. In an Estonian oikotype, the diver is in love with a princess. A jealous suitor tells her to throw a piece of jewelry into the sea for the diver to retrieve. The diver transforms himself into a duck & accomplishes this task. He turns back into his human form & marries the princess
485
440-The Frog King or Iron HenryTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA young princess (youngest of three sisters) drops her golden ball into a well, & a frog gives it back to her. (In some variants the frog helps her with some other difficulty.) He makes her promise him that he may eat from her plate, drink from her cup, & sleep in her bed. The animal comes for his reward & the king insists the princess do as she had promised. Angry, she throws the frog at the wall & he turns into a handsome prince. In some variants the frog is disenchanted by means of a kiss, marriage, from being decapitated, etc. In the Grimms’ version: When the prince takes the princess home in his carriage, they meet his faithful servant Henry, whose heart had broken when the prince was enchanted. The iron bands that had held it together break from joy. In some variants the bride has the iron bands on her heart, & they break from pain, not from joy. After the disenchantment, both partners may be put to a test. The princess searches all over the world for her bridegroom, & he must identify his true bride.
486
441-Hans My HedgehogTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandA previously-childless couple (because of a hasty wish or a curse) have a son who is a hedgehog. He becomes a swineherd in the forest, where the pigs thrive under his care. He gives directions to three (two) kings (merchant, count, king, one king three times, etc.) who have lost their way, & is promised one of their three daughters as his wife. Riding on a rooster, he goes to claim his bride three times. Two of the princesses refuse him & he scratches them, but the third agrees to marry him. On the wedding night (on the way to the church, after they have lived together), the animal’s skin is destroyed (the princess kisses the hedgehog, whips him, cuts off his head, etc.). The hedgehog is disenchanted & turns into a handsome young man. (The two other princesses kill themselves from jealousy & anger.)
487
442-The Old Woman in the ForestTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandRobbers attack a group of travelers, & a poor servant girl survives by hiding in a tree. In the evening a dove brings her keys that unlock three trees in which she finds food, clothing, & a bed. The dove tells her to go to a little house where she will find an old woman. She should not answer any of her questions but should bring back a plain ring, leaving the shiny one there. The girl does as the dove ordered, & does not let the old woman distract her. She stops the old woman from running away with a bird cage, & finds the ring in the bird’s beak. While waiting for the dove, the girl puts the ring on her finger. Immediately a tree envelops her with its branches & turns into a handsome young prince who explains that he had been en chanted by the witch. Other trees turn into servants & horses. The prince takes the girl to his kingdom, where they marry.
488
444*Enchanted Prince DisenchantedTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandMisc. type. A prince is transformed (by a supernatural being) into an animal (monkey, fish, dragon, bird, cat, wild boar, etc.). He is disenchanted by a woman who sympathizes with him or helps him (by performing a task, obtaining a magic object, etc.)
489
449-Sidi NumanTales of Magic (300-749)425-449 HusbandThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man discovers that his wife eats corpses in the night. When he accuses her of this, she turns him into a dog. Another sorceress recognizes that the dog is really a human & returns him to his original form. With her help the husband is able to turn his wife into a mare & he beats her (to death). (2) An unfaithful wife turns her husband into a dog, which herds sheep & also rescues the king’s baby. When he returns to his wife, she turns him into a bird. He finds a magic wand, becomes a man again, & changes his wife & her lover into donkeys.
490
450-Little Brother & Little SisterTales of Magic (300-749)450-459 SiblingsLittle brother & little sister run away from their home because of their cruel stepmother or because their parents want to eat them. In spite his sister’s warning, the brother drinks from a spring or an animal’s track & is transformed into a deer (lamb, goat). The children live together in the forest until a prince finds them. The sister hides up in a tree but the prince tricks her into coming down. She marries the prince & they take the animal brother with them. The prince is absent when their child is born. The sister is replaced by another bride, often the daughter of a bad woman (stepmother, witch, maid). The sister is thrown into the water, transformed into a bird (fish), or swallow ed by a fish. She returns at night to suckle her child & to look after her brother. A servant overhears the conversation between the animal brother & the sister & informs the prince. The false bride & her mother are punished. In some variants the false bride & her mother want to kill the animal brother because they fear that the truth will be discovered. The cook saves him.
491
451-The Maiden who Seeks Her BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)450-459 SiblingsA girl rescues her twelve (seven, three, six) brothers who had been transformed into animals (birds). This tale exists chiefly in three different forms but they are often mixed with each other: (1) A stepmother transforms her stepsons into swans (ravens). The sister looks for her brothers & finds out how to release them: She has to be silent for some years & has to make shirts out of cotton-grass for the brothers. A king finds the young woman in the forest & marries her. In his absence she bears a child, but her mother-in-law takes it away & accuses her of eating the child (having borne an animal). The young queen remains silent because of her brothers, even though she is to be executed. On her way to the funeral pyre her period of silence ends & her brothers are disenchanted. Everything is explained & the mother-in-law is punished.In some variants the disenchantment of one brother is not com-plete (he keeps a wing) because the sister cried a tear when her child was taken away (did not completely finish his shirt). (2) A girl finds her brothers in a remote place & keeps house for them. They tell her to take care of the cat (dog), watch the fire, & be careful of the demonic neighbor (ogre, witch). Once she forgets to divide her food with the cat, so it puts out the fire. After the girl asks the neighbor for help, the ogre comes regularly to suck her blood. When the brothers discover this, they kill him. The girl takes flowers (herbs) from the grave of the ogre. Her brothers eat them & they are changed into oxen (sheep, birds). The episode of disenchantment is less important. (3) A mother (father) curses her sons because there is not enough to eat. They are transformed into ravens (swans). The sister seeks for them & asks for directions from the sun, moon, & stars. She finds her brothers on a glass mountain (glass palace). To reach them she needs a little bone as a key (gets help from the wind). She releases her brothers & they go back home.In some variants the episode with marriage & slander fol-lows. Some variants start with the promise of the mother to sacrifice the brothers if a daughter (one more brother) is born. She tries to inform the boys after the birth by a sign, but the wrong sign is sent, so the brothers leave home.
492
452B*The Sisters as OxenTales of Magic (300-749)450-459 SiblingsA witch & her daughter are jealous of three beautiful orphan girls who are in the king’s favor. The witch puts magic powder in the girls’ soup & the two elder girls eat it & are transformed into oxen. The king asks the youngest girl to marry him & she accepts on condition that the oxen are cared for in the king’s palace. The witch visits the palace & sticks two pins in the queen’s head, so she becomes a dove. The witch’s daughter pretends to be the queen. The dove comes to the palace & is caught by a gar dener, who has heard it speak. The king removes the pins from its head & it regains human form. The witch & her daughter are burned to death.
493
459-The Make-Believe Son/DaughterTales of Magic (300-749)450-459 SiblingsA king casts out his first wife because she is childless. Later a maidservant informs the king that this queen has born a son (daughter) but the king is not allowed to see it. The queen is supplied with a house & food. After some years the king arranges a marriage for his “child”. The maidservant makes an image of a youth or puts an animal in a sedan-chair. A god pities the queen & vivifies the image or turns the animal into a handsome youth (young woman). The king is rec-onciled with the queen.In some variants a prince falls in love with a doll thinking it is a young woman & he wants to marry her. Her “parents” convince him to marry the daughter of their neighbor.
494
