460AJourney to GodTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA beggar wants to know why he is so poor. Or, a man has heard that God returns alms given away a thousand times. This does not happen to him, so he goes to complain to God. On his journey to God (fortune, sun) the hero meets men, animals & objects that asks him (three) questions which he should ask God: e.g. (1) a wolf (lion) asks why he is never full after eating (answer: he has to eat a stupid person), (2) a tree asks why it is so dry (answer: a treasure is buried under the roots), (3) a king asks why he cannot enlarge his kingdom by war (answer: she is a queen & she should marry), (4) some young women ask why they are not married (answer: they throw the dirt into the sun), (5) a fish asks why he is alone in a river (answer: he should drown or devour somebody), (6) a river wants to know why there is no life in it (answer: it should drown somebody). God answers the questions & on the homeward journey the traveler passes on the answers & is rewarded. In some variants the traveler disclaims the rewards because God promised him wealth when he comes home. The wolf eats him up because the traveler is the most stupid person it ever met.
495
460BJourney in Search of FortuneTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksTwo brothers live together on their farm but only one of them does the work. This brother wants to divide the farm so he can run his part alone. He works harder than his brother but after a while he wonders why the farm of his lazy brother is more successful. He goes to find Fortune to ask her why. On his way he meets things & people that give him questions, & he promises to ask Fortune for answers. When he arrives at Fortune he is told that he was born on an unlucky day. He sees that Fortune from day to day has less to eat. When her servants tell her how many people are born on that day she orders that they should have as much as she had on that day. On the homeward journey, the man answers the questions of the things & people he has met. Sometimes he marries a lucky woman who brings him good luck. Later he gives someone who had asked him about the owner of the farm an untrue answer, & loses his luck.
496
461-Three Hairs from the Devil's BeardTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA poor young man wants to marry the daughter of a king (rich man). Her father tries to get rid of the young man by sending him to the devil (ogre) to bring him three hairs of the devil’s beard. On his way some objects & animals ask the young man to ask the devil some questions A well wants to know why it has dried up, a tree wants to know why it is withered & the ferryman who rows the hero to the devil wants to know when he will be replaced. With the help of the devil’s mother (grandmother, wife), who asks her son when she louses him or when he is asleep, the young man gets the three hairs & the answers to his questions. The ferryman has to give the oar to someone else, the spring of the well is blocked by a frog, & the roots of the tree are damaged by a treasure (snake). For his answers & help the young man receives a large reward, & the king has to accept him as son-in-law. The greedy king also wants to get treasures on the way to the devil, but he becomes the replacement for the ferryman.
497
462-The Outcast Queens & the Ogress QueenTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA king with three (seven, nine) wives has no children, but his wives become pregnant by eating a pear. When he is hunting he meets an ogress in form of a beautiful young woman whom he wants to marry. She demands that his wives shall be killed (thrown into a pit) & as proof she asks for their eyes (and their hearts). In the forest (a pit) the blinded outcast queens bear their children one after another, but because of their hunger they divide & eat them. Only the youngest queen saves her son. When the son grows up he takes care of the queens. The ogress queen recognizes him & tells him that he could get the eyes of the queens back if he does an errand for her. She gives him a Uriah letter & sends him to her mother. A helper changes the letter & the son is given the eyes, which he takes back to the queens. The king hears the truth & punishes the ogress queen.
498
465-Man Persecuted because of his Beautiful WifeTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA man marries a beautiful young woman of supernatural origin: She is an animal bride (e.g. swan maiden) or she comes from God. She secretly keeps house for him. He discovers her & steals or burns her animal skin to prevent her from turning back into an animal. An envious king coverts this beautiful wife and, on advice of an evil adviser (vizier, old woman), he gives the hero (three) impossible tasks to get rid of him: e.g. to build a castle or bridge in one night, to bring an exceptional baby (who understands 14 languages), to find a living harp, to harvest a field of grain in one night, to bring grapes in winter, to feed an army, to bring a huge tent that fits into one hand, to bring a very small (thumb-sized) man. The man accomplishes two of the tasks with the help of his wife. The last task often leads him to the otherworld, & it is accomplished by one of the wife’s relatives who defeats the king. In some variants the king finds out about the beautiful young woman from a picture that the hero carries with him.
499
467-The Quest for the Wonderful Flower/JewelTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA young man finds a beautiful flower (jewel) & gives (sells) it to a king who demands more of them. The young man looks for the source & finds a prin-cess who produces the flowers (jewels) magically out of her blood. She had been kidnapped by an ogre, & the young man rescues her.
500
470-Friends in Life & DeathTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksTwo friends promise each other to be guests at each other’s weddings. One of them dies but takes part invisibly in the wedding of the living friend. He invites him for a return visit. The living friend also takes part in the wedding of his friend in the otherworld. They take a long journey through the otherworld & see strange things: a broad & a narrow road to heaven & hell, fat cattle in a poor pasture & lean cattle in a green one (formerly rich & poor people), people & animals who argue, etc. When the living man returns he finds that he has been away many (three) centuries. All is changed & he knows no one. He dies or turns to dust.
501
470AThe Offended SkullTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA drunken man finds a skull (statue, a dead man hanging on the gallows), kicks it, & invites it to dinner. The skull (dead person) visits the living person & warns him about his bad behavior (kills him). On a return visit, the living person is a guest in the otherworld. In some variants the living person watches things in the otherworld. In other variants the living person stays in the otherworld only for a short time, but finds that in this world a long time has passed & everything has changed.
502
470BLand Where No One DiesTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA young man seeks for a land where no one dies. On his way to the otherworld he meets animals & men who do things for which they need a very long time (e.g. to clear away a mountain grain by grain), but they are not immortal. Finally he reaches the land where no one dies & lives there together with a young woman. When he longs for his home, the woman advises him against leav-ing. He insists on going, & she warns him not to touch the earth. He passes the people & animals which he had met on outward journey, but they have finished their work & died. Back home he meets a man with a carriage full of worn-cut shoes, & he gets off his horse to help the man. But it is death looking for him, & he dies.
503
471-The Bridge to the OtherworldTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksThree brothers one after the other set out to look for work, or to search for their lost sister who is married to someone in the otherworld. They are given a difficult job: They must herd seven foals (oxen) & at the end of the day they must bring back a sample of the animals’ food (other things).In some variants they have to accompany a supernatural being (sun, death) & are not allowed to talk or to be distracted. The elder brothers fail: They are lured away by a bird, or per-suaded by an old woman to rest, or they fail to cross a certain bridge. They are transformed to stone. The youngest brother follows the instructions & passes across the bridge. He sees visions: Fat cattle in a poor pasture & lean cattle in a green one, stones striking on each other, & animals which, passing in & out of a church, become human beings & take part in the Holy Communion. The boy takes bread & wine from the altar & brings it to the supernatural being. The visions are explained: the fat & lean cattle in the differend pastures fomerly were rich & poor people. The striking stones were people who argued & are forced to continue their conflicts in the otherworld. The animals in the church are angels, priests, or transformed princes. The youngest brother is rewarded & his brothers are disenchanted.
504
471AThe Monk & the BirdTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA monk, thinking about the everlasting life in the monastery gardens, listens to the singing of a bird. He believes it lasts only a short moment but when he returns to the monastery he has grown old & nobody recognizes him because decades (three centuries) have gone by.
505
475-The Man as Heater of Hell's KettleTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA poor soldier (servant) takes a job (for seven years) in hell. Or, parents wish that the devil will take their greedy child. The soldier has to heat the kettles & is not allowed to wash or comb himself. He is also not allowed to look into the pots. He breaks this rule & finds his former masters or unfriendly relatives in the kettles. He heats them even more. Or, he releases poor souls (transformed into animals). In payment he receives sweepings which later change into gold. Or, on the advice of a soul he has released, he asks for something worthless (an old piece of clothing) that gives money. The host at an inn where he stays for the night robs him of his gold, but with the devil’s help he recovers it.
506
476-Coal Turns into GoldTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksThis misc. type consists of various tales (mostly legends) in which coal turns into gold (silver). e.g.: (1) A person finds (the devil gives him) some coal that turns into gold. In some variants the person has to throw a rosary (bridle) onto the coal to effect the transformation. (2) A person breaks apart glowing coals & finds a treasure under them. (3) The gold (transformed coal) brings unexpected good fortune to a poor person (child, charcoal burner, maidservant, shepherd, orphan). (4) A maidservant gets glowing coals for her kitchen fire. The next morning, she finds pieces of gold in the ashes. Her master takes the gold away from her. (5) A man who wants to smoke his pipe has no lighter. He takes a piece of coal from the fire, but his pipe will not light from it even on the third try. When he knocks out his pipe, a piece of gold falls out of it.
507
476*In the Frog's HouseTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA woman promises a frog to be friends & becomes midwife (godmother) to the frog’s wife. She takes the frog’s child to be christened, sweeps the dust in the frog’s house, & takes the garbage home with her. There it becomes gold (money). In some variants she frees drowned souls or brings up the child of the frog for seven years & then is able to release its parents from enchantment.
508
476**Midwife in the UnderworldTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksSomeone (an animal who turns into a supernatural being) summons a midwife to help a supernatural being (dwarf, water spirit, elf, forest spirit, human woman who has been kidnapped by fairies) give birth. As payment for her services, the midwife is given something apparently worthless (coal, leaves, garbage, onions, garlic), most of which she throws away carelessly. Later she finds that the small part she still has, has turned to gold. She looks for what she lost but cannot find it (the gift means danger of life).
509
480-The Kind & the Unkind GirlsTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA girl is mistreated by her stepmother & has to work very hard. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A girl loses an object which is carried off by a river (blown away by the wind), & runs after it (a spindle. She comes upon an old woman (ogress) who asks her to clean (disarrange) & to louse her head. When the old woman lets her choose a box as her reward, she chooses the plain one. (2) A girl falls into a well (is pushed in, jumps in after an object she has dropped), or follows a rolling cake (ball of yarn, etc.). She encounters various animals, objects, or people who ask her for help: e.g. a cow wants to be milked, an old man or woman to be loused or fed, an oven to be emptied of bread, an apple tree to be shaken. The girl helps them all. Then she arrives at the house of an old woman (Frau Holle, old man, supernatural beings like a giant or the twelve months) where she is assigned tasks: e.g. she has to do the household or farm work, has to feed or louse the demon, has to comb the hair of fairies, has to carry water in a sieve or wash black wool white. She is very helpful & hard-working. In the end she is is rewarded with gold, jewels, etc., becomes more beautiful, or jewels fall from her mouth. Or, she can choose her reward & is very modest but the reward changes into wealth when she reaches home.In some variants she is forbidden to enter a certain room. When she breaks this rule, she becomes covered with gold & flees. The grateful animals, objects, & people of her outward journey help her escape from the demon. After she arrives home, her envious stepmother sends her own daughter on the same journey. This girl goes through the same situ-ations but she refuses help, disobeys, & is unkind. She is punished severely (frogs fall from her mouth, horns grow on her head, or she is disfigured, beaten or killed). In some variants the stepmother is also punished. In the end the kind young woman often marries a prince.
510
480AGirl & Devil in a Strange HouseTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA girl leaves home because of her cruel stepmother. On her way she helps some animals & takes them with her. During the night they stay in a strange house. A demon (devil) tries to enter (to dance with the girl, to marry her), but the girl refuses to open the door unless he gives her certain valurable gifts. When morning comes, the demon has not fulfilled all the wishes so he cannot enter the house. He loses his strength & goes away. This is often followed by account of the unfriendly stepsister who gives no help to the animals & is killed by the demon.
511
480A*Three Sisters set out to Save their Little BrotherTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA witch carries away the little brother of three sisters. The elder sisters set out to search him, but pay no attention to the requests of an apple tree, an oven, etc. , & are overtaken by the witch. The third does all she is asked to do; therefore, the grateful objects help her to recover her little brother from the clutches of the witch.
512
480C*Trasporting White Bread to HellTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksA poor brother brings his wealthy brother a gift of coarse white bread (a lamb). The wealthy brother says, “Go to hell with your bread”. On his way to hell, the poor brother meets an old man who tells him what he has to do there. He saves many souls from hell & is rewarded by the old man. The wealthy brother also takes bread to hell, but is discourteous to the old man & gets no advice. He falls victim to the devils.
513
480D*Tales of Kind & Unkind GirlsTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksThis misc. type consists of various tales in which an unkind girl (neighbor, wife) wants to have the same re ward that a kind one received. However, she is too selfish & is punished instead.
514
485-Borma JarizhkaTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksThe tsar sends a man to Babylon to get a crown. He steals the crown & burns the snakes that pursue him. He comes to an one-eyed giant, blinds him, & escapes from the cave under the belly of the giant. He begets a child with a wild woman, but when he leaves her she is so angry that she breaks the baby in two. He helps a lion who brings him home. In spite of the lion’s warning, he boasts of his journey while he is drunk. In justification he shows the lion the power of intoxication, & gets him drunk.
515
485B*The Power of DrunkennessTales of Magic (300-749)460-499 Supernatural TasksThe animal helper (bear, lion) of a man forbids him, on pain of death, to praise him. The man breaks this rule while he is drunk. In order to justify & save himself, he makes the animal drunk. While it is drunk the animal lets itself be bound. It acknowledges the power of drunkenness & forgives the man.
516
500-Name of the Supernatural HelperTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural Helpers(e.g. Tom Tit Tot, Rumpel-stilzchen, Trillevip.) A father (mother) boasts that his daughter can spin gold or impossible amounts of yarn. Or, a mother beats her daughter because she is lazy. The king asks why & the mother says she will not stop spinning. The young woman’s talent is to be tested & she is shut in a room to spin. If she fails she will die, but if she succeeds the king will marry her. She cries. A supernatural being (a little man) agrees to help her if she will promise him her first child (herself) if she cannot guess his name. In some variants she has to remember his name after a long time. The young woman passes the test & the king marries her. After a year the little man, certain that she could not guess his name, comes back to take her child away. By chance the name is discovered (by a servant, the husband or the woman herself) when the little man sings it triumphantly in the forest. When the woman says the correct name to the helper he vanishes or sinks into the earth.
517
500*The Monster Reveals the RiddleTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersStudents must count the peaks of a mountain range. They go to sleep. A monster watches them & thinks they are a multi-headed monster. He says that he walked through all the peaks of the mountain range (naming the number) & had never seen such a strange thing. Thus the students hear & solve the riddle.
518
501-The Three Old Spinning WomenTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThrough a false boast of her mother or of a young woman herself, she is compelled to spin an impossible amount of thread. If she is successful a prince will marry her. She receives help from three old women who are deformed from too much spinning: the first has an enormous foot, the second has drooping lips, & the third has a thick thumb. In payment she must invite them to her wedding. The prince sees them & exclaims in disgust. They tell him that their deformities come from spinning. He swears that he will never let his wife spin again.
519
502-The Wild ManTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA king catches a wild man (Iron John) & puts him into a cage, forbidding anyone to set him free. His son frees the pris-oner because his ball rolls into the cage or because he feels pity for him. The prince is afraid of his father’s anger & leaves home (his father drives him away to be killed or sends him to another king) along with a servant. On their way the servant persuades the prince to exchange clothes. The prince becomes a servant at the court of another king. At a tournament he appears unrecognized three times on a splendid horse which he received from the wild man & wins the hand of a princess. Or, he wins the princess because he has helped her father in war. Often the wild man is disenchanted. In some variants the prince works for a while at the wild man’s house where he disobeys instructions (e.g. looks into a forbidden chamber, cares for a horse although it is not allowed) & his hair turns to gold.
520
503-Gifts of the Little PeopleTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA hunchbacked man takes part in a dance of the witches or people from below the earth (elves, fairies, dwarfs). He sings their song or adds a missing rhyme or more weekdays. As a reward they remove his hump or give him gold. A greedy neighbor (hunchbacked person) wants to get the same reward, but he ruins the song or is unfriendly. The little people add the hump of the other man to his own, or give him coals instead of gold.
521
505-The Grateful DeadTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersOne introductory episode is combined with various main parts in which a man wins a princess & a castle. The ending is also very similar. Introductory episode:While traveling, a man sees a corpse which is not allowed to be buried or is ill-treated by its creditors. He uses all his money to pay the debts of the dead man & for his funeral. Later he meets the grateful dead man in the form of a traveling companion (old man, servant) who wants to help him on the condition that they will divide all their winnings. Main parts: (1) The man ransoms a princess, who had been kidnapped, from slavery & marries her. While the man is away in another country, the father of the princess recognizes the sail of the ship which is emboidered with the princess’s coat of arms & learns that his daughter is alive. When the man goes back to fetch his wife, he finds that she has been abducted by one of her father’s courtiers. The man searches for his wife, & the traveling companion helps him to return to his father-in-law’s court. There the man discloses his identity as the husband of the princess & gets his bride back. (2) The man rescues a young woman from robbers. On their way home by ship the man is thrown overboard by a rival but is rescued by the traveling companion & brought to the prin-cess. He is recognized by means of a ring or otherwise. The rival is unmasked & punished. (506B.) (3) The traveling companion equips the man with a magnificent horse. A tournament takes place in which the winner is to marry a princess. The man wins her. (508.) Ending: The traveling companion asks for his part of the winnings & wants to divide the princess (their baby). When the man, trying to save the princess, offers the whole kingdom, the traveling companion reveals himself as the grateful dead man, says his de-mand was only a test of faith, & vanishes.In some variants the grateful dead man is a saint, who helps the hero because he has redeemed a saint’s picture that was mistreated.
522
506*Prophecy EscapedTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA child is born in answer to a prayer. It is foreseen to the child that it will die by hanging when he is 20 years old. The child is helped by a companion (saint) who favors him because of his modesty. The companion saves the child’s life & wins a princess for him. The helper demands half of the winnings, so the princess is to be divided.
523
507-The Monster's BrideTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis type consists of one introductory part & two different main parts. The ending is often the same. Introductory part: While traveling a young man provides a suitable funeral for an unknown man whose corpse was mistreated by creditors. Later he meets a traveling companion (servant) who wants to help him on the condition that they will divide all their winnings. On their way, the traveling companion obtains (three) magic objects (e.g. boots, magic hood, cloak, sabre, feather). The young man woos a princess who is in love with a magician (ogre, devil). Her suitors have to guess her thoughts three times (bring hidden objects, solve difficult tasks). If they fail they are executed. Main part: (1) With the help of the magic objects, the companion of the young man becomes invisible & follows the princess on her way to the magician. There he finds the solutions. He frees the princess by beating, burning, or killing the magician. On the wed-ding night the young man has to submerge the princess (in different forms) three times in a bath to release her from her enchantment. (2) All bridegrooms of a princess have perished during the bridal night. The young man marries her on advice of his com-panion. A snake (snakes) comes into the chamber or crawls out of the princess’s mouth to kill the young man, but the companion kills it. Ending: (After a year) the companion demands his half of the winnings & divides the princess in two parts. Snakes crawl out of her body. He puts the halves together & the princess is disenchanted forever. In a few variants the companion only pretends to divide the princess to test the faith of the young man, & then discloses his identity as the grateful dead man.
524
510-Cinderella & Peau d'AneTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis type number refers to a cycle of related tales
525
510ACinderellaTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural Helpers(Cenerentola, Cendrillon, Aschenputtel.) A young woman is mistreated by her stepmother & stepsisters & has to live in the ashes as a servant. When the sisters & the stepmother go to a ball (church), they give Cinderella an impossible task (e.g. sorting peas from ashes), which she accomplishes with the help of birds. She obtains beautiful clothing from a supernatural being or a tree that grows on the grave of her deceased mother & goes unknown to the ball. A prince falls in love with her, but she has to leave the ball early. The same thing happens on the next evening, but on the third evening, she loses one of her shoes. The prince will marry only the woman whom the shoe fits. The stepsisters cut pieces off their feet in order to make them fit into the shoe, but a bird calls attention to this deceit. Cinderella who had been first hidden from the prince, tries on the shoe & it fits her. The prince marries her.
526
510BPeau d'AsneTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural Helpers(Cap o’Rushes, Donkey Skin, All Kinds of Fur, Allerleirauh.) A king promises his wife on her deathbed only to marry another woman who is as beautiful as she is (whom a par-ticu lar ring fits). Because she is the only one who meets this condi-tion, the king wants to marry his grown daughter. In order to delay the wedding, the young woman asks him to give her dresses like the sun (gold), the moon (silver), & stars (diamonds), & a coat made of many different kinds of fur (a covering of wood). After he provides all these, the daughter runs away from her father and, disguised in the ugly skin, works as a kitchen maid (goose-girl) in another castle. When a series of feasts is held in the castle where she works, the young woman secretly puts on her splendid dresses. The prince falls in love with her but does not recognize her as the kitchen maid. On the following days he treats the kitchen maid badly. During the feasts he asks the beautiful woman where she comes from, & she gives cryptic answers that refer to how he had treated the kitchen maid. He gives her a ring. Then the prince becomes lovesick. In her character as kitchen maid, she slips his ring into his soup (bread). He finds her & marries her. Sometimes the young woman is discovered while she is bathing or dressing instead of being recognized through a token.
527
510B*The Princess in the ChestTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA widowed king wants to marry his daughter. She demands that he give her a magic golden chest (golden lantern). On their wedding day, she hides herself in the chest. The father sells the chest to a prince (it is cast into the sea, where a prince finds it & brings it into his house). When the princess secretly comes out & eats his food, he discovers her & falls in love with her. The prince’s fiancée discovers the princess & sends her away. The prince becomes lovesick & the princess brings him food in which she has hidden a ring of the prince. He finds her & marries her.
528
511-One-Eye, Two-Eyes, & Three-EyesTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA girl (boy) has a stepmother who does not give her enough to eat but makes her herd cattle & spin a great amount of flax. She tells her sorrows to a (little colored) cow (red ox, god-mother), who gives her food & helps her with her work. The stepmother wants to know why the girl is so well fed, & sends her one-, two- & three-eyed daughters one after the other to find out. The girl sings One-Eye & Two-Eyes to sleep, so they learn nothing, but she forgets to sing to the third eye of Three-Eyes, who tells her mother about the cow. The stepmother determines to have the cow slaughtered. When the girl tells the animal this, the cow tells her to plant its bones (in-testines, or not to eat its meat). She does as she was told, & a tree (apple tree) grows which continues to help her. A rich man notices the tree & asks for an apple. When the step-sisters try to pick one, a branch scratches them. Only the girl herself can pick the fruit, & the rich man marries her. Often the tree goes (is taken) with them. The stepmother & step-sisters are punished. Sometimes, the child & the cow run away when the stepsis-ter discovers their secret. They pass through brass, silver, & gold forests. In each forest, the cow warns the child not to pick the leaves, but the child disobeys. A brass etc. ox (wolf, lion) comes & fights with the cow of the child. The last of these over-comes the cow, which, before it dies, tells the child to save (plant) some part of its body (horn, hoof, skin) because it will help him later. (511A.) Or, the cow dies after the escape & turns into an angel that flies to heaven. (511A*.) In some variants another woman wants to marry the girl’s father. She promises to take good care of the girl & convinces her to kill her mother by having her look into a chest & dropping the lid on her neck. In other variants, after the stepmother discovers the secret of the cow, she tries to kill the girl in a covered pit filled with burning coals . A dog warns the girl in front of the pit. The stepmother kills the dog & the next day the girl falls into the pit. She is burned up, the cow licks the ashes, & a duck comes out. When her brother comes home, the girl in the form of this duck tells him what happened. He punishes the stepmother.
529
513-The Extraordinary CompanionsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis type number refers to a cycle of related tales.
530
513ASix Go Through the Whole WorldTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA discharged soldier (fool) ac-quires many (six) traveling companions with extraordinary abilities: e.g. one who runs fast, one who eats great quantities, one who produces (can withstand) severe frost, one who can shoot & hit the left eye of a fly from far away, one with acute hearing, one who can make himself taller, & one who can rip up trees by their roots. In order to avenge himself on the king who dis charged him, the soldier enters a contest to marry the princess. She has agreed to marry anyone who beats her at running. The king permits the soldier to employ his helpers. The runner overtakes the princess, but he falls asleep & is awakened just in time by the sharpshooter. In an effort to prevent the wedding, the king assigns other tasks: eating (drinking) a huge quantity, which the eater accomplishes, & staying in an oven, which the freezing man accomplishes. Finally the king offers the soldier as much money as he & his companions can carry if he will give up his claim for the princess. The companions ruin the king & overcome his army. The same motifs appear together in a reduced form. A prince (young man) is looking for a wife. He takes as servants men who help him accomplish tasks that have been set for suitors who hope to marry the princess. In the end he marries her.
531
513BLand & Water ShipTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA king offers his daughter in marriage to whoever can build a ship that can travel on land as well as in water. Three brothers attempt this task, but the older two are unkind to an old man (little man) who asks what they want to do. The third who answers honestly gets help from the old man & is then able to build the ship (in one night). The old man also tells him to take with him anyone whom he meets. These turn out to be men with unusual abilities. When the young man brings the ship, the king is amazed, but since the young man is of humble origin, he gives him further (difficult) tasks to prevent the marriage. The young man accomplishes them all with the help of his companions & marries the princess.
532
514-The Shift of SexTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA king who has only (three) daughters must send a son to war (needs a son for other reasons). The daughters ask to be allowed to pretend to be men, but only the youngest passes tests which her father sets. He gives her magic objects (a horse) & she goes to the war.In some variants a queen has only daughters and, afraid of her husband’s anger, pretends that the youngest is a boy. Or for other reasons a woman disguises herself as a man & goes out into the world. The woman in man’s clothing accomplishes heroic deeds and/or goes into service with a king. The daughter (sister) of the king falls in love with her & wants to marry her. The woman in man’s clothing refuses, or the marriage is unconsumated. In order to get rid of the “servant/husband”, impossible tasks are set. The woman is able to accomplish these with the help of a helper (several helpers, the horse). In some variants the tests concern the gender of the “servant”, which had been doubted. For example, her manner of eating & her behavior in a garden are tested, or she is asked to bathe with the brothers of the princess. At the end of the tale, the woman in man’s clothing is transformed into a man. This happens either through a demon’s curse or a saint’s help, seldom by accident. Then the princess is happy with her husband & the former woman becomes king. Her parents are happy that finally they have a real son.
533
514**Young Woman Disguised as Man is Wooed by QueenTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA young woman in man’s clothing works as a doctor (messenger) for a king. The king’s wife falls in love with the doctor but is repulsed (accuses him of attempting to seduce or rape her). Angry, she sets an impossible task, which the doctor must perform on pain of death. Often it is to enable a dumb person to speak. The dumb person reveals the intention of the queen, who is executed. The king marries the young woman who had posed as a doctor.
534
515-The Shepherd BoyTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA foundling child who herds animals finds three objects (of glass) which he gives back to their owners. They promise to reward him. With the help of the last owner, a giant, the boy fulfills three tasks. He acquires a castle in which a princess is confined. He rescues her & marries her.
535
516-Faithful JohnTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA prince wants to marry a beautiful princess from a distant land because he heard her name, saw her picture, or saw her in a dream. A faithful servant (adoptive brother, a dead man whom he has redeemed) helps him in this pursuit. The servant poses as a merchant & traps the princess on a ship, or he enters her room by hiding in a statue of an animal (in a magical manner). The princess is kidnapped or goes voluntarily. On the way back, the helper overhears creatures (birds prophesy the future. They say that certain dangers that threaten the bridal couple can be averted by particular actions, but also that anyone who reveals this will be turned to stone. The dangers are a horse (other animal) that will run away with (kill) the bridegroom, poisoned food (drink, clothing), & a dragon who will kill the bridegroom on his wedding night. When the helper acts to avert the dangers, his actions appear excessive & irrational. When he kills the dragon, drops of its blood fall on the bride’s breast. He removes them (with his mouth, or he sucks them out of her body while she is unconscious). The prince construes this as a sexual attack & condemns the helper to death. Before the sentence can be carried out, he justifies himself & is turned to stone step by step. The prince & his wife mourn the helper. The prince discovers (in a dream) that he can bring his friend back to life by sacrificing his own children. He kills (injures) them & rubs the stone man with their blood. The helper is restored to life & he revives the children.
536
516CAmicus & AmeliusTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersTwo friends who look exactly alike assist each other in time of need. When one of them, in elder versions named Amelius, is challenged to a sword-fight, the other, Amicus, who is a better swordsman, takes his place. Amelius remains behind with Amicus’s wife, & puts a sword in the middle of the marriage bed at night. Amicus wins the fight for his friend. Later, Amicus contracts leprosy. An angel tells them that he will be healed if he bathes in the blood of Amelius’s children. Amelius cuts off their heads to save his friend. The children are restored to life. Or, because his mother had made a vow before his birth, a young man goes on a pilgrimage. He meets a friend through an apple test: a true friend is one who, when he shares an apple, takes the smaller half (who notices that an apple is missing). When the friend is killed (very ill) & can be cured only by the blood of the children of the young man, he sacrifices his children in order to save his friend. The children are later restored to life.
537
517-The Boy who Understands the Language of BirdsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA boy who understands (has learned) the language of birds is asked by his father to tell what he has heard. He is at first reluctant, but then repeats the birds’ prophecy that the father will humble himself before the son (will serve him, bring water for the son to wash his hands). The father pushes the son into the sea (drives him out, tries to kill him). The son is rescued & goes into the service of a foreign ruler. By hearing what birds say, he frees this ruler from ravens that annoy him. The son is honored & is given half the kingdom, & he mar-ries a princess. In his new high position, he goes back to his parents, who serve him without recognizing him.
538
518-Men Fight over Magic ObjectsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA (young) man on a journey meets three (two) men (giants, devils), who are quarreling over the division of three magic objects (e.g. cloak of invisibility, seven mile boots, wishing hat, flying carpet) (which they have inherited). The man promises to render a judgment, but he asks first to try out the objects (to run a race against the owners). He takes the magic objects & runs away with them. He uses them later to accomplish difficult tasks.
539
519-The Strong Woman as Bride (Brunhilde)Tales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA prince falls in love with a powerful young woman who will marry only someone whose own power is as strong as hers. Suitors who try & fail are put to death. Although he is warned against it, the prince sets out along with a strong companion to win her. When they arrive, the helper storms the woman’s defenses, slays her army, & overcomes the woman herself on his master’s behalf. He defeats her in single combat (using a cloak of invisibility): e.g. in a shooting contest with a giant bow, in breaking her wild horse. On the wedding night the strong woman tries to crush the prince. The helper secretly takes his master’s place & beats her for three nights with whips made of three kinds of metal. When the woman discovers the impersonation, she orders the feet of the helper to be cut off & banishes the prince to the pigsty. The helper finds a blind companion & together they force a demon to heal them with Water of Life. The helper re-turns, overcomes (kills) the strong woman, & rescues the prince.
540
530-Princess on the Glass MountainTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA narrative in three parts with several different forms & combinations: (1) At night, a field (haystack, garden) belonging to a family with three sons is robbed (devastated). The sons keep watch. The elder two fall asleep (run away in fear), but the youngest (helped by a mouse, frog, old man) stays awake & captures three magic horses. They promise to help him in the future, & he lets them go free. Or, hiding in a mound of hay, he is carried home by a giant. He kills the giant & finds his treasure (helpful spirits) & three horses. In some variants a dying father orders his sons to watch over his grave. Out of indifference (fear), the older brothers leave this task to the youngest. At the grave he receives three horses, as well as a pipe (stick, bridle) to use to summon them. (2) The king’s daughter is offered in marriage to whoever can ride to the top of a mountain (made of glass, crystal, marble) and/or take a golden apple from its summit. Or he must kiss the princess at the summit & take her ring or scarf. In some variants he must jump up to the princess who sits at the window of the fourth story of a building (and take her ring), or jump over a grave. The young man disguises himself and, with the help of the magic horses, succeeds three times. On the third time, the king (princess) gives him a token (marks him, he is injured). He goes away. (3) Messengers (king, princess) look for the champion, and/or all the men are ordered to march past the princess (the princess sum mons all the men to a feast). Through his token (mark, injury), the youth is discovered at home (in the king’s household). He marries the princess.In some variants the horses are disenchanted & become princes (princesses).
541
530AThe Pig with the Golden BristlesTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA king commands his (three) sons-in-law to get magic animals: a pig with golden bristles, a golden-horned stag, wild boars from the sea, etc. The stupidest of the sons (another foolish boy) gets these wonders, but trades them to his brothers in return for their cut-off fingers & pieces of skin from their backs. At the feast where the brothers are honored, they are exposed as cheaters by the pieces of evidence shown by the fool.
542
531-The Clever HorseTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a clever horse. The tale exists chiefly in three different forms, “The Godchild of the King & the Unfaithful Companion”, “The Golden-haired Maiden”, & “The Clever Horse”. A poor boy goes in search of his godfather, the king (God, Virgin Mary, etc.). On the way he obtains a clever magic horse that offers to help him. Against the horse’s advice he picks up a glimmering feather (golden hair, golden horse-shoe, other bright object), which he later gives to the king.En route the boy is accompanied by a companion (devil, beardless man, Gypsy, etc.) who forces him to change places & to swear silence. At the king’s court the boy is employed as a groom. He helps different animals, who in return promise to help him. A treacherous employee of the king (the boy’s companion) slan-ders him to the king, saying that he had boasted he could find the bird that had lost the feather and/or to bring the golden-haired maiden (princess) as bride for the king. On pain of death he is assigned to accomplish the dangerous tasks. He succeeds with help of his horse. The abducted princess refuses to marry the old king until she receives certain things (her castle, keys that have fallen into the sea, water of life, etc.). The boy brings these with the help of his horse & of the helpers he had met on his way (grateful animals). As the last condition for the marriage the princess demands the boy be killed (burned, beheaded, dismembered, by taking a bath in boiling milk or oil of a herd of wild mares, by water of death, etc.) The horse saves the boy or he is resuscitated by the princess, rejuvenated, & beautified. The king has the same thing done to him with fatal results (the princess does not resuscitate him, he dies in the milk, etc.). The magic horse turns into a young woman (man). The boy marries her (the princess) & becomes king.
543
532*Magic OxTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersWith the help of a (two, several) magic ox (cow), a boy plows the copper (iron, stone) field of the king. He marries the princess & receives (half of) the kingdom.
544
533-Speaking HorseheadTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA princess is sent to her fiancé, a prince of a foreign country. Her mother orders a maidservant to accompany her, & gives her a small rag with some drops of her mother’s blood to protect her & sends a speaking horse to take care of her. When during the journey the princess loses her mother’s charm, the waiting-maid gains control of the princess, forces her to change clothes & roles, & to swear an oath of secrecy. The prince unwittingly marries the maidservant, & the real princess is employed as a goose-girl. When the false wife orders the horse to be killed, the princess persuades a farmhand to hang the horsehead on the wall by a gate where she passes daily. Every day she greets the horsehead with a formula, & it answers regretting the injury that is being done to her. When she speaks a magic formula to make the hat of a goose-boy fly away (to keep an obstrusive goose-boy away from her), he com plains to the king. Thereupon the old king starts observing her & finally makes her tell her life story to a stove (her dog). The truth comes to light, the real bride marries the prince, & the maidservant is punished (she unwit tingly declares her own judgment).
545
535-The Boy Adopted by Tigers/AnimalsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA boy is abandoned in the forest & adopted by wild animals (tigers). He is given a magic bow & a magic arrow (axe). The animals arrange a marriage for him. A monkey (barber) takes his place. The boy goes to live with an old widow who has a love-ly daughter. He proves his identity by using his magic objects. He marries both the girl to whom he was betrothed & the widow’s daughter.
546
537-The Flight of the Grateful EagleTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA man aims his gun three times at an eagle. When suddenly the bird speaks like a human being, the man spares it. The eagle has a broken wing & the man nurses the bird for several years until it recovers, spending all his wealth. The grateful bird carries the man on his back across the sea to his kingdom. On the way it frightens him three times by nearly dropping him into the sea (as the hunter had aimed three times at the bird). On the other side of the sea the eagle’s father (sister) gives the man a box, telling him not to open it before he reaches home. Overcome with curiosity, the man opens the box on the way, & a town (castle) springs out of it. In order to put the town back into the box, the man promises his (unborn) son to the devil (supernatural being). The tale is usually an introduction to Type 313B.
547
540The Dog & the SailorTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersAn unhappy sailor in misery tries to drown himself, but in the water (on shore) he meets a dog (poodle) who offers its help. On the dog’s advice he takes it along with him to sea. After three heavy storms (several years) the dog orders the sailor to jump into the water. At the bottom of the sea he finds a castle & a beautiful woman. The dog had warned him of her seductive powers, so he kills her. Inside the castle the dog is waiting for him. After enduring three painful nights (after accomplishing special tasks), the sailor cuts off the dog’s head, whereupon the prince who had once been enchanted by his mother-in-law (witch, father) is disenchanted & returns to human form.
548
545-The Cat as HelperTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis type refers to a cycle of related tales; it combines episodes from types 545A & 545B
549
545AThe Cat CastleTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA poor girl reaches the king’s castle with the help of a cat (dog), (her sole inheritance). On the cat’s advice she pretends to be the princess of the castle of the cats. The prince falls in love with her (the royal couple receives her). When she looks out of the window & sees her parents quarreling of a pot of porridge, she laughs. Being asked why, she does not want to reveal her humble origin, so she pretends to have been laughing at the poor condition of the king’s castle. The girl’s noble origin is tested. When she says she possesses a castle more beautiful than that of the king, she is asked to show it. The cat goes to the castle of a troll (giant, giantess) & kills him (by making him look into the sun). The girl becomes the owner of the castle & marries the king (guests are received: The cat demands to be killed by the girl & turns into a prince. He marries the girl).
550
545A*The Magic CastleTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA poor girl gives all her food to an animal (cat, dog, fox) or to an old beggar (Christ). Afraid that her grandmother (mother, aunt) will punish her, she runs away & comes to a castle. (On the way, supernatural beings transform her adornments from flowers, snail shells, etc. into precious jewels.) She becomes queen. The grandmother comes & demands the food that she had given away. But the grandmother is pushed off the balcony (ladder), dies, & turns into a grapevine (tree), which continues to question the queen about the missing food. The queen laughs at this & her husband demands that she should explain why she laughed. She replies hastily that the toilet brush is more beautiful than his beard (her own castle or garment is more beautiful than his). The animal (supernatural being) helps her to prove this by giving her a bejeweled toilet brush (castle). In some variants a girl is cast out by her older sisters. On the advice of an old man, she goes to work in a castle. When the owner’s son asks to see the girl’s own castle, the old man helps her to produce one.
551
545BPuss In BootsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersAn animal (cat, fox, jackal, monkey, etc.) intends to help a poor man (out of obligation) to become rich (by marrying him to the princess). In order to gain the emperor’s confidence, the animal tells him that the poor man is very wealthy. When the poorly dressed future bridegroom travels to his bride’s residence, the animal simulates an accident (robbery), in which all his clothes (horses, bride presents, wedding guests) are lost. Thereupon the king gives the poor man good clothes & he is accepted as a bridegroom. When the man has to display his property, the animal leaves before him & coerces the shepherds & farmers to say that their herds & farmland belong to the poor man. The animal kills the real owner of the properties, a demon (dragon, ogre, giant, witch, magician) by burning, slaying, shooting or through a trick. When the bride arrives with her entourage, the bridegroom presents himself as the real owner of the property. The animal tests the gratitude of the poor man by feigning death (it becomes a human when it is decapitated).In some variants the man behaves ungrateful or does not keep his promise.
552
545D*Pea KingTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA poor boy finds a pea (bean) & imagines how many peas might grow from it. He goes to the king & asks for storehouses & sacks for his coming crops. The king is impressed & believes the boy is wealthy. He tests his noble origin by a bed-test The boy is unable to sleep on the hard couch because he is worried about his lost pea. He marries the king’s daughter. When the king wants to see the property of his son-in-law, the young man meets an ogre (devil, grateful ghost) who offers to give him his castle, but only if he can solve some riddles. The ogre tells all the farmers & shepherds on the way to pretend to be employees of the poor boy. An old man helps him solve the riddles. The ogre & his brothers burst, & the poor man becomes the owner of the castle & its land.
553
546-The Clever ParrotTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThe king wins the gratitude of a parrot who takes him to a princess (the parrot brings a princess to the king). On the return trip the king & his bride are separated. The parrot reunites them.
554
550-Bird, Horse, & PrincessTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThe type combines two different introductory episodes with a com mon main part.Introductory episodes: (1) Every night an unknown thief steals a golden apple from the king’s tree. The two elder princes fall asleep when they watch for the thief, but the youngest is successful. He sees a golden bird & shoots one of its colored (golden) feathers. (2) A sick king can only be healed by the singing of a golden bird. He orders a search for it. Main part: The three brothers go on a quest for the golden bird. The first two meet a fox (wolf) which they intend to shoot. The fox warns them against going to a pleasant inn in the village, but they go there never theless. Both of them forget their father & the bird. The youngest son is kind to the fox, follows its advice, & finds the golden bird. Against the fox’s advice he also takes its golden cage & thus wakes the guards. In order to save his life he has to go on a quest for a golden (magic) horse. Again, he also takes its golden bridle, so its guards awake, & he is condemned to death unless he brings a golden maiden (princess). With the fox’s help he succeeds & finally reaches home with the golden princess, the golden horse, & the golden bird. Against the fox’s advice he releases his brothers from the gallows. They steal the bird, the horse, & the princess, & try to kill the youngest brother. They pretend to their father that they have brought him the valuable things. The fox saves the life of the youngest brother (by using water of life). The golden bird, the horse, & the princess identify him as the man who res cued them. (He marries the princess) & his brothers are punished.) In some variants the king is healed by the bird’s singing.
555
551-The Water of LifeTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA sick king can only be healed by a wonderful remedy (water of life, rejuvenating apples, phoenix bird, etc.). Whoever brings it will inherit the kingdom. His three sons go on a quest. The two elder haughty ones are diverted from their goal. The youngest is single-minded & friendly towards old men (dwarf, eagle) who show him the way & give advice. With their help he reaches a magic castle that opens only for one hour. He appeases the animal guards (dragon, etc.) & finds everyone else asleep. He locates the fountain of life (golden apple tree) & takes the remedy. He sleeps with a beautiful woman (princess) & leaves his name (identification token) with her. When he leaves the castle it closes (sinks). On his way back he rejuvenates (releases) the helpful old men & receives magic objects in return. At home his unsuccessful brothers secretly exchange a common (poisoned) remedy for his healing one. They give it to the king & he recovers. These brothers slander the youngest & the king orders him to be killed. With the help of his magic objects he is able to escape this sentence. Meanwhile the beautiful woman in the magic castle has given birth to a boy & has discovered the name of the intruder. She arrives at the head of an army & demands the father of her son. The haughty brothers pretend it is they. They accompany her, riding beside the golden cloth (path) which the princess has spread, but they find that the gate at its end is closed. The youngest brother appears in rags, rides down the middle of the golden cloth toward the castle (is recognized by his tokens), & the gate opens for him. He marries the woman & becomes the ruler of the kingdom. The old king learns what really happened.
556
552-The Girls Who Married AnimalsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Following the wish of his dead father & against his brothers’ advice, the youngest son marries his three sisters to the first suitors who come for them. The suitors take the girls home with them. On a quest for his sisters, the brother reaches the castles of his brothers-in-law & learns that they are the masters of the three animal kingdoms (men transformed to animals). They receive their brother-in-law in a friendly way & provide him with magic means (parts of their body, feathers, hair, etc.) to use to call them at any time (he leaves a signal of distress). With their help he accomplishes difficult tasks & finally marries a woman (princess). (He is dismembered by an ogre, summons the brothers-in-law, & they resuscitate him; They also recover his lost castle). (2) Three girls who despair of being married say that they will marry anyone even if the suitors are animals. Three animals pass by & take along the three girls as wives. When the girls’ father visits his daughters, he finds food & other things magically pro-vided by the brothers-in-law. Later (at home) he tries the same method without success (his effort nearly ends tragically).
557
554-The Grateful AnimalsTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with helpful deeds of grateful animals. In numerous tales the type occurs only as episode. Most of the variants present the following basic structure: A man while travelling meets three animals (from air, water & earth) who are in trouble. Because he rescues them, they promise to help him if needed. Later he falls in love with a princess whose father sets three impossible tasks for him to accomplish. With the help of the grateful animals he succeeds on three successive days & wins the princess.In some variants a part is added in which the man accompanies his elder brothers. When they try to injure some animals, he prevents them from doing so or compensates for their misdeeds & carelessness. When they trample on an ant-hill, he builds it up again, when they leave wounded animals, he takes care of them, etc.
558
555-The Fisherman & his WifeTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA poor old fisherman rescues a super-natural being (magic fish, other animal, divine being, saint, ogre, man in form of animal) from distress (danger of death, imprisonment, transformation). Or the fisherman puts a fish back into the water. In return the magic being grants him (and his wife) that all his wishes will be fulfilled.In the beginning they profit only moderately, but later the wife becomes excessively demanding (e.g. they wish to become noblemen, kings, & finally even God himself). The fish (spirit) takes back his gift & the couple is returned to their former poor condition or punished in addition (transformed to animals).
559
556F*The Shepherd in the Service of a WitchTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA father sends one of his three sons to tend the cattle (sheep, etc.) of a landlord who is a soothsayer (prince of sun, witch). When the boy drives the cattle to pasture, they suddenly disappear (in the forest, crossing a brook). He cannot follow them because he is confined in a tree (by a supernatural woman). After a while the cattle return, but he does not know where they have been or what they have eaten. Consequently he has not accomplished his task (and is punished). Then his brother tries, but he also loses the cattle. When the youngest brother tends the cattle, he succeeds with the help of the animals (the woman who had caught his brothers in the tree). By following the cattle, he learns that they transform themselves to women (daughters of the witch) during their absence. So he has accomplished his task.
560
559-DungbeetleTales of Magic (300-749)500-559 Supernatural HelpersA (stupid, poor) boy (farmer’s son, smith, soldier, old man) buys various animals with special qualities (from a super-natural being): a mouse (rat), a (dung-) beetle, & a crayfish (ant, bee, cricket, louse, flea, lizard). Or he meets (finds) the animals on his way & takes them along. The king promises his melancholy daughter to any man who can make her laugh. The boy accomplishes this by means of the amusing actions of his animals (dancing, playing music). But he is not accepted as a bridegroom & is thrown into a lion’s den. He is rescued by his animals, who also drive out the boy’s rival (prince) by their characteristic behaviors: The dungbeetle carries away the prince’s excrement, the mouse makes him sneeze, etc., or they torment him for three nights in such a way that he does not touch the princess but soils the bed instead. The king sends him away & the boy marries the princess.
561
560-The Magic RingTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA boy buys a dog, a cat, & a snake in order to save them from death (he rescues a snake from burning). In return he receives a magic ring (stone) from the king of the snakes (father of the rescued snake) which will grant all wishes (he finds the ring). With his wishing ring he builds a magic castle & performs impossible tasks (building a castle, a bridge of glass, a church of wax, etc. in one night). He marries the princess, who has a lover. The wishing ring is stolen from him by the princess (by her lover, another person) who wishes herself & the castle (with the princess) to be transported to a faraway island. Her husband finds himself poor again. The grateful dog & cat swim to the castle & recover the ring with the help of a mouse. On their way back they lose the ring in the sea, but a fish (cray-fish) gives it back to them. Finally the boy recovers his ring, the castle & his wife. He punishes the lover (his faithless wife).
562
561-AladdinTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA magician orders a (stupid) boy, Aladdin, to fetch a lamp for him out of a cave of treasures. The cave opens & closes by means of a magic ring. Aladdin finds the lamp, but when he wants to leave the cave it does not open (the magician has closed it). When Aladdin rubs the magic ring (lamp) in despair, a helpful genie appears & leads him out. Aladdin reaches his mother’s house & wishes for riches & a castle. Both wishes are fulfilled by the genie (by another spirit who appears in the same way when the lamp or the ring is rubbed). Aladdin woos the princess, but her father intends to marry her to another man (Aladdin marries the princess.) The magician exchanges the old, magic lamp (which the princess had kept) for a new, worthless one. He wishes himself to be transfered to Africa together with the princess & the castle. Aladdin is imprisoned. He rubs the ring & the genie takes him to the castle where the princess is. She poisons the magician (Aladdin kills him). Aladdin takes the lamp again & uses it to return with the castle & the princess to his home.
563
562-The Spirit in the Blue LightTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA discharged soldier (deserter) is asked by an old woman (witch) to fetch for her a fire-steel (light, tinder-box, candle) from an underground treasury (magic castle) guarded by dogs. He keeps it for himself (kills the old woman). He discovers that when he lights the fire-steel a helpful spirit (dogs, iron man, giant) appears. He orders the spirit to bring the princess to him during three successive nights. She has to serve him (he kisses her, impregnates her). The king tries to discover where his daughter goes by putting a mark on the door. The spirit discovers the ruse & defeats it by putting the same mark on all the houses. The third time the soldier takes the princess, he is discovered (gives up himself) & imprisoned. He asks for his fire-steel, & before he is executed he asks for permission to smoke for one last time. When he lights his fire-steel, the spirit appears & rescues him (and imprisons the king instead). By threatening violence the soldier forces the king to agree that he may marry his daughter. In some variants the spirit is disenchanted by being beheaded or when the candle is burned up.
564
563-Table, Donkey, & StickTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA (poor) man receives from a supernatural being (God, devil, wind) a table that covers itself with food (tablecloth, etc.). On his way home he stays in an inn & others see him use the table (he forbids others to use it). The innkeeper cheats him by exchanging the magic table (cloth) with an ordinary one. After the poor man arrives home the table does not have any magic power, so he goes back to the giver & complains. The giver gives him a gold-dropping animal (donkey, hen, etc.). The same thing happens again. This time the man receives a sack containing a magic cudgel (mannikin) that beats people until it is called off by its owner. The man himself is beaten by the cudgel. When the greedy innkeeper tries to steal the sack, the cudgel beats him until he returns all the stolen magic objects.
565
564-Magic Providing PurseTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA supernatural being (devil, spir-its, fortune, frost, wind) gives a poor man an object (knapsack, sack, purse, pot, box) that supplies him with unlimited food. The man takes it home to his family. A rich man (brother, neighbor) buys (borrows, steals) the magic object, & soon the poor man is hungry again. He asks the super-natural being for a replacement & receives a similar looking object. But this one produces men with cudgels (whips) instead of food; they beat him & his family. The poor man gives the object to his rich neighbor. He is beaten until he returns the food-supplying object to the poor man.In some variants the last scene occurs at a meal organized by the rich man & all his guests are beaten.
566
565-The Magic MillTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA poor man receives a ham from his rich brother (the devil) who tells him to “go to the devil” with it. An old man directs him to the devil, where he exchanges his ham for a mill that grinds anything its owner wishes (meal, salt, other food; a pot that fills itself with porridge). Only its owner can command it to stop. The poor man becomes rich. His envious brother buys (steals) the mill, but he does not know how to stop it. It grinds such a quantity of food (flour, herrings, porridge, etc.) that the man is overpowered (it fills the whole house with porridge). The real owner stops it & takes it back again. Often combined with the following episode: A ship-captain steals (buys) the mill & commands it to grind salt. He also cannot stop it, & it grinds so much salt that his ship finally sinks. The mill keeps grinding at the bottom of the sea, & this is why sea-water is salty.
567
566-Three Magic Objects & The Wonderful FruitsTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic Objects(Fortunatus.) Three brothers (soldiers, a young man) each receive a magic object from a supernatural being (man-nikin, enchanted princess): a purse that fills itself, a coat or cap that takes its owner anywhere, a horn or whistle that furnishes soldiers or brings power). The king notices the glamorous life-style of the owner of the purse. By a ruse (by playing cards) the princess steals the purse (magic objects). Its owner gets the magic objects of his brothers, & they are stolen as well. He eats magic fruits (apple, fig, nut, vegetables, magic drink) that cause & cure disfigurement (horns grow on the head, & are removed). He gives (sells) the princess the magic fruits & horns grow on her head (she grows a long nose, is transformed into a donkey). He sells her the healing fruits only when she confesses her theft & promises to return his magic objects.
568
567-The Magic Bird- HeartTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA man eats the heart of a magic bird & thereby receives the power of spitting gold (of finding a coin under his pillow every day, he becomes king). A woman (his own wife) causes him to vomit the bird-heart, eats it herself (because she learned its secret from an old woman) & casts him out. He finds a magic herb that transforms people into donkies. With the help of the herb he changes the woman to donkey (and makes it work hard). In some variants he changes the woman back to a human being & marries her.
569
567AMagic Bird-Heart & Separated BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsTwo brothers condemned to death (whose stepmother claims they have insulted her ) are spared. They eat parts of a magic bird (magic object, magic fruit, etc.) that will make one become a king, & the other produce gold (precious stones) when laughing (crying). (The magic bird is prepared as a meal for another person [by their mother] but the brothers eat it by mistake.) The brothers flee & are separated (when fetching water). The elder brother is chosen as king (with the help of a royal elephant). The younger brother is enslaved by a foreign king who forces him to produce gold (he falls into the hands of a shipowner who sacrifices him so that his becalmed ship may sail. He is cast overboard, arrives in a distant land, & wins a [several] brides). Finally the brothers are reunited & the younger brother is freed (the elder searches for his younger brother & finds him).
570
569-The Knapsack, the Hat, & the HornTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsThe youngest of three poor brothers obtains a magic object (table-cloth, napkin, table, mill) that magically produces food. On his way he exchanges the object for a knapsack that can produce an army (magic weapon, stick, sabre, cudgel out of the sack). By means of this he secures the first object again. In the same way he gets other magic objects that function as weapons (hat), make walls fall down (horn), provide him with unlimited quantities of money, let him cover enormous distances (seven-league boots, flying carpet), produce a castle (etc.), or resuscitate the dead (violin, flute). Back home he lives a glamorous life. The magic objects are stolen from him by a cunning guest (king, princess, neighbor). By using the last object he recovers them all. With the help of the magic horn he destroys the attacking army & kills the king & his daughter; or, he resuscitates the people he has killed, makes peace with the king, marries the princess, & inherits (half of) the kingdom.In some variants the king is attacked by enemies. The boy rescues him from danger using his magic objects, & marries the princess.
571
570-Rabbit-HerdTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA king offers his daughter in marriage to whoever can herd (catch, tame, train) his 100 (more or fewer) rabbits (roost-ers, sheep, goats, geese, partridges) without losing any. The youngest of three brothers is kind to an old woman (to whom his brothers were unkind) & receives a magic whistle with which he can summon the rabbits. In order to avoid the mar-riage, members (deputies) of the royal family (in disguise) try to buy one of his rabbits. The young man demands a degrading humili ating act (e.g. jumping on one leg, dancing to the whistle, turning somer-saults, attaching a pot to his or her bottom, being beaten, cutting flesh out of his/her own body, branding his/her skin, tearing an animal carcass with teeth, kissing the backside of an animal or of a person, sodomy, eating excrement, kissing him or sleeping with him). After the demands are fulfilled, the young man whistles & the rabbit comes back to him.Not willing to admit defeat, the king sets another task: the young man should fill a sack of lies (truths). When the king real-izes that the “lies” are actually truths that humiliate the royal family, he announces that the sack is filled up & agrees to the marriage.
572
570*Rat-Catcher (Pied Piper)Tales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic Objects(The Pied Piper of Hamelin.) A city has been over-run by rats & mice. A man dressed in odd, colorful clothing promises the inhabitants that he will drive the vermin out in return for a fee. He lures the animals out by playing a flute & drowns them in a river. The citizens refuse to pay him (to keep their promise) & the piper goes away empty-handed. Later, he comes back disguised as a hunter. He plays his flute & all the children follow him out of the city. He leads them into a mountain, & they are never seen again.
573
570AThe Princess & the Magic ShellTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsIn his third catch of fish, a fisherman finds a golden dish (cup, shell, fish-skin) which, whenever someone drinks from it, fills itself with gold pieces. A princess (queen) wants the dish, & he agrees to give it to her if she will sleep with him. She becomes pregnant & is banished by her father (husband). She goes (with the fisherman, alone after he has been killed) to another country where she becomes wealthy (with the help of the vessel). She disguises herself as a man & returns home. Her father wants to have the magic dish, & she says she will give it to him if he will sleep with her. He agrees. She reveals who she is & exposes his hypocrisy. They are reconciled.
574
571-"All Stick Together"Tales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA melancholy princess is promised in mar-riage to whoever can make her laugh. The youngest (most stupid) of three brothers (poor shepherd, son of a farmer or craftsman) receives a magic object (golden animal, vehicle) from an old woman (man, supernatural being) because of his kindness (out of pity, through a lucky bargain). On his way (during an overnight stay) a curious person (thief) touches the object & cannot let it go (the young man makes the person stick to it by a magic formula or stick). Later other (naked) people, objects, & animals become attached to the magic object or to each other. This strange looking parade passes by the castle where the princess sees it & laughs for the first time in her life. The young man marries her (and gets half of the kingdom).
575
571BLover ExposedTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA man falls in love with the wife of a smith (crafts-man, farmer). In order to get rid of the husband he denounces him to the master (of the castle), pretending that the husband practices magic. The master thereupon orders him to perform (three) impossible tasks, of which the last one is to make a “Himphamp” – a fictional word without any meaning. The husband gets help (from the devil, supernatural being) to solve the tasks, the last one by a magic formula that makes things stick together. He surprises the loving couple in bed & makes them stick together (to the chamber pot). Or, a man learns that his wife has commited adultery. By means of a magic sticking formula (magician) he makes the loving couple (clergyman & his wife) stick naked to the chamber pot (basin). Helpful servants get also stuck. The next day the man leads the chain of persons through the streets. Other people (farmhand, maidservant), animals (cow, bull) & objects (food) get stuck in obcene situations & are mocked by passersby. The man presents his “Himphamp” to the master. All are released, & the guilty ones are punished, made to pay compen-sation, or pardoned. They promise to reform, they escape, or they drown themselves.
576
571CThe Biting DollTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA kind girl (boy) receives a magic doll (goose) that defecates money. An envious neighbor borrows the doll, but it soils her house & she throws it out on the street. When the king, who has stopped to relieve himself, uses the doll to wipe himself, it bites his backside & sticks to him (bites him when he passes by). Nobody can remove the doll from the king’s body. He announces that any one who can release him will get a reward. Only the girl is able to make the doll stop biting. She recovers her doll & marries the king
577
572*The Barking Dog's Head, the Striking Axe, etc.Tales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA man (the youngest of three brothers) finds singing, screaming or barking men’s or animal’s heads, self striking axes, singing plants, etc. & puts them all into a sack. When he empties the sack before the melancholy princess (other actions), he makes her laugh for the first time. As reward he marries the princess or he receives land (food & lodging).
578
575-The Prince's WingsTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsRival workmen have a contest to construct the most wonderful object. A goldsmith builds an artificial fish (something else), a joiner constructs an artificial flying object (folding wings, bird, mechanical horse with wings). A prince buys the flying object & flies with it in a foreign country in order to see the princess (who is enclosed in a tower by the king). He becomes her lover, & impregnates her (is taken in the very act). When the king learns what has happened, he orders the prince (and his daughter) to be executed. The lovers escape by riding together on the flying object to the prince’s home country, where they marry.In some variants they land on their way so the princess can give birth. When fetching fire the flying object is burned. The lovers are separated (and later reunited).
579
576-The Magic KnifeTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA young man steals a magic knife from a robbers’ castle, kills the robbers with it, & wins a clergyman’s daughter. He defeats his rival by means of the knife.
580
577-The King's TasksTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsThe king promises his daughter to whoever is able to perform certain difficult tasks. Two elder brothers are unkind to a supernatural being (old woman), whereas the youngest is kind. He receives (finds) magic objects (self-chopping axe, self-digging shovel, self-playing violin, etc.). With their help he is able to perform the tasks (to fell a large oak in one day & in the same time to dig a well at his court, etc.) & win the princess.
581
580-Beloved of WomenTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsAt their father’s death three brothers are each granted a wish: the two elder ones wish for riches, but the youngest wishes for the power to make women love him. They set out on a journey & spend the night in three different inns. The youngest brother sleeps with the wife (daughter) of the house & receives three magic objects: a tablecloth on which food magically appears, a rooster (similar) that produces drinks, & a pair of scissors that produces clothes out of nothing. The brothers reach a town where all who enter must be castrated. The youngest refuses & is taken as a prisoner to an island. With the help of his magic objects he secures a comfortable life for himself & the other prisoners. A princess (king’s widow) wants to buy the objects. The boy is only willing to give them to her if he may spend the night in her chamber, beside her, & finally in her bed. At the end he marries her.
582
585-Spindle, Shuttle, & NeedleTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA prince will marry the girl who is at once the poorest & the richest. Spindle, shuttle, & needle help a virtuous girl out of gratitude for her industry. The spindle guides the prince to her, the shuttle makes a magic road, & the needle transforms the poor room to a beautiful one. The prince marries the girl.
583
