590-Faithless MotherTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA boy sets out on a journey with his mother. On their way he finds an object (armband, belt, sword, shirt, etc.) which gives him super-natural strength. In a house of robbers (giants, other supernatural beings) the son defeats all of them until only one is left with whom his mother (secretly) starts a liaison (she marries him).In order to get rid of the son (the lover fears the son’s strength) the mother feigns sickness & sends her son on a dangerous quest for a remedy (fruit [apple] from the garden of supernatural beings, water of life, animal’s milk) for which he must risk his life. The son returns successful & uninjured, accompanied by wild animals that have become his protectors. In numerous variants the boy rescues a young girl (princess) during one of his adventures & sends (brings) her back to her father, and/or he meets female helpers (old woman, a girl skilled in magic, his bride). The boy’s mother asks him for the secret of his strength & steals it (ties him, gives him a narcotic drink, persuades him to take a bath). Then she (and/or her lover) blinds (murders) the boy. When he is blinded he is found by the princess, who nurses & restores his sight by observing how a blind animal is healed. When he is murdered he is resuscitated by one of his female helpers (using the remedies he procured). He recovers the object that holds his strength & takes revenge on his mother & her lover (kills them). He marries the princess (female helper, daughter of the helper).
584
591-The Thieving PotTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA poor man (farmer, orphan boy) receives (in exchange for his cow) a magic pot which goes to his neighbors where it fills itself with food, money, etc. Then the pot takes its contents back to its owner. When the person whom it robbed tries to catch the pot, it takes him to its poor owner where it has to be redeemed (the theft has to be forgiven). Or, the pot takes the man to hell.
585
592-The Dance Among ThornsTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA poor boy, driven from home by his evil stepmother (dismissed from service with a pittance), gives all his money as alms to a beggar (supernatural being) who in return grants the boy three wishes: a never failing gun (crossbow), a fiddle (flute) that compels people to dance, another magic object or the magic power of having his wishes obeyed. He shoots a bird (on a wager), which falls into a thornbush. When a monk (Jew, the loser of the wager) tries to take the bird out, the boy’s magic fiddle makes him dance in the thorns. The boy is condemned & led to the gallows. He asks for permission to play his fiddle for the last time. The judge & whole assembly have to dance until the boy is released.
586
593-FiddevavTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA poor boy intends to marry a young woman but her father (she herself) refuses. The rejected suitor receives from a person skilled in magic (old woman, witch, priest, devil) a magic stone, which, when put into ashes, makes all people who use it (farmer, farmwife, farmhand, maidservant, preacher, daughter, etc.) stick to the poker & compells them to keep talking nonsense (e.g. “Fiddevav”), (or, a magic root under the doorstep causes them fart). Only the suitor is able to release the people from the charm by taking the magic object away. In return he marries the young woman.
587
594*The Magic BridleTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA boy, setting out, obtains a bridle that tames all kinds of horses, a needle that makes everything fall to pieces, & a gun that always hits what he aims at. The boy works as a servant at the king’s court. By means of his magic objects he performs great exploits & wins a princess as his wife.
588
610-The Healing FruitTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA sick princess is offered to whoever can cure her (with fruit). The youngest of three brothers succeeds. He is kind to a little man (old woman, grateful animals), who gives him the healing fruit, after his elder brothers had reacted with annoyance at the little man’s questions. Before the marriage takes place, the king gives the youngest brother impossible tasks. The little man helps him again. He has to build a ship that moves faster on land than on water, to herd 100 rabbits, & to fetch a feather from a magic bird. He performs the tasks, makes a fortune, returns, humbles the king, & marries the princess. Or, the king copies him in order to gain the same riches. On the way across a lake the ferryman drops him into the water & he is drowned. The young suitor gains his kingdom & marries the princess.
589
611-The Gifts of the DemonsTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsThe son of a merchant is betrothed to the daughter of another merchant (the adoptive son of a merchant falls in love with the merchant’s daughter). When the boy’s father dies, the girl’s parents change their minds & send the boy to sea to get rid of him. The ship sinks but the boy saves himself (on an island). He rescues a child (from a lion, wolf, eagle, dragon, bad man) & receives a magic remedy (magic salve, healing water) as reward from demoniac women (dwarfs, trolls, giants) with which he heals a sick princess (king), & a magic sword (spec-tacles, binoculars, flute, whistle, bone, gun) with which he overcomes a hostile army. He returns home a rich man & marries the bride who had been promised to him in childhood (his first love).
590
612-The Three Snake-LeavesTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic ObjectsA man promises his wife (bride) that if she dies before him he will be buried with her (to keep watch at her grave ). She soon (after the wedding) dies. In the grave (at the graveside) he sees a snake (weasel) revive another dead snake with a herb (three leaves, blade of grass). He revives his wife in the same manner. His wife then falls in love with another man (ship’s captain) and, together with her new lover, she throws her husband into the sea. Or, she leaves her husband & by a ruse causes him to be con-demned to death (as a thief). A faithful servant (friend, his mother) resuscitates him with the snake-leaves. The guilty pair is exposed & punished. In some Indian variants, a god permits a man to resuscitate his wife by giving her half of his own lifespan. She falls in love with another man & tries to kill her husband. He is rescued & asks his wife to return the given years he gave her. She dies for a second time.
591
613-The Two TravelersTales of Magic (300-749)560-649 Magic Objects(Truth & Falsehood.) Two men (travelers, brothers, tailor & cobbler) argue (wager) about whether truth or falsehood (justice or unjustice, whose religion) is more powerful. They call on animals & people they meet to act as judges. The loser (the one who stands for the truth) is robbed & blinded, or the wicked man shares his bread with his hungry companion only if he will let his eyes be put out. The blind man spends the night in (under) a tree, where he overhears secrets of birds (other animals, devils, ogres, witches). By means of this knowledge he is able to restore his sight, to cure sickness (of the princess, king), to end drought, etc. He is rewarded (marries the princess). His companion, intending to acquire the same wealth, imitates him. He goes to the same tree (sometimes also blinded), but the birds (devils) think it was he who betrayed their secrets, & tear him to pieces.
592
650AStrong JohnTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA young man, born of an animal (son of a bear) or from a giant (troll-woman, forged from iron by a smith) develops great strength (at the forge, in the forest, in war, by suckling for many years, by his great appetite, by tests of strength, etc.). Because of his enormous appetite he is sent away from home. He works for a smith but (often) injures his master, who tries to get rid of him by setting trials of strength. The strong man has to uproot trees, to catch wolves & bears (lions, etc.), to tame devils, etc. When he is sent to catch wild animals, he harnesses them to a coach. When he is in a well & a millstone (bell) is thrown on him, he wears it as collar or complains that chickens are scratching dirt onto him. When he is sent to the devil’s mill (hell), he drives the devil to his master’s house. When he goes to the king to be paid, the king shoots him (in vain) with cannons. The strong man accomplishes every task & overcomes all difficulties (kills his master & finally marries).
593
650BThe Quest for a Strong CompanionTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA young man seeks a strong adversary to wrestle with. He stays overnight in a hut where two strong men live. When he discovers them, he secretly runs away.In his flight he meets a giant plowman & begs him to conceal him from the strong men in pursuit. The giant plowman hides the young man in his trousers (pocket), & fights the two men.
594
650CYouth Who Bathed in Blood of a DragonTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ Knowledge(Siegfried of the Nibelungenlied.) A strong young man slays a dragon & bathes himself in its blood. Thereafter he has a tough skin which no weapon can penetrate. He dies from a wound in the only vulnerable spot on his body – his armpit, which the dragon’s blood has not touched.
595
652-The Prince Whose Wishes Always Come TrueTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA godfather (God, Christ, beggar, soldier, Virgin Mary, etc.) gives a prince the power to make all his wishes come true. An envious person (servant, gardener, cook, smith, general, dwarf, court jester, etc.) learns about the prince’s extraordinary ability, & kidnaps the boy. The servant smears blood on the queen’s mouth (clothes), so she is accused of killing & eating her son, & is im-prisoned. The prince is rescued & reared by foster-parents (woodsman). The kidnapper uses the prince’s magic power by telling him to wish for riches (castle). Later the prince falls in love with his foster-parents’ daughter (a playmate he had wished for ), who tells him of his true iden-tity. The prince transforms his kidnapper into a dog & his sweetheart into a carnation (lily, rose) & goes with them to his father’s court where he takes service as a huntsman. He iden-tifies himself to his father. The queen is released & the male factor is punished. The prince restores his sweetheart to human form & marries her.
596
653-The Four Skillful BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeThree (four or more) brothers leave home & acquire extraordinary skills. The first is a huntsman, the second a ship-builder (astronomer), the third a thief (the fourth a tailor). When they return home they demonstrate their skills to their father. They all help to rescue a princess who was captured by a dragon: The ship-builder builds a fast ship to carry them to the island where the princess is imprisoned (the astronomer discovers the place of her imprisonment), the thief steals her, & the huntsman shoots the dragon (the tailor sews the ship destroyed by the dragon back together). Later each of the brothers claims that he should marry the princess. In some variants either their dispute remains unresolved, or the brothers’ father marries the princess. She may decide herself whom to marry. Sometimes it is proposed that she should be divided, & only her true lover objects (Solomon’s judgment). Or, the winning suitor is decided by lot, or the brothers are given money or half the kingdom instead.
597
653ARarest Thing in the WorldTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA princess is offered to whichever of three suitors (friends, brothers) brings the best (rarest, most precious) thing in the world (three men with extraordinary abilities woo the princess). They acquire wonderful (magic) objects: a mirror (telescope, spectacles) which shows everything that is happening in the world, a flying coat (flying carpet) & a fruit (apple, lemon, etc.) or an ointment that heals (resuscitates). When they meet they use the telescope to see that the princess is sick (dead). They go to her immediately with the carpet & use the fruit to heal her (restore her to life). A dispute follows as to who is to marry her. (She chooses the one who loves her most.)
598
653BThe Suitors Restore the Maiden to LifeTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA woman loved by three (four) suitors dies. The first keeps watch at her funeral pyre, the second takes her ashes to the river (Ganges), the third (a wandering beggar) learns a magic formula that restores her to life. A dispute follows as to who is to marry her. Usually the problem is solved in a philosophic explanation: The one who brought the woman back to life is like her father; the one who carried her ashes to the river is like her son; the one who watched the funeral pyre is like her husband & therefore may marry her.
599
654-The Three Agile BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeThree brothers are sent out by their father to acquire skills. The one who learns best will inherit the house. The first becomes a smith, the second a barber, the third a fencer. When they are asked to demonstrate their skills, the smith shoes a horse while it is galloping, the barber shaves a running rabbit, the fencer circulates his sword so fast that he stays dry in a heavy rain. The father either chooses one of his sons, or, he leaves his property to all three of them.
600
655-The Wise BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA father leaves his wealth to his three sons. One of them steals diamonds (pieces of gold) that had been willed to all three brothers. In order to settle the case they consult a wise man. On their way they see tracks of an animal & make the following deductions: It was a camel (horse, pack-animal), it was one-eyed (grass is eaten on one side of the road only), it was lame (because of its tracks), it was carrying oil or honey, etc. (drops are seen on the ground), it had no tail (dung on a heap instead of being spread by the tail), etc. When they meet the owner of the lost animal he overhears their remarks, takes them for thieves, & brings them to the judge. They explain their observations to the judge & are absolved. When they are invited for dinner (by the judge) they say the meat is dogmeat, the wine (bread) smells like a corpse, & their host is a bastard. On investigation all their statements are found to be true. The animal had been suckled by a bitch, the vine (corn) had grown on a cemetery, & the mother (of the judge) confesses her adultery.In some variants the judge tells the story of the noblest act in order to settle the dispute of the inheritance. Based on his reaction he declares the youngest to be the thief. Or, the brothers are asked to shoot on their father’s corpse, so that their behavior discloses the real son & heir. In other versions the judge enforces another test of paternity, or he pronounces another of Solomon’s judgments.
601
660-The Three DoctorsTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeThree doctors display their skills. One removes one of his eyes, the second one his hand (arm, finger) & the third his stomach (heart), intending to replace it later. During the night a cat eats the body parts. A servant substitutes the eye of a cat, the hand of a thief & the stomach of a hog (heart), & the doctors replace them without injury. The one with the cat’s eye can see best at night (always looks for mice), the one with the thief’s hand steals, & the one with the hog’s stomach is always hungry (sniffs & roots at the ground).
602
664*The Soldier Hypnotizes the InnkeeperTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A soldier (passerby) in an inn pays with pieces of gold that turn out to be buttons (small bones). When the innkeeper takes the soldier to court, the soldier hypnotizes the judge so that he thinks a flood is occuring. He is forced to go through a series of adventures without leaving the room. Returning to his senses, the judge acquits the soldier. (2) A soldier tells tales & by his magic power makes an inn-keeper believe that he is a bear, that the soldier is a wolf, & that they are being chased by dogs, etc. The innkeeper falls out of his bed & comes to his senses.
603
665-The Man Who Flew like a Bird & Swam Like a FishTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA man (youngest of three brothers, cheated heir) is given the power of transforming himself into animals of earth, air, & water by an old man in return for his hospitality (construction of a bridge) or by grateful animals whom he had helped. He goes into the service of a king who has departed for war & has forgotten an (two) important object (magic sword, magic ring, telescope, war documents, gloves). The king promises his daughter to whoever can deliver the forgotten object immediately. The soldier offers his help. He reaches the castle fast by swimming as a fish, flying as a bird, & running as a rabbit. He presents himself to the princess in his different transformations. She gives him the forgotten object & keeps a piece of his scale, pelt, a bit of fur, & a feather for herself. On his return the soldier is killed by an envious rival. The murderer takes the forgotten object & claims the reward. When the princess asks to see a second demonstration of the trans-formations, the cheater fails. She refuses to marry him & her father threatens to execute her. The soldier, resuscitated by his magic helpers, arrives at the last moment, proves his identity (identification by feather & marries the princess. The cheater is condemned to death.)
604
666*Hero & LeanderTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeDuring the feast of Adonis in Sestos, Leander sees Hero, a priestess of Aphrodite, falls in love with her at first sight, & wins her love. Hero has been consigned to celibacy, so the lovers can only meet secretly. Leander swims every night through the Hellespont strait to see Hero who shines a light from the tower for him. One stormy night the light goes out & Leander is drowned. Hero sees his body & plunges into the sea to be united with him in death.
605
667-The Wood Spirit's Foster-SonTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA boy, who had been promised by his father in a crisis to a wood spirit (demon, drakos), receives from the latter the power to transform himself into various animals. He frees a princess who had been kidnapped by the demon, & is thrown into the sea by a treacherous nobleman who claims to have rescued the princess. The cheater is exposed, & the boy marries the princess.
606
670-Man Who Understands Animal LanguagesTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA grateful snake gives a man the power to understand animal languages, & tells him that if he reveals the secret, he must die. Once the man hears animals talking & laughs. His curious wife insists on knowing why he does so. Worn down by her nagging, he is about to give in & tell her. Then he hears a rooster say how easily he rules his many wives, while the man cannot rule even his one wife. The man keeps his secret & does not tell her anything.
607
670AWoman Who Understands Animal LanguagesTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA newly married woman who knows animal languages hears jackals (other animals) saying that a corpse floating in the river has a valuable ring on its finger. She pulls the corpse from the river & removes the ring. (In order to remove the ring she has to bite off the finger. Her husband sees her, believes her to be a cannibal ogress, & decides to return her to her family.) En route she overhears animals (birds) talking about where a treasure is hidden. Her husband learns the truth & they are reconciled. (The husband stays to guard the treasure & the wife goes to get her father-in-law. When he sees her returning alone, he concludes she has killed his son & is returning to kill him, & slays her before she has a chance to speak.)
608
671-The Three LanguagesTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA young man learns the languages of dogs, birds, & frogs. His father, angry at such useless knowledge, drives him out & orders him to be killed. A compassionate servant lets him escape & substitutes an animal’s heart as proof for the murder. By means of his knowledge of the dogs’ language the boy Discovers a treasure (he cures a sick princess & marries her later). Through his knowledge of the frogs’ language he learns that he will be elected pope. When he arrives in Rome, two doves come to sit on his shoulders & he is recognized as a man worthy of being pope (birds indicate his election as pope). The two doves tell him what to do so that he will be elected pope, & give him advice on how to act.
609
671D*To Die Next DayTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA farmer, overhearing the conversation of animals talking (during Christmas, New Year’s or Easter night), finds that he is to die (is warned of death) the next day (very soon). The prediction comes true.
610
671E*A Magic BoyTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA boy understands the language of birds & can in-terpret dreams. A merchant takes the boy in payment for goods & orders him to be slaughtered. He wants to eat the boy’s heart & liver in order to obtain his wisdom. The boy escapes. The merchant is called to the king to interpret a dream. He cannot do this. The boy arrives, interprets the dream, & exposes the merchant.
611
672-Serpent's CrownTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a serpent’s crown. (1) A man steals a serpent’s crown. When the serpent pursues him he throws his garment behind him. A cook cooks the crown & learns the language of animals (and/or receives wealth). (2) A girl finds the crown (stone) of a serpent which it had laid down (lost). The serpent dies (kills itself from sorrow). (3) A good-natured maidservant shares milk with a (sick) serpent (wearing a crown) & is chased away by a farmer. When the maidservant marries a (rich) shepherd, the serpent, still grateful for the milk, appears at her wedding & lays down its crown of silver & gold. Or, the serpent gives her its crown in return for her sharing her milk. Later, the maidservant, at her wedding, thanks the snake for its help & returns the crown.
612
672B*Expelling SnakesTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA sorcerer undertakes to expel snakes from a certain region. He succeeds in decoying the king of the snakes (white crowned snake), but dies from a snakebite (is carried off into the earth with the snakes).
613
672C*Testimony of the SerpentTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA woman who owns (is friendly with) a magic serpent is raped by a prince. The woman asks the serpent, who witnessed the act of violence, to testify that the prince should marry no one else. (A prince calls a serpent to witness that he will marry a farmwife.) When the prince is about to marry a beautiful princess, the serpent twists itself about his neck. The first woman comes & frees him from the serpent on the condition that he marries her. (The serpent appears at the prince’s wedding, twists itself about his neck, & unwinds itself only when he will marry the farmwife.)
614
672DThe Stone of the SnakeTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA farmer falls into a pit in which there are serpents (and a dragon). He sees a serpent licking a (white) stone, imitates it & stays alive without food or drink. Finally (in spring-time) he is rescued from the pit by a big serpent.
615
673-The White Serpent's FleshTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeContrary to a warning, a servant (cook) eats the flesh of a white serpent (from the king’s pot), whereupon he understands the speech of animals (birds). Or, a boy (driver) tastes the meat of a white snake that has been prepared by a healer (farmer), whereupon he understands the language of the grass & trees. When he is accused of stealing a ring this knowledge enables him to prove his innocence. By overhearing the conversation of ducks he learns that one of them has swallowed the queen’s ring that fell from the window. He orders the duck to be slaughtered, the ring is found, & he is saved. (He learns that the ring is in the stomach of a grateful fish, who brings it back.
616
674-Incest Averted by Talking AnimalsTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA princess, abandoned by or separated from her husband, gives birth to a son. The son is taken from her by trickery & he grows up without knowing his true mother. When grown up, he sees his mother, falls in love with her, & goes to her at night to become her lover. On the way he overhears animals (calves) talking & learns the truth.
617
675-The Lazy BoyTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA lazy stupid boy releases a fish (frog, serpent, supernatural being), which gives him the power of making all his wishes come true. The lazy boy then makes an axe cut trees itself, water carry itself, a wagon move itself, an oven carry him, etc. When the princess laughs at him, he wishes her pregnant (from eating an apple, etc.). She does not know the father of her beautiful child. The king orders a test of paternity, & the child picks the lazy boy out as father (by handing him an apple, ball, golden ball). The king orders father & mother (and child) to be abandoned in a cask in the sea (in the mountains). By the power of wishing they reach land. The young man wishes to be beautified & makes a castle appear next to the king’s. When the king comes to visit, the young man wishes that an object (golden apple, golden cup) would appear in his pocket. The king is accused of stealing. Thus he is shown that the appearance of guilt & innocence (unwitting pregnancy, unwitting theft) is often deceptive.
618
677-Iron is More Precious than GoldTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeAn unlucky man asks his king for advice about what he should do. The princess advises him to marry because the luck of his wife (children) could counteract his own bad luck. The king allows him to marry the princess. When she sends him out to sell her needlework, he trades it for (threefold) pieces of good advice. He does not dare to return home without any money & finds work on a ship. When the ship is becalmed, he is sent down to the bottom of the sea to repair it, & there he settles a quarrel between two spirits: What is more precious (more useful, harder): gold (diamond, silver, copper) or iron (steel, copper)? He gives a (diplomatic) answer (following the first good advice). He receives a bag of (precious) stones as a reward & re-turns to the ship. Together with the merchants he reaches a strange country where the king favors him because of his jewels. The merchants are jealous & make a bet as to who is the richest of them. Following the second advice, he wins the wager & with it all the servants & the ship. He continues to travel & trades for 7–30 years. Finally he returns home & finds his wife sleeping between two strange men. When he is about to kill all three, he remembers the third piece of advice, to think before he acts. He finds that the men are his two grown-up sons.
619
677*Below the SeaTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA boy (man) who is skilled in playing an instrument finds himself in a submarine kingdom, entertains the king of the sea, chooses a bride for himself, & returns to earth.
620
678-The King Transfers His Soul to a ParrotTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA king learns how to transfer his soul into dead bodies & so does his servant (another person). The king transfers his soul into a parrot, & the servant transfers his soul into the king’s body. The queen discovers the truth. She tricks the servant into leaving the body of the king, & the king returns to his own body.
621
681-The Relativity of TimeTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeThis misc. type comprises various tales mostly from China & other east Asian areas, dealing with a ruler who learns about the relativity of time. In Chinese variants he experiences a long space of time in a moment by having a dream (sometimes caused by drugs), in Indian variants by putting his head underwater, in other (often Asian) variants, the vision takes place by magic.
622
682-Meditation on the TrinityTales of Magic (300-749)650-699 Supernatural Power/ KnowledgeA man (philosopher, St. Augustine), meditating on the mystery of the Trinity, sees a child trying to empty the sea into a little hole at the shore. The child states that he could better bail out the sea with a thimble than the man would be able to understand the secret of the Trinity. The child disappears.
623
700-ThumblingTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural Tales(Tom Thumb) A childless couple wish for a child, however small he may be. They have a boy (by supernatural birth) the size of a thumb. Thumbling takes food to his father on the farm & drives the wagon (plow) by sitting in the horse’s (ox’s) ear. He allows himself to be sold to strangers & then runs away from them. He lets himself be sold to thieves & accompanies them while they steal. Thumbling either helps them or he betrays them by his shouting; he then robs the thieves. He is swallowed by a cow, talks from the cow’s insides & reappears (in the sausage prepared from the intestines of the slaughtered cow). Someone takes the intestines (sausage) and, frightened by Thumbling’s voice inside, throws them away. Thumbling is swallowed by a wolf (fox) who eats the intestines. He talks from the wolf’s belly & the wolf becomes sick & frightens (warns) shepherds. The wolf dies (is killed) & Thumbling is rescued, or he persuades the wolf to take him to his father’s house.
624
701-The Giant's ToyTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThe giant’s daughter takes a farmer with his plow & animals from a field, shows them to her father, & asks what sort of worms these are. The giant-father orders her to put the farmer back, because the farmer belongs to the race that will drive away the giants.
625
703*The Artificial ChildTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesAn aged, childless couple build (carve) them-selves a child from snow. When the child goes into the forest (jumps over a fire), it melts. Or a beautiful girl made from snow organizes a competition. She promises to marry any man who can overtake her on horseback, while she runs. By her magic actions (obstacles), she manages to leave all her suitors behind by magic actions (obstacles). The son of the emperor recognizes the magic, conjures the girl in the name of God to stop, & takes her up on his horseback. When they reach the top of a hill, the girl has disappearsed.In some variants the girl is made from gold & stays dumb until she is addressed by her name.
626
704-The Princess & the PeaTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA prince wants to marry a true princess, but he cannot find one. One evening a young woman arrives at his palace pretending to be a true princess. The queen tests her by putting a pea under 20 (more or fewer) mattresses in her bed. The next morning the woman complains that she has slept badly because of something hard in her bed. Her sensitivity is proof that she is a real princess. The prince marries her at once.
627
705ABorn from Fruit (Fish)Tales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA husband becomes pregnant by eating a magic fruit (fish) meant for his barren wife. He gives birth (from his knee) to a girl. The girl is abandoned & a bird rears her in a tree. A prince notices the reflected image of the (mute) girl in the water & falls in love with her. An old woman lures the girl down from the tree & she is captured & forced to marry the prince. The prince’s mother mutilates his wife during his absence & chases her away. The girl is given supernatural help. The prince’s mother disguises herself as his wife & they have sexual intercourse. The mother becomes pregnant & asks the servants to bring a special fruit. While looking for the fruit they hear a verse that reveals the truth, & they become mute. The prince himself looks for the fruit, learns the truth & is reunited with his wife. His mother is punished.
628
705A*The Banished WifeTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA prince grows tired of his wife because she cannot talk any more. He brings a new bride who insults the wife. The first wife starts to speak again. The prince rejects his new bride & lives with his first wife.
629
705BBorn from KneeTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA man gives birth from his knee to several children. He puts them up in a tree & advises them not to lower the rope. A giant (wolf, other being) induces a child to lower the rope. The giant climbs up the tree & devours the children. When the father returns & realizes what has happened he fights with the giant & opens its belly (toe). All the children come out & become the ancestors of the various ethnic groups.
630
706-The Maiden Without HandsTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA girl has her hands cut off because she refuses to marry her father (because her father has sold her to the devil, forbids her to pray, her sister-in-law has slandered her to her brother). She is exposed in the forest & eats fruit from a garden. A king finds her in the forest (garden, stable, sea) & marries her in spite of her mutilation. She gives birth but is cast out along with her children, because her parents-in-law (father, mother, sister-in-law, devil) alter a letter from the king. During her second banishment her hands grow back again, usually restored by water (river, well, sea water), often with supernatural help (angel, saint, Virgin Mary, God). She is reunited with her husband.
631
706BThe Chaste NunTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A young woman of noble birth (nun) mutilates herself (by cutting off her eyes, hands, breasts, hair) to prevent the persecutions of a lover. She sends her eyes which he had admired, to her lecherous lover (brother, nobleman, bishop). (2) A man (priest) is tempted by the devil. He mutilates himself in order to keep his chastity (not to be tempted by the beauty of a [adopted] girl)
632
706CThe Father who Wanted to Marry his DaughterTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural Tales(The Patient Helena, Helena of Constantinople, Mai & Beaflor.) Father (priest) wants to marry his daughter. She escapes, marries a prince, & gives birth to children. Her father kills the children (child) & puts a knife under her pillow as false evidence of murder. Her husband, believing that she has killed her children, condemns her. Her children are resuscitated by a miracle, & she is reconciled with her husband.
633
706DSt. Wilgefortis & her BeardTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA pagan king promises his daughter (Wilgefortis, Liberta, Ontkommer, Kümmernis), who is a Christian, in marriage to another pagan king who has conquered his country. The daughter wants only to become a bride of the crucified Christ. In order to evade the forced marriage she prays to God to alter her appearance, & suddenly she grows a beard. Her angry father has her nailed to a cross, so that she will be like her beloved. As she dies, she prays for all who suffer pain or sorrow. Her father’s palace burns down.In some versions (The Shoe of St. Anthony) an old musician (fid-dler) plays for the crucified woman before she dies. She (her picture) thanks him by giving him her gold (silver) shoe (ring). The shoe is discovered in the possession of the musician, who is condemned as a thief. On his way to the gallows he asks to be allowed to play again in the collonade of the church. As soon as he begins to play, the holy picture of the crucified woman drops the other shoe for him, thus proving his innocence.
634
707-The Three Golden ChildrenTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThree girls boast that if they marry the king they will have triplets with golden hair, a chain around the neck, & a star on the forehead. The king overhears the youngest & marries her. When she gives birth to three marvelous children the elder sis-ters substitute animals (dogs). She is imprisoned (banished), her children are exposed but are rescued by a miller (fisherman). When they have grown up, the eldest son sets out to find his father, to seek a speaking bird, a singing tree, or the water of life. He & his brother both fail & are transformed to marble columns. The sister, with the help of an old woman, succeeds in rescuing them & in bringing back the magic objects. The attention of the king is drawn to the children & the magic objects. The bird of truth reveals the whole story. The children & their mother are restored; the sisters are punished
635
708-The Wonder ChildTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThrough the magic power of her evil stepmother, a princess gives birth to a monster (Wonder-Child) & is banished. The monster-child uses its magic powers to help its mother & forces a prince to marry her. The monster asks the prince to cut off its head whereupon it turns into a prince.
636
709-Snow WhiteTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesSnow White has a skin white as snow & lips red as blood. A magic mirror tells her stepmother that Snow White is more beautiful than she. The jealous stepmother orders a hunter to kill Snow White, but he substitutes an animal’s heart & saves her. Snow White goes to a house of dwarfs (robbers) who adopt Snow White as their sister. The stepmother now attempts to kill her by means of poisoned lace, a poisoned comb & a poisoned apple. The dwarfs succeed in reviving the maiden from the first two poisonings but fail with the third. They lay her in a glass coffin. A prince resuscitates her & marries her. The step-mother is made to dance herself to death in red hot shoes.
637
709AThe Sister of Nine BrothersTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA girl goes into the forest to search for her nine brothers & stays with them (an abandoned child is reared in the forest by two storks). After they leave their sister in a tree, her fire goes out. Searching for fire, she is finally given some by an ogress. Later the ogress follows the ashes that the girl has dropped & tries to kill her. The girl steps on poisoned nails (tooth, bone) left by the ogress & dies. Her brothers (storks) put her in a glass case. When a prince removes the nails (tooth, bone), the girl is resuscitated & marries the prince.
638
710-Our Lady's ChildTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA father (unwittingly) promises his daughter to a supernatural figure. The Virgin Mary (Christ, saint) or a black woman (wicked stepmother, witch, sorcerer) takes the child into heaven (church, castle) or away in a black coach. The girl looks into a forbidden room, where she sees God (Christ, Virgin Mary), & her hair & finger become golden. Or, she sees enchanted men (black virgins, skeletons). The girl obstin-ately denies what she has seen, is struck dumb & banished into the wilderness. She marries a king & gives birth to three children. The Virgin Mary (foster-mother, stepmother, mother-in-law) takes away her children & the queen is accused of infanticide. When she is to be burned to death on the stake, the queen finally acknowledges her guilt (by keeping silence she delivers the black woman). She is rescued from death & from her dumbness & her children are given back to her.
639
711-The Beautiful & Ugly Twin SistersTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA childless queen is advised by a witch how to have a child, but she breaks a condition connected with the advice. She has two girls, a very beautiful one & a deformed one (with an animal’s head). The ugly sister always assists the handsome one & finally marries a prince. On the wedding day she is transformed & becomes as pretty as her sister.
640
712-CrescentiaTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesWhen her husband the emperor is away, Crescentia is accused of adultery by her lecherous brother-in-law (she locks him in a tower to escape his advances). She is rescued from death (drowning) by a fisherman & nurses the child of a duke. When she rejects a seducer, her foster-child is killed in revenge. She is accused of murder & banished again. Once again she is rescued (by St. Peter) from drowning. Crescentia develops miraculous healing powers & reaches a high position. Her husband & the various men whose love she has rejected come to her for healing. She is recognized by her husband (the emperor), & they go to live in a monastery (convent)
641
713-The Mother Who Did Not Bear Me but Nourished MeTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA stepdaughter is falsely accused of bearing her sister’s illegitimate child & she & the child are expelled. Wherever they go, famine ceases & magic abundance comes. But famine comes to places they have left. Later the truth is revealed by the child’s behavior.
642
715-Demi-cockTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesDemi-cock (half-chick) leaves home in order to claim back a borrowed (stolen) object (money). On his way he meets animals (fox, wolf) & a river. He takes them along by swallowing them (carries them under his wings). When claiming the money from his debtor, Demi-cock is im-prisoned with animals who try to kill him. Fox & wolf eat the attacking animals, & when Demi-cock is thrown into a fire, the river extinguishes it. Finally Demi-cock obtains the money by swallowing. At home he is beaten by his owner (king) & expells the money (he is eaten by his owner & crows from his stomach.
643
715AThe Wonderful RoosterTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesAn old couple (old man, old woman) have a rooster & a hen. The rooster lays no eggs & is driven away. He mocks the king & is sentenced to be drowned, but instead drinks all the water. He is supposed to be roasted but extinguishes the fire with the water he has drunk. He is locked in the treasury & swal-lows all the money. Back home he defecates the money onto a sheet (for the old man). (The old woman sends her hen to do the same, but the animal only produces dung instead of money.)
644
716*The Unbearable SatietyTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA man complains that he is a mere slave of his stomach. God takes away his intestines & the man feels sated without eating. After a while the life becomes boring to the man & he asks God to give him back his hunger. He recovers his stomach.
645
720-The Juniper TreeTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA childless couple wishes for a child. A boy is born but his mother dies. The little boy is slain by his cruel stepmother who closes the lid of an apple chest on him. She cooks him & serves him to his father who eats him unwittingly. The boy’s stepsister gathers up his bones & puts them under a juniper tree. A bird comes forth & sings about what happened. It brings presents to the father & the sister & drops a millstone to the stepmother, killing her. The boy is resuscitated.
646
725-Prophecy of Future SovereigntyTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA clever boy refuses to tell his dream (about his future sovereignty) to his father & to the king. He is punished & endures various adventures (imprisonment). A princess nourishes him in prison. War is to be declared on the emperor if he is not able to solve two riddles & a task. The clever boy solves the riddles & the task, tells the answers to the princess, & is freed from prison. So the boy averts war, marries the princess, & finally receives two kingdoms.
647
726-The Three Old MenTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA wayfarer meets an old man (four or more [relatives]), is referred to an older one & finally to a third very old one. Or, three very old men are asked to solve a problem. The oldest man, who looks the youngest, explains that a man’s appearance depends on the behavior of his wife.In other variants an Irishman goes to Scandinavia & meets an old man, his father & his grandfather. The Irishman obtains certain objects & food that make him see hidden things. When he eats the meat his vision vanishes.
648
729-The Merman's Golden AxeTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA woodcutter drops his axe in a river (pool). A supernatural being (merman) exhibits a golden & then a silver axe. The man rejects both because they do not belong to him; he only accepts his own. The two other axes are then given to him as a gift. A greedy imitator, who pretends to be the owner of the golden & the silver axe, does not get either & loses his own.
649
735-The Rich Man's & the Poors Man's FortuneTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesOne of two brothers (farmers) becomes rich, because his fortune works for him, whereas the other becomes poor. The (personified) fortune of the rich one tells the poor brother that his fortune is lazy (asleep). The poor brother beats it (wakes it up) & learns that he should change his profession. He becomes a successful merchant.
650
735ABad Luck ImprisonedTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA poor brother leaves home to find better luck in another place, but his personified bad luck (poverty) wants to go with him. On a pretext the man locks up the bad luck in a bottle (bag, chest) or buries (drowns) it (and from then on lives happily). When his rich brother frees the bad luck out of jealousy, it attaches itself to him because it is afraid of the clever poor brother.
651
736-Luck & WealthTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA rich & a poor friend make a wager: Does wealth come from hard work or from good luck? In order to test their theories, the rich man gives money to a poor craftsman. The first time the money is stolen by a bird, the second time his wife spends it. The poor man gives the craftsman a piece of lead which a fisher-man uses as weight for his net. He receives from him the first fish he catches & in its body he finds a jewel. This proves that fortune is more powerful. When the poor man recovers his luck, the lost money which was given to him by the rich man is often found in a nest or in a jug.
652
736ARing of PolycratesTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) When King Amasis learns about the military success of Polycrates he advises him not to provoke the jealousy of the gods. As sign of his humility he should throw away the thing he likes most. Thereupon Polycrates throws his most precious ring into the sea. Some days later a fish is given to him in which the ring is found. (2) Because she is haughty (annoyed at a beggar) a rich woman (landlord, businessman) throws her ring into the sea (river, lake) saying, “As improbable as it is that I will see this ring again, so improbable it is that I will ever become poor”. The ring is returned to her & a short time later she becomes poor.
653
737-Who Will be her Future Husband?Tales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesOn New Year’s Eve (Christmas Eve) a young woman foresees her future husband, a soldier. When the apparition leaves, she manages to keep his sabre (sword). When the soldier comes home, they marry. Later he finds his sword in a chest. He (nearly) kills his wife (and himself) with the sword because he had suffered so much from the loss of his weapon.
654
737B*The Lucky WifeTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThis misc. type includes various tales dealing with a luckless man who becomes successful in all his undertakings when he marries a lucky woman & profits from her luck.
655
739*The Luck-Bringing AnimalTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThe children of a luckless family find a luck-bringing animal (dog). The (old) father (grandfather) orders it to be killed (destroyed), but the children eat its meat & become fortunate.
656
740**The Brother about to Hang Himself Finds a TreasureTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA rich greedy man, asked for help by his poor brother, gives him instead of money a rope & advises him to hang himself. The poor brother chooses a tree under which the rich man has buried money. When he tries to hang himself, the tree snaps at ground level & he discovers the treasure. The rich brother, having lost his treasure, hangs himself.
657
745-Hatch-PennyTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with money (treasure) that always returns to its owner or brings bad luck to anyone who steals it.
658
745AThe Predestined TreasureTales of Magic (300-749)700-749 Other Supernatural TalesA miser finds money (treasure), but a voice tells him that it is predestined for someone else. The miser hides it in a hollow tree & throws it into the sea (loses it in a flood). A fisherman finds the treasure & gives it to a smith (a smith finds it when working). The former owner pays a visit to the finder & tells his story. The finder gives him three pastries (caskets), one filled with earth, one with bones & one with the treasure. The miser chooses the wrong one. Thereupon the new owner tries to repay the miser & gives him a cake with the money inside. The miser pays for other goods with it & finally, after other events, the money reaches the predestined owner again.
659
750*Hospitality BlessedReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesGod (and St. Peter) rewards the hospitable farm -er & punishes the inhospitable one In some versions (mostly Hungarian & Czech) a poor woman of-fers soup to Christ & St. Peter. They reward the woman because they appreciate the specks of fat as “stars” in the soup. When the neighbor woman asks Christ & St. Peter to eat her soup, it is covered with fat & the woman is not rewarded at all.
660
750**Girls Plucking BerriesReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesOne of them answers an old man (God) in a friendly manner & is rewarded. The other gives a discourteous answer & is punished.
661
750AThe Three WishesReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist & St. Peter (God, other supernatural being) visit the mortals . A poor farmer who receives them hospitably is granted three good wishes; a rich man, who refused hospitality, receives three evil wishes. The generous poor person uses his three wishes wisely; the selfish rich man makes two foolish wishes (his horse’s neck broken, his wife stuck to the saddle) & must use the third to undo them. (The same with one wish: to keep doing all day what you begin; one gets good linen all day, while the other throws water on a pig.) Or, a husband given three wishes transfers one to his wife who wastes it on a trifle. In his anger he wishes the desired article in her body & must use the third wish to get it out.
662
750BHospitality RewardedReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesAfter Christ & St. Peter (pious beggar) have been refused hospitality in a house where a wedding is taking place, they are received hospitably in a poor man’s house. The farmer kills his only cow (sheep) for them, whereupon it comes to life again (many new cows appear).
663
750CGod Punishes a Bad WomanReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man is kind to a beggar (God), but his wife is unkind. The beggar invites the man to him & shows him (among other things) that the woman has been turned into a cow.
664
750DGod (St. Peter) & the Three BrothersReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesGod (magician) grants each of three brothers a wish. They choose (1) plenty of wine, (2) sheep, (3) a good wife. Later, when God (magician) comes as a beggar he is refused hospitality by the two elder brothers & he takes their wine & sheep away. The youngest brother & his wife are rewarded for their hospitality.
665
750EFlight to EgyptReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with the journey of the Holy Family to Egypt. The events are usually miraculous: (1) Helping trees/persons: Trees (weeping willow, poplar, alder, fig, palm), plants (fern, broom, thornbush, thistle, hazelnut, rose), fruits (date, pine cone, lupine seed), birds (quail, lark, nightingale, partridge, swal low, wag-tail, pipit, bullfinch), other animals (donkey, sheep, goats, wolves), people (smith, mason, farmer, blind man, Gypsy), & various things (river, well, stream, hoofprints) help the Holy Family on their flight by sheltering them from the sun or from a storm, or by hiding them from pursuers. The helpers are blessed for their assistance. (2) In the corn-legend a farmer tricks the men (soldiers) who pursue the Holy Family by telling them that the fugitives passed by when a field of grain, which is now ripe, was sown. The pursuers give up, not knowing that the grain grew & ripened in a single day. (3) Mary washes Jesus’s diapers & hangs them on a bush to dry. Their healing power causes the dried-out bush to turn green or to bloom, or imparts fragrance to its flowers. (4) Having no where else to bathe Jesus, Mary washes him in certain natural springs, which then & ever after produce warm water. (5) Jesus soothes wolves, which aid the family in their flight. (6) A spider spins its web over a cave in which the Holy Family is hiding. Thinking that no one could have entered the cave recently, the pursuers do not look inside for them (7) Animals (beetle) or plants betray the Holy Family on the way to Egypt & are cursed. (8) Gypsies refuse to give the Holy Family refuge, & for this they are condemned to wander ever after.
666
750E*Hospitality & SinReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesOne act of hospitality (to two monks) outweighs a life of sin.
667
750FThe Widow's DonationReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA king has built a church, but will not allow anyone to donate money for it. When the church is ready, he erects a sign saying that he alone built it. The next day, his name has been replaced by that of a poor widow. He learns that the widow had donated hay for the donkeys (oxen) used to help build the church. The king regrets his mistake & recompenses the woman.
668
750H*The Notary Enters HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesJesus & the Apostles are shown hospitality by a woodsman (card player). He is granted a wish & asks that he may always win at cards & be received in paradise. He lives & dies peacefully. On his way to heaven he stops at the house of a wicked, dying notary (enters hell) & wins the notary’s soul from the devil in a card game. St. Peter does not wish to admit the notary, but the woodsman recalls his hospitality & obtains the notary’s ad-mis sion.In some variants he wins twelve games of cards with the devil & is able to take twelve souls out of hell with him. Finally they are all admitted into paradise.
669
750K*The Lost GenitaliaReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesTwo soldiers lose their genitals. One of them becomes a servant. The farmer for whom he works gives him a stallion & sends him away because he would be useless as a son-in-law. The soldier shares his bread with a fairy (helps an old woman) who gives him a wish. He wishes for genitals like those of his horse, & marries the farmer’s daughter. He tells the other soldier what happened & advises him to get a horse & to give bread to a fairy. This man also wishes for genitals like those of his horse – but he had not noticed that this horse was a mare.
670
750K**Wishing the Cat to be a PrinceReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesAn old woman is given three wishes by a fairy (fish). She wants to be young, to have her house become a palace, & to have her cat turn into a young man. All the wishes are fulfilled. However, she realizes too late that she had had her cat neutered.
671
751AThe Farmwife is Changed into a WoodpeckerReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist & St. Peter ask for hospitality from a farmwife (baker’s daughter). She tries to use only a very small piece of pastry to make her bread (to prepare only a very small loaf), but her bread (pastry) magically grows larger. Neverthe less she does not give them anything (gives them only a morsel). As punishment, she is transformed into a woodpecker.
672
751A*A Man Invites God to his HouseReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man (woman) makes grand prep a rations for a visit from God, but drives away a beggar who has come to his door (sets the dogs on him). The beggar was God him self. (The man is punished).
673
751BThe Farmwife Must Take Two Snakes as Foster-ChildrenReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA greedy farmwife gives only a small piece of bread (nothing) to a beg-gar (Christ), even though her bread magically grows larger. As punishment she has to breast-feed two snakes.
674
751B*The Old Man with the Live CoalsReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA poor man looks for a light for his fire. An old man gives him embers. When he takes them home they turn to gold. A wealthy man (envious neighbor) purposely extinguishes his fire & asks the old man to give him some coals. He says, “Your house is full of fire”. He finds his homestead in flames.
675
751C*Wealth Leads to PrideReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man who miraculously became prosperous drives away an old beggar. The beggar was God himself his benefactor. The man is punished & loses everything.
676
751D*St. Peter Blesses Hospital ThievesReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter Blesses Hospital Thieves.
677
751E*Man in the MoonReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type includes various narratives dealing with a man (woman, animal, object) on the moon. Examples: A man (watercarriers, a woman with a butter churn, a man with a bucket of tar) is sent to (can be seen on) the moon for punishment. The punishment is usually for breaking a religious com-mandment (being hard-hearted, stealing, working on Sunday, etc.) In some variants, the figure of a rabbit, a frog, a toad, or a tree is seen on the moon.
678
751F*The Mouse Tower of BingenReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A knight who had plundered the property of St. Clement is attacked at night in his bedroom by an army of mice. Unable to ward them off, he prays to be hung in a chest from the ceiling. The mice go away. When the chest is taken down, the knight is found inside gnawed to death by other mice. Or, the Polish King Popiel flees from mice to a wooden tower on an island. Even there the mice find him & kill him. (2) A prominent cleric (Archbishop Hatto I or II) levies taxes dur-ing a famine & demands that those who do not pay (the poor) be burn ed to death. As they die, he likens their cries to the sound of squealing rats (mice). God punishes him for this cruel deed by plaguing him with mice. In order to get rid of the mice, the bishop flees to a tower on a rock in the Rhine (near Bingen). The mice attack him even there & eat him up.
679
751G*Bread Turned to StoneReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with bread (that has not been shared during a famine) that is turned to stone (and/or gives forth blood). Examples: (1) A poor woman asks her sister for bread for her children. The sister hides her bread & refuses, saying, “If I had any bread, I would rather wish it would turn to stone”. Immediately, her bread turns into stone. (When her husband latertries to cut the bread she had hidden, blood flows from it.) (2) A lay brother (baker) hides his bread instead of giving any to the poor. It turns to stone, & is hung on the church door as a warning.
680
752AChrist & St. Peter in the BarnReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist & St. Peter spend the night in a farmer’s barn . As payment for lodging the farmer wants them to thresh. They separate the grain by means of fire. When the farmer tries to do the same, he burns the grain & the barn.
681
752BThe Forgotten WindReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesGod charges a pious man (St. Peter) with the task of managing the weather. The man sends rain, sun & heat to earth but he forgets the wind. Thereupon God deprives him of his responsibility.
682
752CThe Prodigious MowerReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA saint (God, devil) has to mow a field in exchange for a dinner. He mows so hard that he is believed to be the devil (other mowers become jealous & put some laxative in his soup). Or, when threshing corn he breaks his anvil into two parts.
683
753-Christ & the SmithReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist (St. Peter, St. Eligius, saint) visits a haughty smith, takes off a horse’s foot in order to shoe it, & replaces the foot. He rejuvenates an old woman by putting her in the fire. The smith tries to do the same with his old mother-in-law but only deforms her. The smith’s wife & daughter, both pregnant, are so shocked at seeing her that both give birth to a monkey. This explains the origin of monkeys. In some variants the attempt at rejuvenation produces a monkey.
684
753*Christ (God) Turns a Thief into an AssReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesAn innkeeper intends to rob Christ (God) & St. Peter (saint) . Christ turns him into a donkey & gives him to another person for whom he must work. Later Christ restores him to human form & gives him the money he had earned as an ass.
685
753AUnsuccessful ResucitationReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist (St. Peter, angel) resuscitates a dead princess (girl). A companion tries to do the same, fails, & is warned against trying again (is condemned & rescued by Christ).
686
754-Lucky PovertyReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA poor man (cobbler, weaver, smith, porter, falconer) is happy despite of his meagre living conditions. A rich man, seeing this apparent contradiction, gives him money. The poor man worries about his new wealth & loses his former happiness. Finally he returns the money so as to be happy again.
687
754**St. Peter & His WifeReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesPeter, having quarreled with his wife, stays out in front of his house in the rain. When the Lord asks him why he is outside, he lies & says that the house is full of smoke. The Lord enters. At the rear he finds St. Peter’s wife holding up a broom handle.
688
755-Sin & GraceReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA woman (on the advice of an old woman, devil) prevents the birth of her illegitimate children by using magic to procure abortions (kills the children, marries only when infertile, makes a contract with the devil). Later her husband (priest, preacher) realizes that she throws no shadow & casts her out as a sinner. She cannot be pardoned until a rose grows from a stone table. A churchman takes the woman at night into the church. The (souls of the) unborn children appear one by one, whip (rend) her, & finally forgive her. When the woman returns home a rose springs up. (She dies or her body is torn up by animals.)
689
756-The Three Green TwigsReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesLegends about a wooden stick that grows roots & twigs & becomes a cypress, etc.
690
756ASelf-Righteous HermitReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA hermit mistrusts divine justice, or a man who thinks he is without sin complains about God’s decision of his place after death (punishment [hell] or reward [heaven]). This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) An angel ceases to appear to a hermit because he spoke disparagingly of an evil-doer who was taken to the gallows. Thereupon the hermit has to do hard penance by wandering about as a beggar with a small dry branch. The hermit converts a band of robbers with the story of his misfortune. The next morning the hermit is found dead, with green twigs on his small dry branch. (2) A discontented hermit, an evil-doer, & a naked man covered with sand worry about their place in heaven. Angel Gabriel tells them God’s answers to their questions: the place of the hermit will be in hell because he doubts God’s justice, the evil-doer will be in heaven because of his hospitality, & even the sand will be removed from the naked man because of his ingratitude & impa tience. (3) A criminal has to do penance after confession: every time he passes a crucifix he should say the Lord’s prayer. When doing so he is killed by the relative of one of his former victims. The hermit, his father confessor, sees that the criminal is taken into heaven by angels, & he decides to leave God’s service. When he leaves his cell, he breaks his neck & is taken by the devil. (4) A murderer overhears the confession of a dying hermit. In despair the criminal utters a fast prayer regretting not having lived a life like the pious hermit’s. The hermit hears the exclamation & as he dies, he behaves haughtily towards the criminal, whereupon his soul is taken by the devil. The criminal runs away, falls into a pit, & is taken into heaven by angels.
691
756BRobber MadejReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA boy who intends to become a priest has been sold to the devil by his parents before birth. When the boy becomes aware of this contract he first asks a priest, then a bishop, & finally the pope for advice. The boy wants to go to hell in order to dissolve the contract, & the pope sends him to a hermit. The hermit directs him to his brother, a robber. The robber takes him to hell. In hell the boy obtains his contract (after many efforts to per suade the devil) & sees the fiery bed (chair) prepared for the robber. In anticipating his punishments the robber decides (is told) to do penance until his dry staff puts forth fresh blooms & fruit. Assured of forgiveness, he dies happy & goes to heaven. The hermit is astonished but reconciles himself to God’s judgment (blasphemes God & is damned). The boy returns from hell & becomes a priest.
692
756CTwo SinnersReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA robber seeks to do penance for murdering ninety-nine men or for murder-ing his parents (for shooting at a consecrated wafer). After being rejected by several confessors he is as-signed the following penance by an old man: to “plant” a fire brand (live coals, small twig, axe, garden) & to wait until it grows into a green tree; to water the firebrand with water brought from a distance in his mouth; to carry a bag of stones (one for each murder) on his back or an iron hoop on his head till it falls off; to pasture black sheep till they become white Furthermore he should behave mercifully, carry a traveler over a stream, & offer free hospitality to all. For many years the robber does penance in vain until he inter-cepts a man who is about to commit a great crime. The robber kills the man & then regrets the deed. Thereupon the firebrand blooms (the stones or the hoop fall off or the sheep turn white). His confes sor tells him that all his sins have been forgiven because of the crime that was prevented by his last murder (because God is pleased with the hundredth murder).
693
756C*Receipt from HellReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA tenant goes to hell (with the help of a little man) in order to procure a receipt for the rent from his dead landlord. He brings it back (and receives a mark as sign of contact with the dead).
694
756D*Who is the more Devout?Religious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA hermit (St. Peter) asks Christ if anyone is more devout than he. He is directed to a widow who hides in her house & takes care of the murderer of her only son (to a butcher who shelters the murderer of his father)
695
756E*Charity Rewarded.Religious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesCharity is rated higher than prayer or attendance at mass. Friends make a pilgrimage to Christ’s grave, & another friend stays at home (on the way, in the shop). When he sees a poor man carrying a dead sheep (hen) in order to feed his children, he gives him money (and goods). When the pilgrims return they say that they have also seen their friend who had stayed behind at the grave (their friend’s name on the table in church). So they realize that the soul of a person who does good goes to Christ’s grave.
696
756G*Faith Moves MountainsReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A sultan orders that all Christians in his domain be put to death unless they can, by the strength of their belief, move a certain mountain. A poor (one-eyed, blind) shoemaker accomplishes the miracle: the power of his words pushes the mountain into the sea (along with the sultan & his courtiers). Thus the Christians are freed from their imprisonment. (2) A bishop imprisoned by heathens must demonstrate the power of his belief by moving a mountain. While he hesitates, a youth in his service accomplishes the miracle by the strength of his belief. The witnesses are so impressed that they convert to Christianity. (3) A Catholic craftsman uses his hammer to strike a mountain, which is moved into the sea.
697
757-The Emporer's Haughtiness PunishedReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThe emperor Jovinian feels like God. When he bathes, a stranger (angel) who looks like him takes away his clothes & reigns in his place. When Jovinian re-turns naked to the court nobody recognizes him & he is driven away. In his despair he starts to regret his former haughtiness. Later, when he asks again for the sovereignty, he is accepted as emperor. The stranger who had ruled in his place discloses himself as his guard ian angel & disappears. From then on the emperor lives humbly in a godfearing manner.
698
758-The Various Children of EveReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesAfter the expulsion from paradise Eve gives birth to a child every year. Her children are all different: some beautiful, some ugly. When God pays her a visit Eve bathes her beautiful children & dresses them nicely. She hides the ugly ones. (She is ashamed of the number of her children & therefore hides some.) When God arrives he blesses the beautiful children & des-tines them to become kings, earls, citizens or traders. Thereupon Eve wants her ugly children (hidden in the straw, hay, oven) to be bles sed as well. God destines those to be farmers, fishermen, smiths, tanners, shoemakers & servants. Upon Eve’s protest God explains that every class is necessary & legitimate for the functioning of society. Sometimes Eve consents to God’s will.
699
759-Angel & the HermitReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA saint (Moses, Rabbi Joshua Ben Levi, St. Peter, hermit) doubts God’s justice & blames him for sending suffering to virtuous people & well-being to bad ones. Or, a saint asks God for the reason for his decisions, an angel asks a saint (hermit) to accompany him to see God’s secret decisions, or, an angel & a hermit meet & decide to travel together. The angel (God’s messenger) forbids his companion to speak or to ask questions. On their way the angel does many seemingly unjust & cruel things: he kills the child and/or the servant of a hospitable host & a man he meets in the street; he repays hospitality by stealing a cup, in hospitality by giving a cup (present); he repays an inhospitable person by constructing a house (rebuilding a fallen wall); he destroys the house (harvest) of hospitable people; he damages (sinks) a ship because of one sinner on board; he kills the only cow of a poor woman; he offers good wishes to inhospitable people, & bad wishes to hospitable ones. Later the angel explains why each of these strange deeds was just. When the hermit sees the justification for each deed, he agrees that none of God’s acts should be blamed or doubted. God’s deeds are always justified.
700
759*The Hospitable Widow's Cow KilledReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA poor widow (man) hospitably receives God & St. Peter for the night. The next day, when God orders a wolf to kill the widow’s only cow, St. Peter rebukes God for ingratitude. God replies, “She has no need of the cow, for tonight she will be with me”. Or, when the widow suffers her loss without reproach, God rewards her generously.
701
759AThe Sinful PriestReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man refuses to receive holy communion from an unworthy priest. God sends him a dream of unbearable thirst. He finds a well where a leper draws water for many people to drink. When he also wants to drink from it, the leper draws back his hand & says, “Why do you want to take water from a leper’s hand but you refuse to receive the sacrament from an unworthy priest?” It is reprehensible to say that the power of the sacrament depends on the virtue of the man who gives it.
702
759BHoly Man Has His Own MassReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man never comes to mass. When upbraided for not coming, he hangs his coat on a sunbeam. The priest realizes that he is a pious man & that even though he stays at home, he is nearer to God than the priest himself (other people).
703
759CThe Widow's FlourReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA poor woman shares her small property with beggars but loses her last flour (bread) in a storm. When some traders arrive safely in spite of a leak (calm) she complains to the king (Solomon) about the injustice of the wind. In thanks for their rescue, the traders deliver a certain amount (of money) to the king to be given to the poor. At first they do not know where the leak is, but then they discover that a flour sack plugged the hole. The poor woman identifies the sack as the one she had lost, & the king gives her the money as compensation. (The god of the winds has to pay for the compensation).
704
759DThe Punishment of the AngelReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesAn angel (the death) is sent by God to take the soul of a widow with two children. He does not fulfill the task. Thereupon God, in order to show that he cares even for the smallest creatures, tells the angel to fetch a stone out of the sea where a small worm is hidden. The angel is punished by becoming deaf, blind or senseless, or he is driven out of the sky. He has to do penance for his sin on earth by pretending to be human & by serving a man (abbot, hermit, custodian, farmer) on earth. As a servant he works for his master but he acts in a ridiculous & strange way, smiling mysteriously. He mocks a man who buys shoes that will last a long time, because the man will die soon. He throws stones at a church (wedding procession) because he sees the devil there. He favors a pub because the people inside pray & ask for God’s mercy. At the burial of a dignitary he behaves disrespectfully, while at the burial of a poor man he renders his reverence. He mocks holy things & scorns a crucifix (holy statue, shrine). He contradicts a judgment, saying it is wrong. He insults a beggar for being in reality a rich man. When he meets an emperor & his brother, a bishop, he smiles because he recognizes them as the two pitiful children who were the reason why he had been punished, & who had both achieved high positions. By this the angel finally learns something about divine justice.
705
759EThe Miller of Sans SouciReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA ruler’s new palace is built where there is already a building (house, mill) that belongs to one of his subjects (old woman, miller). Because this subject objects to losing his home, rather than demolishing the small building, the ruler permits it to be incorporated into the new palace.
706
760-The Unquiet GraveReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man burns his three pregnant fiancées (wife, wives). After the man’s death his corpse reappears (again & again) in the church. Guests come to the parsonage to see the corpse. The clergyman’s maidservant is paid to take the dead man & return him to his grave. But the corpse holds her fast & asks her to beg his murdered fiancées’ pardon when they come to the church. They agree only after the third time, whereupon the corpse returns to the grave & finds rest.In some variants a boy who mocks the church (clergyman, Virgin Mary) is condemned & sinks to earth as a stone. Later the stone is found & carried into a room where it laughs & tells its story. A special word cancels the curse & the corpse in the form of the stone changes to dust.
707
760**The Obstinate ChildReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesAn obstinate child (son) is disobedient & hits (mistreats) his mother. He becomes ill & dies. After he is buried, his hand keeps reaching out of the grave & will not decompose . The authorities advise his mother to strike the hand with a stick until it is bloody. It then goes back into the grave & the child is able to rest in peace.
708
760***Salvation in the CradleReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThe soul of a dead man is unable to rest (is tormented in purgatory). It explains to a passerby (someone who wants to help) that its salvation is governed by the growth of a certain tree. The first child who lies in a cradle (coffin) made from the wood of this tree will be the one who lays the soul to rest. In some variants, the child must become a priest. When he serves his first mass, the restless soul will be able to rest.
709
760AThe Forgiven SkeletonReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA man kills his wife (bride), dies (is executed), & comes back to haunt the living. The dead man’s body (skeleton, skull, bone, hand, etc.) is re moved (because of a wager) from the cemetery. The dead man is willing to be taken back to his grave only by the person (brave girl) who had taken him out of it. (The skeleton clings to the girl until they reach home, where it explains that it could not find peace because in its lifetime it had slandered an illegitimate child. It asks the girl to beg the mother’s pardon.)Once it has been forgiven the skeleton disintegrates to ashes & finds peace (deliverance).
710
760A*The Death of a MiserReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA miser swallows his money before he dies. The devil (his sons, his servant) shakes the money out of him & carries off his body (to hell).
711
761-The Cruel Rich Man as the Devil's HorseReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA farmer is helped in a con flict with his hard-hearted landlord. His magic helper performs all tasks (gives him a horse that performs all tasks for him). Finally the man learns that the horse is an ancestor of the landlord & that it comes from hell (devil).
