When he tells his landlord what has happened, he is friendly from then on for fear of being trans-formed as well.
712
762-Woman with 365 childrenReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA childless noblewoman accuses a poor mother of twins (triplets) of adultery, whereupon the woman curses her to bear as many children as there are days (months) in a year . In the absence of her husband she gives birth to seven (nine, twelve, thirteen, or more) children (sons). Being ashamed she orders her servant to drown all except one. The servant meets the father on his return & pretends to be carrying puppies in the basket. The father secretly educates the children & finally presents them to his wife & some guests. Guests & sons pray for mercy for the mother. From this time children of multiple birth have been called Guelfs (Dogs, Trazegnies, Porcelets, etc.).
713
763-Treasure Finders Who Murder One AnotherReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThree (two, more) men (hunters, friends, brothers) find (rob) a treasure. When one of them goes to town to fetch some food, the others plan to murder one another in order not to share the treasure. Those who stayed kill (stab to death, drown) the one who left when he returns, but they die later from eating bread (wine) which he had poisoned. In some variants Christ travels with some of his followers. When they find a treasure he tells them not to touch it but to continue their way. Later two of them return secretly to take the treasure & they murder one another.
714
765-The Mother Who Wants to Killer Her ChildrenReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA woman tries to kill her (illegitimate) children (twins, her third, her twelfth child, etc.) (by hiding them). The father rescues the children & keeps them hidden. After many years they emerge. The mother dies of fright (is executed)
715
766-The Seven SleepersReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with persons who are cast into in a magic sleep extending over many years. Twelve children are cast into a three hundred years’ sleep by an angel (only the eldest child St. Peter is mentioned by name). They go back in time, & they awake on the night when Jesus is born. From then on they follow him as his twelve apostles
716
767-Food for the CrucifixReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA pious (simple) boy offers bread to a statue (crucifix, image of Christ or the Virgin Mary). As his reward he is entertained in heaven.
717
768-St Christopher & the Christ ChildReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThe giant Reprobus (Christopher) wants to serve only the mightiest master. First he serves the king, but leaves because the king fears the devil. The giant serves the devil, but he leaves him when he refuses to pass a crossroads. A hermit (ferryman) tells the giant to carry a child across the river. The child becomes heavier with each step & finally explains the reason: that he is Christ who carries the sins of the world. The giant is doubtful, but then his staff changes into a blossoming plum (fig) tree. Thus he is convinced & from then on he bears the name Christophorus – the man who carried Christ .
718
769-The Child's GraveReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A mother discovers her dead child in a procession of dead children. It is forced to carry a heavy jug & tells its mother to stop weeping because it has to collect all her tears in the jug. From then on the mother stops weeping. (2) A dead child returns to tell its mother to stop weeping. Its shroud is so wet from her tears that the child cannot find rest in the grave. From then on the mother bears her pain without weeping & her child stays quiet in the grave.
719
770-The Nun Who Saw the WorldReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA nun (named Beatrice) breaks her vow & leaves the convent (out of love or passion). During her absence the Virgin Mary takes her place in the community. When the nun returns to the convent the miracle becomes evident.
720
770A*Guardian AngelReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type includes different tales dealing with people who are protected by an invisible being (angel) from danger, injury, or acting badly. Examples: (1) A priest offends the new (second) wife of a prince. The prince wants to take revenge. He summons the priest, intending to shoot him. When the priest arrives, the prince instead invites him to dinner. The courtiers ask the prince why he suddenly changed his mind. He says that someone standing next to him told him what to do. No one else saw such a person, so the prince thinks it must have been an angel. (2) A girl going through a forest is followed by a man who tries to rape her. She falls to her knees & prays to God, & the man lets her go. A few days later he attacks another girl & is arrested. He is asked why he let the first girl go, & replies that someone was with her. (3) A clergyman who is disliked by his congregation is called to go to the house of someone who is dying. When he arrives he finds no one there. He thinks he was the victim of a prank & goes home.Years later when he goes again to a deathbed, he learns that the false summons had been made by someone who intended to kill him. But the villain saw that the clergyman was accompanied by someone else (angel, man dressed in white) & gave up his plan.
721
772-Wood for the Holy CrossReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises various legends dealing with the wood used for the Holy Cross (wood from a tree in Paradise used for Jesus’s Crucifixion; the Holy Cross rediscovered by St. Helena & recovered by the Emperor Heraclius). Examples: Adam’s son Seth wants to bring oil from the tree of mercy to his dying father. An angel gives him instead a branch (seed) from the Tree of Life (Tree of Knowledge), which Seth plants on Adam’s grave. Later, Solomon has this tree cut down to use in his temple. The beam does not fit so it is used as a bridge & subsequently buri ed. It is discovered just in time to be used to make the cross for the Crucifixion.
722
772*The Flies Instead of Nails on Christ's HeartReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesFlies look like nails & prevent more nails being driven in.
723
773-Contest of Creation between God & the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises different tales dealing with the theme, “God & the devil as creators”. They have a strong dualistic tendency. Examples: (1) The creation of contrasting animals. The devil makes crea-tures in competition with God (often copies the creatures God made). (2) The devil tries to create humans but fails, & instead he creates certain animals. For example, God makes Adam out of clay & the devil tries to copy him. He shapes the clay & blows life into it, but it turns into a mon-key. In other variants, the devil makes inferior races of humans. (3) The good principle competes with the bad one, as God & the devil create various animals. God creates a wolf which is called “God’s dog”, & the destructive devil deliberately creates goats. The devil’s animals devour God’s animals. (4) The devil’s animals are brought to life by God. The devil shapes some animals but only God (the name of God) can bring them to life. When the devil refuses to utter God’s name, the animals remain lifeless. (5) God takes the devil’s animals. The devil creates (owns) animals that God wants for himself. God alters the appearance (colors) of the devil’s animals so that he cannot recognize them.
724
773**God & Devil Dispute over Miser's SoulReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesGod says the devil may have the soul of a miser if he can fill a cask with money. God knocks the bottom out of the cask & hangs it in a tree over a gorge. The devil is unable to fill the cask & leaves the soul to God.
725
774-Christ & St. PeterReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type consists of various jests about Christ & St. Peter during their visit on earth or creating the world.
726
774ASt. Peter Wants to Create a ManReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & Punishes(replaces the head of an innocent, beheaded person). He puts the head on backwards. St. Peter consoles himself with the idea that the resuscitated person could become a rope-maker who has to walk backwards while working. In some variants Christ asks St. Peter to settle a dispute between a woman & the devil. Thoughtlessly he cuts off the heads of both. When he puts the heads back, he exchanges them. Since that time it is said that women have had the devil inside their bodies.
727
774BSt. Peter Cannot Sell His DonkeyReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter Cannot Sell His Donkey because he points out all its defects.
728
774CThe Legend of the HorseshoeReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist & St. Peter find a horseshoe. St. Peter is unwilling to lean over to pick it up. Christ picks it up, sells it & buys cherries with the proceeds. He drops them one by one on the way & the thirsty St. Peter has to bend over to pick up every single cherry.
729
774DSt. Peter Acts as God for a DayReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA girl takes her goat (cow, pig, goose) to pasture & leaves it, saying, “May God take care of you!” There-upon St. Peter, who is taking God’s place, has to run everywhere after the goat.
730
774ESt. Peter Gets Permission to Gather GrapesReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter returns to heaven late & says that in prosperity men forget to pray. Thereupon God sends rising prices to earth. This time St. Peter returns to heaven quickly & says that now all the people pray & ask for God’s help.
731
774FSt. Peter with the FiddleReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter, against Christ’s advice, insists on going into a pub where carpenters, soldiers & Gypsies are celebrating. Christ puts a violin on his back & when St. Peter explains to the people that he cannot play the instrument, they beat (laugh at) him.
732
774HChrist Puts Knots in WoodReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter, angry at carpenters, wants Christ to make wood (trees) with iron knots (branches, nails). But Christ makes the branches only out of hard wood.
733
774JWhy St. Peter Became BaldReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter receives two (three) cakes from a farmwife (bakery woman). He shares only one (bad) cake with Christ & hides the other (good) one under his cap where it burns all his hair off. In some variants St. Peter becomes so tousled during a fight in a pub that he loses all his hair.
734
774KSt. Peter Stung by BeesReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter becomes angry at Christ for destroying the harvest of all the farmers because of only one sinner. But he himself drowns a whole hive because of one bee sting. When Christ points to the parallel, St. Peter is subdued. Or, St. Peter protests when a ship is sunk by Christ because one sinner is aboard. Christ sends him to fetch honey from a hive. St. Peter crushes all the bees when one stings him.
735
774LMushrooms from St. Peter's SpittleReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter receives a cake (pancake, bread) from a woman & eats it secretly. When Christ talks to St. Peter he tries to hide what he is eating & spits it out. Afterwards mushrooms grow from the cake.
736
774NSt. Peter's GluttonyReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist keeps asking questions of the gluttonous St. Peter so that he must continually spit out mouthfuls in order to be able to answer.
737
774PSt. Peter & the NutsReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesSt. Peter (man) doubts the justice of the cre-ation & complains that large trees have small fruit. Thereupon Christ (God) lets gourds (melons) grow on small branches & nuts (walnuts, acorns, pears, figs) on strong trees. When an acorn falls on St. Peter’s head, he understands the order of the natural phenomena
738
775-Midas' Short-sighted WishReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesPhrygian farmers take an old man (Silen) to Midas (to a nameless poor man), who recognizes him as the educator of Dionysos. Midas organizes a feast for the old man & then hands him over to Dionysos. The grateful Dionysos gives Midas a wish. He wishes that everything he touches will turn to gold. Even his food & drink turn to gold so that he cannot eat. He asks Dionysos to take back the gift. Dionysos agrees & Midas has to bathe in the river Paktolos. From that time on the river contains gold. In some variants Midas dies from hunger & thirst.
739
777-The Wandering JewReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesChrist carries the cross to Golgotha. When he wants to rest for a moment, a Jew (shoemaker), who owns the house there, does not permit it. From then on the Jew has to wander about on earth forever, unable to die.
740
777*The Flying DutchmanReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA captain (Dutchman) is unable to sail around a cape (reach a harbor) because of a strong wind. He swears that he will reach his goal, even if it takes forever. (He is condemned to sail forever because of his sins.) Ordinary sailors who encounter this ship believe it to be a ghost ship (they see it in different forms). Often its crew give them letters addressed to people who died long ago. Meeting the Flying Dutchman portends storm, shipwreck, or death.
741
778-To Sacrifice a Giant CandleReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA sailor (farmer, Gypsy) in distress at sea (in a difficult situation) promises to sacrifice a giant candle (as high as a mast, as long as a pole) more expensive than he can afford. When he is asked to produce it, he replies that the candle would become smaller by itself, or he discharges his promise by offering a small light, or does not fulfill the promise at all. Version from the Middle Ages: A farmer leading a cow & a calf to St. Michael fears the sea & calls on the saint for help, promising to sacrifice the calf. When free from danger, he says that St. Michael was foolish to expect him to give the calf. Again the sea rises, again the farmer calls for help, & St. Michael appears. Now the farmer promises to sacrifice both the cow & the calf, but again he does not discharge his promise. The third time the sea swallows him up together with the animals.
742
778*Two CandlesReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA pious man (old woman) lights a candle for (before the image of) God (a saint), & another one for (before the image of) the devil. When a priest (sexton) asks him why he does this, he explains that one never knows where one will end up. So it is wise to be on good terms with both.
743
779-Misc. Divine Rewards & PunishmentsReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with divine rewards & punishments from God (Christ, St. Peter) for mothers, fathers, children, orphans, poor persons, emperors, kings, queens, robbers, etc. for piety, generosity, toler ance, birth, crime, blasphemy, laziness.
744
779E*The Dancers of KolbeckReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesOn Christmas Eve, outside a church, a farmer of (the fictitious town) Kolbeck holds a dance with fifteen other farmers & three women, while a mass is said. When the priest comes out of the church, he curses all the dancers in God’s name. From then on they have to dance ceaselessly. They dance themselves into the earth, hollowing out a hole, & finally die. After their death, as many stones as there were dancers were set up as a memorial.
745
779F*Mass of the DeadReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A woman (man) who thinks she has overslept for an early church service (during Advent, on Christmas or New Year’s) hurries to church. She finds it brightly lit & filled with unfamiliar worshipers – it is the Mass of the Dead. A dead acquaintance (neighbor) tells her to leave. Terrified, she runs away, but leaves a piece of clothing behind. She goes back but cannot retrieve it because the church door will not open. The next morning, the clothing is found, ripped to shreds, in the graveyard. In some variants, the witness becomes ill & dies shortly after. (2) A person accidentally witnesses a Mass of the Dead (during Advent, on Christmas or New Year’s, on All Saint’s Day, All Souls Day, or the day of a particular saint). A priest asks him if he will re ceive (serve) Holy Communion. The man agrees & is blessed. The priest tells him that he had been unable to rest in peace until he could administer this sacrament to a living person. The visitor dies shortly after.
746
779G*Crime Against GrainReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA woman uses bread (corn, grain) to clean her child. As punishment Christ (God, Virgin Mary, saint) shortens the grain to the length it has today.
747
779H*Star MoneyReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesA poor mistreated orphan leaves her foster-parents & reaches a dark forest. After she gives all her belongings to four other children, suddenly a beautiful woman comes down from heaven & takes the fourth child. The woman is grateful & promises all heaven’s blessings to the orphan girl. When she waves to the stars, silver coins fall down into her outstretched shirt.
748
779J*Breaking the SabbathReligious Tales (750-849)750-779 God Rewards & PunishesThis misc. type comprises various religious legends dealing with offences against the commandment to rest on Sunday (another holy day) by people who work in the house or fields, go hunting, or participate in forbidden amusements. Punish-ments for these offences are various. Examples: Hay harvested on Sunday turns to stone. Someone who goes picking berries instead of going to church becomes ill (dies, is lost). Someone who goes hunting instead of to church suffers an accident (dies). Someone who plays bowls on Sunday is killed by a ball. A choirboy who plays cards behind the organ is caught by the devil.People who play cards or dance on Christmas instead of going to church sink into the earth along with the house in which they met.
749
780-The Singing BoneReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA brother (sister) kills his (her) brother (sister) & buries him (her) in the earth. From the bones a shepherd makes an instrument (harp, violin, flute) which brings the secret to light. Or the murder is revealed by a (speaking) tree growing from the grave.
750
780BThe Speaking HairReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA stepmother buries a girl alive under a tree (kills her daughter). Her hair grows as wheat or as a bush & sings about her misfortunes. Thus she is discovered & rescued. The stepmother is buried in the same hole.
751
780CThe Tell-Tale Calf's HeadReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA murderer buys a calf’s (sheep’s) head. On his way home blood drops out of the head. When the officials find him, the calf’s head turns into the head of the man whom he had murdered.
752
781-The Princess Who Murdered Her ChildReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA queen (princess, step-mother, father) kills her child. A young man learns bird language. A bird (dove) sings, “The bones lie under the tree”. (The dead child is found, the murderer killed).
753
782-Midas & the Donkey's EarsReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightMidas (a nameless emperor), disgusted with his riches, has retired to the forest. Without being asked he intervenes in the judgment of a musical challenge between Pan & Apollo in favor of Pan. As punishment Apollo gives him donkey’s ears (horse’s, sheep’s or goat’s ears). Midas hides them under a crown. His barber (cossack, his foster-brother) cannot keep the secret, so he digs a hole, whispers the secret into it, & covers the hole up again. But a reed growing there (a musical instrument made from the reed) gives the secret away.
754
785-Lamb's HeartReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightWhile traveling on earth God (Christ, St. Peter, Nicholas) asks his com-panion (soldier, beggar, craftsman, clergyman, St. Peter) to prepare a lamb (goat, cow, chicken). The companion secretly eats the lamb’s heart (liver, kidney, brain, tongue) & denies having done so. He explains that this sort of animal had no heart. When God shows his might by various miracles (resuscitation, healing), the man still does not tell him the truth, but instead tries to imitate God. He fails & is condemned to death. God offers his help, but the deceiver prefers to die rather than to yield. Neverthe less God rescues him. Later God divides a treasure into three parts. The third part is to go to the one who ate the heart, whereupon the companion confesses that it was he who ate it.
755
785AThe Goose with One LegReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA servant (cook, St. Peter) is asked by his master (Christ) to prepare a goose (crane, chicken). The servant eats one leg & maintains that the goose had only one leg (all cranes generally have only one leg). He enforces his point by showing geese who stand on one leg. The master refutes his servant’s assertion by shooting away the geese so that they use both legs. The servant replies that if he had frightened the roasted goose in the same way, it would have showed its second leg as well
756
788-The Man Who Was Burned Up & Lived AgainReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA man (hermit, saint, angel) has committed a sin & is burned (is told by an angel to burn himself). A part of his body (heart) is carried away by Christ (God, twelve apostles, St. Peter, beggar, monk, girl, mother of the dead man), & from contact with it a woman conceives & bears a child. Or, a hunter finds the hermit’s heart in the ashes & takes it home, telling his daughter to prepare it for him. The daughter (his sister, girl) instead eats it herself & becomes pregnant from it. The newborn child can walk, talk, prophesy, can do magic things & has supernatural powers. It is the reborn hero (hermit)
757
790*St. George Teaches the Poor ManReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to Light“Whoever steals a little & lies a little will become rich.” Russian variant: St. George teaches a poor man (Nesterka, Gypsy) how to become rich: one has to steal & to lie. Thereupon the poor man steals a golden stirrup (saddle, goblet) from him & denies the theft.
758
791-Christ & St. Peter in Night-LodgingsReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightA host gives shelter to St. Peter & Christ, who must sleep in the same bed. In the night the (drunken) host beats St. Peter (for various reasons). St. Peter changes places with Christ. The host then comes to beat the other lodger, & St. Peter again suffers the blows.
759
798-Woman Created from a Monkey's TailReligious Tales (750-849)780-799 Truth Comes to LightWhen God intends to create Eve from Adam’s rib a monkey (devil, dog, cat, fox) steals it. God pursues the monkey (sends an angel to catch it) & catches its tail. The tail tears off, God holds it in his hand & creates Eve from the monkey’s tail (devil’s, dog’s, cat’s, fox’s tail).
760
800-The Tailor in HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenIn God’s absence, St. Peter lets an unworthy tailor into heaven. The tailor throws God’s foot-stool at an old woman thief on earth. He is expelled from heaven.
761
801-Master PfriemReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenA self-righteous shoemaker (driver, rich man) who is never satisfied, criticizes his journeymen, his servants, & his wife. He dreams he is dead. Before he is admitted to heaven, St. Peter warns him against fault-finding Despite his good intentions he continues to complain. He criticizes angels who carry a beam crosswise, & other angels who carry water in a sieve or pull a wagon with two horses harnessed in front & behind. Finally the faultfinder is expelled from heaven. When he awakes from his dream, he continues to criticize the things he had seen there, showing that his character did not change.
762
802-The Farmer in HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenA poor farmer (beggar, old woman, poor girl, preacher) arrives in heaven at the same time as a rich man (priest, lawyer, townsman, nun, hermit, saint, old couple). The rich man enters first & the poor man outside overhears that he is received with rejoicing. When the farmer enters nothing similar happens. When the farmer complains that things in heaven are handled as partially as on earth, St. Peter explains that poor people come to heaven every day, but a rich man comes only once in a hundred years.
763
802AHis Faith into the BalanceReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenA clergyman sees his good & evil deeds being weighed. He asks them to have his faith in Christ (Virgin Mary) thrown onto the scale. He is saved.
764
802A*The Rooms in HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenWhile a good man is yet living on earth, sev eral spendid rooms are prepared for him in heaven (paradise). A dead miser asks the living man to give him at least one of them.
765
803-The Devil in ChainsReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenChrist rescues dead people (sinners) from hell but leaves Solomon there to rescue himself. Thereupon Solomon forges the devil (Satan, Lucifer) to a chain, which he gnaws at continuously. Every year, just before Easter, the devil nearly manages to bite through the chain, but it immediately renews itself.
766
804-St. Peter's Mother Falls from HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenSt. Peter (other saint) in heaven is allowed to free his mother (sinner, witch, his father, woodcutter; clergyman, thief) from hell (purgatory). When she is pulled to heaven on a rope (stalk) the other inhabitants of the hell (the dead) catch her feet in order to be freed as well. She does not want them to come up & kicks them away. The rope tears & she falls back into hell (St. Peter acknowledges her bad character & casts her out).
767
804AThe Beanstalk to HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenAn old couple climb up a beanstalk (which grows through the roof of their house) to heaven. The old man climbs carrying his wife in a sack which he holds with his teeth. The old woman keeps asking him, “Is heaven still far away?” When he answers, she falls to earth (her husband reaches heaven). In another variant an old couple who climbed to heaven on a bean stalk promise not to eat bread dough (pie, apples) & not to sit in God’s little carriage. They break their promise (the woman sits in the little carriage, which promptly drives off with her) & they are cast out of heaven.
768
804BThe Church in HellReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenA person (Solomon, soldier, smith, miller, shoe-maker, Gypsy, farmer, etc.) in hell threatens to build a church (monastery) there. The devil cannot let this happen, so the person is expelled from hell (receives gold as rent, can marry the daughter of a king or a landlord).
769
804B*The Tavern at Heaven's GateReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenIn order to pay his drinking debts a man (Nobis) promises himself to the devil. But he payed the devil by taking a beating instead of his soul, so he is not allowed to enter either hell nor heaven. Thereupon he starts to run a tavern (named “Nobiskrug”) between heaven & hell (outside heaven’s gate, outside hell’s gate). In some variants so many people remain at the tavern in front of the entrance to heaven that finally the host is allowed to enter heaven as a preventive measure. Or, many candidates for heaven bring their own drinks from earth (they are already drunk), so that the host has to close his business.
770
804CUnsuitable for HellReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenA clergyman assures an old woman that she is not destined for hell because it was made for weeping & gnashing of teeth. She, however, does not have any teeth left any more.
771
805-Joseph & Mary Threatens to Leave HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenSt. Peter (God, Christ), the porter of heaven, notices unfamiliar faces among his people. He learns that Joseph had opened the back door for them. When he asks Joseph why he did such a thing, Joseph too becomes angry. He vows that he will not obey St. Peter’s orders & threatens to leave heaven with Mary & the child. St. Peter relents.
772
808-The Devil & the Angel Fight for the SoulReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenThe devil & an angel quarrel at the deathbed of a rich miser for his soul. Finally the scale tips in his favor because of a stalk (other objects) which the rich man had used to help a beggar. He is granted a place in paradise.
773
808AThe Death of the Good and of the Bad ManReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenWhen a good man dies, a bee (his soul) flies out of his mouth. A white & black bird fight over it & the white bird catches it. When a bad man dies, the black bird catches the bee. In an Estonian variant an angel shows a rich man how a good man dies by taking him to a deathbed. Two white doves sit at the head of the bed & two black ravens at the foot. When the man dies the doves fly up & take his soul away. At the deathbed of a bad man, the two ravens sit at the head & the doves are at the foot. When the man dies the ravens take his soul away & the doves cry.
774
809*Rich Man Allowed to stay in HeavenReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenRich Man Allowed to Stay in Heaven because of single deed of charity. (Sometimes he is repaid & sent to hell.)
775
809**Old Man Repaid for Good DeedsReligious Tales (750-849)800-809 HeavenHe helps a beggar (gives him money) to build his house. When he goes there to see it, he finds himself in paradise.
776
810-The Snares of the Evil OneReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilAn unborn child is promised to the devil in a crisis. When some years later the promised child is to be fetched by the devil, he takes refuge in a holy place (church, altar, cemetery) in a magic circle reading the bible (clergyman draws a ring around him). The devil cannot tempt him outside the circle so the contract is voided.
777
810AThe Devil does PenanceReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA poor pious man puts his last piece of bread on a tree stump. A young devil steals the bread in order to test him. The pious man blesses the thief. In hell the devil is reprimand ed by Lucifer & ordered to serve the farmer for one (three, seven) year. The devil works to make his master prosperous, punishes an evil landowner, & then returns to hell.
778
810A*The Priest & the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilMisc. type. A clergyman (priest, businessman) agrees to give his daughter (soul) to the devil (devils) if the devil is able to build a church (building, castle, palace, bridge, dams, streets) overnight. The clergyman (his wife) makes the rooster crow earlier than usual, & the devils disappear.
779
810B*The Youth Sold to the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilWhen the devil (giant) comes to fetch a youth, his parents sew him up on three successive nights in a dog’s skin, a ram’s skin, & a goat’s skin (they hide him in an ear of corn as a kernel, on a swan’s neck as down, in a flounder as spawn). The devil cannot find him.
780
811-The Man Promised to the Devil Becomes a ClergymanReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilHe sprinkles holy water on the devils in hell; & tears up the contract his father had once concluded with the devil. He becomes a high priest. He tells a sinner to do penance & later, as bishop, he releases him from his sins.
781
811A*The Boy Promised to Go to the Devil Save Himself by His Good ConductReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA boy is sold to the devil for money (before his birth) by his parents. He is to be handed over at a fixed time (when he is four years old). When the boy learns about his destiny, he decides to manage his fortune on his own. He leaves home & meets the Virgin Mary (another holy person). In gratitude for the boy’s helpful & friendly behavior, Virgin Mary gives him a magic tool (water) by which he can save himself from the devil when he comes to fetch him (he fights the devil & wins).
782
812-The Devil's RiddleReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA man (three starving soldiers) promises himself to the devil (in the shape of a dragon) for money (food). If, at the end of a certain time (seven years), he can solve three (seven) riddles which the devil pro-pounds, he will be released from the contract. The devil has ob jects which appear different from what they really are, & the man must guess their real nature: he-goat – horse, cloth – goat-skin, gold cup – cup of pitch, roasted meat – dead dog, spoon – whale-rib, wineglass – horse’s hoof. Or the devil asks seemingly impossible questions: what is sweet-er than honey, softer than swan’s down, harder than stone? Or he asks for the symbolic meaning of the numbers one to seven (ten, twelve). Or he sets impossible tasks. An old woman (devil’s grandmother) helps the man to solve the riddles. Or he finds the solutions by hiding in a tree & overhearing the devil’s conversation with a companion. Or he is hidden by the devil’s grandmother, who gets the secrets from the devil, or is helped by another being (angel, St. Andrew, Gypsy). Finally the man saves his soul & escapes from the devil.
783
813-Careless Word Summons the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilThis misc. type comprises various tales in which someone uses the word devil carelessly, or carelessly utters a curse (e.g. “The devil will get you!”). The curse becomes true & the devil appears (often in disguise, as young man, as dog) & fetches the person who made the curse or who was cursed (often boy, girl, daughter)
784
813*Not to Sleep Three NightsReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA poor man in desparate intends to hang himself in despair. Then he makes a bargain with the devil: If the man does not sleep for three nights, the devil will give him a large sum of money. Whenever the devil asks the man if he is sleeping, the man pretends that he is thinking about something. While the devil verifies the things the man is thinking about, three nights pass & afterwards the man receives the money from the devil. A rich man (neighbor) follows the poor man’s example but confesses that he has slept, & so the devil takes his soul.
785
813AThe Accursed DaughterReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA man wants to marry a wife even if she comes from the devil. He gets a woman who had been carried off by the devil because of the careless words of her mother (“Go to the devil”).
786
813BThe Accursed GrandsonReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilAn old woman curses a young boy (grandson) at his wedding & the devil carries him away. His wife goes after him & brings her husband back from the devil.
787
813CThe Perjured Man & the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA man (farmer) perjures himself during a trial & exclaims, “May as many devils come as hairs are in my body & tear them out!” Thereupon the devils really come & tear out all his hair.
788
815-The Devil Who Skins a CorpseReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA poor man promises three times to hold a wake for a rich man. When the rich man dies, the poor man goes to the cemetery & draws a circle around himself. The devil appears, digs the grave up, takes the corpse out of the coffin, & skins it. While the devil puts the grave in order the poor man pulls the skin into his circle. The devil wants it back because he intended to wear it to haunt people. The poor man is able to delay by negotiating with the devil until the time of his wake has passed. The skin is buried again.
789
815*Shoemaker Who Made Shoes for the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA shoemaker (smith, tailor) is always cursing (unwisely boasts that he could shoe the devil’s own horse). He meets the devil (on his horse, disguised as a man) who asks him to make shoes for him (for his horse). Realizing that he is dealing with the devil, the shoemaker asks a clergyman for help. The clergyman advises him not to take (all) the money from the devil, because if he does, he will have sold his soul. A soon as the shoes are handed over, the devil, delighted, offers him a sum of money. But the shoemaker saves his soul by refusing it. (From that time he never curses again.)
790
816*Devils Tempt the PopeReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The Devilclergyman overhears a conversation of devils (ravens) & learns that the devil (devils) in the shape of a woman is preparing to tempt the pope (bishop, priest) in Rome. He ties the devils together with some holy object (rosary, etc.) & has them carry him on a church door to Rome, where he warns the pope against falling victim to temptation by the devil in female shape. (He receives thanks.)
791
817*Devil Leaves at Mention of God's nameReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilThis misc. type comprises different tales dealing with people who meet the devil in the shape of a person, an animal, or an object (they sell their soul to the devil). By mentioning the name of God, Christ, Virgin Mary, Allah or by saying a prayer or by using holy water, a crucifix, or other holy objects, the devil is made to vanish.
792
818*The Devil goes to ConfessionReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilHe performs severe penance but cannot bear to humble himself & bow before the altar.
793
819*The Devil's PortraitReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA painter is ordered by his master (the king) to paint a portrait of the devil. As he has never seen the devil, he does not know how to paint him. Then the devil appears & assists by showing himself (the painter paints the picture in the steam-bath, he paints only single parts, the devil presents himself only one part at a time). The painter does not look at the finished portrait (may not look at it). When his master looks at it, he dies (all those in the palace who look at it are frightened & flee or die, the king does not die). In a German variant a rich farmer orders a poor painter to paint the devil & offers him his farm as payment. The painter is worried because he does not know what the devil looks like. On the third night his guardian angel appears & tells him he should close his eyes & paint single parts on a paper roll. Every section should be rolled up immediately. He should never look at it & should burn it after the farmer sees it. When the farmer looks at the painting, he dies, & the painter becomes the owner of the farm.
794
820-The Devil as Substitute for Day Laborer at MowingReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilThe devil in the shape of a little old man (workman, hunter) assists a weak farmhand, who works as day laborer for a greedy nobleman, with the mowing (treshing). He does a wonderful job: he mows & threshes as never before & carries the whole harvest plus a bull on his back. When the noble man realizes that the workman must be the devil, the devil takes him to hell, & the day laborer becomes the owner of the whole harvest & the bull.
795
820AThe Devil Mows with a Magic SickleReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA poor old innkeeper works as a farmhand for a rich landlord. The malicious foreman abuses the workmen but especially the innkeeper who cannot mow as fast as the others. The devil comes to the innkeeper & offers to mow for him in his shape at the landlord’s farm. He would bring his own sickle. As the devil mows with his sickle, he follows the foreman. He mows faster than all other workmen & the foreman tries desperately to keep up with him. He exhausts himself & dies of overexertion (the devil takes his soul, wrings his neck). The devil gives his sickle to the old innkeeper, who becomes the best mower from then on.
796
820BThe Devil at HayingReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilAn old woman (farmer) must have her haying done on a certain day (has a contract with the devil). A mysterious stranger appears & promises his help. He comes at the last moment & mows the whole crop in one day (and the woman is released from the contract with the devil).
797
821-The Devil as AdvocateReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilThe Devil as Advocate
798
821AThief Rescued by the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilAn innocent man (in league with the devil, who once was kind to the devil) is accused of theft. The com-plainant swears by the devil that the man is guilty. The devil helps the accused by carrying the complainant (judge) out of the the court room (and thus repays the hospitality of the accused man.
799
821A*Devil's Trickery Seperates Married Couples & FriendsReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilMisc. type. Devil is helped by old woman (witch) to create quarrel (murder) between couple.
800
821BChiickens from Boiled EggsReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA traveler (soldier, sailor, merchant, student) eats a meal of eggs in an inn & leaves without paying. Some years later when he returns to pay his debt, the innkeeper claims the value of all chickens that would have hatched from the eggs in the meantime. The traveler cannot (is not willing to) pay such an enormous sum, so the innkeeper brings the case to trial. The traveler meets a man (devil, farmer, shepherd, servant, wise man, lawyer, Gypsy, child) who offers to act for him as his lawyer. On the day of the trial the lawyer comes late & excuses himself by explaining that he was cooking beans (other seed) for planting. The judge states that cooked beans could not germinate, & the lawyer answers that chickens could not be hatched from boiled eggs. The case is rejected (the devil carries off the judge).
801
821B*The Devil as Host at DinnerReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilIn heaven people can eat as much as they like, but in hell everyone’s arms are so long (the spoons have fathom-long handles) that the people cannot feed themselves. The greedy & selfish ones do not get anything to eat, but the unselfish people feed one another & have plenty of food.
802
822-Christ as MatchmakerReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilOn their way Christ & St. Peter meet a lazy man lying in the grass. When they ask him for the way, he points out the direction with his foot. Later they meet a hard-working girl who leads them briskly on their way. When St. Peter asks how the girl should be re-warded, Christ answers that the two people should marry, for then they would complement one another.
803
822*The Mythical CreditorReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA supernatural being (devil) lends money to a poor man on the condition that he will claim the man’s soul if the man does not repay the debt within one year. When the poor man comes to pay his debt, the supernatural being is no longer there (is dead, is killed by lightning or has been disappeared secretly). In some variants the farmer avoids having to repay his debt to the devil by giving excuses, or he exempts himself from the obligation to pay by solving the devil’s riddles, by destroy ing the written agreement, or by giving the devil a brooding hen instead of his mother or his “pungent smell” instead of his soul.
804
823A*A Mother Dies of Fright When She Learns that she was about to commit Incest with her sonReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA mother (of Solomon) has a rendezvous with a young man. Her son (Solomon) disguises himself & goes to the meeting place instead of the young man in order to test her chastity. (The mother caresses him & he denounces her. She curses him: the tree should swallow him. Solomon carves a violin while sitting inside the tree.)
805
824-The Devil Lets the Man see his Wife's UnfaithfulnessReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilHe transforms the husband into a goat which he brings to see his wife & her lover. In some variants the devil (wood spirit) shows a man how false his wife is by bringing her a sack of gold. In order to keep the money, she agrees to cut off the head of her sleeping husband. The man awakes in time & punishes his wife.
806
825-The Devil in Noah's ArkReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilThis misc. type comprises various anecdotes dealing with the devil in Noah’s ark. The motifs mentioned do not all occur in any single variant. God commands Noah to build the ark in secret to escape the deluge. In order to keep the work secret, the hammer is silent or the axe never gets dull on the stone chopping block. The devil finds out the secret of the construction of the ark from Noah’s wife. He persuades her to give Noah an intoxicating drink, so Noah tells his secret & the devil destroys the ark. Noah weeps & an angel instructs him how to rebuild it. By performing a washing ritual (water circle) Noah is able to keep the devil away from the ark. A gong calls the animals to board the ark. Some creatures are barred but finally they all enter: the serpent, the insects, the fly, fabulous creatures like the unicorn, the phoenix & the giant. By a ruse the devil manages to enter the ark: he hides near Noah’s wife (at her breast, in her work-basket, in her shadow). She does not enter the ark until Noah calls her with a curse addressed to the devil. On board, the devil, in the form of a mouse, gnaws a hole in the ark & tries to sink it, but a cat swallows the mouse. Helpful animals (serpent, hare, fish, dog) offer to close the hole with part of their body (tail, nose); smaller animals (tortoise, salamander, rabbit) are used as a plug. The serpent demands fresh (human) blood every day for its help. After the deluge, Noah throws the serpent into a holy fire. Its ashes spread with the wind & turn into bloodsucking fleas (lice, mosquitos) .
807
826-List of Sins on CowhideReligious Tales (750-849)810-826 The DevilA pious clergyman has a vision in church: he sees the devil at the altar writing down all the sins of the participants of the mass. In the name of God he takes the list, reads it to the community, & everyone repents. The devil leaves the church.
808
827-A Pious Innocent Man Knows Nothing of GodReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA pious man (farmer) worships God in his own way & never goes to church. A traveling preacher teaches him how to pray properly & continues on his way. When the pious man forgets the prayer he follows the preacher’s ship by walking on the water. By this miracle the preacher recognizes the man’s holiness & understands that pious innocence is pleasing to God.
809
830AThe Boastful DeerslayerReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA lazy man grumbles against God because he feels neglected. An old man advises him to set a trap, & God will certainly help him. The lazy man follows his advice & catches a deer. While he is skinning the animal the old man reappears & points out that God had helped him. But the lazy man emphasizes his own ability. The old man revives the deer & it runs away The lazy man understands too late that God helped him to catch the deer. In some variants the white spots on the deer’s belly (the bones on the leg resembling a knife, the grey hair on the leg) are explained as a result of the skinning process.
810
830B"My Crops will Thrive Here Without God's Blessing"Religious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A farmer sows crops. Unrecognized saints (God) wish him God’s blessing & a good harvest, but the farmer replies his crops will thrive without God’s blessing. When weeds grow in his field, the farmer is converted. (2) A poor & a rich man (farmer, sower, two brothers) sow crops. Saints (passersby) greet the poor farmer, “May God help you!” The farmer thanks them for the greetings & is rewarded with a good harvest. The saints greet the rich in the same way, but he rejects their greetings by saying that his crops will also grow without God’s blessing. His harvest is very poor & he repents his behavior too late. (3) The discourteous sower. A passerby (God) asks a farmer what he is sowing. Rudely he answers that he is sowing stones. The passerby wishes him a good harvest, which turns out to be stone plants. (A farmer tells Christ that he is sowing pumpkins [turnips], though his seed is maize. Thereupon he harvests only pumpkins.) (4) Weather forecast. Christ asks farmers if there will be rain. Two answer that frogs (foxes, other animals) predict rain. The third farmer says that he prays to God for rain. Only the last is blessed with rain.
811
830C"If God Wills"Religious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales, all of which connect the phrase “If God wills” with an event in an instructive or funny way. In most variants a person’s efforts meet with successive misfortunes because he forgets to say, “If God wills”.
812
831-The Clergyman in Disguise as the DevilReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A poor, miserable man finds (advised in a dream, through an angel) a treasure (receives money from God), & tells a clergyman (priest, landlord, rich neighbor) about it. The clergyman disguises himself in an animal skin & pretends to be the devil. He frightens the poor man & takes the treasure. But at home he cannot take the skin off (until the stolen treasure has been returned). (2) The rich man (miller, butcher, baker) fails to take the treasure because the devil himself in disguise as a traveler (black horseman, soldier, hunter) stays at the poor man’s house as an overnight guest (meets him on his way) & kills (abducts) the rich man.
813
832-The Disappointed FishermanReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA fisherman always catches three fishes (bread) for himself (his wife, & his child [children]). The greedy parents kill the child (expose the children) in order to have more fish (bread) for themselves. But from then on the man catches only two fish (the fish disappear completely, they do not have any more bread).
814
834-Poor Brother's TreasureReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales all featuring the phrase “God determines” or “God will care for all”. A person (spouse, brother, sister, girl, man, relative, a rich, a lazy man, neighbor, friend, servant) tells his dream to another person (spouse, brother, sister, relative, a poor, neighbor, friend, servant) saying that in a certain place a treasure is buried (finds a treasure). The second person tries to dig up the treasure at the indicated spot (tries to dig up a treasure at the same spot), or a third person (thieves, neighbor) overhears the conversation & digs there. But instead of the treasure the person unearths only a dead dog (dead cat, some toads, beetles, pot of ants, pot of serpents, pot of glowing embers, pot of dung, skeleton). Angered by this deception he/she throws the animal (pot) into the house (bed, through the window, through the roof) of the dreamer, & everything is transformed into gold (silver, money).
815
836-Pride is PunishedReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA rich man (woman) boasts (often during mass) in his thoughts (in a conversation) that his wealth is so immense that even God could never take it away. When he returns home his property is completely destroyed (house has burned down) & he stays poor for the rest of his life.
816
836FMiser & the Eye OintmentReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA man rubs ointment on his left eye & tells a miser that he can see the treasures of the world. The miser copies him & sees mountains of gold. When he wants to rub oint ment on the right eye as well the man advises him not to do so for he will become blind. The miser does not listen & rubs it on his right eye. He is immediately blinded & becomes a beggar.
817
837-The Beggar's BreadReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA beggar (female beggar) periodically receives a loaf from a rich man (his wife). (A rich miser refuses to give food to a beggar.) When ever the beggar receives the bread he states, “Everything you do, you do it to yourself!” The rich man becomes tired of this (angry about the beggar’s words, wants to get rid of the beggar) so he (and his wife) puts poison into the beggar’s bread. Further on his way the beggar meets a hungry young man (traveler) to whom he gives his bread. The young man dies & it turns out that he is the son of the rich man. So the beggar’s state ment was true.
818
838-Son on the Gallow'sReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesFrom his childhood a mother (in older variants: father) teaches her son to steal (she does not prevent him from stealing). He is caught & condemned to death. On the gallows he asks for permission to kiss his mother for the last time & bites off her nose (tongue, ear). He explains that she taught him to steal (that she spoiled him as a child, that this is her punishment for her neglect).
819
839-One Vice Carries Other With ItReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious Tales(The Three Sins of the Hermit.) A man (hermit, monk) has to choose one of the following vices: theft (murder), lust, drinking. He chooses the last, which seems him to be the least harmful. But when he is drunk, all the other vices follow in its wake.
820
839A*The Hermit & the DevilsReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesIn order to tempt a hermit (bishop, monks), the devil (devils) disguised as a clergyman tries to rejuvenate him or to get him married. Or, a man (pupil of the bishop) is suspected of being a devil because he does not cross himself & leaves the church when in cense is burned & benedictions are said. The brother of the hermit (old man, poor man, monks) overhears the devils discuss their plan sitting under a tree (near a well, at a rock), & warns the hermit. The hermit orders all doors, windows, holes, etc. of the church to be closed. When he burns incense & asks for heaven’s blessings, the devil bursts & mice (spiders) jump out of his mouth. The bishop throws his gloves, which turn into cats & catch the mice. Or the hermit crosses himself & in place of the church (forge), only a stake remains.
821
840-The Punishments of MenReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesWhen a father & his son (travelers) pass the night in a certain house, the son is unable to sleep. He sees wonder ful things happening: a snake creeps from a sleeping man’s mouth into his wife’s mouth; a man’s head is split by an axe, etc. In the morning the master of the house explains that these are punishments of mankind (he explains that the visions were caused by family disharmony & quarrels).
822
840B*The Judgements in This WorldReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA virtuous man, a robber, & a thief (clergyman, farmer & host [teacher]) ask a hermit (old man, God) about their fate (which of them is most certain to go to heaven). He tells them to take three different roads, where they spend the night in various situations. When they come back & tell about their experiences (the first sleeps in a fine house, the second in a forest during a storm & the third in water), the hermit explains that the experiences they had foretell their conditions of life in future.
823
841-One Beggar Trusts God, the Other the KingReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesTwo beggars (blind men, shoemakers, craftsmen), one of whom asks God for help the other of whom asks the king (emperor, sultan, mas-ter), receive two loaves (flat cake, cakes, roasted chicken) from the king. In one of the loaves nothing (bones) is hidden, the other one is filled with (pieces of) gold. By this gift the king intended to reward the beggar who had asked for his help, & to demonstrate his secular power. But the beggars exchange their loaves, because the one who trusted in secular power thought that his loaf was not well baked because it was so heavy. When the king learns about the exchange he agrees that God’s power is stronger than his own.
824
842A*The Beggar Dies in Night LodgingsReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA large sum of money is found in a dead beggar’s clothes (sewn up in his coat). On a clergyman’s advice, the money is used to buy pigs & fatten them. All the pigs are slaughtered except one, which leads the clergyman to the graveyard, where it sinks into the dead beggar’s grave (the beggar is seen riding in flames on one of the pigs to hell). It shows that the money was acquired in a dishonest way.
825
842C*Floating CoinsReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesCoins earned by hard work float on water & bring happiness.
826
843*The Lazy Weaving WomanReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesWhen she sees how a persistent little bird pecks a hole in a stone, she resumes her work diligently.
827
844-The Luck-bringing ShirtReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA ruler (king, mayor, sovereign couple) is sick (unhappy). A doctor (wise man, hermit) advises him to wear (to look for) the shirt of a lucky man. Servants are sent out to look (the ruler himself looks) for such a man, but a lucky man cannot be found. Finally they meet a poor man (shepherd, boy) who seems to fit the requirement. But it turns out that the man has no shirt. The king dies (realizes that luck cannot be bought).
828
844*The Revenge of the Castrated ManReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA male slave (servant, farmhand) who had been punished for a serious crime (adultery) by castration (blinding) blackmails his master to be mutilated (to mutilate himself) by threatening to kill his children (sons, wife). When the man has obeyed, the slave kills the children anyway.
829
844**One's Own Cross is BestReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA man (poor people) who is unhappy with his situation has the opportunity to trade (in a shop) his cross (bag of sorrows) with another one. He discovers that his own fate fits him better.
830
845-The Old Man & DeathReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesAn old man has to carry a heavy load of wood a long way. Tired & exhausted, he puts it down & wishes for death. When death appears & asks why he had been called, the old man explains, “I want you to help me with the load!”
831
846-Devil Always BlamedReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesGod & the devil go for a walk on earth . The devil complains about men’s injustice (after being criticized by God for his impoliteness: he did not answer the people’s greetings & showed them his tongue). He is always blamed for God’s mistakes, but whenever he does something well, God receives the thanks. The devil proves it by pushing a cow (horse, ox) into a ditch. The farmer blames him by asking which damned devil had done that. While the farmer fetches help in the village the devil pulls the animal out of the ditch. When the farmer comes back & sees that his cow has been saved, he exclaims, “Thank God!”
832
846*The Vengeful SaintsReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA man (farmer, shepherd) praises only one of the saints (on his nameday) & disparages the others. The neglected saint takes revenge by sending hail & a bad harvest. But the praised one helps the man & informs him about the other saint’s plans. In another variant the saints dispute as to which of them the man addressed his words, “Good day”.
833
849*The Cross as SecurityReligious Tales (750-849)827-849 Other Religious TalesA merchant borrows money, leaving a cross (icon) as security. During a storm, fearing a shipwreck, he throws a barrel with the money into the water. The barrel floats back to the creditor. In another version a poor man borrows flour from a rich man, leaving an icon of St. Nicholas as security. The rich man threatens to destroy the icon if it is not redeemed in time. A young man over-hears the deal, procures money, redeems the icon, & places it in his mother’s house. In order to earn money he decides to sell goods at a fair. On his way he gives a lift to an old man who later helps him to endure dangers during a wake. Finally the old man revives the dead daughter of the czar & the young man marries her. The old man makes the young wife into a happy, healthy person before he leaves. The young couple returns to the boy’s mother where they learn that the icon is back in its usual place, but that it had disappeared for a while.
834
850-The Birthmarks of the PrincessRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA princess is promised in marriage to whoever is able to describe her birthmarks. A young swineherd (shepherd, tailor) has hogs (geese) that dance to his magic flute. In return for his dancing hogs the princess lets the shepherd boy see her naked & thus he comes to know her secret birthmarks. Or a fisherman offers the princess colorful fishes. In return she undresses herself three times, so that finally he knows the answer. Another suitor (rich man) guesses the answer. As both rivals have solved the riddle, the king then gives a further test: the princess is to marry the suitor to whom she turns in the night. The rivals sleep with her & she turns to the shepherd (because his rival has eaten bad-smelling food or has soiled the bed).
835
851-The Princess Who Cannot Solve the RiddleRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA princess is offered in marriage to whoever can pose a riddle that she cannot solve. A man (prince, stupid boy, shepherd) makes a riddle based on unusual circum-stances which he has witnessed (experienced). (She marries him at this point & the tale ends here.) She sends her maidservants & then goes herself to him at night to learn the answer. He keeps her nightdress (braid) as proof. In court, she answers his riddle but permits him to ask an-other. It refers to her night visit, & rather than answer it, she agrees to marry him. Different riddles are used, for example: (1) I ride on my father & wear (carry) my mother – he has sold his parents & bought a horse & clothes (gun). (2) I ate (am) the unborn – a fetal animal (he was cut from his mother’s womb). (3) I drank water from neither heaven nor earth – horse’s sweat (conden sation from a lamp). (4) One killed three & three killed twelve – his horse was poisoned, birds ate it, thieves ate the birds, & all died. In Turandot the princess herself is the one to set riddles for her suitors to answer: riddle of the sun, of the ocean of the year. If they are not able to find the solution they will be punished by death.
836
852-Lying ContestRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA princess is offered in marriage to the man who can tell so big a lie that she (her father) will exclaim, “That is a lie”. A suitor tells impossible tales of his extraordinary great ox, of a tree that grows to the sky overnight, of a river of honey, of his ascent & descent on a rope of chaff from the sky, of a great cabbage, stable, animals, mushroom, large man, a man who cuts off his head & replaces it, a man who cuts ice with his own hands or of a man who drinks water from his skull. When finally the suitor states that her father served his father as swineherd (when he threatens to report [falsely] her amorous conduct), the princess (king) is brought to say the required words & she has to marry the suitor.
837
853-Hero Catches Princess with Her Own WordsRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA princess is offered in marriage to any man who outwits her in repartee. On the way to the contest the young est of three brothers (stupid boy, suitor) picks up rubbish: a dead crow, an egg, & other objects. The (two) elder brothers fail in talking to the princess. The youngest brother, by producing these objects at the proper time, is able to give an eloquent (often obscene) answer to each of the princess’ questions. He wins her as his bride. In some variants he is imprisoned & escapes by means of his magic tablecloth, magic purse & magic fiddle. He uses his magic fiddle to capture the princess & will release her only if she says, “No” to all his questions. By this means he wins her to his desires & marries her
838
853A"No"Realistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA king with a daughter of a marriageable age is told about the conversation of three of his officers (suitors, young men, soldiers). One says that he intends to love the queen, another wants to sleep with the princess, the third wants gold. The first gets nothing, the third receives the gold. Then the king advises his daughter that she must answer all the questions of the second suitor (suitors who wanted to sleep with the princess) with “No”. By a clever framing of his questions the suitor overcomes her resistance & marries her (the princess agrees to the suitor’s question by saying “No”).
839
854-The Golden RamRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA young man (soldier) writes on a wall (states), “Money is all powerful” (“With money one can even win the princess”). The king is provoked & sets what he believes to be an impossible task. The young man receives as much money as he wants, but within a certain time he has to seduce (find) the princess. If he fails he will be condemned to death. The princess is hidden in a secret place (tower, room under earth, island, secret room, iron palace at the bottom of the sea) & guarded. The young man demands a hollow golden (silver, copper) animal statue (ram, goat, lion, deer, elephant, ox, horse, dancing bear, bird, eagle) & hides inside it. The king buys the statue (which can play music) & installs it in his daughter’s room as en-ter tainmen At night the youth steals out of the statue & amuses himself with the princess. When the statue is damaged it has to be sent for repair, & the youth comes out. Having won the contest the youth may now marry the princess (after she has become pregnant or has given birth to his child). In some variants a king offers his daughter to whoever is able to find her. Three sons of a merchant travel & reach the town where the contest is held. Two of them fail to find the princess & are killed. The third, on the advice of an old woman, orders a hollow golden animal, inside of which he is carried into the secret hiding place of the princess. When the statue is damaged it is taken back. In this way the suitor comes out again & is able to describe the way to the princess’s hiding place (to show a token) to the king. Or, the suitor has to recognize the princess among several similar looking girls or animals; the princess helps him by giving a sign.
840
855-The Substitute BridegroomRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA handsome youth is hired to take the place of a one-eyed (crippled) prince (merchant’s son) at the latter’s wedding. The bride falls in love with the youth & refuses the one-eyed prince. In some variants the young man escapes with the bride. Or, the one-eyed prince is tested. He cannot remember the conversation between the bride & the youth on the preceding night Sometimes the bride searches for the young man & eventually finds him. She gives alms to all passersby, until eventually she recognizes her husband. In other variants the bride offers a reward to all those who tell her a story. The young man appears & tells his story. Or, the youth has left his name (a verse) with the bride. In numerous variants it is predicted that the young man will die at the age of twelve (sixteen) but he outwits this fate.
841
856-The Man with Four WivesRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA youth is driven away by his father when he states that he will marry four wives. While acting as a servant, the youth pretends to be unable to read. He is given a message & learns that the princess intends to elope with the son of a court official. He informs the court official who locks up his son. The youth takes his place & elopes with the princess. At daybreak the princess realizes she cannot return to her par-ents. The young man is bitten by a snake & restored to life by a girl whom he marries. In the form of a parrot he is bought by another princess, whom he marries as well. Forced to flee, he hides in the house of a rich merchant & marries his daughter. Finally he returns to his father with his four wives.
842
857-Louse-SkinRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA louse that has been found on a princess (king) is fat tened to an enormous size (becomes as big as a sheep, calf, ox) & slaughtered. The king (princess, queen) displays the skin in public (has a dress, shoes, gloves made from it; has a chair or drum covered with it; has the louse’s meat pre pared) & announces, that whoever guesses the kind of animal the skin belongs to will receive half of the kingdom & also the princess in marriage. A (disguised) monster (real or false beggar, shepherd, animal, dis-guised robber, devil, cannibal ogre), who learns the secret by trickery, guesses correctly & wins the princess. In some variants the princess is rescued from the monster’s power. She escapes with a magic flight (with the assistance of super natural or skillful helpers).
843
859-The Penniless Bridegroom Pretends to WealthRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA penniless suitor pretends to be wealthy by boasting & manages to marry the daughter of a rich man. This tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) A rich man wants to marry his daughter only to a rich man. A poor suitor (sometimes two) pretends to be rich by disguising him self & telling lies to the girl’s father. When the father is ready to marry him to his daughter the suitor burns a wooden tower & pre tends that all his riches have vanished in the fire. Sometimes the bride exposes him by visiting him incognito in his home. (2) After the marriage the bridegroom takes his bride to show her his land. He puts on soiled (patched) clothes. When she looks at the land he points to a patch in his jacket (trousers) saying, “This patch is mine!” (3) An uncle wants a wife for his nephew. He gives the boy a coin & food to hold while he makes the arrangement. He tells the girl’s father that his nephew has money in his hand & plenty to eat. So he wins the girl. (4) When a servant boasts that his house has 150 lights & a goat-pen, his master marries his daughter to him. Arriving at his home they realize that the lights are the stars shining through the cracks in the roof & one goat is tied to a tree. (5) A suitor touches his whiskers saying, “All of these are mine!”, whereupon the girl thinks he is referring to the fields & livestock which they are riding past.
844
860-Nuts of "Ay ay ay!"Realistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA princess is offered to any man who can bring a glass containing all kinds of water, a bouquet of all the flowers, & nuts of ay, ay, ay! A suitor brings seawater, a beehive, & hazel nuts with thorns so that the king cries, “Ay, ay, ay!”
845
860B*The Abducted WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA merchant abducts another man’s wife (builds an underground passage to her home). Her sons & the husband search for her. After a series of ad ventures they find her. The abductor is punished (escapes).
846
861-Sleeping at the RendezvousRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA mar ried (unmarried) man falls in love with a beautiful woman (prin cess), who makes signs or gives gifts to him. His wife (another helper) tells him that the signs show where the beautiful woman lives. He arranges to meet her but arrives too early & falls asleep. She does not wake him but leaves a token. A later meeting is successful. The adulterous couple is caught & taken to prison. The man sends word to his wife (sister, servant, old woman). She visits him in prison & changes clothing with the beautiful woman (husband), who goes out of the prison, leaving the married couple (two women) behind. The prisoners are set free because there is now no evidence of a crime.
847
861AAbduction at the RendezvousRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA prince (gardener, orphan) falls in love with the image of a beautiful woman & goes to seek her. He is secretly admitted to her room, & the two of them plan to elope together. However, the prince falls asleep & misses their appointment. Another man comes & runs away with the beautiful woman. She escapes from her abductor and, disguised as a man, finds employment. She relates her life story & through this the villain is discovered. He is put to death & the beautiful woman mar ries the prince.
848
862-"He that Asketh Shall Receive"Realistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA hermit wants to prove the truth of the following verse of the Bible (Matthew 7,7), “He that asks shall receive; he that searches shall find; he that knocks shall be admitted.” He asks to marry the ruler’s daughter, & his demand is accept ed on the condition that he will fulfill a difficult task. He returns to his cell where he meets the devil (imprisoned). He lures the devil into a water jug (glass, bottle), forces him to give him the requisite objects (jewel, a lost mug, key to hell, pearls, gold), & hands them over to the ruler. Then he lures the devil back into captivity (jug, glass, bottle). He tells the ruler about his intention & renounces the princess (marries her).
849
863-Baking PancakesRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessA greedy king proclaims a competition to choose the best suitor for his daughter. Three kings’ sons apply & are told to bake pancakes. The first tosses a pancake in the air, where it turns over three times before he catches it in the pan. The second tosses it up the chimney & runs outside to catch it. The third lets the pancake cook until it becomes brown, turns it over, & cooks the other side. He is declared to be the best suitor.
850
864-The Falcon of Sir FederigoRealistic Tales (850-999)850-869 Man Marries the PrincessThe nobleman Federigo Alberighi loves a woman, Monna Giovanna, who does not return his love. He spends all his wealth to woo her until only his falcon is left, which one of the best of its kind. When the lady’s sick son wants the falcon she goes to ask for it. In order to gain her favor, Federigo, not owning anything anymore, serves her unwittingly his precious falcon to eat. When she makes her request it is too late. Nevertheless she is impressed by his gener-ous attitude, changes her mind, & chooses him as her husband.
851
870-The Princess Confined in the MoundRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceBecause of her faithfulness to her betrothed (separ-a tion of the lovers by a quarrel or a war), a princess (along with her maid servant, sister) is confined by her father in an underground prison (cave, hollow hill, cellar, tower). After many (seven) years she escapes & enters service in the king’s (father of her lover) castle (without being recognized). She finds her lover about to marry another (witch, pregnant woman). (She works as lady’s maid for the prince’s new bride.) In order to conceal the pregnancy (because of the hideousness or sickness of the bride) the heroine is asked to take her place on wedding day. On the way to the church she talks to her horse, to the bridge, & to the church-door, & thus reminds the prince of his first love. After the wedding he gives her different objects or she loses things which the second bride had given to her (glove, muffler, necklace, ring, belt). The prince picks everything up. When in the evening the prince tests his wife’s identity by demanding that she repeat their conversation on the way to church she can not recall it without consulting the maidservant. When he demands to see the necklace (when he asks for the objects he had collected), the truth comes to light. He sends the second woman away & marries his faithful princess.
852
870AThe GoosegirlRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA poor girl (neighbor’s girl) is determined to marry a prince, who thinks this is an absurd idea. In vain he tries to make her understand that her plans are senseless. When he is about to marry a bride in accordance with his rank, the poor girl takes the place of his new bride in the marriage bed. The prince discovers the substitution (by the ornaments given to her or by a stone indicating chastity), but never theless he accepts the poor scorned girl as his wife. In the oldest variant from the northern area, a goose-girl declares to a prince that she intends to marry him even if he refuses. When the prince finds a bride of his own rank, the goose-girl warns her about a stone which will reveal her past sexual experiences. The bride asks the goose-girl to substitute for her during the wedding night. Never-theless the stone reveals the truth about the bride’s lost virginity & the prince finally accepts the goose-girl as his true bride. In the southern variants, a neighbor’s daughter believes (because of a prophecy) that she will marry a bey (shah, prince). When he learns about her idea he mocks her. When he marries a woman of his own rank the neighbor’s daughter is asked to substitute for the bride on the wedding night, because the bride had run away (was ugly or was not a virgin). Through special signs he discovers the de cep tion & finally accepts the neighbor’s daughter as his legal wife.
853
871-Princess & OgressRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA princess who looks into a forbidden chamber sees a man’s picture & falls in love. A magician in bird form brings the princess at night to her lover. Once they stay too late. The sun sees them, so that the magician bursts & dies. The girl, left alone, becomes a servant in the palace, where she is threatened by a cannibal princess. She escapes through a narrow window & goes down a well which leads her to the underworld where she meets the chief of devils boiling the brains of the ogress princess. The heroine turns the pot upside down & returns to the well. The ogress is now normal. As a reward for her good deed the heroine is sent to her lover’s house, where she arrives just as he is about to marry another. He recognizes the princess & marries her.
854
871*The Princess Who Goes to Seek TroubleRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceShe loses her way in the forest, hides in a tree. A hunter camps under the tree. His dogs reveal the princess’s hiding place, & she is forced to come down. The hunter sleeps by her side, holding her plaits tightly in his hands. By cutting off her hair, the princess, unnoticed, makes her escape. In Russian variants the hunter pretends to be a sick girl. By ordering the young women to assemble, he recognizes the one who passed the night with him & marries her.
855
871AThe Unfaithful QueenRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA woman goes to a king’s garden (underworld) & sees the queen meet a black lover (beggar, cripple). She denounces the queen & even tually marries the king. Or a friend of the king (another person) follows her & sees everything. On the order of her lover, the queen murders her husband. When she returns to her lover, he spurns her, saying that she will also murder him when she is tired of him.
856
