872*Brother & SisterRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA brother is married to an evil jealous wife who slanders his sister (accuses her of illicit sexual behav-ior) & expels her into the woods. Thanks to the advice of an ogress (water spirit, bird, giant woman) whom she meets there, the sister survives, proves her innocence, & marries a prince.
857
873-The King Discovers his Unknown SonRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA king (in disguise, unrecognized) leaves a token (ring) with a woman (widow) with whom he has passed the night. If she gives birth to a son she is to give him the token. The boy, mistreated because he is a bastard, goes to search for his unknown father. He becomes a baker & has a liai son with a noble girl. The king (his father) orders his execution. Just before the execution the token is discovered & the son is recognized as the son of the king. The king marries the boy’s mother.
858
874-The Proud King is WonRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA woman (princess, the youngest of three daughters) falls in love with a king (prince) whom she knows only from hearsay. She writes to him (has a letter or message sent by her father). But the king scorns & rejects her. (When she tells him that she weeps for him, he sends her a handkerchief; when she tells him that she intends to hang herself, he sends her a rope; when she threatens to commit suicide, he sends her a knife or dagger.) She takes revenge by humiliating him. She arranges to become one of his slaves. After he falls in love with her, she proves who she is by showing him the objects he had given to her. They are reconciled & marry.
859
874*Ariadne's ThreadRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA king promises his son to whatever woman can find her way through the 1000 rooms in his palace. A poor but clever girl succeeds by unwinding a spool of thread.
860
875-The Clever FarmgirlRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceThis type combines various introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductions: (1) A king looks for a wife and/or meets a clever girl by chance . (2) The father of the girl finds a golden mortar in a field and, against the advice of his clever daughter, takes it to the king who demands the pestle as well. (3) A quarrel between a farmer & a nobleman in court is settled by giving both riddles to be solved. The daughter of the farmer gives the right answers. (4) A king finds a girl in a house. When he asks her about her relatives she answers with wit & cleverness. Main part: The clever girl has to perform various tasks set by the king: she must come to the king neither naked nor clad, neither by horse nor on foot. She should estimate the value of the king’s beard or weave a cloth with only a few threads. Or she has to make boiled eggs hatch or carve a fowl & give appropriate pieces to all members of the family. The king marries the girl but orders her not to meddle in his affairs. When he settles a dispute between two farmers unjustly, she advises the wronged man to show the king the absurdity of his decision by an equally foolish act. When the king casts her out & allows her only to take with her the one thing she holds dearest, she takes her sleeping husband with her & thus moves him to forgive.
861
875*The Woman of WeinsbergRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceWhen Weinsberg is besieged, the king per-mits the women to leave & to take with them whatever they can carry (whatever is dearest to them). Each woman carries her (sleeping, drunken) husband out of the city. When the sol diers see what is happening, they try to prevent it. They appeal to the king. He appreciates the women’s clever plan & declares that his promise to the women must be kept.
862
875AGirl's Riddling Answer Betrays a ThiefRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA prince sends his servant to a clever girl with a round tart, thirty cakes, & a capon, & asks the girl if it is the full moon, if it is the thirtieth of the month, & if the rooster has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month & that the rooster has gone to the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge’s sake. She thus shows him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, & the capon.
863
875BClever Girl & the KingRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceThe contents & combinations of the impossible tasks & their countertasks vary in the numerous variants of this type, where a person imposes an impossible task on someone who, in return, imposes an equally absurd countertask. (1) A prince (king) makes an impossible demand: Three unwed girls (virgins) should all give birth to a child at the same time (within nine months). Being summoned to the palace they present themselves disguised as pregnant women by hiding cushions under their dresses. When they are granted a wish, the youngest sister asks for roasted snow. Being unable to produce it, the prince realizes the absurdity of his own demand & marries the girl. (2) A king imprisons an adviser & will release him only on the condition that he brings a horse that is neither black nor white, neither gray nor reddish brown. The adviser claims to have such a horse at home, but the king cannot fetch it on any day of the week. The king sees the absurdity of his own demand & releases his prisoner. (3) A prince finds a block of white marble so beautiful that he orders his tailor to sew him a suit out of the stone. No tailor in the kingdom can do this & he orders them all to be killed. Finally an elderly tailor is asked to make the suit. On the advice of his granddaughter he asks the prince for meat made of mud & a cake of snow for lunch. Thus he points to his master’s own absurd task, whereupon the prince recognizes his mistake & marries the granddaughter. (4) A king orders his adviser (boy) to bring him bull’s milk or to have a bull bear a calf. The adviser’s daughter pretends that her father has given birth to a child & the king thus sees the absurdity of his order. (5) A Muslim king orders his adviser to convert him into a Hindu. The adviser stands by the road rubbing a donkey. When the king asks why, the adviser explains that he is trying to change it into a horse (cow). The king thus sees the absurdity of his order. (6) A king orders his adviser to move a well. On the advice of his daughter, the adviser tells the king that the king must help by send ing him the well. The king thus sees the absurdity of his order. (7) The king asks a farmer for a tribute of calves born to bulls. The farmer’s son replies, “Let me go & ask my father who is guard ing the fields, lets fish come up from the seashore & eat the millet”. (8) Other impossible tasks that occur in some variants are: grow-ing onions out of a stone, winding a rope of chaff, making a rope of sand, counting the leaves of the flowers or the stars in the sky, measuring the sky, sewing a millstone, drying snow on the stove, drying a candle.
864
875B*Storytelling Saves a Wife from Death (Sheherazade)Realistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA king who discovers that his wife is unfaithful has her executed. Then, each night, he takes a new wife & has her killed the following day (after she gives birth). After three years (one year) the vizier is unable to find a suitable woman, so the king condemns him to death. The vizier’s daughter volunteers to marry the king (although her father objects). She tells stories to the king (with the help of her sister, or a courtier tells the stories). The king postpones the execution. After ayear of storytelling (after the wife gives birth), the king realizes that it would be wrong to kill this woman.
865
875DClever Young Woman at the End of the JourneyRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceShe explains various enigmatic statements & actions encountered by people on the way. Finally she succeeds in a contest in repartee & in performing impossible tasks. A (dried) fish laughs in the palace. The king orders his vizier (a man) on pain of death to find out why (to solve another problem). The vizier (his son) sets out on a journey. He meets an old man & makes various enigmatic suggestions (two men travel together & one makes enigmatic suggestions). “Let us carry one another”, means, “Let us tell stories to shorten the way”. – “Let us get horses in the forest”, means, “Let us cut walking sticks”. Or, one man does seemingly absurd things e.g. he wears his shoes in the streams & carries them on dry land. The man’s daughter correctly interprets the enigmatic remarks or the seemingly absurd actions. Finally the vizier’s son marries the girl because she answers the original question: The fish laughed because there was a man dressed in woman’s clothes in the harem.
866
875D*The Prince's Seven Wise TeachersRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA prince goes to seven wise teachers to be educated. When he comes back to the palace he pretends to be mute (on the advice of his teachers). The prince’s stepmother makes advances to her stepson, & then accuses him to his father who condemns the prince to death. The seven wise men & the queen argue the case by telling stories for seven days. In some variants the prince (on advice of his tutors) proves to his father, that one of the queen’s maidservants is a man dressed as a woman. The queen & her lover are hanged (and the prince’s innocence is proved).
867
875EThe Unjust Decision: The Oil Press Gives Birth to a FoalRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA traveler ties his mare to an oilman’s mill. During the night the mare gives birth to a foal. The oilman claims it, saying the mill (vehicle, pale, crutch ed stick) has given birth to the foal. Or, a rich neighbor claims a calf (from his poor neighbor, who owns the cow) saying that his ox had given birth to it. The judge (jackal) has to decide the case. He arrives late, explaining that the sea was burning & that he had to put the fire out with straw (other absurd explanations). Thus the absurdity of the oilman’s claim becomes clear (and the traveler may keep the foal).
868
877-The Old Woman who was SkinnedRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceAn ugly old maid succeeds in marrying her old & ugly sister to a king (prince) who wants to marry a young woman. In order to hide the ugliness of his bride, she shows the prince only her fingers through the keyhole & the sound of her voice. On the wedding night he discovers the deception & throws the bride out of the window where she is caught in a tree. Some fairies observe this & laugh at the dangling old woman. The fairies, grateful for the amusement they have had, recompense the old woman by rejuvenating her into a beautiful girl. The king marries her. Being jealous of her sister’s fortune, the other old maid asks her how she became young. The latter, fearing another ruse of her sister’s, explains that she has been skinned. She advises her sister have a barber skin her (the sister has herself skinned & dies).
869
879-The Basil MaidenRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA prince (young man) passing by asks a girl who is watering her basil plant (ridiculing her) how many leaves her plant has. The girl answers with a counter question: How many stars does the sky have?. The prince does not know the answer & continues on his way ashamed. The next day he returns masked as a merchant (fisherman) & sells something precious to the girl in return for a kiss. Or, the prince repeatedly pricks the girl with a needle; she com-plains of insect bites. The next day the prince mocks the girl or reveals the deceit (the kiss & the pricking) to her. Next the girl disguises herself as a doctor (death, angel of death), pays a visit to the prince who is feeling sick, & mistreats (mocks) him or makes him believe that death has come to him. Disguised as merchant the girl sells something to the prince on the condition that he kisses his donkey under the tail (his horse’s leg). The prince marries the girl, intending to avenge himself by killing her on the wedding night. But she puts a life-sized doll made of sugar (syrup) in her place & hides herself under the bed. When the prince destroys the doll with a sword-thrust & accidentally tastes its sweet “blood”, he regrets his deed. (The girl comes out of her hiding place & they are reconciled to one another.)
870
879*King Serves His Future WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA king in disguise overhears three (two) (poor) girls expressing their wishes. The youngest declares that even if the king would like to marry her, he would have to serve her first. The king fulfills the wishes of the elder ones & punishes (imprisons, condemns to death) the youngest. The clever girl escapes (is saved) and/or finds a treasure (and builds a castle). Dressed in new clothes she makes the king fall in love & serve her. She discloses her identity & they marry.
871
879AFisher Husband of the PrincessRealistic Tales (850-999)870-879 Woman Marries the PrinceA princess falls in love with a very beautiful fisherman’s son & wants to marry him. The boy, worried about his low social standing, warns her that if she ever reproaches him for his social status, he will never talk again. On the wedding night the princess mocks him for his clumsy manners. He leaves her immediately & takes employment at the king’s court. The king, impressed by his beauty, regrets that he cannot speak & promises a reward to whoever succeeds in making him talk again; failure will be punished by death. The princess comes disguised as a man (doctor). For three nights she tries in vain to cure him & is finally led to the gallows. The boy (her husband), who is one of the spectators at her exe cution, speaks to her (in a very degrading way) at the very last mo ment & so saves her life.
872
880-The Man Boasts of his WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA man boasts of the cleverness of his wife at a king’s court. He is imprisoned (in the royal castle) in order to test whether his wife is able to find & to free him. When she learns about his imprisonment, she disguises herself as a man & comes to live at the court. The princess falls in love with her & their marriage is planned. When her masculinity is doubted she has to undergo ordeals to prove her sex, but passes them all. Finally she manages to free her husband by a trick (ex change of clothes) & escapes with him.
873
880*The Gambler's WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA soldier beats his general at gambling & then marries the general’s daughter. Later, he loses all his money at gambling, & returns to his poor parents. His wife wins back what he had lost & finds her husband.
874
881-Oft-proved FidilityRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA merchant marries (falls in love with) a woman (princess) of high descent (extraordinary beauty). During the absence of her husband (on a journey), another man (relative, several men) tries to seduce her but is rejected. The man slanders her to her husband. He believes the false evidence that she was unfaithful during his absence & orders that she be killed. She asks to be left in a box in the sea, & escapes. A doctor (another man) heals her & wants to marry her (she is found by other men who all want to marry her). Through her cleverness she eludes or escapes from all the men who (fall in love with her and) want to possess her. After these adventures she disguises herself as a man & becomes king. She has her picture (painting, photo, statue) displayed in a public place (a personal report is published, her life-story is written on a vault). Every person who comments on the picture is imprisoned. All the men she had known during her life, her husband included, come (to the picture) & describe their meeting with her. The woman in man’s clothes condemns, pardons, or recompenses them according to the roles they played in her life. Finally she discloses her identity & is reunited with (marries) her husband. (She changes roles with her husband so that he becomes ruler.)
875
881AThe Abandoned Bride Disguised as a ManRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA prince & his bride are separated in a forest. She escapes from her would-be seducers. (She shoots an arrow, saying she will marry the one who first re turns with it, & escapes while the men pursue the arrow.) The bride disguises herself as a man & is chosen king (given other high honors in a strange land). Or she dis-guises herself as a servant to the king & overpowers an ogress. (She hears a cry at night & finds an ogress trying to devour a human corpse. She cuts off the ogress’s leg or the like & is rewarded by the king.) She “marries” a princess (princesses). She displays her picture (statue) in a public place & posts servants (stays there herself) to overhear comments. She gives alms to all comers. In this way she finds her husband. The would-be seducers are punished.
876
882-The Wager on the Wife's Chastity (Cymbeline)Realistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & Innocence(Cymbeline.) A husband (ship captain) praises the virtue of his wife (poor girl) & makes a wager with a friend (business partner, merchant, adversary) regarding her chastity. After trying in vain to seduce the woman, the friend, with the help of a corrupt servant, secretly goes into her bedroom (hidden in a box). There, without touching her, he discovers a birthmark on her breast and/or secures a token (ring or clothing) & uses it to pretend that he seduced her. The hus band believes him, casts off his wife (orders someone to kill her), & leaves home. The woman escapes death & travels in man’s clothes. She gains a high position at a foreign court. There she meets her husband, who has become destitute & proves her innocence to him. In some variants she follows her husband & serves him un-recognized (in man’s clothes) for several years. Finally the slanderer is unmasked & the couple is reunited.
877
882A*Suitors at the Spinning WheelRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceIn the absence of her husband (ship captain) a wife is annoyed by three suitors. She tricks them into a room & makes them spin (work).
878
883AThe Innocent Slandered MaidenRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceIn the absence of her father (parents), a relative (friend, clergyman, guardian) attempts to seduce a young woman. When she rejects him, he writes a slanderous letter (out of revenge) to her father accusing her of loose conduct. The father commands his son to kill his sister. Out of pity (believing in her innocence) the brother spares her & gives the liver (heart, blood) of an animal to the king as proof of the murder. The girl is abandoned. A king (prince) finds her & marries her. When the king has to go to war (when the woman with her children wants to pay a visit to her father), he tells a servant (officer, soldier, dignitary) or a relative (brother, uncle) to take care of (accompany) his wife. A second attempt at seduction is made, & the woman’s children are often killed. She escapes in man’s clothes (dis-guised as soldier, officer or shepherd) & works unre cog-nized as a servant in her father’s house (in an inn, as a shepherd). Despite the slanderer’s statement that the queen is dead (abducted, escaped, has murdered her children), the king searches for his wife (father searches for his daughter). Finally all persons concerned meet together & the woman in man’s clothes tells them what had happened (in the form of a tale). The family is reunited & the evildoers are punished.
879
883BThe Punished SeducerRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceBefore going on a journey, a man (merchant) locks up his three daughters, & gives each of them a magic object (ring, flowers) that will indicate if they are un-chaste. A prince (knight, three princes, three young men) enters the girls’ room secretly (disguised as a merchant) & seduces the two elder ones. The clever youngest sister resists his attempt at seduction & teases the prince. When her sisters have given birth, she dis-guises herself as a beggar & carries the newborn children to the princes’ castle (to their fathers). When the merchant comes home & realizes what has happened, he intends to kill the two sisters. (But when the princes agree to marry his daughters he abandons his plan). The prince who wants to marry his youngest daughter plans to kill her on her wedding night. She puts a sugar doll in her place. He cuts the doll with his sword, & when he tastes the “blood” he realizes “the sweetness” of his wife & regrets his deed. (The girl shows up & they are reconciled with one another.)
880
883CThe Boys with Extraordinary NamesRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA maiden is cast out from home, marries a man of the lower class, & has three sons whom she names “‘What was I?”, “What am I?” & “What will I be?” (the like). In this way she attracts her father’s attention, & becomes reconciled with him.
881
884-The Forsaken Fiancee: Service as MenialRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceThis misc. type comprises various tales with different contents. The variants include different combinations of the following motifs: A woman disguised in man’s clothes, test of a person’s gender, separation of lovers (couple), wife finds lost husband as he is about to marry another, girl in menial disguise at lover’s court, the forgotten fiancée recognition of lover through displaying a picture, & the prince marries his first fiancée.
882
885-The Facetious WeddingRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young woman is forced by her parents to marry a clergyman even though she has fallen in love with a poor boy (soldier). When the young man (returning from a journey) comes unrecognized to her wedding, the priest jokingly marries him to the girl He reveals himself. In German variants Friedrich II requests a mock wedding between the bride & a soldier.
883
885AWoman Feigns DeathRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young woman (princess) has fallen in love with a poor young man, but her parents make her marry another man. The rejected wooer leaves for a journey. At her wedding the girl falls down dead (feigns death). Her lover returns, resuscitates her, & marries her. Or, he secretly escapes with her & a wax doll is buried in her grave.
884
886-The Girl Who Could Not Keep the SecretRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young man leaves his bride because she cannot keep secrets. He finds a new bride. At the betrothal the first fiancée says that she still hopes to marry him. When the new fiancée learns that the young man had abandoned the former bride because of her talkativeness, she boasts of her superiority in keeping silent: that she has concealed all her previous lovers (the killing of her children). The young man decides to marry his first bride.
885
887-GriseldaRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA marquis (king) who loves his freedom marries because his subjects demand it. He chooses a wife of the lower class (named Griselda), & demands that she promise always to be obedient. When she has given birth to two children, he tests her obedience by taking them away making her believe that he has killed them. After 15 years, he casts her off & orders her adult children (who had grown up in another family) to come home. He pretends to marry Griselda’s daughter, & makes Griselda serve her at the wed-ding feast. When Griselda accepts even this humiliation, he explains everything to her (that everything had been a test), & takes her again as his wife.
886
887A*Precious Stones in BricksRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young man complains that he possesses brains but no money. He decides to spend all his hard-earned money to buy a wife. The wife teaches him how to enclose precious stones in bricks. He takes them to the king (czar) as a gift & receives a reward.
887
888-The Faithful WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man who is taken into slavery in Turkey wears a shirt that remains white as long as his wife at home remains true to him. The sultan sends a messenger to seduce the wife, but in vain. Disguised as a pilgrim (monk), she reaches the sultan’s court. Through her harp-playing & her singing she wins the sul-tan’s favor. He presents her with a (three) Christian slave, who is in fact her husband. When the husband has returned home he wonders what happened to his wife. She arrives in her pilgrim dress & identifies herself as his rescuer. (2) A king goes to a foreign land, where he is thrown into prison. His wife disguises herself as a gusli-player, goes to the hostile king & receives his permission to take one of the prisoners with her. She chooses her husband. The husband does not recognize her & later reproaches his wife for not trying to help him. The truth is discovered.
888
888AThe Wife Who Would Not be BeatenRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA prince (merchant’s son) says he will marry only a woman who will submit to a beating each day. When he is married his wife refuses to allow him to beat her, saying he does not support her (but her father does). The prince sets out to win his fortune but is enslaved (loses all his fortune, must work at menial tasks). His wife disguises herself as a man & frees him (by winning back all he had lost) She wins chess games by releasing mice which are chased by a trained cat (she tricks the cheaters, she wins the wager). She secures tokens from her husband. At home, when the husband falsely boasts of his exploits, the wife displays the tokens. Her husband never beats her again.
889
888A*The Basket MakerRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA man learns a trade (basket-making, painting) in order to support a wife. She is taken away by a sea captain. Years later, she recognizes her husband when she sees his baskets displayed.
890
889-Wager on the Faithfulness of the ServantRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA man (king, lord, farmer) boasts that his servant (shep-herd, farmhand) would never tell a lie. His neighbor (foreign king, visitor, friend, governor) makes a wager on the faithfulness of the servant. In order to test the servant he is sent with a letter to the neighbor’s wife (queen, daughter) where the woman makes him drunk & seduces him. In some variants the maidservant (daughter, wife) is sent to the sherpherd & persuades him to give her in return for her favors a lamb or the golden horns (liver, skin, meat) of his master’s best ox (sheep, horse). Or he is made to believe that he lost his master’s pro perty by gambling while drunk. Later the servant rehearses how he could justify his behavior to his master: He puts his stick into the earth with his hat on top & speaks to it. But all possible lies seem inadequate to him, so he decides to tell the truth. Thus his master wins the wager (the servant is rewarded for his honesty).
891
890-The Pound of FleshRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA contract entitles the lender (Jew, merchant, usurer, nobleman) of a sum of money (that has been used to woo or to buy a woman) to cut a pound of flesh (eye, head, single limbs) from the debtor’s (Christian or Muslim merchant, goldsmith, Jew nobleman) body if the loan is not repaid in time. In some variants the husband goes abroad for some time, & other men try to seduce his wife. She deceives them all & takes their money in payment for keeping the matter secret. When the time limit has been reached, the case is brought to the judge (pope, king, sultan, the debtor’s wife disguised as judge, another woman in man’s clothes). In some variants, before the judgment has been executed, the creditor is offered the money if he will forgo the pound of flesh, but he does not agree. The judgment formally favors the creditor but adds some impossible conditions: when cutting the flesh of the debtor he must take the exact amount (he must not shed blood), otherwise he will be punished severely. Thereupon the creditor re nounces his demand to mutilate the debtor (and is punished in addition).
892
890**The Debtor's BedRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA knight (merchant) with heavy debts dies. The ruler (creditor) wants to sell the bed for a high price, saying that it must be very good since the knight slept well in it despite his debts.
893
890A*The Snake in the BosomRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA (sleeping) girl (young man) has a snake in her bosom. All her relatives refuse to help remove it. Finally her lover finds (removes) the snake, which turns to gold.
894
891-The Man Who Deserted his WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA man (prince, merchant) marries a woman, intending to revenge himself for an insult. He deserts her untouched before the wedding night (imprisons her), & sets her the seemingly impossible task of bearing him a son (to get a foal of his mare or to fill a sealed box with gold) & leaves her. She follows him in disguise (first in man’s clothes) & has a love-affair with him without being recognized (three times). She gives birth to a son (three children). Her husband returns, intending to marry another woman. Upon seeing her son (children, tokens) he realizes that she has fulfilled the task. They are reconciled & he sends the other woman away.
895
891ACrystal PalaceRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA princess (only daughter) is kept isolated in a crystal palace. A prince finds her (sees her from far away) & they fall in love, but he leaves without asking to marry her.
896
891B*The King's GloveRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceThe king admires (falls in love with) the (sleeping) wife of a courtier (knight) & leaves his glove (ring) on her bed. She is suspected of unfaithfulness. The king invites the courtier & his wife to a banquet, where all must tell their adventures. The king & the woman do so in rhyme, & the husband realizes their (his wife’s) innocence
897
891C*"The Pig Eats the Money"Realistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA wife falsely accused of giving away money (to her lover). Her husband threatens to kill her but their child says that the pig (ox) has eaten the money. The man kills the pig & finds the money. He begs his wife’s forgiveness.
898
892-The Children of the KingRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceWhile a prince is in the service of another king, his sister must govern the country. However, seduced by a certain knight, the princess substitutes a maidservant. As proof of his seduction (rape) the knight shows a cut finger (hair, knowledge of the birthmarks) to the brother. The prince repudiates his sister, but she justifies herself by giving proof of her chastity. Her innocence becomes apparent & the knight is punished
899
893-The Unreliable Friends.Realistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young man boasts of his numerous friends. His father intends to test them. A slaughtered animal (hog, statue, tub) is hidden in a sack (in a dark corner of the house). The young man pretends to have killed a person unintentionally. When he asks his friends to help him bury the corpse they all re fuse. Only his father’s “half-friend” is ready to share the danger with him (remains true to him in his feigned trouble)
900
894-The Ghoulish Schoolmaster & the Stone of PityRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA princess accidentally sees her school -master eating a corpse (a human being). She escapes. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A princess marries a prince abroad & gives birth to several children, who are kidnapped by the ghoulish teacher. The teacher leaves blood (other signs) that point at the mother as murderer of her children, she is imprisoned. When the prince goes on a journey, his imprisoned wife asks him to bring her a stone of patience (and a knife), which he does. The prince overhears his wife telling her sorrows to the stone. The stone swells & finally bursts because it cannot bear the sorrow (and she tries to kill herself with the knife). The prince embraces his innocent slandered wife, & the cannibal teacher brings back her children. (2) The princess finds a sleeping prince who can only be awakened if she would care for him for a certain period (seven years, seven months, seven days). Just before the end of the time limit, the princess delegates her task to a female slave & falls asleep. When the prince awakens & sees the slave he thinks that she has saved his life. He marries her, & the princess becomes her maidservant . The princess asks for a knife & a stone of patience. The king’s marshal overhears her telling her story to the swelling stone. When the prince listens, the stone bursts out of pity. When she is about to kill herself with the knife, the prince interferes. They marry & the slave girl is punished
901
896-The Lecherous Holy Man & the Maiden in a BoxRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA holy man (trusted adviser) falls in love with a beautiful girl, but she spurns his advances. He convinces the girl’s father (husband) that she is un chaste (will bring calamities to the kingdom) & that she should be placed in a box & cast into the river (delivered to him). He instructs his followers to bring the box to him, to leave it in his room, to securely lock the doors, & to ignore any sounds that may come from his room. A prince (other helper) finds the box before it falls into the hands of the holy man’s followers, removes the girl, & puts a mad dog (tiger, wild animal) into the box. The holy man is torn to pieces when he opens the box. The girl marries her rescuer & is reconciled with her family.
902
897-The Orphan Girl & Her Cruel Sister-in-LawRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young girl is left by her seven brothers while they go on a trip in the care of her seven sisters-in-law. They set tasks for her, hoping she will be unable to perform them so that they can punish her. She is helped by various animals: to carry a large load of sticks from the forest without using a rope, a helpful snake winds around the sticks; to fetch a tigress’s milk, the tigress willingly gives it; to fetch water in a sieve, frogs fill the holes in the sieve; to gather seeds scattered in a field, birds help her. While she is performing the last task, the brothers appear. The sisters-in-law are punished.
903
898-The Daughter of the SunRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & Innocence(The Speechless Maiden. The Doll Bride.) In order to evade a prophecy that a princess would be impregnated by the sun & bear a child, she is confined in a tower. Nevertheless the prophecy is fulfilled. The daughter of the sun is exposed in a garden & rescued by a prince. In some variants a childless couple, after having a dream, build them selves a girl (doll) from wood (lime, paste). A prince wants to marry her. On the way to the prince the (mistress of the) sea ex-changes the doll with her own daughter, whom the prince marries. The prince does not recognize her extraordinary origin, so she stays mute & rejects him. The prince marries three women of royal blood, but they all die when they try to imitate the abilities of the first woman (e.g. objects obey her commands, her cut nose grows again, when she puts her finger in hot oil cooked fish appear, etc.). When the prince feigns an illness the girl cares for him, reveals her origin, & consents to the marriage. In other variants the prince overhears objects quarreling & learns how he should address her: daughter of the sun (daughter of the sea, etc.). When he calls her in this way she speaks & marries him.
904
899-AlcestisRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocenceA young man (only son) is doomed to an early death: He is predestined to die on his wedding day. In some variants Norns (an angel, death) predict his death for the third day after his birth (another day). God (saints, St. George, Demetrius) intercedes with the Norns (death), & they agree that the young man may live if another person is willing to die for him or to give him half (a part) of his own remaining lifetime. The members of his family (his parents) refuse, but his bride is ready to die for him. God saves both the young man & the woman who is willing to sacrifice herself, & punishes the hard-hearted parents.
905
899APyramus & ThisbeRealistic Tales (850-999)880-899 Proofs of Fidelity & InnocencePyramus & Thisbe, children of neighboring families, are in love, but their fathers have forbidden them to meet. They use a crack in the wall between their houses to communicate in secret. One day they decide to meet on the following night outside the city under a mulberry tree. When Thisbe arrives she is frightened by a lion & hides in a cave. Before the lion goes away, he chews on a scarf that Thisbe had dropped, & leaves marks of blood on it.Pyramus comes and, seeing the scarf (other evidence), believes that Thisbe is dead & kills himself. Thisbe returns, finds her lover dead, & kills herself with his sword. The blood-red berries of the mulberry tree commemorate the lovers’ unhappy end.
906
900-King ThrushbeardRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyA princess refuses all (one) who come to her as suitors without giving a reason. She ridicules them & calls them ugly names (Thrushbeard). Her father, angry at this behavior, decides that she has to marry the next man who comes, even if he is a beggar. The last rejected wooer decides to take revenge. He appears disguised as a beggar (in arrangement with her father) & the princess is forced into marriage (the beggar purchases the right to spend three nights with her; she becomes pregnant). The couple runs away (is banished by the king). On the way the prince in disguise humilates his new wife. She has to beg & sell in the marketplace, she has to work in the kitchen of his own castle & he even forces her to steal. During a celebration (supposedly the wedding of the once reject ed prince) he, in his true character as prince, exposes her as a thief before all the people at court. Only then does he reveal himself to her as her beggar husband. He forgives her for her haugh-tiness & their official wedding is celebrated.
907
900C*The Half-PearRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyA princess is to be married to whoever wins a tourna-ment. She mocks a knight who eats half a pear without peeling it (and without offering her the other half) calling him, “Knight of the half-pear”. He disguises himself as a deaf-mute fool & lies down before the palace. He is invited to sit at the fireplace inside the palace. When his penis becomes erect he is summoned by the princess & has sexual intercourse with her. The next day he is thrown out & returns to the tournament in his former knight’s dress where he alludes clearly to the night’s events. He marries the embarrassed princess.
908
901-Taming of the ShrewRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyA man marries the youngest of three sisters, who is strongminded & shrewish. In order to demonstrate how he punishes disobedience, he shoots his dog & his horse when they do not obey his (nonsensical) orders. He brings his wife to sub-mission. In a wager with his brothers about which has the most obedient wife (sisters-in-law) it becomes evident that only his wife is truly obedient. He wins the bet.
909
901B*Who Works Not Eats NotRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyA lazy wife (daughter, daughter-in-law) learns (is forced) to work by the measures taken by her husband (father, father-in-law). She gets something to eat only after she has finished her work.
910
902*The Lazy Woman is CuredRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyA lazy woman does not perform her household work (she deceives her husband by pretending to have finished it). She always shows her husband the same spool of thread, until one day she has only one dirty (no) dress left. Her husband takes her (naked) enveloped in a bundle of straw (animal skin) to a wedding (festivity). The bundle (animal skin) falls apart & the woman stands naked before the public. Thus she is cured of her laziness & becomes industrious from then on. In some variants the woman wears a very dirty dress or is naked. When she sees her husband coming back from the market, she thinks he is bringing a new shirt for her, but instead of a shirt he is carrying a white goose in his arms.
911
903A*Quick-Tempered MaidenRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyQuick-Tempered Maiden finds a man equally quick-tempered. Misc. Type.
912
903C*Mother-in-Law & Daughter-in-LawRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyThe bad mother-in-law who lets her daughter-in-law go hungry is punished (the voice of a hidden clergyman threatens her with the devil). She reforms.
913
905A*The Wicked Queen Reformed by Whipping by a CobblerRealistic Tales (850-999)900-909 Obstinate Wife Learns to ObeyWhile asleep, the wicked queen is made to exchange places (by an angel, magician, ordinary man) with the humble cobbler’s wife (who is always beaten by her husband). When the queen wakes up, she thinks herself in hell. The cobbler reforms her by his whippings & from then on she obeys her husband.
914
910-The Clever PreceptsRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a person who is given a precept (of various types) by another person. The precept is observed or disregarded.
915
910AFather's Precepts DisregardedRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA dying man gives three precepts to his son (to another person). Each variant includes three of the following precepts: (1) Never tell a secret to a woman. (2) Do not make friends with (trust) a policeman (soldier, ruler). (3) Do not plant a thorny tree (without permission) on your property. (4) Do not adopt a child (godchild, orphan, child of thief). (5) Do not visit your friends (parents) too often. (6) Avoid the house of a red-bearded man. (7) Do not marry a woman from abroad (be careful in your choice of a wife). (8) Do not let your wife go to a wedding accompanied only by her parents (do not let her go for a long visit to her parents). (9) Do not bargain for your horse, do not make it run down a hill. (10) Do not lend your horse The son (person) disregards his father’s precepts (he thinks they are nonsensical) & suffers misfortune (in order to test the precepts, he acts against them). (1) After burying (hiding) an animal (human being) at a special place he tells his wife about it. When they quarrel & he beats her, she calls him a murderer & he is arrested. (2) His friend arrests him without listening to the true version of the event (he condemns him by jumping to conclusions without identifying the victim). (3) His turban sticks in the thorns of a tree, & his friend forces him to present himself without it. (The thorn tree he planted causes for a quarrel with a neighbor to whom he has to pay compensation.) (4) His adoptive son is willing to execute him, when an execu-tioner is not available. (5) His hosts are annoyed by his numerous visits & offer him bad meals (mindful of his father’s advice, he keeps a sample). (6) He passes the night in a forbidden house (where a red-haired man lives). After taking a shortcut, he finds himself in a den of thieves. He escapes (with the help of a servant whom he later marries). (7) He finds out that the woman he intends to marry has a lover (he keeps his trousers as evidence). (8) He lets his wife go to a wedding with her family & her new-born child. Disguised himself as a Turk, he meets her & tries to seduce her & takes her son away. His mother-in-law sets fire to the house & says that the child was killed in the fire. The husband re turns the child & forgives his wife. (9) Nobody wants to buy his horse because the price is too high. It falls sick (is injured) & dies (he keeps the skin as evidence). (10) His mare, which his friend had borrowed, dies from over-work. When his friend apologizes for his mistake he forgives him. Finally he realizes that his father’s precepts were indeed wise. (1) Just before he is arrested, he shows the judge where to find the victim. (2) To his astonishment, it is an animal. (3) It turns out that the missing person (animal) is still alive. (4) He explains that he had only intended to test the precepts of his father. (5) He is immediately freed & prosecutes the persons who tried to harm him. (6) He invites his bride & his parents to his home. (7) He explains to them the significance of the souvenirs of his errors. (8) He casts off his bride.
916
910BObservance of the Master's PreceptsRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA poor man who cannot provide for his family takes service with a rich farmer for one year for a certain amount of money. After he has completed his service, the farmer gives him his choice of the agreed wages or a good precept. The man chooses the precept: “Always follow the main road”. Disappointed by this he hires on for a second & then a third year after which he is given various precepts: “Mind your own business” or “Do not sleep where a young woman is married to an old man” & “Always postpone your anger until the next day”. Feeling discouraged the poor man gets ready to go home. His master gives him a loaf of bread (with money hidden inside) which he should not cut until he reaches home. At a fork in the road the poor man follows the farmer’s advice & takes the old main road instead of a shorter new one. He later learns that he would have been waylaid by robbers on the new road. At dusk he reaches a house where he spends the night. There he sees strange events, but he does not interfere. When he is about to leave, his host calls him back & rewards him with a large sum of money for his discretion (indiscretion would have brought death to the host’s wife). After he has refused to sleep in a house where a young woman is married to an old man, he witnesses a murder. When an innocent man, who spent the night at the woman’s house, is condemned for the murder, he testifies to the man’s innocence. When the poor man finally reaches home & looks through a window, he sees a stranger kissing his wife. He intends to kill the man, but fortunately postpones his anger at the last moment. The stranger was his own grown son. When the family gathers around the table to celebrate their reunion, the poor man cuts the bread & finds all the money he had earned hidden inside.
917
910CThink Carefully Before You Begin a TaskRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsIn the market (public place) a young man (king, prince) meets an old (wise) man in a shop where “wisdom” is told instead of goods. The old man explains to the wondering young man that the “wisdom” he sells would be very useful for ruling people. The young man decides to buy a precept for five coins. The old man gives him the following maxim: “Whatever you do, do wisely & think of the consequences” & he adds that if the young man will follow the precept he will become the most powerful person in the whole kingdom. Upon his father’s death the young man becomes king & orders that the maxim be displayed on all the walls of the palace. When enemies bribe his barber to cut the king’s throat while shaving him, he reads the maxim at the last moment. Afraid of the possible conse-quences, he confesses his intention (and desists from his plan). The value of the precept is recognized.
918
910C*The Officer & the Barber's ApprenticeRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsAn officer goes to a barber for a shave. He promises to pay well unless the barber cuts him, in which case the officer will kill him. The barber refuses to shave the officer, & so do the two other bar bers in the shop. Only the apprentice will agree to this bargain. All goes well. As the officer leaves, he asks, “Weren’t you afraid?” The apprentice answers, “No. If I had cut you, I would have cut your throat right away with the razor.”
919
910DTreasure Behind the NailRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsWhen he dies, a rich merchant advises his spendthrift son that if ever he spends his entire fortune, he should hang himself from a special nail (beam, hook). After his father dies, the son wastes his inheritance with his friends until he has nothing left. When he tries to hang himself in despair, the nail tears out of the wall & a treasure, which his father had hidden there, falls down. From then on the young man leads a virtuous life (pays his debts).
920
910E"Find the Treasure in Our Vineyard"Realistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA poor dying farmer tells his sons that he has hidden a treasure in his vineyard (field, ground). After his death his children dig everywhere & thus loosen the soil of the vineyard. They do not find any treasure but the vineyard becomes very fruitful. (Then they understand their father’s advice.)
921
910FQuarreling Sons & the Bundle of TwigsRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA man (king, farmer) explains to his (quarreling) sons, that a bundle of twigs (sticks, arrows, lances) cannot be broken, whereas separately the pieces are easily broken. Thus he demonstrates the value & the strength of unity. His sons apply the lesson.
922
910GMan Buys a Pennyworth of WitRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA rich man has a mistress although he loves his wife. His wife, hoping to change his behavior, asks him to bring her wit instead of a present (gives him a penny to buy the wit). In the market he buys wit in a bundle which also includes some rags. The seller advises him to wear the rags & to present himself as a beggar first to his mistress & then to his wife. His mistress re jects her apparently penniless lover whereas his wife is ready to help him pay his debts. He is convinced of his wife’s love, confesses the truth to her, & decides to be faithful to her. The wife is happy that her husband finally has come to his senses.
923
910KWalk to the IronworksRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA dying nobleman who had served a long time at the king’s court asks the king to employ his son. The king agrees & the dying man gives three precepts to his son. First: “Never associate with enviers or slanderers” (“Do not talk about what you have seen” or “Do not dishonor your master’s house with adultery”). Second: “Al-ways sympathize with your master’s fortune & emotions”. Third: “Never pass a church without going inside” (“Never neglect to go to mass”). When his father has died the young man begins his service at the king’s court. An envious man slanders him & accuses him of de siring the queen. When he, following his father’s advice, starts to weep when the queen weeps, his behavior is interpreted as proof of a love affair & it is decided that he must be killed. His adversary (slanderer) intends to throw him into the blast furnace of the iron-works (limekiln, mine, well, brewery, baking oven) or to kill him by some other means. He is sent to the place where he is to be killed. Those who are charged with his murder are told to kill the first man who arrives (he brings along a message, a letter commanding his murder or cer tain object such as a handkerchief or lemon). According to his father’s advice, the young man goes to mass on the way & is delayed. His slanderer (adversary), impatient to see him dead, arrives the place before him & is killed instead of him. The innocent young man then reports his slanderer’s death. He is restored to favor, or gains fortune, wealth & honor.
924
910LDo Not Drive the Insects AwayRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsThis tale exists chiefly in three dif-fer ent forms: (1) A fox crossing a river falls into a crevice & cannot get out. He becomes infested with lice (flies). A hedgehog passing by sees the fox suffering & offers to help. The fox refuses, saying that these lice are already full, & if the hedgehog takes them away, new lice who are even hungrier will come. (2) A sick (injured) man covered with sores is bothered by flies. He refuses any help, saying that hungry flies bite twice as hard as full ones. (3) A merchant is captured by robbers (farmers want to punish a corrupt mayor or a thievish miller, a landlord wants to punish one of his tenants). They undress him (and cover him with honey) & tie him to a tree where there are many flies. A man (knight) offers to drive the insects away, but the merchant refuses, saying that others even worse & more hungry will come in their place. (The farmers set the mayor [miller] free & decide to let him stay in his office, lest someone even greedier would take his place.)
925
910MPrayers for the TyrantRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsAn old woman prays every day for the health of a hated tyrant. Asked why she does this, she explains that she has twice seen a horrible tyrant die, only to be replaced with one even worse. Therefore she hopes that the present one will live for a long time.
926
910NThe Magic BoxRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA poor farmer (farmwife) complains to his neighbor (clergyman) that his farm is not doing well. The neighbor gives him a box which he says is magic, & tells the farmer to carry it once each day through his house & barn. When the farmer does this, he notices what the problems are & becomes wealthy. In another version, an older woman tells an incompetent house-wife that she should look all over her house & yard for a white sparrow. As she does this, the housewife puts everything in order & becomes prosperous.
927
912-The Wise Man & the Rain of FoolsRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsDuring a certain rainy period, everyone on whom the water falls becomes a fool (is compelled to sing & dance). A wise man arrives & sees that all the adults & children have gone crazy. He joins them in their foolery. He asks why they behave thus, & they reply him that it is because of the rain. The wise man tastes some of the rainwater & he also becomes a fool. In Arabic variants a ruler hears that everyone who came into contact with the rainwater became crazy, so he does not drink it. But when he sees that he no longer holds his former power & authority, he drinks the water.
928
915-All Depends on How You Take ItRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA widower with a clever, industrious daughter marries a widow with a stupid, lazy daughter. When the children are grown & ready to leave home, their mother (father) gives them three indirectly expressed precepts to guide them in their new independence (employment, marriage). On a visit the mother (parents) realizes that her own daughter has followed the precepts literally & therefore caused herself much trouble. Her stepdaughter, however, recognized the underly-ing meaning of the precepts (often with the help of her father) & therefore everything goes well for her.
929
915AThe Misunderstood PreceptsRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsA dying father (mother) gives indirectly expressed advice to his son (daughter) (before marriage): “Always eat bread with honey” (means: “Work diligently & your bread will be as sweet as honey”), “God bless you in your labors” (means: “Start your work earlier than others, so that others will greet you thus & not you them”) & “Always wear your shoes” (means: “Walk the fields barefooted, wear your shoes only when near the town”). When the son follows these pre-cepts literally, he becomes poor. Only later does he learn their real meaning. Or, the father gives ironic precepts: “Whenever you feel like gam bling, do it until your eyes are red & your cheeks are pale”, “Whenever you feel like drinking, do it until you are drunk & fall asleep”, & “Whenever you desire a woman, go there early in the morning & wake her up”. Following the precepts he gambles away all his money. Drinking to forget his losses, he feels so ill the next morning that he wants never to drink again. He visits a woman early in the morning & is so scared by her appearence that he runs home. There he thinks about his father’s “bad” precepts that cured him of gambling, drink-ing & womanizing.
930
916-The Brothers Guarding the King's Bedchamber & the SnakeRealistic Tales (850-999)910-919 Good PreceptsSeveral brothers are hired by a king to guard his bedchamber. The first brother sees a snake in the bedchamber & kills it, but a drop of its poison falls on the queen. While he is wiping the poison, she awakes & accuses him trying to attack her. The other brothers tell stories against making a hasty decision. The next morning the truth comes to light. The stories: (1) The innocent dog. (2) The faithful dog as security for a debt. (3) The falcon & the poisoned water. (4) The parrot & the fruit of youth. A parrot brings to a king, his master, some fruit of youth. Unbeknown to the parrot a snake has dropped poison on the fruit. The king gives one of the fruits to a dog which dies, & then slays the parrot. Later the truth comes to light.
931
920-The Son of the King & the Son of the SmithRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsBecause her young (unborn) son calls his mother a whore, the queen com mands that the child (the young Solomon) be killed. The child asks the servant for mercy; he is not killed but raised by a smith. In order that her husband should not discover this deceit, the queen takes the smith’s son as her own. During their childhood, the two boys play along with others. In their game, Solomon stands out because, playing the part of the king he convicts one of the boys as a traitor. Or, the smith’s son speaks of farming matters, but Solomon speaks of military affairs. His father the king (in person or through a messenger) tests the boy’s wisdom with impossible tasks or difficult questions. Or, the boy (often acting as a shepherd) makes wise judgments or observations that reveal his royal origin. His intelligent answers show him to be the son of the king. In some variants an additional episode may follow, but more often this is a separate tale: Solomon’s wife elopes with a rival king. Solo-mon goes to retrieve her. He is captured but is permitted to blow his horn three times before his death. This was a prearranged signal, & his army comes & rescues him.
932
920AThe Case of Boiled EggsRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA princess as baby is secretly exchanged by her mother with the son of a farmwife, because the king has threatened to kill her if she does not give birth to a boy. Later the king has to judge a case: A merchant who bought forty eggs before a journey, intends to pay for them after his return. But he is asked to pay for the value of all the chickens & their offspring that would have hatched from the eggs. The king does not know how to judge the case, & by chance overhears the exchanged children playing a game, the case of the boiled eggs. The princess plays the role of the king & points out that chickens could never hatch from boiled eggs. The king adopts the girl’s decision. Finally the children’s identity is discovered & they are reexchanged.
933
920A*The Inquisitive KingRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsSolomon states that all women could be se-duced (are more stupid than men), even his mother. He proves his state ment by sending a servant to seduce her. In order to test her chastity Solomon disguises himself & goes in place of the servant to the meeting point. When his moth er is about to commit incest with her own son, she realizes the deception & curses him: He cannot die until he has measured the height of the sky & the depth of the sea (before having gone around the earth & to the bottom of the sea). Thereupon Solomon vainly attempts to measure the height of the sky & the depth of the sea. On the back of a bird he flies to the sun, but the bird’s wings are burned & he falls down (eagles take him up to the sky & let him fall down, the curse becomes true.) He sits inside a box fixed to a chain, & tells a woman to low er it down to the bottom of the sea. Unfortunately a crayfish cuts the chain. In some variants his measuring is successful. On an old woman’s back he rides to the stars, & devils save him from the submerged box.
934
920BBirds Chosen by the Sons of the KingRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA king asks his three sons what kind of bird they would prefer to be. The first chooses an eagle, because it is ruler of birds. The sec-ond chooses a falcon, because it is beloved of the nobles. The third says that he would like to be a bird that flies with many others, so as to receive advice. The king chooses the third son as the next king, because as a ruler he would always seek advice.
935
920B*The Lineage of the King's Three SonsRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA captive king interrogates the three sons of the king who has captured him as to how they will treat him (he gives them riddles). From their answers he learns their real descent. One of the sons is from a family of executioners (bakers), the other one from butchers, while only the third son is from the royal family.
936
920CShooting at the Father's Corpse as a Test of PaternityRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsIn order to deter mine the true heir (his own son) among his three sons, a dying king (rich man) requires that each should shoot at his corpse. The youngest refuses to shoot (at his heart) & is therefore judged the only genuine son of his dead father; the two others are deter-mined to be illegitimate & are disinherited.
937
920C*The Choice of a WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA young man asks Solomon (another king) for advice about what sort of girl he should marry: one with property, one with money, or a poor one with nothing. Solomon answers, “Go away; you don’t know anything; do whatever you like”. (“Be quiet, I am in charge; get up, so I can sit down; do whatever you like.”). The answers mean accordingly, that the first girl would chase him away because the property belongs to her; the second would tell him that the money is hers & he is ignorant; but the third one will not meddle with anything, even if she is bad tempered.
938
920DThe Four PrincesRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsOf the king’s four sons, the one who can name the greatest number of faults of their father, is to become the next king. The youngest son cannot name a single fault. He becomes king.
939
920EThe Three RingsRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA dying father gives each of his three (more) sons (children) a ring (stone). Only one of the rings is genuine, & each son thinks it is his. The questions of which is the genuine ring & which is the true son are decided on religious (Christian, Jewish, Muslim, or sectarian) ground.
940
921-The King & the Farmer's SonRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA boy (farmer’s son, Solomon) as-ton ishes a king passing by his hut by giving clever answers. The an swers refer to questions like: what do you (does your father, mother , brother, sister) do?. And/or they deal with a para doxical demand to come to the king under certain conditions. The following questions & answers are most frequent: (1) What are you doing? I boil those coming & going (I boil peas, beans, and/or lentils that keep rising & falling in the water). (2) What is your father doing? He makes a bad thing worse (he blocks a path in a field which causes another to be trodden). Or, he is in the vineyard doing good & bad (he prunes vines but sometimes cuts good ones & leaves the bad). Or, he makes many out of few (he sows grain). (3) What is your mother doing? She does for another what the latter cannot do for herself (she lays out a corpse). Or, she is baking forgotten bread (to pay back borrowed bread). (4) What is your brother doing? He hunts; he throws away what he catches, & what he does not catch he carries home (he hunts for lice on his body). (5) What is your sister doing? She is mourning last year’s laugh ter (she nurses her child, the fruit of last year’s love affair
941
921ASharing of Bread or MoneyRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA farmer (craftsman) responds to the king’s question, why he is working so hard or how he would use his salary (four coins, bread), by giving enigmatic answers: The first I eat (feed myself), the second I put out at interest (give to my children so that they can care for me when I am old), with the third I pay debts (keep my parents) & the fourth I throw away (give to my wife). The king asks his ministers to interpret the farmer’s answers for him. When they ask the farmer, he demands a reward for each response. In a medieval version, a smith named Focus, who worked on a feast day despite the emperor’s prohibition, is betrayed by a statue constructed by the magician Virgil. He defends himself by stating that he needs to earn eight coins daily. Two of the coins he has to re pay (to his father), two he has to lend (to his son), two are lost (to be given to his wife) & two are to be spent (for himself).
942
921A*The Frank ThiefRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA king asks prisoners why they have been impris-on ed. All say they are innocent except one, who confesses he is a thief (counterfeiter, etc.). He is released so that he will not spoil the others.
943
921BBest Friend, Worst EnemyRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThe central motif of the tale is the follow-ing task: A man should bring his best friend & his worst enemy. He fulfills the task by choosing his dog as friend & his wife as enemy. The tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) When the master orders his servant (Aesop) to bring food to the person who loves him most, the servant serves his dog instead of his wife. The wife feels offended & threatens to leave her husband. The servant explains that only the dog would really love his mas ter for it would return even if it had been beaten. (2) A young man violates the order that all old people should be killed. He hides his father with the help of his wife. Because of the intrigues of some envious men, the king demands that the young man, on pain of death, bring his servant, his friend (jester) & his enemy to the king. Following his father’s advice he takes his donkey as servant, his dog as friend (his child as jester) & his wife as en-emy. The offended wife reproaches her husband for classifying her in this way after she had helped him hide his father. This betrayal turns her into his enemy & so he accomplishes the task. (3) A young man rescues the devil (stranger, saint, ghost, robber) from a wolf (other danger) whereupon the devil promises pay for the service if the young man will bring his most faithful friend to the meeting. The man comes with his wife. The devil appears in a rich disguise & persuades the wife to kill her husband when he is asleep. Later he promises her marriage & wealth. The woman agrees. When she raises the knife (ax, stone) for the murder, the devil awakens her husband. He says that he has now repaid the man by saving his life, & refuses to pay the recompense. The man should have brought his dog instead of his wife. (The man must bring his real friend the next day. His dog follows him without being called, attacks the stranger, & proves its faithfulness.)
944
921B*Beggar, Thief, MurdererRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA nobleman (emperor, clergyman) observes an old farmer laboriously plowing his field. Asked if he has no sons who can help him, the old man answers that he has three university-trained sons, one is a thief (robber, liar, oppressor), another a mur-derer (oppressor, Gypsy), & the third a beggar (deceiver, rascal). The nobleman begins to understand when the farmer explains in detail that his first son is a judge, the second a doctor (butcher) & the third a clergyman (monk, teacher).
945
921CWhy Hair of head is Gray before the BeardRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA man (clergyman, barber) answers the question why the hair of his head is grey (white) & the hair of his beard is black, “The hair of the head is twenty years older than the beard”.
946
921C*Astronomer & Doctor at Farmer's HouseRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA farmer predicts the weather according to his animals’ behavior (when the flies take shelter under the horse’s tail, rain will come) better then the astronomer (philosopher), who is his guest. Moreover the farmer knows more then the doctor, who is also his guest, about the choice of wholesome food & the spread of disease.
947
921DThe Fatal BedRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA citizen asks a sailor why he repeatedly goes to sea even though his father & grandfather drowned there. The sailor asks how the citizen’s ancestors died. The townsman answers, “In bed”, whereupon the sailor asks if the citizen isn’t afraid of going to bed?
948
921D*Witty AnswersRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a man who makes another man angry by giving absurd answers. A master (nobleman, lawyer) asks a farmer (foreman) returning from the market, if the market was large. The farmer answers, “I did not measure it!” The master says, “No, I wanted to know if it was crowd ed?” The farmer says, “I did not count the people!”Thereupon the master becomes angry & plans to invite the farmer for dinner & then to set his dogs on him. On the way to din-ner the farmer finds two hares. When the master lets his dogs loose the farmer releases his hares so that the dogs chase them. The master orders his servant to serve the farmer wine in the cellar & then to beat him. When the farmer takes away the plug from the cask, the servant has to hold the hole closed & the farmer beats him. Later the farmer hides a piece of bacon under his shirt & bends over as he climbs the stairs. When people ask him if he has enough, he answers, “Now I have enough for my children & for myself to lick for six weeks!” When the farmer is brought to court for beat-ing the servant, he pretends to be an idiot & therefore cannot be tried.
949
921ENever Heard BeforeRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA man is required to say something that neither the king nor his courtiers has ever heard before. The man reads a letter supposedly from another king demanding repayment of money that this king had borrowed.
950
921E*The PotterRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA potter amazes the king with his clever answers. The king orders his nobles to buy pots from the potter. The potter raises the price. One noble does not want to pay & agrees, instead of payment, to carry the potter into the palace on his shoulders. Or, the king sets a riddle to his nobles: What is the worst evil in the world? They do not know an answer. Only the potter knows it. He demonstrates the solution by placing himself onto his cart with pots & tells a nobleman (who asked him for the solution) to pull it to the palace. The king appoints the potter nobleman.
951
921FPhilosopher Spits in the King's BeardRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA philosopher is invited to dine with the king. During the meal he is obliged to spit & does so in the king’s beard. The servants become indignant & want to beat him, but the king insists on asking the philosopher why he did such a thing. The philosopher answers that everything else around him was silk or gold, so the king’s beard was the most suitable place for spitting. The king accepts this explanation.
952
921F*Plucking GeeseRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA farmer (craftsman) impresses a ruler by his clever questions & answers, which his courtiers were not able to give. The ruler promises to send the farmer geese (other birds, animals) for him to pluck (cut, milk, skin). The “geese” are courtiers who, under threat of dismissal (death), have to solve riddles that the farmer poses. (The ruler says, “The geese from Russia are flying here [the nobles]; pluck them!”) Making use of the ruler’s advice, the farmer takes much money from them (for explaining the answer to the riddle).
953
922-The Shepherd Substituting for the Clergyman Answers the Kings QuestionsRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA person of high social status (emperor, king, civil servant, teacher) demands that a clergyman (bishop, abbot, priest, petitioner) answers three difficult questions within a certain period of time on pain of death. The clergyman cannot answer the questions & therefore sends a (disguised) representative (servant, shepherd, miller, brother ). This man answers all the questions correctly for him. When the deception comes to light, the questioner forgives the ruse & re wards the person who answered (often spares the life of the superior or the brother). Many of the questions require measuring (counting) something that cannot be measured (counted). By means of wordplay (How much does the moon weigh? A pound, since it has four quarters), by setting an impossible condition at the end of a non-provable statement (How many leaves are on the tree? So & so many, & if you do not believe, count them, or as many as there are stems), or of a non-provable comparison (How many stars are in heaven? As many as grains of sand are on the beach, & if you are able to count them, you know how many stars are in heaven), etc., the person answering turns the questioning ad absurdum. The questions include, “How many drops of water are in the sea?”; “How high is heaven?”; “How many hairs are on my head?”; “How many seconds are there in eter-nity?”; “How far is one end of the world from the other?”; “Where is the center of the earth?”; “How much is the king worth?”; “What is the sweetest song?”; “Which is the best fowl?”; “What is the swiftest, the sweetest & the most costly?”; “How much is a golden plow worth?”; “What does God do?”; “How far is it from for-tune to misfortune?”; “What am I thinking?”
954
922AAchiqarRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA childless minister adopts his nephew (Achiqar), rears & teaches him. He presents his foster-son to the king, who likes the boy’s clever answers. When the minister becomes old, he recommends the king his foster-son as his successor. The young boy is appointed to the office, but slanders his foster-father. The king orders that the old minister to be killed. Instead, he is saved, & a slave is killed in his place. When a hostile king learns about the minister’s death, he sets the king tasks that cannot be accomplished by anyone. He asks for a person who is able to build a castle in the air & who can answer difficult questions. The king searches desperately for his old minister. When he learns that he is still alive, he just reinstates him in his former position. Under a different name the old minister travels to the hostile king. He lets a child sitting in a basket be carried into the air by an eagle, where the boy exclaims, “Give me stones & lime so that I can start building the palace!” After solving all the riddles set by the king, he returns with a rich reward. He asks his foster-son to be summoned & punishes him with a cruel death.
955
922BThe King's Face on the CoinRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA king meets a farmer (smith) & re-ceives enigmatic answers to his questions. When the farmer later explains the sense of his answers the king forbids him to reveal the solutions unless he has seen him (his face) 100 times. Then he gives a (several) coin to the farmer. When the king reports his strange conversation with the farmer to his advisers, none of them knows an answer. They locate the questioner who, as instructed, refuses to tell them anything. But he gives in when his demand the payment with a certain number of coins with the king’s picture on it is fulfilled. When the king hears the solution from his advisers, he suspects that the farmer has told the secret & reproaches (punishes) him. But the farmer is innocent because he had seen the picture of the ruler 100 times on the coins. He is rewarded by the king (appoints him adviser, marries him to his daughter).
956
923-Love Like SaltRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA king (rich man) asks his three daughters, how much they love him. The two elder ones compare their love with pre cious (sweet) things (gold, precious stones, sugar, honey, precious clothes), but the youngest says that she loves him like salt. The father is offended by his youngest daughter’s answer & casts her out (orders her death), whereas he rewards the elder daughters in proportion to the value of their flatteries. The youngest daughter then works as a maidservant in a foreign country, whose king she later marries. She invites her father to the wedding meal & serves him dishes without any salt. Thus the fath er becomes aware of the indispensability of salt. The daughter discloses her identity.
957
923ALike Wind in the Hot SunRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA wife says that she loves her husband like wind in the hot sun. First he is offended but later in the hot sun he learns the value of the wind on a hot day. He understands the meaning of his wife’s words (and returns to her)
958
923BThe Princess Who was Responsible for her own FortuneRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsWhen a king asks his (three) daughters who is responsible for their good fortune (who has the blessing of the kingdom, wealth & honor), the elder daughters answer that he is the one, but the youngest says that she herself (only God) is responsible (she states that a woman is responsible for her husband’s fortune). Her father becomes angry at her statement & forces her to marry a beggar (cripple) with whom she must live in humble circum stances (she is driven forth). Some variants begin with a description of a prince who became a cripple: A prince observes the struggle of two snakes & helps the weaker one, asking that it not harm him. Nevertheless the snake creeps through his mouth into his body, deforms him, & makes him sick. The prince is cast off by his father & becomes a beggar. Through his wife’s wit (skill) the beggar becomes rich, becomes a king, or is cured of his disease. In other variants the husband magically returns to his former iden tity as prince. The father visits the new king, recognizes his daughter & is forced to admit that she is responsible for her own fortune. Or her father has, in the meantime, lost his kingdom, & wanders impoverished to the palace of his daughter.
959
924-Discussion in Sign LanguageRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsTwo men (king & shepherd, priest & Jew, Roman & Greek, soldier & artist) have a conversation (dispute) in sign language. Interpreting signs falsely they misunderstand each other; e.g.: The king holds up one finger meaning, “I alone am powerful”.
