The shepherd thinks the king is asking for one sheep & holds up two fingers, meaning he will give two sheep to the king. The king interprets the two fingers as meaning, “God is as powerful as you”.
960
925-Tidings for the KingRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThe king states that anyone who tells him his horse is dead must die. A servant tells the king about flies creeping into the mouth of his horse & creeping out where the tail is. When the king exclaims that his horse must be dead then, the servant tells him, “You said it, not I”.
961
925*The Most Beautiful in the GardenRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA poor woman sends her three sons out into the world. They arrive (one by one) at the garden of the royal palace where they meet the princess. She asks each of them, what the most beautiful thing in the garden is (what he likes most). The youngest replies, “Yourself”. Thereupon the princess marries him.
962
926-Judgment of SolomonRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsTwo women both claim a child. The judge Solomon offers to cut it in half. One of the women refuses (lets go when the child is to be torn asunder, tries to stop the judge from cut-ting it) & is therefore determined to be the real mother.
963
926AThe Clever Judge & the Demon in the PotRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsIn order to possess a beautiful woman, a demon (magician) takes on the appearance of her husband & claims her as his wife. The husband & the demon argue about which is the real husband. Numerous persons are asked for advice, but nobody can distinguish between the two men. Finally a judge (clever boy [who plays at being a king or a judge], shepherd, hare, jackal, parrot) states that whichever can creep into a pot (tube) is the real husband. The husband is not able to enter, but the demon creeps inside immediately. The pot is covered, & the demon is recognized & trapped. The real husband gets his wife back.
964
926A*"Purchase Not Him Who Surpasses You."Realistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA father (widow) sends his son (three sons) away to learn a craft (earn money). But the boy learns to play an instrument & cards instead. When he is to be sold as slave to a merchant (when he seeks employment with a rich man) he says, “Do not buy someone who is superior to you”, or “Whoever takes me will regret it; whoever does not take me will regret it twice as much”. By his clever actions, by playing off persons against each other, by his music, & by gambling he succeeds in different situations. At the end he marries the daughter of the rich man (dealer, captain). When his father-in-law violates a king’s decree (ships are no longer allowed to shoot cannons) & is condemned to death, the youth frees him from the gallows (with three empty nutshells, which signify his father-in-law’s worth). At the end, the young man attains wealth & honor.
965
926CCases Solved in a Manner Worthy of SolomonRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with the idea of unusual, of-ten clever, methods to determine the truth. Examples: (1) A poor man finds a purse with money in it & returns it to its owner hoping for a reward. The owner pretends that some money is missing, & that the finder took it already for his reward. The judge decides that, since the amount of money is different, the purse did not belong to the man who claimed it, & that the poor man may keep it until its rightful owner is found. (2) A judge gives sticks to all the suspects in a court case & tells them that the guilty one’s stick will grow during the night. The guilty man cuts a bit off his stick & thus is discovered. (3) Someone announces to all the people in the village that the thief has a gnat on his cap (that his cap is burning). One man reaches for his cap & thus shows himself to be the thief. (4) All the suspects are required to touch some object in the dark, & are told that the hand of the guilty one will be blackened. In fact, the object blackens any hand that touches it. The guilty man does not touch the object & is thus the only one whose hand is not blackened. (5) In order to determine which of two women is the owner of a spindle of thread, the judge asks them what the spindle is made of. Only the owner knows the right answer. (6) Disputants are ordered to fabricate a copy of the disputed ob ject (precious stone). The owner & the cheater can do so, but the false claimants cannot. (7) A man (innkeeper) whose silver has been stolen summons his guests (employees) to the table & orders them to make various ridiculous gestures. When they are all engaged in this game, he com mands them to put their heads under the table. Then he asks if the thief has head under the table. The thief answers, “Yes”.
966
926C*The Betrothed ChildrenRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThe children of two merchants have been betrothed from childhood, but they live in different cities. The boy is given allegorical orders (if the duck has fallen into the chaff, carry her, etc.) & sent off by his father. The bride recognizes her bridegroom by these allegorical expressions.
967
926DThe Judge Appropriates the Object of DisputeRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a dispute between two parties that is decided in favor to a third person who is to judge their case. The judge either takes the contested object as evidence or destroys it. For example, two cats fight over a rice cake, & the monkey who is to decide the case eats it. A lawyer who is to decide the case of two men charges them such high fees that he is able to buy the disputed object (calf) with his earnings. The song of a bird was not meant for the plaintif but for the judge.
968
926EEginhard & EmmaRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsAfter spending the night with the emperor’s daughter in her chamber, her lover cannot leave without being Discovered because snow has fallen. She carries him on her back to his apartment because her own footprints are less suspect. The emperor observes this & brings the case before his advisers. To end the ensuing arguments, he permits the lovers to marry.
969
927-Out-riddling the JudgeRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA man (woman) condemned to death is set free when the judge cannot solve the riddle propounded to him by the condemned person (by a relative of the condemned). The riddle refers to extraordinary or accidental events that happened to the person setting the riddle, & thus is unsolvable for outsiders. There are four main riddles: (1) Samson riddle of the living in the dead, “From the eater came forth meat & from the strong sweetness” – Swarm of bees collects honey in a lion’s carcass. (“What has seven tongues in one head?” – Bird’s nest with seven young found in a horse’s head; “Drink this wine which a bird took to its nest” – A stork took a bunch of grapes to nest, & a boy makes wine from them.) (2) Riddle of the nursing daughter, “Formerly I was daughter, now I am mother; I have a son who was the husband of my mother” – Woman has nursed her imprisoned father (woman nurses her son, wife nurses another man) through a crack in the prison wall. (3) Ilo-riddle (propounded by a woman), “Love I sit, Love I stand; Love I hold, fast in hand; I see Love, Love sees not me. Riddle me that, or hanged I’ll be” – A woman has killed her dog named Love (Ilo); from its skin shoes, gloves & a chair-covering have been made; (“With what thinks, I drink; what sees, I carry; with what eats I walk” – A woman has killed her lover, from his skull a cup has been made, from one of his eyes a ring & she carries two of his teeth in her boots). (4) Riddle of the unborn, “I am unborn; I ride the unborn (I eat the unborn)” – A boy was born by Caesarean section; he has a horse that was also born unnaturally (he eats the meat of an animal that was taken out of its dead mother’s body).
970
927AAn Execution Evaded by Using Three WishesRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsKing ordains that the guest who turns the fish on his plate (drops his knife, talks loudly) shall be executed, & also that anyone so condemned may have three wishes granted. A (young) man violates the order & pronounce his three wishes. One of the wishes is, all those who saw him turn the fish are to be blinded. All persons present pretend not to have seen anything & the accused man is freed.
971
927A*"Old Saddle" Granted by the KingRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA farmer does a king a good turn (a soldier claims pay for a long period of service). In return he asks for an old saddle. The unsuspecting king signs the deed of gift. Later the “old saddle” turns out to be a large estate. Nevertheless the duped king keeps his promise & gives it to him.
972
927BCondmened Man Chooses How He Will DieRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a man condemned to death who is permitted to choose how he will die. Examples: (1) The condemed says he wants to die from old age. (2) The condemned (Seneca) chooses to open his veins & bleed to death.
973
927CThe Last RequestRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA convicted man is permitted a last request be-fore he dies. He asks for strawberries although it is winter (a meal of nightingales or canaries, to learn Hebrew before he dies). Or, a barber asks to shave the judge. He puts the razor to the judge’s throat & commands him to alter the death sentence.
974
927C*The Ground is Measured with a Horse's Skin/ Ox HideRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA man (monk, members of a different ethnic group) asks his master for a piece of land the size of an ox’s (horse’s) hide. This is promised to him. He cuts the hide into a long thin strip which he uses to encircle a great area.
975
927DMan Allowed to Pick Out Tree to be Hanged OnRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA man who has been condemned to death is allowed to choose the tree on which he will be hanged. He looks for a long time but cannot find one he likes. Or, he chooses one that is only knee-high (a bush, sunflower, etc.) The judge (hangman) lets him go free.
976
928-Planting for the Next Generation.Realistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA man plants a tree even though he is told that it will never bear fruit in his lifetime. Nevertheless he plants the tree: for the next generation.
977
929-Clever DefencesRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with the clever defense of an accused person who is finally (unexpectedly) rescued.
978
929*A Penny for AlmsRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA beggar claims to be the brother of the king because all people descend from Adam (God). The king gives him one penny, saying that if all his brothers gave that much, he would be richer than the king himself.
979
929AUneducated FatherRealistic Tales (850-999)920-929 Clever Acts & WordsA son defends his father’s behavior, saying that the man could not do any better. He learned everything from the grandfather.
980
930-The ProphecyRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThis misc. type contains various tales dealing with a poor boy for whom future greatness or a marriage to a rich girl is foretold. A rich man (king, merchant, landlord) learns of the prophecy (he dreams) that a poor boy will become his son-in-law (heir). Therefore he tries to kill the boy by various plots (exposure). Finally the boy has to deliver a letter that orders his own death. The letter is exchanged (modified) by a helper, so that the boy is married to the daughter of his adversary & shares in his rank & wealth.
981
930*Fate Foretold as PunishmentRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA man invites God to his house, but mistreats an old beggar who comes to ask for a night’s lodging. At night he hears the birds talk to the old man & as punishment learns his future.
982
930APredestined WifeRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA respected man learns by a predicition that a very young (newborn) girl will be his future wife. Not willing to marry the ugly child, he tries to kill her by stabbing her, by piercing her forehead with a needle, or by adopt-ing her in order to expose her afterwards. The girl survives, grows up, becomes very beautiful, & is married to the mafter the wedding he discovers the scar (needle) & learns from his wife’s life-history that the prediction has been ful filled despite his actions. In various regions different forms of the tale have originated : Northern cycle (Danish, Swedish, Estonian, Irish & Icelandic variants): A man witnesses the prediction of his future, tries to kill the girl in various ways by exposing her in water, by nailing her by her hands to a tree, or by sending her out with a letter that orders her death. The girls survives, marries the man, & is finally recognized by her scars as the predestined wife. Southern cycle with a wide regional dispersion (Greek, Slovene, English, Scottish, Irish, Estonian, Spanish & Brazilian variants): The marriage of the fated child is combined with the further condition: A ring that had been thrown into the water has to be found again. The ring is finally located in a fish’s belly.
983
931-OedipusRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA prophecy (dream) foretells that a certain newborn child will kill his father & marry his mother. In order to avoid this fate, the child (Oedipus) is exposed. The boy is rescued & reared by shepherds (he grows up at a strange king’s court). There he unwittingly kills his father (who was employed as a gardener) whom he did not recognize. Upon the king’s advice he marries the wife of the dead man & learns later that she is his own mother.
984
931AParricideRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThis misc. Type comprises various tales (with legendary traits) dealing with a person who kills his father (parents). Examples: (1) A father reproaches his son for his dissolute life, & the son kills him. A saint protects the sinner from despair & leads him to repent & do penance for his crime. (2) It is prophesied that a certain child (Judas) will bring great sorrow to humanity. The child is exposed but is adopted & raised by a childless queen. When she gives birth, the adopted child murders her child & flees to Jerusalem. When he steals apples in a garden he is caught there by the owner. He kills the owner & marries his widow, who is (although he does not know this) his own mother. (3) It is prophesied that a certain young man (Julianus Hospitator) will murder his parents. He flees in order to avoid this, & marries. His parents search for him & come to his house, where his wife invites them to rest in their marriage bed. When the son arrives home & sees two people in his bed, he thinks his wife is unfaithful to him & kills both of his parents. When he learns what he has done, he repents & does penance. His sin is forgiven. Or, a young man kills his parents (father only) because a false adviser has lied to him, saying that his wife is an adulteress. (4) After his wife dies, a lord falls in love with his own daughter. She gives birth to a son (Albanus), who is exposed. He is rescued & raised by a childless king. When the boy grows up, he becomes king himself. His natural father hears about this young king & marries his daughter to him. Before the adoptive father dies, he tells the young man what he knows about his origins. The young man’s wife realizes that she has married her own son. After the king dies, the three others go to the bishop & confess their sins. They are required to do penance for seven years. On their way home, they spend the night in a forest, & the father & daughter renew their incestuous relationship. Albanus discovers this & kills them both. He becomes a hermit, is killed, & later becomes a saint. (5) A drunken man spends the last of his money. The devil prom-ises to make him rich if he will murder his own parents, but the man refuses. The devil gives him money anyway, & tells him to restrict his binges of drunkenness to one day each week. The man disobeys, gets drunk every day, & murders his parents.
985
933-Gregory on the StoneRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThe son of an incestuous union is abandoned. His mother adds ivory tablets that describe the circumstances of his birth. The boy is saved, baptized by the abbot Gregorius who gives him his own name, & grows up in the monastery. At the age of 15, the child Gregorius learns about his mys terious origins & leaves in order to find his real parents. Unwittingly Gregorius reaches his native country where his un-married mother rules. When he saves her from a neighboring ruler’s unwelcome advances, she agrees to marry Gregorius. He has no idea that she is his mother. When she finds the tablets with the history of his origins she discloses her identity. In order to expiate the unwitting incest, she lives a pious life. Gregorius undertakes a pilgrimage as penance. At his request a fisher -man fetters his ankles with chains to a rock in the sea & throws the key into the water. Seventeen years later Gregorius is chosen by an angel as successor of the deceased pope. Messengers from Rome look for Gregorius & arrive at the fisherman’s hut. In a fish prepared for the guests, the key for his chains is found. Gregorius is elected pope, & when he enters Rome healing miracles take place. His mother makes a pilgrimage to Rome in order to confess her sins to the pope. They recognize each other. She enters a convent. After their death both gain spiritual salva tion (Gregorius is worshiped as saint).
986
934-Tales of the Predestined DeathRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThis misc. type com prises various tales dealing with the prediction of a person’s death. Examples: The time & manner of the future death of a newborn child (adult) is forecast by norns (nurse, judge, etc.; in dream). The parents of the child overhear the prophecy (they learn it from another person). Different manners of death are predicted: Death by natural forces (storm, thunderstorm, falling tree), by an animal (wolf, tiger, snake, horse), by drowning, when drinking water, when shearing sheep, by poisoning, on the wedding day, by hanging. The three-fold death of a person caused by e.g. starving, burning & drowning is prophecied. Various precautions are taken in order to evade fate (the person is immured in a wall, isolated, hidden in a tower). Nevertheless the prophecy is fulfilled. In some variants the predestined fate is averted (by a helper, step mother, eagle)
987
934CDeath Forestalls Evil FatesRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA mother mourns for her dead children. When she goes to church she realizes that the mass is being performed by dead relatives. Then she is shown at the altar what the evil fates of her children would have been (one son is on gallows, the other one is bound to a wheel) if they had not died. She thanks God for having taken her children.
988
934DNothing Happens without GodRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateAn only son goes into military service & wants to take vengeance on the officers who recruited him. An old man (God) shows in spirit a newborn child with a gun & uniform. Now the youth understands that God has determined everyone’s fate.
989
934D1Outwitting FateRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA man overhears the fate predestined by a god (goddess, soothsayer) decreeing that a boy (prince) will spend his life in poverty but will always own an ox (kill a stag every day) & that his sister will become a prostitute. When the boy grows up, the man advises him to sell his ox every day so that the god must furnish him a new one each day (to wait inside his hut so that the god must bring the stag to him). He advises the girl to demand a handful of pearls for her favors. The god must come in disguise each day because no man can pay such a price. The god soon tires of his duties & agrees to reverse the decrees of fate.
990
934FThe Man in the WellRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA man fleeing from a unicorn falls into a well where a dragon lives. A tree grows beside the well, and, as he falls, the man grasps one of its branches. He finds two mice, one black & one white, gnawing at the branch, & sees snakes at the base of the tree. Observing all this, the man forgets his perilous position. When a drop of honey falls from the crown of the tree, he reaches to taste it (reaches for money that lies near him). The branch breaks & the man falls into the jaws of the dragon.
991
934GThe False ProphecyRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateAn astrologer prophesies that a certain ruler will die within a year, but that he himself will live another twenty years. A knight kills the astrologer, thus discrediting his prophecies.
992
934HThe Origin of DeathRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThis misc. type consists of various tales dealing with the origin of death and/or the time of death. Examples: (1) Formerly God let human beings die & return to life, but the moon died forever. A goat (hare) was sent by men to tell God that they wished to continue to live in this way. But the goat con founded the messages, & the dog arrived too late to change it. Since that time, humans die forever. (2) God sends out a chameleon to tell humans that they should live forever (continue to live after death). On the way the chameleon is overtaken by a faster animal that delivers the opposite message. (3) Formerly Death walked along singing, but he did not enter the houses of men. An old woman listened to him, liked his song, & repeated it. Thereupon Death followed the woman to her house & bedroom, & when she lay down (to have sexual inter-course) he strangled her. This is how Death first entered the houses of men. (4) In the year before they were to die, people neglected their responsibilities (they repaired their fences with temporary materials). Therefore, God decided that they should not know in advance when they will die.
993
934K"The Time Has Come but Not the Man."Realistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA water spirit shouts three times from a river, “The hour has passed & the man did not come”. The call is heard far outside the town. A young person runs to the river & drowns.
994
935-The Prodigal's ReturnRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA lazy (stupid) son leaves home & dissipates his fortune abroad. He becomes a soldier & asks his father for money by sending him a (three) letter pretending to have become a lieutenant (captain). The deception is discovered & the father expels his son. Through a trick (cleverness, magic) the young man makes his fortune & becomes king by marrying a princess. Rich & mighty, he decides to return home. On the way he is held up by robbers (he gambles away all his belongings). His com-panions are all killed, & he himself escapes, but he has to aban-don his royal clothes. When he reaches his parents’ home in humble clothing, his father accuses him of lying & punishes & humiliates him (by forcing him to tend pigs, goats, sheep, geese). His wife (disguised as hermit, priest, bishop) follows him, (overwhelms the robbers) & rescues him from the difficult situation. He then puts on his royal clothes, returns home, & proves his royal identity to his parents.
995
935*The Stepson MarinerRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA merchant’s stepson is sent to sea & makes his fortune. The merchant’s own son, living protected at home, has bad luck.
996
936*The Golden MountainRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of Fate(Hasan of Basra.) A man hires himself out to a merchant (landlord) who promises high payment for unspecified labor. The merchant leads him to a high (golden) mountain that cannot be climbed. He (drugs him and) sews him up in an animal skin. Big birds carry him to the mountaintop as prey. There he slips out of the skin & throws precious stones (gold) down to the merchant. Later the merchant leaves him, helpless, behind on the mountain. Through lucky circumstances (passage under the earth, plunge into the sea) he escapes. Later he takes service with the same em-ployer. When they arrive at the mountain again, the merchant is tricked into the animal skin & is carried up the mountain. After disclosing his identity to the merchant, the workman makes him throw precious stones down in the same way he had done before. Then he leaves the merchant on the mountain where he dies.
997
938-PlacidasRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FatePlacidas, a colonel of the emperor Trajan, hunts a deer, between whose antlers a cross disclosed it to be Christ in animal form. His wife has a similar vision. Both are baptized together with their two sons. Placidas is named Eustacius, his wife Theopiste . When Eustacius rides again to the place of the vision, the deer reappears. Christ prophesies for him a period of suffering similar to that of Job. He can choose if he wishes to have the suffering now or at the end of his life. Eustacius decides to have it soon. When his servants & his animals die & all his property is stolen, he escapes with his family to Egypt. A boatman claims his wife as payment for the ferry; when Eustacius crosses a river with his two sons, the boys are carried off by a lion & a wolf. Farmers & shepherds take the animals’ prey & raise the boys. Eustacius works as farmhand. Many years later Eustacius is found by a legation of the emperor. They persuade him to return. When serving as colonel, he recovers his sons & his wife by chance. The new emperor in Rome wants them to make sacrifices to idols. When they identify them-selves as Christians, the new emperor Hadrian orders them to be thrown to the lions, but the wild animals do not touch them. Then they are pushed into a red-hot iron bull. Their uninjured bodies are buried by Christians; on the grave a church is built.
998
938*
Master Discovers That the Slave Girl He Wants to Marry is a Near Relative
Realistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA man (prince, farmer’s son, master) intends to marry a beautiful girl (slave, servant) (after having redeemed her). She turns out to be his sister.
999
938AMisfortunes in YouthRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA girl has to choose if she prefers to suffer in youth or in old age. She decides to suffer in youth & has to endure a long series of misfortunes. Finally she has good fortune.
1000
938BBetter in YouthRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA married couple has to choose if they prefer to suffer in youth or in old age. They decide to endure hardship in youth. The husband sells his wife (voluntarily, by force). The money is carried off by a bird. As a workman in a foreign land, he Discovers the lost money in a felled tree in which the bird had built its nest. He is brought before the widowed queen, who recognizes him as her first husband. In some Jewish variants a couple can choose if they want seven good years now or in the future. The woman decides to have it now in order to educate her children. They receive money, most of which they give away as charity. At the end they are told that their good deeds have compensated for the bad years ahead.
1001
939-The Offended DietyRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA king offends a deity. He loses his kingdom & his fortune & is forced to wander for years in poverty. His wife is stolen from him. He must labor at menial tasks. Taken in & helped by a friend, he sees a valuable necklace disappear before his eyes. Knowing he will be suspected of the theft, he flees. He is bought as a slave & is ordered to throw corpses into a tank for a fee. His wife brings the corpse of their son. The king is eventually restored to his former position. His wife (and child) are restored to him.
1002
939AKilling the Returned SoldierRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThe son of an innkeeper couple gains riches abroad & returns home. He shows his wealth but does not disclose his identity. During the night he is killed by his parents out of greed. The deed is discovered by a third person (usually by his sister) or by an identifying possession. The parents commit suicide.
1003
940-The Three Suitors in the CemetaryRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateAs proof of his love & his courage, a suitor is told to lie in a shroud in a coffin at the cemetery at night. Another must disguise himself as angel & perform a wake, & a third, disguised as the devil, has to carry away the coffin. When the angel & the devil start to fight, the pretended dead man jumps up. All three flee & thereby lose their chances of the promised sexual intercourse (marriage). In some variants an episode follows in which the men take revenge for the trick. In Swedish, Finnish, Flemish, German, & Swiss variants the re jected suitors disguise a beggar as prince & send him with coach & servant to the young woman to woo & marry her.
1004
940*The Forgiven DebtRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA farmer finds a sum of money which belongs to several gentlemen. With it he pays off the debt on his land. After ten years he confesses his guilt & wants to repay their money. They let him keep it all.
1005
944-King for a YearRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateIn a certain city it is the custom that a stranger who is not familiar with its laws is made king. At the end of his reign, all his possessions are taken from him & he is banished to an island. A wise man (who has been warned about this custom) arranges to send everything that he will need to the island (has a city built there), before his banishment. In some variants a dying ruler gives his son a golden ball (apple), telling him to give it to the greatest fool whom he can find. The son decides to give it to a king who is willing to be banished after reign-ing for a year. Sometimes the gift reminds the king to arrange for money, possessions, & food to be taken to the place where he will be banished.
1006
944*"Easy Come, Easy Go!"Realistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA musician & his little house are carried off by an inundation of the sea. He fiddles the whole time. Or, the owner of an easily-acquired possession that is borne away by water is not sorry but rather says, “As it came easily, so it now has gone easily”.
1007
945-Luck & Intelligence.Realistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateThis conglomerate tale type occurs in different forms. The Silent Princess frame with inset dilemma tales is common without the outer Luck & Intelligence frame. The various dilemma tales also occur without any frame. The outer frame is a dispute between Intelligence & Luck, as to which is the more powerful. As a test a shepherd (gardener, farmer) is endowed with intelligence. He participates in a suitor-test for a mute princess, who is offered in marriage to whoever can make her speak The clever shepherd tells to the princess that end with a question (e.g. a carpenter, a taylor & a clergyman pass the night together. The carpenter carves a girl, the tailor dresses her, & the clergyman animates the figure. To whom does the girl belong?) When the princess continues to be silent, he starts to talk to objects or animals who answer wrongly (he himself) in order to tempt the princess to contradict them. Finally she breaks her silence. But the king refuses to give the shepherd his daughter & con-demns him to death. He is saved by Luck, which means that Luck is more powerful than Intelligence.
1008
945A*Money & FortuneRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateMoney & Fortune (Luck & Blessing) test their power on a poor man. The one who can make him richest will be the winner. Money gives the man money. Soon (three times) he loses all the money (when he is stung by wasps or because he hides it in a pot where his wife finds it & spends it). With Fortune’s help he finds the money again. From then on the man believes in Fortune & becomes wealthy. Fortune has won the bet because where there is no good fortune, money is worth nothing. In some variants the frame tale is missing. A poor man (rope-maker, beggar) is given a sum of money three times. Two times he loses the money because of unfortunate circumstances (a bird carries it away; his wife unwittingly sells the pot where it is hidden, he ac cidentally drops it in the river; he forgets the hiding place). The third time he recovers everything because of lucky circumstances, or he finds his fortune in an object which to all appearances seemed worth less (he receives a fish in whose belly a diamond is hidden).
1009
947-The Man Followed by Bad LuckRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA man who is attacked by wolves jumps into a river to save himself. He nearly drowns but is rescued by fishermen who lay him down beside a wall. When he regains consciousness, now apparently safe, the wall falls down & kills him.
1010
947ABad Luck Cannot be ArrestedRealistic Tales (850-999)930-949 Tales of FateA patron (God, rich man) leaves money by the wayside (bridge) where a poor man (hermit) walks. When the poor man reaches that place, he closes his eyes (to feel how a blind man feels when he walks) & so passes by the money without seeing it (he stumbles against the money, thinks it is a stone, & kicks it aside). In Chinese variants he fails to see the gold left in his way by God because he is too lazy to sweep away the dust that covers the gold. In some variants the man is followed by bad luck.
1011
950-RhampsinitusRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersTwo thieves (architect & son, two sons of the architect) rob the king’s treasury where a stone in the wall had intentionally been left loose. The entry-hole is discovered by a ruse. The king sets a trap & captures one of the thieves. At his request, his companion cuts off his head so that his identity can be concealed. The thief’s body is carried through the streets in order to identify his relatives (and consequently him) by their reactions. The thief’s mother is not able to bear her grief & asks her remaining son to bring the corpse home. He manages to steal the corpse by disguising himself & by getting the king’s guards drunk. To identify the thief, the king allows all men to sleep with his daugh ter but orders her to ask each one about his most impious deed. If one tells her about the theft of the treasure, she is to seize him & hold him fast. When the thief visits the princess she marks his forehead, whereupon he marks all the other suitors in the same way (he brings along his dead brother’s arm, which is what the princess seizes). Impressed by the thief’s cleverness, the king announces that he will give his daughter to him. The thief discloses his identity & is honored as the most cunning Egyptian of all.
1012
951AThe King & The RobberRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A ruler, roaming about incognito (during the night), meets some robbers. They boast of their extraordinary abilities & qualities: One can open any door, one understands the language of dogs, & one recognizes any person he has seen once, etc. The king then states that he can save any person from the gallows. Together they rob the royal treasury. When the robbers are captured the next day, the king makes his statement come true. (2) A man (king, bishop, clergyman) is warned that he will die if he does not perform robberies. He does so, & meets a robber (often a man of honor) from whom he learns that he himself would be murdered. They both exchange their identifying marks (caps, clothes) & meet again later. The leader of the conspirators is then forced to poison himself. His accomplices are punished & the robber is rewarded. (3) A robber (soldier) can open any door with a certain magic object, but he only steals the profit that merchants have earned unjustly. The king wonders about the robber’s wealth, dis guises himself, & joins him. While robbing the royal treasury the robber prevents the king from stealing (criticizes his greed). The next day the king discloses his identity & rewards the robber for his honesty.
1013
952-The King & the SoldierRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA retired soldier (executioner, merchant) meets a hunter (butcher, tailor) on his way (in the forest). Together they pass the night in a house of robbers but their hostess warns them of the danger. At night the robbers return home & take their meal. Enticed by the smell of food, the two companions leave their hiding place & join the robbers. The soldier makes the robbers drunk & paralyses them by magic (a spell). He renders them harmless by his courage & by a ruse or he pours hot wine (oil, water) into their eyes (both guests are discovered by the robbers in their hiding-place; in a fight the courageous soldier kills all the robbers) The other companion behaves more passively & anxiously. Back in town the stranger discloses his identity as king to the soldier. The sol dier is richly rewarded for his efforts that saved the ruler’s life.
1014
952*A Sausage & a RevolverRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersWhen attacked, a man (woman) scares robbers by aiming a sausage at them as if it were a revolver. Later he boasts of the event at an inn. The robbers hear this & plan to attack the man again. The innkeeper secretly lends the man a gun. When the robbers begin their second attack, the man shoots them.
1015
953-The Robber & His SonsRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersAn old robber has to tell three of his most dangerous adventures to the queen (king) in order to free his three captured sons. The first is the legend of Odysseus & Polyphemus, in which he represents himself as the hero (who overpowers ghost-like cats). The second tells how he saved a child who was to be slaughtered by its mother & cooked & devoured by an ogress. To fool the ogress he had to hang himself on gallows among other corpses & allow the ogress to cut pieces of flesh from his body. The third adventure is a continuation of the second & tells how he himself was nearly devoured by the ogress. In the end he restores the child (and its mother) to its father. Because of his good deed the queen frees his three sons & rewards him. In some variants the rescued child turns out to be the queen’s child.
1016
954-The Forty ThievesRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & Murderers(Ali Baba.) The tale consists of two parts: (1) A poor man (woodcutter) witnesses robbers entering into a mountain by pronouncing magic words like “Open, sesame”. He then tries the formula, enters the mountain, & finds a huge amount of gold which he takes home. (2) His greedy brother, who lends him money scales, discovers his secret when a piece of gold remains in the scale. The brother goes to the mountain, but he is dismembered by the robbers because he forgets the formula for opening the mountain. At the request of his sister-in-law, the woodcutter fetches his brother’s corpse, tells a cobbler to mend it & buries it. The robbers plan to take revenge. With the cobbler’s help they find the house of Ali Baba & mark it with a chalk circle, whereupon his maidservant (daughter) marks all other houses in the same way. The robber chief disguises himself as a merchant & asks the woodcutter for lodging for the night for himself & for his mules laden with jars (casks) of oil. When the maidservant goes to take some oil for her lamp, she realizes that only one jar is filled with oil, & that the robber’s companions are hidden in the others. She heats the oil, pours it into the jars, & kills the robbers. The robber captain escapes & comes back in disguise (as a suitor ). At dinner he asks for a meal without salt (in order not to be obliged to his host). Thereupon the maidservant becomes suspicious, recognizes the robber, & kills him. As her reward the woodcutter marries her to his son (nephew).
1017
955-The Robber BridegroomRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA robber (murderer, ogre) disguised as a rich man woos the daughter of a miller (princess) who agrees to marry him. The bridegroom asks his bride to pay him a visit in his castle in the forest. She sets out before the arranged time, marking the path with peas or ashes (the bridegroom has marked the way). When she reaches a house, animals (bird) warn her that it is a house of murderers & that she should go back (she gives food to watch dogs in order not to be betrayed). She finds corpses in the house. When she hears the robbers coming, she hides. Her bridegroom (the robbers) brings in a young woman, kills her, & cuts her into pieces. Her finger with a golden ring on it falls into her hiding place. The bride runs away at night & finds her way home safely (with the help of the marks on the path) where she reports to her family what she has seen. When the bridegroom comes to marry her, she recounts her adventure to her guests as a dream. As proof she shows the severed ring (finger). The robbers are arrested & condemned or killed. (The house of the robbers is destroyed, their treasure is distributed, & the girl marries another man.)
1018
955B*The Woman among the RobbersRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA woman, traveling with her children, loses her way & is taken in by robbers who feed her human flesh. They cook her baby in a boiler. She escapes, conceals herself along the way, & reports the crime to the authorities.
1019
956-Hot Chamber in the House of RobbersRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA (fat) man (merchant, soldier, sailor, policeman) hap pens to enter a house of robbers. (He is confined in a hot chamber where human fat is melted.) Many corpses are hanging there. When the robbers return home the man cuts off their heads one after the other & takes their treasures.
1020
956BThe Clever Maiden Alone at Home Kills the RobbersRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA daughter (servant, three daughters) of a miller (farmer, merchant, innkeeper, ruler) stays alone in the house at night (tower in the sea, treasury of her father). When a crowd of (twelve) robbers enters the house through a window, she cuts their heads off one by one & pulls their bodies inside. The leader of the robbers is wounded but is able to escape. In revenge he comes back disguised as a nobleman, woos the girl, & leads her to his house in the forest. He discloses his iden tity by the scar that he got from the girl’s attack & tells her to expect a cruel death. She escapes (with the help of the robber’s mother, maidservant, boy), & hides herself in a tree (in the cargo of a carriage) where the robbers search in vain. Finally she reaches home safely. The robbers’ house is found & the robbers are punished.
1021
956DHow a Young Woman Saves Herself When She Discovers a Robber under her BedRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersMisc. Type. A robber lies under the bed of a young woman. Pretending not to have noticed him she speaks loudly while combing her hair at the open window, “If I am married & my husband comes home drunk & seizes me by the hair, I shall cry, ‘Help!’” People come to help the girl & the robber is captured.
1022
956E*The Young Woman's Revenge on the RobberRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersThe robber rapes & kidnaps a girl. She scalds him with boiling water; then he repents & dies.
1023
958-The Shepherd Youth in the Robbers' PowerRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA shepherd (shepherd girl) is attacked by robbers (soldiers, inhabitants of a neighboring valley). The shepherd manages (by a trick) to play (sing, shout) a melody on his flute (milk funnel, horn). It is heard & understood by the inhabitants of the valley (his lover, sister, brother, parents). The villagers come to help & save the shepherd & his animals.
1024
958A*The Thief Tied to a TreeRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersHaving caught a thief in the act of stealing a horse, a farmer ties him naked to a tree & leaves him at the mercy of gnats & ants. After some time, having lost his way, the farmer finds shelter in the very same man’s house. He is greatly alarmed. But much to his surprise, the man he has wronged, instead of taking vengeance upon him, entertains him generously. He even thanks him for the lesson he received, because it has cured him of the habit of stealing.
1025
958C*Robber in ShroudRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA stranger traveling with a coffin is taken in for the night by a stationmaster, who discovers that a (another) robber is hidden in the coffin. Help (summoned by telephone) arrives at the last minute.
1026
958D*Robber Disguised as a WomanRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA strange woman asks for a night’s lodging at a farm. A farmhand hides under her bed (in order to frighten her) & discovers that the stranger is not a woman but a robber in disguise. He kills him (and his accomplices).
1027
958E*Deep Sleep Brought on by a RobberRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA robber, disguised as a beggar, gets lodging for the night at a farmhouse. Using a candle made of hu man fat (hand of corpse), he tries to charm the household into deep sleep. One of the household who has not gone to sleep sees this & kills the robber. The rest of the family does not wake up until twenty-four hours later.
1028
958F*Test of Sex: Catching an AppleRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA robber disguised as a woman is recognized because, when an apple is thrown into his lap, he brings his legs together. He should have spread them apart to catch the apple in his skirt, as a woman would do.
1029
958K*Robber in the CarRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA driver (woman) gives a ride to a woman (man) whom he meets on the road. During the journey the driver sudden-ly sees that the passenger’s hands are hairy (that the passenger is a robber). The driver stops & pretends something is wrong with the car. He asks the passenger to get out & push. As soon as the pas senger gets out, the driver goes off to tell the police. They find a mur der weapon (stolen goods) in the passenger’s bag.
1030
960-The Sun Brings All to LightRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA man (Jew, cattle dealer, girl) is held up & beaten by another man (tailor, coachman, innkeeper) & later dies. Just before dying he says, “The clear sun (god, moon, wind) will bring everything to light”. The robber looks in vain for money in his pockets, dumps him behind a thicket, & continues his travels. In the next town the murderer marries & later has a family. One morning as he sits with his wife at the window, he pours coffee into his cup & sees how the sunbeams gleam in it & reflect patterns on the wall. He repeats the last words of the dying man. His wife does not understand the meaning of his words & urges him to give an explanation. He finally tells her confiden tially about the murder. His wife promises not to tell anyone. But she does not keep her promise & three days later the whole town knows what happened. The man is condemned.
1031
960ACranes of IbycusRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA traveler becomes a victim of robbery at a remote place. Just before dying he calls on cranes (ravens, wild ducks, doves) passing by to bear witness to the crime. When the cranes pass by again, one of the murderers reveals himself without thinking (the cranes follow the murderer & point him out). In some variants the murderer is exposed by partridges, geese, birds, dogs, thorns, a plant, a tree, the sun, a calf’s head or by a (singing, bleeding) bone.
1032
960BLate RevengeRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA poor man (farmhand, boy) wants to marry a rich widow (mistress, daughter of a rich merchant). The woman favors him but does not like his poverty. In order to please her & to be able to marry her the young man murders a merchant & seizes his property. He presents himself as a rich man to the woman, who wants to know how he became rich in such a short time. When he (out of love) confesses the truth to her, she asks him to watch at the murdered man’s grave for one night (as a condition for their marriage). He does so. In the middle of the night the dead man rises from his grave, & asks God for justice. Thereupon a (God’s) voice comes from heaven saying, “30 (40, 50) years from today you will be avenged”. The young man reports his experience. Know ing that the revenge will take place only after 30 years, the woman agrees to marry him. At the appointed time the couple is invited to dinner in a castle & the prophecy is fulfilled. A minstrel who had left the festivity earlier (because he was forewarned), returns to the castle in order to fetch his forgotten glove (book, another object). He sees that the castle (together with all people) has sunk into the earth & only a well remains.
1033
960CThe Miracle of the Cooked ChickenRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersTwo friends sit at the table to eat, with a chicken on a platter before them. They remark that the chick en cannot get up, not even if St. Peter or Christ commanded it to. The fowl comes to life, flaps its wings, & crows. In some variants someone is accused of having stolen a chicken & wants to defend himself from the accusation. The half-cooked chicken announces (in a song) who the real thief was, & the accused person is set free.
1034
960DToad on the Head of a CorpseRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & Murderers(Murder with a nail.) Encouraged by his mistress, a lover kills her husband (a smith) by putting a nail into his head as he sleeps. The wound is not noticed because it is covered by hair. (People suspect the mourning widow but do not find any proof.)After a long time (20 years) the bones of the dead man must be moved. A toad (frog) is found sitting on his skull, which rolls around. A grave-digger (policeman, sexton) discovers the nail. The wife, who had married in the meantime, is called before a judge (clergyman) & confesses (and is condemned to death).
1035
961-Conqueror of Robber Discovers His Money-StickRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersThinking that he has killed a robber in a struggle, a man takes the robber’s stick (knife) & continues on his way. Disguised as a beggar he meets the robber who has recovered in the meantime. The robber looks at the man’s stick inquisitively, whereupon the man becomes suspicious, examines his stick, & unexpectedly finds money inside it. In some variants the dead robber’s companion appears instead & tries to get hold of the money hidden in the stick.
1036
961AThe Forgotten CaneRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA man believes he has killed a robber in a struggle. During the fight the man loses his own cane. Many years later he finds his cane in the house of this robber (who has become an honest man in the meantime).
1037
961BMoney in the StickRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA refugee entrusts his host with his money. When the refugee asks for the money back, the host denies that he has it. The refugee, hoping for justice, files a lawsuit. The clever host hollows out a walking stick & puts the money inside it. He gives the stick to the refugee to hold and, under oath, swears that he has re-turned the money.Enraged by this falsehood, the refugee throws the stick to the ground & it breaks. The money falls out & the trick is exposed. The refugee takes his money back & the cheater hangs himself.
1038
962**The Girl Who Played with the BreadRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA vain girl (boy) is given bread for her mother by her mistress on the way to the church. At a mud puddle (brook) she lays the bread in the water (on the ground) in order to step on it so that her fine shoes will not be spoiled. But when the girl steps on the bread it starts slowly sinking into the ground (it is transformed into a bird or a stone). When the people return from church they see only the top of the the girl’s head & cannot save her.
1039
965*Robbers' Alarm BellRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersIn order to know when travelers pass, a robber (robbers) has stretched a wire to which a bell is fastened across the road in front of his cave. The robber seizes the travelers, drags them into the cave, robs & kills them. A girl whom he had caught stays in his cave & keeps house for him. After seven years with the robber, the girl asks permission to go to church. She is allowed to go on condition that she will not talk to anyone about the robber or where she is living. After mass, the girl stands before the church door & tells her story in public to the door (wall, oven of the clergyman). She further explains that she intends to buy peas in order to mark the way to the cave. The clergyman & the village people follow the traces, encircle the cave, seize the robber, free the girl, & destroy the cave.
1040
967-Man Saved by a Spider WebRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersA man (father & son, saint, Virgin Mary & Christ-Child, King Solomon) escapes from his pursuers & hides in a cave. A spider spins its web over the hiding place (and remains sitting in the middle). When the pursuers see the spider web they think the cave is unoccupied & do not enter it.
1041
968-Misc. Robber & Murder StoriesRealistic Tales (850-999)950-969 Robbers & MurderersThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with robbers & murderers as characters. In numerous tales robbers are cheated by the clever actions of a girl (other person): e.g. the girl seizes the beard of a robber concealed under bed; slams the lid of a (money-) chest on a robber when he looks into it; blinds a robber & escapes by throwing magic objects; puts a corpse instead of herself in the rob-ber’s house. Sometimes the robbers escape when a girl enters their house or mocks them. In some variants the robbers cheat a person in order to take their goods, or someone simulates a robbery in order to get money.
1042
970-The Twining BranchesRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesTwo lovers are not allowed to live together. They die of grief (commit suicide) & are buried side by side (in the same cemetery). Plants grow from their graves; the branches intertwine (meet over the roof of the church). Thus the lovers are united in death.
1043
973-Man as Sacrifice to the StormRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA ship is in the middle of a dangerous storm. One man on board, an apparent evil-doer, seems to be the cause for the distress at sea. He has to be identified & thrown overboard to placate the storm. The sinner is found by casting lots (throwing dice), & when he is thrown into the sea the storm abates. In some (Christian) variants the guilty person confesses his deed voluntarily, whereupon the storm abates (supernatural deliverance of the victim).
1044
974-The Homecoming HusbandRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesIn the absence of her husband (lover) who is far away on a journey (in prison), a woman is forced to choose another husband. The first husband (disguised, as beggar) returns (with supernatural help, carried during a deep sleep, warned by a dream) on the wedding day & discloses his identity to his wife (by a ring well known to her), is recognized by domestic animals (horse, dog), or answers the woman’s questions correctly (concerning features of the house or birthmarks). The revenge on the rival follows.
1045
976-Which was the Noblest Act?Realistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesOn their wedding night, a man allows his bride to visit her former lover (fiancée), in order to keep a promise she had made previously (to cancel the engagement). On her way she meets a robber. When she tells him her story he leaves her unmolested. When her lover (fian-cée) hears about her bridegroom’s (the robber’s) magnanimity, he takes her back to her bridegroom without touching her. In some variants the tale occurs in conjunction with a frame tale that deals with the discovery of a thief: Three (four) sons inherit jew el ry (money) from their father (merchants bury their fortune). The money is stolen by one of the brothers (merchants). The robbed owners call a wise man (judge, king, Solomon), who is to discover the thief. The wise man (his daughter) then starts to tell the story (see above). The thief betrays himself unconsciously when he answers the question, “Who acted in the noblest way?” He argues that the robber in the story was the most noble one (he answers other questions in a revealing manner).
1046
978-The Youth in the Land of the CheatersRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA young man sets out on busi-ness & comes to a land where cheaters flourish. After a while he loses all his goods. A one-eyed man (woman) states that the youth’s father had taken the other eye & demands compensation. The same with a one-legged man, who states that the youth’s father had once taken his other leg & now asks for compensation. A barber agrees to shave the young man for “something” & then demands a huge sum of money (other valuables). Finally the young man is rescued from his difficult situation by someone (his wife, another person) who outwits the cheaters & recovers her husband’s lost property. The rescuer demands that the one-eyed man should give up his remaining eye so that he could match it with the other. In the same way he demands the remaining leg of the one-legged man, in order to compare it with the other one. The rescuer tricks the barber into accepting “something” for his service.
1047
980-Ungrateful SonRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesThis miscellanous type comprises various tales dealing with ungrateful children (son, daughter-in-law) of an ageing father. They think about & eventually change their behavior because of the analogous actions of their own son (daughter). (1) When an aged father is banned from the table & served his meals in a wooden cup by his son & his daughter-in-law, the little grandson starts to build a similar cup for his parents to use when they grow old. Thereupon the couple starts to reflect on their undig-ni fied behavior. Thinking of their own old age, they bring the old father back to the family table. (2) A son gives his father half a blanket (carpet, cape, cloth) to keep warm. Thereupon the little grandson keeps the other half of the blanket & explains that he will save it for his parents for when they are old. (3) An aged father is abandoned by his son in the wilderness (abyss) in a cart (sledge, basket). The grandson keeps it in order to use it in the same way for his parents when they have grown old. They reflect on their behavior. (4) The ungrateful son drags his old father out of the house by pulling at his hair. At the threshold the father says, “Do not drag me further; I dragged my own father only this far!”. The son reflects on his bad behavior.
1048
980*The Painter & the ArchitectRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesPersuaded by a painter, a king (landlord) orders his architect to build a tower for the architect (the king himself) to go to heaven to see his father (to build a mansion up there). The architect leaves through an underground passage. He entices the painter to climb up to heaven. But the painter (king, landlord) meets his death when the tower burns.
1049
980DMeat Springs as a Toad on the Face of an Ungrateful SonRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA couple (son) intends to eat a roasted chicken (meal). When the man’s old father passes by unexpectedly, they hide the chicken in order not to share it with him. The old man takes a drink & then continues on his way. When they replace the chicken on the table in order to have their meal, it has turned into a toad (snake) & jumps onto the son’s face where it stays until his death.
1050
981-Wisdom of Hidden Old Man Saves KingdomRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesDuring a famine (war), the young people have an assembly & decide (the emperor orders) that all old & seemingly useless men should be killed. One man hides his father. When everything goes wrong under the young rulers, the wise old man comes forth & saves the situation with his good advice (he helps perform difficult tasks with his wisdom). Thereupon he is honored & the custom of killing old people is aban doned. In some variants the son, who intends to kill his father, realizes that the same will happen to him when he is old, & lets his father live.
1051
981A*Life by a Silk ThreadRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA wise king, asked by his brother (Damocles, courtier, court jester) why he always looks sad even in happy situations, answers the question by sending for the questioner & pretending to plan his execution. The brother is placed on a chair over a pit filled with red-hot coals, with four lances pointing at him & a sword (stone, millstone) suspended over his head on horse’s hair (thread). The king explains that this situation resembles his own: the pit stands for the fire in hell, the lances for death & the sword signifies the divine judge. This is the reason for his sadness & fear.
1052
982-Pretended InheritanceRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesTrusting to his children’s care when he is old, a rich man leaves all his property to them. They soon forget their intentions & neglect their father. Thereupon the old man plans a ruse: He starts counting money conspicuously & points to a chest giving the advice that it contains another considerable inheritance. Thereupon the children change their behavior & look after their father carefully. When the father finally dies they find only sand & stones in the chest. In some variants they find a mace with the advice that it should be used to kill anyone stupid enough to give away his inheritance before his death.
1053
983-The Dishes of the Same FlavorRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA virtuous woman (virgin, wife, widow ) tries to escape from the attentions of a mighty man (king, ruler). She serves him dishes that look different but taste identical (different colored eggs, same drinks in different glasses). In response to his question what this means, she compares the dishes with women: Even if they look different, they are all alike. This is why it is not worthwhile to change sexual partners. The man is dissuaded from his amorous purpose & contents himself with his own wife.
1054
984-Palace from Bird BonesRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesIn accordance with his wife’s wish, a king gives orders to build a palace made of bird bones. One bird comes late, & when it arrives, it says it was thinking about whether men or women were worth more. It decided that women must be worth more because those who obey women are subordinate to them. The king rescinds his order.
1055
985-Brother Chosen Rather than Husband or SonRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesThree men are condemn ed to death. A woman appeals to the ruler for clemency, ex-plain ing that they are her brother, her husband & her son. When the ruler agrees to release only one of them, she chooses her brother, because she is still young enough to marry again & give birth to another son. Only a brother cannot be replaced. Impressed by her explanation (ruse, logic), the ruler frees all three men (brother & son, the brother alone).
1056
985*The Suckled PrisonerRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA man (woman) condemned to starvation is closely guarded. Only his daughter has permission to visit him daily, but before her visit she is always checked thoroughly so that she cannot bring any food. After a long time the condemned man shows no signs of exhaustion. One day the guardians observe that the daughter suckles her father through a crack in the prison wall (woman suckles son, wife suckles strange man, daughter suckles mother). Impressed by the woman’s devotion, the judges release the prisoner.
1057
985**Measure for MeasureRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesAn official who desires a certain woman agrees to set her husband (brother) free from prison if she will sleep with him. She complies, but her husband is to be executed anyway. When the wife brings a suit against the official, the ruler restores her honor by marrying her to the official. Later the official is executed & his wife receives his property.
1058
986-The Lazy HusbandRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA king marries his daughter to a lazy man (mother’s boy, beggar). Forced by his wife to work, he joins a caravan. In the desert he climbs into a well in order to fetch water. He finds a kidnapped girl (princess) & a pomegranate. He sends the pomegranate to his wife, & out of it fall jewels. She becomes rich & builds a palace. He returns the kidnapped girl to her father & returns home to his wife.
1059
987-False Magician Exposed by Clever GirlRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A magician deceives the eyes of spectators making them be-lieve that a rooster can pull (carry) a heavy beam (a rope-dancer can push a cart, juggle a beam). A girl with a four-leafed shamrock (snake, dead toad, salamander) understands the trick & states that the rooster can only pull straw. The magician takes revenge by making the girl believe she is going through deep water. She raises her dress as high as possible & all spectators mock her. (A lock magically closes the girl’s mouth so that she cannot speak.) (2) A juggler pretends to be able to creep through a thick beam (stone). The girl with the shamrock discovers that he only creeps over it or next to it. The water-episode follows, & in some variants the girl is bewitched into being lame or crooked.
1060
990-The Seemingly Dead RevivesRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA woman becomes ill during an epidemic & falls into a deathlike faint. Her husband orders her buried & puts a precious ring (clothes) into her coffin. One of the grave-diggers returns to the cemetery at night, reopens the grave, & tries to rob the dead. Thereupon (when he tries to cut her finger) the woman revives, leaves the grave, & returns home to her husband. He receives her kindly & they continue to live together for a long time in good health.
1061
992-The Eaten HeartRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA knight woos a married woman. The husband kills his wife’s lover (suitor) & orders the cook to prepare his heart & to serve it to his wife. When she praises the meal, he tells her what she has eaten, remarking that her lover pleases her dead as well as alive. Thereupon she jumps out the window (refuses any food, dies from pain). The husband regrets his deed (is punished by the ruler, by the woman’s relatives).
1062
992AAdulteress's PenanceRealistic Tales (850-999)970-999 Other Realistic TalesA merchant admires a sovereign who in-vites him to his castle. At dinner the merchant observes that the sovereign’s wife is served her meal in a skull (her lover’s head with beard). In his bedroom he finds two dead young men hanging. The sovereign explains to him that his wife had committed adultery with a duke whereupon he had him beheaded. In return, the son of the duke killed the two young men. As penance, the woman has to eat from the skull, & the two corpses are a reminder of the murder.
1063
1000-Contest Not to Become AngryTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand (poor boy, strong man, three sons one after another) agrees to a contest with his master (devil, ogre, priest) that whoever becomes angry first (before the cuckoo calls) must allow strip(s) of skin (flesh) to be cut out of his back (have his nose or ears cut off, be beaten) or must pay a large sum of money. The farmhand (third son) heaps abuse on his master or feigns stupidity until the latter erupts in anger. The master tries to flee but finally must take his punishment.
1064
1001-Cutting WoodTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractThe devil’s helper has to cut some trees for firewood, but his axe does not split the wood (the woodpile becomes larger with every cut). The helper finds a cat (snake) in the pile, kills it, & then is able to finish his work.
1065
1002-Destroying the Master's PropertyTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand harms his master (ogre, priest) by destroying (selling, giving away, exchanging) his property.
1066
1003-PlowingTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA master (ogre, devil) bids his farmhand to plow following the dog (as long as the dog sits still), & to take the horses wherever the dog goes. The farmhand plows over hill & dale. (He beats the dog.) The dog runs home & enters the stable through a small aperture (hole in the wall). To take the horses in the same way, the farmhand cuts them into quarters. In some variants, a farmhand must guard the cattle. In the evening he will get his dinner only if he comes home before the dog. Dur ing the first few days, the farmhand does not get dinner. Then he kills the dog.
1067
1004-Hogs in the mud; sheep in the airTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) Left to guard the pigs (cows, horses), a farmhand sells them but sticks their severed tails in the muddy ground. His master pulls the tails out & thinks that the pigs are sunk in the mud (have escaped underground). (2) A farmhand sells his master’s sheep & hangs their severed tails (bells) in a tree. He thus makes the master believe that the sheep have been carried away by a strong wind (have escaped into the air, have gone to heaven). (3) A farmhand (thief) kills one ox & puts its tail in the mouth of another, so that his master (the owner of the ox) thinks one ox has eaten the other.
1068
1005-A Bridge (Road) of CarcassesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractAn ogre orders a man to build a bridge (road) not of wood, stone, iron, or earth. The man slaughters all the ogre’s livestock & builds the bridge out of their carcasses.
1069
1006-Casting eyesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is ordered by his master to “cast an eye” over something (somebody). He intentionally takes this request lit erally, kills the master’s livestock, & throws the animals’ eyes at the object (person), where the misunderstanding is unintentional.
1070
1006-Kill the Sheep That is Looking at YouTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is told by his master (devil) to kill the sheep that looks at him first. The whole flock looks at him, so that the farmhand kills all the animals.
1071
1007-Other Means of Killing or Maiming LivestockTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractMisc. type with diverse variants, e.g.: A farmhand is ordered by his master to pasture the cattle in such a way that they come home dancing & laughing, so he makes them limp & tears off their lips. A farmhand frightens his master’s oxen on a bridge so that they drown. A farmhand removes the skin of oxen’s legs so that they will not get them wet while drinking.
1072
1008-Lighting the RoadTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is ordered by his master to light the road (paint the house red). He sets the house on fire.
1073
1009-Guarding the Store-room DoorTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand (foolish man or woman) is ordered to guard the door of the store-room (house). He pulls the door off its hinges & carries it with him. In some variants, a farmhand is asked to close the door tightly. He uses iron nails in order to do so.
1074
1010-Repairing the HouseTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is ordered to repair the house (tidy up the rooms, rebuild the dunghill, fill up a well). He takes all the objects outside (tears out the stove or the floor, smashes the furniture or the dishes, carries everything to the dunghill, throws it into the well, etc.). In some variants, the farmhand is told to do what the neighbors do. He tears off the roof (destroys the house).
1075
1011-Tearing up the Orchard (Vineyard)Tales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is told to cut wood. He cuts down a neighbor’s orchard (vineyard).
1076
1012-Cleaning the ChildTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is ordered by his master to wash the child. He holds the child under water until it is drowned (cleans the child outside & inside: takes the intestines out & washes them).
1077
1013-Bathing (Warming) GrandmotherTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA farmhand is ordered to bathe (warm) the grandmother. He scalds her or puts her on (into) the stove.
1078
1015-Forging a HissTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA man (boy) wants to (is expected to) learn how to forge metal objects simply by watching the smith. After a while (three years) he finishes his “apprenticeship”. As his first piece, he wants to forge a plowshare for a farmer (his uncle). He hammers so powerfully that the iron becomes too thin for a plowshare. So he decides to forge an axe instead. This does not work out, either. From the rest of the iron, he tries to forge a knife & after that an awl. Finally only a tiny piece of iron is left. He tells the farmer that he will forge him a hiss & throws the iron into water, where it sinks hissing. In some variants, a farmhand is ordered to whet a knife. He whets the whole blade away.
1079
1016-Cleaning the HorseTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA master (devil) asks his farmhand to clean the horse(s). The farmhand cuts off the horse’s tail (mane, etc.) (washes the horse in boiling water, curries it with a sharp razor). In some variants, the farmhand cleans the horses both outside & inside: He takes their intestines out & washes them.
1080
1017-Covering the Whole Wagon with TarTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractA master (devil) tells his farmhand to grease the wagon. The farmhand covers the whole wagon (the inside of the wagon) with tar.
1081
1029-The Woman as Cuckoo in the TreeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1000-1029 Labor ContractThe anger bargain between a master (ogre) & his farmhand is to end when the cuckoo calls. In order to hasten the contract’s end, the master’s wife climbs into a tree & imitates the cuckoo. The farmhand recognizes the trick & shoots (throws a stone) at the “bird”. The woman is killed.
1082
1030-The Crop DivisionTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, bear) & a farmer (God, saint, Gypsy, fox) want to divide the crop. In the first year, the devil claims what grows above the ground. The farmer plants turnips (potatoes), & the devil only gets the greens. In the following year they want to divide the other way. The farmer sows wheat (other kinds of grain, cabbage) & the devil, who gets what is growing beneath the ground, again comes away empty-handed.
1083
1030*Choice of CowsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreA clever & a foolish brother, who want to divide their livestock, build a new cow-shed: The foolish brother will get all animals which go into the new cow-shed, & the clever brother all those which go into the old one. Only one ox (usually old, blind, lame) goes into the new cow-shed.
1084
1031-Granary Roof Used as Threshing FlailTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreA giant & his farmhand have a threshing contest. The giant’s iron threshing flails are too heavy for the farmhand to lift. So the farmhand pretends to use the barn roof (rafter) as threshing flail. The giant gives up.
1085
1035-Clearing Out ManureTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreAn ogre (devil) asks his farmhand to clear out the manure. The farmhand digs a hole for the manure or piles it high. In some variants, the farmhand puts a cork in the ox’s backside to keep the stable clean, or he kills the animal for soiling itself.
1086
1036-Hogs with Curly TailsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreThe devil (giant, dragon) & a man (Gypsy) have a contest to see who is able to throw more hogs out of a stable (over a roof, fence). The man throws only one hog, the devil all the others. When they are about to divide the animals, the man pretends he can recognize the hogs he has thrown out by a sign: He had turned around their tails. Thus the man gets all hogs with curly tails, the devil only a sick one with a straight tail.
1087
1037-The Ogre Shears a PigTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreAn ogre & a boy, who breed sheep & pigs, are going to divide what the animals produce. Of the sheep, the ogre gets the lambs to fatten, the boy gets the wool & the milk. Of the pigs, the boy gets the young ones, & the ogre is allowed to shear the pigs & take their milk. In a shorter version, an ogre (numskull, devil) tries to shear a pig & comments on this experience, “Much screaming, no wool”.
1088
1045-Pulling the Lake TogetherTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A man (workman, shepherd boy) threatens the devil (ogre) by pretending that he will pull together a lake (pull away a forest or mountains) with a rope (chain). The devil is intimidated (because he lives in the lake. He tries to kill the man, or gives him gold or other gifts to stop him). (2) A man threatens an ogre (devil) by pretending to pull away a warehouse with a rope. The ogre is intimidated by the man’s seeming power. (They tie a rope around the warehouse; the ogre pulls & is crushed beneath the house.) (3) A man (farmhand) makes a long rope so he can lead home the whole herd of cattle.
1089
1048-Buying WoodTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreA poor man (often the youngest of three brothers) becomes a farmhand of the devil (master, a red-haired man, God). The farmhand is ordered to get neither straight nor crooked wood, or semi-straight & semi-crooked wood, in equal parts (buy a forest). The farmhand cuts down the wood & thus does his master harm. The master discharges him immediately (gives him another order).
1090
1049-The Heavy AxeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreA master (ogre, devil, bear) asks his farmhand (boy, old man, tailor) to fetch firewood & water, but the axe & the buckets are so heavy that the farmhand cannot lift them. The farmhand demands an axe heavy enough to cut down the whole forest & a bucket large enough to bring in the whole well. The master is frightened & does the work himself.
1091
1050-Felling TreesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil, dragon, bear) & a man (boy, old man, Gypsy, tailor) each try to fell a large tree in order to see who is faster & stronger. The man exchanges the ogre’s axe with a dull one.
