In some variants, the man secretly saws into his tree in advance, uses an axe while the ogre uses his fists, or tricks the ogre into doing all the work.
1092
1051-Bending a TreeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil, dragon, bear) & a man (Gypsy, tailor) have a contest to see who is the stronger. The man is not able to bend a tree & to keep the tree-top down. He tricks the ogre into performing this task. When the tree-top springs up, the man is shot into the sky. He pretends to have made a high jump to fetch (catch) something. (The ogre is unable to imitate the jump, falls to his death, or gives up.)
1093
1052-Carrying a TreeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil, bear) & his helper (man, fox) are going to carry home the tree they have felled. The helper says that he is stronger (does not know the way) & will carry the top, while the ogre carries the bottom-end. The ogre goes first & carries the bot tom-end. But instead of carrying the branches, the helper sits on them, & the ogre has to carry the whole burden alone.
1094
1053-Shooting Wild BoarsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) asks his farmhand to shoot a wild boar or two. The farmhand asks, “Why not a thousand at one shot?” The ogre is frightened by the presumed power of his farmhand
1095
1059*Riding on a HarrowTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1030-1059 Partnership between Man & OgreA farmer (boy) makes the devil ride on a reversed harrow (roller, sit on the thorny end of a tree)
1096
1060-Squeezing the (Supposed) StoneTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) & a (poor) man (tailor, Gypsy) have a contest to see which of them can squeeze water out of a stone. The ogre squeezes a stone; the man a cheese (egg, turnip) & thus intimidates the ogre. (In some variants, the actors are animals.)
1097
1060ASqueezing the HandTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) & a man (tailor, sailor) com-pete to determine whose handshake is stronger. The man wears an iron glove & wins. In some variants, the man holds out a (glowing) iron rod (fork, etc.).
1098
1061-Biting a Stone to PiecesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (devil) & a man (boy, tailor, soldier) compete to see who can bite (bruise) a stone to pieces. The man takes a nut (pea) & bites it easily. The ogre, who is not able to bite the stone to pieces, is impressed by the man’s strong teeth. In some variants, a tailor must stay for a night in the stable with a bear. The tailor makes the bear curious by cracking nuts & then gives him stones, which the bear cannot crack.
1099
1062-Throwing a StoneTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil, dragon) & a man (boy, tailor, Gypsy) compete to determine who can throw a stone higher: The one whose stone falls first to the ground will lose. The ogre throws a stone. The man throws a bird (sparrow, lark, bat), which never comes back
1100
1063-Throwing a ClubTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) & a man (boy) compete in throwing a (golden, heavy) club (hammer, axe) higher. The ogre throws the club up high. The man hesitates, pretending to wait for a cloud to throw the club into (takes care not to hit a star, wants to throw the club up to a relative in heaven). The ogre gives up. In some variants, the man shows the ogre the club in a cloud, or he pretends that he had already thrown the club & it will not come back.
1101
1063AThrowing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) & a man have a throwing contest. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The man pretends to throw a stone (rock) so far that it will destroy a village (house) beyond the sea (mountains), or he warns Angel Gabriel (St. Peter) to look out. (2) The man pretends that he will throw a stone to a distant point (Constantinople) where it will strike one of the ogre’s relatives.
1102
1064-Making Fire by Stamping on the GroundTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) & a (timid , old) man have a contest: They want to make fire (get water) by stamping on the ground. The man wins the contest because he pre pared hot ashes beforehand (buried a tube filled with water in the earth), & thus he intimidates the ogre.
1103
1070-Wrestling ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, magician, dragon, demon, bear) & a man (Gypsy, famous wrestler) have a wrestling contest. The ogre squeezes the man so hard that his eyes bulge out. When the ogre asks him why he is staring, the man answers that he is looking for where to throw him. The ogre gives up (flees, promises money, swears eternal friendship).
1104
1071-Wrestling Contest (with Old Grandfather)Tales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) challenges a man (boy, farmer) to a wrestling contest. The man sends his “grandfather” (“brother”, “uncle”) – a bear – instead. The ogre loses.
1105
1072-Running ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) challenges a man to a race. The man persuades the ogre to run against his little son – a rabbit – instead of himself. The rabbit wins.
1106
1073-Climbing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) challenges a man to a climbing contest. The man persuades the ogre to compete with the man’s child – a squirrel – instead of himself. The squirrel wins.
1107
1074-Race Won by Deception: Relatives as HelpersTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) challenges a man (a man challenges an animal) to a race. The man places his relatives (others that resemble him) along the course (at the finish). The ogre thinks that the man is just ahead of him (has won).
1108
1080*Laughing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) & a man have a laughing contest. The man puts a dead horse with a grinning mouth in his place. The ogre tries to laugh as long as the horse, & laughs till he dies.
1109
1082-Carrying the HorseTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) & a man (Gypsy, shoe-maker) take turns in carrying a horse. The ogre carries it on his back & is soon exhausted. The man takes the horse between his legs, i.e. rides, & thus “carries” it without effort.
1110
1082ASinging ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (monk) & a man (soldier) come to an agreement: While one of them sings a song, the other must carry him on his back. The dev il’s song is short. The man, however, sings an endless song (continuously sings the same song). The devil gives up (bursts).
1111
1083-Duel with Long Pole & CudgelTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, giant) & a (poor) man (smith, teacher, Gypsy, God, old woman) duel in a little room (stable, fold, forest). The man gives the devil a long pole & chooses a short cudgel (hammer) for himself. The devil cannot do anything with his pole, so the man beats him up. (After this, they continue the duel outside, but exchange weapons. So the man beats the devil up again.
1112
1083ADuel with Bayonet & PItchforkTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil & a man want to fight. The devil has a bayonet (sword, pike), & the man has a pitchfork. The man threatens that he will inflict five wounds on the devil with each thrust, while the devil himself can give him only one wound. Therefore the devil wants to exchange weapons. The man stands behind a fence so that the devil cannot hit him.
1113
1084-Screaming or Whistling ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) & a man (boy) have a screaming (whistling) contest. The man binds up his head to prevent it from breaking in two when he screams. The ogre is frightened & begs the man to bind up his head, too. The man does so & then strikes him on his head. The ogre acknowledges the man to be the stronger. In some variants, the man blindfolds the ogre & strikes him with a hammer on his head (forehead).
1114
1085-Making a hole in a treeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant) & a man have a contest to see who can make a deeper hole in a tree with his head (fist). The man wins because he already had prepared the tree beforehand: He had cut a hole with his axe & replaced the bark. In some variants, the actors are animals.
1115
1086-Jumping into the GroundTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) & a man (boy, Gypsy) have a contest to see who can jump deeper into the ground (can get the earth’s bowels out). The man wins because he has dug a pit beforehand & covered it with boughs or a mat (buried fish guts in the ground).
1116
1087-Rowing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreAn ogre orders a man to row him to go fishing. The man tells him that he will break the oars. The ogre then rows him self. In some variants, the rowing contest is won by deception: The boat has already been sawn through.
1117
1088-Eating/Drinking contestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An ogre (giant) & a man (boy) have an eating contest. The man slips his food (drink) into a concealed bag (behind his shirt) & makes the ogre believe he is the bigger eater. In many versions the hero cuts open the bag to eat even more; the ogre imitates & kills himself. (2) The devil (giant) & a man have a drinking contest. The man drinks water, the devil is given alcohol (vinegar, vitriol). The devil feels sick & acknowledges the man as the better drinker.
1118
1089-Threshing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, giant) & a (poor) man have a threshing contest. The man has a wooden flail, the devil one of iron. The old & weak man accomplishes less than the devil. When they finally divide the result, the devil chooses the big heap of chaff, while the man gets the smaller heap of grain.
1119
1090-Mowing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, giant) & a man (smith, farmer, boy) have a mowing contest. (The man takes the center of the field.) The devil is given a dull sickle (and he mows around the outside of the field, tiring himself out). In some variants, during the night the man secretly prepares the part of the meadow the devil has to mow the next day: He sticks harrow-tines (teeth) among the grass. Thus the devil’s scythe becomes chipped, & the man wins the contest.
1120
1091-Bringing an Unknown AnimalTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The devil (dragon, death, bear) & a man make a deal (contest) to see who can present (after a certain space of time) a horse un like any other. (The devil puts a mask on a sheep, but the man recog nizes it.) The man brings his wife, naked but covered with tar & feathers (hair combed over her face), on hands & knees with her but tocks as the head. The devil has never seen such a horse & is defeated. (2) Like (1) with the difference, that the man is to present an un known game animal. He brings his wife covered with tar & feathers & pretends to shoot her.
1121
1091AGuessing the Name of the Devil's Secret PlantTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil plants tobacco & asks a man who is unfamiliar with this plant to guess its name. (The devil threatens to kill him if he does not succeed.) The man’s wife, covered with tar & feathers, approaches the plant (ruins part of the field), so that the devil orders the supposed animal to get away from his tobacco. Thus the name of the plant is discovered.
1122
1093-Talking ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, giant) tries to outdo a girl (man, boy, shepherd, God) in a talking (counting) contest. He does not succeed (and bursts with rage).
1123
1094-Cursing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, giant) & a (poor) man compete to see who can curse (insult, frighten) the other more. The devil frightens the man with hellish tortures or insults him until his clothes fall off his body. The man throws an iron flax-comb against the devil’s back (sends arrows as curses against him).
1124
1095-Scratching ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An ogre (giant, devil) & a man compete in a scratching contest. The man sends his wife to tell the ogre that her husband has gone to have his nails sharpened. She shows her vulva to the ogre pretending that it is a deep wound her husband has scratched into her body. The ogre flees. (2) An ogre (devil) & a man (boy) have a scratching contest. The man covers himself with several oxhides (wears iron gloves).
1125
1096Sewing ContestTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreThe devil (ogre, giant) & a tailor (shoemaker, Gypsy, woman) have a sewing contest. The devil sews with a very long thread: Making his first stitch, he has to run around the house (jump out of the window). When he returns, the tailor has already finished his task & wins the contest.
1126
1098*ExhalingTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & Ogre(Sometimes part of a contest: Who can exhale more strongly?) An ogre (dragon) exhales (sighs, sneezes) so intensely that a man is lifted up in the air. The man pretends that he jumped for joy (to catch a bird, look for his father’s club).
1127
1099-The Giant as Master BuilderTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1060-1114 Contest Between Man & OgreMisc. type; the following version is the most common: A giant who is a master builder builds a cathedral in a certain city. As his payment, he demands something impossible or horrible (sun & moon, the eyes of the person who commissioned the building), unless someone can discover his name. This happens, & the giant loses not only his payment but also his life (he is stoned to death). In some variants the giant (giants) destroys the building when someone calls his name and/or turns into a raven & flies away.
1128
1115-Attempted Murder with a HatchetTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreIn a contest, an ogre (giant, devil, bear) has been defeated by a (young, foolish, strong) man & wants to kill him while he is sleeping. The man learns about this plan und puts an object (e.g. butter cask) under his bedspread. The ogre strikes it with a weapon (often axe). In the morning, the man tells the ogre that he was troubled by vermin.
1129
1116-Attempted BurningTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) An ogre (giant, devil) has been defeated by a man in a contest & wants to burn him while he is sleeping. The man learns about this plan & hides in another place. When the ogre returns to the scene of fire, the man is found sitting in the ashes saying that it was a little hot (2) The devil wants to burn his helper. He locks him up in the hot bathhouse, but the man knows how to escape (runs away, digs a hole under the floor). (3) The devil & a young man make a contest to see who can stand more heat. When both of them are getting hot, the man pretends that he is cold & asks for a pillow. The devil gives up.
1130
1117-The Ogre's PItfallTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreAn ogre (ogress, giant, demon) arranges a trap for a man (tells a man to climb a tree which the ogre has cut). The man tricks the ogre so that he falls into the trap himself (is killed by the falling tree). In some variants, an ogre (animal) is tricked into a basket & then rolled down a mountain, or a demon is told to put a millstone around his neck to help him cross the sea. He drowns.
1131
1119-Ogre Kills His Mother (Wife)Tales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreAn ogre (devil) intends to kill a (young) man who is stay-ing in his house overnight. During the night the man exchanges his place with the ogre’s mother (wife, daughter). The ogre mis takenly kills his mother instead of the man.
1132
1120-Ogre's Wife Thrown into the WaterTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreWhile they spend the night near a river, an ogre (devil) & his wife want to drown their helper. During the night, the man changes places with the ogre’s wife, so that the ogre mistakenly throws his own wife into the water. In some variants, the ogre is tricked into throwing his wife into a well.
1133
1121-The Ogre's Wife Burned in Her Own OvenTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreA man throws the ogre’s (giant’s, devil’s) wife (sister, mother, daughter) or a witch into the fire (furnace) or tricks her into climbing into her oven. The ogress is burned.
1134
1122-Ogre's wife killed through other tricksTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreMisc. type. e.g. a man stabs her with her own knife, or she is persuaded to test a rope & hangs herself.
1135
1130-Counting out PayTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreUsing a trick, a man is released from an agreement with the devil (seldom with another demonic being). The devil has to give the man a hat (boot, bag or other container) full of gold. The man digs a pit & plans his hat with a hole in it (fixes a bottom less container on the roof of a house) so that the devil has to give him an enormous amount of gold (cannot fill the container). The devil disappears.
1136
1131-Hot Porridge in the Ogre's ThroatTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreA man (woman, animal) who is threatened by an ogre (devil, demon, robber, tiger, badger) burns the ogre’s throat by feeding him hot porridge (hot stones instead of potatoes, glowing coal instead of fish, etc.)
1137
1132-Flight of the Ogre with His Goods in the BagTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreAn ogre (giant, devil, master) tries to get away from his farmhand. The farmhand hides in the ogre’s bag (chest) so that the ogre unwittingly takes him along.
1138
1133-Making StrongTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man tells an ogre (giant, devil) that an ox (horse) is strong because it is gelded. To become strong, the ogre orders the man to castrate him, & they agree that the ogre will castrate the man the next day. The man substitutes his wife in man’s clothes. The ogre thinks that she is already castrated. (2) An ogre (demon) wants to become as strong as a man. In order to toughen (heal) the ogre, the man scalds him (injures him otherwise).
1139
1135-Eye-remedyTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreA man (with the absurd name “Myself”) pretends to heal (replace) the eyes of an ogre (giant, devil, cobold, water nix, fairy child, jackal). He pours a glowing mass (melted lead or tin) into the ogre’s eyes so that he is blinded. Queried about who has hurt him, the ogre answers, “Myself”.
1140
1137-Blinded Ogre (Polyphemus)Tales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures Ogre(Polyphemus, Tepegöz.) A man (together with others) who is traveling (in a forest, in the wilderness) accidentally comes to the cave (hut) of an (one-eyed) ogre living alone (with his mother) & tending sheep. The ogre catches the man & threatens to devour him. The man pretends to be a physician & promises to heal the ogre’s eye(s) (the ogre falls asleep). The man heats a metal spear, thrusts it into the ogre’s eye, & escapes from the blinded ogre by covering himself with a sheepskin or by hiding under the belly of a ram that walks out of the cave. In some variants, the ogre later tries to recapture the man by using a magic ring (object) which compels the fugitive to keep call-ing out,“Here I am”. The man succeeds in escaping from the ogre once more: He cuts off his finger with the ring & throws it into the sea. The ogre goes after the ring & is drowned.
1141
1138-Gilding the BeardTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreA (young) man who calls himself “Such a one” persuades an ogre (devil, priest) to have his beard gilt. He covers the beard with tar & leaves the ogre stuck to the tar-kettle. The ogre wanders around with his kettle & asks everyone, “Have you seen such a one?”. In some variants, a trickster who calls himself “Such a thing” pretends to heal a woman: He covers her with treacle. When she asks her neighbors, “Have you seen such a thing?” they tell her that they never have.
1142
1139-Carrying a Sham-Dead PersonTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) carries an apparently dead man & pretends that the man already smells.
1143
1140-Sleeping with Open EyesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreA man claims to sleep with open eyes. Thus he beguiles an ogre (devil) into sleeping, & can rob him.
1144
1141-Drinking a ReflectionTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreAn ogre (giant, devil) sees the reflection of a beautiful girl (fugitives) in the water. He attempts to drink the lake (river) dry (and bursts).
1145
1142-How the Lazy Horse Was CuredTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreAn ogre (giant, farmer) has a lazy horse (donkey). A man (smith, pharmacist) advises him to put something burning (e.g. pepper, hot paprika, hot tin) into the horse’s anus. The owner does so & the horse runs away. (In order to catch the animal, the owner tries the remedy himself & runs faster than his horse.
1146
1143-Ogre Otherwise InjuredTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1115-1144 Man Kills/Injures OgreMisc. type. An ogre (giant, devil, witch, old man) is tricked into getting his tongue (nose, beard) caught in a split log of wood (hole in the door). After his tongue has been cut off, the ogre cannot speak clearly & gets into trouble, or his nose is caught in the ventilation hole in the roof. In some variants, the ogre is persuaded to sit on a pole & is pierced to death.
1147
1145-Afraid of Strange NoiseTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManAn ogre (giant, devil) is afraid of what rustles or rattles (voices of unknown animals). A man sets some juniper on fire (imitates animals). (The ogre flees or fulfills the man’s wish.) In some variants, the devil & God frighten one another: The devil makes a great storm & beats with a cudgel on the bark of the tree, but God is not frightened. The devil is afraid of thunder.
1148
1146-MillstonesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManA man & an ogre (giant) boast about their strength. The man pretends that mill stones are his mother’s pearls or that a harrow is his sister’s (grandmother’s) comb. The ogre is overawed. In some variants, an ogre uses a harrow as a hair brush & hurts his head.
1149
1147-ThunderTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) An ogre wonders about the mighty noise of thunder & is told that it is just the noise of a wagon passing by. (2) An ogre (devil) is terrified by a thunderstorm. He flees & hides himself under a tree (rock). Lightning strikes & destroys the ogre’s hiding place. (3) An ogre (devil) tells a man to wake him if it happens to thun-der. The man does not obey (deceives the ogre) & lightning strikes the ogre. In some variants, the man wakes the ogre, who mows grass for him.
1150
1148BThunder's InstrumentsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManThe devil (son of the devil, ogre) steals the thunder-god’s instruments (bagpipes, whistle, hammer, etc.). The thunder-god goes to retrieve the instruments. He catches the thief & releases him in exchange for an invitation to the wedding of the devil’s daughter. Many instruments are stored there in a room, but nobody is able to play the biggest one, the bagpipes. The thunder-god & his son ask for permission to play, & thunder & lightning come out of the instrument. Many wedding guests die on the spot, & others disappear forever.
1151
1149-Bluff: Children Desire a Tiger's FleshTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A woman (man) sees a tiger (other animal). In order to frighten it, she makes her children cry & then tells them that here is a tiger whose meat they can eat. The tiger, terrified, runs away. A jackal wants to show the tiger that he had been tricked & insists that they go together back to the woman. The tiger, fearing that the jackal will desert him, insists that he & the jackal be tied together. On seeing the two of them, the woman scolds the jackal for having brought only one tiger instead of two (three, ten). The tiger thinks the jackal betrayed it. He flees, dragging the jackal with it. (2) A (weak, old) man (Gypsy) frightens an ogre (dragon, devil, tiger) by cunningly demonstrating his power. The ogre fails in trying to kill the man at night, carries a treasure to his home in order to get rid of him, & flees when supposed flesh of his companions is offer ed to him. The ogre returns together with a helper & again is frightened away. In some variants, a weak animal makes a strong one believe that it (its children) eats the flesh of the strong one’s companions.
1152
1150-"St. George's Dogs"Tales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by Man(Wolves.) A man who is threatened by the devil shouts for “St. George’s dogs” to help him. Immediately a num ber of wolves appear. The devil hides or flees, pursued by the wolves. In some variants, the wolves are described as dogs of the devil (St. Blasios), which do harm to other animals (man).
1153
1151-Big ShoesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManA man makes huge shoes & places them in such a way that a giant will think the man is as big as the giant. In some variants, a man makes a devil believe that boats are the shoes of a girl (the man’s grandfather) & a bathhouse is her cap.
1154
1152-Indimidation by Displaying ObjectsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManA man (men, boy, weak animals) stays overnight (hides) in a house (den) of an ogre (giant, devil, strong animal) & tries to overawe the ogre by claiming to be even greater (stronger). The ogre demands proof. The man pokes through the door or window objects which he has accidentally picked up on his journey: e.g. he pretends that a rope (porcupine bristle) is one of his hairs, a grain shovel is his ear, curds (lime, etc.) are his spittle, a turtle is a louse from his body, a sword (knife) is his tongue or teeth, a tree trunk is his leg, a tub or pot is his belly (head). Asked by the ogre to beat his chest, the man beats a drum (asked to cry, the man twists the tail of a donkey which brays). The ogre is intimidated.
1155
1153-Wages: as much as he can carryTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManTo get rid of his farmhand, an ogre (giant, devil, troll) offers him as his wages as much as he is able to carry himself. The farmhand says that this will be too much & that he will be contented merely with what the ogre can carry.
1156
1154-The Man Who Falls From the Tree & the DemonsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1145-1154 Ogre Frightened by ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Two (three or more) men (domestic animals) take refuge in a tree. Below them demons (predators) assemble. One man, acciden-tally or overcome by fear, falls from the tree into the midst of the de-mons. The man in the tree orders his companion to grab the biggest one, while he himself goes to attack the others. The demons flee. (2) A man (men) intimidates a demon by claiming to have been sent to collect the skins of demons, etc.
1157
1157-The Ogre & the GunTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An ogre (devil) has never seen a gun. A hunter tells him that it is a tobacco pipe. The ogre puts the end of the gun in his mouth, & the hunter pulls the trigger. The ogre spits, supprised that the to bacco is so strong. (2) An ogre wants to look through a gun barrel in the smithy. The smith shoots.
1158
1159-The Ogre Caught in the CleftTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An ogre (giant, devil, dragon) wants to learn to play a flute (violin, bagpipes). A man (boy, shepherd) tells him that his fingers are too crooked (claws too long) & they first have to be straightened (cut). The man squeezes the ogre’s fingers in a cleft of a tree (vice) & beats him. The ogre frees himself & threatens revenge on the man. The next time they meet, the man shows the ogre the naked genitals of his wife. When he sees the crevice, the ogre flees. (2) A man wants to expel an ogre (devil) from a haunted castle. He catches his beard (fingers) in a cleft (vice). Sometimes ends like version (1).
1159
1161-The Bear Trainer & His BearTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilA bear trainer with his (polar) bear comes to a mill (farmhouse) & requests quarters for the night. The miller (farmer) gives him a room & tells him that the house is haunted by an ogre (giant, devil, demon, ghost, goblin, troll). During the night, the ogre appears & starts to attack the guests, but the bear hurts & expels him. Since this night, the building has not been haunted. After a long absence, the ogre comes back & asks the farmer whether he still has the big (white) cat. The man answers that the cat in the meantime has given birth to four (seven) kittens. The ogre vows never to come again.
1160
1161AThe Fattened CowTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilThe devil gives a poor man a cow to be pastured for an indefinite length of time. The man sells the milk & gradu ally gets wealthy. After waiting in vain for the devil to claim his cow, the man sells it. When at last the devil does come for his cow, the man shows him his wealth & gives him strange gifts: his father’s comb for combing whiskers (which is a harrow), a whip (flail), a sugar-basin (large wooden mortar), a tobacco-box (trap). Instead of the cow, the man shows him a bear. The devil rides the bear & thanks the man for having fattened the cow.
1161
1162-The Iron Man & the OgreTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilA man (boy) asks an ogre (devil) to fight with the iron man in his place. The ogre is defeated. In some variants, the devil is made to put his hand into the throat of an iron man.
1162
1163-The Devil is Tricked into Revealing a SecretTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilThe devil (ogre, giant) maliciously watches a smith trying unsuccessfully to forge iron (plate a vessel with tin). When the smith claims falsely that he has succeeded, the devil asks who told him to use sand (salammoniac). In some variants, a miller learns from the devil to install a vibrat-ing sieve in his mill.
1163
1164-The Devil & the Evil WomanTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilThree main introductions can be distinguished: (1) A man throws his quarrelsome wife into a pit (well, gorge). Later he feels sorry (compassionate) & he wants to get her out. But instead of her, he pulls up a devil (demon) who lives in the pit & cannot endure the evil woman either. (2) A devil marries (wants to marry) a young woman & is tricked by his mother-in-law into a bottle (box). A hunter sets him free. (3) (Belfagor.) Souls in hell complain about bad women on earth. The devil(s) wants to test what it is like to live with a wife. In some variants, a man prefers to endure the torments of hell rather than live with his evil wife. The devil comes to an agreement with him: If the devil cannot live with the man’s wife for a certain time, the man may leave hell. The devil marries (lives with) an evil woman (widow) whom he wants to get rid of quickly. He gets help from a man (farmer, farmhand). The tale is usually continued by an agreement between the grate-ful devil & the man who helped him: A (rich) person (princess) is possessed by the devil. Twice the devil allows the helper to expel him from the possessed person, & the helper is given a big reward. The third time, the devil refuses to leave the possessed per son. The helper threatens the devil with the evil woman (his wife, mother-in-law). The devil flees.
1164
1165-The troll & the BaptismTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilA farmer is on friendly terms with a troll whom he does not want to come to his child’s baptism because he knows the troll’s appetite. Not wishing to offend him, he invites the troll, but says that among the guests there will be the Virgin Mary, Thor the Thunderer, etc. The troll thinks he had better stay away, but he will give the finest present. In a Latvian version, the devil promises the youth the maiden he desires, but he must let the devil spend the first night with her. The devil comes to the wedding, but when he hears that Thunder & Lightning have also been invited, he runs away.
1165
1166*The Devil & the SoldierTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilThe devil keeps guard in place of a soldier (enlists in military service instead of a youth, who promises him his soul). He cannot endure it that the straps of his knapsack cross each other & is punished.
1166
1168-Various Ways of Exorcising DevilsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilMisc. type. The devil is frightened by a shoe-maker & gives him gold. He is threatened (beaten) by a soldier, who uses a crucifix or exorcised by a foolhardy man who draws a magic circle, etc.
1167
1168AThe Demon and the MirrorTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilA man has a mirror in his bag. He tells a demon (tiger) that he has captured other demons & shows him the bag. The demon sees his reflection, mistakes it for another demon, & flees.
1168
1168BThe Tree Demon Pays the Man to Save the TreeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilA man is about to cut down a tree. The demon who lives in the tree promises to bring the man a large amount of rice each month (year) or a treasure of gold if he will desist. When the demon later on gets tired of the bargain, he enters the man’s house (sends another demon) in order to kill him. By chance the man discovers the demon. He threatens to kill him & thus forces him to bring even more rice.
1169
1168CThe Virgin Mary Saves a Woman sold to the DevilTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilA man sells his wife to the devil. Before the woman is to be delivered, she goes to church to pray for help to the Virgin Mary. Substituting for the woman , Mary goes to the devil, who flees.
1170
1169-Changing HeadsTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1155-1169 Man Outwits the DevilWhile wandering on earth, Christ & St. Peter (Santa Claus) meet a woman (old man) who is quarreling with the devil (serpent). Christ orders St. Peter to settle the quarrel, so St. Peter strikes off the heads of both the devil & the woman. Christ wants to undo the damage & orders St. Peter to replace the heads, but he unfortunately places them on the wrong bodies.
1171
1170-The Unsalable WomanTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (merchant) comes to an agreement with the devil (ogre): If the man is able to sell all his goods, he is to belong to the devil. If anything is left as unsalable, he is to be free. The man puts an evil old woman in a glass case. Even the devil is convinced that no one wants to buy her. Thus the man goes free. In some variants, the devil loses the contest because he does not succeed in selling three women.
1172
1171-A Rabbit in Each NetTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to catch a rabbit in each of a hundred nets set in high trees.
1173
1172-All Stones from the Stream or the FieldTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (woman) saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to gather all the stones from a stream (field); or because the devil is not able to count uncountable things like stars, grass, sands of sea, drops of water, etc.
1174
1173AThe Devil is to Fulfill Three WishesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA farmer asks the devil for all the tobacco in the world, all the brandy in the world & finally some more brandy in addition. The devil can fulfill the first two wishes but not the last one.
1175
1174-Making a Rope of SandTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to make a rope of sand (chaff). In some variants, a ruler demands a rope of sand (ashes) from one of his subjects (man, woman), who – sometimes helped by good advice – is able to perform the task.
1176
1175-Straightening a Curly HairTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man saves his soul from the devil by wish ing for something impossible. The man’s wife gives the devil one of her curly hairs & orders him to straighten it (forge it straight). The devil is unable to do this, & the man is free.
1177
1176-Catching a Man's Broken WindTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (woman) saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to: (1) catch (make a knot of) his fart (breath); (2) make knots from drops of spilled brandy; (3) catch a noise.
1178
1177-The Devil & the BeesTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA poor weaver (servant of a miller) sells his soul to the devil for money. As agreed, after seven years the devil takes the weaver away in a sack. The devil leaves the sack outside when he stops at an inn. A beekeeper sets the weaver free & puts a beehive in the sack. When the devil gets to Hell & opens the sack, the bees fly out & sting him. After this, he does not want any weavers in hell.
1179
1177**Fetching the Woman's GrindstoneTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to fetch a woman’s grindstone – the woman needs it to sharpen her tongue.
1180
1178-The Devil OutriddledTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilMisc. type. A man (boy) promised to the devil saves himself by pos-ing riddles or setting enigmatic tasks that the devil cannot solve or perform: The man asks the devil whether he will hold onto a hammer or let it fall, etc. He orders the devil to catch frogs & place them on a high tree or to shovel grain with a hayfork without tines. In some variants, the devil must unravel a net in a short time or heal a woman’s “wound” by licking.
1181
1178**The Devil at the GrindstoneTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilThe devil is ordered to turn a grindstone until he gets tired.
1182
1179-The Devil on the ShipTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (sailor) saves his soul (himself) from the devil (ogre) because the latter does not accomplish a difficult task. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The devil is unable to pump the whole sea out of a leaky ship. (2) The devil is unable to hold a ship fast on its anchor chain.
1183
1180-Catching Water in a SieveTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (woman, girl) saves his soul (herself) from the devil (ogre) because the latter is not able to catch water in a sieve.
1184
1182-The Level BushelTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA poor man (farmer, student) is to come into the devil’s power if at the end of a year (after ten years) he does not give back a level bushel of gold in return for a heaped one. The man at once hands back the level bushel & keeps the surplus.
1185
1182AThe Copper CoinTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilThe devil comes to an agreement with a man: He will give the man a copper coin, & whenever it is spent, a similar coin will appear in his pocket again. In return, the man will come into the devil’s power when he is sixty years old. The man buys an expensive property & pays with copper coins, so that all the devils in hell are employed in coining them. When the man threatens to buy another property, the devil terminates the agreement.
1186
1183-Washing Black Wool WhiteTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (woman) saves his soul from the devil because the latter does not succeed in washing black wool (cloth, cattle) white.
1187
1184-The Last LeafTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) The devil creates goats which do so much damage that God finally orders the wolves to kill them. The devil asks for compensation, & God promises to give it when all the oaks have no leaves. When the leaves have fallen, the devil again claims his compensation, but God tells him that there is a big oak in Constantinople which still has its leaves. The devil searches for this tree for months. When he comes back, he sees that all the oaks are in leaf again. Boiling with rage, the devil puts out the goats’ eyes & replaces them with his own eyes. (2) God & the devil argue about the division of power. God wants to rule during the time when the trees are in leaf, the devil at other times. A wren who witnesses this contract makes some of the trees to keep their withered leaves until spring comes, & the devil gives up. (3) The devil helps a man to perform a task (by giving him money). In return, the man is to come into the devil’s power when the last leaf falls from the (oak) tree. It never falls. (The devil angrily slashes the leaves.)
1188
1185-The First CropTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man has to pay the devil when he harvests his first crop. He plants acorns. In some variants, monks argue with a noble family about a piece of land. The noblemen lose in court, but claim a last sowing & harvest. They plant acorns.
1189
1185*When Pigs WalkTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA debt must be repaid to the devil when pigs walk home. But they always run.
1190
1186*The Devil & the LawyerTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilThe devil & a lawyer (judge, bailiff, inspector, etc.) go for a walk. Three (two) times, they meet various persons: e.g. a butcher who wishes the devil will take a pig away, then a farmer who wishes the same for his horse (ox), then a woman who wishes her child be sent to hell.Each time, the lawyer urges the devil to seize the opportunity, but he refuses because the wish was not in earnest. Finally they meet a poor widow (farmer, farmhand) who curses the lawyer for fraud with such intensity that the devil carries him off to hell.
1191
1187-MeleagerTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man (knight, captain, woman) is helped by the devil & in return cedes him his soul. When the devil comes to get it at the appointed time, the man asks for a delay until a short candle burns out. The devil agrees. Thereupon the man blows out the candle (eats up the candle) & is free.
1192
1187*Unfinished WorkTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man is to belong to the devil after he has finishes a certain task, e.g. putting on two boots, counting to three, hitting the devil three times. He never finishes the task & thus saves himself. In some variants, despite his tricks, the man does not win.
1193
1188-Come TomorrowTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilAn old woman (man, smith, farmer) bargains with the devil (death, creditor who claims his money). Finally she persuades him to come tomorrow, and, in order to be sure, the devil writes the word “tomorrow” on her door. Each time the devil comes for her, the woman shows him the inscription, & the devil goes away. After some days, the devil erases the inscription & threatens to get the woman the next day. The frightened woman hides first in a barrel full of honey & then in a feather-bed. When the devil comes, he is frightened by the strange creature covered with feathers, & flees. In a Russian version, the devil sets out one day & is tricked by the inscription “come yesterday”. In some variants, the devil comes every day until the gate with the inscription rots. He then claims the soul.
1194
1190*The Man Thought HangedTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA man promises himself to the devil in ex change for money. To save his soul, he stuffs his clothes with straw & hangs them up. The devil thinks the man has hanged himself & is satisfied.
1195
1191-Sacrifice on the BridgeTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA master builder is not able to finish a bridge or church (within a fixed time) & asks the devil (ogre) for help. The devil demands in return the first being that crosses the bridge (comes into the church). The mas-ter builder drives an animal (e.g. dog, wolf, cat, rooster, pig, goat) across the bridge (into the church), so the devil is cheated out of his human soul. Because its central element corresponds to Type 1191, the follow-ing version is included here: A king vows to sacrifice the first thing he meets, which turns out to be a miller driving a donkey. When the miller is about to be killed, he pleads that the donkey was in front of him. The donkey is beheaded.
1196
1192-The First BundleTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA young woman wants to marry anyone, even if it is the devil. A man (mannikin) appears & agrees to marry her (to help her) but demands that she pays him with the first thing she ties up in the morning. Instead of her clothes she ties up (on someone’s advice) a sheaf.
1197
1199-Prayer Without EndTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Death (angel of death, devil) goes to take a man who begs for a delay long enough to offer a last prayer. The man does not finish the prayer, so death cannot take him. After a while, death causes the man to finish his prayer (having grown very old, the man decides to finish the prayer & die). (2) Death (devil) cannot take a man (woman) as long as he (she) sings a hymn or a song that never ends.
1198
1199APreparation of BreadTales of the Stupid Ogre (1000-1199)1170-1199 Souls Saved from DevilA woman (women, man) can save herself from the devil (demon, dead persons, bear) by describing in detail how bread (flax) is prepared (what it suffers during preparation). When finally a rooster crows (the sun rises), the devil has to disappear (is transformed into a trunk or stone). In some variants, the bread (flax) itself tells about its sufferings & urges the devil to endure the same. The devil flees.
1199
1200-Sowing SaltAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools (numskulls) sow salt in a field & expect it to grow so they can sell the crop for a high price. Instead of salt, nettles grow, & the numskulls are proud of how well the “salt” is doing. In some variants, instead of salt, various substances like cooked grain, needles, gold dust, a small coin, chopped bacon or a hog are sowed or planted.
1200
1200ASowing the Seed in One PlaceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskull(s) sow(s) all the seeds in one furrow.
1201
1201-Carrying the Horse Anecdotes & JokesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFour men (numskulls) carry the plow horse so it will not trample down the (sprouting) seeds. In some variants, they carry the man who guards the field on horseback (on a cart, boat, rack, ladder) when he wants to scare away an animal (e.g. stork, cow, pig, horse), so that he will not trample down the growing seeds.
1202
1202-The Dangerous SickleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIn a land where the use of the sickle is unknown, grain is picked or shot down with guns. When the people try to use a sickle, it cuts one of the men. People think the sickle is a dangerous animal & drown it as punishment.
1203
1203-The Scythe Cuts a Man's Head OffAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull carries a scythe (sickle) around his neck. When he tries to take it off, he cuts his head off.
1204
1203AThe Sickle Thought to be a SerpentAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls find a sickle & mistake it for a serpent (worm, dragon, monster). They strike it & it bounces up & lands around the neck of one of them. When they pull on the “serpent”, they cut off the man’s head.
1205
1204-Fool Keeps Repeating His InstructionsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFool Keeps Repeating His Instructions so as to remember them. He usually forgets them.
1206
1204**Milking a HenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis misc. type includes tales in which a fool misunderstands the nature of domestic animals. For example, an (old) woman tries to milk a hen, or she insults (slays) it because it does not suckle its chicks.
1207
1208*The Belled SalmonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA bell is tied on a salmon (eel, pike) so that the fish can be found later.
1208
1210-Cow is Taken to the Roof to GrazeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIn some variants, the animal is driven up a ramp; in others it is hoisted up to the roof or a (church-) tower & strangled.
1209
1211-The Cow Chwing Its CudAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA farmwife (numskull) kills the cow (goat, ox) because she thinks it is mimicking her (will not give her any chewing gum). In some variants, an animal is killed because its lowing (bleating, or the like) is misinterpreted as laughter or mockery. In other variants, a villager believes that the donkey listens to what he tells him, because its ear move.
1210
1213-The Pent CuckooAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools build an enclosure of hedges to hold a cuckoo. It flies over one of the hedges. They say that they have not built the walls high enough In some variants, a numskull decides to close the town gate so that a bird (e.g. falcon, dove) that flew away cannot escape.
1211
1214-The Persuavive AuctionerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAn auctioneer (salesman) praises a man’s worthless cow so much that the man takes it back himself.
1212
1214*Driving a Horse into Its BridleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesDriving a Horse into Its Collar (Bridle) instead of putting it on the horse.
1213
1215-The Miller, His Son, & the DonkeyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool Stories(Asinus vulgi.) A miller & his son travel with one donkey (horse). First the son rides & is rebuked by a passerby for letting his father walk. Then the father rides & is criticized because he makes his son walk. When both ride or both walk, they are still blamed. As a lesson, the father shows the son that it is difficult (impossible) to please every one. In some variants, at the end the father & son carry the donkey (horse) between them & throw it into the water, or kill it.
1214
1216*The Lost PrescriptionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIt was written in chalk on door & washed off by rain.
1215
1218-Numskull Sits on Eggs to Finish HatchingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A stupid son (a foolish husband) stays alone at home. Among other things, he is responsible for a brooding hen (goose), but bungles the task: The bird is disturbed & runs away (the numskull kills it). Because he is afraid of his mother (wife), he sits on the eggs himself to finish the hatching (sometimes covers himself with honey or tar & feathers before sitting on the eggs). (2) A rogue undertakes the strenuous job of hatching eggs for which he is to be well paid. When the employer (e.g. lady of the manor) asks for the results, he burns down the barn with the osten-sibly hatched chickens & pretends that they all have died. (3) A rogue induces someone to sit on eggs in order to put him in a humiliating position.
1216
1221A*The Fish Too Large for the PanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools (numskulls) throw away a fish (cake) because it is too large for the pan. Or they shorten a ladder because it is too long to carry between trees.
1217
1225-The Man without a HeadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA rogue’s (numskull’s) head is cut off by accident (bitten off by a bear, wolf, or crocodile while hunting, torn off in a mill, smashed off by a rock, caught in tree branches). His compan-ions find the corpse without a head & debate: Did he ever have a head?. They remember only his beard. His wife knows that she once knitted a cap for him (that the barber often came to shave him), & he therefore must have had a head.
1218
1225AHow Did the Cow Get on the Pole?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in two dif fer ent forms: (1) A student (often the son of a farmer) comes home from the university for a visit. Lying in bed, he wonders how cow-dung could get on the roof. His father informs him that the beam was already dirty when it was installed. (2) (On advice of a rascal) a fool (fools) hide(s) a purse on top of a pole (in a nest on a high tree). The rascal substitutes dry cow-dung for the money. The fool is interested only in how the cow could have climbed the pole.
1219
1227-Catching the squirrelAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTwo numskulls (men or women) plan to catch a squirrel. One pursues it while the other runs back home to get a pan (a pot). The first falls from a tree (and is killed). The face of the first is covered with blood from the fall & the second thinks that his companion has eaten the raw squirrel & choked on it. Full of anger, he breaks the pot (on his head).
1220
1228-Firing a GunAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A fool looks down the barrel as a gun is fired (2) Two fools mistake a gun for a flute. They decide that one will blow it while the other will press the “keys”. The gun goes off & shoots off the head of the “flutist”. (3) Fools fire a wooden gun which explodes & kills several of them. They rejoice that the enemy has suffered an even greater loss.
1221
1229-If the Wolf's Tail BreaksAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTrickster & companion go wolf (bear) hunting. One slips into the wolf’s den. When the wolf returns, the man outside catches him by the tail. The wolf scratches the earth so that dust gets into the companion’s eyes. “What a lot of dust.” – “If the wolf’s tail breaks, you will see quite another kind of dust!”. In some variants, the trickster in the den asks, “Why is it so dark in here?” – “If the tail breaks, you will know.”
1222
1229*Shoveling Nuts with a PitchforkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls try to shovel nuts with a pitchfork. A stranger shows them how to do this work more easily with a shovel (a basket). (He gets a large reward.)
1223
1230*The Pilgrimage VowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA woman on a pilgrimage accidentally disarranges her skirt (and shirt), exposing her naked buttocks. Her husband does not say anything to her about this because he thinks this is part of her pilgrimage vow.
1224
1230**Rebuke for Going with Naked HeadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA woman, having been criticized for walking in the street with her head uncovered, covers it with her skirt & thus exposes her buttocks.
1225
1231-The Attack on the Rabbit (Crayfish)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesSeven (nine) men plan to attack the fierce animal. One of them screams from fear & the animal runs away.
1226
1238-The Roof in Good & Bad WeatherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man does not build a roof on his house (does not repair it): He does not need a roof when the weather is fair; & he cannot put one on in the rain.
1227
1240-Cutting Off the BranchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool sitting on a branch of a tree cuts it off. In a Greek version, he climbs with difficulty onto a dead branch of a tree, which breaks off.
1228
1241-The Tree is to be Pulled DownAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools (numskulls) pity a tree (usually a willow) that stands near a pond & hangs its branches down as if it wants to drink. They pull it down in order to give it water. One man sticks his head in the branches while the others pull on his legs. In some variants, they tear his head off, in others, they all fall down.
1229
1241APulling Out the TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls (a fool & his donkey) try to pull out a tree that stands on a cliff. The tree falls & drags them down with it. In some variants, fools fell a tree so that it will fall directly onto a wagon. The tree breaks the wagon & kills the horse (the ox).
1230
1242-Loading WoodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool loads wood piece by piece into a wagon saying, “If the horses (oxen) can pull this, they can pull one more piece”. When he finally finds that they are unable to pull the load, he throws off piece after piece, reasoning, “If they cannot pull this, they cannot pull one less”. He drives home with an empty wagon. (In some Finnish variants, the foolish person is female.
1231
1242ARelief for the DonkeyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesInstead of placing a sack of flour (some other load) on the donkey’s (ox’s) back, a rider puts it on his shoulder to relieve the animal of its burden. In some variants a man puts a load on one side of a saddle & balances it on the other side with a rock.
1232
1243-Wood is Carried Down the HillAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools carry a heavy tree trunk (millstone) down a hill. On the way, they drop the trunk & it rolls the rest of the way down. When they notice that the job is much easier this way, they carry the trunk back up the hill in order to roll it down again.
1233
1244-Trying to Stretch the BeamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools are given a beam (pole, footbridge, bench) which is too short. They try in different ways to stretch the beam. Of course they do not succeed, but in a German variant they think they do.
1234
1245-Sunlight carried in a bag into the windowless houseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools collect sunlight in a sack (basket, sieve) & try to carry it into a windowless house. When this plan does not succeed, fools gradually pull down the house in order to get light. (A stranger shows them how to make a window.) In some variants, fools use a white sheepskin as a source of light or try to catch light in a mouse trap. Similarly, fools carry out smoke in a sieve.
1235
1246-Axes Thrown AwayAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool lets his axe fall. The other people think that this was intentional & throw theirs into the same place. This short episode is usually followed by a second one, in which the fools try to cut down trees in different ways: (1) By burning them down: In order to get fire, one fool beats another’s head so that the latter will see sparks. (2) By pulling them out: One fool sticks his head in the branches, the others pull & tear his head off.
1236
1247-The Man Sticks His Head into the Hole of the MillstoneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools want to roll a millstone down a hill. One of them sticks his head into the hole of the millstone in order to lead it (to see where it rolls). It rolls into a lake. The fool’s head is torn off.
1237
1248-Tree-Trunks Laid Crosswise on a SledgeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools want to trans-port a stack of wood (a long tree-trunk). They lay it crosswise on a sledge (a wagon) & cannot get out of the forest (through a gate). Only when they see a bird passing by carrying a blade of straw side-ways do find the solution for their problem.
1238
1250-The Human ChainAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools want to measure the depth of a well (retrieve something from the water). They lay a log across its top. One man holds the log with his hands, the next climbs down & holds his feet, & so on. The uppermost man becomes tired & lets go to spit in his hands. All fall into the well. In some variants, the human chain is built in order to reach the top of a tree. In an Indian/Sri Lankan version, the human chain (a chain of monkeys) dangles from the tail of a flying elephant.
1239
1250AHampers Pilled Up to Measure TowerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools place baskets one on top of the other in order to measure the height of a tower. The one at the bottom is removed & all fall. In some variants numskulls want to reach a bird’s nest (an animal’s den) in a high tree. They climb on each other’s shoulders. When the fool at the bottom falls down, all the others fall too.
1240
1255-A Hole to Throw the Earth InAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskull(s) plan(s) to dig a hole so as to have a place to throw the soil from his excavations.
1241
1260-Porridge in the Ice HoleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) Numskulls put flour (rolled oats) into the bubbling current of an ice hole & then, one after another, jump in to taste the porridge. They die. (2) Numskulls buy a kettle that is supposed to boil by itself. It does not work so & they throw it into the water. As the kettle sinks down it sends up bubbles. Thinking that the kettle is finally boiling, the numskulls jump into the water to retrieve it. (3) A woman puts flour in a river (sugar in a well) in order to make dough for bread (lemonade). She loses it all (and her husband throws her out).
1242
1260**Jumping into the Sea for FishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull jumps into the sea (into a lake) to catch fish.
1243
1260ARabbit SoupAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls throw a rabbit (crab, locust, sparrow) into boil-ing water in order to make soup. The animal escapes. Later the num-skulls drink the water & maintain that they have good soup. In some variants the “soup” is made from (1) the shadow of an animal (rooster, chicken) that falls on a kettle of water, (2) a rabbit that runs through a puddle (gets drowned in a river) or by ducks that swim on a pond, (3) water from washing hands (washing out bas kets) that were in contact with meat or fish.
1244
1260B*Numskull Strikes All Matches in Order to Try ThemAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA farmhand is sent to buy the best matches. To make sure that the matches will burn he lights them all to try them out.
1245
1262-The Effectiveness of FireAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThe elabor-ate form of this type consists of several events: A rich man (ruler) promises a reward to anyone who can survive a cold night on the roof of the palace naked. A poor (foreign) man agrees to this proposal & survives the frosty night. In the morning the ruler refuses to give the poor man the reward, claiming that he had used a distant fire (the moonlight) to warm himself. On the advice of a wise man, the poor man invites the ruler to a meal. He puts the pot so far away from the fire that the food cannot cook. When his guests demand an explanation, he explains that the pot will be heated as he himself was warmed by the distant fire. The ruler pays the reward. This tale also exists in a short form: A numskull pretends to roast (believes he is roasting) meat: The fire burns on one shore of a lake, the meat is on the other.
1246
1262*Spitting into PorridgeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIn order to find out whether it is hot, a smith spits on a horseshoe. A fool who observed him spits into the porridge (soup) to test its temperature.
1247
1263-The Porridge Eaten in Different RoomsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools sit together in a room & eat porridge. Every time they want a spoonful of milk (cream, honey) to eat with their porridge, they go into the room (cellar) where the milk is. A stranger tells them to put a jug of milk on the table.
1248
1264*The Boiling of the Porridge PotAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMistaking the sound of boiling, a woman who is cooking porridge thinks the pot is complaining to her a fool thinks the porridge is calling him).
1249
1265*Two for the Price of OneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool sells two fox skins rolled together for the price of one. In some variants a female knife-dealer tries to “cheat” her famous guest by selling a knife at half price.
1250
1266*A Third for One-FourthAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool sells a third of a cask of grain for the price of a fourth. In some variants buyers boast of their “cleverness”: They payed a higher price than the seller asked.
1251
1268*Electing a MayorAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: Numskulls want to elect a mayor. (1) The applicant who is able to make a short rhyme will be elected . All fail except the pigherd. (2) All candidates sit around a table & lay their beards on it. A louse is put into the middle. The man into whose beard the louse crawls will be elected. (3) The wives of the candidates have to undress & to put their heads into a haystack. Whoever is able to recognize his wife from her backside will become mayor. Various signals, either prearranged or accidental, affect the outcome. (In recent variants the parts are changed: The women have to recognize their husbands by their naked backsides.) (4) The winner of a footrace will become mayor. A calf crosses the finish line first, winning the race.
1252
1270-The Drying of the CandleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull lays wet (recently manufactured) candles on (in) the stove to dry. They melt. In a Japanese version, numskulls mistake a candle for food & try to cook it. It melts.
1253
1271A*Warming the Stove with WoolAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAn (old) foolish woman (maid) tries to warm her house with wool, which she burns in a stove. In some variants, the woman tries to warm the stove by putting a burning candle into it. In a Livonian version, yarn is tied around the stove so that the heat will not escape.
1254
1271C*Cloak Given to a StoneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA foolgives a cloak to a stone in order to keep it warm. In some variants, a trembling tree is covered with cloth, a stump is covered with a cap, or stone Buddhas are protected by straw hats from snow & rain.
1255
1272*Drying Snow on the StoveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull dries snow on a stove (water in the sun). In a Mexican version, a numskull carries ice cream in his pocket, where it melts. He thinks that he has been cheated.
1256
1273A*Bailing Out the StreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull comes to a stream & sits down to wait for the stream to run down so his feet will not get wet. Finally he tries to bail out the water out of the stream with a hazelnut shell, & keeps working for months. In a Cambodian version, a married couple wants to bail out the sea in order to get the treasures of sunken ships. Fish deliver gold & silver to the couple to make them stop bailing.
1257
1275-Sledges TurnedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls turn their sledges (wagons, shoes) in the direction of their journey. At night a joker turns the sledges around. The numskulls do not notice the trick & drive (go) back home. They do not recognize their own town.
1258
1275*Travelers Lose Their WayAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskull(s) lose(s) their (his) way & get(s) turned around. They find themselves back home. (They do not recognize themselves & ask their wives where their husbands are.)
1259
1276-Rowing without going forwardAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTwo women (men) row in opposite directions. They make no progress at all. (To solve the problem, they take out the plug at the bottom of the boat, so that one is obliged to baile out the water.) In some variants numskulls row a boat which is tied up.
1260
1276*Prayer for a Change of WindAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAn old woman walking (rowing) against the wind prays for it to change. The wind changes & she must walk against it on her return.
1261
1278-Marking the place on the boatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAn object falls into the sea from a boat. Numskull(s) mark(s) the place on the boatrail (place a sign on the water) to indicate where it fell. In some variants, numskull(s) mark a good fishing spot by a sign on the bottom of their boat, seek the ears of grain in the direction of the cloud that marks where they had sowed the grain, or hide money in the ground, taking the moon (a cloud) overhead as a mark.
1262
1281-Getting Rid of the Unknown AnimalAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesPeople who have never seen a cat (owl) buy one to free them from a plague of mice. The cat eats many mice & the people are afraid that it might eat them, too. So they decide to kill the cat but cannot catch it. They finally set the house on fire.
1263
1281AGetting Rid of the Man-Eating CalfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man who likes the shoes on the feet of a man hanging from the gallows, cuts off the swollen feet in order to carry off the shoes. In the room where he sleeps that night there is a newborn calf. The next morning the man takes the shoes but leaves the feet (he leaves the feet in the shoes). The people in the house think that the calf has eaten the man all but the feet. They kill the calf (burn the house to destroy the calf). In some variants, a cat (tom cat) is supposed to be a maneater.
1264
1282-House Burned Down to Rid It of InsectsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools burn down a house (tree) to rid it of insects (rats, crows, owl). In some variants, a garden (meadow) is paved to keep out moles.
1265
1284-Person Does Not Know HimselfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesWhile a foolish man (farmer, numskulls) sleeps, someone modifies his appearance (puts a cap on his head, cuts his beard or hair off, dresses him in new clothes, takes away a significant object, etc.). When the fool wakes up, he does not know himself or mistakes himself for someone else.
1266
1284*Forcing the HenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesForcing the Hen to brood her chickens. A foolish woman forces a hen to keep her chicks underneath her so that it is not possible for the hawk to steal them.
1267
1284AWhite Man Made to Beleive He is BlackAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA white man who wants to stay in an inn overnight has to share his bed with a black man. While the white guest is sleeping, the host blackens his face. When the white man gets up in the morning & sees his dark face in a mirror, he thinks that the host has awakened the black man instead of him.
1268
1284BMan Needs Patch on Pants to Recognize HimselfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man (fool) recognizes himself by some peculiar sign (patch on his trousers, ribbon around his hand or foot, flask on his belt, etc). Without this sign, he cannot tell himself from other people (he becomes confused when he meets someone else with the same sign).
1269
1284C"You, Or Your Brother?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool meets two people & asks one of them, “Are you you or your brother?”. In other versions the fool asks which is the man & which is the woman. Or he meets a man & asks him, “Was it you who died recently, or your brother?”
1270
1285-Pulling on the ShirtAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA foolish woman has sewn a shirt for her husband (son) without a hole for the head. She tries to beat the shirt over the man’s head, or she cuts his head off so that the shirt can be put on him.
1271
1286-Jumping into the BreechesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool does not know how to pull on his breeches. He jumps down from a high place (e.g. rafters, tree) while his wife (another fool) keeps the breeches open (the breeches are hung up from hooks). (A stranger explains how to pull on the breeches & usually is rewarded.) In some variants, a child wears trousers with one leg (baby is wrapped in one piece of cloth). Therefore it cannot stand & seems to be crippled.
1272
1287-Numskull unable to count their own numberAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls go swimming & then want to find out if everyone is back. The fools cannot get the right result because whoever counts forgets to count himself. They conclude that one of them is drowned. A stranger who finds the numskulls in distress tells them to stick their noses in the sand (loam) & to count the holes. So they confirm that everyone is still alive.
1273
1288-Numskiulls Cannot Find Their Own LegsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls (wearing trousers or stockings of the same color, being drunk) fall down in a crowd (sit side by side swinging their legs). When they want to stand up they cannot find their own legs. A stranger helps the numskulls by whipping (striking) their legs. In some variants, a fool’s boots are stolen while he is drunk. He does not recognize his feet without boots.
1274
1288**The Long NoseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man runs in the dark holding his arms stretched out in front of him. He hits his nose on a ladder (the edge of an open door). He is surprised that his nose seems to be longer than his arms.
1275
1288ANumskull Cannot Find the Donkey He is Sitting OnAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull counting his donkeys (horses, camels) forgets to count the one he is sitting on. When he dismounts he always has one donkey more than when he sits on one of the animals. (He decides to walk rather than to lose one donkey.)
1276
1288BThe Stolen DonkeyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool thanks God that he was not sitting on the donkey when it was stolen.
1277
1289-Each Wants to Sleep in the MiddleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesEach of three (two) numskulls wants to sleep in the middle. They do not know how to manage this & finally lie down head to head (feet to feet).
1278
1290-Swimming in the Flax-fieldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls (a foolish man or woman) mistake a waving blue field of flax for the sea (a lake, river). They take off their clothes & jump in for a swim.
1279
1290B*Sleeping on a FeatherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull who has slept on a feather (piece of straw) during the night finds himself completely sore & stiff in the morning. He wonders how anyone could stand to sleep on a featherbed (straw mattress).
1280
1291-One Cheese Sent to Bring Back AnotherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA foolish woman loses a cheese which falls & rolls down a hill. She sends a second cheese (the other ones) to bring back the first.
1281
1291AThree-legged Pot Sent to Walk HomeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls buy a three-legged pot (spinning wheel, tripod) at the market. They try to send it home reasoning that, since it has three legs, it can walk home more easily & quickly than a two-legged man. In some variants, a four-legged table is sent home.
1282
1291BFilling the Cracks with ButterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA foolish woman (man) sees cracks in the ground (house wall) & feels sorry for them. She greases them with the butter she is taking home (to the market).
1283
1291DOther Objects or Animals sent to Go by ThemselvesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool Storiese.g. food (peas, flour) or animals (donkey, cow, pig, billy goat, hare). In the most popular version, a rabbit is sent to pay the rent. The foolish farmers hang a purse with money on him & often give him a tip in addition.
1284
1292*Etiquette of a GuestAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA married daughter visiting her mother will not stop a hog from rooting in the garden since she is a guest in the house. In some variants, a young wife, having been told how to behave “properly”, says “sir” to the dog as well as to the grandfather.
1285
1293-A Long PissAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull (drunken man) who is urinating outside misunderstands the noise of a flowing stream (well, falling rain) & thinks he has not finished yet. He keeps standing there for hours (more than a day).
1286
1293*Learning to SwimAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool almost drowns when swimming. He swears never to go into the water again unless he has already learned how to swim.
1287
1293A*Woman Breaks All Her DishesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA foolish woman buys several earthenware pots (dishes). She sets the pots on a fence. When they refuse to make room for the last pot, she breaks them all. (When the woman does not have enough room in her kitchen, she nails the crockery to the wall.)
1288
1293B*Head in the WaterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man tied to a floating log turns over so that his head is in the water & he is almost drowned. His comrades on the shore say, “He has not yet crossed the water & is already drying his legs”.
1289
1293C*The Wrong DoorAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIn the night, a man urinates outside through a door (wants to know what the weather is).
