Someone inside asks him how the weather is. He answers, “The sky is overcast & it smells like bread (there are no stars)”. He had opened the door to the pantry (cellar) by mistake.
1290
1294-Getting the Calf's Head out of the PotAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA calf (camel, ox, sheep, dog) gets its head caught in a pot (jar). On advice of a fool, the calf’s head is cut off & then the pot is broken to get the head out.
1291
1294A*Child with Head Caught in JarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA child (woman) gets her head caught in a jar (glass). A fool advises that the child’s head be cut off, but people prefer to break the jar. In some variants, a jar has to be broken because a foolish (greedy) woman (girl, child) cannot get her hand out of the narrow opening. She has made a fist to hold on to some contents of the jar.
1292
1295-The Seventh Cake SatisfiesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool regrets that he did not eat (drink) the seventh cake (various other kinds of food or beverages) first, since that was the one that brought him satisfaction. In some cases, the eating is part of a contest.
1293
1295A*Tall Bridegroom Cannot Get into ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA very tall bridegroom (bride) does not fit through the door of the church (her home). His foolish attendants argue whether to cut off his head or to pull down the door. A stranger hits him on his back & the bridegroom falls down. Now he can enter & the stranger gets a reward. In some variants, a man (woman) riding on a camel (horse) does not fit through a gate. The doorway is broken down. (A stranger advises him to dismount.)
1294
1296-Fool's ErrandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool (apprentice) is sent out to get imaginary things, e.g. a left-handed monkey wrench, a bag of lies.
1295
1296AFools Go to Buy Good WeatherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool Stories(storm, spring). They bring back a bumblebee, (hornet, butterfly, swarm of bees) in a box (sack). They become curious & open the box before they reach home. The good weather flies away.
1296
1296BDoves in the LetterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool is to take two doves (crayfish, eels, bunches of grapes, gingerbread) in a basket to a farmer, along with an explanatory letter. On the way the doves escape (the fool eats the food). The farmer reads the letter & asks, “Where are the two doves that are in the letter?” – “They escaped from the basket. It’s lucky they are still in the letter.”In some variants a servant (girl) is sent to bring a basket of fruit along with a letter. On the way, he eats one of the fruits. The letter states how much fruit there was, so the recipient asks the servant what happened to one of the pieces. He replies that it was not in the basket. He is sent again on the same errand the following day. He hides the letter before he eats the fruit, because he thinks it can observe him.
1297
1297*Jumping Into the River After Their ComradeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA Fool (fools) jump(s) into a river (sea, well) in order to cross the water (get imaginary sheep from the bottom, commit suicide). The fool’s comrades think that he wants them to follow, & all jump in & are drowned. In some variants, someone else makes the fools jump.
1298
1305-Miser & His GoldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) Instead of asking for his wages from a miser, a workman asks to be allowed to see the miser’s treasure. When asked why, he explains that this would give him the same satisfaction as it gives the miser. The latter repents & distributes his wealth among the poor. (2) A miser, whose treasure has been stolen, is advised to imagine that it is still intact; he will thus get as much pleasure from it as before. (3) A miser, wishing to take his gold to the grave with him, orders it to be melted so that he can drink it. Molten butter is substituted, & the miser is duped. (4) Even in grave danger or on his deathbed, the miser thinks about how to make or save money. (5) A miser is robbed while lying on his sickbed, or his hoard is found after his death.
1299
1306-Miser Refuses to Give his HandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA miser (clergyman, drunken man) falls into a well. Men hurry to rescue him (with a rope) & tell him to reach out his hand. He refuses. A wise man advises them not to ask for the hand of the miser but to propose him that he take their hands. The man seizes their hands & is rescued.
1300
1309-Choosing the Clean FigsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFrom figs (melons) which have been urinated on, a fool is to choose only the clean ones. In testing he eats them all.
1301
1310-Drowning the crayfish as punishmentAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A small water animal (e.g. turtle, crayfish, toad) has made an enemy of a big land animal (e.g. monkey, fox, lion, elephant) or of a man. The small animal, condemned to death, begs not to be drowned. Thereupon it is thrown into the water & escapes. (2) Numskulls find a crayfish. Because of its claws, the fools mistake the unknown animal for a tailor & put it on a piece of cloth which it is to cut up. The crayfish ruins the cloth. He is condemned to be drowned & is thrown into the water. When the animal swims with difficulty, one of the fools says, “See how it suffers”. (3) Numskulls set out pickled herrings in their pond & hope the fishes will propagate. When the fools drain the pond, they find a big eel which they suspect has devoured the herrings. As a punish ment the eel is to be drowned.
1302
1310*The Crab is Thought to be the DevilAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls find a crab (snail). They mistake the unknown animal for the devil (land-monster).
1303
1310ABriar-Patch Punishment for RabbitAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA rabbit (fox, jackal), who has stolen food, is caught & is to be punished. It pretends to be afraid of being thrown into a briar patch & thus induces its captor to do just that. The rabbit runs off.
1304
1310BBurying the Mole as PunishmentAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls catch a mole which has devastated a meadow (field, garden). They consider how to punish the unknown animal & decide to bury it alive. The mole escapes.
1305
1310CThrowing the Bird from a Cliff as PunishmentAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA captured bird (insect) which is to be punished for some misbehavior (e.g. stealing grain, stinging) pretends to be afraid of being thrown into an abyss. The man (animal) who caught the bird throws it down from a cliff (tower) & the bird flies away.
1306
1311-The Wolf Taken for a FoalAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThe wolf is mistaken for a foal (shepherd’s dog, the luck). In the man’s absence the wolf eats a mare (parts of the flock, horse).
1307
1312-The Bear Taken for a DogAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA bear is mistaken for a dog. In some variants, the dog is mistaken for a bear (wolf) (and killed).
1308
1312*Trying to WAsh Black Animal WhiteAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull tries to wash a black hen white because a customer wants to buy a white one. In some variants, numskulls try to wash a black bull white so that it will match the white cows. (They wash or paint their only bull in order to pretend that they own more than one.)
1309
1313-The Man Who Wanted to Commit SuicideAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A fool has been told by his mother (wife) to perform various tasks. He fails & decides to kill himself. Remembering a pot full of food (beverage) which his mother said was poisoned, he eats (drinks) all of it & lies down as if dead. (2) A master (priest) tells his apprentice (novice) not to eat (drink) from a pot full of food (beverage) which he says is poisoned. The apprentice disregards the warning & nibbles at the attractive food. He defends himself by pretending that he wanted to commit suicide.
1310
1313AThe Man Takes Seriously the Prediction of DeathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA passerby tells a numskull who is sawing the tree limb on which he is sitting that he will fall. When the fool falls, he believes the passerby to be a prophet & demands that he might tell him when he will die. The “prophet” tells him that he will die(1) when his donkey (horse) breaks wind three times, (2) when his hands & feet become cold, (3) when a red thread or the like comes from his body, (4) other signs. The prophesied event occurs & the fool thinks he is dead. When his pallbearers or passersby argue over which road to take, the fool sits up & advises them, “When I was alive, I took that one”.
1311
1313A*In the Open GraveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA drunken man falls into an open grave & lies down to sleep. When he wakes up, he thinks he is dead. In some variants, a fool hides from soldiers (robbers) in an open grave. When they ask him what he is doing there he tells them that he is dead. (After the “dead man” is beaten by the soldiers, he returns home to warn his friends to avoid soldiers in the other world.)
1312
1313B*The Cold GraveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA drunken man walking through a graveyard at night falls into an open grave. Someone finds him there (another drunk falls into the same grave), & the first man complains about how cold it is. “No wonder”, says the second man. “You pushed off the covers (earth)”; or, “you don’t have your shroud”.
1313
1313C*Not Yet DeadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool Storiesdoctor at the bedside of a sick man tells him that he is practically dead. The patient argues that he is not dead yet. His wife (someone else) tells him to be quiet, the doctor knows best.
1314
1314-Mistaking Harmless Objects for Dangerous OnesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools mistake a butter churn for a dead man (the devil). They break it in two. In some variants, numskulls mistake a big tree for a snake (tree trunk for a devil or bear, big sausage for a dragon, bag full of rags for a bear, etc.). They try to kill the dangerous object with guns or spears.
1315
1315*The Steamship Thought to be the DevilAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls mistake a steamship for the devil. In some variants, a drunken man mistakes a train (bicycle) for the devil, refuses to get out of its way & is hurt.
1316
1315**A White Mare Thought to be a ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA short-sighted man (foolish woman, numskulls who have never seen a church but have been told that it is big & white) mistakes a white mare for a church.
1317
1316-Mistaking One Animal for AnotherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) A foolish farmhand who has been sent out to bring in cows (sheep) thinks that the rabbits running among them are part of the herd. (2) Numskulls mistake an earthworm for a snake (monster) or a frog for a lark (turtledove). (3) Numskulls (a hunter) mistake a donkey for a rabbit because of its long ears & kill it. (4) A fool mistakes a dungbeetle for a bee (5) Storks are mistaken for cows.
1318
1317-The Blind Men & The ElephantAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFour blind men feel an elephant’s leg, tail, ear, & body respectively, & conclude that the elephant is like a log, a rope, a fan, or something without beginning or end.
1319
1318-Mistaking a Person (Animal, Object) for a Supernatural BeingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesBesides this general type, three specific versions can be distinguished: (1) A person (animal) who is hiding in a church (graveyard, hearse) is mistaken for a ghost (death). (2) A fool mistakes overflowing dough for a ghost. (3) A person in a haunted house shoots off all his toes because he mistakes them for ghosts.
1320
1319-Pumpkin Sold as a Donkey's EggAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull (numskulls) finds (buys) an unknown fruit (pumpkin, melon, etc.). He mistakes it for the egg of a donkey (mare, camel, etc.). When the fool tries to bring the “egg” home it falls down & scares a hidden rabbit (rabbit, fox, mouse). The fool thinks the fugitive is a young animal hatched from the egg. He pursues it or tries to attract it.
1321
1319*Other Mistaken IdentitiesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type. One person (animal, thing, process) is mistaken for another.
1322
1319A*The Watch Mistaken for the Devil's EyeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools find a ticking watch lying in the street. They mistake it for a devil’s (dragon’s) eye or an animal & break it to pieces.
1323
1319G*Boot Mistaken for an Axe SheathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesNumskulls find a boot & wonder what it could be. The cleverest of them declares it to be an axe sheath.
1324
1319H*Boat Believed to Have Had a ChildAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool sees a small rowboat which is tied to a bigger boat & believes it to be its child.
1325
1319J*Fool Eats Beetle Thinking It is a Blueberry with WingsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIn some variants, a frog (toad) is mistaken for a fig (plum, pear).
1326
1319P*Devil's ShitAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool thinks that a black man (chimney sweep) is the devil, & that his excrement must be devil’s dreck (asa foetida, a medicine).
1327
1320*Fish-EAting IconAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool loses fish from a torn bag. He thinks that the icon which he carried together with the fish has eaten them. The fool breaks the icon.
1328
1321-Fools frightenedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type with diverse variants.
1329
1321AFright at the Creaking of a Wheelbarrow/ MillAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man is frightened by the creaking of a wheelbarrow (mill), or a guest is afraid of the cracking of a rooftree.
1330
1321BFools Afraid of their Own ShadowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools are afraid of their own shadow.
1331
1321CFools are Frightened at the Humming of BeesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThey think they hear a drum announcing the attack of their enemies.
1332
1321DPickling the GrandmotherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA farmer’s grandmother (mother-in-law) who lives with him has died. When the farmer sends the farmhand (boy) for half a sack of salt, he runs away. The explanation: all the animals that die on the farm have to be salted so they can be eaten.
1333
1321D*The Ticking of a Clock Thought to be the Gnawing of MiceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA young country man (woman) hears a clock ticking & mistakes it for the gnawing of mice.
1334
1322-Words in a Foreign Language Thought to be InsultsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAn ignorant man (woman) mistakes polite words from a foreign language (e.g. pardon, merci) for insults (he gets a wrong translation of these words from a jester). In some variants, the insults in a foreign language are misinter-preted as polite remarks.
1335
1322A*Grunting PigAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool thinks that a grunting pig is calling his name. In some variants, the croaking of a frog (singing of a bird) is misunderstood.
1336
1323-The Windmill Thought to be a Holy CrossAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools (an ignorant man) see a windmill & do not know what it is. They mistake the mill for a Holy Cross (church), the miller for a priest & the guests from the inn for saints. In some variants, they kneel down for a prayer & are hurt by the working mill.
1337
1324*The Man behind the CrucifixAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThe Man behind the Crucifix says “Good evening” to a drunk passerby. The drunk man thus thinks Christ is speaking to him.
1338
1324A*Crucifix PunishedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesVillagers ask a carver to make them a crucifix & to shape the crucified as an image not of a dead body but of a living man. In the night, after the crucifix has been set up, a hail storm devastates the fields. When the villagers seek the reason, the clergyman tells them that, being able to see, the crucified man recognized their sins & sent the hail storm as a punishment. The villagers thereupon shoot out the eyes of the crucified statue & obliterate his face.
1339
1325-Moving the Wrong ObjectAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools try to solve a problem by moving the wrong object (e.g. mountain, island, house).
1340
1325*Bird's Dung Falls on Record BooksAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesIn a town so much birds’ dung falls from the trees that it becomes a problem. Finally the municipal council decides to banish the birds from the town. When the mayor reads the order of banishment in front of the townhall, a bird flies over his head & drops something onto the recordbook. The angry mayor looks up & shouts, “And you may never ever come back to this place again!”
1341
1325AFireplace Gives Too Much HeatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool Storiesn wintertime some farmers sit around an oven (in an inn). Soon the heat becomes so strong that they sweat & even their clothes burn. Looking for a solution, they finally decide to move the oven (to throw cold peat on the fire). (They ask the innkeeper to move the oven. He sends them outside & moves meanwhile their chairs. When they come back into the room again, they are persuaded that he has moved the oven with much force.)
1342
1325BMoving the Church Away from the DungAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesOn the way to church a clergyman notices that one of his congregation (cow, dog) is relieving himself at the church wall. He is angry & shouts that such a stench near the church is an offence to God. He forgets the service & runs to tell the mayor what happened. The municipal council is convocated & they decide, on the advice of the altar boys, to use a robe to pull the church with a robe away from the dirt. When the men pull, tear the altar boy, as their leaders, pretending to take the leadership stays behind the church. Each time they pull, he secretly shovels the dirt farther away from the church. When the clergyman sees the result he believes that the church has been moved from the dirt. Satisfied & in good con-science, he can officiates at the service.
1343
1326-Moving the churchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools want to move (expand) their church (town hall). As a mark they put down a coat (jacket). While the fools push hard together against the wall, the coat is stolen by a stranger. When the fools see that the coat has disappeared, they feel happy about how far they have moved the church.
1344
1326BMoving the Large StoneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFools want to move a large stone (rock, island). They tie a rope to it & pull (try to pull it by a boat). The rope breaks & all the fools fall down (into water).
1345
1327-Emptying the Flour SackAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTwo fools are arguing. To convince them of the nonsense of their quarrel, a third fool empties his sack of flour (pot of oil) with the words, “There is as much flour in my sack as wit in your two heads”.
1346
1327AFool Reenacts His Case in CourtAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool explains how the pig was kicked to death & causes the judge to play the part of the pig. In some variants, a foolish woman illustrates how a pot was accidentally broken by smashing a second one.
1347
1328*Letting Milk Boil OverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool is to take care of the boiling milk. He feels happy when the milk rises thinking he will get more. When the milk boils over, he finally gets nothing. In some variants, while the boiling milk is rising, a fool prays to God to give him more. When the milk boils over, he is dissatisfied with God.
1348
1328A*Oversalting the SoupAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesEach member of the family puts salt into the soup not knowing that it has been already salted.
1349
1328B*New TrousersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man complains that his new trousers are made too long. Without knowing what the others did, each woman of his household cuts off a piece so that the trousers finally are much too short.
1350
1330-Extinguishing the Burning BoatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesPeople row to land & fetch water from a spring to put out the fire. In a Persian version, a foolish girl walks with a burning candle in her hand to get fire.
1351
1331-The Covetous & the EnviousAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesGod (angel, saint, ruler) tries to reconcile a covetous man & an envious one (two hostile neighbors): Whatever one of them wishes, the other shall receive double. The covetous one, hoping to get the double price, gives the envious one the opportunity to wish first. The envious one wants to have one of his eyes removed. In some variants, the actors are two animals (three men).
1352
1331*IlliteratesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis type comprises various anecdotes about people who are not (hardly) able to read (write). Within This misc. type, two versions can be distinguished: (1) A boy cannot read a book because the letters are smaller than in his schoolbook. (2) A fool writes a letter very slowly because the recipient cannot read fast.
1353
1331A*Buying SpectaclesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAn illiterate person believes that he can immediately read (write) when he buys spectacles (pen). In some variants, a man gets a letter written in a foreign language (Turkish). He thinks that a well-dressed stranger (stranger with a big turban) must be able to read it. The stranger proposes to change their clothes (give him his turban) so that the owner of the letter can read it himself.
1354
1331D*Teaching LatinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA person (rogue, robber, Jew, fool) wants to learn Latin (French, singing). The “teacher” cuts off (the tip of) his tongue or orders him to lick cold iron so that the pupil injures himself.
1355
1332-Which is the Greatest Fool?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA passerby salaams to or tosses a coin to two (three, four) men. They ask him for whom it was intended. He says he meant it for the greatest fool. Each tells a tale of his own foolishness to prove he is the greatest: (a) Who will speak first. (b) The hungry fool at his in-laws – cheeks cut. The fool goes to visit his parents-in-law and, being bashful, refuses to eat. Later he stuffs eggs, etc., into his mouth only to be discovered by his mother-in-law who calls a surgeon. The surgeon believes the fool’s cheeks are abcessed & cuts them open. (c) The fool at his in-laws – falls into well. The bashful fool dresses as a beggar to visit his parents-in-law. When his mother-in-law comes out of the house to give him food, he backs away & tumbles into a well, etc. (d) The hungry fool at his in-laws – the priest beaten. (e) Other tales about fools. The passerby (king, judge) chooses the winner (all are judged as equally foolish).
1356
1332*Forgetfulness (Aimlessness) Causes Useless JourneyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesWithin This misc. type, four versions can be distinguished: (1) Fools forget to borrow a horse until their journey is almost over. They return for it. (2) Fools forget to greet the hostess of the inn. They return. (3) As the fool starts for the doctor his wife tells him that she is not ill anymore. The fool nevertheless wants to go to the doctor to tell him that now he need not come. (4) A fool who is away from home writes a letter to his wife but cannot find a messenger. He delivers the letter himself & then goes back to where he was.
1357
1333-The Shepherd who Cried "Wolf!" too oftenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA shepherd (Gypsy, woodcutter) repeatedly makes fun by crying that a wolf (tiger, lion, panther, robber) is attacking his herd. He laughs when the farmers approach in haste to help. When the wolf really comes, no one be-lieves the shepherd’s cries & he looses his sheep.
1358
1334-The Local MoonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A traveling man (woman) is surprised to see that the moon elsewhere is the same as at home (watches a half-moon & is proud of their full moon at home; he thinks he sees his own moon so he must be near his home). (2) A traveler in a strange place (a resident leaving his home, not knowing whether it is day or night) asks a passenger whether the star in the sky is the sun or the moon. The passenger answers, “I don’t know. I’m a stranger in this town.”
1359
1334*The Old Moon & the StairsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA scholar is asked by an ignorant man (shepherd) what happens to the old moon when the new moon comes. The scholar tells him that old moons are broken into pieces & made into stars (lightning). In some variants, people think the old moon cuts pieces from the stars & comes back as the new moon.
1360
1334**Two SunsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA farmhand (two farmhands) is sent to guard pigs, & is told to come home when the sun goes down. When the sun sets, the moon rises. The farmhand goes home, saying, “The devil can guard the pigs! When one sun goes down, the other comes up.”Or, he continues to work on, believing there are two suns.
1361
1335-The Swallowed MoonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool watches his cow (donkey, mare) drinking from a pool where the moon is reflected in the water. When the moon hides behind a cloud, the fool thinks that the cow has swallowed the moon. He tells his wife (other fools) what has happened & they decide to slaughter the cow in order to recover the moon. However, they cannot find the moon in the cow’s belly & regret having killed their poor cow in vain.
1362
1335*Setting Sun (Rising Sun) Mistaken for FireAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThe fire service (a night watchman) sounds a fire alarm. When the villagers crowd together it turns out that sunlight (moonlight, northern lights) had been mistaken for fire.
1363
1335ACatching the MoonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A numskull sees the moon reflected in a pond (well) & supposes it has fallen in. He calls his companions in order to rescue the moon. One of them throws a rope (net) into the pond, pulls, but falls in himself (together they try to rake out the moon). Lying on his back, the numskull sees the moon in the sky & thinks they have saved it. (2) Numskulls want to catch the moon in order to have light all the time (to bring light into a gloomy building), or they think that people in the next village have stolen the moon & want to bring it back. They climb a hill (ladder) & try to capture the moon in a sack (see the moon’s reflection & try to keep it by fixing a clamp across the well or pail).
1364
1336-Diving for CheeseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull sees the moon reflected in the water & mistakes it for a cheese (a clump of gold). He dives for it (tells his companions, & together they try to rake the “cheese” out) with animals as actors.
1365
1336ANot Recognizing Own ReflectionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A villager goes to town & sees a mirror for the first time. When he looks at his reflection in the mirror, he thinks he sees his dead father’s face in it. He buys the mirror, hides it at home & often looks into it to greet his “father”. His wife finds the mirror, takes it up, & sees her reflection. She thinks there is another young woman in it, feels jealous & starts quarreling with her husband. A nun who passes by takes up the mirror & says that the woman in the mirror has become a nun (their old mother sees her reflection in the mirror & tells them that there is only an old woman). (More people look into the mirror & are astonished. Finally the mirror is broken. Or, the real nature of the mirror is discovered.) (2) A foolish son sees his own reflection in the water of the well & mistakes it for a thief. He calls his mother to have a look. She agrees with her son’s judgment & adds, “And the thief is accom-panied by such an ugly old woman”.
1366
1337-A Farmer Visits the CityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type with diverse variants: All kinds of mistaken identities & escapades.
1367
1337CThe Long NightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Two (male or female) farmers (merchants, master & farmhand) stay overnight at an inn (in a train compartment). When one of them wants to open the window in the morning, he instead opens the door of a cupboard (opens the window but does not realize that the window shutters are still closed). He says that it is still dark out-side (and the weather is smelling of cheese) & goes on sleeping throughout the day (three days). In some variants, the travelers sleep in an alcove & cannot find the door. (2) A stupid man (several men) is locked in a dark room for several days. He is made to believe that it is continuous night. Various reasons are given for this trick: A man wants to get rid of his brother who has been visiting him for too long, or whose unfashionable clothing embarasses him. A father wants to prevent his two sons from going to a party & spending money unnecessarily. People in the city want to stop farmers from going to market to sell their animals. Servants at a hotel want to make fun of one of their guests. Often the victim is a villager who gets the idea that nights in a town must be longer than those in the country.
1368
1338-City People Visit the CountryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesAll kinds of mistaken identities & escapades. Within this misc. type, a special version can be distinguished: A girl who lives in the city does not know whether turnips (potatoes) grow on the ground or on a tree.
1369
1339-Strange FoodsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type with diverse variants: An ignorant man (woman) is not familiar with a certain food
1370
1339AFool is Unacquainted with SausagesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type. The fool squeezes the inside out & mistakes the covering for a sack.
1371
1339BFool is Unacquainted with BananasAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type. The fool throws away the fruit & finds the rest bitter. In a Hungarian version, an ignorant woman boils only the stalk of an asparagus because she thinks that the top is not yet ripe
1372
1339CWoman is Unacquainted with Tea/CoffeeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesShe serves the boiled leaves with butter (boils unground coffee beans).
1373
1339DFarmers are Unacquainted with MustardAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTwo (three, four) men are eating porridge (soup). The first takes a spoonful. The food is so hot that his eyes run with tears. The second asks his companion why he is weeping & is told, that he is thinking about his father (brother, grandmother) who died (was drowned, hanged) a year ago. Now the second man eats a spoonful & tears rise in his eyes, too. When asked why he is weeping he answers, because his companion did not die likewise a year ago. In other versions, the food is mustard (hot sauce): Farmers in the city (Indians) eat too big a portion. In some variants mus-tard is sold to ignorant persons as honey (vinegar as wine).
1374
1339EAll Cooked for One MealAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA farmer (foolish man, foolish woman) cooks various foods (e.g. tea, sugar, bacon) together for one meal. Or, he cooks all the available beans (rice, grain) so that the food fills all of the containers (the room).
1375
1339FFrog Eaten as HerringAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool buys a herring & is told to cut its head off before he eats it. He loses it in the grass (it falls out of his hand). Instead of the fish, the fool picks up a live frog & eats it: “Croak if you want, but I’ll eat you anyway!” In Bulgarian variants, the fool buys soap (a frog) instead of cheese (ham). Even though the soap makes lather, he eats it, saying, “If you foam, or if you don’t, I paid for you & I’m going to eat you!”
1376
1339GThe Relative in the UrnAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool Stories(During the years after World War II) a family gets a parcel from the U. S. (other western country, Australia) containing among other foods a box filled with an unknown powder. The family members mistake the powder for a certain sort of flour (special spice, instant drink), use it to bake a cake (scatter it on the food, dissolve it in milk) & enjoy the meal (drink). A few days later they get a letter telling them that the box contained the ashes of a relative whom they might want to bury.
1377
1341-Fools Warn Thief What Not to StealAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool (fools) explains to a stranger (strangers) where in the house his valuables (e.g. food, money) are kept & where the key can be found. He warns the stranger not to steal. The stranger uses the key & steals the valuables. In some variants, a fool tells a thief to come back later because the inhabitants of the house are still awake.
1378
1341AThe Fool & the RobbersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) Robbers stumble over a fool lying on the ground & wonder, “What is this, a log?” The fool answers, “Does a log have five annas in its pocket?” When the robbers have taken away his money, the fool says, “Ask the merchant in the tree if my money is good”. Thus the thieves rob the merchant, too. (2) Three numskulls hide when they see thieves coming. The thieves find one of them, kill him, & wonder why his blood is so dark (red). On hearing this remark, the second numskull explains from his hiding place that it is because he has eaten blackberries (prickly pears). When the second numskull is killed, the thieves re-mark, “If this one had not spoken we would not have found him”. The third explains aloud, “That’s why I didn’t say anything”. The thieves kill him, too. (3) Two foolish slaves are recaptured because of their talkativeness.
1379
1341A*Thief as DogAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA thief enters a house to steal but stumbles over an object. The husband wonders what the noise is. The wife says that it is probably the dog. Thus the thief crouches like a dog & says, “It is me, the dog”. In some variants, two boys spend the night in a girl’s house because of bad weather. The father hears one boy in bed with the girl & asks, “Who is there?” The boy meows like a cat & the father is satisfied. The second boy has the same experience. When the father asks again, “Who is there?” the boy answers, “It is me, the second cat”.
1380
1341BThe Lord is RisenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA clergyman hides his money beneath the altar (in the monstrance) & leaves as a marker, “The Lord is in this place”. A thief (the sexton) takes the money & leaves the statement: “He is risen & is no longer here”. In some variants, a fool hides his money under a stone with the inscription, “Here it is”. Another person finds the money & takes it, leaving the message, “Here it is not”.
1381
1341CRobbers CommiseratedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA thief (thieves) visits the home of a man at night & cannot find anything of value to steal. The master of the house wakes up in his bed & tells the thief, “What you are looking for in this house in the dark, I even cannot find in the daylight”.
1382
1341DThe Thief & the MoonlightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA thief climbs to the roof of a house, hoping to steal something. The owner hears him & speaks to his wife loudly enough that the thief can hear, telling her the following story: Once he himself had tried to steal something by climbing through a window in a roof. He said a spell (prayer) so that the in-habitants would stay asleep. Then he let himself into the house by sliding down a ray of moonlight & stole what he wanted. The thief on the roof copies this & says the spell. The man & his wife snore loudly, pretending to be asleep. When the thief tries to slide down the ray of moonlight into the house, he falls & breaks his leg. He is beaten (hanged).
1383
1342-Warming Hands & Cooling Soup with the Same BreathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesDuring a cold winter, a satyr (wood spirit) meets a man (boy) who is cold & accommodates him in his cave. The satyr watches the man blowing in his hand & is told that in this way he wants to warm his numb fingers. When the satyr serves up a meal, his guest blows on the food & explains that he wants to cool it. The satyr is afraid of this strange human behavior, blowing hot & cold in the same manner, & chases the man away.
1384
1343-Hanging GameAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTwo) fools (children) want to try out how it feels to be hanged. They agree that one of them (shall tie a blade of straw or thread around his neck and) shall be pulled up, while his comrades shall take care to get him down in time (when the hanging man whistles). During the trial, a wolf (devil in the form of a hare) passes by, the fools run after it, & forget to watch their hanging comrade. He dies. (The hanging man tries to whistle, but no sound can be heard. The others tell him that it might not be enough just to purse his lips.
1385
1343*The Children Play at Hog-KillingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale combines a common introduction with either of two main parts. Introduction:Children, having seen a hog being slaughtered, play at slaughtering. The child who plays the butcher kills the child who plays the hog with a knife. Main parts: (1) After this, the children hide in the oven. They are burned to death when their mother lights it to heat the room. (Or, the angry mother chokes the culprit. Meanwhile the baby drowns in the bath tub, & the mother hangs herself. The father comes home & dies of grief.) (2) The murderer is taken to court. In order to decide whether he is guilty or innocent, a wise man says that he should be offered a choice between an apple & a piece of gold. The child chooses the apple & is declared to be innocent.
1386
1344-Lighting a Fire from the Sparks from a Box on the EarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA numskull wants to light a fire from the sparks of a slap.
1387
1345-Greasing the Judge's PalmsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA foolish woman (foolish farmer) who is involved in a lawsuit is advised to grease the judge’s palms. She takes it literally & greases the judge’s palms using a sweet-scented oil (melted butter). The judge recognizes the woman’s stupidity & tells her that now he needs some yards of linen to dry his hands. The woman goes for the linen & the judge says that drying was more helpful than greasing.
1388
1346-The House without Food or DrinkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA boy (fool & his son) hears a woman on the street mourning her dead husband, “He goes to the place where there is darkness & nothing to eat or drink”. The frightened boy rushes home & tells his master that they are bring-ing a corpse to their house. (The son supposes, “They must be coming to our house”.)
1389
1346A*"Guess How Many Eggs I Have & You Shall Get All Seven!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA fool (farmer) says to his companion, “If you can tell me how many eggs I have in my bag (young pigs my sow brought forth) you will get all seven (four, ten)”.
1390
1347-Living Crucifix ChosenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesFoolish people order a new crucifix. The artist asks them whether they want a live or a dead one. They choose a live crucifix with the argument: If they wanted a dead one later they can still kill it.
1391
1347*The Statue's FatherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA Spaniard (farmer) threatens to smash the image of Christ (St. Anthony) if the latter does not cure his son, who is ill (help him to win a law suit). The sexton overhears the threat & tells the priest, who orders the sexton to place a smaller image in the church so that the loss will not be so great if the image is damaged. The ill son dies, & the Spaniard returns. He sees the smaller image & addresses it saying, “Tell your father that I am here. I have no business with you.”
1392
1348-The Imaginative BoyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA braggart, usually a boastful boy, tells his companions (father) about a great number of wolves (bears, hares, thieves) which he pretends to have seen. When the number is called into question he reduces it gradually until no animal is left at all. He heard only a rustle in the bushes.
1393
1348*The Boy with Active ImaginationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA boy (man, farmhand) wants to (is supposed to) catch fish (bring back a wandering cow). His father (a farmer, someone else) asks him if he has caught any (found the cow). He answers (he did not look for the cow but found three birds instead), “If I had one & then I got two more, I would have three”. (“I see one, I hear one, & I catch one.”)
1394
1348**The Man Who Beleives His Own LieAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man tells his neighbors (customers, children) that a whale has been washed up on shore (the king is coming, they can get free food or other items). When the people hurry away to take advantage of this opportunity, he runs after them, believing his own lie.
1395
1349*Misc. Numskull TalesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesMisc. type with diverse variants.
1396
1349D*What is Intelligence?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesTwo men digging a ditch wonder why their foreman can sit in the shade with a cool drink. One of them asks him for the reason & gets the answer, “Because I got intelligence”. The workman does not know what “intelligence” means. To explain it, the foreman holds his hand up in front of a tree & tells the workman to hit it. Right before the man hits his hand, he pulls it down, & the workman smashes his hand into the tree. The comment is, “That’s intelligence”. The workman returns, & asked by the other one he explains that the foreman “got intelligence”. His companion does not know the word either. So the first man holds his hand up in front of his face & invites his companion to hit it. He pulls his hand down & takes the blow right in his face. In some variants, a nobleman explains to a stupid farmer what a joke is (Irishman shows his companion a Yankee trick).
1397
1349G*Cold Spell Has BrokenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesOn a very cold winter day, a woman comes back home freezing. She is concerned about her son who is outside in the cold, & wonders if she should call him back into the house. When she sits by the stove for a while & feels warmer, she believes that the cold spell has broken & that her son can stay outside.
1398
1349L*Curing Fever by Dipping into WellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesWhen his mother (wife, etc.) is ill with a fever, a fool dips her into a well, because he remembers see ing a red-hot iron sickle cooled in that way. In some variants, a fool advices a person suffering from an eye-disease to put out his eye, because he himself once cured his toothache by pulling out the tooth.
1399
1349M*The Answered PrayerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesA man without food prays to God. He accidentally gets food & thinks God has answered his prayer.
1400
1349N*The Mistaken PrescriptionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1200-1349 Fool StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A physician prescribes leeches to a patient. The patient does not know how to use them. He eats some of the leeches raw & asks his wife to roast the others. (2) A sick fool takes the physician’s written prescription with water & gets well (3) A foolish woman reads the instruction “to shake before use” & shakes her ill husband instead of the medicine. (4) A foolish farmer brings a door to a pharmacist. The pharmacist is astonished & tells him that the carpenter lives across the road. The farmer answers that his wife is sick but they did not have a pencil & paper in the house, so the doctor had to write the prescription with chalk on the door.
1401
1350-The Soon-Consoled WidowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man feigns death in order to test his wife’s faithfulness. The wife is eager to take the man who brings her the news for her new husband (lover).
1402
1351-The Silence WagerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man & his wife make a wager: Whoever speaks first must do certain work (close the door, wash the dishes, feed the animals, etc.). Strangers (robbers) enter their house & take or abuse their belongings (believe the couple are dead & share their estate). A man rapes the woman (a woman tries to rape the man). The husband (wife) protests (becomes jealous), cries out, & thus loses the wager.
1403
1351A"God Help You!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband & wife quarrel & do not speak to each other for a whole day. Before they go to sleep, the husband puts a board (pillow) in the middle of the bed between them. In the night the man sneezes. “God help you”, says his wife from the other side of the bed. “Do you really mean that?” asks the man. “Yes”, says the wife. The man replies, “Then take away the board!”
1404
1351A*Lost TongueAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man criticizes his wife for talking too much & so she stops speaking at all. After two days he starts searching everywhere & she asks him what he is looking for. He answers, “Your tongue”.
1405
1351B*Misc. Tales of Quarreling CouplesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with married couples who quarrel or who play tricks on each other.
1406
1351F*The Unsuccessful MurderAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman wants to poison her husband. The pharmacist gives her herbs instead of the poison that she re-quests. He tells her husband that she had asked him for poison. The wife sprinkles the herbs on a bowl of soup & serves it to her husband. He pretends to die. The wife puts a rope through a hole leading upstairs & ties it around the man’s neck. She goes upstairs & tries to pull him up, but he unties himself & ties the rope to his workbench. She uses the rope to pull it up & fastens the rope. Then she calls out the window for help, saying that her husband hanged himself. The wife is tried & convicted.
1407
1351G*Bearing His CrossAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man (farmer, baker, barber) suffers at the hands of his obstinate wife. He complains to the clergyman (his master), who tells him that each man has his own cross to bear (carry). The man goes home, lifts his wife on his back, & carries her. After this, she becomes more tractable.
1408
1352-The Devil Guards the Wife's ChastityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man who is exasperated with his quarrelsome wife exclaims, “May the devil take you!”. The devil takes this command seriously, defends her chastity, & carries off her would-be lovers (even in hell, she is unmanageable). Finally he gives up & sends her back to her husband, saying it would be easier to herd wild horses (wild pigs).
1409
1352AThe Tale-Telling ParrotAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA rich man (merchant) gives his wife a (two) parrot so that she will have company while he is away. She falls in love during her husband’s absence (and kills the parrot [one of the parrots] because he will not let her visit her lover). Every time she wants to go to her lover, the (other) parrot holds her back by telling a long story (he tells seven stories in seven days), until her husband returns.
1410
1353-The Old Woman as TroublemakerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThe devil wants to separate a man & his wife (because he is jealous of their happiness). He asks an old woman to help him (promises her a pair of shoes). The old woman tells the wife that her husband is unfaithful to her, & that in order to make him love her again, she should cut three hairs from his beard when he is asleep. The old woman tells the husband that his wife intends to kill him. When the wife comes at night with a knife to cut the hairs, he beats (kills) her.
1411
1354-Death for the Old CoupleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman whose husband is ill wishes that death would take her (instead of him). When death (a neighbor dressed as death, death in the form of a bird [owl, crow, goose, chicken]) comes (sent by the husband to test his wife) to take the wife, she points instead to her husband.
1412
1354A*Widower's ReliefAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesAn old man feels relieved by the death of his wife. He says to death, “You have caused me a lot of trouble, but now you will not do so any more”.
1413
1354C*Seemingly-Dead Woman Returns to LifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA dead woman (man) is being carried to her grave. One of the coffin bearers bumps into a wall & the shock brings the dead woman back to life. She dies again the following year. Her husband tells the coffin bearers to be careful how they go, so the same mistake will not happen again.
1414
1354D*Fertile WeatherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesTwo farmers are discussing the weather. “This weather is good for growing”, says one. “Tonight everything will spring out of the ground”. “I hope not”, says the other, “My wife (two, three wives) is buried there”.
1415
1355-The Man Hidden under the BedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises different anecdotes dealing with adultery, some of which are not clearly described in the regional type catalogues: The lover hides under the bed when the husband comes home. In most cases the lover misunderstands something that the husband says & betrays himself by his spontaneous reply.
1416
1355AThe Lord Above the Lord BelowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesWhile her husband is away, a wife is visited by two of her lovers. When her husband suddenly comes home, one hides on the roof & the second hides under the bed. The wife distracts her husband with foolish phrases & accuses him of having wasted all his money on drink. He defends himself & says, “The Lord above will pay for everything”. The man on the roof says he will pay for half, but the man under the bed (below) must pay for the other half. In Italian variants the meeting of the adulterous wife & her lover is interrupted by a fool who follows his dog into the house. He embraces the woman & hides from the husband in the hearth. When the husband starts a fire, the fool defends himself, “I had your wife only once, but the man under the bed has her a thousand times”. The husband kills the lover & gives the fool money to keep quiet.
1417
1355A*Unfaithful Wife as JudgeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA neighbor (miller) tells a husband about his wife’s unfaithfulness, & they surprise her with her lover. She assumes the role of judge & sentences all three men to be punished.
1418
1355B"I Can See the Whole World!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA farmer (herdsman) who has lost an animal (horse, donkey, cow) climbs a tree to look for it (looks for it under a bed). He accidentally witnesses a couple embracing. Af-ter their intercourse (on seeing the woman’s naked body) the lover (man or woman) says metaphorically, “I have seen the whole world!” (some similar expression). The farmer asks the man if he has seen his lost animal. The couple are frightened & run away so fast that they leave some article behind which the farmer takes. (The adulterer gives the farm-er money to keep quiet. If the couple are married, they beat the farmer.)
1419
1355CThe Lord Above Will ProvideAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesLovers are consorting under a tree (in a barn). The woman worries about the consequences & asks her lover, “Who will provide for the child?” He answers, “The Lord above us will take care of it”. A man hiding in the tree (on the roof) says, “I certainly will not!”
1420
1357*Wife's Duty to Have Lovers.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband wants to sound out his wife. He tells her that every wife should have a lover so that other men will respect her husband (because otherwise her husband will not respect her). The wife admits that she does have a lover.
1421
1357A*Peas in the JarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA married couple frequently engage in adultery. The wife puts a pea in a jar each time, & the husband puts a marble in a bag. After a while they compare numbers, & the husband sees that the wife has fewer peas than he has marbles. She explains that she used some of her peas to make soup (three times). In some variants, only one of the two partners keeps count in this manner.
1422
1358-Trickster Suprises Adultress & LoverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type refers to a cycle of related anecdotes concerned with adultery. Usual-ly a husband catches his wife with her lover & exposes their affair.
1423
1358*Child Unwittingly Betrays His Mother's AdultryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesWhile her husband is away, a wife makes advances to one of his employees. This man draws a chalk circle on the floor & warns that he will “take revenge” on her if she crosses the line. The eager wife crosses the line & the employee has intercourse with her. When the husband returns, a child, who has seen what happened, warns him not to cross the line because if he does, the employee will do to him what he did to the mother, lie beside him & “fight”
1424
1358AHidden Lover Buys Freedom from DiscovererAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA priest makes advances to a married woman. She pretends to agree to meet him, but tells her husband. At the rendezvous when the husband knocks on the door, the priest, who is already undressed, hides in a vat that contains tar (sirup). When he looks for a better place to hide, he finds himself in a vat of feathers. The man & his wife see him covered with tar & feathers & exhibit him as the devil (the man puts him in a crate & parades him around). Important people (people who come to the market) pay to see this “devil”. The priest often has to give all his wealth in order to ransom himself.
1425
1358BHusband Carries Off Box Containing Hidden LoverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesAn adulterer (priest) who was surprised by his lover’s husband hides in a chest (which contains garbage, spoiled food, etc.). The husband (another lover, someone else) transports the chest together with its contents & exhibits it publicly (for a fee). The prisoner (who cries out from inside the chest) is set free after he pays a fine or a ransom (his friends or relatives pay it).
1426
1358CTrickster Discovers Adultery; Fool Goes to Husband Instead of LoverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA traveler (student, soldier, etc.) asks for food & lodging, so a housewife gives him plain food & tells him to sleep in the haystack. He sees her (through a window) feasting in the company of her lover. When the husband comes home unexpectedly, he tells the traveler he would invite him in if he could offer him decent food. When the wife pretends that there is no food in the house, the traveler (with the help of a bird or magic implement) pretends to use magic to produce the (hidden) food leftover from the feast. He uses pretended magic a second time to raise the devil (actually the hidden lover) & chase him away. The lover & the wife or the host give the traveler a generous reward. Often the husband buys the magic object from him.
1427
1359-Husband Outwits Adultress & LoverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis type refers to a cycle of related anecdotes concerned with adultery. Usually a husband catches his wife with her lover & exposes their affair.
1428
1359AHiding the Lover.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man tries twice to catch his wife comitting adultery, but each time she manages to hide her lover. The third time, the husband burns down the house. The wife man ages (with the unwitting help of her husband) to rescue her lover.
1429
1359A*Pulling Out HairsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA merchant (clergyman, monk, Jew) spends the night in a farmhouse, sharing a bed with the farmer & his wife. When the traveler wants to have intercourse with the wife, he pulls out a hair from the husband’s backside to find out if he is asleep. This happens several times, until finally the husband turns over & says, “I don’t mind what you do with my wife, but please don’t use my backside as a scoreboard!”In some variants the cheated person (teacher) discloses his identity by joining in the chorus when the two others (priest & nun) talk about the pleasure they have had the last night in a reciprocal song.
1430
1359BHusband Meets the Lover in the Wife's PlaceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband suspects that while he is away at mass, his wife is having an affair with their children’s tutor. The husband wants to find out if this is true. One day when his wife is away & the husband is at home with the tutor, he invites the young man to a luxurious feast & offers him plenty of wine in order to loosen his tongue. The young man con-firms the husband’s suspicions, & is pardoned on the condition that he breaks off the relationship. Soon after, however, the merchant notices that the affair is still going on. In order to put an end to it, one morning he orders his wife to go to mass instead of him. As she leaves, she slams the door hard to signal to the young man that it was she & not her husband who went out. The young man wakes up late, believes that the husband has left, & goes to the wife’s bed, where he finds the merchant. The merchant insults him & beats him (castrates him).
1431
1359CHusband Prepares to Castrate the CrucifixAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA sculptor (icon-maker) & his wife want to put an end to the unwelcome attentions that the clergyman has been paying to the wife. She plans a meeting with the priest in the studio (in the church) & persuades him to take off his clothes (and paints his body). Surprised by the sudden appearance of the sculptor (icon-maker), the priest pretends to be Jesus standing before the cross among the sculptures (icons). The husband is about to castrate the figure (correct the sculpture) because the customer (bishop) supposedly does not like such a realistic representation. The priest runs away naked.
1432
1360-Man Hidden in the RoofAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with adultery, most of which are not clearly described in the regional type catalogs.
1433
1360BFlight of the Woman & her Lover from the StableAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesWhen the husband is away from home a servant (guest, the husband himself) accidentally (from the roof) observes the housewife (his wife) with her lover (man, priest). When the servant is asked why he did so little work, he recites a verse that describes what he saw (he describes the event in the form of a story which he tells at dinner). The wife gives him money to stop telling the story. He concludes by saying that it was only a dream In some Estonian variants the tale continues: Because there are too many guests, the housewife cannot receive her lover. One guest pretends to be the housewife & refuses to let the lover come in, but instead castrates the lover through the window.
1434
1360COld HildebrandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesAn unfaithful wife pretends to be ill & sends her husband for medicine. On his way the husband meets another man & has him carry him in a basket (sack, bundle of straw) back to his house, where his wife is entertaining her lover (the priest). They invite the man with the basket to eat with them. All three sing verses: first the wife, then the lover, then the guest. Often the husband in the basket sings the final verse. He comes out & a brawl ensues.
1435
1361-The FloodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA clergyman (student) who wants to have a private meet-ing with a woman announces that a flood is coming. Her husband (carpenter, merchant, miller, farmer) tries to escape the flood in a tub tied up under the roof. While the adulterous couple are enjoying themselves, another lover comes & wants to take part or at least to have a kiss. The wife (clergyman) puts her (his) backside out the window & invites the lover to kiss it. He realizes he was tricked and, as if it were a second kiss, brands the backside of the clergyman with a hot iron. When the clergyman cries for water, the husband in the tub thinks the flood is coming. He cuts the rope, falls to the ground, & injures himself (dies).
1436
1362-The Snow-child (Modus Leibinc)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple Stories(Modus Liebinc.) The wife of a merchant gives birth during her husband’s absence. When he comes home, she explains that she had become pregnant from eating snow (an icicle). The man pretends to accept the child as his son. When the boy grows up, the father takes him on a trip & sells him. Later he explains to his wife that the boy melted & dripped into the sea
1437
1362A*The Three Month's ChildAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThree months after the wedding, a young woman gives birth. Her husband thinks he has been cheated, but she (the priest) explains to him that he was married for three months, she was married for three months, & they were both together married for three months. This makes nine months in all, so he must recognize the child as his own. In some variants the father is told that his premature son will sur pass other children & become a good courier*.
1438
1362B*Marrying a Man of FortyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA dying husband advises his wife to marry a man of the age of forty. She prefers to take two men of twenty.
1439
1363-Tale of the CraddleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesTwo traveling students spend the night in the house of a family with a beautiful wife & daughter. Everyone sleeps in the same room, with the youngest child in a cradle at the foot of the marriage bed. During the night one of the students sneaks into the bed of the daughter. When the mother leaves the room, the second student moves the cradle, so that when she comes back she mistakes his bed for hers & him for her husband. When the first student tries to go back to his own bed, he too is confused by the position of the cradle. He gets into bed with the father and, thinking that this is his friend, tells him what he has done. The father becomes angry & starts to beat the student. When the mother turns on the light, her lover puts the cradle back & moves his friend into their original bed. When she realizes what has happened, she tells her husband that they were visited by a demon. The students leave the following morning.
1440
1364-The Blood-Brother's WifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA lover boasts to his good friend that he has had a narrow escape from the husband of his mistress. The lover does not realize that this friend is in fact the husband, & tells him the particulars of his plans for the future (the time of their next appointment, etc.). Unbeknownst to the lover, the husband uses this information to try to surprise the guilty pair. Three times the couple are surprised by the husband, but the lover escapes by hiding behind a curtain, under the bed, in a cupboard, in a cistern, etc. Later (at a banquet) the lover boasts about his liason & adventures. He is accused of misconduct & asked to confess. He saves himself by saying it was all a dream.
1441
1365-The Obstinate WifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type refers to a circle of related anecdotes dealing with a married couple each of which insists on being right. The wife in particular is blamed for being obstinate.
1442
1365AWife Falls into a StreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman who has been contrary all her life falls into a river. Her husband searches for her upstream because she would be too obstinate to go with the current.
1443
1365BCutting with the Knife or the ScissorsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife argues with her husband, insisting that a meadow has been cut with scissors instead of a scythe (that he has cut his beard rather than shaved his face). The fight goes on until the angry husband pushes his wife into a river. As she drowns, she continues to argue by making scissors-motions with her fingers.
1444
1365CWife Insults the Husband as Lousy-HeadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife accuses her husband of being a lousy-head (i.e. being a miser). He throws her into the river. Even as she sinks, she continues to accuse him by holding up her hands & snapping her fingers together as if she is cracking lice.
1445
1365DThank God the Basket is ReadyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesEach time when a basketmaker finishes a basket he wants his wife to say “Thanks God the basket is ready”. When his wife refuses to obey, he beats her. Other men (judge, lawyer, overseer, farmhand) of the happening who witness this tell the story to their wives. Those who would also not have been refused utter the thanks & are beaten by their husbands as well.
1446
1365EQuarrelsome CoupleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with married couples who quarrel about some minor problem, such as which of them should have the third of three eggs (previously whose is the hair that is in the soup, or whether the holes in the floor were made by rats or by mink. Or, the husband always asks the wife for the opposite of what he wants. Sometimes they argue about the kinds & sizes of birds or other trivialities, & the wife lets herself be buried alive rather than give in. In some variants the husband is so stubborn that he lets himself be buried rather than give in to his wife.
1447
1366*The Cowering HusbandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife beats her husband regularly. In order to escape her blows, he cowers under the table (bed). When she orders him to come out, he re plies that in his own house he can certainly make his own decisions.
1448
1367-Trickster Shifts Married Couples in BedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesFor financial reasons, a young woman marries an old man & a young man marries an old woman. They are unhappy with their spouses. A magician, in order to demonstrate his powers to a nobleman, rearranges the couples while they are asleep. In the morning, the young people are happy & want to stay together. But the old people are displeased & ask a nobleman to decide the case. He decides that they should go back to the partners that they had originally married.
1449
1367*Better to Hang Than to Marry an Evil WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA pilgrim is convicted of a crime & is sentenced either to pay a fine or to have his eyes put out (be executed). He has no money so he is brought, blindfolded, to the place of exe cution. A rich but ugly woman offers to pay the fine for him if he will marry her. When his blindfold is removed & he sees her, he asks to have it replaced, saying that it is better not to see at all than to have always to look at something so unpleasant. The judge lets him go free.
1450
1367**Double the FeeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesWhen his master dies, a farmhand marries the wi-dow although he had been warned against this (she cannot man age money, does not know how to keep house). While doing housework, she injures her arm. The new husband pays the doctor twice for the treatment, saying that her other arm will need it soon. From then on the wife does her work properly.
1451
1368-Marriage to a Small Woman: The Smaller EvilAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man is asked why he married such a small woman. He explains that it is the smaller evil.
1452
1368**The Nine Skins of the WomenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesTwo men discuss about the animal (bad) characteristics of women. They come to the conclusion that those charactertraits result from several (nine, four, three) animal skins women possess. The skins have to be beaten off one by one. Only the ninth is the real human skin & only with this skin will a woman behave well, be piously & obedient
1453
1369-The Woman's TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman (several women) hangs herself from her husband’s fig tree. When he tells his neighbor about this misfortune, the neighbor asks for a twig from the tree. He wants to plant it in his garden, saying that he hopes it will bear similar fruit (to see what his wife will do).
1454
1370-The Lazy Wife is ReformedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA young man marries a rich (beautiful) woman. He knows she is lazy, but promises not to beat her (he finds out how lazy she is only after the marriage). Before he leaves he orders the cat (dog, donkey, purse, animal hide) to do the housework. When he returns & finds that the work has not been done, he asks his wife to hold the animal (object) while he beats it for its disobedience. The blows fall on the wife as well as on the animal. After this happens once (twice, three times), the wife does the house work without complaining.
1455
1370B*Wife Too Lazy to SpinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA lazy woman refuses to spin. When her husband pretends to be dead, she wraps his body in flax (wool). He gets up & beats her for not putting a shirt on him even when he is dead.
1456
1370C*Misc. Tales of a Lazy WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type contains various tales dealing with lazy women & the results of their laziness.
1457
1371A*Darkening the FlourAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man steals white flour so that his wife can bake a cake for their guests. When he comes home, he is afraid that his theft will be discovered, but his wife reassures him that she will bake the cake so dark that it will seem to have been made from rye flour.
1458
1372-The Box on the EarsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA farmer goes to get medicine for his sick wife. But instead of medicine the pharmacist (doctor) gives him a beating (because he offends the pharmacist, enters the shop dirty, rings the night bell too loudly, or demonstrates his wife’s sickness in an of-fensive manner). The farmer returns home, & believing that this is the medicine, gives his wife a box on the ear. This cures her miraculously. Not need-ing the remaining boxes on the ear, the farmer “takes” them back to the pharmacist.
1459
1372*The Wife's DiseaseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman pretends to suffer from a disease that can only be cured if all her wishes are fulfilled (if someone brings food for her from the delicatessen). When her husband pretends to catch a similar (the same) disease, she takes care of him & is cured of her “illness”.
1460
1373-The Weighed CatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man brings some meat home, but his wife eats it secretly. When he asks what happened to it, she says that the cat ate it. The husband weighs the cat and, finding that it weighs the same as the meat he had bought, says, “Here is the meat, but where is the cat?”.
1461
1373AWife Eats So Little.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA (newly-married) woman eats very little in the presence of her husband (she pretends she is too sick to eat). When her husband is away, she eats well. He discovers her deception & punishes her (he exposes her pretence, ridicules her, beats her).
1462
1373A*Wife Says Cat Ate the MeatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man brings some meat home, but his wife eats it secretly & says that the cat ate it. He complains to a witch, who gives him some magic beans (nuts, stones). He puts them in the house where they speak to the wife & warn her against such selfishness.
1463
1373B*Daughter Offers Father Her Own FleshAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA daughter secretly eats the chicken intended for the family meal. Instead, she serves her father meat from her own breast (buttocks). When he asks for more of this delicious meat, her ruse is exposed. (Parrot, chicken, or turkey tells the man what he has eaten.)
1464
1374*Woman Who Does Not Know How to Bake BreadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA young wife does not know how to knead (bake) bread. Her father-in-law (mother) says the bread will succeed only if she sweats from her forehead & backside when she is kneading it (she should continue to knead until the front of the oven [her fore-head] sweats). She follows his advice & touches these parts of her body again & again while she kneads in order to see if she is sweating. (A neighbor advises her to add a handful of dirt, which she does.)
1465
1375-Who can Rule His Wife?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis type exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A man goes on a journey to discover whether husbands or wives have more power. He takes along two (more) horses (symbols of masculinity) & many eggs (nuts, hens, other symbols of femininity, agricultural products that belong to the female sphere of work). Wherever a husband rules the house, the traveler gives him a horse, & wherever a wife is the master, she receives an egg. There is a great demand for eggs. Finally the traveler finds a man who claims to be master. When this man chooses a horse, his wife contradicts him & he has to settle for an egg. (2) A ham is offered as a price to any man who does not regret his marriage vow during the following year (and a day), or who can prove that he is not afraid of his wife. (3) A piece of bacon is hung at the city gate with a written mes-sage: “It will go to whichever husband will swear that his wife does not dominate him”. The farmer who claims the bacon refuses to hide it under his smock, because he is afraid of what his wife will say if he gets marks from the fat on his Sunday coat. (4) A priest asks all the men who consider themselves to be mas-ters of their house to sing the song “Christ is Risen”. All the men are silent & all the women (only one man) sing. Or the priest sings the song by himself. The next year, even he is silent, because now he has a housekeeper.
1466
1376A*How a Husband Cures His Wife of Fairy TalesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThe wife of an innkeeper loves to hear stories so much that she allows travelers who tell stories to stay for free at the inn (only storytellers to stay). This ruins the innkeeper & he wants to cure her of her habit. A traveler comes who offers to tell stories throughout the night on the condition that the woman does not interrupt him. But when he repeats the same story over & over she finally stops him. Her husband beats her for this breach of promise, & so she loses her interest in storytelling.
1467
1377-Husband Locked OutAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple Stories(Puteus.) When an adulteress comes home to her husband late at night, he refuses to let her come in the house. She threatens to throw herself into the well. When the husband runs outside to prevent this, she goes into the house & locks him out.
1468
1378-The Marked Coat in the Wife's RoomAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA matchmaker finds a wife for her client. She leaves a man’s coat in the woman’s room & marks it. The woman’s husband discovers the coat and, thinking that his wife is an adulteress, casts her out. The wife goes to the client. In order to reconcile the man & his wife, the matchmaker goes to the husband & asks him if he found a coat with a particular mark on it. The husband realizes that it was she who left the coat. He regrets having been suspicious of his wife & takes her back.
1469
1378A*The Husband in the TavernAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife goes to look for her husband in a tavern. Having found out how much he usually spends for drink, she demands twice that amount of money for herself.
1470
1378B*Wife's Temporary SuccessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife insists on getting the better of her husband. For a while the husband lets her have her way. Then (because she did not pay the taxes) he beats her (and she becomes more tractable).
1471
1379-Wife Deceives Husband with Substitute BedmateAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man intends to commit adultery & plans a rendezvous with the maidservant. The maidservant tells his wife about it & she decides to go herself. At the last moment the husband hesitates & orders his servant to take his place. Later he meets the maidservant, who tells him that his wife had taken her place. The husband rushes to stop them, but he is too late.
1472
1379*False MembersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesOn the wedding night the bridegroom watches his new wife remove her artificial limbs (false breasts, wooden leg), wig, dentures, & a glass eye. Finally he says, “Throw me your backside for a pillow!”
1473
