1379**The Sailor & The OarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA sailor (Odysseus, St. Nicholas, St. Elias) is tired of the sea after many adventures. He walks inland with his oar hoping to find a place where no one has ever seen the sea or tasted its salt (salted food). Eventually he meets a man (woman) who thinks his oar is a winnowing shovel (bread paddle, ladle, piece of wood) & thus proves his ignorance. The sailor makes offerings to the gods & constructs al tars on the mountain peaks. Or he marries the woman, who on her wedding night proves to be more knowledgable than she had admit.
1474
1379***One-Eyed Man MarriesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThe beautiful daughter of a poor knight mar-ries a rich blind man. On the wedding night the blind man notices that she is not a virgin anymore. He reproaches her & she replies that the loss of his eyes would be a greater defect. Her blind husband explains that this injury was caused by his enemies. The young woman thereupon tells him not to reproach her, because her friends caused her defect.
1475
1380-The Faithless WifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA married woman is afraid her husband will discover that she has a lover. In order to prevent this, she asks several advisers what she should do. They suggest different foods that would incapacitate her husband. She does not know that one of the advisers is her own husband (one of his friends). After she serves the foods to her husband, he pretends to be blind. Believing it is now safe, she invites her lover into the house. Her husband punishes (slays) both of them.
1476
1380A*The Petitioner FooledAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a person (wife, young woman, maidservant, etc.) who asks a tree spirit (holy image) to grant some favor & to give a sign that this wish has been fulfilled. A trickster hiding behind (in) the tree or picture (the person affected by the wish, husband, employer, suitor, etc.) answers in a disguised voice, giving some unexpected information or saying something that furthers his own interest. The petitioner takes this reply as a divine command.
1477
1381-The Talkative Wife & the Discovered TreasureAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man (woman, boy) finds a treasure. Worried that his stupid (talkative) partner will say something that will cause him to lose the treasure, he pretends to his partner that something miraculous has happened: a rain of food, fish found in a field (in an animal trap), animals caught in a fish trap, the end of the world, a war of the birds, etc. When the stupid partner tells people that they found a treasure on the day it rained sausages, etc., no one believes what he says. The trick succeeds & the clever man keeps his treasure.
1478
1381AHusband Discredited by Absurd TruthAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman plants fish in the field where her husband is sure to plow them up. He finds them & gives them to her to cook. In the evening, in front of their guests, the woman asks her husband (so loudly that the neighbors can hear) what sort of fish he was talking of. When the guests hear the man say that it is the fish he found in his field, they think he is insane. He is restrained & taken to prison (madhouse), where he has to stay until his wife rescues him.
1479
1381BThe Sausage RainAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA stupid boy commits a murder. His mother helps him hide the body in a well. In order to discredit her son’s testimony, the mother exchanges the body for that of an animal & stages a rain of sausages (figs, fish, milk). Because of the son’s talkativeness, investigators come & discover the dead animal. The son insists that the murder took place on the day it rained sausages. The investigators think he is insane & release him.
1480
1381CBuried Sheeps HeadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesIn order to test his wife’s ability to keep a secret, a husband confides to his wife that he has killed a man & hidden the corpse. The woman does not know that he has killed an animal instead & hidden the carcass. When later they have a fight & the husband beats her, she re-veals the secret (tells it a friend who tells other people). The man is accused of murder but can prove his innocence because only the dead animal is found where the body is supposed to be.
1481
1381DWife Multiples the SecretAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesIn order to test his wife’s ability to keep a secret, her husband tells her that he has laid an egg (that a crow flew out of his belly) & makes her swear not to tell this to anyone. Against her promise not to reveal this embarassing fact she tells her friends (neighbors), adding to the story. Everyone adds more eggs (crows). Finally the authorities ask the man if he really laid 100 eggs.
1482
1381D*Secret SenateAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband (son) tells his curious wife (mother) of a pretended new law passed by the city council that permits men to have two wives. The wife tells other people & the rumor becomes well known. (Finally all the women of the town want the law to be reversed.)
1483
1381EOld Man Sent to SchoolAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesAn old man (farmer, workman, father) decides (is persuaded) to go to school in his old age (because he thinks it will help him become rich). On the way to school he finds a box (purse, bag) full of money. The man who lost it asks the old man if he found such a box, & the old man replies that he found it on the (first) day he went to school. The owner believes that it must have been a different box, because he lost his only recently.
1484
1381F*Riding on the SowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA farmer leaves home to go on a trip with his farmhand, but sends the man back to tell the farmwife not to let a certain man into the house. Knowing that this order will backfire, the farmhand tells her instead that her husband orders her not to ride on a sow. Curious, she disobeys, & the sow bites her on the toe (she falls of & hurts her self). Later on their trip, the farmer & the farmhand hear that a woman in their village was eaten by a sow.
1485
1382-The Farmwife at the MarketAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman (man) takes a cow (ox, ram, butter, grain) & a chicken (rooster, eggs) to sell at the market. because she misunderstood her husband’s instructions, she sells the cow for the price of the chicken & demands in vain the price of the cow for the chicken. Finally she sells her wares for “what the market will bear” to a customer (Jew) who says he is “the market” & spits in her hand instead of giving her money. Or, she sells without receiving money & adds a pledge (skirt, silver belt, jewelry) or a deposit (a silver spoon). Or, she must go & collect the money herself & is tarred & feathered. She returns home con fused, does not even recognize herself, & tells her hus band what happened. He goes to the town with a fishing rod & pretends to fish in a gutter (well) until the man who cheated his wife passes by & mocks him for being as stupid as his wife. Thus the cheater is exposed & the bargain is undone (renewed).
1486
1383-A Woman Does Not Know HerselfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesTo punish his wife for her foolishness (stupidity, drunkenness), a man covers her with tar & feathers (puts a different dress on her, cuts her hair off). No one recognizes her, & even she does not recognize herself (she thinks she is an animal or a devil, asks her children who their mother is).
1487
1384-The Husband Hunts Three Persons as Stupid as his WifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis is a frame story into which other anecdotes about stupid people are set. A man who is exasperated by the stupidity of his wife (bride, sister, daughter) goes out to find three (more) people who are equally stupid. He swears that if he cannot do this, he will leave his wife (beat her, kill her). He finds three such people quickly with out any trouble.
1488
1385-A Foolish Wife's SecurityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesUsually an introduction to other anecdotes about stupid people. A farmer sends his wife to the market to sell cattle (chickens, grain). The buyer tricks her into giving him some free of charge, saying that she should keep the others as the security for his debt (the buyer receives one half of it as credit & owes her the second part).
1489
1385*Learning About MoneyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA stupid woman knows nothing about money. Her husband comes home with a purse full of money & she asks him what is in the purse. He answers lentils (peas, pumpkin seeds, lice, nuts, grain, the plague). Later when he is away, the wife trades the purse with the money in it for something worthless.
1490
1386-Meat as food for cabbageAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesBefore he leaves home a man tells his wife, “The meat is for the cabbage” (meaning that she should cook them together). The wife follows this advice literally & puts pieces of meat by each cabbage in the garden. When the man sees how stupid his wife is, he leaves her. Usually he goes to look for other fools & meets people who do things even more stupid than what his wife did.
1491
1387-A Woman Goes to Get BeerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman is sent to get some beer (wine). While she is in the cellar, the meat burns, or the dog takes it & runs away. She chases the dog but forgets to close the tap, & the beer runs out all over the cellar. The woman tries to cover up her mistake by strewing meal on the cellar floor. Or, she throws bread out the window instead of putting it back in the oven, so that the mowers will go home hungry.
1492
1387*Woman Must Do Everything like Her NeighborsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man marries a woman who has no idea how to do housework. He tells her to go to a neighbor & see how she does it. The wife watches the neighbor winnow wheat, scald clothes, & bake bread. She goes back home & winnows flour, scalds her husband’s fur coat & boots, & puts the calf in the oven, etc. Her husband gives her other instructions which she follows literally, with disasterous results.
1493
1389*The Stingy Farmwife Gives her Servant some Little and some Big lumps of Sugar Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA stingy farmwife offers her servant girl (boy) little or big pieces of sugar, saying that the little ones are sweeter. The servant replies that she is not fond of sweets, & takes the big pieces.
1494
1390*The Dish He HatesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman repeatedly cooks a dish for her husband which he does not like. Finally he tells her that he loves it, & she stops serving it to him.
1495
1391-Every Hole to Tell the Truth.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple Stories(Les bijoux indiscrets.) A man helps a beggar (dervish, soldier) & receives as reward three magic objects, one of which is a stick that makes all holes able to speak. Before the man will marry a woman, he tests her chastity with this stick while she sleeps. Three women (daughters of a merchant, official, & nobleman) fail this test, & the man finally marries an “innocent” shepherdess. The fathers of the rejected women accuse him of slandering their daughters. They are tested again with the stick: the vagina of the first admits that it was unchaste. The second woman stuffs her vagina with hemp, but her anus speaks. The third silences her vagina & anus, but her ear admits to having had premarital intercourse.
1496
1393-The Single BlanketAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThe husbands of two women who are quarreling leave them together in a cold place with only one blanket. Since they have to share the blanket, they become reconciled with each other.
1497
1394-Polygynist Man Loses His BeardAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man has two wives, a young one & an old one. The young one pulls out his gray hairs, the old wife his black. They do this until his beard & head are bald.
1498
1405-The Lazy Spinning WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms, which appear alone or in combination: (1) A lazy wife lies to her husband, saying that she has spun many spindles of thread. But she always shows him the same spindle. (2) As an excuse for not spinning, a wife tells her husband that she has no reel. He goes to the forest to get wood to make one for her. Afraid that she may have to work, the wife follows him secretly & hides. She calls out, “If anyone cuts wood for a reel, he (his wife) will die”. The man is frightened & goes back home without the wood. (3) A wife tells her husband that the thread she had spun has turned into hemp (has burned, was lost) through his negligence: He should make sure that no birds fly over the house while she winds the thread. If they do, the thread will turn into shreds (be burned up). Or, when the thread is transported in a sack, the spindles disappear (the thread turns into shreds).
1499
1405*Woman Will Never WorkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA lazy woman (who does not want to spin) complains to her husband that there is no day on which she can work: Monday is rest day, Tuesday is exempt from work, Wednesday is for sleeping, Thursday is for no effort, Friday is Good Friday, Saturday is for bathing, & Sunday is for church.
1500
1406-Three Clever Wives WagerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThree wives wager which of them can best fool her husband. They play various tricks on their husbands, causing them to do foolish things. For example, one wife convinces her husband that he is sick, dead, a dog, a monk, (he retreats into a monastery), a minister (he preaches in a church), or that he should have a healthy tooth pulled. Another wife goes away for a week & convinces her husband it was only for a short time, that while he was absent, his house went elsewhere, or that he is wearing clothes when he is not.
1501
1406A*Women's Tricks are Better than Men'sAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man claims to understand all women’s tricks. A clever woman decides to prove he is wrong. (He makes disparaging remarks about women in the hearing of a clever girl, who seeks revenge.) She makes the arrogant man fall in love with her & tells him she is the daughter of the king. When the man asks the king for the hand of his daughter, the king insists that his daughter is ugly & sick, but the man woos her anyway, marries her, & then discovers that he has been tricked into marrying the wrong woman. On the condition that he keeps her secret, the clever woman helps him out of this difficulty: he should tell the king that he is a Gypsy. The king annuls the marriage with his daughter, & the man marries the clever woman.
1502
1407-The MiserAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman appears to eat nothing, but she does not lose weight. This appeals to a miserly man who decides to marry her. After some time he grows doubtful & spies on his wife. Instead of going to work, he hides in a cask (chimney). His mother-in-law arrives, sees where he is hiding, & tells her daughter she should pour hot water in the cask (light the hearth). When the husband re-covers from this injury, he is still distrustful & hides in bed to spy on his wife. His mother-in-law & his wife again know where he is & beat him.
1503
1407A"Everything!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA miserly man marries a woman who pretends to eat nothing. When her husband is away, she eats three chickens (two ducks, a huge meal). When he returns the husband learns how much she ate & becomes sick from anger. On his death bed, he can say only, “My wife, all three (two, every thing)...” The wife (other relatives) hears only “three” (“two”, “everything”) & thinks that he is bequeathing her three things (properties, everything he owns). In Swedish variants a miserly man (woman) becomes sick & sees that the maidservant takes too much to eat. The sick person wants to say that she had taken away everything from him, but can only produce the word, “Everything”, & this is understood to be his final will.
1504
1407A*Dream & RealityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man dreams that he is in a cave where he has sex with a naked woman. Afterwards, he comes to a place between two mole hills & attempts to relieve himself. His wife wakes him up & berates him, “It is all right for you to have sex with me, but I will not let you shit between my breasts!”
1505
1407BThe Great EaterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man who is invited to dinner eats an enormous amount of food. He apologizes for having eaten so little, saying he does not feel well today & that next time he will do better.
1506
1408-The Man who Does his Wife's WorkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis type is usually a framework into which other anecdotes of stupid people are set. Its basic form is as follows:Following a quarrel in which the husband complains that he works hard while his wife stays comfortably at home, a married couple agree to exchange work. Or, the husband (son) is unable to work outside. His wife (mother) must do the outdoor work for him, while he does the housework. Often, the wife gives her husband instructions about what work he should do. He does not pay attention & wastes half the day resting. The man tries to do several chores at once, & does everything wrong so that he suffers a series of accidents, e.g. he leans over the well while he is carrying the butterchurn on his back, so that the cream falls into the water, he lets wine or beer run out of the cask & throws flour on top of it to dry the floor, he lets the cow graze on the roof, bathes the baby in boiling water, or demands that the pots walk home by themselves, etc. When the wife returns home, she finds that her husband has made a mess & that everything is in chaos. The man admits that he had undervalued his wife’s work, & they agree that both of them should go back to their accustomed duties. Or, the couple do not become reconciled: the wife beats her husband & drives him away.
1507
1408BFault-Finding Husband NonplussedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband is hypercritical & nothing his wife does pleases him. In order to give him no grounds for complaint, the wife cooks several dishes for dinner. Each time he objects to what she serves him, she is able to produce a substitute dish. When he grows more & more unhappy, she asks him what he could like to eat. He says, ”I want to eat – shit!” Shortly before, their child had relieved himself on a tablecloth, so she readily gives her husband what he asked for.
1508
1408CThe String of ChickensAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA foolish husband is supposed to take care of the animals & the house while his wife is away. A hawk steals one of the chickens, so the wife beats her husband when she returns. When she goes away again, the husband vows to do better. He ties the chickens (and the chicks) all together with a string to protect them from predators. This enables the hawk to steal the whole flock at once.
1509
1409-The Obedient HusbandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises various tales (three subtypes) dealing with a husband who follows his wife’s instructions literally & without thinking. Examples: (1) A husband is so compliant that he hangs his wife, although she had only been trying to test his willingness to obey her commands. (2) A wife (who insists on cleanliness) tells her husband (who has tracked dirt into the house) that he should go away for a while. The husband takes this command literally & goes away for many days. Or, after some time, he sends his friend to ask his wife if he has been gone long enough yet. (3) A husband moves slowly at the request of his wife. Therefore he comes home only at dawn, after her lover is sure to have left.
1510
1409*The Woman Cooks the Dog for DinnerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife serves her husband cooked dog instead of a pig, because she ate the pig by herself. After the unsuspecting husband has finished eating, he looks for the dog as usual to give it the bones. His wife scoffs at him (tells him a wolf ate the dog).
1511
1410-Four Men's MistressAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA jealous husband accuses his wife of adultery and, in order to confirm his suspicions, disguises himself as a priest to hear her confession. Recognizing him, she confesses that she has slept with a servant, a knight, a fool, & a man of God. When her angry husband identifies himself to her, she explains that all of these were himself: at first he served her, then he went to war, then his jealousy turned him into a fool, & now as a priest he has heard her confession.
1512
1415-Lucky HansAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesHans works for seven years & receives a lump of gold as big as a man’s head as his pay & goes home. Because he finds it too heavy to carry, he trades the gold for a horse, which throws him because he does not know how to ride. He trades the horse for a cow, the cow for a hog, the hog for a goose, the goose for a whetstone, which through his awkwardness falls into a well. Unencumbered but happy, he arrives home.
1513
1416-The Mouse in the Silver JugAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA poor married couple bemoans life’s harshness & blame Adam & Eve who through their disobedience & curiosity brought sin into the world. The king (rich man) hears their complaint & invites the poor couple into his house to live in luxury. He stipulates only that they must not open any covered vessel. They cannot resist the temptation & remove the cover from a dish. A mouse jumps out (a bird flies out). The king reproves the disobedient couple & sends them back to their old way of life.
1514
1417-The Cut-off Nose (Hair)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife sends another woman to bed with her husband. The husband speaks to her & receives no answer, so he cuts off her nose (hair, braid). In the morning his wife still has her nose, & the husband believes that it grew back through a miracle (that he only dreamed he mutilated her).
1515
1418-The Equivocal OathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple Stories(Isolde’s Ordeal.) A (guilty) woman whose husband accuses her of adultery clears herself under oath & by ordeal (wearing a red-hot iron without being hurt) by means of a trick: She summons her lover, who appears disguised as a pilgrim (donkey driver) & carries her from the boat dock to the lawcourt. She makes sure that the two of them fall to the ground (she falls off the donkey) & her lover lands on top of her (sees under her skirt). At the trial, she swears honestly that no one except her husband & the pilgrim (driver) has ever lain on top of her (has ever seen her naked). Because what she swore under oath was true, she is not burned by the red-hot iron used for the ordeal.
1516
1418*The ConfessionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA young bride (wife) confesses to her bridegroom (husband) that she has had sexual relations with another man (has an illegitimate child, after her bride-groom had confessed to her that he too has an illegitimate child). The bridegroom complains to his prospective father-in-law (and leaves her). The two men send the mother to the bride to speak to her about the matter, & hide so that they can listen to the conversation. The bride confesses to her mother about her sexual experience (illegit-im ate child). Her mother tells her that she also had lovers before she was married (had three illegitimate children), but never told her hus band about them. (Her husband, overhearing, decides to follow his son-in-law & leave his wife.)
1517
1419-Returning Husband HoodwinkedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a husband who returns home to an adulterous wife, who further deceives him. Examples: (1) While her husband is absent a wife commits adultery with a servant (scribe, farmhand, cook, fisherman). The two are surprised by the husband’s sudden return. The wife tells her lover not to worry & to wait in the garden, & goes quickly to her husband. He suspects something is amiss & asks where the servant is. She sug-gests he should wear women’s clothes & go & look for him. The husband does so & finds the servant in the garden. The servant slaps him & tells him that a woman should not cheat on her husband. The husband is reassured & rewards the servant for his good morals. (2) When her husband comes home suddenly, a wife quickly hides her lover in a chest (featherbed, cupboard, suitcase). A betraying part of his body (clothing) hangs out, & she manages to warn him indirectly to pull it in. Later he escapes.
1518
1419AThe Husband in the Chicken HouseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband returns home unexpectedly to find his wife with her lover. The wife tells her husband someone is following him & convinces him to hide in the chicken coop (dovecot). She locks him in & spends the rest of the night with her lover. Her husband is grateful that she saved him from the supposed pursuer.
1519
1419BAnimal in the ChestAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband notices that his wife is having an affair. When the lover arrives, the husband catches him & traps him in a chest (cupboard, room). The husband takes the key & brings his wife’s relatives (friends) to show them the evidence. Meanwhile the wife frees her lover & substitutes a ram (donkey, dog, goat). When the husband comes back & opens the chest, the animal jumps out. (He believes that his wife has transformed her lover .) Ashamed, he asks his wife & the relatives to pardon him.
1520
1419COne-Eyed HusbandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband comes home unexpectedly, & his wife quickly hides her lover in a cupboard (under a bed, etc.). (1) (Linteus [the cloth] form.) The wife & her mother spread out a sheet (blanket, sack, trough) that obstructs the husband’s line of vision for a moment, so that the lover can escape. (2) (Oculus [the eye] form.) The husband has only one good eye, which the wife covers on some pretext (kiss, effort to treat either it or the other eye). Often she claims to have dreamed that his blind eye was cured.
1521
1419DLovers as Pursuer & FugitiveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA woman has two (more) lovers. When her husband comes home suddenly, she has one of them go outside with his sword drawn, & the other she hides in the house (she stages a struggle). The wife convinces her husband that she gave refuge to a persecuted fugitive. (The husband acts as a mediator.)
1522
1419EUnderground Passage to Lover's HouseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple Stories(Inclusa) A knight & a lady dream of each other & fall in love. He finds her in a tower behind ten locked doors. Her husband always keeps the key with him. The knight joins his service and, having earned his respect, is permitted to build a house next to the tower. The knight has a tunnel constructed between his house & the tower, & to ensure secrecy, he kills the architect. He is able easily to visit his lover, who gives him her ring. When the husband sees that the knight has this ring, he becomes suspicious. He goes quickly to his wife, who, because of the tunnel, now has the ring herself. Later the knight introduces the wife to her husband as his (i.e. the knight’s) wife. The husband again is suspicious, but, because of the tunnel, finds his wife back where she belongs. In the end the husband is so confused that he cannot recognize himself any more. He is tricked into marrying his wife off to the knight, without recognizing who she is. The couple escapes safely away on a ship.
1523
1419FHusband Frightened by Wife's Lover in Hog PenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesWhen a wife & her lover are surprised by her husband’s sudden return, she quickly puts her lover into the hog pen. When the husband hears suspicious noises, he calls out, “Who are you?” The lover grunts, “I am only a poor hog”. The husband thinks his hog is possessed by the devil (and runs away).
1524
1419GClergyman's BreechesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man unexpectedly comes home in order to get some warmer trousers. His wife gives him her lover’s trousers by mistake. This lover is a clergyman (shepherd, major, neighbor, butcher). Later she explains to her husband that she belongs to a religious order for which she has to wear such trousers.
1525
1419HWoman Warns Lover of Husband by Singing SongAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA wife has a lover who visits her regularly when her husband is away. One time her husband stays home unexpectedly. When the lover knocks on the door, the wife sings a lullaby in despair in which she warns him & tells him to go away. Or, when there is a knock on the door at night, the wife tells her husband it must be a ghost, & they both say prayers. The lover under stands the warning & goes away.
1526
1419J*Husband Sent for WaterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband comes home unexpectedly when his wife is with her lover. The lover hides & the wife pretends to be ill. She asks her husband to get her some water (medi cine, gin, an apple, etc.) which, she says, is the only thing that will cure her. After the husband goes out to get the water, the lover secretly escapes.
1527
1420-The Lover's Gift RegainedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis misc. type includes various tales dealing with a lover who gives a gift to his mistress & takes it back by means of a trick.
1528
1420AThe Broken (Removed) ArticleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man seduces a woman by means of a gift (jewelry, ring, coat, dress, silk, fur, fish, etc.). When he leaves, he (intentionally) breaks a glass (jug). When the husband returns, the visitor tells him that the wife has taken the object as compensation for the damage. The husband gives the gift back to the visitor.
1529
1420BHorse & Wagon as GiftAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA farmer, bringing a load of wood to a nobleman, gives his horse & wagon to the nobleman’s wife in re-turn for sexual favors. He tells her husband that she kept the horse & wagon because she found a bad piece of wood in the load. The husband lets him keep the horse & wagon.
1530
1420CBorrowing from the Husband & Returning to the WifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA lover borrows money from a husband & uses it to seduce the man’s wife. Later he tells the husband that he repaid the debt while the husband was away. He shows him evidence or tells him where to find the money. The wife has to give the money back to her husband.
1531
1420DAccidental Discovery of IdentityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man gives a woman money in order to seduce her. Later, he accidentally tells her husband about this. The husband forces his wife to restore the money.
1532
1420GBuying the GooseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA farmer selling a goose refuses to take money for it; instead, he wants to sleep with the woman who is buying it. The woman agrees & they sleep together. He refuses to give her the goose because, he says, she had more pleasure than he did for she had taken the upper position. After a second copulation in a different position, he claims that now they are even. While they are fighting about this, the woman’s husband comes & is told that they were quarreling about the price of the goose. He settles the fight by paying for the goose, & is thus doubly swindled.
1533
1422-Parrot Report's Wifes AdulteryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA parrot (another bird) tells a man that his wife is an adulteress. When the husband has to go on a journey, he orders the parrot to give him a report on his wife’s behavior when he returns. The wife & her maidservant plan a trick: in the night they pour water through a hole in the roof onto the parrot, throw things at him, blind him with mirrors, & make noise like thunder. When the husband returns, the weather has been fine, but the parrot complains about the thunderstorm. Hearing what he believes to be a falsehood, the angry husband disbelieves everything the parrot says, & kills him. In some variants the husband goes up on the roof & discovers evidence of the deceit. He forgives his wife, kills her, or falls into despair.
1534
1423-The Enchanted Pear TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesWith her husband nearby, a wife climbs up a tree ostensibly to pick fruit but really to meet her lover. The rest of the anecdote follows one of two patterns: (1) Although the husband sees his wife together with her lover, she convinces him that this was an optical illusion caused by the magic power of the tree (window, other objects). (2) The husband is old & blind & therefore very suspicious & jealous. In his delusion of love he embraces the trunk of the tree in order to protect his wife’s virtue from the eyes of passersby. At the critical moment, God (Jesus, Jupiter, St. Peter) restores his eye sight. He cries out in surprise, & his wife realizes what has happen ed. She assuages his anger by pointing out that her arborial adultery provided the means of restoring his eyesight.
1535
1424-Friar Adds Missing NoseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple Stories(fingers) to unborn child. A clergyman (neighbor, friend) seduces a pregnant woman by telling her that her fetus has not been constructed properly by her husband. He offers to add the missing parts (nose, ears, head, limbs) for her. In some variants, the tale continues: When the husband returns home, he thanks the clergyman for his help. Or, the husband takes revenge by inviting the clergyman & his daughter to dinner. He steals the daughter’s ring & convinces that it has gone inside her body. He offers to retrieve it by having sex with her, & she agrees.
1536
1424*Wife Recovers What Her Husband First Found & Then LostAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man finds money which he gives to a beggar. (His wife spends the money. When her husband returns home, he falls into despair & wants to divorce her because of her stupidity.) His wife takes her son & follows the beggar in order to get the money back. She spends the night with the beggar, pretending to be a widow & that she & her child have vulgar names. During the night she takes the money & goes home. The beggar follows her, calling the vulgar names, which makes the passersby think he is insane.
1537
1425-Putting the Devil into HellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesAn innocent young woman asks how she should serve God, & is told that she should avoid earthly pleasures. She goes into the wilderness where she finds a hermit & asks him what she must do to lead a pious life. The hermit tells her about God’s greatest enemy, the devil, whom people who love God must send back down to hell. He tells her his penis is the devil, & that instead of a devil she has a hell. Thus she is seduced into helping him send the devil into hell, believing that this will serve God.
1538
1425B*Why the Seventh Child has Red HairAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA dying husband asks his wife why six of their children have hair alike, but only the seventh has red hair. If the seventh’s father is someone else? “No, only seventh is yours”, explains the wife.
1539
1426-The Wife Kept in a Box.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesTwo brothers (kings, knight & king, friends) discover that their wives have lovers. Hoping to distance themselves from this problem, the brothers set out on a journey. They meet a man (fakir, demon, etc.) who carries a small case (shrine) with him. When the man takes a rest, he opens the case & a beautiful woman comes out. The couple enjoy themselves & the man goes to sleep. The woman then seduces the two travelers. (Or, she also releases a lover from such a case that she carried with her.) So the brothers (the man himself) realize that even a well-guarded woman can betray her husband, & go back home knowing that there is no way to prevent women’s treachery.
1540
1429*Remedy for QuarrelsomenessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA husband whose wife continually quarrels with him beats her. A passerby (healer, old woman, magician, hermit) gives her some “magic water”. As long as she keeps it in her mouth, she stops quarreling.
1541
1430-Man & His Wife Build Air CastlesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A poor married couple (father & son, two brothers, herds-men, maidservants, other people) plan to turn their possessions (glassware, milk, honey, eggs, money) into great wealth (herds of animals, houses). As they imagine this wealth, they destroy what they already have. (2) A person (poor man, hunter, Gypsy, married couple) dreams of having a valuable possession (catch from hunting, etc.), which he then tries to obtain. His efforts fail because he imagines his success (e.g. the hunter is so excited that he frightens his prey). (3) A married couple (other people) imagine that they will obtain the means to achieve future wealth, but they disagree about how to manage it. One wants to keep reinvesting the future profits, while the other wants to enjoy part of the wealth.
1542
1430AFoolish Concerns for an Unborn ChildAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA married couple make plans for their future child. While they discuss what they want to do for this child, whom to invite to the birth, how the child should be raised, whether to let the child ride on a donkey, etc., they get into a serious quarrel.
1543
1431-Contagious YawnsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA man notices that his wife & a farmhand yawn one after the other, & sees in this evidence of adultery. Plan-ning to hang his supposedly-unfaithful wife, he takes a rope & goes with her into the forest. He runs from one tree to another, trying to find one suitable for his purpose. The wife follows him & says that he behaves just like a rabbit (squirrel, bird) jumping all around. She tells him that his behavior is just like people’s yawns, which go from one person to another. This cures the husband of his suspicions, & the couple go back home together.
1544
1435*The Cuckoo Calls from Inside the CaskAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA nobleman courts a farm-er’s daughter. When he comes to take her away, he cannot find her because she hides from him. After he has searched for her with no success, he hears a voice from inside a cask calling “Cuckoo!” He finds her & takes her away. In older variants, an abbess hides a nun from a knight. The knight looks for her but soon gives up his search. She tells him where she is by calling “Cuckoo!” After their tryst, the knight abandons the nun.
1545
1437-A Sweet WordAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1350-1439 Married Couple StoriesA dying woman asks her husband (son) to say something sweet. He replies, “Honey”. Or a man who has been told to discipline only with good words hits his wife on the head with a prayer book. In some variants, a simple man (husband) is told to speak only round, i.e. good, words (to speak about big & deep, i.e. wise, things). He names only round (big & deep) objects.
1546
1440-Substituted AnimalAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanA tenant farmer (neighbor, miller) promises his beautiful daughter against her will to his master. On the wedding day the master sends a farmhand to take “that which was promised to him”. The father sends him to the field where the daughter is at work, & she gives the messenger a mare. His master tells him to take that which he brought into the bedroom (the mare is dressed as a bride & put into the bed). In some variants the daughter calls herself (the father calls his daughter) “Mrs. Donkey” (“Mrs. Horse”) by ruse. When the master asks for “Mrs. Donkey”, the messenger brings a real donkey.
1547
1441*Old Woman SubstituteAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanA man (priest) pays to be permitted to spend the night beside a young woman. She acts bashful & nervous, so he agrees to come in the dark. The next morning, he finds beside him an ugly old woman (wooden figure, heap of excrements).
1548
1441A*The Inked GirlAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanA young woman is brought to an old man to spend the night with him. During the night she smears herself with black The next morning, when the man sees the black face beside him, he thinks he has slept with the devil.
1549
1441B*Godfather & GodmotherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanA godfather would like to have an affair with a godmother. She agrees to meet him in the barn but sends her husband to meet him. The godfather says he only wants some straw. The same thing happens in the pigsty (sheep or cow stall), & the godfather tells the husband that he heard he had piglets to sell. The godmother invites her suitor into the house & he hides in the oven. When the husband finds him there, he says he was only measuring it. Finally the suitor turns up in their bed, & he claims he is there because he made a bet that the husband does not have two testicles (is circumcised).
1550
1443*Pillow Too HighAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanAn unmarried man & woman meet on their journeys & spend the night together in a single room. They sleep in the same bed with a pillow between them. The next day, the woman’s hat is blown over a wall (hedge). When the man goes to get it for her, she objects, “No, if you could not climb over the pillow last night, you certainly can’t climb over this wall!”
1551
1446-"Let them eat cake!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanWhen the queen was told that the poor people had no bread, she answered, “Let them eat cake!”
1552
1447-Drinking Only after a BargainAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanA man & a woman swear to each other not to drink any wine except on market day. Then they open their own market where they sell their own donkey to each other. Or a woman swears to drink only after concluding a bargain. She sells & buys the same wares many times in one day.
1553
1447A*Selling Wine to Each OtherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanTwo men (husband & wife) sell small quantities of schnapps (wine) to each other always for the same coin. Each time, the buyer drinks the glass of schnapps. In the end they have only the single coin as payment for the entire cask (and they believe they have been robbed).
1554
1448*Burned & Underbaked BreadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1440-1524 Stories about a WomanIn order to rid herself of her old father-in-law, a woman gives him hard, burned bread to eat. Instead of starving, he grows healthier. Then she gives him soft, underbaked bread, & he soon dies.
1555
1449*The Stingy Hostess at the InnAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA stingy woman (innkeeper, house-wife, farmwife) says that her guests are welcome to eat whatever they want, but unfortunately she has no spoons to give them. A clever man brings his own spoon (the needed spoons).
1556
1450-Clever ElsieAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA (supposed) suitor visits the family of a marriageable young woman. Her parents send her to the cellar to fetch something for the visitor to drink. While drawing the drink the woman grows despondent over the fate of a child she might have after she is mar-ried. She worries about his cradle or his name, or weeps because she fears he will be killed by a tool (hammer, knife, hoe, stone) that may fall down on him, or an illness that may kill him. Her parents come to see what is the matter with their daughter. She tells them her worries & they too begin to weep. Meanwhile all the drink pours out of the cask, & the suitor leaves the house.
1557
1451-The Thrifty GirlAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA thrifty young woman weaves herself a dress from flax that her sister carelessly dropped on the floor. When the sister’s suitor learns of this, he leaves the lazy sister & marries the thrifty one.
1558
1452-Thrifty Cutting of CheeseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor wants to be sure he marries a good wife. He observes three young women (sisters) eating cheese (apples). The first eats the cheese with its rind. The second cuts the rind off, but discards some good cheese as well. He chooses (his mother advises him to marry) the third sister because she is careful & thrifty, & discards only the rind.
1559
1453-Key in Flax Reveals LazinessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor puts a key into the flax which a seemingly-industrious young woman (according to her mother’s or her own statement) is about to spin into thread. On a later day he finds the key still there, & thus knows that the woman is lazy. Or, a suitor tests three young women. Only the youngest finds the key that he has hidden in the flax, so she is the one whom he marries.
1560
1453**The Slovenly FianceeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor who wants to choose a bride sees a young woman who bakes (cooks) while a drop is hanging from her nose. He decides to marry her only if the drop does not fall. When it falls into the dough (bowl), he leaves. Or, the suitor has come to find out whether or not the young woman is a neat housekeeper.
1561
1453***Three-Weeks-Old DoughAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor discovers that his fiancée still has dough under her fingernails three weeks after she last baked. He decides not to marry her. (He chooses a young woman with proper fingernails.) In some variants the suitor remarks that he has not been able to find seven-year-old mash, which was prescribed for him as medicine. The mother of his fiancée tells him they have old mash adhering to their pots & pans. The suitor leaves.
1562
1453****The Flatulent GirlAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman (wife) who farts easily creates embarrassing situations. A suitor observes her secretly & counts her farts. Or, she tries to cure her problem by stopping up her backside with the alarm whistle of the fire department. As she dances, the whistle plays, & the other people think a fire has broken out. In some variants, the shoemaker’s wife farts so horribly that her husband stops up her backside with tar & leather. To prevent her from bursting, he makes a small hole in the leather with his awl. This is the origin of organ pipes (wind instruments).
1563
1453AThe Fast WeaverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman boasts to her suitor that she can weave very fast. While the suitor watches, she weaves so fast that she drops the shuttle.
1564
1453B*The Wedding That Did Not Take PlaceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeOn the way to the wedding the bridegroom steps into a puddle & soils the dress of his bride. Angry, she refuses to marry him. Later they try again to have the wedding, but this time the bridegroom balks. By the third time, the mayor (clergyman) refuses to officiate.
1565
1454*The Greedy FianceeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman is visited by her suitor (s). Her mother brags that she can finish three portions per day. The suitor thinks (is meant to think) that this refers to her ability to spin. How-ever, he sees that the young woman is eating from several dishes at once. He does not want to have a wife with such an appetite, so he leaves.
1566
1455-The Hard-hearted FianceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA father-in-law disguises himself as a beggar & visits the house of his future daughter-in-law. He finds the house ill-kept, & the woman treats him badly. (He advises his son not to marry her.)
1567
1456-The Blind FianceeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman of marriageable age is blind (half blind, nearsighted). When a suitor visits her, the young woman & her mother try to trick him into overlooking the daughter’s dis-ability. The mother hides a nail somewhere (in the hay, on the floor) where the daughter can pretend to find it. Later, the daughter reveals her poor vision by mistaking the butter (coffee pot) for the cat & shooing it off the table. The suitor leaves. In some variants the suitor asks her to kiss him & presents his naked backside for the kiss.
1568
1456*The Blind Girl & her FianceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor leads his blind fiancée around her house (in the forest, through the swamp) & steals her posses-sions. Or a doctor treating the eyes of a nearly-blind woman steals all her possessions. When he leaves, she refuses to pay for her treatment. She insists that she could see better before her treatment, because then she was able to see the things in her house.
1569
1457-The Lisping MaidenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeIn order not to reveal their speech impediments, sisters are forbidden by their mother to speak to a suitor who has come to visit them. The daughters forget & speak, thus exposing their speech defects.
1570
1457*Stutterer Goes MatchmakingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA stutterer is going to be married (is a matchmaker). As he goes to the young woman’s house, he is advised not to speak if possible. At the table, he notices that the po tatoes are about to burn (that he has no spoon). He begins to speak & reveals his stutter. The marriage is canceled.
1571
1458-The Girl Who Ate So LittleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a Wifemother boasts that her daughter eats very little. Her suitor observes the daughter as she cooks or bakes & sees that this is not true. Or, the fiancée, who claims that she eats hardly any bread, drinks extra wine.
1572
1458*The Careless CookAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young wife cooks food that is always full of lumps (garbage). She explains to her husband (mother-in-law, guests) that what he found in the food is not a lump, but her child’s sock.
1573
1459*The Suitor Takes Offense at a WordAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeThe Suitor Takes Offense at a Word used by the girl. A suitor takes of fense at the woman wooed by him (at something she says), but then thinks better of it.
1574
1459**Keeping Up AppearancesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor visits a poor farm. The family (the potential bride or bridegroom) desperately try to pretend that they are rich (they refer to their one cow as cattle, play other word games). The suitor discovers the truth.
1575
1460-The Big JumpAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA princess wants to marry whichever boy is able to jump over a haystack so big that she cannot urinate over it. The boy has sexual intercourse with her & easily performs the feat because the young woman has lost her unusual ability along with her maiden head.
1576
1461-The Girl with the Ugly NameAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman is ashamed of her ugly name. Her mother gives her a prettier one. When she addresses her daughter by her new name, the daughter does not respond, so the mother has to revert to using the old name.
1577
1462-The Unwilling Suitor Advised from the TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman whose suitor hesitates to propose to her wants to hurry him along. She hides behind a tree and, pretending to be an angel, advises the man that he should get married. The man obeys the divine command & marries the young woman.
1578
1463-Finger-Drying Contest Won by DeceptionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeThree young women dip their hands in water. Whichever of them has the hands that are the first to dry will be the first to marry. The clever youngest insists that she does not want to marry, & waves her hands in the air to emphasize this. Thus her hands dry the quickest & she wins the contest.
1579
1463A*Foolish Bride Gives Away Her DowryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor & a matchmaker visit a foolish young woman whose parents are not at home. The young woman follows her mother’s advice literally & gives the visitors her dower.
1580
1464C*Good HousekeepingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA suitor comes to visit three sisters although their house has not been cleaned. The first two sisters apologize for the disorder, but the third cleans the room for him. He marries the third.
1581
1464D*Nothing to CookAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman tells her suitor that she cannot cook. “That doesn’t matter”, he says, “because I have nothing to cook anyway”.
1582
1465A*The Concentrated WasherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA mother seeks a suitable wife for her son. She decides on a young woman who does nothing else when she washes.
1583
1468-Money in the BibleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeThe king visits the house of a man (family mem-bers) who complains about his poverty. The king asks whether he reads the Bible regularly, & the man says yes, he is a great Bible reader. The king secretly puts some money inside the poor man’s Bible. On his next visit, it is still there.
1584
1468*Marrying a StrangerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeA young woman worries about her approach-ing marriage. When her mother tries to reassure her, the daughter replies, “It was easy for you because you married father, but I have to marry a stranger”.
1585
1470-Misc. Bride TestsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1450-1474 Looking for a WifeMisc. type with diverse variants.
1586
1475-Marriage Forbidden Outside the ParishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsA proclamation is read in church that says that it is forbidden for any young man to marry a young woman from another parish (that the men are required to marry the local old maids).
1587
1476-Prayer for a HusbandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid prays to God (saint) for a husband. The sexton (the wished-for husband) hides behind the altar (saint’s statue) & tells her (pretending to be God) to put her foot on her neck (to denude herself) or to do something else that puts her in an shameful situation.
1588
1476APrayer to Christ Child's MotherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid prays to a statue of the Virgin Mary, asking her to grant her a husband. Hidden behind the statue, a man (sexton) answers that this cannot be. The old maid tells the baby Jesus to keep quiet, she had been speaking to his mother who will be more sympathetic to her request. In some variants a saint does not answer the prayer of a certain woman. The woman curses him or takes violent revenge on his picture (statue).
1589
1476BOld Maid Married to a DevilAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid who is tired of living alone cries out in despair, “I would even marry the devil, if he would have me!” The devil comes & carries her off (marries her). Or as she lies down hoping to die. A trickster climbs into her bed & she enjoys the sensation of “sweet death”.
1590
1477-The Wolf HusbandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid wants to marry regardless of who her husband is. A wolf (bear) passes by (is brought by). She takes him for her husband (and he eats her).
1591
1478-Nibbling the NailsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid wants to get married. A man promises to marry her if she is able to nibble (three) nails (beans, nuts). After a while he asks her if she has nibbled the nails yet? “We can get married now”, she replies, “After the one in my mouth I’ve only two more to go”.
1592
1479*Old Maid on the RoofAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid courts a young man. He promises to marry her if she will spend the entire night naked (lightly clothed) on the roof of the house (another place). While waiting she repeats a saying again & again, freezes to death & falls down from the roof.
1593
1485*Pretty LipsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsA mother tells her old maid daughter to say “Tirlipp” repeatedly, to keep her lips pretty.
1594
1485A*Old Maid Wants to Attract AttentionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsAn old maid complains that she goes to church but no man has ever taken notice of her. Her father advises her to wear a dog’s collar or a wreath of twigs around her neck. She follows this advice & reports back that everyone in church stared at her & even laughed.
1595
1486*The Daughter Talks Too LoudAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsA mother advises her unmarried daughter to keep her mouth half closed in front of her suitors. The daughter does so but speaks even more loudly.
1596
1488-Misc. Tales of Old MaidsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1475-1499 Jokes About Old MaidsMisc. type with diverse variants.
1597
1501-Aristotle & PhyllisAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman StoriesAn aged philosopher (Aristotle) warns his stu-dent (Alexander the Great) against letting himself be dominated by his wife. Alexander withdraws from his wife (Phyllis, Roxane, Candacis, Campaspe). In revenge the neglected queen makes the phil-osopher fall in love with her & he pursues her with proposals.Pretending to woo him, she demands that he crawls on his hands & knees & let her ride on his back. Alexander surprises Aristotle in this undignified position. Ashamed, the philoso-pher an swers quickly that he was trying to warn Alexander against such fool ishness. Alexander forgives Aristotle & continues to follow his teachings (Aristotle is so ashamed that he has to leave the country).
1598
1503*The Daughter-in-Law & the Real DaughterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman StoriesA mother favors her own daughter, whom she thinks is more diligent than her daughter-in-law, although actually the reverse is true. For example she praises her daughter for spinning a big spool every week, & she criticizes her daughter-in-law for spinning only one small spool per day. She does not see that seven small spools are more than one big one.
1599
1510-Matron of EphesusAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman Stories(Vidua.) A woman mourns her dead husband by his grave (in his tomb, in a house nearby) & is completely inconsolable. Near the cemetery a soldier (knight) guards a gallows on which a man has been hanged. One cold night the soldier leaves his post & visits (spends the night with) the widow. When he returns, he finds that the corpse which he was supposed to guard has been stolen. In order to prevent him from being punished, the widow offers to have her husband’s body exhumed & substituted for the one on the gallows (the soldier proposes this). (The soldier promises to marrry her. The woman knocks her husband’s teeth out, in order to make the body like that of the stolen corpse. The soldier punishes the woman for her callousness by refusing to marry her.
1600
1511*Advice of the BellsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman StoriesA woman (widow) who wants to marry her farmhand asks the priest what he thinks of this idea. He advises her to listen to the bells. She believes they recommend the marriage. Her husband turns out to be a heavy drinker, & the wife complains to the priest. He advises her again to listen to the bells. Now these tell her not to marry the farmhand, but it is too late. In some variants, it is a young man who listens to the advice of the bells. His wife’s obstinate nature makes his life difficult. In the end he manages to subdue her.
1601
1512*ConsolationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman StoriesA clergyman visits a woman whose husband has recently died. He advises her to seek consolation for her grief in the Bible. She points to her husband’s trousers hanging on the wall & says, “There are his trousers, but there is no consolation in them any more”. (Or, “No book can give consolation like what was in those trousers used to”.)
1602
1515-The Weeping BitchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman Stories(Catala.) A merchant (knight) goes on a journey (pilgrimage). He leaves his faithful wife alone & unsupervised. A young man falls in love with her, but she rejects his advances. Sick with love, he goes to an old woman (nun) who promises to help. The old woman gives her female dog nothing to eat for two days, & on the third day gives it food cooked with mustard (pepper), which makes its eyes water. The old woman (often disguised as a nun or dervish) takes this “weeping” dog with her to visit the wife whom the young man loves. When the wife asks what is the matter with the dog, the old woman at first does not reply. Then she tells the wife that the dog is actually her daughter (sister), who turn ed into an animal because she did not reciprocate a man’s love. The young wife believes this false story & asks the old woman to ar range a meeting for her with the young man. The go-between cannot find the lovesick young man but does not want to lose her payment for arranging the meeting. She meets a man (who happens to be the husband, returning home) & offers him an assignation. When the wife recognizes her husband, she berates him & accuses him of adulterous intentions. She pretends to have set up the situation as a test. Thus she is exonerated, her hus band is made to seem to be an adulterer, & the old woman loses her payment.
1603
1516*Marriage as PurgatoryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1500-1524 Other Woman StoriesThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A dead man would rather remain in purgatory than return to his quarrelsome wife on earth (would rather not go to heaven because he does not want to be with his wife). (2) A shepherd compares his own sorry situation with the crucifixion: Christ suffered on the cross for only a few hours. Being mar-ried would have been a real punishment for him, especially if he had had children & no money to buy them presents for Easter. (3) An old man comes to the door of heaven & St. Peter asks him what he did on earth. He answers that he was married. Peter lets him come right in because he already suffered his time in purgatory. A second man, who overheard this exchange, also wants to enter heaven. He tells Peter that he was married twice. Peter tells him that there is no place in heaven for such fools. (4) A priest demands payment from a man for having performed his marriage. The man proposes that he “unmarry” him instead.
1604
1525-The Master ThiefAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManMisc. type. This type refers to a cycle of related tales & is not clearly specified.
1605
1525ATasks for a ThiefAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA good-for-nothing young man from a poor family learns the craft of stealing & comes home as a master thief. He (his father) boasts about his skill in front of the earl (godfather), who demands (usually) three tests. (1) The master thief steals a horse (dog) out of a closely-guarded stall. He disguises himself as an old woman (beggar) & gives liquor (a drug) to the farmhands (guards, soldiers) to make them sleep. (2) He steals the bedcover (shirt) & wedding ring of the earl’s wife. He contrives that the earl shoots a corpse (straw man) & goes to bury the body. The thief tells the earl’s wife that the earl needs the blanket & ring for the corpse. (3) He traps the priest & the sexton in a sack & puts candles on the backs of crabs. The men take him for an angel & the lights for wandering souls. He carries the sack to the goose house (hangs it in the bell tower or chimney). After these tests, the master thief is banished from the country (pardoned, rewarded).
1606
1525BThe Horse StolenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A thief pretends to show how a horse can be stolen, but actually he steals the horse himself. In some variants something else is stolen (shoes, clothing, a watch, dishes, purse, meat, etc.) (2) In a German version the horse is stolen in a different way. A rider meets a poor beggar who asks him to retrieve his crutch, which a prankster (bad boy) had hung up in a tree. When the rider climbs the tree, the pretended cripple jumps on his horse & rides away.
1607
1525CFishing in the StreetAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA traveler (travelers) watches a man fishing in the street. The companions of the fisherman meanwhile rob the traveler’s wagon.
1608
1525DTheft by Distracting AttentionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master thief (apprentice) steals an ox (ram) of a farmer (farmhand) who is going to market. The thief drops first one, then the other, of a pair of matched objects (shoes, boots, sword & sheath, knife & fork) in the road. The farmer passes by the first object but, when he sees the second, he goes back for the first, leaving his animal behind. The thief takes the animal. Other tricks are also used to distract the farmer’s attention: the master thief pretends to hang himself in the forest (pretends to be dead). Or he imitates the cry of the farmer’s animal or sets a rabbit (chicken) free. In other variants one of the thieves takes the bell off a sheep that is following a donkey. He ties the bell to the donkey’s tail & steals the sheep. A second thief steals the donkey by offering to take care of it while the owner goes to look for his missing sheep.
1609
1525EThieves Steal from One AnotherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThieves (robbers) test their expertise through a contest in which they steal from each other. Or a new member of a band of robbers has to demonstrate his skill & outdoes his teacher. This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) One thief steals an egg out of a bird’s nest without disturbing the bird. A second thief steals the same egg from the breast (pants pocket) of the first, or steals the trousers (shoe soles) off him while he climbs up to get the egg. Or the first thief takes off his cloth in or-der to get the egg, & the second thief steals the cloth. (2) Two thieves steal a ham (butchered hog, goat) from the wife of a former member of their band. This man steals the ham from them, & finally they steal it back again. (3) Two thieves trick each other. First, they exchange supposed-ly valuable sacks which turn out to contain only worthless things (sand, hay, etc.). Next, they exchange jobs (tending an un manageable cow, carrying water in a leaky pot, etc.) because each thinks the other’s work is easier, & both come to grief. Together they find (steal) a treasure & each tries to trick the other out of his share. One hides in a chest, & the other, believing it to be full of gold, carries it home.
1610
1525GThief in DisguiseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master thief, in order to vindicate himself & his deceased mother in the eyes of the king (his father), disguises himself (as Shiva, fakir, woman, etc.) & steals repeatedly from the king.
1611
1525H4The Youth in the BeehiveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA boy (thief, boaster, fool, Eulenspiegel, couple) hides (falls asleep drunk) in an empty beehive. Two thieves come at night to steal the bees & weigh all the hives. Believing that the heaviest is the best, they carry off the one with the boy in it. He pulls the hair of one of them, who gets angry at his companion for bothering him. Then the boy pulls the hair of the other thief, who also blames his companion. The boy continues this until the thieves put down the hive to fight each other. In some variants the boy (man) does not bother the thieves. They take the hive & build a fire under it. When the boy cries out, they are frightened & run away.
1612
1525JThieves Cheated of their BootyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) An uncle & his nephew (grandfather & grandson, group of thieves) steal an ox (sheep) & roast it. The nephew (apprentice thief) wants to keep all the meat for himself. He takes the hide to a waterhole. Hiding in the bushes, he beats the hide as if he himself were being beaten. He cries & shouts that it was not he but his uncle who stole the ox. The uncle thinks that the boy has been caught, so he runs away. In some variants the thieves cut the tail (head) off the ox (sheep) & stick it in the mouth (backside) of another, so that it looks as if one ox has eaten the other. Or they put the severed part in a swamp. When the owner swims out to get his drowned animal, they steal his clothes. (2) A boy (woman) tells a passing thief (soldier) that he has lost a silver cup (pail, etc.) in the well (river), & asks him to get it back for him. The thief takes off his clothes, climbs in the well, & finds nothing. When he comes back up, he finds that his clothes have been stolen.
1613
1525KUbiquitous BeggarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA beggar manages to obtain alms from the same person three (twenty-one) times by wearing various disguises.
1614
1525K*Awarding the Stolen PropertyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo thieves steal something valuable (fur coat, crown, cup) & dispute over how to divide it. At night one of them climbs into the bedroom of the owner (judge, lord of the manor) & tells him what happened in his dream. The owner gives him a deci sion in his sleep as to who should keep the object. Meanwhile the second thief robs the storeroom (pantry) of the owner.
1615
1525LCreditor Falsely Reported Insane When He Demands MoneyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA hard-hearted merchant sends an assistant several times to (unwarrant edly) collect payment from a debtor. The debtor reports that the assistant is mentally deranged. The man is locked in an abbey where he is treated with prayers & holy relics. He resists these measures & is beaten. The merchant forgives the debt when he is threatened with the same treatment.
1616
1525L*Theft Commited While Tale is ToldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo (three) thieves steal from a man (woman). While one of them accomplishes the theft, the other relates a tale that describes what is actually happening. With the victim thus distracted, his com-panion can work without being noticed. In another version, one thief performs a song (dance) that tells his companion where to find the booty.
1617
1525MSheep in the CradleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (farmer) steals (secretly kills) a sheep (hog). He is denounced by a neighbor (owner) & has to hide the animal. He wraps it in clothing (cloth) & lays it in a cradle as if it were a (sick) baby (in bed as if it were his brother, sets it on a toilet). The police (authorities) come looking for the stolen animal, but do not recognize it. In some variants a living pig is hidden in a cradle & is discovered when it squeals. In other variants a farmer smuggles a slaughtered hog wearing his wife’s clothes through a guarded gate (a stolen sheep is dressed & propped up at the rudder of a boat.
1618
1525N*Theft of Butter by CompanionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier weighs a stingy farmer (teaches him how to fish with a chisel). Meanwhile a companion of the soldier steals the farmer’s butter (fish).
1619
1525QTwo Thieves Married to the Same WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo thieves (day & night thieves, burglar & pickpocket) are both married to the same woman. When they discover this, they fight over her. They go to a judge or to the woman who decides that they should have a contest to see which of them is the better thief, & he will keep the woman as his wife. In some variants, one (the less able) thief breaks into the bedroom of his ruler & tells him his story. The ruler decides that the woman should belong to this thief.
1620
1525RThe Robber BrothersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo older brothers refuse to take their stupid youngest brother on their thieving expeditions. The youngest brother hurries out before them & arranges with their intended victim to be paid to guard his belongings against theft. When the older brothers break in, the youngest, without being recognized, beats them, & they return home empty-handed. This happens twice. The third time the brothers take the youngest with them. Instead of valu-ables, he carries off the owner’s door.
1621
1525Z*Other Tales of TheftsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManMisc. type with diverse variants.
1622
1526-The Old Beggar & the RobbersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManSwindlers (thieves, Gypsies, female trickster) dress a beggar (foolish farmer) as a noble lord. (They take him to an inn & pretend to be his servants.) They steal from one or more merchants by saying that their master will pay for what they take (they say they will get money from their master). Leaving the man hostage in the inn or with the merchants, the swindlers leave with their spoils. The “noble” lord is discovered to be a beggar. He is either punished or permitted to leave.
1623
1526ASupper Won by a TrickAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThree (four) tricksters (thieves, students, soldiers) want some supper. They have no money, so they obtain their food through (three) successive tricks. Usually someone else has to pay for their food. In some variants a single trickster gets a free meal through one of various tricks, e.g. by pretending that he is an invited guest.
1624
1526A**Waiting Until the Tower FallsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo men (students, farmhands) in an inn look out of the window & see that the churchtower is lopsided. They wager as to which side the tower will fall toward, to east or to west. The loser has to pay for the meal (wine). They enjoy their meal. When later the innkeeper asks for the payment they tell him, he has to wait until the tower falls.
1625
1527-Robbers are Tricked into FleeingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master covers his farmhand (workman) with tar & feathers (honey & wool) & takes him to the robbers’ house. The robbers are frightened & run away, leaving their treasure behind.
1626
1527*Night Lodging RequisitionedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThree travelers need a place to spend the night. After they are turned away by an innkeeper, one of them climbs up to the roof & stops the chimney with his coat, so that the inn fills with smoke. (The other guests leave and) the innkeeper lets the travelers stay there (for free).
1627
1527AThe Robber DisarmedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A boy in the forest comes upon a robber who takes his sword & robs him. The boy asks the robber to cut off his hand, to make it appear that the boy had fought to defend himself. When the robber swings the sword, the boy pulls his hand back & the sword be comes stuck in a tree trunk. The boy pulls the sword out & kills the robber. (2) A robber attacks a farmer (merchant) & takes his money. The victim asks the robber to shoot his hat (clothes) so that it will appear that the robber had to use considerable force. When the robber has used up all his ammunition, the farmer chases him away with his stick.
1628
1528-Holding Down the HatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A merchant is chasing a thief who stole from him. Disguised as a farmer, the thief stands by the side of the road pretending to be guarding a valuable falcon which he has hidden under his hat. When the merchant comes by, the “farmer” offers to chase the thief, if the merchant will guard the falcon & lend him his horse. The merchant pays him for helping, & the thief keeps the horse in addition. (2) A man defecates by the side of a road & covers the pile with his hat. When a priest comes by, the man explains that he has caught a beautiful bird. He sells the “bird” to the priest with the condition that he should not pick up the hat until the man is out of sight. After the man has left, the priest reaches under the hat to grasp the bird, & finds only a handful of feces.
1629
1529-Thief as DonkeyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA clever thief (student, beggar, traveling monk) steals a donkey (horse, mule, ox, cow) that had been tied up (to a tree or hedge, behind a wagon) or saddled or yoked. He leaves his compan-ion in place of the stolen animal. The companion convinces the owner (farmer, minister, pilgrim) that he had been turned into the animal as a punishment for his sins (for cursing his father or mother). The period of his punishment is now over & he has become human again. The owner of the animal believes this & lets him go free (and often apologizes for having beaten or insulted him, & gives him hospitality or money). The owner goes to buy a new donkey at the market, where he finds his old animal. Believing that this is his acquaintance, the owner reproaches him for having sinned again, & refuses to buy the animal.
1630
1529A*Exchange of HorsesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A gentleman agrees to exchange his good horse for the poor horse of a farmer, provided the farmer will eat its dung. The farmer does so & discovers valuables in the dung. (2) A gentleman (Englishman) agrees to give a farmer (Russian) a cow (his fortune) if the farmer will eat a frog. The farmer succeeds in eating half, & offers the other half to the gentleman to eat if he wants to keep the cow (the Russian fulfills the condition but the Englishman cannot; so he does not get back his fortune).
1631
