1529B*Wolf-Hunting SheepAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer sells a gentleman (pope) a sheep (goat) which supposedly hunts wolves. The wolves devour the sheep.
1632
1530-Holding up the RockAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA dupe puts his shoulder under a huge rock (tree, stationary animal) & pretends to hold it up. He persuades a passerby (fool, shepherd) to take his place (so he can go & get a drink of water) & then runs away with the passerby’s horse (belongings, animals).
1633
1530*The Man & his DogsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man has two (three) dogs with peculiar names, e.g. “Shepherd” & “Get-the-Stick”. When the man calls his dogs, a thief (thieves) believes he has been discovered & will be beaten (caught). He runs away.
1634
1531-Lord for a DayAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA rich man (ruler) orders that a drunken farmer (a merchant who has been drugged into sleep) be brought into his house. He dresses him in fine clothes & feeds him well (and lets him perform the rich man’s duties). After a day (an hour, three years) the farmer is taken in his sleep back to his old house. He thinks he has been in heaven (has dreamed it all. He is no longer satisfied with his old position).
1635
1532-The Voice from the GraveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo swindlers hear of a wealthy man who has died recently. One of them takes the dead man’s place & is buried (hides near the grave). The other finds the relatives of the dead man & tells them that the man had borrowed a large amount of money from him. Asking that they repay the money, he suggests that they verify the debt by asking the dead man. They do so & the confederate answers from his hiding place that the debt must be paid. The swindler who takes the money goes away, leaving his confederate still buried in the ground.
1636
1533-The Wise Carving of the FowlAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A poor man (farmer, clever man) brings his master (ruler) a chicken (dove, goose, etc.) as a present. The master asks him to divide the bird appropriately among the members of his household. The poor man gives the master the head & his wife the neck, because the head & the neck belong together (the wife the rump, because she sits at home, or the heart). He gives the two sons the legs, because they work outside the house to support the household, & the two daughters the wings, because they will fly away. He takes the body for himself. The master rewards him well for his wisdom. Sometimes the tale continues: A neighbor hears of the poor man’s good fortune. He brings the master a present of five chickens along with rice. When he is asked to divide these appropriately he cannot do so, & he is beaten. (2) Sometimes as a conclusion to the version above: A master asks the poor man to divide (these) five chickens (other birds) among the members of his household. The poor man gives the master & his wife one bird, to make three. Likewise he gives one to the two sons & one to the two daughters. Finally he takes the last two for himself, to make another set of three.
1637
1533AHog's Head Divided According to ScriptureAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA clergyman, a sexton, & a schoolmaster (three students) want to divide a roasted pig (a pig’s head) among themselves. The criterion for the division is their skill in quoting Scripture. The minister cuts off an ear & says, “So Peter cut off an ear from the servant of the high priest”. The sexton cuts the head off the pig (the second ear) & says, “So was the head of John the Baptist cut off” (“and they gave him a box on the ear”). The schoolmaster considers for a long time. Finally he spreads a cloth & puts the rest of the pig (head) on it & says, “And then they took the holy body away”. In some variants, three monks find a single egg & agree that it should go to the one who gives the most appropriate quote from the Bible. The first says, “Purify it from the shell of falsehood”. The second says, “Sprinkle it with the salt of wisdom”. The third says, “Come in to praise the Lord!” & eats the egg.
1638
1533BThe Third EggAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer’s son who is studying philosophy (medicine) has returned home. One day two eggs (fowls, pancakes) are served for dinner. In order to show off his education, he explains that these are not two but three: “This is one, that makes two, & together they are three”. His father refrains from contradicting him. He takes one egg for himself, gives the second to his wife, & invites his son to eat the third egg.
1639
1533CThe Clever Division of the HerdAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (farmer, Turk, Arab) leaves his three sons (nephews, farmhands) a total of 17 cows (horses, camels, coins) to be divided as follows: the oldest son is to have half; the middle son, one third; & the youngest, one ninth. They are unable to solve this problem until a bystander adds one of his own animals to the herd. From 18 animals, each son can take his proper inheritance, & then the bystander takes his own animal back.
1640
1534-Series of Clever Unjust DecisionsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever Man(The Decisions of Shemjaka.) A poor man (merchant, baker) causes a series of accidents: He pulls off the tail of a (borrowed) horse (one of two oxen that he has borrowed dies). The owner sues him. The poor man flees into a house & frightens (hits) a pregnant woman so that she miscarries. Or a woman invites him in out of the rain, & he sits on her sofa & accidentally kills her child. Her husband (the woman) sues him as well. Out of desperation, the poor man jumps from a high tower (bridge) & kills a passerby, whose brother (other relative) sues him. The injured parties bring the poor man before a judge. The judge decides as follows: The poor man should keep the borrowed horse until its tail grows back. He should impregnate the mother with another child (and her husband should hit her again, to give her another miscarriage). Her husband rejects this settlement & withdraws his suit. (In some variants, he has to pay a fine to the poor man.) The brother (other relative) of the killed man should jump from the tower upon the poor man in order to kill him. He also withdraws his suit. (In some variants he also has to pay a fine to the poor man.) (The poor man leaves with the horse & his settlements.) Some variants have a frame tale: The judge persuades a baker (merchant) to give him a goose (duck) that belongs to someone else. He promises to protect him if the owner of the goose accuses him of theft. Then as above.
1641
1534AThe Innocent Man Condmened to DeathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA holy man & his disciple come to a city where the king & all his ministers are fools, & where all kinds of food are sold for the same price. The holy man leaves at once & warns his disciple to do so too, but the disciple stays despite the warning. A thief tries to break into a house at night but is killed when the wall collapses (he puts his eye out on a projecting stick). The house-holder is called before the king & sentenced to death (to have his eye put out). The householder, however, blames the mason who built the wall who, in turn, blames the man who supplied the mortar, etc., until finally one man is found who is too stupid to find someone else to blame. He is condemned to death. The owner explains that he needs both his eyes for his work, but his neighbor, who is a hunter, needs only one. The hunter says he really needs both eyes, but his neighbor, who is a musician, always closes his eyes when he plays, etc. The king decrees that one of his eyes be put out. The condemned man is too thin to fit the stake (noose). The disciple is chosen to be executed in his place. The holy man returns & announces that he has discovered that the next man to be executed will go directly to heaven. The king leaps upon the stake himself.
1642
1534A*Barber Substituted for Smith at ExecutionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA smith commits a crime & is condemned to death. The villagers complain to the judge (mayor) that they cannot manage without the smith. They ask him to execute a barber instead, because they have two of those.
1643
1534D*Sham Dumb Man Wins SuitAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA trickster (farmer) (carrying a tall tree) calls to a (rich) man to get out of the way. The man refuses & the trickster overturns his wagon (tears his clothes). The rich man brings him before a magistrate. The trickster pretends to be mute (is too afraid to speak). The angry plaintif protests that the man is not dumb, & that he had given him a loud warning. Thus the plaintif loses his case, because he did not heed the man’s warning.
1644
1534E*Good Decision.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo men bring their argument before a judge. The judge hears one side of the case & decides that it is right. Then he hears the other side & decides that it too is right. When someone complains that both sides cannot be right, the judge says, “You are right too”.
1645
1534Z*Other Absurd DecisionsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManMisc. type with diverse variants.
1646
1535-The Rich & the Poor FarmerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever Man(Unibos.) This tale often begins with one of the following episodes: (1) The family of a poor man (farmer) kills their only cow (two oxen) & uses all their flour to bake bread. They invite all the vil-lagers to a big dinner. The family waits in vain for a return invitation from the guests. (2) A rich man kills his poor brother’s only horse, & gives him its skin. Main part: The poor man goes to the city to sell the cowhide (oxhide, horse-hide). During the night he discovers the innkeeper’s wife with her lover & threatens to expose them. They bribe him not to tell. Or, a merchant believes that the poor man’s sacks of refuse contain valu-ables. The merchant takes the sacks, & in return leaves his goods for the poor man. Back at home, the poor man tells his rich brother (the villagers) that he received all the money for the animal hide (the refuse). The brother (villagers) kills all his cattle in order to sell their hides, & im poverishes himself (tries to sell refuse & is beaten). In some variants the rich man is angry & tries to kill his brother, but instead he kills an old relative (dead man) who is lying in his place in bed. The poor man takes the corpse away, & convinces an innocent man that he killed the person. This man bribes the poor man not to tell. Then the poor man claims that he had sold the corpse. The rich man kills all his relatives, hoping tsell their corpses. He is put in prison & set free after he serves his sentence. Still angry, he tries to drown his brother. The poor brother, con-fined in a sack (chest), finds a passerby (shepherd, rich lord) who is willing to trade places with him. After this person has been thrown into the water, the poor man comes back to the village with the sheep (horse, riches) & claims he found them under the water. The jealous rich man (the villagers) jumps into the water & drowns.
1647
1536-Disposing of the CorpseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThe motif of having to get rid of a corpse appears in a series of different narratives. It has different results depending on its situation in the tale.
1648
1536AThe Woman in the ChestAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA poor brother (neighbor, sexton) steals a hog (cow, food) from his rich brother (neighbor, clergyman). The rich man suspects his brother, but wants to be certain, so he hides his mother-in-law (mother, wife, cook) in a chest (cupboard) in his broth er’s house to spy. The woman confirms the rich man’s suspicion & cries out (curses, makes noise). The poor brother opens the chest, strangles the woman (kills her in some other way), & puts some food (cheese, meat, sausage, bread) in her mouth. The rich brother opens the chest, sees that the woman is dead, & thinks she has suffocated. He wants to keep her death secret & bribes the poor brother not to tell any one & to bury her. Later, the poor brother digs her up at night (keeping some of her valuables) & sets her body at his brother’s door, where it falls over when the door is opened in the morning. The rich brother thinks the corpse has returned to haunt him. He pays his poor brother more money to bury the corpse again (often three or four times), but it turns up in the barn, close to the well, on a foal that follows the rich man, etc. The poor man gets so much money (cattle, provisions) for reburying the body that he becomes as rich as (richer than) his brother.
1649
1536BThe Three Hunchback Brothers DrownedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThere are two parts to this tale. The first part exists in two forms, but the second part is largely the same. (1) Three hunchbacked musicians are asked by the wife of another hunchbacked man to play some music. (One of the three hunch-backed brothers marries a rich widow, & his poor brothers visit her uninvited.) The husband unexpectedly comes home. The musi-cians hide in a chest (oven, cellar), where they die (kill each other). (2) Three monks (clergymen, knights, students) court a beautiful woman. On the advice of her husband, she invites them to visit her. The visit of the first lover is interrupted by that of the second, etc., & they hide in a chest (oven, cellar). The third lover hides when the husband arrives. The husband kills them in their hiding place. A drunken man (stupid farmhand, farmer, porter, undertaker, beggar, soldier, the devil) is employed to dump one of the dead bodies into the river (to bury it). When he returns, he finds the second body in the same place as if it had come back from the dead, & then the third. After he gets rid of all three bodies, he meets the hunch backed husband (another monk, clergyman, knight) and, think ing that this is another revenant, kills him & dumps him into the river (buries him) also.
1650
1536CThe Murdered LoverAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA woman wants to meet her lover without her husband’s knowledge. She asks a neighbor (God, saint) for advice, & is told (by her husband hiding in the church or behind the saint’s picture) that she should give her husband a particular food that will make him blind (and deaf). She does so & he pretends to be blind. When the wife receives her lover, her husband finds an oppor tunity to kill him (and puts some food in his mouth to make it look as if he choked on it). The husband brings the body of the lover back home (to a shop, inn) & asks in a disguised voice if he may come in. The wife (the shopkeeper) thinks her husband (a drunk) is at the door, & tells him to spend the night with his mistress (to go home). The woman refuses to open the door even when the man says he will die (hang himself). The husband leans the corpse against the door (hangs it on the door). In some variants the woman (repeatedly) has the body delivered to another place where it is “killed” again by someone else (thief, etc.).
1651
1537-The Corpse Killed Five TimesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA certain woman’s lover (often a clergyman or a monk) is killed by her angry husband, or a man (clergyman, occasionally a woman) is killed by accident (on purpose, is murdered). The wife (married couple, bystanders, murderer) secretly leaves the body by the neighbors’ door. The neighbor thinks it is a robber (adulterer) & “kills” it again. To cover up this murder, the neighbor takes the body to a monastery (and puts it in the abbot’s room, or on a toilet), where it is “killed ” again because it will not speak. This “murderer” puts the body into a sack & throws it into the river. Fishermen find it & hang it in a shop (put it in a boat or on a sledge, or tie it on a horse & drive it into a field or into a crockery shop), & the shopkeeper “kills”’ it again. Often the trickster (the first murderer) blackmails the subsequent “murderers” for not exposing their “murders”.
1652
1537*Corpse's Legs LeftAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier finds a corpse & cuts off its legs. He stays overnight with a rich farmer, & goes away early the next morn ing leaving the legs. A comrade of the soldier accuses the farmer of murder & blackmails him
1653
1538-Revenge of the Cheated ManAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA youth (farmer, fool) goes to the market to sell cattle (fowl, eggs). On the way he meets a trickster (monk, robber, landlord, judge) who convinces him that his cattle are not worth very much. He sells (is compelled to sell) them for a very low price The youth resolves to revenge himself on the trickster. He dis-guises himself as a beggar-woman (bride, carpenter, woodcutter, builder) & tricks him so that the trickster lets himself be tied to a tree & the youth is able to beat him. The trickster goes to get medical help. The youth disguises himself as a doctor & beats him again (in a monastery, bathhouse, robbers’ den). In the end the youth takes his cattle back & also gets some money. In some variants, instead of one trickster, the youth takes revenge on many (seven, twelve, forty).
1654
1538*The Jester as BrideAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA witty fellow (trickster) dresses himself in his sister’s clothes & works as a servant girl (employee) to a clergyman (master). The son of a rich man (mayor) chooses him as his bride & prefers him to the priest’s daughters, because only he is able to pass a test of feminity (is the cleverest of the girls). On the wedding night a rope is tied to the “bride”s’ leg. He frees himself, ties a goat (ram) to the end of the rope, & goes away. Then he returns wearing his own clothes & demands compensation for his sister’s having been turned into a goat. In some variants the bridegroom discovers that his bride is a man & leaves town. The groom’s parents bribe the “servant girl” not to tell what happened.
1655
1539-Cleverness & GullibilityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThree students (butchers, rascals) convince a farmer (fool, trickster) that his cow (donkey, mule, ox) is a goat (hen, donkey), so he sells the animal cheaply. (In variants from southern & eastern Europe, the farmer is persuaded to cut off the animal’s horns, ears, & tail in order to get a better price.) The farmer pays in advance at three inns & invites the students to eat with him. Instead of paying, he turns his hat around three times (hits it on the table, throws it on the floor, rings a bell), & the innkeeper says that the bill has been settled. The students buy the hat for a high price. When they try to use it, they discover the trick. (Variants from central Europe end here.) When the students come back for revenge, the farmer pretends to be dead. His wife (occasionally the students) revives him with a stick. (Or, the farmer ties a skin filled with blood under his wife’s clothes & pretends to kill her.) He revives her with a “magic wand” (flute, violin, knife), which he sells to the students. The students kill their wives (mothers) but cannot revive them. They put the farmer into a sack (cask) to be drowned, but he trades places with a herdsman who comes by. By pretending to have found the herd of cattle on the bottom of the sea, the farmer induces his greedy adversaries to jump into the water. In variants from southern & eastern Europe, after the intro-duction in which the animal is mutilated, the farmer puts coins in the anus of his donkey (horse, cow) or mixes them with its dung. He sells the animal as a gold-producer (and says that the animal must remain in its stall for two weeks or forty days. The animal dies.). In some versions, the farmer sells his adversaries supposedly wonderful objects, e.g. a messenger rabbit, a pot that cooks by itself, a pick that locates gold, a rifle that always hits its mark, or a self-propelled sled. Or the farmer promises to teach them to speak Latin & cuts their tongues off. Some variants end with the farmer buried alive. When his adversaries come to rob the grave, he brands them or cuts off their genitals (noses).
1656
1539A*Closing Up the Wine Cask.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master (landlord) makes up a pretext to send a boy (a farmer) who has offended him to the wine cellar, where the servant is supposed to give him a beating. When the boy sees the servant, he pulls the bung out of the wine cask so that the servant has to use his thumb to close it up. The boy beats him up & runs away, taking bacon (sausage), bread, & a jug of wine with him. In some variants, a guest tries to cheat an innkeeper (leaves with-out paying his bill) who has boasted to him that such a thing had never happened to her. He tells her that he can draw both red & white (any kind of) wine from the same cask. He bores two holes in one cask & tells her to stop them with her thumbs while he goes upstairs to get a glass (some glasses). He leaves & does not come back, so the innkeeper has to wait until her husband comes to rescue her.
1657
1540-The Student from Paradise (Paris)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA student (beggar, traveler, clergyman) tells a (foolish) woman that he comes from Paris. She understands this to be Paradise. (Or, he sings, “I come from heaven”, or says he comes from the beyond or is a messenger from hell). The wife tells him that her husband (son) died shortly before. The stu-dent claims to have met him in paradise (hell) & tells her that her husband needs certain things. The wife gives the student money (clothes, food, horse, etc.) to take to her husband. The oldest son (brother-in-law, husband) goes after the trickster to retreive the moeny. The Trickster steals his horse (the son runs his own horse to death).
1658
1540A*Lady Sends Pig as Wedding HostessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA trickster (farmer) tells a foolish woman (lady) that he has come to invite her hog to a wedding. She puts a gold necklace on the hog & lets him take it. (She also gives him a horse & coach to transport the animal.) In some variants her husband sets out after the man hoping to re trieve the hog. The trickster manages to steal his horse.
1659
1541-For the Long WinterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (farmer) has accumulated a store of pro visions (saved some money, good clothing, or a sausage). His stupid wife reproaches him with this, & he says that it is for the long winter (spring, emergencies, a good day). Later, when he is away, a trickster (beggar) comes to the woman & says (in answer to her question) that he is the long winter. (He greets her with “Good day”, & she thinks that is his name.) The wife gives him the provisions.
1660
1541**The Student Betrays the ShoemakersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA student (Gypsy) orders the same kind of new shoes (boots) from two shoemakers. He tries on those of the first shoemaker & says that the left shoe needs adjustment, & keeps the right shoe. He goes to the second shoemaker & says that the right shoe needs adjustment, & keeps the left. He leaves town with one shoe from each shoemaker, without having paid for them.
1661
1541***"Today for Money, Tomorrow for None"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA barber (innkeeper) hangs out a sign, “Today for money, tomorrow for none”, meaning that the shop is about to go out of business. Customers wait a day & think, they will not have to pay. The proprietor throws them out
1662
1542-The Clever BoyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThe king challenges the trickster Peik (Eulenspiegel, Abū Nuwās, Aldar Iwan, Nasreddin Hodja, Toba, etc.) to play a trick on him.Peik borrows the king’s horse to go home & get his fooling sticks (book of lies, trickster’s secrets). Instead of coming back, he sells the horse. When next he meets the king, Peik sells the king a cooking pot that is supposed to cook without fire. Later, Peik pretends to stab his sister, who has hidden a blood-filled bladder under her clothes. He “revives” her with a supposedly-magic flute, which he sells to the king. The king kills one of his daughters but cannot revive her with the flute. Peik wears his sister’s clothes & is engaged as a lady-in-waiting in the king’s court. A prince wants to marry him, but Peik flees on the wedding night. (He is found to be responsible for the preg nancy of the princess. Peik is sentenced to death & is to be drowned in a sack (cask). He tricks someone else into taking his place. The king forgives Peik & makes him his son-in-law.
1663
1542*Sailor SubstituteAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA woman loves a sailor, but she will only kiss him in the dark. His captain hears about this, disguises himself as the sailor, & sleeps with the woman. The woman marries the sailor. He is surprised that his wife has a baby six months later.
1664
1542**The Maiden's HonorAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA mother tells her daughter to take care not to lose her honor (virginity). A tailor offers to “sew up” the daughter’s honor. In some variants, the tailor sleeps with the daughter (repeatedly), & then says he cannot sew her up because he does not have enough thread. She asks him, what about the spool(s) he has behind his needle (penis).
1665
1543-Not One Penny LessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A poor man (soldier, youth) prays to a saint’s picture for a certain amount of money, promising to give back double that amount at the end of a month. The sexton overhears and, hoping for the large repayment, gives the poor man what he asked for. The sexton claims to be the messenger of the saint, but the poor man refuses to repay the money to him. (2) A poor man (journeyman, farmhand, sexton, trickster) asks God (a saint) for a certain sum of money, no more & no less. A rich man (master, gentleman, priest, Jew) tests him by giving him (as a joke) 99 (999) instead of 100 (1000) (gold) coins. The poor man ac cepts them, saying, “Whoever gave me these will surely give me the last one too”, (he counts the value of the purse as the missing coin, adds a coin of his own). He refuses to pay back the money & makes blasphemous excuses (God is old & forgetful, or He cannot count) Often the tale continues: The lender goes to a judge in order to force the poor man to repay his money. Before the case is tried, the poor man tricks the lender out of his overcoat, shoes, & often his horse. Even the judge is tricked by the poor man, who makes the lender so suspicious that the judge thinks he must be insane. On his way home, the poor man meets someone who says he is the Son of God. The poor man demands that he give him the missing coin which his father had overlooked.
1666
1543*The Man without a MemberAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA father (farmer) has a marriageable daughter who is ignorant about (afraid of) sex. He finds a husband for her who claims to have no penis. This man sleeps with her & entertains her with his “curry-comb” (“comb” or some other word for his penis) so successfully that she becomes too demanding for him. He tells her that he does not have his curry-comb any more (he had only borrowed it & had to give it back, etc.). She gives him money (he borrows it from her) to go to the market & buy a new one. After he leaves her (is sent away by her father because she became pregnant), she goes after him & asks him to leave her his curry-comb. He pretends to cut off his penis, but instead puts a stone in water & says that that is his comb. She asks a passerby (monk, her father) to get it out of the water. When the passerby takes off his clothes, she discovers “her” curry-comb hanging between his legs & grabs hold of it (tears it off).
1667
1543AThe Greedy DreamerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man dreams that he has nine coins (bills). He demands ten (he wants to change the bills into gold). He wakes up & realizes that he had been dreaming. He regrets that he did not accept the nine coins (the bills). In Arabic variants the greedy man dreams that he is trying to sell his sheep (hogs) for eight dirhams (100 denari) each. A customer offers to pay him half of that. When he wakes up & sees no money, he closes his eyes & says, “At least give me four”.
1668
1543C*The Clever DoctorAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man complains to a doctor that he has no sense of taste, can never tell the truth, & has a bad memory. The doctor treats him with three capsules filled with feces (puts dung in his mouth). The first restores his sense of taste, after the second, he is able to speak the truth, & when he takes the third, he proves that his memory is good. In some variants, a clever doctor heals a patient by diverting his attention. For example, in a Jewish variant a king has an inflamed eye because he touches it all the time. The doctor tells him that he is pregnant & will give birth in nine months. The king begins to worry about his stomach & touches it: Thus his eye is able to heal. When the birth does not take place, the doctor explains his trick & is made court physician.
1669
1543D*Stone as WitnessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer makes a contract with his farmhand & calls on a stone to witness it. When the farmhand demands his wages, the farmer refuses to pay him. They go to court. The judge orders the stone be brought to the court to testify. The farmer ex poses himself by explaining that it is too heavy (too far away) to be brought.
1670
1543E*Tree as WitnessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo friends with names that describe their charac-ters (e.g. stupid, clever) become rich (find a treasure) in a foreign country. They decide to bury the money under a tree in order to share it later. The clever one steals the money, accuses the stupid one of theft & brings him to trial. He names the tree(spirit) as witness. The next day the judge intends to interview the tree. The clever one asks his father to hide in the hollow of the tree & to tell the judge that the stupid one has stolen the money. The astonished judge (the clever one) orders the tree to be burned. The father screams, & his son is exposed & punished. The stupid one is given all the money.
1671
1544-The Man Who Got a Night's LodgingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA rascal (trickster) pretends to be deaf & takes a householder’s greeting as an invitation to sit at the table & help himself to the best food. (He ignores the householder’s hints & eats well.) He trades the householder’s horse for his own, & when he is asked to pay for his food with a goatskin, he kills one of the householder’s goats. At night he sleeps with the wife and/or daughter. When the wife bakes pancakes for her hungry husband, the guest sneaks them him-self. He informs the husband about his sexual relations with the wife (daughter). The husband becomes angry & goes to kill the guest’s horse, but kills his own instead. Every time, the guest gets the better of the householder.
1672
1544A*A Soldier's RiddleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier (apprentice, beggar) is given hospitality by an old woman (farmwife, priest, etc.). He induces her to leave the kitchen, puts the goose (chicken) that she is roasting into his sack, & substitutes his shoe. The woman asks him what the latest news is (how the war is going; the priest asks him what he wants to confess). The soldier an swers with wordplay: “King Goose has moved from Ovenhome to Sackhouse”. The woman does not understand & lets him leave with the goose.
1673
1544B*The Troublesome GuestAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManMisc. type. This Type comprises various tales in which a rascal (relative) manages to receive hospi-tality from a stingy host (relative), or in which, against the host’s will, the guest demands hospitality for too long a period of time.
1674
1545-The Boy with Many NamesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man is employed as a farmhand by a master (king, rich man, clergyman), but refuses to use his right name. Various people call him absurd names, for example, Bird, Hair, Sultry (I Myself, Cat, Cramp). The different names cause misunderstandings that work to the farmhand’s advantage: He sleeps with the daughter & wife of his master. When they accuse him, the master does not understand them, & the farmhand continues this behavior. The master knows that the servant has stolen money (other valuables), but because of his peculiar names he is not convicted of the theft. After the farmhand leaves, his tricks are discovered, but he is not apprehended because the people who seek him are ridiculed for calling out his names.
1675
1545*Keeping Warm in Bed Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA young man (student) teaches the daughter of his master (clergyman, innkeeper) how to keep him warm in bed. When her father feels cold, she offers to warm him too.
1676
1545ALearning to Sleep in BedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man seduces a woman by pretending that he does not know how to go to bed. She must teach him.
1677
1545A*"It's a Man!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man disguises himself as a pregnant woman & is admitted to a house where a beautiful daughter (wife) lives. The daughter discovers his true identity (the wife wants to help at the birth & is raped by the man) & cries out, “It’s a man!” Her father (husband) thinks the pregnant woman has given birth to a son & blesses the child. (The young man is driven out, but in the end he marries the daughter.)
1678
1545BThe Boy Who Knew Nothing of WomenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA rich clergyman (farmer) wants a farmhand who will not seduce his daughter (s), & asks applicants about the genitals of a horse (other animal), the procedure of copulation, or the difference between men & women. The boys who know the right answers are not hired. After a time, a youth in disguise comes again pretending that he cannot answer the question(s), & the clergyman hires him. The clergyman calls the wife’s & daughter’s vaginas prisons, & the youth pretends to be innocent & not to know what they are for. Through other tricks (e.g. using ambiguous names), he seduces the sexually-naive wife & daughter in the presence of the clergyman. For example, in a Russian variant, one night the farmhand tells his employer that he has caught a thief (which is his penis) who should be sent to prison. In the presence of the unsuspecting clergy man, he sends the “thief” into the prisons of the wife & daughter. When he realizes what has happened, the clergyman gets angry & curses the farmhand, thus losing an expensive wager, & has to let him go free.
1679
1546-The Lump of GoldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer (farmhand, rascal) asks a goldsmith (master, rich man) what he would pay for a lump of gold of the size of a brick (cat, horse’s head, etc.). The goldsmith, thinking to get the gold cheaply, pays him a substantial amount of money (offers him hospitality). When the trickster is supposed to produce the lump of gold, he makes an excuse: He had only asked the question so he would know what to expect if he ever found such a lump. He leaves town with the money (thanks the goldsmith for the meal).
1680
1547*The Trickster with Painted PenisAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier (student) lodges with a farmer (innkeeper). He wants to seduce the housewife (and the daughter) but can never find her alone. He paints three colored rings on his penis & lets it hang out of his clothes (at night, or as if by accident). The wife is curious & asks him why his penis is so different from her husband’s. He tells her that, depending on which rings go in, he can beget a soldier, officer, or general (minister, dean, or bishop). The couple ask him to beget an officer & pay him for his services. While the soldier & the wife are having intercourse, the farmer gives the soldier a push from behind, so that, for the same price, the wife should get a general instead of an officer. In some variants the farmer, who is unable to impregnate his wife, initiates the bargain.
1681
1548-The Stone SoupAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier (traveler, monk) asks an old woman for food & lodging for the night. She agrees to the lodging but will not give him any food. The soldier offers to show her how to make soup from a stone (nail, ax, horseshoe) (sometimes without the introduc-tory situation). She agrees. While the stone “cooks”, she brings him all that he asks for, one after another: flour, grease, meat (bacon), vege tables, etc. After they eat the soup, the soldier says he is too full to eat the stone (he sells the wonderful stone to the woman).
1682
1548*The Fool's TalentAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThree brothers have different talents: the oldest makes shoes for the queen & the princess, the second sews clothes for them, & the third (fool) gives them children.
1683
1551-The Wager that Sheep are HogsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer (poor man) drives his sheep (cow, horse) to market. A trickster (soldier, student) who would like to buy the sheep cheaply tries to convince the farmer that they are piglets (goats, donkeys). The farmer insists that they are sheep. An accomplice of the trickster arrives & offers to settle the dispute: he proclaims that the animals are pigs. Another passerby, also an accomplice, agrees. The farmer sells his sheep for the price of pigs. In some variants, five tricksters one after the other convince a farmer, who is taking his lamb to market, that it is a dog. The farmer throws the animal away, & the five men get roast lamb for free.
1684
1551*How Much the Donkey CostAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man who has bought a donkey is ask ed by the villagers one after another how much he paid for it. Annoyed by the repeated question, he has the church bells rung to summon all the villagers. The people think that a saint (angel) wants to make an announcement (that it is Judgment Day). The man announces what price he paid.
1685
1552*Soup Made from Rabbit SoupAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (farmer, Nasreddin Hodja) is given a rabbit (chicken) as a gift, & treats the man who gave the gift to a meal to thank him. Soon after, another man (men) comes who claims to be a neighbor of the man who gave the hare. The recipient gives him a meal too. Later, yet another man (men) comes who claims to be a neighbor of that neighbor of the man who gave the hare. The recipient serves him only hot water, “soup made from the soup of the hare”.
1686
1553-An Ox for Five PenniesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManDuring a crisis (after he lost his way, or on his deathbed) a man (trickster, rich man, farmer, knight) promises to sell a valuable animal (camel, horse, donkey, cow, ox) for no profit (he will sell it ridiculously cheaply, or will give the proceeds to chari ty). Later (after his death), he (his wife) offers the animal for sale as promised. However, it must be purchased along with a small animal (cat, rooster, dog, occasionally a goat) for which a high price is demanded.
1687
1553B*Pleasing the CaptainAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA ship’s captain (innkeeper) promises to set a Galician (guest stay & eat for) free if he will sing a song that pleases the captain. The Galician sings that he would like to pay the captain. This pleases the captain & he sets the Galician free (the innkeeper gives the guest food & lodging for free).
1688
1555-Milk in the CaskAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA number of people are ordered each to contribute a small amount toward filling a cask with milk (wine). Each of them pours only water into the cask, thinking that no one will notice a little water in all the milk. In the end, the cask is filled with pure water.
1689
1555APaying for Bread with BeerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man orders a glass of beer, returns it without drinking any, & orders a loaf of bread. He refuses to pay for the bread because he bartered for it with the beer, & he refuses to pay for the beer because he did not drink it.
1690
1555BWine & Water BusinessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA trickster fills a jug half full of water, then has it filled with wine (rum) at a liquor shop. When the seller refuses to give him credit, he pays for the half & pours back half of the liquid – now half wine & half water. Sometimes the trickster repeats the operation, getting more wine with each transaction.
1691
1555CThe Good MealAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA well-dressed man in a restaurant orders “a soup for his money”. After the soup he orders other dishes for his money. He also agrees to take a glass of wine for his money offered by the innkeeper. After the meal it turns out that his money is not enough to pay the bill. He explains to the angry innkeeper that he only ordered “a meal for his money”. The innkeeper is willing to forgive him on the condition that he should behave in the same way in his neighbor’s restaurant. The man confesses that he came to him on his neighbor’s advice.
1692
1556-The Double Pension (Burial Money)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA poor man (poet, fool) & his wife, who had been in government service, are both entitled to death benefits. Each of them reports that the other is dead & receives money for the burial. When the king finds out about this, everyone is amused at the trick (the man is hired to work again).
1693
1557-Box on the Ear ReturnedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer (soldier, fool, sometimes sailor, ambassador, foreign minister) is given hospitality by the king & sits beside him at the dining table. One of the courtiers wants to embarrass the farmer, so he suggests that each person should hit his neighbor (on the head). When it is the farmer’s turn to hit the king, he says, “When the plow comes to the end of the furrow, the plowman has to turn the horse around”. Instead of hitting the king, he returns the blow to the man who hit him.
1694
1558-Welcome to the ClothesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA wise man (adviser) had been invited to the king’s (mayor’s) banquet, but he is denied entry because of his poor clothes. When he comes back in new clothes he is welcomed. When the food is served, the wise man pours it on his clothes. He explains that it is they who were welcomed.
1695
1559A*Always HungryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master maintains that animals’ hunger is easier to ap-pease than humans’. His shepherd argues the opposite. When the guests have finished their meal, the shepherd sets some nuts on the table. The guests crack & eat the nuts, so the herdsman wins the argument.
1696
1559C*Some Things Not for SaleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer goes into a store in which every-thing is supposed to be available. He bets with the owner that something that he wants is not for sale in the store, & the owner accepts the bet. The customer asks for something unusual (e.g. sunglasses for his cow) & wins the bet. The owner sends the customer to another store & warns the storekeeper there. The customer makes the same bet. This time he asks for something different (e.g. shoes for his rooster) & wins again. (Sometimes there is a third episode with higher stakes, which the farmer wins again.)
1697
1560-Make-Believe Eating; Make-Believe WorkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (farmer) & his farmhand work in the field. At noon, other people who are also work ing near by stop for a rest & eat. The farmer stops working but tells his farmhand, “We will only act as if we are eating”. When they resume work, the farmhand swings the scythe back & forth without cutting anything. The farmer turns around & asks him what he thinks he is doing. The farmhand says he is acting as if he is working.
1698
1560**"Is It Still Raining?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer & his farmhand climb un-der a haystack to get out of the rain. The farmer keeps asking, “Is it still raining?” The farmhand says yes, although in fact the rain has stopped.
1699
1561-Three Meals in a RowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA foolish farmhand (servant) refuses to work while he is hungry. He eats all three meals of the day one after another, & then goes to sleep. In some variants, a farmer (master, clergyman) insists that his farmhand eat all three meals one after the other so that he will not eat so much (not spend so much time eating). The clever farmhand goes to bed right after “supper”.
1700
1561*A Cure for NearsightednessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmhand complains to his master (farmer, skipper, shoemaker) that he must be growing nearsighted (blind), because he cannot see the filling in his sandwich. (He asks for glasses to see what has been given to him to eat.) The wife of his master takes the complaint to heart & gives him more cheese on his bread for his next meal. The farmhand says this is much better, because now he can read the newspaper through the cheese.
1701
1561**Eating & WorkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master invites two workmen (Gypsies, his sons) to dinner, after which he wants them to do some work for him. He asks them if they would like certain things to eat, & one of the two guests says yes. Then the host asks which of them will do certain work. The same man tells his companion that now it is his turn to volunteer.
1702
1562-"Think Thrice before you Speak."Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master (teacher) cautions a boy to think three times before he speaks. The boy obeys even when he sees that the master’s clothing (turban) is on fire.
1703
1562A"The Barn is Burning!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master has instructed his farmhand (a traveler) to use peculiar names for everything, for example, Purity for the cat, Beauty for the fire, High for the roof (and punishes the farmhand when he does not). The farmhand plans revenge & ties a bundle of straw, which he lights, to the cat’s tail. When the burning cat sets the barn roof on fire, the farmhand uses the special words to tell his master. The fire burns out of control before the master understands the complicated message.
1704
1562A*Deceptive Bargain: Fasting TogetherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThe miserly master & his servant have a contest in fasting. The servant eats secretly. The master will not admit defeat, & dies.
1705
1562BWife Follows Written InstructionsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master (husband) writes a list of instructions for his apprentice (servant, wife) (the apprentice asks for such a list). One day when they are traveling together, the (drunken) master falls into the mud (ditch, stream) & asks the ap prentice to rescue him. The apprentice answers that he does not know whether this is part of his duties & runs home to look up the situation in his instructions. (The master manages to get himself out, & tears up the list.)
1706
1562B*Dog's Bread StolenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA miserly master gives his farmhand one loaf of bread for the day, instructing him to eat all he wants but to feed the dog too & leave the loaf whole. The farmhand takes the center out of the loaf, leaving the crust in one piece.
1707
1562C*Miser Eats at NightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA miserly old man (clergyman & his wife) gives his daughter-in-law nothing to eat. He himself (hides the food and) eats secretly during the night. The daughter-in-law complains to her family. Her father (youngest brother) comes, prevents the old man in different way to eat at night, & cures him of his miserliness.
1708
1562D*The Boy Goes to Sleep on His JobAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA young man falls asleep at his work, but his master does not dare to wake him & punish him.
1709
1562F*The Hunt for the PeaAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA miserly farmer gives his farmhands poor food. Or, a clergy man (several soldiers) is invited to dinner by a miserly friend (housewife). The soup is mostly water with hardly any peas (barley, rice). One of the farmhands (the clergyman, one of the soldiers) takes off his jacket & shirt. Someone asks why, & he explains that he is going to reach into the dish to look for the pea.
1710
1562J*"Sing It!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA pharmacist’s (farmer’s) servant who stutters tries to tell his master that the laboratory is burning (that he fell into a canal along with his horse & wagon). He cannot pronounce the words, so the pharmacist tells him to sing the news. The servant sings the following to the tune of a children’s song, “The laboratory is on fire, hurrah!” (“The horse & wagon fell in the water, the farmer must come & see.”)
1711
1563-"Both?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmhand (often an ill-treated one) is sent by the farmer into the house to get something. He tells the wife that he has been ordered to sleep with her and/or her daughter (s). They are shocked & call out to the farmer something like, “Shall we give it to him?” – “Both?” – “All three?” The farmer says yes, & they go to bed with the farmhand In northern Italian variants, the trickster is a wild man (giant, magician), & instead of sex he takes money or gold. In variants from the Caucasus & middle to western Asia, the trickster wants to take the daughters away & marry them.
1712
1563*The Terrible ThreatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A man’s horse (saddle, bridle, etc.) is stolen. He threatens that if it is not returned immediately, he will do what his father would have done in these circumstances. The bystanders are horrified & give him a new horse (the thief returns his horse). They ask the man what it was his father would have done. He replies, “He would have walked” (have bought a new saddle). In oriental variants, the man’s shoes are stolen, & the man says his father would have bought new shoes. (2) Two travelers (horsemen, teamsters) meet on the road & neither will give way to the other. One of them threatens that if the other does not let him pass, he will do to him what he did the day before to another man who was in his way. The other traveler lets him pass, & asks what it was he had done the day before. He re-plies that he had let the man pass. (3) A beggar (dervish, Gypsy) threatens the inhabitants of a village (a single person) that if they do not give him some particular thing, he will do to them what he did to the people in another village (what his father did in the same situation, something he does not want to have to do). They give him what he wants but ask what he meant by his threat. He explains, he had to go on without the thing (had to work). (4) A lazy student (night watchman) asks his father for money (asks for more pay). He threatens that if his request is not granted, he will have to do something that he does not want to have to do. The answer to the question is, he will have to study (work for his same wages)
1713
1564*The Clever Granary WatcherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man who is supposed to guard a certain farmer’s granary steals the grain. The wagon he uses to carry the grain falls into a ditch. When the farmer comes by, the thief tells him that the grain belongs to himself. The farmer orders his other farmhands to help the thief. In some variants, the thieving guard says he is bringing the grain to the owner’s barn. The farmer realizes that it is his own grain.
1714
1565-Agreement Not to ScratchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) A man (trickster) continually scratches his head or body (because of a disease) (he sneezes continually). He is promised a reward if he can refrain from scratching (sneezing) for a certain length of time. When he can no longer resist the itching, he tells a story (calls out) in which he can make gestures or sounds that permit him to scratch (sneeze). Sometimes the listeners realize what he has done, but they reward him anyway because they admire his cleverness. (2) A bald (mangy) man (with head lice), a man who scratches him self, & a man with a dripping nose agree (are ordered, often by the king) not to touch themselves. All of them manage to break the pro hibition by telling stories which they illustrate with their for-bidden movements. For example, the bald man says that his father bought him a fur cap, & he mimics putting it on & taking it off. The scratching man says his father bought him clothes, & touches himself to show where they did not fit. The man with the dripping nose calls them both liars & points at them by rubbing his nose twice with his fingers. (3) A god offers a prize (his daughter, an ox, both) to whichever animal can clear a field of nettles without scratching himself. After other animals try & fail, a certain animal (spider, Brer Rabbit) wins the prize by disguising his scratching in his animated description of the ox. (4) Two men (a Jew & a Russian) agree not to scratch. Each tries to make the other break the agreement. For example, the Jew sprinkles pepper in the Russian’s shirt, & the Russian puts lice in the Jew’s trousers. When the Russian can resist no longer, he says that his uncle received medals from the czar, which he wore “here & here & here”, thus scratching those places. The Jew replies that his uncle received so many medals that he had to put them in his trousers’ pocket & feel around for them – which he demonstrates.
1715
1565*The Big CakeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManDuring Lent, the farmers are not allowed to eat more than a single cake. They bake a cake as big as a cart wheel. In some variants they may eat only one spoonful of porridge, so they make a huge spoon. In a Jewish version (Sephardic), a man has to abstain from alcohol for health reasons. However, he is allowed a glass of wine on the Sabbath. He has a big glass made that holds an entire bottle of wine.
1716
1565**Turnips as BaconAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer who gives his farmhand only turnips to eat all winter, makes him agree that they are bacon (beans are fish, herring are carp, etc.); otherwise the farmer wants the man to leave. During the hard work at harvest time, the farmhand threat-ens to leave the farmer if he does not call a cat a rabbit (bear, stork).
1717
1566**Butter v. BreadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA baker orders four pounds of butter from a farmer. Later he complains that the weight was short. The farmer explains that he had weighed the butter against a four-pound loaf of bread which he had bought from the baker.
1718
1566A*Maids Must Rise Even EarlierAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThe maids kill the rooster for wak-ing them too early. Then their mistress wakes them even earlier.
1719
1567-Stingy HouseholdAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA stingy master gives his farmhand bread crusts to eat. The farmhand claims that he would get full more quickly on soft bread, so the master gives him both. In a Spanish version, a landlady serves a tailor only one egg, & he sings a little song about it. For his next meal she gives him two eggs. He composes other songs to compel her to give him more eggs & a sausage, etc., as well. A master gives his farmhands no butter to eat, intending to sell it instead. The farmhands make a fish into a model of a “butter-dealer”. Their master asks what it is, & when they explain, he relents & gives them their butter.
1720
1567AStingy Innkeeper Cured of Serving Weak BeerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA householder (inn-keeper) gives his farmhands watered beer (plain water) to drink before meals, to fill up their stomachs. The farmhands tell him that the drink serves to clean out their insides so that they actually have more room for the food.
1721
1567CAsking the Large FishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA humble guest (beggar, juggler, the son of selfish parents) is served small fish, while the hosts (parents) take (hide under the bed) the large ones for themselves. The guest holds a small fish up to his ear. The host asks why, & the guest replies that he had asked the fish where his recently-drowned father (Jonas & the whale) is. The fish answered that he is too young to know such a thing, but the guest should ask the older fish (under the bed). In some variants, a stinking fish should have said he does not know what happened recently in the sea because he was caught eight days ago. Everyone laughs, & the guest is served a bigger (fresher) fish.
1722
1567EThe Hungry Man's LiesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManAn apprentice tells lies about his stingy master (often in front of other people). The master gives the apprentice more food (rice, beans, eggs) in order to silence him. Thus the master loses his hoard.
1723
1567FHungry ShepherdAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA hungry shepherd is not invited to eat by his master. He tells about a cow (goat) with four teats who bore five calves (kids). The people ask what the fifth calf does while the other four are nursing. The shepherd says, “It just watches as I am doing now”. He is then invited to join the meal.
1724
1567GGood Food Changes SongAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManWorkmen employed at a temporary job (threshing, mowing, woodworking) complain about their food in song (e.g. SO-O-OUP, SO-O-OUP, SO-O-OUP) & slow down their work. The next day, their master gives them better food. They change their song to reflect this (BREAD-MEAT-AND-PUDDING-TOO, BREAD-MEAT-AND-PUDDING-TOO) & work faster.
1725
1567HThe Big & the Small FishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo men buy fish from a fishmonger who has only one big & one small fish. At dinner, one of the men takes the big fish for himself, explaining to his partner that a good host would naturally take only the smaller portion.
1726
1568*The Master & the Farmhand at the TableAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer & his farmhands help themselves to food out of a common dish. The farmwife always places the dish so that the best piece of meat lies near the farmer. Once the farmhand comes to the table early. No one is in the room, so he moves the dish to put the best serving near his own place. The farmer sees what he did, picks up the dish saying, “This dish once costed one thaler”, & moves it back to its customary position. Before he can stab the meat, the farmhand picks up the dish, says, “And it is still worth that today”, & moves the dish back near his own place. In some variants the farmer (clergyman) gets the best pieces (e.g. cracklings, butter) from the common dish by asking the other diners whether they know which way the sun (moon) rotates. He rotates the dish right or left to move the best part near himself. When the dish is in place, the farmhand says, “And then the thunderstorm begins”, stabbing his fist into the dish (stabbing the dish on the farmer’s head).
1727
1568**The Master & the Pupil QuarrelAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA stingy tailor sticks all the bits of meat together. When the meal is served, he takes the first helping, & all the meat lands on his plate. He announces, “What God has joined together, let no man put asunder”. The hungry apprentices plan revenge. They tell a customer that their master does good work but his temper is unpredictable: he often strikes the table with his fist & then falls in a rage. Before the tailor cuts the cloth, he hits the table to make the shears bounce so he can hear where they are & find them. The customer thinks the tailor is going to attack him & defends himself by grabbing the tailor around the neck & fighting. The tailor calls his apprentices to help, but they answer, “What God has joined together, let no man put asunder”.
1728
1569**Clothing the ServantAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master agrees to clothe a servant (i.e. pro vide his clothing) at his expense. The servant insists that the condition be fulfilled literally, that the master dresses him.
1729
1570*"Gorge Silently"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier (guest), who is spending the night, eats up a whole dish of food. He asks the landlady (housewife) what this delicious food is called. She answers, “Gorge silently”. The soldier says, “Please give me some more of this gorge-silently”.
1730
1571*Servants Punish Their MasterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master hides in order to watch his farmhands at their work. The farmhands discover him spying, make as if he is a thief, & beat him. He defends himself by saying that he is the master. They make as if he said something else & continue to beat him.
1731
1571**The Boastful ServantAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA servant boasts that he has scolded his master. But he does it secretly, so that the master does not hear.
1732
1572*The Master's PrivilegeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer asks his farmhand if he has any per sonal defects, & the farmhand replies that he sometimes gets into a rage (other description). The farmer says that his own defect is that he sometimes gets into a frenzy (etc.). The first time the farmhand man gets into a rage, he stays in bed (leaves his work), so the farmer gets into a frenzy & beats him. This cures the farmhand’s rage, & the master no longer gets into a frenzy either.
1733
1572A*The Saints Ate the CreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA clergyman sets a jug of sour cream (cream, milk, ham, honey) near a saint’s picture (in the pantry). When he is gone, the sexton (farmhand) steals (empties) it, smearing a little cream on the saint’s picture (statues). The clergyman believes that the icon stole the cream. He insults it & removes it from the church (the sexton hides it secretly, & the clergyman thinks it has run away). On the next holy day (the saint’s feast day), the clergyman asks the sexton (offers to pay him) to get a new icon. The sexton polishes the old icon & pretends that the saint has returned. The clergyman promises always to give the icon good food. The sexton thus eats well in the future.
1734
1572B*What God Gave HimAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA guest pulls all of the meat out of the soup & says, “What I caught, that is what God gave me”. After dinner the host pulls the guest by the hair & speaks the same words.
1735
1572C*"Don't Contradict Me!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA guest refuses something that his host has offered. Snapping, “Don’t contradict me!”, the host beats him. The guest replies, “Don’t tell me what to do!”, & strikes back. In some variants, the host beats one guest for contradicting him. Another guest eats everything that is offered to him, trades his poor clothes with the better ones of the host, & rides away on the host’s horse.
1736
1572E*The Clever Coachman & the Hungry MasterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManWhile traveling, a master neglects to bring (order) food for his coachman. The coachman intentionally leaves his master behind in the forest.
1737
1572F*Turning the Shovel BackwardsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmhand dislikes large peas (beans), so he eats with his spoon upside down, saying, “If you stay on, I will eat you”. He gets married (his master sends him away) & has to provide for himself. Being in trouble, he asks his former master for a shovelful of uncooked peas. They go to the storeroom & the master turns the shovel upside down. He scoops the dry peas, saying, “If you stay on, I will measure you”.
1738
1572K*Not Many WordsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master (woman) explains to his new farmhand that he does not like to use a lot of words. When he winks, the farmhand should come. The farmhand answers that that is fine with him, because he does not like to waste words either. When he shakes his head, that means he is not coming
1739
1572L*No Pay for Lying in the SunAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManInstead of working, a lazy farmhand lies down outdoors & sleeps. His master tells him that he does not deserve the sunshine that falls on him. The farmhand answers that he is lying in the shade (he will lie in the shade in the future).
1740
1572M*The Apprentice's DreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManAn apprentice tells his master that he dreamed he fell in a barrel of liquid manure & that the master fell into a barrel of honey. The master says that if this had happened the other way around, he would have punished him. Then the apprentice tells him the end of the dream: After they climbed out of the barrels, they had to lick each other clean.
1741
1572N*Cure for ConstipationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master (king) complains to his servant (coach man) that he is constipated. In order to cure him, the servant takes the master for a drive. After a while, the master feels his bowels loosen & asks the servant to stop. The servant keeps on driving until the master cannot wait any longer. Then he stops the coach & lets him get down. This time, the master’s bowels open immediately.
1742
1573*The Clever Servant as Trouble MakerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA servant creates great discord in his master’s household: he puts dough in his master’s bed & a newborn lamb in his daughters’, ties the dogs together, sticks a flute in the donkey’s backside, etc. The next morning, a fight breaks out over which of the parents relieved himself in bed, which of the daughters gave birth, etc.
1743
1574-The Tailor's DreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManFor many years, a tailor has stolen cloth from his customers. He dreams that on Judgment Day he has to answer to God by making a flag out of all the pieces of stolen cloth. After this dream, he swears not to steal any more, & asks one of his em-ployees to remind him of the dream if he ever lapses. For a long time, the tailor steals nothing. One day he is given some particularly fine material & plans to steal it. When the employee reminds him of his resolution, the tailor replies that this particular piece of material was not part of the flag.
1744
1574*The Foresightful FarmhandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManWhenever the master tells his farmhand what work should be done the following day, the farmhand says, “I already thought of that”. Finally the master dupes him by saying that tomorrow they must sow salt. The farmhand says that he had already thought of that.
1745
1574AThe Stolen Piece of ClothAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) By mistake, a tailor sews a piece of cloth he has stolen on the outside of his coat, rather than on the inside. (2) A tailor takes advantage of an opportunity to cut a big piece of cloth. Then he realizes that he cut it out of his own coat Or, the tailor, who regularly takes part of his customers’ cloth for himself, cuts out some cloth for himself & lays a piece aside. When his wife asks what he is doing, he replies he did not want to get out of practice. (3) A stingy woman has the tailor come to her own house so that he will not be able to steal her cloth. The tailor cuts a piece & throws it out of the window, saying, “That is the devil’s piece”. While the woman runs outside to retrieve it, the tailor cuts another big piece of cloth for himself.
1746
1575*The Clever ShepherdAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master refuses to pay back the money he has borrowed from his shepherd (the master makes his farmhand work too hard or gives him poor food). The shepherd hides up in a tree. When the master passes by, the shepherd calls out his name in a disguised voice & demands that the master pay (assign different work, give better food). The master believes that it is God speaking to him & does what the shepherd demands.
1747
1575A*God SpeaksAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (clergyman) rides his bicycle (walks) along a road bordered by trees. One (more) of his neighbors hides behind a tree & calls out his name (calls, “Turn back!”). After this happens three times, the man thinks it is God who is speaking to him, & he answers, “Yes, Lord, I hear you”.
1748
1577-Blind Men Duped into FightingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA trickster (Eulenspiegel) says that he is giving one of several blind men some money which they all should share. However, he does not give any of them any money. Each suspects the others of cheating & they fight. The trickster watches from a safe distance. In some variants, the trickster takes them to an inn to drink but does not give any of them the money.
1749
1577*Blind Robber Paid BackAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA blind trickster steals from (does not return some money to) a harmless man. The injured man follows the blind man home & steals his whole hoard of money. Often he robs (tricks) several blind men.
1750
1577**The Blind Man TrickedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA boy who works as a guide & servant to a stingy blind man is so hungry that he steals a sausage (pie) from him. The blind man smells that the boy has eaten the food & beats him. The boy takes revenge by pretending to help the blind man cross a pit. He leads the man near a post (tree), runs a few steps, & pretends to jump over the pit. The blind man copies him & jumps into the post. He falls & is injured. The boy comments, “If he could smell that I ate the sausage, he should have smelled that there was a post there”.
1751
1578*The Inventive BeggarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA beggar gives a woman his knife to cut off a piece of bread for him & pretends that he used the knife before to dismember a dog. (Or, a Gypsy tells a bishop that he tasted food from the bishop’s dish.) The woman (bishop) is so appalled that she gives him the whole loaf (dish).
1752
1578A*The Drinking CupAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA boy (girl, servant girl) offers a thirsty guest a glass (bowl) of water (milk, juice, wine). After he drinks, the boy tells him that a mouse had drowned in the water or that the bowl had been used as a chamber pot (dog’s dish).
1753
1578B*How a Woman Came to Loathe TripeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA woman develops an aver-sion to offal (tripe) after she sees the unappetizing manner of its preparation.
1754
1578C*The AppleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer (boy) brings two apples (pears) to his landlord. The landlord bites one himself & gives the other back to the farmer. The farmer takes out a knife to peel his apple, & the land lord asks why he does not eat the peel. The farmer tells him that one of the apples fell into a cowpat (manure) but he is not sure which one it was.
1755
1579-Carrying Wolf, Goat, & Cabbage across StreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man has to cross a stream in a boat that will hold himself & only one other object. He needs to transport a wolf (lion, jackal), a goat (sheep), & a cabbage (bundle of hay, pumpkin). He must be sure that, when he is out in the boat, the wolf does not eat the goat & the goat does not eat the cabbage. There are two solutions. (1) He takes the goat across, then takes wolf across & brings goat back; he takes cabbage across, comes back, & takes the goat across last. (2) He takes the goat over, then takes the cabbage over & brings the goat back; he takes wolf over, & then takes goat over last.
1756
1579**A Hundred AnimalsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (farmer) is driving a herd of pigs (sheep). Someone asks him where he is going with his hundred animals. He answers, “If I had this many again, & half, & a quarter, & one, then I would have a hundred animals”. Answer: He has 36 animals.
1757
1580A*Mounting the HorseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA drunken traveler (clergyman) is unable to mount his horse. He calls on God, various saints, & the forty holy martyrs to help him. He then manages to get up onto the saddle, but falls over the other side. He concoles himself that he had too many helpers.
1758
1585-The Lawyer's Mad ClientAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer (in financial distress) sells the same animal (hog, cow, calf, hare) to several different people (has committed other misdemeanors) & is to stand trial. His lawyer ad-vises him to plead insanity, & to speak only in animal noises (barks, bleats) or always to answer in the same words (yes, aha, nothing, nonsense words). He is not convicted, & his lawyer demands his fee. The man uses the same trick & does not pay.
1759
1585*The Farmer's PromiseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer consults a lawyer & promises to send him a rabbit as payment (is paid for a rabbit which he claims he sent to his master). When the lawyer (master) later asks where the rabbit is, the farmer answers that he sent it to him, but perhaps the animal did not know (forgot) the address.
1760
1586-The Man in Court for Killing a FlyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man (farmer, baker, fool) goes to court, accusing flies of stealing. The judge (mayor, czar) decrees that the man may kill whatever flies he can. A fly lands on the judge’s nose (cheek), & the complainant carries out the sentence. The judge is injured or killed, but no one can accuse the foolish fly-killer. (2) A fool (several fools) tries to kill (shoo away) a fly (several flies, bees, etc.) with an unsuitable instrument (ax, cannon, sword, gun, etc.). He accidentally kills the person whom the insect had been bothering. In some variants the killer is an (tame) animal (e.g. bear, monkey).
1761
1586BThe Fine for AssaultAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man who hates the mayor (judge) asks him how much the fine would be if he hit someone (is required to pay a fine for having hit someone). He pays that amount (double) & hits the mayor.
1762
1588*The UnseenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA judge calls a certain man as a witness & asks him whether he saw something. The man answers, he only heard. The judge dismisses him, saying that anything he heard is worth nothing. As he leaves, the witness produces a powerful fart. The judge reproves him, but the man asks him whether he saw it: anything he heard is worth nothing.
1763
1588**Cheater Caught by Seizing on His Own WordsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA father warns his sons against red-haired & red-faced men. They stay with a red-haired innkeeper. They like his food so much that they tell him each spoonful is worth ten francs. The innkeeper secretly counts how many spoonfuls they eat. When they go to pay, he demands a great amount of money. Further on, the sons meet a red-faced man & are about to flee. He stops them & asks why, so they tell him about their father’s warning & the innkeeper’s trickery. The red-faced man goes back with them to the inn. The innkeeper is about to slaughter an animal, & the red-faced man contracts to buy a quarter (the shoulder). He draws his sword as if he would slaughter the innkeeper & take a quarter of his body. The innkeeper redeems himself for as much money as the sons had paid for their food. The red-faced man gives them the money.
1764
1588***The Fraudulent WillAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA trickster (who has been coached by a relative, or who is working with an accomplice) impersonates a man who has died & dictates his will to a notary who does not know about the death. Contrary to a prearranged plan, the new will benefits the trickster (gives him the entire estate).
1765
1589-The Lawyer's Dog Steals MeatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA butcher sees a dog stealing meat. He runs after it & finds out that it is a lawyer’s dog. He asks the lawyer what the punishment is for this crime & is told how much the damages would be. The butcher tells the lawyer that it was his (i.e. the lawyer’s) dog. The lawyer pays the damages, but calls the butcher back & de mands more money (double) in payment for his advice.
1766
1590-The Tresspasser's DefenceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Two men fight over a piece of land that each claims is his own. The case comes to court. The false owner (one or more witnesses) swears a false oath: The perjurer takes earth from his own prop erty & puts it in his shoes (a ladle or comb under his hat). He goes to the property (before the judge) & swears that he is standing on his own ground, or calls on the creator (the ladle, German Schöpfer) or the judge (the comb, German dialect Richter) as witness. The case is decided in favor of the trickster (he is punished through an ordeal or by human or supernatural forces immediately or after death). The tale concludes with an explanation of local property ownership (a warning against false testimony). (2) Through laziness (criminal activities, etc.), a man (Eulen spiegel) falls out of the favor of his king (master). As punishment (to get rid of him), he is banished. The man comes back in a cart with foreign soil (foreign dirt in his shoes) & thus cleverly avoids his punishment. He is reconciled with the king (is banished again; is captured & subjected to a fake execution, & dies of fright).
1767
1591-The Three Joint DepositorsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Two men leave money with a woman & instruct her to return it only when both of them demand it. Later, one asks for the money & explains that the other has since died. The woman gives it to him. The second man comes & demands the money. The woman will not give it to him so he takes her to court. Her lawyer (Demosthenes) advises her: She should tell the judge about the agreement & offer to pay out the money only when both of the men come & demand it. The case is dismissed. (2) Three men leave money with a banker, with the same instructions as in version (1). One of the three arranges with the others to withdraw some of the money. He tells his companions he will take only a small amount, but he takes the entire sum from the banker. The banker asks the two others, who agree, thinking it is only a small sum. The cheater leaves, & the tale ends as in version (1), following the instructions of a clever adviser.
1768
1592-The Iron-eating MiceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA merchant going on a journey leaves some iron (iron object, lead, gold) in trust with someone (another merchant, innkeeper, friend, Jew).
