When he comes back later for his property, the trustee claims that mice (rats) have eaten it. The merchant kid-naps the son of the trustee & claims that a falcon (other raptor) carried him off. The judge decides that the two men should make an exchange. In a Middle Eastern version, the cheated man calls on a trickster (Nasreddin Hodja, Bohlul) for help. This helper threatens to destroy (burn) the house in order to punish the thieving mice. The trustee relents.
1769
1592AThe Transformed GoldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA merchant (carpenter, pilgrim) gives his neighbor (friend, cadi, Jew) (a vessel of) gold to keep for him. When the merchant later asks for it back, the trustee gives him (a similar vessel of) copper (brass, tallow) & claims that the gold changed to base metal. The merchant kidnaps the son (children) of the false trustee. He trains an animal (monkey, bear) so that it welcomes the trustee & claims that the boy turned into the animal. The trustee relents.
1770
1592BPot Has a Child & DiesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA borrower returns a pot together with a small one, claiming that the pot gave birth to a child. He borrows the pot again but does not return it, claiming that the pot died.
1771
1592B*The Deceiving MerchantAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManWhile counting a hundred eggs, an egg merchant cheats a woman by asking questions about the ages of various people (family members) & adding those numbers to the number he has recorded.
1772
1593-The ClotheslineAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man refuses to lend his neighbor a clothesline, saying that he needs it to dry flour (grain). When the neighbor questions this, the man replies that he will use his clothesline for anything at all in order not to have to lend it.
1773
1594-The Donkey is Not at HomeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer wants to borrow his neighbor’s donkey, but the neighbor says it has already been loaned to someone else (sent out to pasture, sent to work, etc.). The farmer hears the donkey braying in its stall (sees it tied up) & says the neighbor must be lying. The neighbor asks why he would believe a donkey rather than a man like himself.
1774
1595-The Rabbit PoacherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManIn order to catch hares in his garden, a man (shoe maker) sets a trap with a cord tied to a bell that will ring when an animal is caught. When the game warden learns about this, he goes to talk to the would-be poacher. Just then the bell rings. The two men go together into the garden & find the rabbit in the trap. The poacher takes the animal out, beats it with a stick, & then sets it free, saying, “That will teach you not to come back here!”
1775
1600-The Fool as MurdererAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA fool murders a man (finds a corpse) whom he throws into a well. His brothers (father) remove the corpse unnoticed & put the carcass of a goat in its place. The fool confesses to the murder & is told he must show the head of the dead man as evidence. He finds only the dead goat & is surprised to see that the murdered man had horns. With this evi-dence, no one believes he committed a murder, & he is set free.
1776
1605*The Tax ExemptionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer buys a stallion in order to avoid paying taxes. When the tax collector comes, the stallion copulates with his mare. The tax collector is frightened & runs away. Or, a soldier rides into a village on his donkey. He claims that his donkey can take care of all the villagers’ taxes. When the tax collector comes, the donkey attacks his horse. The tax collector forgives all the taxes owed.
1777
1610-Sharing the RewardAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer finds the king’s hawk, which had been lost while hunting, & wants to give it back to the king. He meets a soldier (watchman, Jew, minister, general) who offers to lead him to the king if the farmer will give him half of the reward. The farmer agrees. When they arrive with the hawk, the king asks the farmer what reward he would like. The farmer asks for a beating, half of which is given to the soldier. When the farmer explains their arrangement, the king gives him an extra sum of money.
1778
1611-Contest in Climbing the MastAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA youth climbs up the mast of a ship, falls down, & is caught in the rigging. He calls to the sailors, “Can you do that?” They think he fell on purpose & take him for an ex-perienced sailor.
1779
1612-The Contest in SwimmingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTwo swimmers are to compete. One of them takes a knapsack with provisions. His rival gives up the contest.
1780
1613-Playing-Cards are my Calendar & Prayer Book.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA soldier (servant) is caught playing cards dur ing church. His sergeant demands that he put the cards away, but the soldier refuses. When the soldier is brought to the major for punishment, he ex-plains that each card has a spiritual significance: the ace is God the Father, the deuce is the dual nature of Christ, the three is the Holy Trinity, the four is the four evangelists, the five is the wounds of Christ, etc., up to ten. Then come the face cards: the four queens are the Virgin Mary & the three women at the Holy Sepulchur, the four kings show the three wise men & the greatest among them whom they came to worship, etc. Then the soldier explains that the deck of cards is also a calendar, with 365 spots, 52 pages & 12 pictures. He lays the jack of clubs aside, saying that this card is not respectable. The major asks what it represents, & the soldier replies that it is the sergeant who accused him of blasphemy. The major rewards the solider with money (and punishes him in addition).
1781
1613A*Political ConvictionsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManIn the 18th century a man is brought before a group of men & asked if he is a monarchist or a republican. He answers, “A republican”, & is beaten because the group of men are monarchists. Some time later, he is questioned again. Now he answers, “Mon-ar chist”. This time the group is republican, so the man is beaten again. The third time this happens, the man answers, “I belong to the devil!” This time no one beats him.
1782
1614*Repairingg the WellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer digs a well, but it caves in. He puts his jacket & cap next to the hole & hides. The passersby think that someone has been trapped in the well & dig to rescue him. When they have repaired the hole, the farmer comes out of hiding & thanks them.
1783
1615-The Marked CoinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA trickster observes thieves dividing their booty. He ties a red string through a hole in his only coin & puts it in among the thieves’ money. Then he claims that all the money is his, because it includes his marked coin. The thieves give him a share of the booty.
1784
1617-Unjust Banker is Deceived into Delivering DepositsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (woman) goes on a journey (pilgrimage) and/or gives his money (jewels, other valuables) to an acquaintance (official, religious person, judge) to keep on his behalf. When he asks for his money back, the ac quaint-ance lies & says that he has nothing of that man’s. A friend (wife, ruler) helps the man get his money back by making the cheater believe that if he returns it, he will be given even more. In addition to this European form, this type exhibits considerable variation.
1785
1617*The Blind Man's TreasureAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA (blind) man buries a treasure, but is ob served by another man (neighbor). Or the blind man tells his god father where the treasure is hidden. The money is stolen. The blind man tricks the suspect by telling him that he had planned to put the same amount (an even greater sum) of money in the same place . The thief brings the stolen money back in the hope that he can steal double the amount. In the end he gets nothing.
1786
1620-The Emperor's New ClothesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis type exists chiefly in two different versions: (1) A trickster pretends to be a painter & is hired to decorate the walls in the house of a wealthy man. While he works (along with his assistants), his employer pays his expenses (and gives him an ad-vance payment). The trickster paints nothing, but he claims that his paintings can be seen only by persons of noble birth (chaste women). Everyone praises the paintings rather than risk being accused. A fool (foolish woman, soldier) says that he would rather be a bastard, but that he does not see any pictures. (2) A man (two, more) pretends that he can weave fine cloth (cloth-ing, coat, cap), & is employed by a ruler. When the weaver is asked how his work is progressing, he explains that the clothing can be seen only by people of noble birth (chaste women). The ruler comes to be fitted. Neither he nor his courtiers will admit that they can see no clothing. When the ruler goes outside naked, only a child speaks the truth.
1787
1620*The Conversation of Two Handicapped PersonsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in three different versions: (1) A one-eyed man tells a hunchbacked man that he took up his burden too soon. “No, it is not too soon” answers the hunchbacked man, “it only looks so to you because you have only one of your windows open”. (2) A young woman jokes with a hunchbacked man, saying that he has too much back. He answers, “Be careful that you don’t end up with too much belly”. (3) A short man tells a one-eyed man that he needs another eye. The one-eyed man answers, “To see a giant such as yourself, I would need two more eyes”.
1788
1621*The Horse is Cleverer Than the PriestAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer says that his horse is cleverer than the priest, because once the horse has stepped into a hole in the road, he avoids it. In contrast, the priest has had two children by the same woman.
1789
1621A*Donkey Refuses to Drink after It Has Had EnoughAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer claims that his donkey is cleverer than he is. The donkey (ox, horse) stops drinking when it has had enough, but he himself always keeps on drinking (to please his friends).
1790
1623*An Old Hen Instead of a Young OneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA master asks his servant to bring him a young woman, but instead the servant brings an old one. The master dismisses him. The servant tells the mistress why he lost his job, & she gives it back to him.
1791
1624-Thief's Excuse: The Big WindAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man (Gypsy) is caught stealing vege-tables from a garden. He claims that the wind carried him over the fence & also uprooted the vegetables. When he is asked how the vegetables got into his sack, the thief says he was wondering about that himself.
1792
1624A*Shortest RoadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA Gypsy trying to break into a house to steal falls through a hole in the ceiling. He explains that he was only taking the shortest way.
1793
1624B*The Theft of BaconAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A thief (Gypsy) accidentally comes through the chimney into the living room with the bacon he has stolen. Because he is black with soot, he convinces the inhabitants of the house that he is the devil (he says that the devil sent him with the bacon, & they reply that he should take it back to hell). (2) A thief (soldier, Gypsy) goes into a house to steal bacon (suit). When the owner hears a noise, he comes & finds the thief with the bacon. The thief asks him if he would like to buy some.
1794
1624C*The Horse's FaultAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA horse thief brought before a judge explains that the horse had been standing across the road. He had intended to jump over the animal but instead he landed on its back, & it ran away carrying him with it.
1795
1626-Dream BreadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManTraveling companions (pilgrims, friends, brothers, master & servant, clergyman & Gypsy) agree that whichever of them has the most wonderful dream may eat their last loaf of bread. One man stays awake & eats the bread. The next morning, the others tell their dreams: one dreamed that he was in heaven (paradise) & another that he was in hell. The third man says he saw them there in his dream (he had dreamed they were dead), & he ate the bread because he thought they would not need it (would not be coming back).
1796
1628-The Learned Son & the Forgotten LanguageAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA farmer’s son, having returned home from college, pretends that he has forgotten his native language or that he can speak only Latin. But when he inadvertently steps on a rake & the handle hits his forehead, he cries, “Damned rake!”
1797
1628*So They Speak LatinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA father sends his lazy son to college. When the son comes home, he demonstrates how successful he was in his studies by putting Latin endings on all his words (uses bits of Latin) until his father loses patience & uses similar formulas to order him to work (until the priest who has been summon to test him throws him out).
1798
1629*The Supposed Magic SpellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA thief tells a farmer to crawl into a tub & sit there without looking out while he says a magic spell (to cure the farmer’s sterility). While the farmer obeys, the thief steals all his belongings.
1799
1630A*Son Has Only Beaten Father's CapAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA father & son (mother & son, married couple) have an argument during which the son hits his father (pushes him downstairs). Later he claims that he only hit (threw down) his father’s cap (jacket, coat, socks), & it was unfortunate that his father was inside it.
1800
1630B*The Bear Thought to be a LogAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA man sees what he thinks is a tree trunk in the river & swims out to get it. It turns out to be a bear, which catches hold of him. His friends on the bank call out, “Let go of him!” The swimmer answers, “He will not let go of me!”
1801
1631-Horse That Will Not Go over TreesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA dealer selling a horse says that it eats too much & will not go over trees. The unsuspecting buyer discovers that the horse bites everyone within reach & refuses to walk over a wooden bridge.
1802
1631*The Tailor & the Smith as WooerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA tailor & a smith (and a shoemaker) woo the same woman. The tailor tells her that the smith is blind: if she watches him work, she will see that he hits the iron twice & then hits the anvil. The woman confirms this. In revenge, the smith tells the woman that the tailor is insane. He puts a red-hot piece of iron in the tailor’s boot. When the tailor puts the boot on, he falls down with pain & cries, “It is burning!” Everyone agrees that he must be insane. The woman marries the smith (no one).
1803
1631AMule Painted & Sold Back to OwnerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA donkey (mule, horse, cow, goat) is stolen or sold. The new owner (thief, dealer, farmer, Gypsy, servant) paints it (makes it look young & fresh) & sells it at a big profit to its original owner (master, priest, charcoal dealer, farmer), who likes it because of its similarity to his old animal. (Even though he had been warned, he does not notice the trick.)After the buyer takes the animal home, the paint washes off in the rain (river, wash water) & the owner recognizes his old animal.
1804
1633-Joint Ownership of the CowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA father dies, leaving his possessions for his two sons to divide. The older son takes the hind end of the cow & the younger son gets the front end, so that the first takes the milk but the second must feed the animal. Similar unfair settlements follow. A friend (relative) advises the younger son how to obtain a fair share.
1805
1634*Various Tricks Played by GypsiesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManMisc. type with diverse contents
1806
1634A*Fish Promised in Return for Food & MoneyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA Gypsy is told by the fishermen that it is difficult to catch fish. In return for food & money, the Gypsy promises to tell the fishermen a time when all the fish will be ready to be caught. They agree. After five days as the fishermen’s guest, the Gypsy takes the money & goes to the lake, saying now is the right time. He tells the fishermen to drink up all the water in the lake, & then they will be able to catch all the fish. He will even help them.
1807
1634E*Throwing the Thief over the FenceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA thief is surprised by the owner of the house he is robbing. The thief cries, “Do whatever you want to me, but don’t throw me over the fence!” The angry owner throws him over the fence & the thief runs away.
1808
1635*Eulenspiegel's TricksAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManMisc. type with diverse variants, esp. popular in German-, Dutch- & Polish-speaking countries.
1809
1636-The Repentant ThiefAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA repentant thief brings a stolen cow back to its owner, pretending to have found the animal. He warns the owner to be more careful with it in the future.
1810
1638*Why It is Not a Sin for a Gypsy to StealAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA Gypsy stole one of the nails that was intended to have been used for the crucifixion of Jesus. Because of this, it is not a sin for Gypsies to steal.
1811
1639*The Royal Order Concerning ClothingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1525-1639 Clever ManA garment dealer is oversupplied with a certain type of garment (fur) & stands to lose money. The friendly king orders that everyone who appears before him must wear that type of gar ment. The dealer becomes rich.
1812
1640-The Brave Tailor (Seven with One Stroke)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky Accidents(Seven with one stroke.) A tailor kills seven flies with one blow & wears a sign on his belt, “Seven at one stroke”. He goes out into the world & finds something (cheese, bird) which he puts into his pocket. He meets a giant who challenges him to prove his strength. The giant squeezes water out of a stone, & the tailor matches him by squeezing his cheese. The giant throws a stone high into the air & the tailor throws his bird. The giant orders the tailor to help him carry a tree out of the forest, so the tailor takes the top end & rides in the branches. Using various tricks, he accomplishes other feats. The tailor goes to the king’s palace. The king promises the tailor his daughter in marriage & half the kingdom if he can accomplish several tasks: vanquishing two giants, catching a unicorn (the animal runs into a tree with its horn, & cannot get free), & catching a wild boar (he drives it into a church). The tailor uses tricks to accomplish the tasks. After the tailor marries the princess, he accidentally (by speaking of needle & thread, or in his sleep) discloses his humble origin. The king sends his soldiers to take back the tailor’s kingdom. The tailor pretends to be asleep & brags about his heroic deeds. The soldiers flee in fear, & the tailor keeps his kingdom.
1813
1641-Doctor Know-AllAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA farmer named Crab (Cricket, Rat) dresses as a doctor & calls himself Doctor Know-All. In exchange for food & lodging for three days, he offers to Discover who stole a ring (treasure) from a rich man (king). He is to be hanged if he fails. When servants enter the room (at the end of the three days), he says, “That is the first (second, third)”. The servants believe he has discovered their theft, & admit to having stolen the ring. To prove his power, he must say what is inside a covered dish (closed fist). He has no idea & bemoans, “Poor Crab (Cricket, Rat)!” He is lucky that this is the right answer. He gives a purgative to a person whose horse had been stolen. When the person has to go outside, he discovers his missing horse. Or Dr. Know-All hides the horse himself & then Discovers it. In variants from northern Europe, he becomes a clergyman. He impresses the local farmers with his short & incomprehensible sermons (when his pulpit suddenly collapses, because it had been sawed through.
1814
1641ASham Physician Pretends to Diagnose Enitrely from UrinanalysisAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA man posing as a physician claims to be able to diagnose by examining the patient’s urine. He actually depends on his own observations & makes inferences from trifling details.
1815
1641BPhysician in Spite of HimselfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA wife who is beaten by her husband takes revenge by claiming that her husband is a famous doctor who can prescribe medicine only after he has been beaten Through his foolish behavior the false doctor cures a sick princess by making her laugh so hard that the sore in her throat opens & heals (she dislodges a fish-bone from her throat).
1816
1641B*Who Stole from the Church?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA man promises that in exchange for a good meal he will reveal who stole something from the church. After he eats, he declares, “They were thieves”.
1817
1641CGibberish Thought to be LatinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA farmer (charcoal burner, uneducated man) speaks (by accident) some Latin-sounding words & is taken for a clergyman or an educated person (and marries a princess).
1818
1641C*"Do Not Postpone till Tomorrow What You Can Do Today."Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA farmer asks a seemingly-clever lawyer if he can buy some “good advice” (“intelligence”). The lawyer writes something on a piece of paper, puts it into an envelope, & gives it to the farmer. The farmer pays him for this. The following day, the farmer & his workmen cannot decide whether or not they should mow the hay (grain). The farmer opens the letter, which says, “Never put off until tomorrow what you can do today”. They cut the hay & store it. Suddenly it begins to rain, & they see the wisdom of the lawyer’s advice.
1819
1641DThe Sham PhysicianAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA sham physician heals sick people (malingerers) by threatening to kill them if they do not get well. He cures patients in a hospital by threatening to incinerate whichever of them is the sickest or to make ointment out of his body. After he receives his reward, he goes away. Some days (one week) later the really sick patients come back.
1820
1641D*Misc. Tales of CharlatansAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a charlatan, a sham physician, or a sham wise man who pretends to be able to cure people.
1821
1642-The Good BargainAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsThis anecdote is comprised of various motifs & episodes from other humorous tales. A foolish farmer performs various senseless actions that turn out to be to his advantage:Because he misunderstands the croaking of frogs, he throws money into the pond for them to count. He sells meat to a dog, expecting it to carry it to the butcher. Or, he puts goods to be sold to a signpost. When he returns for his money & does not receive it, he com-plains to the king (takes the dog to court) & thus causes the melancholy princess to laugh. He declines to marry her & is offered a different reward, which he promises to a guard (soldier) & a Jew. The king orders a beating instead of money, & the Jew receives the blows. The Jew takes the farmer to court, loaning him his coat (boots). At the trial, the farmer denies that he has borrowed the coat & thus renders the Jew’s testimony unbelievable (makes the Jew appear to be insane).
1822
1642AThe Borrowed CoatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA farmer (Gypsy, Jew, sexton) is summoned to court by a Jew (farmer, clergyman). The farmer refuses to go unless he has a new coat, so the Jew loans him one. In court, the farmer says the Jew is a liar. He will even say that the coat that I am wearing is his. The Jew confirms this, & all his testimony is discredited.
1823
1643-Money Inside the StatueAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA woman sends her foolish son to sell some linen (cow, other wares), telling him not to deal with people who talk too much. The son takes this literally & refuses to sell to anyone who asks the price of the cloth. He sells the cloth (cow, other goods) to a statue (crucifix) because it does not speak, & says he will come back the next day for the money. His mother is dismayed when being told at her son’s stupid bargain. When he goes back to get the money, the cloth has been stolen & the statue will not speak. Angry, the son throws a stone at the statue. It breaks & inside is a pot of money (treasure) which he mis takes for bean.
1824
1644-The Early PupilAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsAn old man (farmer, workman, father) decides (is advised) to go to school (because he thinks it will make him rich). The teacher tells him that he has come too late, meaning that he is too old. Each day, the man arrives earlier. One day at dawn he finds a chest (purse) full of money.
1825
1645-The Treasure at HomeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA man dreams that he finds a treasure on a bridge in a distant city. He goes to find it but is unsuccessful. While he is there, he tells his dream to a man (beggar), who in turn relates a similar dream in which he found a treasure in the house of the first man. When the first man returns home, he finds the treasure there.
1826
1645ADream of Treasure BoughtAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA king falls asleep under a tree. A servant observes an animal creep out of his mouth, run to a stream, & try to cross it. The servant lays his sword across the stream, & the animal runs over it & into an opening in a mountain. Later the animal goes back into the mouth of the sleeping king. The king awakes & relates that he dreamed that he went over a stream on an iron bridge & entered a mountain where he found a great treasure. The servant tells the king what he had observed. The king looks into the mountain & discovers the great treasure, which he donates to the church. In many variants, someone else buys the dream & then finds the treasure.
1827
1645BDream of Marking the TreasureAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA man dreams that he finds a treasure (is told where a treasure is buried). It is too heavy for him to carry so he marks the place with his own excrement. In the morning he finds that only the end of this dream was true: he has defecated in his bed. In later European variants, a man (farmer, gambler, rich man, poor man, miser, clergyman, fool, married couple) lights a candle to the devil (saint). That night he dreams that the devil took him to a place where a treasure was buried. The devil tells him to mark the place with his excrement. Again, only the end of the dream is true.
1828
1646-The Lucky BlowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man pulls the crown (turban) off the king’s head & throws it on the ground. A snake comes out of it & the king believes that the man saved his life. (2) A man is angry at the king. He drags him out of the palace & into the courtyard (to beat him). The floor of the throne room gives way & the king thinks the man has saved his life
1829
1650-The Three Lucky BrothersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA poor man dies, leaving his three sons only a rooster, a cat & something else (musical instrument, scythe, rake, flail, winnowing shovel, hammer, millstone, ax, etc.). This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Each son takes his inheritance to a foreign country where it is unknown & sells it there for a fortune. A king buys the rooster because he thinks that it makes the sun rise. Fools who had used awls to harvest their grain pay generously for the scythe. The cat is sold at a high price in a country plagued by rats where cats were unknown. Or, the inhabitants flee because they are afraid that the cat will devour everything, not just the rats. (2) The brothers turn their inheritance into riches by some other means. For example, the millstone falls down onto robbers who are counting their treasure; the robbers flee leaving the money behind Or, one brother who has inherited a rope uses it by the shore to make sandals. The devil comes out of the water & asks what he is doing, & he replies that he is making a trap for the devil (to tie the lake together). The devil offers him gold in exchange for the rope. Or, one of the brother inherits a musical instrument (fiddle) that makes wolves dance. He is given money when he threatens to let the enchanted wolves go free (to call them back).
1830
1651-Whittington's CatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA youth (man, merchant, poor woman) buys a cat & gives it to a merchant (gentleman) to take away on his ship (caravan) & sell (the owner himself takes it on a journey). The cat is taken to a country (island, Africa, India) where there are no cats. This country is so overrun with mice (rats, snakes) that the inhabitants cannot sleep for fear of being bitten; or, while eating, they have to defend themselves from the animals’ attacks with cudgels & hammers. The man demonstrates the cat’s ability to hunt & sells it for a high price. (The cat returns to him twice, so he is able to sell it three times.) The merchant intends not to give the money to the cat’s owner, but a storm (miracle) convinces him to be honest. The young man who was the cat’s original owner marries the merchant’s daughter (a princess in the foreign land).
1831
1651AFortune in SaltAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA man (merchant, youth) finds a country in which salt is unknown. He sells a cargo of salt for a high price & becomes rich.
1832
1651A*The Accidental HeiressAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA woman inherits the entire wealth of a rich man because she was the only person who signed his condolence book when he died – & she did so only by accident.
1833
1652-The Wolves in the StableAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA young man plays a musical instrument whose music makes wolves dance. He charms some wolves thus & then locks them up. The man who was supposed to guard the wolves & had let them out gives the young man a large sum of money to return the animals to the stable, because they belong to the ruler.
1834
1653-The Robbers Under the TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsThis tale exists chiefly in five different forms: (1) Travelers (a single traveler) in need of a place to spend the night climb a tree. While they are hidden in the branches, robbers (rich people) settle under the tree to count their booty (to have a feast). The people in the tree overhear the activity below & let some thing (e.g. a door) fall (accidentally). It lands on the robbers, frightening them so that they flee & leave their valuables behind. The travelers keep the booty & thus become rich. (2) On leaving home, a husband tells his wife (wife tells her husband, mother tells her son) to mind (shut or lock) the door, but in-stead she takes it with her. At night they climb a tree. The door falls, frightening robbers who flee & leave their booty behind. (3) Two (more) brothers exclude their youngest brother from their thieving expeditions because they think he is a fool. In order to get his own wealth, he climbs a tree, taking a door (corpse, millstone) along with him. He lets it fall on robbers who have gathered under the tree. They run away, leaving their booty behind. (4) A person in a tree drops part of a dead animal (head, intestines, hide) on rich people (robbers) who are enjoying a feast under the tree. (5) Robbers overhear a foolish man (woman) talking to himself. The robbers misinterpret the words, think they have been discovered, & flee, leaving their booty behind.
1835
1654-The Robbers in the Death ChamberAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsTwo friends disagree about a bargain (found money): one thinks he has been cheated & wants to get even, or they try to cheat each other. When the creditor demands payment (that the contract be fulfilled), the debtor pretends to be dead. He is taken to the church where the creditor holds a vigil. During the night, robbers come by to divide their booty. The seemingly-dead man sits up suddenly & cries out, “Get up, all you dead people!” The creditor replies, “Here we are!” The robbers, thinking the dead are coming out after them, flee. The creditor & the debtor share their wealth.
1836
1655-The Profitable ExchangeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA poor man finds a bean (pea, grain of millet) which is eaten by a rooster. The old woman who owns the rooster gives it to the man. When the rooster is eaten by a pig, he is given the pig. A steer (cow) kills the pig, & he takes the steer as com pensation. Similarly, the man is given a horse as compensation for the steer. Eventually he demands a woman (princess) as compensation & puts her into a sack. His luck turns: strangers set her free & replace her with a big dog who jumps out & attacks the man.
1837
1656-How the Jews Were Lured Out of HeavenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) In heaven, St. Peter announces that a favorite food (drink) is available elsewhere. All the members of some group (municipal council, scissors-grinders, cowherds, robbers, etc.) run out of heaven after it. In some variants, Jews are evacuated from heaven with the cry, “Clothes are being auctioned off in hell!” (2) A group of soldiers have entered heaven illegally. St. Peter lures them out with a simulated roll call. Or, coastal inhabitants (noisy violinists) are expelled from heaven.
1838
1659-Late SatisfactionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA man applies for a job as a hotel porter (sexton, ticket-seller for a movie theater), but he is not hired because he cannot read or write. He emigrates and, through a series of lucky circumstances, becomes wealthy. When he goes back home to visit, he stays at a hotel where he is asked to fill out a form, & it becomes obvious that he is illiterate. The porter remarks, “Whatever could you have done if you had been able to read?” The man answers, “I would have been a porter in this hotel”.
1839
1660-The Poor Man in CourtAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA poor man who has been called before a judge brings a stone in his pocket which he intends to throw at the judge if the case is decided against him. The judge thinks the man has a bribe in his pocket. He decides the case in the poor man’s favor.
1840
1661-The Triple TaxAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA poet (farmer) receives the right to demand a tax from the first afflicted person (hunchback, leper, one-eyed man, etc.) he meets & from everyone with a certain name & also from every-one from a certain city. When he meets the first hunchbacked person & explains the situation, it happens that the man is also of that name & from that city (suffers also from the other handicaps). The poet demands more money from him as he reveals each of these circumstances, but the hunchbacked man refuses to pay.
1841
1663-DIviding Five Eggs Equally between Two Men & One WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA king sets a task: five eggs must be divided among one woman & two men in such a way that each has three eggs. A clever woman solves the problem: each man gets one, because he already has two [testicles], & she herself takes the remaining three. In some variants, a father gives three eggs to his three daughters. Whichever of them best multiplies her eggs will be the first to marry. The oldest gives one to her father, saying, “You already have two, so that makes three”. She gives one to her mother, saying, “In the night, when father gives you his two eggs, you will also have three. I will keep one for myself, & when I am married I will have three eggs”. Neither of her sisters is able to give so clever an answer, so she is the first to marry.
1842
1670*How a Naked Soldier Became a GeneralAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA soldier takes off his clothes to have a bath. Unexpectedly, the king comes by, & the soldier hurries naked back to his post. The king takes him home still naked & asks the women there which of them would like to marry this soldier. The daughter of a general volunteers, & the soldier is made a general.
1843
1674*Anticipatory WhippingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1640-1674 Man & Lucky AccidentsA teacher whips his students before they do anything wrong, so that they will learn not do anything wrong.
1844
1675-The Ox/ Donkey As MayorAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManTricksters (students, a butcher) fool a farmer into thinking that his ox (calf, donkey) is so clever that it should be sent to school. The farmer gives them money for its tuition, & they take it away & sell (slaughter) it. Later when the farmer wants to visit his ox, they tell him that it has graduated & is now the mayor (a judge, lawyer) of another city. The farmer is offended by the animal’s ingratitude & goes to find it. He demands to see the mayor (who is named Ox or has the same name as the ox). The mayor summons help to throw the angry farmer out. Or, the farmer beats the mayor until he pays back the tuition money.
1845
1676-Pretended GhostAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (girl) spends the night (keeps watch) in a graveyard (haunted place). A trickster (several men) decides to frighten him by pretending to be a ghost (dead man). The watcher beats (injures) the false ghost (drives him away). In some variants, the victim does not defend himself. An unknown creature (the devil, in African American variants, e.g. a monkey in disguise) frightens (injures, drives away) the false ghost.
1846
1676*The Foolish Farmer Studies MedicineAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA stupid farmboy (Gypsy boy) wants to study medicine with a doctor. The doctor brings him when he visits a patient & has him taste the contents of the chamber pot.
1847
1676BFrightened to DeathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (soldier, maid) who claims to fear nothing makes a bet that he is brave enough to go to a graveyard at night. As proof of his visit, he is going to stick a knife (fork, spindle) in one of the graves. The man does this, but when he sticks the knife into the grave, it catches his clothing. When he tries to leave, he feels that he is caught & thinks the dead person (the devil) is pulling him back. He dies of fright. The next morning, he is discovered lying on the grave.
1848
1676CVoices from the GraveyardAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA trickster speaks (in a disguised voice) to men (soldiers, other people) carrying a coffin in a graveyard. They think it is a ghost (dead person) & flee in panic.
1849
1676D"That's My Head!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManSeveral young men (at an inn) dare each other to steal a skull from a graveyard. One of them who is not frightened (the innkeeper’s daughter) goes to the graveyard to steal the skull, & the others go & hide among the graves. When the fearless man finds a skull, a voice calls, “Leave it alone, that is my head!” He throws the skull back & finds another one. Again the voice calls, “Leave it alone, that is my head!” The fearless man replies, “No one has two heads”, & takes it away with him. In some variants, the situation is repeated several times, for the head (bones) of the grandfather, father, uncle (other relatives).
1850
1676H*The Devil's SisterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (farmer, merchant) goes each night to the inn to drink (worries a lot). His wife (a sailor) wants to discourage this (frighten him). She disguises herself (in a white sheet) & meets him on his way home. The man asks, “Who are you?” She says, “I am the devil”. He replies, “Oh then, I am married to your sister (niece)”.
1851
1678-The Boy Who Had Never Seen a WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManAfter his mother dies, a boy is brought up in seclusion & never sees a woman. When he is fourteen (eighteen) years old, his father takes him to the nearest town. There he sees girls for the first time, & he asks what sort of creatures (animals) they are. His father says they are little devils (geese). The boy asks his father to buy some to take home. Or, some-one asks what he liked best & he replies, “The devils”.
1852
1678**First Time in ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA foolish boy goes to church for the first time in his life. He tells his mother what he saw: There was a man who screamed the entire time, someone walked around with a nightcap full of money, a strange contraption roared (the organ was played), etc.
1853
1679*Conscript Cannot Tell Left from RightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA recruit cannot tell right from left. To help him get through their drills, his supervisor ties straw to one of his arms & hay to the other (names his feet “bread” & “meat”) & uses these words when he gives orders.
1854
1680-The Man Seeking a MidwifeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (fool) needs to get a midwife for a pregnant woman. Through a series of unfortunate events, he kills a dog & drowns the midwife. He helps the mother give birth & then kills the baby when he bathes it in boiling water.
1855
1681-The Boy's DisastersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. A stupid man (boy) accidentally kills his horse (dog). He throws his axe into a river (lake) because he wants to kill a pike (duck). When he goes into the water naked to retrieve his ax, his clothes are stolen. He falls into vats of tar & feathers & returns home covered in feathers. His dog does not recognize him & bites him. Inside his house, he kicks the baby to death. He bumps a knife which falls from the cupboard & cuts off his penis. After this, his wife sends him away. Some versions add other accidents: the man hides naked in the cellar, becomes drunk & lets the wine run out of the cask, uses the flour to dry the floor, & stops the cask with the head of a hen. He tries to hatch her eggs but instead he breaks them & becomes covered in egg & bran (honey or tar & feathers). He is mistaken for the devil.
1856
1681APreparations for the WeddingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA stupid young man (bridegroom) buys pots at the market. When his shadow frightens him, he throws the pots at it. When he gathers wood in the forest, he thinks the bare trees must be cold & covers them with his clothes. Frighten ed by a dead dog, the boy gives it his food so it will not bite him. He smears butter on the path to ease the horse’s burden & throws salt in the river to make it taste better. When horse-flies bother his horse, the boy hits them, killing the horse. He kills a cow & “sells” its meat to dogs (frogs). Although he has nothing for dinner, he invites guests whom he astonishes with his bad manners. In some variants, the accidents happen to a foolish married couple who are going to visit their married daughter.
1857
1681A*Take Care of the StopperAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man tells a stupid boy to take care of the stopper, meaning that he should put it back in the barrel. The boy takes the order literally & puts the stopper in his pocket. The con-tents of the cask (tar, wine) run out.
1858
1681BFool as Custodian of Home & AnimalsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. When a foolish man must keep house & take care of the animals, he causes a series of accidents: He scalds his mother (grandmother) by bathing her in boiling water. He smothers her when he tries to feed her & kills the baby (by feeding it hot porridge). He kills an animal which is eaten by crows, & then demands that they pay for it. He tries to hatch eggs, & kills an old woman who scolds him for his mistakes, etc.
1859
1682-The Horse Learns Not to EatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManPossibly on the advise of someone else, a stupid (miserly) scholar (farmer) wants to teach his horse to live without food. He gives it less & less (nothing) to eat. When the horse dies after some days, the owner regrets that this happened just before it had learned how not to eat at all.
1860
1682**The Communal MuleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManThree brothers share the use of a mule. None of them gives it anything to eat because each thinks the others must be feeding it. The mule dies. In oriental tradition, two men share the use of a slave. When one beats the slave, the other complains about it. The first one explains that he was only beating his half part. Or, The first one promises that in the future he will beat only his half.
1861
1683*Counting BirdsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA stupid farmer counts birds. A soldier extorts a fine from him based on how many he has counted. The farmer thinks he has tricked the soldier by telling him that he had counted fewer birds than he actually had.
1862
1685-The Foolish BridegroomAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. A young bachelor (bridegroom, often a trickster) proves his stupidity through a series of absurd mistakes (follows his master’s advice literally in order to injure him). The following episodes are the most common: (1) Left alone at home, the fool is instructed to put a certain ingredient (e.g. parsley) in the food he is cooking. He puts the dog (cat) that is named Parsley into the soup. (2) The fool is told to clean a certain area. He takes this order lit-erally & throws out everything that is in it. (3) When he goes courting, he is advised to cast eyes at the girl. He puts out the eyes of animals (often sheep) & throws them at her. In some cases, the metaphoric meaning of the gesture is understood; in others, the young woman rejects the foolish suitor. In some versions, the protagonist is a stupid son-in-law.
1863
1685A*Fool Sets Up a Trap Beside His Own HouseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA fool sets a trap beside his house. His own mother falls into it (and is killed).
1864
1686-The Wedding NightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type.A stupid bridegroom does not know what to do on his wedding night. His mother (parents, bride) gives him advice, but he misunderstands it & injures himself, or causes some other accident. In some variants, he finds a man in the bed & thinks his bride has turned into a man. On the wedding night, the bride wants to leave her husband because of his foolishness. She says she has to go out. He does not trust her, so he ties her to a rope. She goes out, frees herself, & ties the rope to a goat. In the dark, the bridegroom at first does not notice the substitution. When he feels the animal’s body (beard, testicles, horns), he asks his mother about them. She does not know about the substitution & explains that these are normal parts of the bride’s body.
1865
1686*The Price of WoodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManIn return for a load of wood that he gives to a woman, a foolish young man demands that she sleep with him. She serves him coffee & he believes that she has fulfilled her part of the bargain.
1866
1686ALike DogsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA newly-married man is ignorant about sex & makes no attempt to consummate his marriage. After some time his young wife complains to her mother-in-law. The mother-in-law tells her son that he should do what dogs do. The next morning, the wife wants to divorce her husband. The mother-in-law asks the wife what happened. The wife replies that her husband sniffed her bottom & urinated on the bedpost. In another version, the young man asks the clergyman for advice. The clergyman closes the curtains & lights candles before he shows him what to do. The man understands, but later he complains that it uses up too many candles.
1867
1686A*The Pike's MouthAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid Man(Vagina Dentata) A girl (young woman, boy) who is tired of her eager suitor (soldier, clergyman, servant, workman) catches his penis in a pike’s mouth. Her mother (the farmer) had told her to hide the fish’s mouth in her vagina (pants), or to put it in a gap in a hedge (fence, tent) where the man went to urinate. (The Duke of Alva laughed for the first & last time in his life when he witnessed this event.)
1868
1687-The Forgotten WordAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA foolish boy is supposed to fetch something from a merchant (fools want to settle something). So that he will not forget the purpose of his errand, he repeats the word over & over. On the way, he trips & falls down & forgets the word. He looks in the ground to find the forgotten word (fools think the earth swallowed it, & try to dig it out). A passerby asks him what he is doing & coincidentally speaks the word. The boy is delighted that the word has been found again.
1869
1688-The Servant to Improve on the Master's StatementsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA wealthy suitor wants to impress a young woman whom he is wooing. He engages a friend (servant) not only to attest to his wealth but to double the worth of all things he names. When the suitor admits that he has a weakness (weak eye, cough), the friend exaggerates & says that he cannot see at all, or that he coughs even more at night. This upsets the bride & she calls off the marriage.
1870
1688A*Jealous SuitorsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManTwo men are wooing the same woman. Each schemes to outdo the other & have her to himself. For example, one skins the legs of four of his oppo nent’s horses & rolls the skin up to the knees. The other gets revenge by cutting off the upper lips of four of his opponent’s horses, saying that they are laughing at the horses wearing stockings. In another version, a poor suitor triumphs over his rich rival through various machinations & wins the woman for his wife.
1871
1689-"Thank God They Weren't Peaches"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA poor man (fool) plans to bring peaches (beets) to the king (another high-placed person) as a present. His wife persuades him to bring figs (plums, onions) instead. (Because they are not ripe,) the king throws them at the man’s head. He is glad (thanks God) that they were not peaches.
1872
1689*Fool Appointed to Fictitious Office Boasts of ItAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA fool whose master (ruler) has appointed him jokingly to a fictitious office brags about his position. The villagers laugh at him.
1873
1689ATwo Presents for the KingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (farmer, gardener) produces a huge turnip & takes it to the king as a present. The king rewards him well. His neighbor (gentleman, noble, rich man) learns about this & decides to give the king a much better present (his daughter in marriage), in the hope of an even better reward. The king gives him the giant turnip as his reward. Some variants, including the literary text, continue as follows: The duped rich man wants to revenge himself & lures the farmer into the forest to kill him. He & his men put the farmer into a sack & tie it up in a tree, but when a traveling scholar comes by, they run away. The farmer calls to the scholar, pretendings that he can see the whole world from inside the sack. The scholar takes his place & the farmer rides away on the scholar’s horse. In some variants, the farmer sends someone back to rescue the scholar.
1874
1689BThe Unedible MeatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA fool (woman) comes home with (is cooking) some meat which is stolen by an animal (hawk, dog, cat). He is glad that the animal does not have the seasonings (recipe) to cook the meat properly.
1875
1691-The Hungry ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA clergyman & a sexton (married couple, two brothers) are invited to dinner. The clergyman (husband, stupid brother) is told by his com-panion not to eat as much as usual; the sexton (wife, clever brother) will nudge his foot to remind him. When the clergyman has eaten just a few bits, a dog (cat) under the table bumps him. He thinks it is the sexton warning him, & he stops eating.
1876
1691AHungry Suitor Brings Food from HomeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA matchmaker warns a bride groom not to eat too much when he goes to visit his potential parents-in-law. The bridegroom restrains himself during the meal, & afterwards goes outside to eat food which his mother has pre-pared for him. There is a severe snow storm. His potential mother-in-law makes a remark about the weather, but the bridegroom misunderstands & thinks she is referring to his appetite (pun). He re plies that he is not eating her food.
1877
1691BBad Table MannersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA bridegroom visits his potential in-laws for a meal & afterwards tells his mother what he did (e.g. he was served only eggs, which he ate one after another with his hands). His mother rebukes him for his bad table manners & tells him what he should have done (use a knife & fork). The next time he goes out wooing, he does what she advised, but the situation is different (he tries to eat peas or nuts with a knife & fork). The story continues in this manner & he never manages to get married.
1878
1691B*Too Much TruthAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA young workman (traveler, Eulenspiegel) needs a place to stay for the night. He complains to a woman who keeps an inn (clergyman, farmer) that anyone who tells the truth will not be given lodging. She invites him to stay for the night. He remarks that her husband, she herself, & the cat have only three eyes among them. He is driven away for his unwelcome honesty.
1879
1691C*Permission MisunderstoodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA farmer & his wife give supper (pan-cakes, peas, pudding) to a tramp who has asked to stay with them for the night. Some food is left over. When they go to bed, the tramp sleeps between them. In the middle of the night, the farmer has to go outside. The tramp asks the wife, “May I?” She answers yes (“Now is your chance”). The tramp gets up, goes to the kitchen, & eats the rest of the pancakes.
1880
1691D*Sleep with BabyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (Scot) who is staying overnight is asked by his host if he wants to sleep with Baby. He says he would rather not. The next day, he learns that Baby is the name of the maid (an attractive young woman). She asks him his name, & he tells her it is Jackass (Stupid).
1881
1692-The Stupid ThiefAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA fool joins a band of robbers. They send him into a house to steal while the rest of them wait outside. He bungles the job in one of several ways: He takes the robbers’ instructions literally. They tell him to bring some thing substantial (i.e. valuable), & he brings something heavy (e.g. a mortar). They tell him to bring something shiny (i.e. gold), & he brings a mirror. The fool awakens the household. He wants to take more than he can carry, so he wakes the owner & asks him for help. The fool finds a musical instrument & plays it loudly. He decides to cook something to eat. Hearing the owner sigh in his sleep, the fool thinks he must be hungry, so he puts hot food in his mouth (hand).
1882
1693-The Literal FoolAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid Man(The Burning of Lanka) Misc. type. A fool takes the instructions of a salesman (clergyman, doctor, his wife, etc.) literally & thus causes (suffers) damage or injury.
1883
1694-The Company to Sing like the LeaderAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManTwo (drunken) men (married couple, a group of people) on their way home from a market day (wedding) try to sing together. The leader’s foot becomes caught in a wheel. He (she) cries for help, but no one understands; the cry is taken to be part of the song & is thus repeated by the group. Often the leader’s foot is broken before the wagon is stop ped. In a Berber variant, a teacher from the city is supposed to teach prayers from the Koran to men in the mountains. They stand out side & repeat the words of the prayers after him. The teacher bows to the ground & touches a board, which he is using to protect himself from the mud, with his forehead. His nose becomes wedged in the board. The teacher calls for help, but the companions take this for part of the prayer & repeat the words zealously. The teacher tears his nose away, leaving the tip behind. He tells the companions they must first learn Arabic, & departs.
1884
1694AA Foolish WelcomeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManVillagers (serfs) intend to wel-come (congratulate, honor) a visiting nobleman. The mayor leads the delegation, & the others are supposed to copy everything he does. (They each present a dish of food to the nobleman.) The leader stumbles & falls (spills the food on the table or on the floor), & the others do likewise. In his anger over the accident, the mayor curses, e.g. , “Go to the devil!” The others add, as they had rehearsed, “With your wife & children”, “and your aunts & uncles”, “and the noble lady, & the whole company!” In German & Austrian variants, the inhabitants cannot decide what to wear. When the visiting dignitary arrives, they hurry, still naked, to greet him. When the mayor is bitten on his backside by a horse-fly, he uses his hand to shoo it away, & all the others copy this gesture. In other variants, the reception goes wrong for other reasons.
1885
1695-Shoes for AnimalsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (fool, Eulenspiegel) who works for a shoemaker is supposed to cut some leather for shoes. He asks his master, “How (big) should I make them?” & is told, “Big & small, just as the herdsman drives them through the gate”. The man makes shoes for pigs (sheep). When the master sees this, he throws the man out. Or, they take the shoes to market & tell customers that the winter will be so cold, even the animals will need shoes. The customers pay well for the shoes.
1886
1696-"What Should I Have Said?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. A mother tells her stupid son (man tells his wife) what he should have said (done) in a particular situation. The son follows the advice at the next opportunity, where it turns out to be inappropriate. He is punished (is told again what he should have done or said, & he follows that advice in the wrong circum-stances, etc.) For example, the fool congratulates mourners & offers sympathy to a bridal couple.
1887
1697-"We Three; For Money"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManThree Valaisans (men of another nationality) who are going to England (another foreign country) learn in advance some important English phrases. The first one learns to state who they are: “We three Valaisans”. The second one learns how to convince a prospective landlord to give them food & lodging: “For the money”. The third one learns to agree to a stipulated price: “That’s right”. On their journey they are accused falsely of having committed a murder. The judge asks who committed the crime, & the first man answers, “We three Valaisans”. The judge asks why they did it, & the second man says, “For the money”. The judge condemns them to be hanged, & the third man responds, “That’s right”. The three men are hanged (or, the real culprit is found & the three men are freed).
1888
1698-Deaf Persons & Their Foolish AnswersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. Two (or more) people cannot understand each other because of their impaired hearing. Misunderstandings ensue.
1889
1698ASearch for the Lost AnimalAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManOne deaf person has lost sheep (other animals) and, while he is looking for them, meets another deaf person. Neither recognizes the other’s disability. A asks if B has seen his sheep. B misunderstands but gestures in a certain direction as he re plies about something else. A goes in that direction & finds his sheep. He thanks B & offers him one of his animals which is de form ed (lame, etc.) as a reward for his help. B thinks A is blaming him for the animal’s deformity. They fight. They take their argument to a judge, who, unknown to either of them, is also deaf. His judgment is absurd.
1890
1698A*Burning Off the DirtAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA master (priest) who has accidentally dirtied his finger with excrement demands that his servant cut it off (burn the dirt off). He sticks the finger through a hole & the servant strikes it with a burning piece of wood. The master is in so much pain that he pulls his finger out & puts it into his mouth to soothe it.
1891
1698BTravelers Ask the WayAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA traveler asks for directions, but a deaf man misunderstands & thinks that he is offering to buy his ox for a certain price. The traveler repeats his question & the deaf man refuses to sell his animal. His deaf mother brings his dinner. When he tells her about the traveler’s offer, she thinks he is telling her that the food is too salty. The daughter-in-law misunderstands what her mother-in-law says about the salty food, etc. The whole family is deaf & they all misunderstand each other.
1892
1698B*Refusal to EatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManThe servant thinks that he will punish his master by refusing to eat.
1893
1698CTwo Persons Believe Each Other DeafAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA trickster tells each of two people (often women) before they meet that the other is deaf & must be shouted at. They do this, & each thinks that the other is insane. After a while, the trickster reveals his trick.
1894
1698DThe Wedding InvitationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA landlord meets a deaf farmer & asks him how much he wants for the livestock he has with him. The farmer thinks he is being asked about his daughter’s wedding, & tells about this. The landlord asks if he may come, & the farmer replies with the price of the livestock. The landlord says that the farmer is crazy, but the farmer thinks he is wishing him well, & returns the good wish.
1895
1698GMisunderstood Words Lead to Comic ResultsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. A deaf person misunderstands similar-sounding words, which leads to unexpected (comic) results or dialog. In some cases, someone feigns deafness in order to avoid an obligation or some other unpleasant situation In others, a hearing person wants to make fun of a deaf person but is embarrassed by his answers.
1896
1698HThe Deaf Man in the TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA traveler asks the way of a man who is up in a tree, who happens to be deaf. The man in the tree keeps telling him about the bird he has caught (apples he has picked).
1897
1698IVisiting the SickAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA deaf (hearing-impaired) man goes to visit a sick friend. He wants to hide his impediment so he plans a conversation with questions & answers. The resulting dialog is absurd: “How are you?” – “I am dead.”– “Thank God! What have you eaten?” – “Poison, I think.” – “I hope it agrees with you.”
1898
1698JThe Misunderstood GreetingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA traveler (nobleman) greets (questions, insults) a deaf workman (farmer, fisherman), but the workman answers as if the traveler had meant to comment on his work. Often the workman had imagined what a potential interlocutor would say to him & had rehearsed his answers. Or, he pretends to be deaf because he is afraid that the traveler will ask him to do some thing he does not want to do (e.g. lend him something).
1899
1698KBuyer & the Deaf SellerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA deaf seller cannot understand what his customer asks him & gives inappropriate answers. The customer does not know about the man’s impairment & thinks he is insane. Often the seller has imagined what a potential customer would ask & has rehearsed his answers (has been given instructions about what to say).
1900
1698MThe Deaf BishopAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA minister (priest) is called before the bishop because he has been accused of drinking too much. The bishop is old & deaf. The minister confesses his sins publicly in the church: “In the morning I have a drink” (spoken loudly), “and after that five or six little drinks” (spoken softly). “At noon I have another drink” (loudly), “and then five or six small ones” (softly). The bishop, who hears only the loud words, tells the congregation that the minister has the right to have a drink with his meals, & finds him innocent of the charges.
1901
1698NPretended DeafnessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man (farmer, farmhand, old man, woman) is asked to do something or is told something that he does not want to hear. He pretends to be deaf. But when something is said that he wants to hear, he can hear that.
1902
1699-Misunderstanding Because of Ignorance of a Foreign LanguageAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. Two people who speak different languages cannot understand each other. One of them pronounces the words so that they seem to have a different meaning, or the words sound like different words in the other person’s language. Often an absurd conversation leads to unexpected events. In some variants the misunderstanding happens because one person does not understand a foreign word (technical term). Or an ambiguous message (statement) leads to the discovery of a criminal (planned crime).
1903
1699BThe Changed OrderAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManNew recruits learn answers to questions in a foreign language. When the order of the questions is changed, confusion ensues.
1904
1700-"I Cannot Understand You"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA traveler (apprentice) comes to a city in a foreign country (usually Amsterdam, but also Paris, Hamburg, Vienna, Moscow, etc.) where he sees a beau-tiful building (villa, palace, factory). Curious, he asks a passerby, “Whom does it belong to?” The passerby replies, “I can not understand you”, which the traveler misunderstands & takes to be the name of the owner. Similarly, he asks other people in turn the name of the husband of a beautiful woman, of the winner of the lottery, or the owner of a ship. He is amazed at the wealth of Mr. “I Cannot Understand You”. He becomes reconciled to his own modest circumstances when, as he follows a funeral procession, he learns that Mr. “I Cannot Understand You” has died.
1905
1701-Echo AnswersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA woman (man) asks an echo a question. The echo repeats the last phrase, which gives the (often unwelcome) answer.
1906
1702-Anecdotes about StutterersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type. Besides various single variants, two main versions of this story can be distinguished: (1) A stutterer (barber) is addressed by a stranger (student) who also stutters. He thinks the stranger is making fun of him, & a fight ensues. (2) A bride & groom will not talk to each other, because neither of them wants the other to know about his (her) stuttering.
1907
1702A*A Laconic ConversationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManTwo taciturn farmers understand each other through half words.
1908
1703-Anecdotes about Near-Sighted MenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type with diverse variants.
1909
1704-Anecdotes about Absurdly Stingy PersonsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type with diverse variants.
1910
1704*Saber & ForkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA soldier who is quartered with a farmer demands food & lays his saber on the table to emphasize his order. The farmer brings a pitchfork & lays it beside the saber. The soldier asks what this is for, & the farmer explains that such a great knife warrants an equally great fork.
1911
1705-Talking Horse & DogAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man becomes alarmed by animals who speak. For example, he meets a dog who greets him, or he curses his ox & it replies to him. In North American variants, the man wants his horse to jump over a hole. The horse says, “I will not”. The man turns to his dog & says, “Isn’t that strange, a horse talking!” The dog says, “Yes, it is”. Often the man runs away, meeting other animals which answer him. In some variants, objects as well as animals speak.
1912
1706-Anecdotes about DrunkardsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMisc. type with diverse variants.
1913
1706AThe Steadfast DrinkerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA hard-drinking man wagers a drink (piece of bread) with himself (someone else, his horse) that he will be able to pass by an inn without going in. He succeeds (because he throws away his purse by the door of the inn). He (picks up his purse) & goes back to the inn to reward himself for his will power with the promised drink.
1914
1706BThe Obedient DrinkerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManThree (five) tipplers make a bet (with the inn-keeper) for a certain amount of alcohol that they will do whatever their wives ask of them. The first stumbles over a washtub (chair). His wife says, “Good, just fall into the tub (smash up the chair)!” He obeys. The second drops a pan (wakes the baby). “Throw everything around (wake all the children up)!” He obeys. The third stumbles. His wife says, “Go ahead, break your leg!” He does not obey & loses the bet. (He spills some sauce & she says, “Smear it all over the table!” He obeys.) The wife of the fourth man tells him to sleep all day in an empty cask, & he obeys. The wife of the fifth tells him to drink all the water in the pipes. He cannot, & loses the bet.
1915
1706CThe Jacket with 36 ButtonsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA drunken farmer comes home & cannot find his bed. He falls asleep in the pig sty, where he feels the sow’s belly & thinks it is his wife’s. He asks, “Are you wearing the jacket with 36 buttons?”
1916
1706DHow the Drunken Man was CuredAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA wife cures her husband of his alcoholism by a ruse. When the husband is drunk, she organizes a funeral procession, lays him in a coffin & puts a shroud (fool’s costume) on him. When the drunk husband awakes he thinks he is dead. Later, believing that he has been revived by his wife, the man swears he will never drink any more. Or, a drunken man lies under the bed & thinks he is lying in his shroud. This cures him of his alcoholism. In some versions the drinker is uncurable. When his wife, dis-guised as a ghost, brings him food, he tells her, “If you had known me better you would have brought me drink”. The wife capitulates.
1917
1706EDrunk Man in the MineAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManMiners (nobleman) take a drunken man (drunkard, tax collector, miser, broom maker) into the mine (into the castle of a nobleman). When he awakes he thinks he is in hell. The miners pretend to be devils. Only when he promises to reform do they allow him to go home.
1918
1708*The SharpshooterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA nobleman shoots the pipe out of the mouth of a commoner (Jester).
1919
1710-Boots Sent by TelegraphAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA young man (student) asks his father to send him a new pair of boots. The father tries to send them by telegraph, & throws them over a telegraph wire. A vagrant takes the boots & leaves his old ones in their place. The father thinks that his son had received the new ones & returned his old pair. In some variants, a fool (foolish woman) wants to send a package & a letter by telegraph. He hangs the package on the wire & reads the letter out loud.
1920
1711*The Brave ShoemakerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA shoemaker (apprentice) is afraid of nothing. His friends want to test this & ask him to keep watch over a dead man. One of them pretends to be dead & lies (instead of a real corpse) in a cof-fin. During his watch, the shoemaker repairs some shoes. Suddenly the “dead” man begins to move (breathe). The shoemaker orders him to lie still. When the “dead” man moves again, the shoemaker says, “Whatever is dead must stay dead”. He hits the impostor on the head with his hammer & kills him.
1921
1717*The Fancy AilmentAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA fine lady explains her ailment to her doctor in com plicated, poetic paraphrase. The doctor does not understand her. The lady’s servant explains briefly in vulgar language.
1922
1718*God Can't Take a JokeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1675-1724 The Stupid ManA man in danger of death prays to God for help (makes a vow that if he is rescued, he will do something for God). He escapes the danger but denies that God helped him (does not fulfill his promise). When he again finds himself in a dangerous position, he asks God, “Can’t you take a joke?”
1923
1725-The Lover DiscoveredAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA farmer & his servant are plowing. The servant goes home to overhear the farmwife & her lover (often a clergyman). The lover hides. The servant pretends that he is supposed to do some job that threatens the lover’s hiding place: light the oven, clean the chimney, clean the wool. He is about to throw a chest in which the lover is hiding into water or to throw it down the stairs (he lets the lover free in return for a ransom). The lover hides in the calf’s stall & the servant drives him out with a whip. The wife wants to bring food outdoors to her lover, whose where-abouts she thinks she can locate by following certain signs along the way. The servant manages to alter the signs (e.g. he puts cloth on a horse to change its color) so that the wife brings the food to him instead. The wife sends the servant to take food to her lover (to invite him to a meal). The servant drops the food on the way & tells the lover that the husband has discovered the adultery. On his way back, he tells the farmer that the lover has refused to come. Or, he says that the lover wants the farmer to help him repair his broken plow. When the lover sees the farmer collecting the food strewn along the way, he thinks he is coming with the tools or going to attack him, so he runs away. Meanwhile, the servant has told the wife that her husband knows about her adultery, so she runs away. He tells the farmer that she left because her village (house) burned down. Or that she had promised always to cook food just as good as she did today if her husband can catch up with her. The farmer immediately goes after her. In the end, the wife confesses & she (and her lover) are possibly punished.
1924
1730-The Entrapped SuitorsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedMisc. type. A pretty, faithful wife is courted by three men (usually clergyman). With her husband’s consent, she invites them to a private rendezvous. Before the first man’s wishes are gratified, the second arrives & the first must hide in an uncomfortable position. When all three of the lovers are caught thus, they are killed or punished in some other manner, or are ridiculed or made to pay a ransom.
1925
1731-The Youth & the Pretty ShoesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA young man goes to a clergyman’s house & seduces the servant girl, the daughter, & the wife. He promises to give them each a beautiful pair of shoes which he has stolen. Instead, he threatens to expose them to the clergyman & makes them pay him not to tell. In some variants, he also tricks the clergyman. He gives him medicine for his bald (mangy) head & orders him to say, “I know what I know, but I will not tell”. The clergyman does this & the women confess their sexual liasons to him.
1926
1734*Whose Cow Was Gored?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is Tricked(An eye for an eye.) A sexton hears the preacher give a sermon about the biblical phrase, “an eye for an eye”. When the preacher’s cow gores the sexton’s cow with its horns & kills it, the sexton wants the preacher to give him a new cow. The preacher refuses. It would have been different, though, if the sexton’s cow had killed the preacher’s.
1927
1735-"Who Gives his Own Goods Shall Receive It Back Tenfold"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA preacher gives a sermon saying that whoever gives alms will receive them back tenfold. A farmer brings him his only cow. In the evening, she goes back home to the farmer, & all the preacher’s cows follow her. The farmer wants to keep all the cows because God has sent them to him. The farmer & the preacher agree that the cows will belong to whichever of them says, “Good morning” to the other first. The farmer stays secretly in the preacher’s house & sees that the preacher spends the night with his female servant. In the morning, the farmer greets the preacher & lets him know that he is aware of his liason. The preacher lets the farmer keep the cows.
1928
1735AThe Wrong SongAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA clergyman is so miserly that he will not give the farmers any parts of the hogs he has slaughtered. The sexton (teacher, poor farmers) steals one of his hogs (cow, sheep, ham). The clergyman overhears the young son (daughter) of the sexton singing, “My father stole the clergyman’s hog”. The clergyman praises the child or the song & promises to give him money & clothes (shoes, a picture) if he will sing it on Sunday in church. The child tells his father (the father becomes suspicious), who teaches him another song. On Sunday, the clergyman announces from the pulpit, “What this child sings is true”. The child sings, “The clergyman has slept with my mother (all the women in the village)”. Or, “All the children with red hair belong to the clergy man”. The clergyman tries to deny this, but the farmers mock him & he has to leave the church (loses his position, dies from shame).
1929
