1735BThe Recovered CoinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA man puts a coin in the offering box & retrieves it by means of a thread. The clergyman says, “May God repay you!” The man answers, “He has done so already”.
1930
1736-The Stingy ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedThe servant (servants, Eulenspiegel) of a stingy clergyman sleeps instead of mowing the meadow. He puts a wasp nest (anthill, beetle) into a box (bag) & tells the clergyman that he has found a box full of gold in the meadow. The clergyman says it is his. The servant protests but finally agrees, threatening that the gold will turn into wasps & the grass in the meadow will grow back.
1931
1736ASword Turns to WoodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA king disguises himself & visits an inn. There he meets a soldier who has sold his saber to buy drinks. The king asks him how he will salute, & the soldier replies that he has bigger problems than that. He later substitutes a wooden sword for his saber. The next day, the king orders the soldier to behead his friend (another man). The soldier prays to God to turn his sword into a piece of wood so that he will not have to kill his friend (if the man is innocent). The king forgives him.
1932
1736BThe Firm BeliefAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedKing Friedrich II of Prussia asks a soldier what he believes. The soldier says he believes what the shoemaker believes. The king asks what that is, & the soldier explains that he owes the shoemaker for a pair of boots but the shoemaker believes he will not be paid for them. The soldier also believes this. The king gives him money to pay the shoemaker. Later the king asks the soldier if he ever payed for the boots. The soldier replies that he & the shoemaker would not alter their beliefs for such a small amount of money.
1933
1737-The Clergyman in the Sack to HeavenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA man (master thief) is ordered to capture the preacher & put him into a sack. He dresses as an angel (Gabriel, Michael, angel of death) or as a saint (Peter) & waits at night near the church (parsonage, cemetery, pulpit) to conduct the preacher to heaven alive. The credulous preacher willingly gets into the sack (chest, trunk), & the man takes him to the goose house (bell tower, chimney; hangs him by the gate). The next day, the preacher is discovered by his maidservant as she feeds the geese (bell-ringer as he rings the bells). She lets him out of the sack.
1934
1738-The Dream: All Clergymen in HellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedThree main versions of this story can be distinguished: (1) A priest refuses to go to the deathbed of one of his parishioners to perform the last rites, because the man has not come to church (for another reason). The sick man recovers & meets the priest. He tells him that he dreamed (that it really happened) that he died & went to the gate of heaven. St. Peter would not let him in because he had not received the last rites. The sick man had asked if he could not receive them postumously in heaven. Peter explained that there are no priests in heaven: they are all in hell. Also told of other professions (e.g. lawyers, commissioners of police), ethnic groups (e.g. Scots, Jews), & rich people (noblemen). (2) A fool comes down a hill. The clergyman asks him where he comes from. He answers, “From above”. The clergyman asks him what God is doing up there. The fool answers, “He is won-dering why there are so few clergymen in heaven”. (3) In order to enter heaven, a clergyman & a sexton are required to make a chalk mark for each of their sins on the stairs. The clergyman has to go back & get more chalk.
1935
1738B*The Clergyman's DreamAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedOn Sunday morning, a preacher warns his parishioners from the pulpit that their contributions are overdue. He says that he dreamed that he died & went to heaven. There, he was overcome by an urgent need, & asked St. Peter if he could go to the toilet. When he looked down the hole, he saw his village underneath him. He told St. Peter that he could not use that hole because he would soil his parishioners. In response, St. Peter asked him if this would not serve them right, since they did not pay their contributions.
1936
1738D*Alone in HeavenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA man (Catholic) comes to heaven & St. Peter conducts him to his proper place. When they pass a certain room (a high hedge), St. Peter tells him to be quiet because this is where the Reformed Protestants (Adventists, Methodists) are. “We let them believe that only members of their denomination are in heaven.”
1937
1739-The Clergyman & the CalfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA man (usually a clergyman) who has a stomach ache sends his servant (maid) to the doctor with a sample of his urine. On the way the bottle breaks, & the servant fills a new bottle with urine from a pregnant cow (mare). The doctor diagnoses that the man will give birth to a calf. The man be-lieves him (and goes away embarrassed). Some time later (in a stall, when he is drunk, after taking a laxative) he evacuates his bowels. He happens to see a calf there & believes it to be his child.
1938
1739A*A Miser Gives Birth to a ChildAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA miserly man who has been married many times will not give his wife anything that she can cook to make a meal. Then, to punish her for not cooking, he stops up her nose & ears & leaves her. Another young woman takes revenge: She marries the miser, secretly takes some of his money, & gives him so much food that it gives him a stomach ache. Then she tells him that he is pregnant. When he farts (during his sleep), she puts a newborn baby in his arms. He is so embarrassed that he leaves home.
1939
1740-Candles on the CrayfishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedAt night (Halloween) a man (rascal, thief, trickster, clergyman) sticks lights (candles) on the backs of living crayfish (crabs, beetles) & sets the animals loose in a room (the graveyard). Gullible people take them for spirits (devils, souls from Purgatory) & are frightened (run away, pay money for a mass, let themselves be put into a sack to be conveyed to “heaven”).
1940
1740BThieves as GhostsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedMisc. type. Thieves (tricksters) disguise themselves out of various intentions & in various ways as supernatural figures. Either they succeed in their tricks, or they are exposed.
1941
1741-The Priest's Guest & the Eaten ChickensAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA man (priest) directs his wife (cook, maidservant) to cook two chickens (geese, hares, fish) for a dinner to which he has invited a guest (the clergyman). The wife & her lover secretly eat (nibble at) the fowl. Before (during) the dinner, as her husband sharpens his carving knife, she tells the guest that her husband intends to cut his ears (testicles) off. The guest runs away. She tells her husband that the guest took the chickens with him. The husband chases after him, crying, “At least give me one of them!”. In some variants, the wife tells the guest that her husband in-tends to put the pestle up his backside (oven-fork in his mouth). The husband runs after him, crying, “Let me put it in just a little way!”
1942
1741*The Sausage TaxAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedAt Christmas, every farmer must bring the clergyman a sausage. One poor man’s horse dies, so he has a huge intestine to use for sau sage. He fills it with mashed potatoes, groats, & other (strange) fillings. The clergyman praises the man for his nice big sausage. Later, he announces in church that the sausage tax has been abolished.
1943
1743*The Promised GiftAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA woman (man) confesses her sins to the priest. The priest admits to her that he has committed similar sins himself. In return for her absolution, the woman promises to give the priest a turkey (fish). During the sermon, the priest reminds her to bring what she had promised. She answers that he had told her that he too had committed such sins.
1944
1744-In PurgatoryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A clergyman demands repeated payments from a dying man (the man’s relatives) who wants to buy his way out of Purgatory. The man asks if his place in heaven is guaranteed. The clergyman replies, “Nearly”. (He has his hand on the doorknob to heaven, the fire in purgatory is only as high as his knees.) The dying man (his relatives) says that he can take care of himself from here. (2) An old woman asks a clergyman whether her deceased husband is in heaven or in hell. He asks for a donation & she gives him some money. After a while the clergyman tells her that her husband is still burning in hell (up to his knee) & she should give more money to save him. The old woman refuses, saying that her husband always had cold feet. Or, an old woman asks the clergyman if it is warm enough in heaven, or if she would be better off in hell.
1945
1750-The Hen Learns to SpeakAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA mercenary lover makes the clergyman’s foolish wife (a neighbor woman who has discovered the liason) believe that a hen (chickens) can be taught to talk (sing). The woman gives him the hen (eggs to hatch) & feed for it. (The man eats the hen or eggs.) When the woman asks what the hen (chickens) has learned to say, the man answers, that it can say, “The clergyman’s wife has slept with the farmer”. She lets him keep the hen & feed (bribes him not to tell anyone).
1946
1750ASending a Dog to be EducatedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA clergyman (farmer) wants his dog to learn to speak. His servant offers to bring the dog to the school-master (to teach it himself). The clergyman gives the servant money for the dog’s education. After some time the clergyman sends the servant to get the dog back. The servant returns without the dog, saying that he drowned it (killed it in some other way) because it said that its master was sleeping with the maid. (The master agrees that the tattletale dog should be punished.)
1947
1750BTeaching the Donkey to SpeakAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1725-1774 Clergyman is TrickedA ruler (landlord) wants his donkey (camel, dog, calf) to learn to speak (read, pray), but cannot find any-one who will teach it. He offers a big salary to any teacher who can do this in ten (25, etc.) years’ time. If the teacher fails, he will be punished (killed). A poor man (Eulenspiegel) accepts the task, hoping that by the end of the time, either he, the donkey, or the master will be dead.
1948
1775-The Hungry ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonThis type combines one of two introductory episodes with a common main part. Introductory episodes: (1) (2) Master & servant (clergyman & sexton) go hunting (in the forest). The servant brings food but the master does not. When they become hungry, the servant eats his food privately & tells the master that he is eating hay (horse droppings). In the evening they are tired when they come to a farm. The servant warns his master not to accept an invitation to eat when it is first offered. He also tells the farmer not to invite the master more than once, or he will become angry. The master declines the first invitation, & it is not repeated. During the night, he goes out in search of food, & gives the servant the end of a rope to hold. The servant ties his end of the rope to the innkeeper’s bed, which motivates the next part of the tale. Main part: The hungry man eats his fill & wants to take some food to his companion. He winds up in the host’s bed & thinks the backside of the housewife is his companion’s face. When she farts, he thinks his companion is blowing on the food to cool it. Angry that the “man” will not eat, he slaps the porridge into his “face”. The woman wakes up & thinks she has soiled the bed. In some variants, the tale continues: The guest washes his messy hands in a jug & cannot get them out. Intending to break the jug on a stone, he breaks it instead on the bald head of the host or on the buttocks of the host’s wife, who has gotten up to clean herself.
1949
1776-The Sexton Falls into the Brewing VatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA sexton goes to steal some beer from a clergyman. He hides & observes the clergyman in intimate relations with the maid (his wife). The sexton falls from his hid ing place into the brewing vat. The couple think it is the devil, & flee. The sexton gets the beer.
1950
1777A*"I Can't Hear You."Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA sexton confesses to a priest, who wants him to admit that he stole from the priest’s wine cellar (communion wine, field) when the priest was away. The sexton pretends not to understand what the priest means. Intending to demonstrate, the priest exchanges places with the sexton (in the confessional, in the church). Acting as the priest, the sexton asks who visits (kisses, sleeps with) his wife when he is away. The priest pretends he cannot hear the question.
1951
1781-Sexton's Own Wife Brings Her OfferingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA clergyman & a sexton agree that the sexton may have all money given as offerings by the women who have slept with the clergyman. When a woman whom he has slept with comes with an offering, the clergyman says, “Take it”. This happens also when the sexton’s wife comes.
1952
1785-The Clergyman Put to Flight During His SermonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonMisc. Type. For one reason or another, a clergyman runs away in the middle of the service. For example, he sees a dog eating his dinner or a man stealing his hat; or, a man hiding behind a saint’s image curses him, etc.
1953
1785AThe Sausage in the PocketAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA preacher is given a sausage by one of his parishioners & goes directly to the church with it in the rear pocket of his coat. A dog smells the sausage & follows him. When the preacher is in the pulpit, the sexton brings him a book which he had forgotten. So as not to be observed, the sexton bends over & crawls up the steps to the pulpit & pulls on the preacher’s coat. The preacher thinks it is the dog & kicks him.
1954
1785BThe Needle in the PulpitAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA preacher has a habit of striking his hands on the pulpit (Bible, communion bread). Some boys (confirmation students, altar boys, students) want to play a trick on him. They stick needles into the edge of the pulpit (smear it with manure or butter). The preacher poses a rhetorical question, “Who created the world?” (“What is our earthly life?”), strikes the pulpit, & hits a nail (the manure). He answers his question, “Those damn boys!” (“Shit!”)
1955
1785CThe Sexton's Wasp NestAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonBoys (sexton) hide a wasp nest in the pulpit. During the sermon, the wasps sting the preacher. Finally he cannot stand it any more & leaves, saying, “I have the word of God in my mouth, but the devil is in my pants”.
1956
1786-The Clergyman Rides an Ox in the ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonOn Palm Sunday, a preacher wants to show his congregation exactly how Jesus came to Jerusalem, & rides into the church on an ox (horse). The sexton sticks the ox with a needle, & it runs wild.
1957
1790-The Clergyman & the Sexton Steal a CowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA clergyman & a sexton steal a cow (other animal), & are suspected of the theft. The sexton is ready to find a solution (says his conscience troubles him; he wants to admit publicly to the theft; makes the clergyman give him money not to tell anyone). In court (before an assembly), the sexton, to the clergyman’s horror, describes their theft & its aftermath in detail. At the end, he says, “Then I woke up” (fell out of bed from fright). The judge (audience) takes the story for a dream, & lets the thieves suspects go free.
1958
1791-The Sexton Carries the ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonTwo thieves (farmhands, apprentices) decide that one of them will steal cabbage (nuts) while the other steals a sheep (pig, horses). They plan to meet in the graveyard (tomb) at night to divide their booty. The man who took the cabbage arrives first & begins to divide: “One for me, one for you”. The sexton hears this & thinks it is a ghost (the devil, the Last Judgment). He brings the clergyman to come & hear this for himself. The clergyman is lame (suffers from rheumatism), so the sexton has to carry him on his back. The cabbage-thief thinks this must be his con federate with the sheep, & calls out, “Throw it here so we can slaugh ter it”. The sexton, terrified, drops his burden & runs away, but is overtaken by the clergyman who is so frightened that he forgot about his injury.
1959
1791*The Murderer's HouseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonTwo young men lose their way on an autumn evening & stay overnight in a secluded house. One of them hears the owner (sees him take a knife and) say, “No matter how young they are, they have to die”. (“It’s lucky that he is so fat.”) The young man thinks he & his friend are about to be murdered. It turns out that the owner was planning to kill two sheep (a rooster).
1960
1792-The Stingy Clergyman & the Slaughtered PigAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA clergyman (citizen, farmer), who has benefited from others’ communal slaughtering parties, does not want to give away any of his own pig. His sexton (neighbor) advises him to hang the animal’s carcass outdoors over night & to take it inside secretly early in the morning. He can tell the neighbors that it was stolen. The clergyman follows this advice, but, in the night, the sexton comes & steals the pig. In the morning, the clergyman comes & complains that his pig really was stolen. The sexton pretends not to believe this, & tells the clergyman that his act is so convincing, no one will mind his not sharing the meat.
1961
1792BThe Clergyman & the Sexton Steal a HogAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1775-1799 Clergyman & SextonA clergyman steals a hog, kills it, hides it in his boat, & rows away. When his followers ask him if he has seen a hog thief, he denies it. He takes the hog home where he shows it to the sexton, who thereupon wants to steal a hog as well. In the night, they plan to light the hog’s head with tinder, in order to kill the animal. But when in the darkness the clergyman puts the burning tinder for a moment on his own knee, the sexton thinks it is the hog’s head, & he cuts his companion’s knee with his axe. The cries of pain awaken the inhabitants of the house, & the two thieves are caught.
1962
1800-Stealing Something SmallAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesIn confession, a man admits he has stolen something small – a rope. However, at the end of the rope there was a cow (sheep, ox, donkey).
1963
1804-Imagined Penance for the Imagined SinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis tale exists chiefly in two dif ferent forms: (1) A penitent (young woman) comes to confession & says that he has planned to do something sinful. The clergyman answers that the thought is as good as the deed, & orders the penitent to pay a cer tain amount of money for his absolution. The penitent says that the sin was only imaginary, so the clergyman must accept an imaginary payment. (2) After the confession of an imagined sin, a penitent is supposed to work for the clergyman, but instead he lies under a tree. The clergyman asks him why he is not doing anything, & he answers that his intention to work is as good as the deed.
1964
1804*The Eel Filled with SandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman promises absolution to a penitent in return for a large eel. The penitent sends him an eelskin (skins from many eels) filled with sand. The clergyman says that the man’s sins will not be absolved.
1965
1804**Tales about Payment for AbsolutionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which a penitent cheats a clergyman out of payment that he has demanded in return for granting absolution.
1966
1804BPayment with the Clink of MoneyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man demands payment from other persons because they smelled the first man’s dinner (softened their bread in its steam) while it was being cooked. A judge decrees that the other persons should pay with the clink of coins. In Lithuanian variants, a clergyman shows a communion wafer to a sick man through a window & tells him to imagine that he has received it. The sick man shows the clergyman some money through the window & repeats the same instructions.
1967
1804CPoem for PoemAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA poet sends a flattering poem to his ruler & hopes for a generous reward. Instead, the ruler sends a poem to the poet. The poet sends his ruler a little money, saying that it is all that he has. The ruler recognizes this trick & makes friends with the poet.
1968
1804DThe Shadow of the DonkeyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA donkey driver lets a farmer rent his donkey. It is a hot day, so the farmer stands (sits) in the donkey’s shadow. The driver protests that the farmer rented only the donkey, not its shadow
1969
1804EConfession in AdvanceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA penitent has committed a small sin, for which he is assessed a small amount of money. He pays double so that he can commit another sin for free (can do the same thing again, steal a horse that belongs to the confessor.
1970
1805-Confessions of a Pious WomanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesAn old woman confesses her carnal sins to a clergyman, who replies that they must have taken place many years before. The woman agrees, & adds that she still enjoys remembering them.
1971
1805*The Clergyman's ChildrenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA red-headed clergyman demands that a (cattle) thief confess his sins publicly from the pulpit. The clergyman tells the congregation that everything the man says there is true. The thief announces that the clergyman is the father of all the red-haired children in the village.
1972
1806-Dinner in HeavenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman visits a condemned criminal to offer him consolation, & tells him that tonight he will be having dinner with God. The criminal invites the clergyman to take his place, but the clergyman declines the invitation (says he is fasting). In some variants, a high-ranking clergyman speaks to soldiers before a battle, encouraging them to fight bravely & saying that those who die will dine with God that very day. The soldiers ask why the clergyman does not join them. He replies that he is not hungry.
1973
1806*Tales of ConfessionsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecedotes about confessions. e.g. the penitent offers to trade his fate (future) with the clergy man’s or gives some other quick-witted answer.
1974
1806A*The Clergyman as ProsecutorAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesTwo farmers (grandfather & grandson) go to confession. The clergyman asks the first (the grandson) where God is, but the man cannot answer. The clergyman asks the other one the same thing, but he also cannot answer. The two men think that the clergyman is blaming them for God’s disappearance & hurry away.
1975
1807-The Equivocal ConfessionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA thief (Gypsy) who has stolen a piece of bacon from the clergyman’s soup (the clergyman’s fur coat or hat) tells the clergyman in confession that he drove a hog out of the vegetables (rescued someone from a bear, or tipped his hat). The clergyman praises him for his good deed (manners) & only afterwards discovers what really happened.
1976
1807A"The Owner Has Refused to Accept It."Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA thief (Gypsy) steals the clergyman’s gold watch (snuffbox). The thief confesses that he stole a watch & offers to give it to the clergyman, who refuses it saying that the thief should return it to its owner. The thief says honestly that the owner has refused to accept it. The clergyman tells the thief that he may then keep the watch, & gives him absolution. Later, when the clergyman discovers his mistake, it is too late to get his watch back. In some variants, the clergyman wants the thief to announce his finding in public, but the thief reminds him that what is said in con-fession is secret.
1977
1807A*"Who has lost this?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man comes to confession with a purse of money which he has found (a clergyman finds such a purse). In order to return it to its owner, the man is supposed to announce his finding in the city, but he speaks so softly (has hidden the purse so) that no one understands. Since no one claims the purse, the man is permitted to keep it.
1978
1807BSleeping with God's DaughtersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesFor his penance, a man is required to abstain for four weeks from eating flesh & drinking liquor, not to sleep in a feather bed, & to abstain from sexual relations with women. He goes to a convent where he is provided with meat & wine, & where he sleeps on a bed of down with the nuns. When he tells his confessor about this, the clergyman is angry at the man for sleep-ing with the daughters of God. The penitent replies that now that he is the brother-in-law of Jesus, he does not need a confessor any more.
1979
1810-Anecdotes about CatechismAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes that are structured as a series of questions & answers about religious subjects. The clergyman tests the knowl-edge of one or more of his parishioners. The humor comes from the ignorance of the person questioned, from wrong answers, or from mis understandings evidenced in the answers. The questioner (clergyman) is often thought to be a fool by the person whom he interrogates.
1980
1811-Jokes about Religious VowsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes with ambiguous interpretations of religious vows, in which someone who has taken a vow profits from a misunderstanding.
1981
1811AVow Not to Drink from St. George (April 23) to St. Demetrius (October 26) Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man has vowed not to drink from St. George to St. Demetrius. Instead of the period between the two saints’ days, he interprets this to mean he cannot drink between two churches that bear these names.
1982
1811BThe Patience of Job.Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman preaches about the exemplary patience of Job. His wife tests him by saying that the kitchen maid has wasted the wine supply (he discovers that she spoiled a cheese or let the beer run out). The clergyman becomes angry & refuses to follow Job’s example.
1983
1820-Bride & Groom at Wedding CeremonyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about weddings in which the couple to be married give absurd answers to the clergyman’s questions or otherwise behave comically. In some variants, a fool hits a man on the head because he sings too loudly.
1984
1821-Naming the Child (Baptism)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which the godparent who is to give the child its name does not know what to say. (1) The godparent says, “Name him something”. (2) The clergyman suggests to name the child after his father (god father). The father is afraid that he must then go without a name him self for the rest of his life (he is not sure whether he can live with-out a name). (3) The godparents are told to repeat what the clergyman says. He says something that is not part of the ceremony & they repeat.
1985
1822-Equivocal BlessingsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes that include ambiguous blessings. In some variants, the clergyman blesses the spring fields, saying they should be as fruitful as a nut that he is holding in his hand. When the nut is opened, it is hollow, so the clergyman has to alter his blessing quickly.
1986
1823-Jokes about BaptismAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about comical events at a child’s (seldom adult’s) baptism. For example, the clergyman misunderstands the Latin instructions & hops around. Or, he mistakes the midwife’s (mother’s) fart for a sign that the devil has been driven out. But when they tell him it was the child who farted, he curses it for its bad habits.
1987
1824-Parody SermonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various parodies of sermons. They range from rhymes with absurd contents to improvised sermons (delivered by the clergyman or by someone disguised as a clergyman). Some of them are critical of the authorities or of the audience.
1988
1825-The Farmer as ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis type consists of three introductory episodes in which an unqualified person takes over the office of the clergyman but cannot fulfill his duties. (1) A congregation is no longer able to pay the clergyman & chooses one of themselves (a stranger, someone who can read) to take his place. A wife induces her husband to volunteer to be the clergyman, or a farmer in debt goes to the clergyman for instruction. (2) The clothes of a farmer who is drunk (asleep) are exchanged by his wife (a passerby) with the clergyman’s. The farmer attempts to carry out the clergyman’s duties. (3) A farmer wants to exchange roles with a clergyman because he believes the clergyman has an easy life & only works on Sundays.
1989
1825APreaching the TruthAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA congregation complains about their clergyman to the bishop. The bishop comes for a surprise visit. Before the service begins, the clergyman, who pretends to be asleep, witnesses the bishop propositioning his wife. The clergyman preaches about this in his sermon, & the bishop decides to drop the matter of the complaint In some variants, the bishop instructs all the clergymen always to speak the truth in their sermons. When the bishop comes & hears a clergyman preaching about the bishop’s own misconduct, he removes the clergyman from his position.
1990
1825BPreaching as the Congregation WishesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A congregation (master) requires that the clergyman preach an impromptu sermon on a text that has been placed in the pulpit. The page there is blank. The clergyman begins his sermon with the words, “From nothing, God created the heavens & the earth”. Sometimes he ends there. More often, the sermon that follows is con sidered a particularly good one. (2) A congregation complains that their clergyman, often a layman, knows no Latin. He goes to the sexton for advice. As they walk around, the sexton tells him some mock-Latin words which he makes by adding endings onto familiar words. The clergyman copies this formula in his next sermon, & the congregation is appeased. (3) An ignorant clergyman repeats the same words over & over, e.g. “I preach the word of God”; “I am a good shepherd”; or, “Service & sermon”.
1991
1825CThe Sawed PulpitAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A clergyman, often a layman, promises his congregation that they will witness a miracle. Secretly, he saws the pulpit almost through. When in his next sermon he refers to the miracle, the pulpit falls down. (2) A clergyman (monk) gesticulates wildly during his sermons. One of the parishioners saws the pulpit almost through. It falls down during the next sermon, while the clergyman cites John XVI,16, “A little while, & ye shall not see me”. (3) A clergyman preaches standing on a barrel that caves in during the sermon.
1992
1825D*Fire in the BootsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman, often a layman, serving mass tells his congregation to do as he does. By accident, coals fall out of the censer into his boots. He stamps his feet & then lies down on the floor & kicks. The parishioners imitate him.
1993
1826-The Clergyman Has No Need to PreachAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (often a layman, Nasreddin Hodja) asks his congregation whether they know what his sermon will be about. They do not know, so he berates them for their stupidity. He repeats his question the following week. This time they say they know, so he thinks he need not preach any more. The third week, the congregation is divided in their answer to the question: half say no & half say yes. The clergyman tells those who understand to teach the others. In some variants, a clergyman has to preach a sermon about a certain saint on the appropriate saint’s day. In order to avoid preach-ing this sermon, he announces that, since the saint performed no miracles that year, he need not give a sermon about him.
1994
1826A*The Saint Who Ran AwayAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA saint’s picture is stolen from a church. The clergyman thinks that the saint ran away because he was a bad clergyman. In some variants, a clergyman & a sexton remove a saint’s statue. It is found in a bean field. The clergyman tells the congregation that it had gone to look for some food because they gave so little money for it.
1995
1827-"You Shall See Me a Little While Longer."Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman makes a bet with one member of his congregation that he will be able to empty a jug of wine during his sermon without being observed by the congregation (an alcoholic clergyman depends on his liquor to preach his sermon). In order to be able to drink behind the pulpit, he preaches on John 16.16, “A little while, & ye shall not see me, & again a little while, & ye shall see me”. After the sermon the clergyman shows the empty jug & asks if someone had lost it. In some variants the clergyman goes behind the pulpit to drink during the prayers.
1996
1827ACards (Liquor Bottle) Fall from the Sleeve of the ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesDuring his sermon, a clergyman drops playing cards (liquor flask) out of his sleeve (pocket). He asks the congregation (children) if they know what the cards are for. They show that they are well acquainted with cards. He replies that they know more about cards than they do about God (that on Judgment Day they will fall down just as the cards did).
1997
1827BBilly Goats Instead of SheepAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman preaches a sermon to his congregation, telling them that on Judgment Day when he stands before God (St. Peter at the gate of heaven), he will have to tell Him that, instead of faithful sheep, there were only billy goats (pigs, cattle) under his care (that none of them belong in heaven).
1998
1828-The Rooster at Church CrowsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesDuring the service, a rooster flies into a church through an open window. He crows & wakes the sexton, who thinks it is his cue to answer part of the liturgy (sing a certain song).
1999
1828*Weeping & LaughingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman makes a bet that he can give a sermon that will cause half the congregation to laugh & half to weep. Or, a clergyman wants to show his bishop (the lord of the area) how badly his congregation behaves. He preaches a moving sermon that causes half his audience to weep. But he wears no trousers under his gown (he has fastened an animal’s tail to the seat of his trousers), so that the part of the audi-ence that is behind him breaks out in laughter (the bishop is seated where he cannot see why the people are laughing).
2000
1829-Living Person Acts as Image of SaintAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) On a certain saint’s day, the saint’s statue is missing (it was broken during cleaning, sold, stolen). The sexton suggests to the clergyman that a shoemaker (tailor, beggar) who happens to look like the statue should stand in its place. The shoemaker agrees. Before the end of the service, however, he has to move (he sneezes or has to urinate, is bothered by insects, burns his foot on a candle). Often he curses. The statue’s coming to life is said to be a miracle. (2) A woodcarver who is supposed to carve a saint’s statue does not finish it on time. He finds someone who looks like the statue to take its place. A representative from the church comes & asks the woodcarver to alter the statue with a knife. The person taking its place becomes frightened & runs away.
2001
1830-Producing the WeatherAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA congregation needs to appoint a new clergyman (sexton). They choose one who says he can produce whatever weather that they want. However, they cannot agree what the weather should be: one group wants rain, & another, sunshine. The new clergyman suggests that they let God decide what the weather should be (that it should be the same with the weather as it was before).
2002
1831-The Clergyman & Sexton at MassAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman tells his sexton (deacon) that he should steal a sheep (hog) during the service. When the sexton returns, the service is still going on. The clergyman asks him, as if it were part of the liturgy, whether his theft was successful. The sexton replies, also as if it were part of the service, that he got the sheep (that his theft was discovered), but that he lost the clergyman’s horse. Or, other dialogs on other subjects are incorporated into the liturgy, e.g. between the clergyman & his cook or between the sexton & the clergyman.
2003
1831A*Inappropriate Actions in ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which people in church act in inappropriate ways because of ignorance. Or, the clergyman (clergyman & sexton) acts in unsuitable ways, e.g. fighting, ordering alcohol (for cooking), misunderstanding Latin phrases.
2004
1831BThe Clergyman's share & the Sexton'sAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesDuring the sermon, the clergyman asks the sexton if anyone is coming. The sexton answers that a man carrying a wheel (cudgel) on his shoulder is coming. The clergyman says that the sexton may have the wheel. The sexton then sees a man coming carrying half a hog (an old woman with a tub of butter). The clergyman says he will keep that for himself.
2005
1831CThe Clergyman Takes a BribeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man named Secula boasts to his rich neighbor Micula (Matila, Picula) that he is named in the church service when the clergyman sings, “Saecula saeculorum”. The neighbor offers nine sheep to the clergyman if he will sing “in micula micolorum” instead. The organist (sexton) points out the mistake, so the clergyman gives him one of the sheep.
2006
1832-The Sermon about the Rich ManAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA rich man lets a boy ride to church with him in his coach. The boy accidentally leaves his coat (wooden shoe) behind in the coach. The clergyman preaches about a rich man who went to hell. The boy calls out in dismay, “He took my coat with him!”
2007
1832*The Boy Answers the ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which the clergyman questions a boy during the service (in the street). The boy gives a quick-witted answer (which leaves the clergyman speechless).
2008
1832B*What Kind of Dung?Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (man) sees a boy on the road who is looking at something. The boy says he does not know what it is, & the clergyman tells him that it is horse’s dung (a horseshoe). The boy replies that he was wondering whether it was the dung of a horse or of a mare.
2009
1832D*"How Many Statements are There?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman asks a boy (servant girl) how many sacraments (gods) there are. The boy does not know, so he asks in return if the clergyman knows how many teeth a rake has (how much cloth can be made from a certain amount of flax, how to braid a straw hat). The clergyman does not know the answer, & the boy tells him that one person cannot know everything. To the question of the number of gods, a member of the congre-gation (farmer, child) answers a number that is too high. The clergyman refuses to continue with the person’s confirmation (sends the person home). The candidate repeats the question to another person who tells him that there is only one God. The candidate cannot believe that the clergyman would want so small a number as this for the answer.
2010
1832E*Good MannersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA boy brings a cheese (other item) to a clergyman (merchant, lawyer). The clergyman thinks that the boy did not act politely, so he exchanges their roles in order to teach him how to behave. The clergyman makes a polite speech as he gives the boy the cheese. The boy thanks him & reaches into his pocket for money to give him a generous tip.
2011
1832F*Invitation to DinnerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA boy (farmer) is invited to a meal (by some students or a clergyman). A whole turkey (suckling pig) is served. The host warns the boy that whatever he does to the turkey, the host will do to him. The boy thinks for a while & then puts his finger in the animal’s rear to draw out the stuffing (and licks his finger).
2012
1832M*Clergyman's Words RepeatedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (sexton) has smudges on his glasses (he has forgotten to bring them) so he cannot read the liturgy during mass. He absent-mindedly sings out about his handi-cap & the congregation repeats his words as usual. The clergyman tries to correct their mistaken response, but the congregation repeats that too. Or, the clergyman chooses a man to help with the service. The man thinks he has to repeat everything that the clergyman says, so he repeats the clergyman’s questions about what his name is & where he comes from.
2013
1832N*Lamb of God Becomes Sheep of GodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man (boy, farmer, shepherd) comes to confession but does not know any prayers. The clergyman teaches him a short prayer that begins with the words, “Lamb of God”. Later the clergyman asks the man if he still remembers the prayer. The man begins with the words, “Sheep of God”. The clergyman asks why the man changed the word, & the man answers that the animal must have grown up in the meantime. In Arabian variants, the man is asked for his astrological sign & he answers, “Goat” (“Ram”). When he is asked to explain, he says that he was born in the sign of the Kid, but surely it must be grown up by now.
2014
1832P*"The Devil!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThe clergyman asks a boy in the confirmation class, “Who is the worst enemy of mankind?” The boy does not know the answer. For some other reason, another boy curses, “The devil!” The clergyman recognizes this as the right answer. Or, a clergyman asks a question of a stupid person (asks him to read something). The person mumbles something about a fish. This is the right answer, & the person is praised for his intelligence.
2015
1832Q*A Clergyman Asks for the WayAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman asks a boy the way to the next village. He also warns the boy not to smoke, or he will not go to heaven. The boy replies that if the clergyman knows the way to heaven, he must surely know the way to the next village.
2016
1832R*Hymnbook Upside DownAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA person in church who cannot read holds his (her) hymnbook upside down. When the person beside him tries to correct him, the man with the book explains that he is left-handed.
2017
1832S*Church of DungAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesBoys are playing in the dung (with mud). The clergyman asks them what they are making. One boy answers, “A church”. The clergyman asks if they are going to make a clergyman to go along with it. The boy answers, “If we have enough mud leftover”. (“You are so fat, we do not have enough mud.”)
2018
1832T*"Who Was the Father of Noah's Sons?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA foolish farmer (young man) wants to become a sexton (teacher). Among other questions, the clergyman (landlord) asks him, “Who was the father of Noah’s sons?” The farmer cannot answer this question & tells his wife about it. She wants to help him & asks him, “Who is the father of our miller’s sons?” – “Our miller”. Now the fool believes he knows the right answer. He goes back to the clergyman & says to him, “The father of Noah’s sons is our miller”.
2019
1833-The Clergyman's Rhetorical Question MisunderstoodAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which a person (who arrives late to church) thinks that he has to answer a rhetorical question posed by the clergyman during the sermon. For example in some (German) variants, during the Easter service, the clergyman asks about the disciples on the road to Emmaus (Luke 24,13): “Who were these two who went there?” Someone in the congregation thinks he is asking about two men on the village street & answers, “Two butchers”. Or, the clergyman warns against dying while drunk, because such a person will be buried drunk & be drunk still on Judgment Day. A listener remarks that it must be powerful wine, since it makes one drunk for so long.
2020
1833A"What Does David Say?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman sends his servant to buy something from the butcher David (Paul, Moses). The servant returns to the church just as the clergyman asks in his sermon, “What does David say?” The servant thinks the question is addressed to him & replies, “He says you must pay your old debt first”.
2021
1833B"Where is the Father?'Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman asks a boy (man) who the personages in the Trinity are (asks someone how he crosses himself or how he has baptized his child). The boy answers, “God the Son (Father) & the Holy Ghost” (“In the name of the Father & the Holy Ghost.”). The clergyman asks where the father (son) is, & the boy tells him where his own father is, e.g. holding the oxen (calf) or at home by the stove mending his clothes.
2022
1833C"Where was Christ when He was Neither in Heaven Nor on Earth?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThe clergyman asks where Christ was, when he was neither in heaven nor on earth (he asks, what does God do). The answer is, he was looking for a good stick (getting a whip ready) to beat the person who asks such questions.
2023
1833DThe Names of the Persons of the Holy TrinityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman wants to teach a boy (shepherd, cowherd) the names of the persons of the Holy Trinity (a prayer). To help him, the boy is to associate the names with three (four) animals (buttons on his jacket). Later, when the clergyman meets the boy & asks for the names, the boy cannot remember them all because one of the animals died (was sold, one of the buttons fell off). Or, a farmer is supposed to associate the names of the Holy Trinity with members of his family, father, son, & wife. He refuses to do so because he is certain that the Holy Ghost is not such a spend thrift. Asked how many persons constitute the Holy Trinity & who they are, a boy answers, “Four”. He counts God the Father, his Son, the Holy Ghost, & Amen.
2024
1833EGod is DeadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesAn old woman (other member of the congregation, child) hears from the clergyman (other person) that Christ died for our sins (God is dead). She says she is sorry for the death, & that she did not know of it because she lives so far out in the country that she never gets any news. Then the old woman wonders about who God’s successor will be.
2025
1833FThe Same Old StoryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man goes to church on Good Friday (Christmas Eve) & hears the sermon. The next year, he goes again on that day (his son goes forty years later) & hears the same sermon. He complains that they are telling the same old story over again. (2) In Jewish variants, an old woman is so affected by the story of Joseph & his brothers that she stops eating & becomes ill. A year later she is recovered. She goes to the synagogue & hears the same text. She decides not to fall ill a second time.
2026
1833HThe Large LoavesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. tale exists chiefly in four dif-ferent forms: (1) A clergyman preaches about the miracle of the loaves & fishes, when 5000 people were fed with seven loaves & two fish. The congregation doubts whether this is possible. The clergyman ex-plains that the loaves were as big as mountains (houses). The people ask how big the ovens were. (2) A clergyman reverses the number of loaves & people by mistake. Someone in the audience says that he could do that too. The following year, the clergyman gets it right & asks the congregation if they could do that. Someone says yes, because there would be leftovers from the previous year. (3) A clergyman says that God made the world in six months. He is corrected by the congregation but sticks to what he had said. (4) In variants from eastern Europe, a clergyman says that God made Adam out of clay & put him on a fence to dry. Someone in the congregation asks where the fence came from, since no one was there to have made it.
2027
1833J"Abraham, What do you have on your breast?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man named Abraham (Joseph), on his way to church, steals a ham (pair of ducks) & hides it under his jacket. In his sermon, the clergyman asks rhetorically what Abraham has on his breast (repeats rhetorically, “I can see you”). The man believes he has been discovered & admits to his theft.
2028
1833KThe Thief Betrays HimselfAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesIn order to expose a thief (adulterer), a clergyman threatens during his sermon to throw something (stone, fruit, Bible) at the sinner’s head. The clergyman swings his arm back to throw. Someone else in the congregation calls, “Duck!” to the thief. Or, the clergyman watches the congregation from the pulpit, & sees several (many) of them duck their heads out of the way.
2029
1833LA Clergyman Wakes His Sleeping CongregationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman wakes his sleepy congregation by calling out, “Fire!” Someone asks excitedly where the fire is, & the clergyman answers, “In hell".
2030
1833MThe Long SermonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman is so preoccupied with his long ser-mon that he does not notice that his congregation is becoming restless. Little by little, all the people leave. Finally the sexton gives the key to the clergyman, & tells him to lock up when he is finished.
2031
1834-The Clergyman with the Fine VoiceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman notices that when he sings (preaches), an old woman starts to cry. He thinks his singing is affecting her deeply & so he sings more forcefully. After the service he asks her why she was crying. She answers that his voice (beard, face) reminded her of her recently-dead goat (donkey). In some variants the woman answers that the clergyman reminds her of her son who is studying theology. She is crying because it is such a waste of money.
2032
1834*The Person from Another CongregationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesDuring the sermon, all the congregation weeps except one visitor. After the service, the clergyman asks him why he did not weep. He replies that he does not belong to this congregation.
2033
1834A*A Fool's VocationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man (innkeeper, shoemaker) wants his son to become a clergyman because he is too stupid to take up his father’s line of work.
2034
1835*Not to Turn AroundAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman forbids the people to look behind themselves during the service (sermon). Instead, he will call out the names of the people who arrive late.
2035
1835A*Gun Accidentally Discharged in ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman comes to the service directly from hunting (from getting his gun). By accident, during the sermon, as he gesticulates, the gun goes off. The clergyman says that it will be louder at the Last Judgment. The congre -gation ducks under the pews, or the clergyman threatens them with the gun.
2036
1835B*The Pasted Bible LeavesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesDuring the service, a clergyman reads dir-ectly from the Bible. Two pages stick together (he turns two pages by accident) so he is suddenly in the middle of another story & reads an absurd sentence. Or, the clergyman’s hymnbook drops from the pulpit. He can sing only, “La-la-la”.
2037
1835D*Wager: Clergyman to Read Prayer without Thinking of Anything ElseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man (St. Bernard) promises a clergyman (chattering woman, hermit, man) a horse (pig) if he can say a prayer (the Lord’s prayer) without thinking of anything else. While praying, the clergyman stops to ask whether the horse comes with its harness too.
2038
1836-The Drunken ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes of drunken clergymen who say or do inappropriate things.
2039
1836AThe Drunken Clergyman: "Do as I say, Not as I Do."Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman who has many vices admonishes his congregation to follow his words rather than copy his actions. Sometimes the clergyman blames his many vices on his small income.
2040
1837-Holy Ghost in the ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman who wants to perform a miracle for his congregation arranges for the sexton (his cook, servant girl) to let loose a dove (something burning) from a hole in the ceiling as if it were the Holy Ghost (fire from heaven). When the clergyman gives the signal, the sexton, who lost the dove, answers, “The Holy Ghost was eaten by the cat” (broke his neck, or the material for the fire is gone). The female cook falls through the roof with her naked buttocks exposed. The clergyman warns that anyone who looks up will go blind, but one person risks an eye & looks up to see what happened.
2041
1837*A Pet Dove Drops Excrements in the Clergyman's SoupAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (shoemaker) has a tame bird. When his cook (wife) brings the soup, the bird sits on the edge of the bowl & lets droppings fall into the soup. Everyone laughs, or the cook fishes the droppings out with a spoon. The clergyman complains, “If I had done that I would be punished”.
2042
1838-The Hog in ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA sexton accidentally locks a hog in the church. He hears a noise & alerts the clergyman, who puts on his vestments, takes the Bible, & asks the sexton to open the church door. The hog runs between the clergyman’s legs & hurries away with him riding on his back. The clergyman thinks he is being taken away by the devil.
2043
1838*Not Often Seen in ChurchAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA church officer wants to make some farm-ers (a woman) come to church more often. He scatters millet outside the church & treads it down after it sprouts. Then he accuses the farmers of having dropped it. They reply that it could not have been they, because they have not been to the church for a long time.
2044
1839AThe Clergyman Calls Out CardsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about drunk-en ness & card playing in church. In many variants a clergyman falls asleep in the church. When he wakes up (is awakened by the sexton), he thinks he is at an inn. He declares which cards are trumps or orders another drink.
2045
1839BSermon IllustratedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA card-playing clergyman makes a bet that he will be able to call out a trump suit during his next sermon. In his sermon, he declares that a certain card is trump but adds that God is a better trump than any card.
2046
1840-At the Blessing of the Grave, the Clergyman's Ox Breaks LooseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesWhile officiating at a burial (church service), the clergyman observes that his ox has broken its tether. He curses it (says it is possessed by the devil), & the congregation thinks he is cursing the dead man.
2047
1840BThe Stolen Ham/GoatAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman steals something but promises to pray for the man from whom it was stolen. However, he accuses the man who was stolen from, & absolves the man who stole.
2048
1841-Grace Before DinnerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman asks a boy how his family says grace. The boy does not understand, so the clergyman asks what his father says before they eat. The boy answers, “Come here, children!” (“Come & get it, lions!”)
2049
1842-The Dog's LegacyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThe owner of a faithful dog (donkey, goat, hog) wants the animal to be buried in the churchyard with a proper burial service. The clergyman refuses. After the owner explains that the animal left a large legacy to the church, the clergyman changes his mind. The clergyman (animal’s owner) has to answer to the bishop because he has buried the animal. He offers him some of the money from the supposed legacy & the bishop overcomes his objection to the burial.
2050
1842A*The Avaricious ClergymanAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which an avaricious clergyman tries to get money but is outwitted.
2051
1842C*The Clergyman's NightsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (rector) invites an acquaintance to dinner & shows him his house. The guest takes a silver spoon & hides it in the clergyman’s (cook’s) bed. Some time later the clergyman asks his guest about the spoon, which has been missing since this visit. The acquaintance answers that if the clergyman had slept in his own bed during this time, he would have found the spoon.
2052
1843-The Clergyman Visits the DyingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes in which a clergyman goes to someone’s deathbed, with absurd results.
2053
1843AThe Stolen BicycleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman intends to pay a visit to a man whose wife has recently died, but he comes to the wrong house where a man lives whose bicycle has been stolen. The clergyman expresses his condolences, & the man answers, “She was not worth much – she kept creaking & groaning whenever I was on her (was only good for yokels to ride)”.
2054
1844-The Clergyman Visits the SickAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes, e.g. a clergyman eats beside someone’s sickbed (deathbed). The sick person hears him & complains, “How he gnaws away!” The clergyman answers, “Yes, illness is like that”.
2055
1845-The Student as HealerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA student comes to a village & promises to cure a calf (donkey) that belongs to an old woman (to cure the old woman herself). He writes, “If he does not live, let him die”, on a piece of paper which he puts in a bag & tells her to hang it around the animal’s neck. The calf recovers. Some time later, the student comes again to the village as a clergyman (teacher). He becomes ill, & the villagers recommend an old woman who is known for her ability to cure the sick. She gives him a little bag to hang around his neck. Inside the bag he finds his own message, & he laughs so hard that he recovers.
2056
1847*Biblical ReparteeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA man (Jew, robber, farmer) praises a sermon on the theme [Matthew 7,2], “If someone strikes you on the right cheek, turn the other cheek to him also”. He gives the clergyman a blow on the ear to see if he will act as the Bible recommends. Instead, the clergyman hits him back, quoting [Matthew 5,39], “With the measure you use, it will be measured to you, & even more”. In some variants there are witnesses to the fight who say that both men are interpreting the Bible. Or, the fight is between a gentleman & a clergyman. The gentle -man hits the clergyman with a stick, saying, “This is Moses’ staff, with which he drew water out of the rock”. The clergyman draws a pistol & says, “This is Aaron’s holy censer”.
2057
1848-A Pebble for Each SinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA farmer (boy) who comes to confession cannot remember how many times he sinned. The clergyman tells him that every time he sins, he should put a pebble (potato) aside. The next time he comes to confession, the man brings two large sacks of pebbles (a wheelbarrow load of potatoes).
2058
1848AThe Clergyman's CalendarAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (Nasreddin Hodja) who cannot read the calendar puts beans (peas, grains of corn, pumpkin seeds) into his jacket pocket cor responding to the number of days in Lent (Ramadan). Each day he removes (eats) one bean (throws it in a pot). His wife (daughter) finds the beans and, thinking her husband likes them to eat, adds another handful. When the clergyman is asked how many more fast days there are, he counts the beans in his pocket & names an absurdly big number (says that Easter will not come this year; or, he finds colored eggshells & says that Easter is here already). Or, a clergyman makes a broom (wheel; collects a single egg) each day of the week so that he will know when Sunday comes. When he has six brooms, he tells the sexton to ring the bells on the follow-ing day. A neighbor (sexton) notices this scheme & hides one of the brooms, so that the clergyman makes a mistake & misses the service on Sunday.
2059
1848DThe Clergyman Forgets EasterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman who cannot read forgets to announce the holy days to his congregation. He hears that it is already Palm Sunday. When he goes back to his congregation, he tells them that Lent was shortened to one week this year because of the hard winter & that Easter will come next week. Or, an illiterate clergyman forgets or mixes up others of the holy days of the church calendar.
2060
1849*The Clergyman on the Cow's TailAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1800-1849 Other Clergyman JokesA clergyman (organist) has a cow that swishes her tail to shoo away flies when she is being milked. In order to stop this, the clergyman ties her tail to his jacket (around his neck). When a wasp stings the cow, she runs away, dragging the clergyman after her. In some variants from southeast Europe, a clergyman sits on the back of an unruly cow while his wife (farmhand) milks it. The cow runs away with the clergyman. Others ask him where he is going, & he replies, “Only God & this stupid cow know!”.
2061
1851-Anecdotes about Devout WomenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes that make fun of the extreme credulity of devout old women.
2062
1853-Anecdotes about MillersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about millers, especially in which they steal from their customers.
2063
1855-Anecdotes about JewsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about Jews. Most are anti-Semitic.
2064
1855AJewish Woman Makes Parents Believe that She is to Give Birth to the MessiahAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA young Jewish woman (nun) becomes pregnant by a student (clergyman). Out of fear of her father, the student disguises himself as an angel & tells the father that his daughter will give birth to the Messiah. Many people come to witness the birth. The woman bears a daughter (whom her angry father kills).
2065
1855BThe Check in the CoffinAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleOn his deathbed, a Jew (farmer) asks his sons how much money they will put in his coffin to be buried with him. After he dies, two of the sons put the promised money into the coffin. The third writes a check for the entire amount. He puts this in the coffin & takes out the money that his brothers had put there for himself.
2066
1855CThe Rescuer's SabbathAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA Jew falls into a well (canal) but refuses to be pulled out, because it is the Sabbath. On the following day (Sunday) he calls for help, but now his Christian rescuer refuses because of his own Sabbath.
2067
1855D"You Don't Know What You are Missing"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA priest rides in a train eating a ham sandwich. He offers one to a rabbi (Jew) sitting across from him. The rabbi explains that he is not allowed to eat pork. The clergyman says, “You don’t know what you are missing – pork is very good”. When the clergyman leaves the train, the rabbi says, “Greetings to your wife”. The clergyman answers that he is not allowed to marry. The rabbi replies, “You don’t know what you are missing – women are very good”.
2068
1855EThe Rabbi & the Collection MoneyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA rabbi asks two clergymen of different religions how much of the collection money they keep for themselves. One keeps five percent, & the other, ten percent. They ask him the same question, & he answers, “I throw it all into the air & whatever those above do not take, I keep for myself”.
2069
1856-Children by Day & by NightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA painter paints beautiful children, although his own children are ugly. Someone asks him why this is, & he explains that he makes the first by day & the second by night.
2070
1857-Painting the Red SeaAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleIn order to atone for his sins, or because someone has asked him to, a man (nobleman, Eulenspiegel, woman) under takes to paint a picture of the children of Israel crossing the Red Sea. He covers the canvas (wall) entirely with red. When asked where the children of Israel & the Egyptians are, the painter answers that the Israelites have already passed through, & the Egyptians havedrowned.
2071
1860-Anecdotes about LawyersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about (usually) clever lawyers.
2072
1860ALawyers in HellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man tells a magistrate (mayor, lawyer, policemen) that he dreamed about (went to) hell. There, in the fire, he was about to sit on an empty chair, but one of the devils stopped him, saying that it was reserved for the magistrate. (2) A man (St. Peter, several saints) in heaven wants to have a trial to establish his rights, but there are no lawyers there to conduct it.
2073
1860BDying Like Christ - Between Two ThievesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA dying man asks his wife to summon the lawyer & the notary (clergyman & sexton). When they stand on both sides of his deathbed, he says that he feels like the dying Christ, between two thieves.
2074
1860CDoubts His Own GuiltAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA defense lawyer speaks so eloquently that his client, who had confessed to a crime, comes to doubt his own guilt & changes his plea.
2075
1860DThe Lawyer's Letter OpenedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleTwo farmers (neighbors) have an argument (over their common boundary) & go to court to settle their dispute. They go one after the other to the same lawyer, who refers the second man to a colleague, giving him a letter. The farmer opens the letter & sees that the lawyer promises his colleague & himself a good profit. The farmer shows the letter to the other farmer, & they settle their dispute without legal help.
2076
1860EThreshing DocumentsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA farmer has received a legal statement from a lawyer. When checking the document, for which he has to pay by the page, he realizes that the lawyer has written the paper with wide spaces between the lines (and that the last part of the page is blank). The lawyer explains that this is how documents have to be written. The farmer cannot pay the bill & offers to repay the lawyer with his own work. He takes revenge by threshing the lawyer’s grain (plowing his field), leaving wide spaces unthreshed between the rows. He explains that this is called “document-style threshing”.
2077
1861-Anecdotes about JudgesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type comprises various anecdotes about judges, in most of which the judge settles a case to his own disadvantage.
2078
1861*"Keep Your Seats!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA proud woman (mayor’s wife, male student) arrives late in church (appears before an academic assembly) just as the congregation (audience) is standing up to pray. She thinks they have stood up on her account, so she bids them sit down (the student says he will take the seat by the door). She too had once been poor.
2079
1861AThe Greater BribeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleIn order to resolve their dispute, two men go to a judge. Before the judge makes his decision, one of the men brings him a wagon (ox, ax, jar of oil, milk, brass lamp). The other man brings him a horse (fur, cow or butter, sow, piglet, mule). The judge decides in favor of the second man. When the first man complains that his wagon went the wrong way, the judge explains that it went the way the horse pulled it. (the fur stopped up the ox’s throat, the sow knocked over the oil jar, the piglet drank the milk, etc.)
2080
1862-Anecdotes about DoctorsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about doctors. In many cases, the doctor does not know how to treat a patient (and the patient dies). In others, the patient takes the doctor’s instructions literally or follows them incorrectly.
2081
1862ASham Phsyician: Using the Flea PowderAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA huckster sells powder that he guarantees will kill fleas. When someone asks how to use it, he replies that one has to catch the flea, hold its mouth open, & put a grain of powder in it.
2082
1862CDiagnosis by ObservationAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA doctor diagnoses that a sick man has eaten too much chicken (fruit). The doctor’s son asks how he knew this. The doctor answers that he looked through the man’s garbage & noticed the bones (peels). The son is called to a different sickbed. He notices a donkey sad-dle under the bed (by the door) & diagnoses that the sick man has eaten too much donkey meat (horse & wagon, a pillow). The doctor’s son is ridiculed. Or, he diagnoses that a sick woman has overexerted herself in church work (politics), because he finds a clergyman (politician) under her bed.
2083
1862DThe Constipated CowAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA veterinarian (charlatan) is called to treat a sick cow. He tells the farmer (farmhand) to hold the animal’s mouth open & look in. The veterinarian holds up the cow’s tail & holds a lantern under it. The farmer looking into the mouth cannot see the light, so the veterinarian says the cow suffers from constipation.
2084
1862EThe Most Common ProfessionAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA court jester wants to show the king that the most common profession in the kingdom is that of doctoring. He ties a cloth around his head & pretends that he has a toothache. Everyone who comes by offers advice about treatments for toothache, & thus the king can see how many doctors there are.
2085
1862FWhat is Good for One is Not Good for AllAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA sick smith comes to a quack doctor who prescribes that he should eat bacon pancakes (cauliflower with bacon) three times a day. Three days later the doctor sees the smith working hard & thinks that his prescription cured him. Later, a sick tailor comes to the same doctor & the doctor gives him the same prescription. When the tailor dies, the doctor decides that his prescription was good for smiths but not for tailors.
2086
1864-Anecdotes about MadmenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about people who are insane.
2087
1865-Anecdotes about ForeignersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about foreigners (people from a neighboring country or town). Often the people are stereotyped, e.g. as thieves, as lazy, or as malicious. Some of the anecdotes refer to their ancestors: they are said to descend from some kind of animal.
2088
1867-Anecdotes about the GentryAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about noblemen.
2089
1868-Anecdotes about Hanging (Gallows Humor)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes consisting of humorous dialogs between a criminal & the hangman, or in which the hanging can not take place because the gallows falls apart.
2090
1870-Anecdotes about Various Religions & SectsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about people of a particular religion.
2091
1871-Anecdotes & PhilosophersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleAnecdotes & Philosophers
2092
1871AStar Gazer Falls into WellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA philosopher (Thales) always looks up in order to observe the stars. He falls into a well. An old woman asks him why he wants to learn about the stars, when he cannot even walk on earth without stumbling.
2093
1871BKing Cannot Destroy the CityAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA king wants to destroy a city. A phil-osopher from the city comes & asks for mercy. The king says that he always does the opposite of what people ask him to do. The philosopher asks him to destroy the city & thus saves it.
2094
1871CThe Cynic Wants SunlightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThe king asks the cynic (Diogenes) what he can do for him. The philosopher asks him to move his shadow & get out of his light. He says, “Don’t take away from me what you can’t give me”.
2095
1871DThe Cynic & the Bald-headed ManAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleA bald man insults a philosopher. The philosopher replies, “I envy (praise) your hair. It left you a long time ago”.
2096
1871EThe Cynic & the Stone-Throwing BoyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleAn illegitimate boy who throws stones is warned by a cynic, “Watch out, you might hit your father”.
2097
1871FDiogenes & the LanternAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleDiogenes carries a lantern through the marketplace in broad daylight. When he is asked what he is doing, he replies, “Looking for an honest man”.
2098
1871ZOther Anecdotes about DiogenesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1850-1874 Jokes About Other Groups of PeopleThis misc. type consists of various anecdotes about the philosopher Diogenes. Examples: (1) When Diogenes sees children drinking from their cupped hands, he gives up his own drinking cup. (2) A servant of the king sees Diogenes eating cabbage (washing lettuce) & says, “If you worked for my master, you would have better things to eat”. Diogenes answers, “If you would eat cabbage, you would not have to flatter your master”.
2099
1875-The Boy on the Bear's (Wolf's) TailAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA boy (man, girl, woman) becomes lost (has run away from home or from his master, etc.). (In the forest,) he meets robbers (thieves, Gypsies, Indians) who put him into a cask. A wolf (fox, dog, bear) comes to eat the robbers’ leftovers (sniffs at the cask). The boy reaches out through a hole & seizes the animal by its tail (so that it cries out). It runs away dragging the cask behind it until the cask breaks. Often the boy discovers that he has been taken back home. (The animal loses its tail or is killed.) There is a northern group of variants in which a cabin boy an-noys the crew with his pranks (bad work, stupid conversation) or is blamed for a dangerous storm.
