The sailors throw him into the water in a cask along with some provisions (including honey) & tools. When he comes to a shore, he bores a hole & smears it with honey. Thus he lures a bear (fox, cow) & seizes its tail.
2100
1876*The Succesful HunterAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA hunter shoots a captured rabbit tied to a pole. He hits the string & breaks it. The rabbit escapes.
2101
1877*The Boy in the Hallowed TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA young man plunges into (hides in) a hole in a tree. Woodcutters come to take the tree down. The young man speaks from inside the tree. This frightens them so that they run away, leaving their equipment (bread, horse) behind.
2102
1880-Riding on the CannonballAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man (soldier) who wants to enter a fortress jumps onto a cannon-ball that has been shot from a cannon. Half way there, he reconsiders his plan & decides not to go after all. He jumps onto another can-nonball that has been shot in the other direction & rides it back home.
2103
1881-Man Carried Through the Air by GeeseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man (farmer, hunter) catches geese (ducks, cranes) by tying bread (bacon, worms) to a string. The geese come, eat the bread, & become tied one after another to the string. (A man catches geese by giving them liquor to drink & then ties them all to a string.) The hunter tries to take them home, but on the way they sud-denly all fly up at once & lift him up in the air. They take him to his house & set him down. He climbs home down through the chimney.
2104
1881*Parrots Fly Away with a TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man is annoyed by loud birds (parrots, crows) sitting in a tree. He climbs the tree & smears syrup on the branches. When the birds alight there again, he frightens them (with fireworks). The birds fly up carrying the tree with the man still in it along with them (to a city).
2105
1882-The Man who Fell out of a BalloonAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man is carried to heaven in a balloon (by a bird), in an airplane). He tries to climb back down to earth on a rope (of sand, flax, chaff, but the rope is too short (breaks). The man falls & becomes stuck in the ground up to his neck. He runs home to get an axe (spade) to dig himself out.
2106
1882AMan Caught in Log (Cleft Tree) Goes Home to Get AxeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man is caught in a tree trunk (hole in a tree). He goes home & gets an axe to cut himself free.
2107
1886-A Man Drinks from his Own SkullAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man takes his skull off & drinks from it (carries water in it, uses it to break ice). The skull falls into the water & a duck builds her nest inside it.
2108
1887*Cattle Merchant's Voyage Across the SeaAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man floats across the sea on a raft. One after another, he brings a herd of cattle across to the op posite shore. He himself rides along with the last animal, holding on to its tail.
2109
1889-Munchhausen TalesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with exaggerations & lies.
2110
1889AShooting off the Leader's TailAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA blind bear (wild sow) follows after a young bear (young boar) by holding its tail in his mouth. A hunter separates them by shooting a bullet through the young bear’s tail. He leads the blind bear home by holding on to the amputated tail of the young bear.
2111
1889BHunter Turns Animal Inside OutAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA hunter thrusts his fist into the mouth of an animal (wolf, bear) & reaches his arm in up to his shoulder. He seizes the animal’s tail (intestines) & turns it insideout.
2112
1889CFruit Tree Grows from Head of a DeerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA hunter uses a cherry pit to shoot a deer. A year or two later he recognizes the animal by the cherry tree that has grown between its antlers. This time he kills it.
2113
1889DTree Grows Out of a Horse & Gives Rider ShadeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThe broken backbone of a horse is repaired by a smith who pieces it together with a laurel sapling. The sapling grows into a tree which provides shade for the rider.
2114
1889EDescent From the Sky on Rope of Sand (Chaff)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man who is in the sky (on the moon, in another high place) wants to return to the earth. He makes a rope out of flax (leather, sand, chaff, dough, soap, intestines), but this is too short. He cuts a piece off the top & ties it to the bottom. The rope breaks & the man falls down to earth.
2115
1889FFrozen Words (Music) ThawAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man tells (in jest) about a place (town) where it was so cold that all the words (songs) froze in extreme cold as soon as they were spoken. When spring came the words thawed & could be heard again.
2116
1889GMan Swallowed by FishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA huge fish (whale, several fishes) over-turns a ship & swallows the crew (a sailor). When later the fish is caught & its stomach is opened, all the men are still sitting inside & can be rescued.
2117
1889HSubmarine OtherworldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA sailor goes across the ocean to see where it ends, where the tide comes from, & where the tide goes when it is out. On his journey he experiences various adventures (under water).
2118
1889JJumping Back to the Starting PlaceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man tries to leap over water. Halfway across, he changes his mind, & returns to his starting place.
2119
1889LSplit DogAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesWhile chasing a hare, a hunting dog runs through a fence & splits himself into two parts. The hunter puts him back together, but with one pair of legs pointing upward. The dog recovers & learns to run on two legs. When he gets tired, he flips over & runs on the other two legs.
2120
1889L**Mittens Chase DeerAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA hunter’s best dog dies. He has its skin made into a pair of mittens (piece of clothing, flask for drink) which he wears while hunting. Seeing some game (hare), he exclaims, “I wish I had my dog!” The gloves come off & chase the game.
2121
1889MSnakebite Causes an Object to SwellAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA snake (bee, hornet, dog) bites (stings) an object (tree, yoke, walking stick, axle of a wagon, stirrup) which swells to a monstrous size.
2122
1889NLong HuntAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA hunting dog following a scent refuses to go back. After a year (some months), the hunter finds its skeleton with the skel eton of the hunted animal in its mouth.
2123
1889PHorse RepairedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA horse breaks into two pieces. (The owner repairs it temporarily with willow wands.) The owner rides to his destina tion on the front part of the horse. When he comes back, he sews the two parts back together.
2124
1890-The Lucky ShotAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA gun goes off by accident. It kills a grouse, which falls & kills a rabbit (falls into some branches & kills a bear, etc.
2125
1890B*Fatal BreadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA boy drops a piece of bread from a tree. It lands on a bear’s nose & kills the bear.
2126
1890FShot Causes Series of Lucky/Unlucky AccidentsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tall tales dealing with an amazing shot (a gun that shoots by accident) that causes a series of lucky or unlucky accidents.
2127
1891-Catching a RabbitAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tall tales dealing with hunting rab-bits (hares), such as the following examples: (1) A rabbit is caught because on a cold night it freezes tight to the ice (2) A rabbit is blinded by a bright light. It begins to cry & its tears freeze it to the ground. (3) A rabbit smells pepper (snuff) & sneezes. It hits its head on a stone & dies (a stone falls on its head). (4) A rabbit slips while trying to steal a cabbage & falls into an icy hole. (5) A rabbit gets stuck hanging on a branch & loses its sense of direction. (6) A cabbage is used to lure a rabbit into a garden, where it is caught in a sack. (7) A rabbit’s nose is smeared with wax. It runs away in fright, runs into another rabbit, & both are caught.
2128
1892-The Trained Horse Rolls in the FieldAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA horse comes into a field. A tree (willow, oak, buckwheat, oats) grows from its flank. The farmer fastens a sickle to its tail (throws a sickle that sticks into its backside). The horse rolls over, killing other animals or harvesting the field.
2129
1892*Wolf Made into CheeseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA wolf falls into a vat of milk which is made into cheese. When the cheese is cut by the farmhands at harvest time, the wolf jumps out of the cheese. His tail catches on a scythe & as he runs away, he mows the meadow.
2130
1894-A Man Shoots a Ramrod Full of DucksAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man sees a flock of wild ducks (wolves) on a pond. He tries to shoot them but his ramrod is still in his gun. The whole flock of ducks is speared by the ramrod (by a single shot).
2131
1895-A Man Wading in Water Catching Many Fish in his BootsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man (merchant, hunter) goes wading. When he comes back to the shore, his boots are full of fish.
2132
1896-Man Nails the Tail of the Wolf to the TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man nails the tail of a wolf (bear, fox, sable) to a tree (shoots a fox with a nail that sticks in a tree) & beats the animal. The wolf jumps out of its skin & runs away.
2133
1897-The Pike Caught by the FoxAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA fox catches a pike’s tail & the pike catches the fox’s tail. A farmer captures both.
2134
1900-How a Man Came Out of a Tree Stump (Marsh)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A man falls into a hollow tree where he finds honey (bear cubs), but he cannot get out. When a bear comes, he grabs its tail (leg, etc.) & it pulls him out. (2) A man falls into a marsh & gets stuck. A duck (stork, goose, sparrow, etc.) builds its nest on his head. When a wolf (fox, bear) comes to raid the nest, the man grabs its tail & is pulled out.
2135
1910-Bear (Wolf) HarnessedAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA wild animal (bear, wolf, lion, snake) or a mythical creature (dragon, div, devil) kills (devours, dismembers) a tame animal (ox, cow, horse, donkey, mule, deer). The dead animal’s owner objects that he still needs the work which the dead animal had done for him (riding, plow ing, hauling). The wild animal has to take its place & do its work (pull the wagon, carry the load or the man). The wild animal is forced to do this by the man, or it puts the yoke on by itself.
2136
1911AHorse's New BackboneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA horse (other pack animal) breaks its spine. A man repairs it with a stick. A tree grows out of it.
2137
1916-The Breathing TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA hunter cuts down a tree packed so full of animals that a crack opens when the animals inhale & closes when they exhale.
2138
1917-The Stretching & Shrinking HarnessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man driving a heavy wagon in the rain comes to a hill. The horse climbs up the hill, but the wagon is so heavy that the harness stretches, leaving the wagon back at the foot of the incline. The man unharnesses the horse & lays the harness on a stump to dry. When the sun comes out (the rain stops), the straps shrink so that the load is pulled up the hill.
2139
1920-Contest in LyingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales in which two or more people compete to see who can tell the biggest lie (in a believable manner). Often the narrator induces someone to say, “That is a lie!”
2140
1920A"The Sea Burns"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesMisc. type with diverse contents. Three main themes can be distinguished: (1) A man brags that he shot a single arrow through the hoof & the ear of a deer, so that the hoof remained stuck to the ear. When hearers doubt this account, another man (servant) corroborates the lie, explaining that the deer was scratching itself on the cheek & ear with its hoof, so the arrow went first through the hoof & then through the ear. (2) One man says that the sea is burning. The other says, “Then there will be plenty of roasted fish”. (3) One man tells about a great turnip, another man about a great kettle to cook the turnip in.
2141
1920A*Tall CornAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man boasts about his grain which has grown ten feet high. Another man claims that his grain is as tall as a two-story house. When the first man asks him how he is able to harvest it, he replies, “From the upstairs windows”.
2142
1920B"I Have No Time to Lie"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA habitual liar is asked to tell a lie. He says he has no time for that now because he has to go to a neighboring town where there has been a huge catch of fish to buy some cheap (where children have fallen off the bridge into the water; or, his neighbor is sick & he has to get the doctor). Thus the liar induces his audience to go with him to the town, where they discover that the whole story was a lie.
2143
1920B*Big StrawberriesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man boasts that his strawberries are so big, four of them fill a half-liter measure. Another man claims that none of his strawberries would even fit through the opening of a half-liter measure.
2144
1920C"That is a Lie!"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA master offers a reward to anyone who can tell such a lie that he interrupts him & accuses him of lying. His farmhand tells a story in which he claims that the master owes him a large amount of money. The master interrupts & exclaims, “That is a lie!” The farmhand has won.
2145
1920C*Speed in SkillsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesTwo liars compete with each other over which of them has the most remarkable skill to do something amazingly quickly
2146
1920DLiar Reduces the Size of His LieAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA liar agrees with his friend that the friend will step on his toes if he begins to lie excessively. When this happens it causes the liar to end his story with exaggerated smallness rather than largeness. For example, he says he has seen a barn that is 300 feet long & three feet wide.
2147
1920D*Climbing to HeavenAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThree brothers compete in lying to see which of them will receive the biggest inheritance. The first tells about a plant that is so big it grows to the sky. The second tells about a string that also reaches the sky. The third says that he snuf fed out a cigarette on the moon. When his brothers ask how he got there, he answers,‘“I climbed up on the string & back down on the plant”. He wins the best inheritance.
2148
1920EGreatest Liar Gets His Supper FreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesSix young men (students) have a lying contest, for which the prize is a free meal at an inn. A friend of one (all) of the liars arrives late & pretends to be a stranger. He corroborates & reinforces his friend’s story so that it seems to be true.
2149
1920E*Seeing (Hearing) Enormous DistanceAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesLiars boast about seeing (hearing) small things that are far away. For example, one can see a fly (gnat, ant) on the church tower, & another says he can hear it beat-ing its wings (running), etc.
2150
1920FHe Who Says, "That's a Lie" Must Pay a FineAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesTwo liars come to an agreement that whichever of them first says, “That is a lie!” must pay a fine. One tells a story in which he claims that the other owes him so the same amount of money as the fine. Whether he voices his objection or not, the other has to pay him the money.
2151
1920F*Skillful HoundsAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man tells about a hunting dog that had kept a raccoon in a tree so long that the dog finally died. Another tells about a hunting dog that followed game to where it was born, etc.
2152
1920GThe Great Bee & Small BeehiveAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA liar tells about a place where the bees are as big as sheep. The beehives, however, are the normal size. A listener asks him how the bees can go into their hive.
2153
1920HBuying Fire by StorytellingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis is a frame tale into which different tall tales can be set. Three brothers meet an old man (forest spirit, wind spirit, devil, giant) sitting beside a camp fire & ask to borrow some of his fire. He asks them for a story in return. The third brother agrees, but only if the old man will not interrupt him. However, the old man does call out, “Lie!” during the story. According to their agreement he has to let the brother cut strips of skin from his back.
2154
1920H*Will Blow Out LanternAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA fisherman boasts about catching of large fish. Another boasts about catching of a lantern which is still burning. The first teller remonstrates; the second agrees that if the first will take twenty pounds off his fish he will blow out the light in his lantern.
2155
1920JBridge Reduces a LieAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA boy (servant) who has just returned from a journey, travels on foot through the country with his father (knight). The boy tells a story about a dog (fox, cat, hare) that is bigger than (as big as) a horse (ox). Instead of scolding him for lying, the father tells him (1) that they will soon have to wade through a river that will swallow up anyone who has told a lie that day; or, (2) that they are coming to a bridge on which any liar will break his leg, or (3) which will fall to pieces if a liar crosses it. The boy is frightened & gradually reduces the size of the animal down to its normal size, as they come near the river (bridge).
2156
1921J*Various Tales of LyingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesMisc. type with diverse contents
2157
1924-The Man Known by EveryoneAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThree friends get together after several years & talk about their travels & experiences. The first one says that during a celebration in Paris General de Gaulle greeted him by name. The second one was in Washington where President Johnson shook his hand. The third one, who is named Miller, tells about his experience in Rome: “A hundred thousand people were gathered in St. Peter’s Square. When the pope arrived, carried in his gestatorial chair, he caught sight of me & motioned to me to come up & sit in the chair beside him, which I did. As they carried us along towards St. Peter’s I could hear the people asking, ‘Who is that sitting next to Mr. Miller?’”
2158
1925-Contest in WishingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type includes various tales in which several men (brothers, men of different nationalities, servants, clergymen) compete in making wishes.Each of them makes an impossible wish (the wishes may be en-couraged by their master, a fairy, etc.). For example, the first man wishes for great riches (a church full of needles, plenty of food & drink, etc.), & the second tries to outdo him. The third wishes to be the heir of both the others (to marry the master’s daughter, etc.). Or the last has nothing left to wish for, since the others have wished for everything & left nothing for him.
2159
1927-The Cold May NightAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesDuring a very cold night in May, someone tells a man that long ago there was an even colder night. He goes on a journey to learn more about it. He meets an otter that has been lying on a rock in his cave for so long that his body has worn out the rock. The otter has heard of the cold night, but it was before his time. He sends the man to an eagle who has been sitting for so long on an anvil that the anvil is worn off away from the whetting of his beak on it. The eagle sends the man to an one-eyed salmon who remembers the cold night. As he was jumping out of the water, it froze beneath him, & he landed on the ice. After a bird came & picked his eye out, the salmon’s blood thawed the ice & he was able to swim again.
2160
1930-SchlaraffenlandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA tale about a world where impossible, utopian things happen & everything is topsy-turvy. For example, doves pluck a wolf, frogs thresh grain, mice ordain a bishop, etc. Generally there is an abundance of food & drink, such as a river of honey, food growing on trees, edible houses & mountains, & roasted chickens & pastries that fly into people’s mouths, etc.
2161
1931-The Woman Who Asked for News from HomeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA woman asks her guest for news from her home (house, village). He tells her impos-sible, absurd things, such as: Is the same rooster there? – No, he be came the sexton. Is the cat still there? – No, she was made the over seer. Is the pond still in front of the house? – No, it burned up last summer, etc. The woman believes these answers. She agrees & pretends that she had already known that these things had happened.
2162
1932-Church Bulit of CheeseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThe Gypsies’ church is made of cheese, ham, cake, sausage, etc. (They received this in exchange for their stone church.) Once when they were hungry, they ate it up, & now Gypsies have no church.
2163
1935-Topsy Turvy LandAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesVarious tall tales often in the form of a sermon, a poem, a song, or a travelogue in which everything is mixed up or in verted. For example: the weak overpower the strong, cripples can catch hares, lying is the “finest art form”, the laziest person is the king, etc.
2164
1940-The Extraordinary NamesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales in which animals, people, or things are called by unusual names, which leads to confusion or disaster. The basis for the misunderstanding is either that the usual names have been switched (in humorous anecdotes) or that different names are adopted because of their symbolic, accoustic, or nonsense value (in cumulative tales, sayings, songs, & rhymes).
2165
1948-Too Much TalkAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThree silent men (trolls, brothers, captains, farmers) withdraw from the world & retreat to a hermitage (canyon, monastery, island). After seven years, one of them speaks, “I think I heard a cow moo”. The others are irritated but stay silent. Seven years later, another man says, “It could have been an ox”. The third is annoyed but does not speak. After seven more years, he says, “I am leaving this place because there is too much talking (noise)”.
2166
1950-The Three Lazy OnesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA king wants to leave his kingdom to the laziest of his three sons. Each boasts about his laziness. The first says that when he is lying down & drops of water fall in his eyes, he is too lazy to shut them. The second says that when he sits by the fire, if his foot starts to burn, he is too lazy to pull it back. The third says that if he were to be hanged & had a knife in his hand, he would be too lazy to use it to cut the rope. The father decides that the third is the laziest, & gives him the kingdom. In another form of the tale, five sons boast of their laziness. The first is too lazy to close his mouth when he eats, so the birds carry off the bread. The second will not pull his leg out of the fire. The third lets mice gnaw on his ear. The fourth will not cut the rope used to hang him. The fifth lets raindrops beat his eyes out.
2167
1950AHelp in IdlenessAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA master (supervisor) asks two workmen what they are doing. The first says, “I am not doing anything”. The second says, “I am helping him”.
2168
1951-"Is the Wood Split?"Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA lazy man is offered a load of wood as a gift. Before he accepts it, he asks, “Is it already split?”. Sometimes other gifts are offered: “Is the rice cooked?” – “Is the wheat ground?” – “Has the flour been made into bread?”– “Are the nuts roasted & shelled?
2169
1960-Great Animal or ObjectAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an unnaturally-large object, animal or plant.
2170
1960AGreat OxAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales about enormous animals, domestic (ox, cow, horse, sheep, goat, hog, dog, cat, etc.) or wild (fox, bear, hare, boar, opossum, frog, turtle, snake, etc.). For example, an ox is so big that it takes a bird a whole day (week, year) to fly from the end of one of its horns to the other. Or, one of its horns is used in a mill as a funnel, & it holds a whole cask of grain. A hog is so big that it has been coming around a corner for three days & its eyes are still not visible. A sheep has a tail so heavy that it must be carried in a wheel-barrow, & when it is sheared it yields two hundred weights of wool.
2171
1960BGreat FishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with enormous fish. The following are the most common variants: A huge fish (pike, perch, burbot, salmon, eel, whale, etc.) has wound itself three times around an island. For three days people try to pull it up onto the land, but its eyes are still not visible. Inside the great fish are found the bells from seventeen sheep. The fish’s flesh is pickled in 300 pounds of salt, & it feeds an entire hospital for a year. The fish’s eyes alone weigh five pounds. Its scales are removed with a plow & used to roof a barn. Its bones are used to fence a field, & its skull is made into an oven.
2172
1960CThe Great Catch of FishAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales about catching a great load of fish. The catch of fish is so great that it has to be pickled in barns. There are enough scales to roof many buildings. There are so many fish in the sea that it is possible to walk on top of them & keep one’s feet dry. The fishermen have to put worms on their hooks behind a rock, to prevent the fish from tearing the worms from their hands.
2173
1960DGreat VegetableAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous vegetable (turnip, cabbage, mushroom, potato, melon, pumpkin, cucumber, grain, tobacco, etc.). The following are the most common variants: A turnip grows so big & so fast that the fence has to be moved three times during the summer. It takes a whole day to pull up the turnip, & seven days for a swallow to fly around it. A sow (hare) eats her way into the turnip, which grows back around her. When the turnip is cut open, the sow is found inside with seven piglets (seven cartloads of hares are found inside). Fifteen men uproot the turnip using levers, & two horses are needed to move it. A boat is made from its rind. The cabbage (mushroom) is so big that an entire regiment of sol-diers fits under its leaves (cap). Part of it is used to make soup for a battallion, but the rest of the vegetable is still too big to pass through the lock of the canal. Six men work for six weeks to dig up the potato, but they excav-ate only its top half. A stalk of rye is so fat that a hog can go through it, or a man can drive a horse & wagon through the stalk & turn around inside it. Five men can stand on its stump. One grain is so big that just cutting it in two yields a bucket of sawdust. The tobacco is so tall that, to prune it, nine ladders have to be stack ed one on top of the other. It takes two men a whole day to cut out both sides of the stalk. Standing on the stump they fight for two days over the tobacco.
2174
1960EThe Great FarmhouseAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous farm, its separate buildings (house , barn, kiln, granary, mill, church, etc.), or the management there. The following are the most common variants: A building is so tall that when an axe falls from the peak of the roof, a swallow is able to build her nest in it, lay her eggs, & rear her young, before the axe hits the floor. A barn is so long that when a cow is taken to the bull at the other end, she gives birth to her calf before she gets back to her stall. A church is so big that when a baby is baptized, he is old enough for his first communion before he comes out. A room is so big that, for three years, the father & mother look for each other inside it. On his way to his morning coffee, the farmer has to stop twice for meals. From the middle of the room the walls are not visible, so people have to use the floorboards to orient themselves. Everything on the farmstead is enormous: buildings, animals, fields, tools, plants, catch of fish, oven, containers, cooking imple-ments, pipes, people, & cattle. The cows give so much milk that it flows out of the stall like an ocean, & someone in a boat has to float on it to skim the cream, etc.
2175
1960FGreat KettleAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesIt took ten (fifty, a hundred, etc.) smiths to forge the kettle. They stood so far apart as they worked that none of them could hear the others. Or, the enormous kettle belongs to a giant farmstead or giant ship. In the latter case, often either the cook or the ship itself, tossed in a storm, lands in the porridge pot & is mixed within the porridge.
2176
1960GGreat TreeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous tree (plant or beanstalk that grows up to the sky, etc.) The following are the most common variants: An oak tree is so big that eighty people can dance on its stump. A church is built on the stump of a pine tree. A hole in the tree is used for a barn, & three hundred bears hibernate under the tree’s roots. A road runs through the tree. A man drives a horse & wagon into the tree through a hole, & is lost there for three days before he finds his way out. When the tree is transported, its roots pass by a certain place on Easter but its crown does not come by until after Christmas.
2177
1960HGreat ShipAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous ship. The following are the most common variants: A ship is so long that it takes a train three days to go from the bow to the stern. It is too long to turn about, & carries six million crew. When it was turned about in the Baltic Sea, its jib swept all the sheep into the water. In order for the ship to pass through the Kat-tegat Strait, its sides had to be rubbed with soap. A young cabin boy who climbs up the mast comes down as a gray-haired old man. The coxswain gives his orders from horseback (airplane or helicopter). The cook rides in the pot in a motorboat to stir the porridge.
2178
1960JGreat BirdAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous bird (eagle, grouse, hawk, crane, etc., some-times a goose, duck, or chicken). The following are the most common variants: A bird is so big that when it is transported, people see only its neck for two days, & on the third day they come to see its body. Its nest is made from three cartloads of twigs & inside it are some sheeps’ bells, harnesses, etc. When a man tries to burn the nest, the bird puts out the fire with a load of water it has carried in a boat. A bird is so big that it darkens the whole sky.
2179
1960KThe Great Loaf of BreadAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous loaf of bread (cake, pudding, turn-over, cheese, etc. The following are the most common variants: A loaf of bread is so big that it never comes to an end. It was orig inally made for the wedding of the family’s great-great-grand-father. A turnover is filled with seven sacks of turnips & meat from two pigs. Two casks of rye flour were used for the dough. A farmer uses a pitchfork to cut it & serve it to his family. Three hundred people are killed by the steam that escapes when it is pierced. A boat is made from the crust.
2180
1960LThe Great EggAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous egg. The following are the most common vari ants: An egg is so big that it has to be cut to pass through a doorway. When the egg is broken open, forty cities are flooded.
2181
1960MThe Great InsectAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an enormous insect (bee, fly, gnat, louse, flea, grasshopper, etc.). The following are the most common variants: Giant lice eat three puppies. One louse holds a whole loaf of bread in its feet & eats it. A louse with a sheep’s leg bone stuck between its teeth climbs into someone’s bed. The bones of a great gnat are used to make a fence. Giant mosquitos bore through the side of a kettle (as if with nails) & carry it away through the air. Flies carry away people or animals. A giant bumblebee fights with a bear.
2182
1961-The Big WeddingAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with an unusual wedding (most are endless tales). The following example is common in Norway: A giant has sixty daughters (sons) who all ride to a wed-ding on the same horse. The horse’s backbone breaks & is repaired with a tree used as a splint. The giant gets the horse in his eye, a fox in his beard, etc.
2183
1962-My Father's Baptism (Wedding)Anecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA boy tells lies. For example, he claims that he was born before his father was born, baptized, or married. People send him to a mill (to climb up a sky-high tree) to get some flour (to find a witness for his parents’ marriage or a name or godfather in heaven). He harnesses six sacks of flour to the wagon & loads it with six oxen. When he arrives at the mill it is not there, but out picking strawberries. He finds the mill & drives it home. While he was gone, the handle of his whip has grown into a sky-high tree with birds’ nests in its branches. When he climbs up, the fledgling birds catch him & carry him away, & then drop him. He delivers the flour to his parents, dances with his mother at her wedding, & is born two years later.
2184
1962AGreat WrestlersAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tales dealing with two (more) enormous, strong wrestlers (eaters) & their wrestling (eating) match.
2185
1963-Boat without Bottom Sails SeaAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesSomeone tells about three ships loaded with cargo that sail on a brook (sea) without water. The first has no bottom, the second is without sides, & the third ship is not there.
2186
1965-Disabled ComradesAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThree (one to six) disabled (blind, lame, dumb, deaf, naked) comrades (brothers) (pretend to) achieve feats that are incompatible with their disabilities. They go hunting in an impossible place: in shrubbery that has not yet grown, using only defective weapons. Or, they go fishing on dry sand or in a dry river bed. They catch game (fish) that is non-existent. They come to strange (decrepit) places (houses) where they meet dead people who become their servants & who give them an im-possible vessel to cook their game (fish) in it. The game is prepared & cooked in a strange way & they have a strange meal. One of the dead servants dies during the meal & inherits. After the meal, the comrades go to a well (flood, river). They find a strange church (clergyman).
2187
1966-Faster than the ColdAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesA man can ride his bicycle (horse, wagon, can run) so fast that he can stay ahead of the raindrops of an approaching thunderstorm. Only the tail of his horse gets wet.
2188
1967-The Big FreezeAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesThis misc. type comprises various tall tales dealing with a big freeze. Examples: (1) In very cold weather, when pots full of boiling water freeze, a woman goes out to urinate. While relieving herself she freezes to the ground. Her husband has to fetch a pair of blacksmith’s shears to cut her free. (2) It is so cold, that a man freezes to his saddle. He must be thawed out beside a stove (3) It is so cold, that the urine of a man, who goes outside to relieve himself, freezes in an arc. (4) A man puts a pot with hot milk (chocolate) on ice. The milk freezes so fast that the ice is still warm.
2189
1968-Severed Head Freezes to BodyAnecdotes & Jokes (1200-1999)1875-1999 Tall TalesOn a very cold day the head of a decapitated man freezes back on his body before it can fall down to the ground. In a tavern (at home) in front of the fire he sneezes (blows his nose), & the head falls into the fire (the head melts).
2190
2009-Origin of ChessFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesThe inventor of chess demands kernels of grain for each square on the board: one for the first, two for the second, four for the third, etc., i.e. each square has double the amount of the pre-vious square. The king is unable to provide so much grain.
2191
2010-Ehod mi yodea (One, who knows?)Formula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesReligious (Jewish) song in which the numbers from one to twelve in sequence are associ ated with cir-cumstances, beings and/or persons that have religious (theological) significance. For example, in Catholic countries of western Europe (for Jews in Bohemia in the 16th century), the answers run as fol lows:One God, two tablets of laws, three patriarchs, four evangelists (ancestral mothers), five clever virgins (books of Moses), six pitchers in Canaan (books of Mishna), seven sacra ments (days of the week), eight beatitudes (days until circumcision), nine choirs of angels (months of pregnancy), ten commandments, eleven thousand virgins (stars), twelve apostles (races of Israel) (thirteen characteristics of God).
2192
2010AThe Twelve Days (Gifts) of ChristmasFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesChain tale (song) in which gifts are brought each day, or a de scription of the generous dowry that a king provides for his daughter. One partridge, two turtledoves, three french hens (wood doves), four collybirds (ducks), five golden rings (rabbits), six geese (hares), seven swans (dogs), eight maidservants (sheep), nine drummers (oxen), ten pipers (turkeys), eleven noble ladies (hams), twelve noblemen (cheeses)
2193
2010IHow the Rich Man Paid his ServantFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesA man who works for a gentleman is paid for his first six months with a chicken, for the second six months etc. with a hen, a goose, a goat, a cow, a horse [...] a girl, a farm. The animals often have peculiar names (voices).
2194
2010IAThe Animals with Peculiar NamesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesFolk song in which, in each verse, a man buys an animal. In answer to questions about what they are called, it turns out that all of them have peculiar names.
2195
2011-"Where Have You Been, Goose?"Formula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesFacetious questions & answers built upon the anatomy of an animal. For example,“Where have you been, goose (lamb)?” – “Out in the fields.” – What do you have in your beak?” – “A knife (brick, water, ox, stick, old woman, monk, mass, coat), etc.”
2196
2012-The Days of the WeekFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesThis misc. type comprises various chain tales in which the months of the year, days of the week, or hours of the day are con-nected to actions or events. (1) A forgetful man enumerates the chores done on the various days of the week & comes to the conclusion that today must be Sunday. (2) A widower relates how he courted, married, & buried his wife within a single week. (3) The chief events of a human life, from birth to death, are assigned to the hours of the day (from one o’clock to ten o’clock). (4) In a children’s rhyme, the main events of a human life, from birth to death, are assigned to the various days of the week. (5) A bird gives a father instructions for educating his lazy chil-dren. She tells him what she does for her chicks each month from March to August, when they are ready to fly away.
2197
2013-"There was once a woman, the woman had a son."Formula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesThis misc. type comprised of rounds in which a narrator repeats his tale in a never-ending circle. For example, articles of clothing (parts of the body) are enumer-ated or described,“There once was a woman who had a son. He wore red pants, the pants had black buttons, etc. Shall I tell it again?”
2198
2014-Chains Involving Contradictions or ExtremesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesThis misc. type comprised of various chain tales that feature contradictions or extremes. The following are the most common variants: (1) A man who has recently been married meets a friend (neighbor, stranger) who tells him what has happened at home while he was absent. The friend makes the events sound positive, but as the married man asks for more information, the situation turns out to be disasterous. During their conversation they exchange other news. For example, one says that a goat (hog) ate a giant cabbage & became fat enough to be slaughtered. Questions & answers follow, with com ments like, “That’s good.” – “No, not so good.” – “That’s bad.” – “No, not so bad.” One tells the other his house burned down. “That’s too bad”, answers the other, but the first man says, “Not it’s not so bad, because my wife died in the fire”. (2) Two godparents (strangers) discuss a coin (saw, pea) which one of them has found (lost). The conversation conveys alternating incidents or commentary. At the end, one tells the other that he killed a wolf which had eaten a wild boar. The other says, “That’s good”. The first replies, “Yes, it is good, but not very good, because the squire claimed its skin”.
2199
2015-The Goat Who Would Not Go HomeFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesA boy is not able to bring his mischievous goat home. He asks people (hunter, shepherd, St. Nicholas), animals (bear, hare, dog, cat, mouse, pig), and/or objects (rope, water, fire) for help. None of them can (will) make the goat go home. A wolf (bee, wasp, fly) bites (stings) the goat, & it runs home fast
2200
2016-Wee Wee WomanFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesOnce there was a teeny tiny woman who had a teeny tiny cow which she milked into a teeny tiny pail. A teeny tiny cat drank all the milk. The woman killed the cat (it died), & all the milk flowed back into the pail, etc.
2201
2019-Pif-Paf-PoltrieFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesA suitor (suitors) with a peculiar name (e.g. Pif Paf Poltrie) asks a father for his daughter’s hand in marriage. The father consents & sends the suitor to other relatives, who also consent. The suitor asks the bride about her dowry, which is poor. She asks him what his profession is. He is not a tailor, shoemaker, farmer, carpenter, or smith, but a maker of brooms
2202
2019*Louse & Flea Wish to MarryFormula Tales (2000-2399)2000-2020 Chains based on Numbers, Objects, Animals or NamesChain tale or song about the wedding of a louse & a flea (other animals). Other animals (fly, frog, ant, beetle, newt, snake, rat, etc.) help with the preparations (come as guests, bridesmaids, musicians, baker, cook, etc.). Various complications ensue
2203
2021-The Rooster & the HenFormula Tales (2000-2399)2021-2024 Chains Involving DeathA hen (rooster, cat, other animal, young woman) has a nut (cherry pit, a corn, etc.) stuck in her throat (dies in some other way). A rooster goes to get water for the hen to drink, but the water sends him to get red silk from a bride first. The bride sends him to get a wreath, etc. Or, the rooster asks for help from various animals (pig, cow, etc.), people (miller, baker, shoemaker, etc.), and/or objects (river, tree, etc.). When the rooster comes back with the water, the hen is already dead. All the animals participate in the funeral procession. At the end, a flea (fly, mouse) falls & is crushed under the wagon’s wheel. The rooster buries the hen & then dies from grief. (The hen who had been choking is bumped & the nut becomes dis-lodged from her throat.
2204
2021BRooster Strikes out the Hen's Eye with a NutFormula Tales (2000-2399)2021-2024 Chains Involving DeathA rooster throws a nut that strikes out a hen’s eye. He blames the hazelnut bush, because it tore his pants. The bush blames the goat for eating its leaves. The goat blames the herdsman who did not give him good pasture; the herdsman blames his master for not giving him enough to eat, etc.
2205
2022-Death of the Little HenFormula Tales (2000-2399)2021-2024 Chains Involving DeathChain tale, game, song, or rhyme in which a small animal (chicken, flea, louse, other insect, small child, etc.) dies (falls into a cooking pot & is scalded, is burned, is drowned). Various people (girl, woman, father, etc.), animals, & objects (door, window, wagon, broom, tree, water, well, etc.) lament the death, which they announce in their characteristic manners. For example, the flea weeps, the tree loses its leaves, the door squeaks, the broom sweeps, the table “entables”, etc.
2206
2022BThe Broken EggFormula Tales (2000-2399)2021-2024 Chains Involving Deathll the wit-nesses show their grief at this misfortune. For example, the hen ruf-fles her feathers, the rubbish begins to burn, the stairs creak, the oak falls down, the magpie sprains his leg, the ox breaks his horns, the river flows with blood, the maidservant breaks her jug, the house-wife smears dough on the wall, etc. The master locks his wife up & the maidservant goes to look for people who are equally stupid, etc.
2207
2023-Little Ant MarriesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2021-2024 Chains Involving DeathAn ant (beetle, cockroach, grasshopper, snail, cat, etc.) finds some money, buys new clothes, & sits in her doorway. Many animals come by & ask her to mar-ry them, in their characteristic voices. The ant chooses the mouse, because he is quiet. When the mouse stirs the stew (wedding soup), he falls in the pot & drowns. When the ant discovers this, she weeps. The bird tears his own beak off, the seagull tears his own tail off, etc.
2208
2024*Rabbit Borrows MoneyFormula Tales (2000-2399)2021-2024 Chains Involving DeathA rabbit borrows money from a beetle, a hen, a fox, a dog, a tiger, & a hunter. When the beetle asks for the money back, the rabbit tells him to wait behind to count the money. Instead, the hen eats the beetle, then the fox eats the hen, etc.
2209
2025-The Fleeing PancakeFormula Tales (2000-2399)2025-2028 Chains Involving EatingA pancake (pudding, cake, cookie, cabbage strudel, round bread) jumps out of the pan (plate) & runs away from the cook (mother) who wants to eat it. The pancake runs outside & meets a series of animals (hen, rooster, duck, goose, fox, pig) or people who also want to eat it. The pancake runs away from all of them, bragging about all the others it has already escaped from. The fox (pig) induces the pancake to come close by pretending to be deaf, & gobbles it up. The pig drops part of the pancake, so now all pigs root around in the mud looking for it.
2210
2028-Devouring Animal That Was Cut OpenFormula Tales (2000-2399)2025-2028 Chains Involving EatingA cat (wolf, troll, mouse, giant, bear, chick, pump kin, woman, louse) with a huge appetite drinks a great quan-tity of milk, then eats a lot of food & devours the family with whom he lives. He goes out & people (animals) whom he meets on the road ask him why he is so fat (where he is going, why he is out so early). The cat lists everything he has eaten & announces that he will eat this person too. He devours everything he meets, e.g. certain animals, a cowherd, a flock of birds, a driver & his team of horses, etc.
2211
2030-The Old Woman & Her PigFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsThis misc. type consists of various chain tales in which a person (animal) wants an animal (person, object) to do something (go home, pick pears, grow, get some beer, eat, reap grain). The animal refuses. The person threatens him by asking someone else (person, animal, object, or element: e.g. dog, stick, fire, water, butcher) for help. The request is not granted (the help is postponed until some demand can be met). Finally someone (hangman, angel of death, animal) obliges, & all the others in succession do what the person had wanted them to. In a few variants, a mouse eats cheese (wheat, wick of an eternal flame). A cat condemns the mouse & eats it as punishment; a dog eats the cat for eating the mouse. Each animal, object, or element is blamed for having damaged the one before it, & is then punished.
2212
2031-Stronger & StrongestFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsAn ant (sparrow, hare) hurts himself on some ice, which he thinks must be the strongest thing in the world. The ice says this is not true, because the sun can melt it. The sun says it is not the strongest, because a cloud can obscure it. The cloud thinks a mountain is stronger. The mountain thinks grass or a mouse is stronger, the mouse thinks the cat is stronger, etc. (also fire, water, cattle, knive, butcher). The cat (rat, God, human) is finally the strongest, or the question remains undecided.
2213
2031AThe Esdras Chain: Stronger & StrongestFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsThe Jewish bodyguards of the Persian king Darius discuss the question, what is the strongest thing in the world? The first thinks it is the king; the second, wine; the third, a woman. But the truth is the strongest of all.
2214
2031BAbraham Learns to Worship GodFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsAt nightfall Abraham worships a star, then the moon which outshines it, & in the morning the sun. Finally he learns to pray only to God.
2215
2031CMightiest Being as Husband for the DaughterFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA magician rescues a mouse (rat) which he transforms into a girl. Or, a childless couple wish for a child but instead have a mouse. The magician (parents) thinks the girl is the most beautiful creature in the world & wants to marry her to the mightiest husband. They ask the moon, who refuses & says the sun is brighter than he. The sun refuses because the clouds cover him. The clouds say the wind blows them. The wind says the mountain (castle) stops him. The mountain says a mouse digs inside him. The mouse is therefore the mightiest & becomes the daughter’s husband.
2216
2032-Healing of the Injured AnimalFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsAn animal (mouse) is wounded (by another animal) & asks for help. He is told that this will happen only if he brings a particular object (fulfills some other request). The injured animal has to ask someone else for this object. This develops into a chain of demands & counter-requests, until finally someone (thing) agrees without a counter-request. The animal is treated for his injury, or else he dies before all the requests are granted. In Spanish & Portuguese variants, a toad asks a magpie to throw something (a nut) down from a tree. The magpie is afraid its beak will break, but the toad promises to repair it. The beak breaks & the toad goes after horsehair to mend it. He is sent to fulfill other requests, until finally someone does not make a counter-request. Everyone in the chain gets what he or she wanted, & finally the toad brings the horsehair to the magpie .
2217
2034-The Mouse Regains its TailFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA hunting cat bites off a mouse’s tail. Or, a woman cuts the tail off (belly open) of a mouse (cat, rat) because it stole her milk. The mouse wants to get its tail back. The mouse asks the cat for its tail (the cobbler to sew its belly), but is told it must do something (e.g. bring milk from the goat or cow). The goat wants the mouse to give it grass, the meadow wants water, the well wants eggs, the chicken wants corn, etc. Finally someone complies & all the rest get what they want. Or, the mouse is eaten.
2218
2035-The House That Jack BuiltFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsThis chain tale leads step by step to the following conclusion: This is the farmer that sowed the corn, that kept the rooster that crowed in the morn, that waked the priest all shaven & shorn, that married the man all tattered & torn, that kissed the maiden all forlorn, that milked the cow with a crumpled horn, that tossed the dog, that worried the cat, that caught the rat, that ate the malt that lay in the house that Jack built.
2219
2036-A Drop of Honey Causes Chain of AccidentsFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA hunter is about to buy some honey, but he drops it. A weasel eats the honey & is chased by a cat. The hunter’s dog kills the cat, & the grocer beats the dog to death. This causes a bloody war between two villages.
2220
2039-The Horseshoe NailFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA merchant on his way home stays at an inn & someone tells him that one of the nails is missing from one of his horse’s shoes. At the next inn the shoe has fallen off. Nevertheless, the merchant rides on. The horse becomes lame, stumbles, & breaks a leg. The merchant has to carry his goods himself & go home on foot. In some variants the horse of a soldier loses a horse shoe, & in the end a battle & a kingdom are lost.
2221
2040-The Climax of HorrorsFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA man who has been away for a long time asks an acquaintance for news from home. The acquaintance tells him that his dog (raven) is dead. The man asks why, & is told that it ate too much horse (camel) flesh. The horse had been burned in its stall (died from exertion during a fire); the barn caught fire from the house; the fire had been started by candles in the house; the candles burned on the occasion of the death of the man’s mother (wife).
2222
2041-The Bird Indifferent to PainFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA man catches a bird eating mangoes & strikes it against the roots of a mango tree. The bird says that it was not hurt. In turn, the man puts it in water, strikes it again, singes its feathers, cooks it, & eats it. The bird always says that it was not hurt. At last the bird flies out of the man’s nose (and the man dies).
2223
2042-Chain of AccidentsFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsThis misc. type consists of various chain tales in which a minor incident (insect sting, snakebite) causes a series of other events leading to someone’s death (loss of valuable property).
2224
2042A*Trial among the AnimalsFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsThis misc. type consists of various chain tales in which an animal is injured by another animal (accidentally or on purpose). The injury causes a series of accidents in which other animals are injured. At the end, a high-ranking animal (person) investi gates the matter & discovers all that has happened
2225
2043-"Where is the Warehouse?"Formula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA game, song, or rhyme composed of questions & answers that lead to the next question. For example, “Where is the warehouse (God’s house)?” – “The fire burned it.” – “Where is the fire?” – “The water quenched it.” – “Where is the water?” etc.
2226
2044-Pulling up the turnipFormula Tales (2000-2399)2029-2075 Chains Involving Other EventsA man attempts to pull up a turnip. He cannot do it alone, so he calls his wife to help him: she pulls on him, he pulls the turnip, but still the turnip will not come out of the ground. More people & animals are brought in to help. At the end, a long line of helpers pulls on the turnip & it comes out of the ground
2227
2200-Catch TalesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesMisc. type. The manner of telling forces a listener to ask a particular question (to complete something that is mis-sing). The narrator gives him a ridiculous (obscene) answer
2228
2202-Teller is Killed in His Own TaleFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesThe narrator relates a dramatic event that supposedly happened to himself. The listener is induced to ask a question about what happened further, to which the narrator replies that he was killed
2229
2204-The Dog's CigarFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesA man in a train smokes a cigar (pipe), which falls out of the train. His dog jumps out after it, & is waiting at the next station when the train arrives there. “What do you think he had in his mouth?” – “The cigar?” – “No, his tongue.”
2230
2205-"Come Here, Lean!"Formula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesThree girls find three coins & use them to buy three pigs, named Lean, Fat, & Tail. They call their pigs: “Come here, Lean!” – “I can’t, I am too lean.” – “Come here, Fat!” – “I can’t, I am too fat.” – “Come here...” to the listener, “What was the third one called?” – “Tail” – “Lift your tail.” (Another answer that depends on double-entendre.)
2231
2250-Unfinished TalesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesMisc. type. The narrator tells about some-one who has found something, but stops just as the tale gets interesting. “If the found object had been longer, so would my tale.”
2232
2251-The Rabbit's TailFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesWhen he dies, the king leaves a great mountain to his three sons. They dig into it & find a big iron box with a frying pan inside it, & a little rabbit under that. The rabbit has only a stump for a tail. If his tail had been longer, so would this tale.
2233
2260-Golden KeyFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesA boy finds a little box & keeps it. Later he finds a little key. He discovers that the key fits the lock on the box. When he opens the box, he finds a calf’s tail (mouse’s tail, fur) inside. If the tail had been longer, so would this tale. (Or, he opens the box but what he finds there will be told another time.)
2234
2271-Mock Stories for ChildrenFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesMisc. type. When children annoy their parents by persistently demanding a story, the latter retaliate by telling a brief “mock story”. For example, the parents tell about people (animals), of whom the third is named Enough (Stop). The parents ask the child what the name of the third person was. When the child answers, “Enough”, the parents end the tale
2235
2275-Trick StoriesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2200-2299 Catch TalesThe narrator asks the listeners a question & ex pects a particular answer. The dialog continues until the answer is given. For example, “I’ll tell you the story about the green pig? Shall I?” – “You should.” – “I didn’t say you should. I’ll tell you the story about the green pig”, etc.
2236
2300-Endless TalesFormula Tales (2000-2399)2300-2399 Other Formula TalesMisc. type. The narrator reports on something that takes a long time & says that he will continue the tale when it is com pleted. The following is the most common version: a shepherd has to take many sheep over a bridge, which is so narrow that they have to pass over one at a time. The listeners have to wait while each sheep crosses the bridge to the other side
2237
2301-Corn Carried Away One Grain at a TimeFormula Tales (2000-2399)2300-2399 Other Formula TalesA master rich farmer promises his daughter in marriage to whoever can tell a tale without an end. Many suitors try & fail & are put to death. One young man says, “A farmer harvested a large amount of grain. While he congratulated himself on his success, a mouse came & took a grain of wheat. The next day, another mouse comes & takes a grain of wheat. The next day...” etc. The master loses patience & lets the narrator marry his daughter.
2238
2302-The Crow on the Tarred BridgeFormula Tales (2000-2399)2300-2399 Other Formula TalesEndless tale about a crow whose beak & tail alternately stick to the tar on a bridge
2239
2335-Tales Filled With ContradictionsFormula Tales (2000-2399)2300-2399 Other Formula TalesMisc. type with diverse variants.
